title: Welcome Back!
description: Welcome back to the Reading Room. Last month, an all-star group of commentators made their way through Tolstoys War and Peace. This month, another distinguished crew (see their bios on the right) will spend two weeks tackling The Education of Henry Adams, an American classic published 100 years ago this year. Well, sort of: The memoir, which covers the years from Adamss birth in 1838 to the death of Adamss great friend the statesman John Hay in 1905, was printed in a luxurious private edition in 1907 and circulated to 100 or so friends  including then-president Theodore Roosevelt  who were invited to return it with comments and corrections in the extra-wide margins. (Only three complied.) The book was republished for a general audience in 1918, the year of Adamss death. An unsigned review in the New York Times Book Review called it a book every American should read. It won the Pulitzer Prize.

description: A San Francisco church believes that the music of jazz legend John Coltrane is divine.

description: Evel Knievel, the hard-living, death-defying adventurer who went from stealing motorcycles to riding them in a series of spectacular airborne stunts in the 1960s and 70s that brought him worldwide fame as the quintessential daredevil performer, died yesterday in Clearwater, Fla. He was 69.

But disappointment was in store for those who attended the first performance of the Movement Research Fall Festival, devoted to improvisational dance, on Thursday at the Danspace Project.

title: Pope Stresses Hope in Latest Teaching
description: VATICAN CITY, Nov. 30  Atheism may be understandable when mankind is confronted with evil and suffering, Pope Benedict XVI wrote in his second encyclical, issued on Friday. But the attempt to banish God, he wrote, has led to the greatest forms of cruelty and violations of justice, whether through Marxist revolution or the science that produced the atomic bomb.

title: European Satellite Project
description: The European Union salvaged its most prominent investment project, agreeing to divert 2.4 billion euros ($3.5 billion) of public money to bail out its struggling satellite navigation project, Galileo. Intended to rival the Global Positioning System developed by the United States, Galileo has struggled with money difficulties and lengthy delays after a consortium that was supposed to get the satellite network off the ground failed to agree on financial terms. The deal was reached after a round of horse-trading among national governments fighting over the economic spoils. Late Thursday, Spain sought to block the deal because it was not granted a ground station as part of the network. Madrid finally agreed to the financing plan Friday after indications that the status of the station in Spain might be upgraded.

title: Peace Conference at Navy Limits Pranks
description: In Annapolis, Md., what is good for peace in the Middle East may be bad for the Naval Academys fighting spirit.

title: American Skier, Inspired by Movie, Is Second in Downhill
description: BEAVER CREEK, Colo., Nov. 30  Most of the downhillers on the United States ski team are devoted to the 1969 film Downhill Racer, which starred Robert Redford as a stubborn and raffish young American trying to break into a sport dominated by Europeans.

title: When Football Moves to the Head of the Class
description: Three of the countrys most talented and successful college quarterbacks  Dennis Dixon of Oregon, Colt Brennan of Hawaii and Matt Ryan of Boston College  are spending more time in the film room this season than in the classroom.

title: Standoff Ends Peacefully at a Clinton Field Office
description: ROCHESTER, N.H., Nov. 30  A man who claimed to have a bomb walked into Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons campaign field office here Friday and took three campaign workers hostage for hours before surrendering to the police.

title: Awaiting a Glimpse of Their Gossip Girl Kin
description: You could tell the tribes apart by variations in dress: the tartan kilts and pleated skirts of Nightingale-Bamford, Sacred Heart and Spence; running shoes on the girls who had made their way over from Chapin and Hewitt; leggings and anoraks for students at Dalton, with its relaxed dress code.

title: Soprano Backs Out of Mets Norma
description: The soprano Rene Fleming has decided that Norma is not in her future.

title: Motorola Replaces Chief With an Insider
description: Motorola said yesterday that its chief executive, Edward J. Zander, was stepping down, a development applauded by the dissident shareholder Carl C. Icahn, who said the company should use the opportunity to split into four parts.

title: Head of Oil Spill Cleanup Is Retiring
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 30  A target of criticism for leading the flawed response to an accident and oil spill in San Francisco Bay this month, the Coast Guard captain in charge of the initial cleanup has announced his retirement.

title: Cervantes Prize Winner Is Announced
description: Juan Gelman, below, an Argentine poet who was forced into political exile during Argentinas Dirty War and wrote about his experiences as a political activist, has been awarded the annual Cervantes Prize, the top literary award in the Spanish-speaking world, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Gelman, 77, has published more than 20 books of poetry. In the 1976-83 campaign that Argentinas military regime waged against leftists, Mr. Gelmans son and daughter-in-law were among thousands who vanished. The prize, 90,450 euros (about $133,000), will be presented on April 23.

title: Iraq Seeks to Execute 3 Former Officials
description: BAGHDAD, Nov. 30  The political battle over a death sentence for Iraqs former defense minister flared again on Friday, with Iraqi government officials saying they had demanded that the Americans hand him over for execution.

title: Tug of War: Rationality vs. Regret
description: ASIDE from having opposable thumbs, what makes us human surely includes our sense of humor, the awareness of our own mortality  and, I would argue, the ability to want what we cant afford.

title: As Talks With Europe End, Iran Gives No Sign of Concession on Nuclear Program
description: LONDON, Nov. 30  Negotiators for Iran and the European Union held a new round of talks on Irans uranium-enrichment program on Friday, but the meeting ended with indications that the Iranians had offered no new concessions to ease Western concerns that Iran plans to develop nuclear weapons.

title: Hey, Brother, Can You Spare a Spectacular? 75 and Still Kicking
description: Nothing says Great Depression like the tap tap tap of dancing shoes and a long, spangled kick line.

title: Labor Pacts in Detroit Didnt Ease Stocks Slide
description: DETROIT, Nov. 30  Detroit auto companies have long expected a quid pro quo from Wall Street when it came to their dealings with the United Automobile Workers union.

title: Traveling With Troopers Has a Price in Privacy Lost
description: In January 2000, an odd little dispute spilled into sight. Hillary Rodham Clinton and her husband had just bought a house in Westchester so she could run for the United States Senate. During the campaign, she was protected by Secret Service agents, just as all members of a presidents immediate family would be, whatever their pursuits. And of course, the Senate campaign often brought Mrs. Clinton to New York City.

title: Rookie Plays a Good Game Instead of Talking One
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Nov. 30  David Harris does not look like a rookie, with muscles rippling off his 6-foot-2, 243-pound frame. And David Harris does not play like a rookie, accumulating tackles like a veteran Pro Bowler.

title: Survivor Keeps CBS on Top
description: With the November sweeps period over, the reruns have returned, and several broadcast networks saw steep declines in the ratings on Thursday. CBS managed to remain No. 1 over all, thanks to Survivor: China, one of the few nonrepeats among the usual top-rated shows on Thursday. The 8 p.m. reality competition delivered 13.7 million viewers, Nielsen estimated, easily surpassing its rivals in its time slot, Foxs Are You Smarter Than a 5th Grader? (9 million), a rerun of ABCs Ugly Betty (6.5 million) and NBCs My Name is Earl (6.6 million) followed by 30 Rock (5.8 million). At 9, opposite repeats of CBSs CSI (12.3 million), ABCs Greys Anatomy (9 million) and NBCs Office (6 million), Foxs Dont Forget the Lyrics (8.6 million) remained mired in fourth among adults 18 to 49. Fox finished third for the night in that demographic, behind CBS and NBC and ahead of ABC.

title: Shanghai Tycoon Falls From Grace
description: BEIJING, Nov. 30  He once was one of Chinas richest and most politically connected businessmen, a real estate tycoon who had started out selling noodles. But on Friday, Zhou Zhengyi was sentenced to 16 years in prison, the latest powerful Shanghai figure to fall from grace.

title: Putins Last Realm to Conquer: Russian Culture
description: MOSCOW  The fight is long over here for authority over the security services, the oil business, mass media and pretty much all the levers of government. Vladimir Putins Kremlin, notwithstanding some recent anti-government protests, has won those wars, hands down, and promises to consolidate its position in parliamentary elections. But now there is concern that the Kremlin is setting its sights on Russian culture.

title: Neither Sprain Nor Snow Will Keep Ward Off Field
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 30  Let it rain, Derrick Ward said. Let it snow, too, and let the cold winds blow along the shore of Lake Michigan on Sunday when the Giants visit the Chicago Bears at Soldier Field.

title: Lawyer Says Pakistan Heading Toward Rigged Vote
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 30  A corporate lawyer dressed in a pinstriped suit, Munawar Akhtar, 71, clutched a poster of a defiant colleague held in solitary confinement for three weeks, and marched Friday to the house of the dismissed chief justice of the Supreme Court.

title: Deceptive Defense Fools Declarer to Stop an Overtrick
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 30  At the Fall North American Championships here on Thursday night, the winners of the Blue Ribbon Pairs were Steve Landen of Ellicott City, Md., and Pratap Rajadhyaksha of Sarasota, Fla. They finished less than half a board ahead of Alejandro Bianchedi and Ernesto Muzzio from Argentina, with Marcelo Branco from Brazil and Diego Brenner, a Brazilian now living in Spain, third.

title: Philippine Authorities Hunt for Revolt Leaders
description: MANILA, Nov. 30  The Philippine authorities searched today for some of the military officers who took over a luxury Manila hotel on Thursday in an attempt to stage a revolt against the government of President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo.

title: Russians Fall, Mostly, Into Step
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 30  Several years into an economic boom that has roused national pride at home and a more aggressive stance abroad, Russians will vote in a parliamentary election on Sunday that has been overshadowed by questions about the future role of President Vladimir V. Putin.

title: A Bid to Ease Credit in Europe
description: The European Central Bank said that it would extend a lending deadline in December to help the banking system through a period of unusually tight credit at the end of the year. The action represents a renewed effort by the bank to calm a lending system that had showed signs of returning to normal recently but now appears nearly as nervous as during the summer days when the global credit turmoil began.

title: That Same Old Beat, With Brand-New Choices
description: Darmstadt: Classics of the Avant-Garde, a series of monthly concerts at Galapagos in Brooklyn, celebrates its anniversaries by rounding up as many Downtown musicians as it can fit on a stage and performing Terry Rileys 1964 Minimalist classic, In C. The seriess third annual reading, on Thursday evening, redefined the work as a cross between a late-1960s psychedelic freakout and a more up-to-date extended dance track, complete with an insistently pounding beat. It was the most vital, audacious and energizing performance of the score Ive ever heard.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A dance review on Thursday about the Ballet Hispanicos Palladium Nights, at the Joyce Theater, misidentified the choreographer. While Tina Ramirez conceived the production and is the companys artistic director, Willie Rosario is the choreographer.

description: One moment that drew particular attention at Wednesday nights Republican presidential debate was a video questioners asking whether the candidates believed every word of the Bible.

title: Jangly Idiosyncrasies With Institutional Support
description: Its tempting to view the career trajectory of the saxophonist Rob Reddy as indicative of a broader shift. He belongs to the constellation of avant-garde musicians who spent the 1990s working in close orbit to the Knitting Factory. More recently, faced with leaner options, he has grown increasingly independent even while courting institutional support.

title: Dozens Hurt in Train Crash in Chicago
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 30  An Amtrak train slammed into the back of a freight train on the citys South Side on Friday, sending about 70 people to the hospital, 8 with serious or critical injuries, the authorities said.

description: Denvers an odd place for a Bollywood goddess, but thats where Madhuri Dixit, Indias biggest female star of the 1990s, has been leading a Clark Kent-type life, married and raising children. Ms. Dixit has been gone from the screen for five years, long enough for a new crop of stars to emerge and for Aaja Nachle, her modest new film, to be a comeback vehicle.

Marshall, 83, who served as the steward of his mothers finances for more than a quarter-century. But indicted this week along with Mr. Marshall was a lawyer with a troubled legal career who has faced disciplinary action in at least two states.

description: DOCTORS are sometimes viewed as an arrogant bunch, and no doctors more so than surgeons  which is perhaps not surprising considering that the decisions they make every day are literally life and death. But Dr. Thomas R. Russell, the executive director of the American College of Surgeons, hardly fits that stereotype.

But that heart lifted upon hearing that Peter Schumanns ragtag collective, the Bread and Puppet Theater, was the company undertaking said riff.

title: Endangered Species
description: In early June, the Audubon Society released a report chronicling the disturbing decline of some of Americas most common bird species. This week, it issued a grim sequel: a survey that highlights the status of the species in most serious trouble, those at or near the verge of extinction.

title: Calls in Sudan for Execution of British Teacher
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov. 30  Hundreds of demonstrators in Khartoum, Sudans capital, poured into the streets on Friday demanding the execution of a British teacher who was convicted of insulting Islam because her class of 7-year-olds named a teddy bear Muhammad.

description: If Mignon Taylor had her way, she would open a craft shop and tearoom for the young people of Spanish Harlem, where she grew up.

title: Russia Suspends NATO Arms Pact
description: President Vladimir V. Putin signed a law suspending Russias participation in a NATO treaty limiting conventional forces in Europe, intensifying pressure on NATO to make concessions, European diplomats said. Mr. Putins action, just before national elections, moved Russia a step closer to carrying out its threat to stop abiding by the accord on Dec. 12. American and Russian arms-control experts said they would step up negotiations. Russia contends that the enlargement of NATO to include Romania, Bulgaria and the Baltic states has given it too much muscle near Russias borders.

title: Basque Militant Group Kills Spanish Guardsman
description: MADRID, Dec. 1  One Spanish civil guardsman was killed and another seriously wounded in southern France today, the Spanish authorities said, accusing the Basque militant group ETA of its first slaying in almost a year.

title: Mets Trade Milledge and Fill Two Holes
description: Two years ago, Lastings Milledge was mentioned prominently as part of trade discussions for the Boston slugger Manny Ramrez. Last year, the Mets dangled him in a package for a front-line pitcher. It was almost a foregone conclusion that they would eventually trade Milledge, which they did yesterday to the Washington Nationals, but on the surface the return was hardly as alluring as it once could have been.

description: To the Editor:

title: Down but Not Really Out
description: In the loopy medical thriller Awake, Hayden Christensen plays Clayton Beresford Jr., a wealthy young man who suffers a condition called anesthesia awareness during a heart transplant. Conscious but immobile, he gives us a voice-over play-by-play of the proceedings, and if you are one of those who viewed his portrayal of Anakin Skywalker as the ne plus ultra of lifelessness, prepare to be proven wrong.

title: Counted Out, Knicks Show Their Resolve
description: In a development that can only make sense at Madison Square Garden, the Knicks closed out their best seven-day stretch of the season last night. They will understand if no one applauds the achievement  or even remembers it.

title: Akons Day in Court
description: Charges have been filed against the platinum-selling singer Akon, below, who picked up a 15-year-old fan and threw him off the stage and into the crowd, where he landed on another concertgoer during a June 3 performance in Fishkill, N.Y., The Poughkeepsie Journal reported. Abby Rosa, the woman who was hit by the falling boy, suffered a concussion. An investigation led to the charges, which were announced by the towns police on Thursday. Akon is scheduled to appear in court Monday morning to face a misdemeanor charge of endangering the welfare of a minor and a charge of second-degree harassment. During a concert in April in Trinidad, Akon invited a girl onstage and simulated having sex with her. When it was later discovered that she was 14, he apologized. Akons latest album, Konvicted, has sold more than a million copies in the United States.

title: Charge the Rent, but Only if You Dont Need To
description: SEVERAL credit card companies have introduced programs over the last year allowing homeowners and renters to pay their monthly housing bills with a credit card. For the cash savvy, the program is a potential windfall, allowing users to rack up rewards points that qualify them for free trips and other perks.

title: Jurors Ordered to Hearing on Bias Remarks
description: BOSTON, Nov. 30  A Superior Court judge has ordered a jury that convicted a black man of the rape and murder of a white fashion writer in 2002 on Cape Cod back to court for a rare public hearing to consider whether racial bias influenced the verdict.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A sports article in some copies yesterday about Dallass 37-27 victory over Green Bay misstated the Cowboys status for the N.F.L. playoffs and the number of field goals by their kicker, Nick Folk. Dallas has clinched a playoff berth; it does not need New Orleans and Arizona to lose tomorrow. And Folk kicked three field goals, not four.

title: None Survive Turkish Plane Crash
description: ISTANBUL, Nov. 30  A Turkish passenger jet crashed in the mountains of western Turkey early Friday, killing all 57 people on board, including several prominent nuclear physicists on their way to a conference, Turkish authorities said.

title: Strike Prompts Layoffs at NBC
description: NBC yesterday laid off the nonwriting staff members of its two late-night entertainment shows, the Tonight Show With Jay Leno and Late Night with Conan OBrien, because of the strike by Hollywood scriptwriters.

description: SAN FRANCISCO

title: Venezuela: Chvez Ready to Rule Until 2050
description: Wrapping up his campaign for changes to the Constitution before tens of thousands of supporters in Caracas, President Hugo Chvez delivered a speech threatening the moneyed elite, investors from Spain, foreign correspondents, the United States and pitiyanquis, a term loosely translated as Yankee lovers. He also ordered soldiers to occupy oil installations ahead of the referendum tomorrow, threatening to cut off oil exports to the United States in the event of American interference. Who votes yes is for Chvez, he said. Who votes no is voting for George W. Bush. Mr. Chvez devoted almost none of his speech to the 69 amendments in the vote, which would centralize power in the presidents hands and abolish his term limits. He said he could see himself ruling until 2050, when he would turn 96. The tensions led the United States to break its silence. We are concerned that people would not be able to have the free and fair elections that they deserve, said Dana Perino, the White House spokeswoman.

title: Your College Application: The Real You?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Sponsor for Tanglewood
description: The Boston Symphony Orchestra said yesterday that Bank of America would make a seven-figure donation over five years to its Tanglewood summer music festival, starting next year. The parties declined to give a precise dollar figure. The festival also announced next summers offerings. Highlights include a two-part concert performance of Berliozs opera Les Troyens by the Boston Symphony; performances of Tchaikovskys Eugene Onegin; Rise and Fall of the City of Mahagonny, by Kurt Weill and Bertolt Brecht; and the festivals student orchestra.

title: Israeli Rocket Kills 5 in Gaza
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 1  Five members of the Hamas armed wing were killed early today by an Israeli rocket strike inside southern Gaza, near the village of Abassan. An additional eight gunmen were wounded, one critically, according to the Health Ministry in Gaza, as the airstrikes were followed up by helicopter gunship attacks.

title: A Urinetown Suit Is Settled
description: A suit filed last year by members of the creative team behind the 2002 Broadway production of Urinetown! The Musical, which argued that a production of the show in Chicago copied their work without permission, was settled on Thursday. In the settlement, those involved with the Chicago production acknowledged that it contained original and creative works from the Broadway production and agreed to pay an undisclosed sum. The eyebrow-raising part of the lawsuit was the charge that Chicago copied the stage direction of the 2002 New York production. Some design elements and choreography are protected under copyright law, but there has not been a conclusive ruling on whether a directors work is protected. John Rando, the director of the Broadway production, applied for copyright protection for his work but was turned down, and the Department of Justice intervened in the case, saying that the federal copyright office had acted properly in rejecting Mr. Randos plea. A separate, similar lawsuit involving a dinner theater production of Urinetown in Akron, Ohio, is still pending.

title: U.S. Urges Freezing Some Rates on Loans
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30  The Treasury Department is leaning on mortgage lenders to temporarily freeze the interest rates on subprime loans for homeowners threatened with foreclosure, but the scope of any relief will depend on crucial details.

title: Andrew Foldi, Opera Singer and Educator, Dies at 81
description: Andrew Foldi, a bass who sang character roles for decades at the Chicago Lyric Opera, the Metropolitan Opera and other houses and later directed the Chicago Lyric Opera Center for young artists, died on Nov. 21 in Federal Way, Wash. He was 81.

title: Iran Offers No Concessions in Nuclear Talks
description: LONDON, Nov. 30  Negotiators for Iran and the European Union held a new round of talks today on Irans uranium enrichment program, but the meeting ended with indications that the Iranians had offered no new concessions to ease Western concerns that Iran plans to develop nuclear weapons.

title: Rambo and the G.O.P.
description: I dont know if children should be allowed to watch the Republican presidential debates.

title: Thompson Bid, Criticized as Sleepy, Is at the Least Unconventional
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Nov. 29  Fred D. Thompson promised even before formally announcing his candidacy for president that he would not run a customary campaign. He was not kidding.

title: Google to Join Spectrum Auction
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 30  Seeking to shake up the wireless industry, Google said Friday that it was preparing to take part in the federal governments auction of radio frequencies that could be used to deliver the next generation of Internet and mobile phone services to consumers.

title: Message Sent in Sentencing of Two Vick Co-Defendants
description: In sentencing two of Michael Vicks co-defendants yesterday to longer prison terms than the government had recommended, United States District Court Judge Henry E. Hudson demonstrated an independence that could hurt Vicks chance of gaining a reduced sentence, legal experts said.

title: Wall St. Sees Silver Lining in Economy
description: As Wall Street rallied this week, it seemed that investors were taking comfort in the notion that the economy had become so imperiled by the crumbling housing market that it was forcing the government to finally mount an aggressive rescue effort.

title: Corzines Slow Pace on Plan for Toll Roads Benefits Its Foes
description: One top New Jersey official says tolls on the New Jersey Turnpike are bound to triple. Another warns commuters to expect a 50 percent increase. Still others tell drivers to brace for a higher gasoline tax as well as a toll rise.

title: Defense Ends Its Arguments in Terrorism Trial in Miami
description: MIAMI, Nov. 30  The lawyers representing seven men standing trial here on charges of planning to wage an armed insurrection against the government wrapped up their closing arguments on Friday and sought to portray their clients as young, misguided indigents rather than, as the government contends, homegrown terrorists eager to do Al Qaedas bidding.

title: Proof That Overscheduled Modern Life Isnt Fit for a Dog
description: EARLY one recent Saturday morning, Steffi woke me with another uninvited lick on the lips. I rolled over, but it was no use. She pawed across the pillows, licking my neck. My wife, Alison, was still fast asleep. I noticed that our 10-year-old son, Harrison, had wandered in from his room during the night. Steffi noticed the same thing, and promptly assaulted him with her tongue.

title: City Urged to Rethink Rail Access to West Side
description: The city should rethink its development plans for the Hudson Yards area west of Midtown, Senator Charles E. Schumer said in a sharply worded letter to the city yesterday. He said that hundreds of millions of dollars budgeted for that work should be put instead into an extension of the No. 7 subway line, including a new station at 10th Avenue.

title: Strike Halts Trains, Planes and Buses in Italy
description: ROME, Nov. 30  Italy struggled through a transportation meltdown today, a reminder of the disruptions to daily life that crop up regularly in this beautiful nation and that can make getting about decidedly unpleasant.

title: Estimates May Have Overstated Job Growth
description: The American economy appears to have created far fewer jobs this spring than has been reported so far, a new government report indicated yesterday. That could provide further impetus for the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates when it meets Dec. 11.

title: Lawmakers Set Deal on Raising Fuel Efficiency
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30  Congressional negotiators reached a deal late Friday on energy legislation that would force American automakers to improve the fuel efficiency of their cars and light trucks by 40 percent by 2020.

title: Chad: Rebels Declare War on France
description: One of the biggest rebel groups, United Forces for Democracy and Development, declared war on France, saying the former colonial power was working to help prop up Chads president, Idriss Dby. A European Union force intended to protect displaced Chadians and refugees from neighboring Darfur is to begin deploying in January; about half the troops will come from France. Nicholas Sarkozy, the French president, brushed aside the threat and said plans for the force would continue.

title: Israeli Court Upholds Gaza Fuel Cuts
description: Israels Supreme Court ruled that the government could continue cutting fuel supplies to the Hamas-controlled Gaza Strip, which it has done since Oct. 28. But it ordered a delay on plans to cut electricity to give the government more time to respond to the groups challenging the plan.

title: Roddick and Blake Give U.S. 2-0 Lead
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 30  Unadulterated tennis joy has been hard to generate for Americas finest mens players in the age of Roger Federer, but there have been no Federer sightings at this Davis Cup final on a quick and friendly home court. And on Friday, with a sellout crowd of 12,000 providing the upbeat soundtrack, Andy Roddick and James Blake earned the emotional highs they have been seeking by staying faithful to their countrys tennis team.

title: Italy: Strike Halts Trains, Planes and Buses
description: Italy struggled through a transportation meltdown as train workers across the country went on strike, buses and ferries halted service, and hundreds of flights were canceled. title: 'Well-Adjusted'
description: When I first started reading about adoption, I kept coming across the words "well-adjusted adoptee." In 1970s the thinking was that adoptees should be content with their present lives and not think about their adoptions. I read studies on the Internet in the 1990s and it seemed little had changed. Questions beyond childhood curiosity and looking anything other than "happy" would get you labeled as having psychological problems or "issues."   Technically, I was a "functioning" adult  a stay-at-home-mom who cooked, cleaned, took care of her children like most of my friends. I wasn't prone to depression though there were times when I would go deep into thought. I laughed and cried, felt joy and anger like most people I knew. The difference was that I had a dirty little secret. I was actually thinking about my adoption and its effects on me.   When people asked why I was digging into my past, my typical reply was that I needed to know the truth to pass on to my children. But there was more to it than that. Answering the questions of why, who, when, where and how might also lead to some understanding of myself. My experiences as an adoptee didn't have everything to do with shaping me as a person, but how much it did was something I'd never considered before.   There were moments in childhood that turned my mind to questioning. As a young girl, I found my green card in my mother's purse. When I was 10, the arrival of another Vietnamese adoptee redirected my perspective from that of the adopted child to that of a Vietnamese adoptee. Then there was Binh, who'd I had come across on the Internet. Binh was Vietnamese and lived in England. Our contact was the first positive experience I'd had with another person from Vietnam.  We didn't talk about adoption or even Vietnam, but shared an interest in movies and anime. It's sad, but our online exchanges were the first real interaction on any "normal" level I'd had with another Vietnamese person. He was almost half my age but thoughtful and compassionate beyond his years. Often our discussions would center on how we felt about the world and our lives in it. This set into motion a process of reexamination. How had I gotten where I was and why? My inner eye eventually turned to my adoption.   Struggling to put my life back into the context of adoption was infuriating and deeply isolating at first. Part of the loneliness was self-inflicted; I felt many wouldn't have understood why I couldn't just "move on." The one family member to whom I disclosed my need to re-examine my adoption felt I'd lost my mind and even gave that impression to others. He suggested counseling. I felt insulted. What I needed wasn't therapy, it was understanding. I hadn't lost my mind; I was going through a process of reclaiming it. For the greater part of my life, I'd simply accepted what I'd been told.   To me, the suggestion of therapy meant I was "maladjusted" and needed to be readjusted  but to what? Adoption itself wasn't viewed as "normal." How do you assign a norm to an unusual situation? As more adult adoptees have grown into adulthood and spoken out about their experiences, changes in the way society perceives adoption are slowly being made.   Today, it's more acceptable for adoptees to question, to seek answers and even mourn their losses as some of us often do. As long as we eventually come to some sense of "peace" and go about our daily lives, all is well. It isn't until some of us become critical that we are confronted by a revised version of "maladjusted." This new term implies the same thing as the old but with a twist. We've come to be known as "the bitter, angry adoptees."   When I first began writing critically about my adoption on my blog, I was surprised by this and even more so to learn I'd been smacked with the same label. While there were a few readers who tried to understand without judgment, there were still those who couldn't get past their misperceptions. People online who didn't even know me gave me well-intentioned advice on how to resolve my "anger issues." Others suggested therapy and still others told me to "grow up." It was still the same attitude, but the language had changed.  I would get e-mails from adoptive parents who would often argue that "things are so much better for adoptees now." But are they? I felt the statement was dismissive and showed a lack of understanding. The labeling itself seemed a sign that some things were not better. Why did it seem anger was not an acceptable emotion for an adoptee to feel?  Many adoptees have valid reasons for being angry. Should someone else decide that those reasons are not valid? Who defines socially acceptable norms? Based on what? I feel these are questions that should be asked. And I think that the answers are at the heart of the "bitter adoptee" label.   Just like many in the adoptee community, I'm not willing to settle for "better." To stop thinking about it now would mean settling into complacency. I know all too well what happens when the mind stops thinking critically. The pressure to conform to someone else's expectations can be overwhelming. In my desire to appear "well-adjusted." I resorted to denial and suppression. I became a chronic people-pleaser as result of my attempts to blend into my surroundings.  It would be a lie for me to say I'm not still angry. I am, but people often misunderstand what I am angry about. I came to terms long ago with the fact that I'm adopted. I've even begun to come to terms with many of my negative experiences that involved racism, isolation and even deception. Much of my anger comes from people labeling me with dehumanizing, dismissive and misleading terms. It also comes from frustration about the condescending attitudes we often face when we speak out. Sometimes it's simply conviction and determination.  There is a difference between anger and all-encompassing, blind rage. I write about painful, anger-inducing experiences because I wasn't allowed to explore them before. Writing publicly about them also contributes to the understanding of the complexities of adoption. As a society, I think we still have an overly simplistic view of adoption. While current studies may scratch the surface by studying the different aspects of adoption, the "either/or" idea is still prevalent. Adoption is either good or bad. Either you're for it or against it. The adoptee is either well-adjusted or maladjusted.  I think the reactions of some adoptive parents are sometimes rooted in fear that their children might turn out to be one of the "the bad ones." I believe most adoptive parents genuinely love their children. They don't want them to be miserable, but that fear is often based on that same all or nothing misconception. Just as adoption itself can't be painted over with a broad brush, neither can adoptees  as a community or as individuals. We also can be paradoxical in nature. I am thankful for what I have but I still mourn what I've lost. I can acknowledge my anger but still think past it to laugh and enjoy life.   Many of the adoptees I know who were initially labeled as "bitter" or "angry" have gone on to do some pretty incredible things. Some have become accomplished writers and artists, formed organizations, become socially and politically aware and active. Some have even entered the field of adoption as professionals. No longer content to adapt and conform, many adoptees are now working toward social change. The "angry, bitter ones" are just a part of a greater whole existing as productive members of that community.  For many like me, critiques on adoption are not just about our own experiences. It just began there. Our eyes have turned toward the next generation, to first mothers and beyond. It doesn't stop at our front door as we've begun to delve into subjects like adoption ethics, racism, civil rights, economics and politics. Angry? Yes, some of us are but sometimes that's a necessary element. History is full of examples. Should we dismiss the Boston Tea Party as a mere temper tantrum? Why are some adoptees getting a bad rap from some adoptive parents? I think it's because adoptees are still thought of as "the lucky ones," the ones who were "saved." What do we have to complain about?   Of course, I can only speak for myself. There will be adoptees out there whose experiences and opinions differ. "We" only refers to those with whom I share certain commonalities, nothing more. Yes, "we" have made progress, but many feel we still have a long way to go. Building our communities and support systems was just the beginning and it seems we're in it for the long haul.

title: Death in the Family
description: "This will be my last campaign, Booth Gardner said. This will be the biggest fight of my career. He walked along the lane between the beach of driftwood and his compound of houses. The driftwood clotted the shore; it was the end of summer now, and the cove was still, but in winter massive branches and trunks churn up out of the water of Puget Sound. Bone-white roots clawed at the air on this late afternoon; Gardners grandchildren climbed across them. His walk was a vigorous lurch. One foot twisted inward, one knee buckled. His torso keeled slightly with each step. He has Parkinsons. He was governor of Washington State for two terms in the 1980s and 90s. He is 71, and his last campaign is driven by his desire to kill himself. I cant see where anybody benefits by my hanging around, he told me, while his blond grandchildren, sticks prodding, explored the waters edge.

title: A Place to Call Home: Somethings Got to Give
description: A long-simmering crisis in housing has led the counties of Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester, Orange, Putnam, Rockland and Dutchess to unite behind legislation encouraging municipalities to build more housing that regular people can afford. It is called the Downstate Suburban Workforce Housing for Economic Sustainability Act. It is a solid attempt to confront a chronic suburban problem and deserves wholehearted support in Albany.

title: Masterpiece Basement
description: If you happened to be in Tehran between 1977 and 1979, you might have seen the incredible collection of 19th- and 20th-century Western masterpieces on display at the Iranian capitals newly inaugurated Tehran Museum of Contemporary Art. Only a handful of Westerners have seen it since, making a trip to the museums basement one of the art worlds most prized  and fraught  pilgrimages.

title: Books of Style
description: THE GREAT FUNK

title: Book Soup
description: On a late October evening, despie the haze and lingering smoke caused by the California wildfires  only the H and D of the Hollywood sign are visible  the Taschens living room still gives way to spectacular views. Lauren and Benedikt Taschen enjoy their perch in John Lautners Chemosphere house, a space-age showpiece from the 1960 that has been referred to as a flying saucer, a Jetson treehouse and, according to the 1961 Encyclopedia Britannica, the most modern house in the world. Benedikt, who over the past 27 years has turned what was a small comic-book shop into an international art publishing empire, bought the house above Mulholland Drive in 1997.

title: Martha Sutphen, Richard Stock
description: Martha Rusk Sutphen and Dr. Richard J. Stock were married on Tuesday in New York. Judge Robert W. Sweet of the United States District Court in New York officiated in the brides apartment.

title: Can Residents Agree to Lower the Heat Setting?
Gimme Shelter
description: How can you not be intrigued by a history of hotels in America that begins with a trenchant discussion of Immanuel Kant? The father of the modern philosophy of international law and human rights, as he is described, published Toward Perpetual Peace in 1795. He proposed that international conflict could be ended only under conditions of universal hospitality, in which ... a right to visit belonged to all people.

title: A Shoe Box Full of Sandwiches
description: Firehouse Deli falls somewhere on the scale between grab-and-go food shops that are little more than convenience stores and the kind of full-service delicatessens that offer just about everything.

title: The Oprah Party Wants You
description: BACK in 1992, the Bush White House deemed Oprah Winfreys daytime talk show insufficiently serious for the incumbent president to visit. But in the intervening years, Ms. Winfreys couch, along with the easy chairs on other chat shows, became so attractive to candidates that the political world is now wondering whether Ms. Winfrey might actually hold the Democratic nomination in her hands.

title: Heil Hitler! Love, Bobo
description: In this age of blogs and celebutantes, the aristocratic, letter-writing Mitfords may seem snobbish, quaint, even kitschy. But to dismiss them as dusty relics would be to miss out on a great deal of eccentric charm, wit and historical resonance. Those features are drolly captured in a 1933 letter from the 13-year-old Debo  later Deborah, Duchess of Devonshire  to Diana, who would soon become Lady Mosley (wife of Oswald), thanking her for the gift of a heavenly evening bag. Thank you SO much for the HEVERN eveninger, she wrote in Mitford family shorthand. I even forgive you being a fascist.

title: Insider Art
description: Among contemporary art collectors  a world in which more is more these days  having your own private, architect-designed art gallery isnt new. But hiding it in the side of a mountain is.

title: Unholy Production With a Fairy-Tale Ending
description: PHILIP PULLMANS novel The Golden Compass, the basis for the new movie of the same name, is set in a parallel universe that runs on something called anbaric power instead of electricity, and where people travel in hot-air balloons and enormous, slow-moving zeppelins. Landing the movie in theaters, where it will open Friday, was not unlike inflating and then piloting one of these exotic, cumbersome airships.

title: The Texas Tate
description: The British artist Tracey Emin asks me if I can stay on the line as she finds her lip gloss and makes herself comfortable on the bed in her suite at the Ritz-Carlton in Dallas. Ive shown in New York and now Ive shown in Dallas, and thats it, she says, sounding incredulous about her United States presence. This is after 15 years of being an artist! It may be Emins first trip to Dallas, but it will not be her last: two of her biggest fans  the former director of a cheerleading supply company and his boyfriend  have just opened a foundation for contemporary British art in the citys Uptown neighborhood.

title: Hester Is Giving Bears and Fans Happy Returns
description: In Chicago, at least, kickoffs and punts are no longer viewed as a mundane transition from one football possession to the next.

title: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
description: Previously recorded $2,481,319.86

title: Dark One-Liners Shine a Light on the Mood of Serbs
description: BELGRADE, Serbia  Why shouldnt we be proud of our past, when each new day is worse than the previous one? asks Aleksandar Cotric, a dissident-turned-politician, whose dark one-liners were once scrawled on banners during the demonstrations that helped overthrow the Serbian strongman Slobodan Milosevic in 2000.

title: Change at Quarterback Gives the Browns Reason to Hope, for a Change
description: BEREA, Ohio, Nov. 28  It is not easy work dragging the Cleveland Browns back to respectability, which explains why the first-year offensive coordinator Rob Chudzinski skulks the hallways of the training complex with puffy eyes and dark circles, appearing as if he had just gone 15 rounds with a film machine.

title: To Run for President
description: To the Editor:

title: Going Green, Luxuriously
description: IF the ski industry has a buzzword this season, it's green. Yes, all those snowmaking guns and high-speed lifts soak up untold amounts of energy, but thanks to eco-friendly capital improvements, skiers can schuss down the mountain this winter with a somewhat clearer conscience. Snow guns are using oil-free air compressors, mountaintop restaurants are being powered by solar panels, and carbon offsets can be purchased as part of your lift ticket. Ignore the S.U.V.'s crammed in the parking lot, and skiing might also seem like a sustainable sport.

title: Lumber Man
description: Hanging tough in buffalo plaid. Clockwise from top: J. Crew hat, $250. At select J. Crew stores. Filson vest, $100. Go to www.filson.com. Woolrich Woolen Mills belt, $100. At Bergdorf Goodman. Yuketen boots, $350. At Bergdorf Goodman. Gilded Age jacket, $798. Go to www.gildedage.net. Junya Watanabe Man Comme des Garons shirt, $535. At Bloomingdales.

title: An Early Haven for Artists
description: Q I grew up in an unusual building, the Vermeer Studios, two side-by-side structures on 66th Street east of Park Avenue. We had 19th-century landscapes in our apartment, and I remember my father going next door to visit A. Conger Goodyear, who collected modern art, and coming back and saying You cant believe what that man has on his walls! What can you tell me about the Vermeer? ... Eleanor Graves, Manhattan

title: Map Quest
description: Maps make us incoherent. They replace speech and transcend description. They leave us awestruck and dumbstruck because they seem shamingly concise and often stunningly beautiful. The difference between maps and other data-conveying graphics is that maps exist to represent spatial relationships  direction, sequence and distance. And space is hard to describe in words.

title: The People We Have Been Waiting For
description: It was 60 degrees on Thursday in Washington, well above normal, and as I slipped away for some pre-Christmas golf, I found myself thinking about a wickedly funny story that The Onion, the satirical newspaper, ran the other day: Fall Canceled after 3 Billion Seasons:

title: Treating What Ails
description: BOTH my father and grandfather were doctors. I studied pre-med as an undergrad, but I found I had an extreme distaste for organic chemistry. It made me face myself in the mirror. I liked business, so I got my masters degree in health care administration at Duke University.

title: I Am America. (And So?)
description: From   Rudy Giulianis making 12 Commitments to America to  John Edwardss taking a Road Trip for One America, our latest crop of campaigners for the presidency seem to take for granted that the word America has a special resonance, that it defines something meaningful. But what, exactly, is it? America doesnt take its name from an ethnicity nor from a clear demographic, whereas the French, say, owe France to their Frankish forebears. Despite the frequency of its use, America is actually somewhat difficult to define, particularly if we acknowledge that many people living on our planet who are neither residents nor citizens of these United States see themselves as Americans.

title: Shana Warshawsky, Arye Dworken
description: Shana Beth Warshawsky, the daughter of Julie Warshawsky and Robert Warshawsky of Howell, N.J., was married on Thursday evening to Arye Dworken, the son of Susan H. Dworken of Teaneck, N.J., and the late Rabbi Steven M. Dworken. Rabbi Shmuel Silber officiated at the Puck Building in Manhattan.

description: An Auteur

title: Got a Hold on Me
description: The Beatles Second Album (the book) is not going to work unless readers can find the equal of The Beatles Second Album (the album) in their own lives. But thats fine by Dave Marsh. True, the 1964 record is among the first he goes to for refuge and reassurance when the scent of freedom that leaped out at me from rock n roll has faded like the smoke from yesterdays joss stick. Its not his only sanctuary in dull times, however, because anyone who tells you there is a single greatest rock n roll record either doesnt know enough to make the claim or doesnt love rock n roll enough to be worth listening to. My pick would be Heres Little Richard, which appeared seven years earlier, though I, too, concede that a couple of decent albums have appeared since.

title: No Gloating as Navy Beats Army for the Sixth Straight Time
description: BALTIMORE, Dec. 1  Their cleats clicking on the concrete floor, Army and Navy football players streamed side-by-side to the locker rooms after Navys 38-3 victory Saturday. Navy linebacker Irv Spencer paused to wish the Black Knights the best.

title: Skis, Boots and Poles, Driven to Your Place
description: Lets face it: skiing means standing in line. Lines at the lift. Lines at the shuttle. And, of course, lines for rental equipment. A new company, Door 2 Door by Christy Sports (866-323-7547; www.d2dskis.com), hopes to take away the tedium of standing in the rentals line by offering its full-service ski shop on wheels inside your chalet, condo or hotel suite. You tell Door 2 Door when and where youd like the service (they are available round the clock), and trained employees will arrive for the fitting, armed with size and equipment information sent to them in advance. Items like jackets and gloves are also available for purchase and, on request, for rental. The Door 2 Door service is offered at 14 Western mountain resorts, including Jackson Hole, Park City, Sun Valley and Aspen. Rental packages of skis, boots and poles are $25 to $50 a day, including delivery.

description: TESTED Cadillac STS-V

title: When Opportunity Came Crawling
description: WHEN I said I was going to become an exterminator, everybody laughed at me. They thought I was nuts. It was 1987, the year of the crash. I worked on Wall Street in commodities and I could see the writing on the wall. People were being laid off. My wife was pregnant, and I told her I had to find something else to do. One day an exterminator came to our condo on Staten Island and sprayed for two minutes and charged $25. I said, Wow.

title: Now Wearing |Next-Gen Fendi
description: The Fendi clan has a new rising star, and its not a fur-covered tote. Delfina Delettrez, the 20-year-old daughter of the designer Silvia Fendi, is crafting jewelry laden with skulls, spiders and other creepy-crawlies. I have a phobia of insects, and this is the only way I can touch them, explains Delletrez, whose fans include Asia Argento and the family pal Karl Lagerfeld. She plans to open a boutique near Romes Piazza Navona around Christmas and is confident that the baubles  which mix materials like wood, leather and bone with Massa-Carrara marble, diamonds and sapphires  will be worn by her friends and by more traditional customers. The minimum price is 300 euros, she says, and the maximum  well, its not very elegant to say.

description: GLASS SLIPPER, GOLD SANDAL A Worldwide Cinderella. By Paul Fleischman. Illustrated by Julie Paschkis. Holt. $16.95. (Ages 5 and up)

title: Rethinking Plastic Bags
description: Two southern New Jersey assemblymen are proposing a partial ban on plastic bags. Though the proposal is controversial, banning plastic bags would be a relatively effortless way to protect the environment, save energy and reduce a danger to wildlife as well as dogs and other pets. It would also make New Jersey a lot prettier by cutting down on the number of ugly bags that get stuck in trees, on telephone polls and in storm drains.

title: Images of an Island Emerging From Chains
description: The Yale Center for British Arts fine exhibition Art and Emancipation in Jamaica: Isaac Mendes Belisario and His Worlds traces the history of Jamaica from the beginning of British rule in 1655 to the abolition of slavery on the island in the 1830s.

title: Bibliogifts
description: Black is the new black. Walking briskly down Madison Avenue in New York, I passed the window of the designer DKNY, but the display therein slowed my gait to a lugubrious plod. All the mannequins in the windows were clothed in funereal chic  outfits suitable for matronly morticians at an undertakers convention.

title: The Long and Short of It at Goldman Sachs
description: FOR decades now, as a writer, economist and scold, I have been receiving letters from thoughtful readers. Many of them have warned me about the dangers of a secret government running the world, organized by the Trilateral Commission, or the Ford Foundation, or the Big Oil companies or, of course, world Jewry.

title: Film on Mexicos Disputed 06 Election Stirs Emotions
description: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 1  A documentary about last years disputed presidential election has drawn big crowds and generated controversy here, after its director, Luis Mandoki, waged a long battle to find a distributor willing to take on a politically charged film.

title: Not Pretty
description: In History of Beauty, Umberto Eco explored the ways in which notions of attractiveness shift from culture to culture and era to era. With ON UGLINESS (Rizzoli, $45), a collection of images and written excerpts from ancient times to the present, all woven together with a provocative commentary and translated by Alastair McEwen, he asks: Is repulsiveness, too, in the eye of the beholder? And what do we learn about that beholder when we delve into his aversions? Selecting stark visual images of gore, deformity, moral turpitude and malice, and quotations from sources ranging from Plato to radical feminists, Eco unfurls a taxonomy of ugliness. As gross-out contests go, its both absorbing and highbrow.

title: L.S.U. Ignores the Talk and Captures a Title
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 1  The confetti rained down on the Georgia Dome carpet, Les Miles looked perfectly happy as the Louisiana State football coach, and his team looked just as satisfied with the championship of the Southeastern Conference. A season-long chase for the national title appeared to fall short and talk swirled of Miless possibly leaving for Michigan.

title: Louder Life, Thicker Windows
description: BLAME the extra sirens, cars or just people, but many New York streets are noisier than theyve been in decades, according to experts.

description: In the capricious world of fashion, where hemlines, fabrics and colors fall in and out of favor with breathtaking speed, designers and retailers have always relied on one constant  the orderly changing of the seasons.

description: Paterson

title: Now Filling | Art Pools
description: The Swiss artist Sylvie Fleury is making a splash with her customized natatoriums. At the Austrian home of the art dealer Thaddaeus Ropac, she used steel cutouts to spell Be Amazing on the pools floor; the edges are ribboned with words borrowed from a Prada cosmetics pamphlet. It lists all the functions that the cosmetics are meant to perform, Fleury says: Revive, shield, hydrate, exfoliate. Fleury, who says she is more interested in what makes us consume than in what we consume, plans to etch another pool in St.-Tropez with the name of Este Lauders Pleasures fragrance. Shes also creating a soundtrack for it, mixing electro and bubbling sounds: I think its so nice to hear music underwater.

title: Performance Upstart
description: With Damien Hirst reportedly selling a $100-million diamond-encrusted skull and Louis Vuitton emblazoning bags with Richard Prince images, its encouraging to watch the rising career of an artist like Mika Tajima. The New York-based Tajima incorporates many disciplines  performance, architecture, graphic design, sculpture, even fashion  into her art, making for esoteric work that isnt necessarily an easy sell to the new breed of hedge-fund collectors. Yet to curators and critics, Tajima is onto something.

title: Six Chairs, Less Waiting at Winter Park Resort
description: Winter Park Resort in Colorado is set to open the Panoramic Express, which will be the highest six-person high-speed lift in North America. Leitner Poma designed the mechanism, the towers of which were flown in to the resort by helicopter about two months ago.

title: Tight Weave
description: Visitors to the Baroque tapestry show at the Met might not blink at the sight of Kehinde Wileys new creation. Like the artists oil paintings and marble busts, Wileys eight-by-six-foot hanging, woven in Belgium, mingles art history (a composition borrowed from Franois Bouchers Ftes Italiennes and botanical tracery from the Besler Florilegium) with urban swagger (the models were culled from the streets of Harlem). The unusual medium is as canny as it is curious. Its borrowing from some of the tenets of modern art, Wiley says. It has to be indecipherable to be worthy of our praise. $15,000, produced in a limited edition of 48 for Cerealart. Go to www.cerealart.com.

title: You Bring Leo, Ill Bring Diddy
description: BEYOND a teak doorway on an unremarkable stretch of far West 17th Street, a hallway is faintly aglow. Carved into its black ceiling and walls are lines of nearly indecipherable script, each word painted with gold leaf, forming an excerpt from Darwins Origin of Species. At the hallways end, curvy leather banquettes outline a fanciful room where light fixtures fashioned from recycled bicycle tires evoke wizards caps, walls are upholstered in ostrich leather and mirrored open-air decks beckon from behind a fireplace.

title: Navigating a Life From East to West
description: IM not very smart at business, Tomoko Matsuyama said. And I dont know the U.S. market. Ms. Matsuyama, a trim woman in a russet-colored sweater, tossed off the self-deprecating comments during a tour of her newly renovated town house on 152nd Street between Broadway and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Signs of Recovery in a Riot Corridor
description: Washington

title: Comics
description: Cartooning is always subjective, so when you look at political comics, its useful to think about where their arguments can lie  not just in their words but in the implications of their visual style. If you were to read only Andrew Helfers text for RONALD REAGAN: A Graphic Biography (Hill & Wang, $16.95), for instance, it would seem to be a straightforward chronological trot through Reagans life story, with particular attention paid to the showmanship of his public persona and his weakness for self-serving fabrications. Most of the books spin, though, is actually in its artwork, by Steve Buccellato and Joe Staton. After an opening montage of notable moments from Reagans public life, which might as well have been sketched from publicity photos, Ronald Reagan becomes a catalog of the sorts of visual rhetoric cartoonists can pull off: nearly every panel incorporates some kind of broad caricature or symbolic distortion, usually at Reagans expense. On a single page, we see a smiling Reagan hobnobbing with three other Screen Actors Guild board members while Jane Wyman checks her watch; then Reagan and Wyman sweating, smiling and pushing away enormous tough guys with shirts labeled Union; then a quizzical Reagan (with a question mark over his head) watching a man with a fez and a hammer-and-sickle jacket whispering in someones ear; and finally the editorial-cartoon shorthand of an eagle and a bear standing on a broken swastika and scowling at each other.

title: Correction: Language as Sculpture, Words as Clay
description: An article on Oct. 21 about the artist Lawrence Weiner misstated the duration that manhole covers he created with the assistance of the Public Art Fund were to remain in 19 locations below Union Square. The manhole covers are to remain there indefinitely; they were not removed several months after their installation in 2000. The article also gave an erroneous description of Mr. Weiners personal copy of the Public Art Fund manhole cover in front of the Whitney Museum. That manhole cover is nonfunctional; it did not replace a working manhole cover. This correction was delayed because a readers query went astray at The Times.

title: Season of the Kitsch
description: Who says Ive never darkened the door of a museum? Though I may have a reputation for avoiding virgins and haystacks like the plague and I hit the Aleve when confronted with rusted metal arcs and sliced cows, I have been in what feels like hundreds of museum gift shops, most of which do not even require that you pay admission to enter. Why even as I write this, I am sipping my instant coffee from a caf au lait cup decorated with the winsome French cartoon character Bcassine purchased in the boutique next to Pariss almost impossible to find Muse de la Poupe.

title: A Fine Blend of Places to Sip
description: THE choices read like chapters in a childrens book: Margarets Hope, Empress of Japan, Sweet Endings. At the Greenport Tea Company, you can even act like a kid in a candy store, lifting the lids on glass jars to inhale the aroma of these exotic-sounding teas.

title: A Decade of Patterns and Promise
description: It is hard to argue with the broad aims of Pattern and Decoration, an American art movement from the mid-1970s to the mid-1980s. The artists associated with the movement wanted to reassert the primacy of aesthetic concerns in art, to make art that was beautiful and that didnt require any sort of theoretical framework for understanding.

title: Buildings Boards: Whos in Control?
description: ONE of the most contentious issues in co-ops and condominiums relates to sponsor control of the building.

title: Deadbeat Water Users
description: New Yorkers are spoiled when it comes to drinking water. The taste is good, the quality is high and the cost is reasonable, less than residents pay in other large cities, including Boston and Philadelphia.

title: Learning How Local Local Food Can Be
description: Bedford Hills

title: A Light Unto Nations
description: Marcus Tremonto is an artist, a sometime furniture designer, an architecture enthusiast and, as his latest series of electroluminescent Perspex works so aptly illuminates, a self-described tech geek. About 16 of these objects  including hanging light pieces, tabletop sculptures and paintings  will be on display (and also for sale) at Phillips de Pury & Companys Chelsea gallery from Dec. 7 to 29. But are they art? Design? Design/art? Dont expect Tremonto to shed any light. While he readily accepts comparisons of pieces like Bahaus (above) to chandeliers, Tremontos sci-fi versions are ultimately still lifes. You arent exactly going to read by them, he says.

title: Im Dreaming of an Eco-Christmas
description: O Christmas Tree, O Christmas Tree, Your branches green delight us. And, we might add, so do your energy-saving L.E.D.s.

title: One Little Village, but Top-Notch Ballet
description: MYSTIC BALLET will open its season on Dec. 8 with Fire and Ice: Sergei Vanaevs Sonata, set to Beethovens Pathtique Sonata, and the United States premiere of his forceful re-interpretation of Stravinskys Rite of Spring.

title: Hes a Model? Consider the Odds
description: EVERY weekday evening, Simon Rogers rides the uptown No. 1 train from his job in the garment district to his home on the Upper West Side. He usually sits near the door for a good view of people climbing aboard, but on this day Mr. Rogers was seated near the center of the car because the train was crowded. Almost automatically, he began evaluating his fellow passengers, and his eyes found an older man in a newsboy cap and glasses.

title: A Sinners Tale
description: Q: Your novel Atonement  the story of Briony Tallis, a novelist who tells a lie in her girlhood and hurts her older sister in a way for which she can never atone  has been made into a film, and I was surprised to see that you are the executive producer. Most novelists run from film, afraid that the care they lavished on their prose will be squandered. I know. Well, it will be squandered whether they run or not.

title: Brut Force
description: Heres a revolutionary idea to usher in the holidays: peace on earth, goodwill toward men. Trite and treacly, you snort? Evidently not. The new millennium seems dark and vengeful, sunk in a mire of militant theology and fundamentalist agitprop. Lets toast humanism and prudence. Rashly optimistic, you say? Sticks and stones, I say. The Sipper is stepping up to the mike alongside Elvis Costello to pose the musical question: whats so funny bout peace, love and understanding? And shes anointing this radical vision with the most revered of holiday symbols, Champagne. Quickly, though, before it all vanishes in an Armageddon of supply and demand, karma and dogma.

title: Now Booking | the Bunny Pages
description: Nina Garcia, the TV style pundit and fashion director of Elle, describes Star Von Bunny as having the cutest tail in the business. The makeup artist Charlotte Tilbury gushes over her perfect pink lips. And shes known to strike a pose with Jean Paul Gaultier. But Star Von Bunny is not a supermodel or starlet. Shes a stuffed rabbit who is also the protagonist of Star Von Bunny: A Model Tale (HarperEntertainment), by Kym Canter, the creative director for the (ahem) furrier J. Mendel. In Von Bunnys quest to become a model, she dispenses diet tips (Always eat dessert), takes yoga lessons with Christy Turlington and even has a go-see with Carine Roitfeld at French Vogue  complete with a knockoff of an Olivier Theyskens dress made for her 14.5-inch waist. Think of it as a Pat the Bunny for adults who have never grown up.

title: A New Kind of Diva
description: Anna Netrebko is a gifted opera singer who at 36 has already mastered many of the roles  Mimi, Violetta, Lucia, Manon  that used to go to the queenly, temperamental sopranos of the old school, with their furs, their atomizers, their entourages. She is also a media-savvy entertainer from the new school, with the knockout looks, the fans, the celebrity of a pop star. Her Traviata at Salzburg two years ago was such a hot ticket that scalpers were reportedly charging $7,000 a seat, and her records regularly top the charts in Europe. In the summer of 2006 she was part of a concert in Berlin that filled a stadium.

title: Youve Got Mail
description: EVERY year around this time, as the catalogs and holiday greetings flood my mailbox, I am reminded of New York Citys defunct 27-mile pneumatic tube system. This underground network fueled by pressurized air carried first-class mail in two-foot-long canisters from Manhattans General Post Office to postal branches around the city.

title: Scrooge Relents. Joy Prevails. Again.
description: PRINCETON

title: Ready for Download: CTS 2.0
description: A SCENE in the 2005 action film, Mr. and Mrs. Smith, shows Mr. Smith (Brad Pitt), a professional assassin, racing home in his black Cadillac CTS-V. He skids around a corner, and in the next shot suddenly he is in a Lincoln Town Car instead of the Cadillac.

title: Datebook
description: BRUSSELS

title: Swept Away
description: OF all the cities in the world, New York is among the most cosmopolitan. It is almost as though different parts of the world had been stolen and pieced together to form a singular city. Nearly every ethnicity has its own territory within New Yorks boundaries. Stores, restaurants, even entire families seem to have been removed from their homelands and shipped to this city in the same way a part of a liver is transplanted into a foreign body so as to eventually become its own organ.

title: Hope for Helping Hands Fuels a Rally
description: Stocks rallied last week on hopes that both the Federal Reserve and the United States Treasury would take action to bolster the market.

title: 4 Rowers to Take on 12 in Trans-Atlantic Race
description: SHELTER ISLAND

title: Maid Marion
description: In La Vie en Rose, you play Edith Piaf from age 17 to her death at 47. Piaf was a brilliant singer, but she was also a drug addict with a deeply dramatic personality. Was it challenging to play a woman who was so extreme in her emotions?

title: Cheap and Cheerful
description: Style Map | Buenos Aires: The 11-hour flight to Buenos Aires is richly rewarded with warm weather (our winter is their summer), great shopping and a still-kicking dollar. The Palermo Hollywood district is a welcome antidote to the already overrun Palermo Soho across the tracks  a quieter place to stumble across young designer boutiques, underground restaurants and an easy-to-navigate flea market. Happy hunting. [?][?][?]CHRISTINE MUHLKE

description: Caroline Leigh Charlston, a daughter of Mary Ann and Harry G. Charlston of Hobe Sound, Fla., was married last evening to Christopher Stephen West, a son of Judy and Stephen O. West of Atlanta. The Rev. George M. Witt, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

description: MY daughter, Gillian, wants a cellphone, a pack of chocolate Bubblicious, Webkinz trading cards, an iPod Mini skin and a pair of Ugg boots.

description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 2  Voters went to polling stations throughout Venezuela on today to cast ballots on a referendum over constitutional changes that would significantly enhance the power of President Hugo Chvez.

title: From the Heights of $100 Oil, Most Stocks Look Vulnerable
description: THE recent spike in oil prices is probably a passing mania, many investment strategists say. But they warn that if oil remains near record levels next year, it would hurt most domestic stocks, with the notable exception of energy companies.

title: Toddy Time
description: Hot toddies may be for thermoses, but not the Colts Neck Toddy from the Bar Room at the Modern. Its really a spiked herbal tea: verbena leaves are steeped in hot water and honey, then mixed with spirits. (Other herbs, like rosemary or sage, can be substituted.) You can use just about anything to make the hot water more interesting, says Ehren Ashkenazi of the Modern. Be artful, in other words, and improvise.

description: ALTOS DE CERRO AZUL, Panama

description: The cheery spirit of Hanukkah, which begins Tuesday, is captured in Carmels fizzy 2006 Young Moscato from Israel ($7.99) and the light 2005 Rashi Malvasia ($9.99) from Puglia, Italy. Both are kosher.

title: O Brother, Where Art Thou?
description: Customarily in presidential races, Americans seek a patriarchal figure, a strong parent to protect the house from invaders and financial turbulence.

title: Letters to the Editor

title: Lawyers Compete, Except in Bonuses
description: BONUSES on Wall Street are going to be bad this year, except if you work at Goldman Sachs. Or, oddly enough, if youre an associate at a white-shoe law firm. (Granted, the scale of banking bonuses is in a rarefied class of its very own, even when compared with law firms, but bear with me).

title: Service Bulletin: Fix Your Car
description: KIAS that wont start in the morning and high-revving Hondas are among the problems found in recent technical service bulletins.

title: Cover Less to Cover More
description: THE governor of New York has been touting his patient-centered approach to health care policy, claiming that it is driven by the needs and demands of New Yorkers. That sounds nice, but the plan is actually centered on more government control of the health insurance market and higher taxes  not exactly a new approach here.

title: On Long Island, Off the Streets and Onto the Court
description: WYANDANCH

title: Stephan Balint, 64, a Founder of the Squat Theater, Dies
description: Stephan Balint, the underground Hungarian writer, actor and director who gained fame in New York with the above-ground Squat Theater in the late 1970s and 80s, died on Oct. 11 in Budapest. He was 64.

title: Me Bid
description: My husband is not the kind of man targeted by the Neiman Marcus catalog. He is not a Man Who Has Everything. He doesnt have enough socks, shoes or underwear. He shuns all things new. I wouldnt dare buy him a personal G.P.S. device for Christmas. Ah, but a 19th-century fishmongers sign? An Albertus Seba illustration of a possum and snake locked in battle? Thats another matter. The man is to antiques what women are to shoes: a little goofy.

title: When the Future Looked Brave and New
description: Aldous Huxley began his literary career on the edge of Bloomsbury and ended it in Beverly Hills, the prophet of a dystopian future and advocate of LSD. Huxley was so preoccupied by the dangers threatening civilization that he could not rouse himself to defend it. The reader of this engrossing collection of letters, many previously unpublished, is dismayed to find him refusing to sign a declaration against Hitler  never mind fight  a few weeks after the outbreak of war, because I do not feel that politics ... are my affair, except such politics as are dictated by the need to make the world safe for mystical experience.  Support from Bloomsbury old boys was not lacking: Have you yet read [Bertrand] Russells new book, Which Way to Peace? he asked a correspondent in 1936, as the Nazis prepared to trample over Europe. It is a most admirably lucid argument leading by remorseless logic to the complete pacifist position.

title: Buyer Beware in Seeking Lower Energy Costs
description: WITH winter setting in and heating fuel prices nearing record levels, Westchester residents may be thinking about taking advantage of Con Edisons Power Your Way program, which allows them to buy gas or electricity from a source other than Con Ed.

title: The Discreet Charm of the Gauloisie
description: REALITY is  like life, or art or dinner  as real as you make it. This concept is not terribly popular right now in the art world, where reality seems to equal the price your work brought at Sothebys. And art that does not have a tangible value is just too abstract.

title: Caught Up in a Storm, With His Eyes Wide Open
description: PASCAGOULA, Miss.

title: Corrections
description: The list of 100 Notable Books of 2007 in the Book Review today misspells the surname of the author of the novel Let the Northern Lights Erase Your Name. She is Vendela Vida, not Veda. (The same error appeared in the Editors Choice column on Jan. 7.)

title: Putting a Price on a Wrongful Conviction
description: WILLIAM GREGORY and David Pope were both convicted of rape. Mr. Gregory served seven years in a Kentucky prison and Mr. Pope was imprisoned by Texas for 15 years before being released because of new DNA evidence.

title: Yoko Mizumoto and Daniel Fleisher
description: Yoko Mizumoto, the daughter of Yuko Mizumoto and Toshihiro Mizumoto of Nara, Japan, was married on Monday to Daniel Aaron Fleisher, a son of Dr. Jan E. Paradise and Dr. Gary R. Fleisher of Newton, Mass. Ralph A. Antonacci, a justice of the peace in Stamford, Conn., officiated at the Stamford Government Center.

description: Karachi, Pakistan

title: The World as an Imperfect Globe
description: NEARLY a quarter century ago, Theodore Levitt, the Harvard business professor, heralded a global convergence of consumer tastes. The global corporation, he proclaimed, sells the same things in the same way everywhere. In 2005, Thomas L. Friedman, The New York Times columnist, sounded a similar trumpet about the effects of technology, inaugurating his world-is-flat franchise.

title: Can a Co-op Demand Health Insurance Proof?
description: Q My co-op board has begun to request proof of health insurance of applicants. There are no specific requirements as to an amount, just proof of insurance. The requirement is not included in the application package, but it is requested after the application has been submitted.

title: Caitlin Wight, Timothy Fitzsimmons
description: Caitlin McDermott Wight, a daughter of Deborah McDermott Wight and William Needles Wight of New York, was married last evening to Timothy James Fitzsimmons, the son of Mary Elizabeth Fitzsimmons and James Edward Fitzsimmons of Whippany, N.J. The Rev. Brenda G. Husson, an Episcopal priest, officiated at St. James Episcopal Church in New York, with the Rev. Luke Travers, a Roman Catholic priest, taking part.

description: WHEN she died last year at 103, Aimee de Heeren  of New York; Palm Beach, Fla.; Paris; and Biarritz, France  became one more lost link to an earlier age of social grace and high society.

title: Pins and Needles
description: HELEN UFFNER, the owner of a theatrical costume company, has a vast inventory of vintage items dating from the 1970s back to the 1860s, among them 8,300 dresses, 3,200 womens hats and 800 cartons of accessories. Items from her collection have made cameo appearances in movies like Capote, in television shows like Saturday Night Live and in countless Broadway plays.

description: An international guide to the best of the winter and spring art offerings.
