title: Toy Stories
description: The All-Ill-Ever-Want Christmas Doll is a rich portrait of a poor black family in the midst of the Depression. Written by Patricia C. McKissack, the winner of numerous awards, and illustrated by the equally renowned Jerry Pinkney, it has the look, sound and feel of a classic. McKissacks direct and unfettered language partners beautifully with the vivid tones of Pinkneys pencil-and-watercolor illustrations. Inspired by a true story, The All-Ill-Ever-Want Christmas Doll is an evocative book with a universal message.

title: Between Buyers and Sellers, a Stalemate
description: BRUCE EPSTEIN has spent the last four months looking for co-ops on the Upper West Side, and he thought he had a pretty good grip on how much they were going for. When he decided to offer slightly less than the $1.15 million asking price for a two-bedroom in a walk-up building that required renovations, he thought he was being reasonable. But the seller said he shouldnt even bother to make an offer if he wouldnt pay the asking price.

title: Twisting and Chatting the Ailey Way
description: DANCES have traditionally been handed down from performer to performer, even since the invention of dance notation. But how do dancers learn about the mysterious culture of performing? Some of that can be soaked up in the daily work, but there is nothing quite like a lazily extended, spontaneous conversation with a veteran choreographer, dancer or company director.

title: One Is No Longer the Loneliest Number
description: SURE, traveling alone can be an extremely freeing experience, with no one else to slow you down or bicker with over which sights to see along the way. But it can also be a drag. When youre hauling your bags around on your own, or when the only other single on your hiking tour is the guide or after your third sunset dinner on the hotels veranda  alone  traveling by yourself can lose its allure.

title: Immigrants in New York Better Off, Study Finds
description: Foreign-born New Yorkers are better educated, more likely to have health insurance and less likely to have entered the country illegally compared with immigrants in the rest of the country, according to a new analysis.

title: Inside the List
description: NOW THAT YOU ASK: Denis Johnsons novel Tree of Smoke saw an uptick in sales after winning the National Book Award, but not enough of one (yet) to put it back on the fiction list. It rests currently at No. 29 on the extended list. Johnson, famously, does not give many interviews, and when he does he is pretty laconic. description: BOZEMAN, an old Montana cowboy town known for long views and a vast sky, is in the throes of development, with big-box stores expanding around its perimeter. But business owners in the city's downtown are steadfastly trying to maintain the history of the area and the character of their shops.

title: One Piece or Two?
description: Its that time of year: sand, sea, salt air  and scene, if thats what floats your boat. Want a beach vacation with billionaires or bohos? Margaritas or mint tea? Here, the ins and outs The bohemians Baja, where a rollicking beach and colorful town square trump the megaresorts lining the rest of the Pacific Coast.

title: Ending Famine, Simply by Ignoring the Experts
description: LILONGWE, Malawi  Malawi hovered for years at the brink of famine. After a disastrous corn harvest in 2005, almost five million of its 13 million people needed emergency food aid.

title: Shaking Up Branford
description: Here is a disturbing national statistic: In general, about 80 percent of 80-year-olds vote, but only about 20 percent of 20-year-olds vote. While young people still go to the polls in significant numbers, its little wonder that the needs of the YouTube generation are not at the top of the average politicians priority list.

title: The Stowaway on Schindlers List
description: MIMI REINHARD, 92, sat very straight on the edge of a sofa, her lipstick freshly applied, her neck garlanded with pearls. Though the furniture was mostly gone from her apartment on West 72nd Street and the carpets were rolled up, an air of the Viennese drawing room hovered about her.

title: Lottery Numbers
Smoke This Book
description: If the mark of a classic is that every time you read it you discover something new, then the 1972 paperback of A. E. Van Vogts science-fiction novel Quest for the Future just might be a classic. Those who read the book when it was first published in hardcover in 1970 certainly wont recognize this passage from Chapter 15: A large gleaming machine with an opening at one end was wheeled in, and once again the cycle ran its Micronite Filter. Mild, Smooth Taste. For All the Right Reasons. Kent. Americas Quality Cigarette. King Size or Deluxe 100s.

title: Israeli Forces Kill 6 in Gaza
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 1  Five members of the Hamas armed wing were killed Saturday by an Israeli rocket strike in southern Gaza, near the village of Abassan. An additional eight gunmen were wounded, one critically, according to the Health Ministry in Gaza, when helicopter gunship attacks followed the airstrikes.

title: Letters: The Ethicist
description: The incomplete grade given by the professor, referred to in the Ethicists update, solves nothing (Nov. 18). The student who copied a paper from the Internet simply writes another paper, and except for possible penalties for lateness, apparently walks away as if the plagiarism never occurred.

title: Where Living in Fear Starts at the Top
description: For more than a year, fearing assassination, the prime minister has lived in his office in the ornate government building, surrounded by concentric circles of barbed wire, soldiers and armored vehicles that separate him from antigovernment demonstrators. Some 40 members of Parliament from the razor-thin majority are holed up in the luxurious, gaudy Phoenicia Hotel a few blocks away, behind three tiers of metal detectors, internal security police and drawn curtains. The two majority leaders are in fortress-like family palaces, one high in the mountains, the other with surrounding city streets sealed off for blocks.

title: For Suns Hill, Quality Time, but Precious Little Quiet Time
description: PHOENIX, Nov. 29  It was a rare day off from basketball, but there was no rest for Suns forward Grant Hill. On a recent Saturday morning, Hill had seen his mother off to the airport and visited the barbershop. Now he was seated at the kitchen table, thumbing through the latest issue of Vanity Fair while cradling his crying 3-month-old daughter, Lael, in his lap.

title: He Writes About What He Knows
description: Art doesnt just imitate life in David Henry Hwangs play Yellow Face. It clones it.

title: Now Wearing | the Other Chlo
description: For her new line, Chlo Sevigny for Opening Ceremony, sold at the eponymous downtown boutique and other hip spots, the actress drew upon her completely awkward and dorky junior-high years. I wanted this collection to embody that spirit of being young, she says. This meant cropped blazers, Liberty-print grunge dresses, even a motorcycle cap made from recycled cassette tapes. My friend told me that the whole collection was a pretty accurate self-portrait, she says. I wasnt sure if he meant it as an insult or a compliment.

description: The Yankees insist they have gone as far as they are willing to go in their trade offer for Johan Santana, the ace left-hander of the Minnesota Twins. Their chances of getting him depend on whether the Twins insist on receiving another top prospect in the deal.

title: Lots of Little Screens: TV Is Changing Shape
description: INEXPENSIVE broadband access has done far more for online video than enable the success of services like YouTube and iTunes. By unchaining video watchers from their TV sets, it has opened the floodgates to a generation of TV producers for whom the Internet is their native medium.

title: To Be Safe, Call the Bride by Her First Name
description: WHEN Jill Van Camp decided to play catcher in a softball game on the September morning of her wedding, her mother worried that the bride might lose a tooth. Ms. Van Camp, 31, was more concerned about losing her good name. Literally.

title: Art Basel 911
description: Noel Lanzas is a full-time concierge at the Ritz-Carlton South Beach and a Surrealist painter in his free time. This month, hell merge both as the hotels Art Basel Miami Beach Ambassador. As an on-call guide, he will shepherd fragile art-world newbies during the four-day event. He can tap into the hotels network of art consultants, create a fair-hopping schedule for seasoned collectors, get V.I.P. party invitations and advise on shipping options for those who score.

title: Letters: The Sleep-Industrial Complex
description: Did Thomas Edisons invention of the electric light wreak havoc on heliocentric sleep behavior, or did our society always cut sleep short? Jon Mooallem (Nov. 18) rightly turns to anthropologists to answer this fascinating question. But the question remains, where do we go from here?

title: Mad
description: If you grew up with the cartoons of Don Martin, which were a fixture of Mad magazine from 1956 through 1988, theres a danger in revisiting them: once youve become a sophisticated-type person  that is, one who has finally grasped that thwap and thoipoing arent real words  does Martins world, in which there are a thousand variations on the squirting-flower gag, and where human beings sport snappy-looking but physiologically untenable hinged feet, still look weird? Or is it really nothing more than comfort food for nostalgic baby boomers who cant let go of that figurative (or perhaps literal) stack of old Mads stashed under the bed?

title: Nonstop Theft and Bribery Stagger Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, Dec. 1  Jobless men pay $500 bribes to join the police. Families build houses illegally on government land, carwashes steal water from public pipes, and nearly everything the government buys or sells can now be found on the black market.

title: The Hang Man
description: When a fashion designers work is called arty, its usually a polite way of saying that the clothes are interesting but unwearable. Christian Lacroix, who during his 20 years as a couturier has whipped up many a masterpiece, makes no pretensions toward being an artist. He has, however, long harbored the fantasy of being a museum curator. With the opening of Christian Lacroix: Histoires de Mode at the Muse des Arts Dcoratifs in Paris, he finally gets his shot. Selecting some 500 garments from the museums vast archive, combined with 80 couture pieces of his own design, Lacroix has revised fashion history in his own checked, polka-dotted, striped and quilted image, exuberantly mixing up styles and periods  much like he does in his own collections  with the flair of a true postmodernist.

Dufresne and Mr. Dufresne Sr. of Suffield, Conn. Thomas Costello, a Roman Catholic deacon, performed the ceremony at St. Josephs Roman Catholic Church in Hewlett, N.Y.

description: ISTANBUL, Dec. 1  The Turkish military said Saturday that it had inflicted significant losses on a group of Kurdish guerrillas in Iraq, though it offered no evidence for its claim.

description: SAN ANTONIO, Dec. 1  After No. 9 Oklahomas 38-17 victory against top-ranked Missouri to win the Big 12 championship Saturday night, Sooners Coach Bob Stoops was quick to campaign for his team to play in the Bowl Championship Series title game.

description: Last summer, even as he talked about facing jail time, Jim Stevenson couldnt stop looking for birds. Theres a couple yellow-crowned night herons, he said, pointing out his living-room window. They roost in that chinaberry tree. He rested his eyes on the blue-gray birds. Anyway, the cops pulled me over and searched my van and found the gun, and

title: The Raiders Fargas Is Ready to Ramble
description: The only thing that has slowed Justin Fargas  since he became the Oakland Raiders starting running back has been the defense of the Minnesota Vikings, which held him to 60 yards rushing. Fargass opponent today, the Denver Broncos, should not be nearly as challenging.

title: Its Only a Game, Right?
description: A few weeks ago, two ill-matched high school football teams played a game so lopsided that the score was 51 to 0 before the end of the first half. This created a problem. Piling up a lead of more than 50 points can get a coach suspended under the rules of the Connecticut Interscholastic Athletic Conference. The coach therefore directed one of his players to field a kick and run the wrong way into his own end zone, intentionally causing a safety and making the score 51 to 2.

title: Effort to Limit Junk Food in Schools Faces Hurdles
description: Federal lawmakers are considering the broadest effort ever to limit what children eat: a national ban on selling candy, sugary soda and salty, fatty food in school snack bars, vending machines and  la carte cafeteria lines.

title: Second Thoughts and Profits
description: PIER LUIGI LORO PIANA, an Italian businessman, yachtsman and scion of a family known for its cashmere and luxury goods business, was caught up in the excitement last year over the conversion of the Plaza Hotel into luxury condominiums. In May 2006, he signed a contract for a $5.8 million one-bedroom on the 14th floor with views of Central Park.

title: Heard Near the Gowanus: Calls for Room Service
description: AS recently as 16 months ago, there were, not surprisingly, zero hotels amid the myriad auto body shops that dot Fourth Avenue and the surrounding Gowanus area. Now there are three, and plans for a fourth, an 18,000-square-foot structure at President Street and Third Avenue.

title: Precious Metals
description: Sometime around 1960, the sculptor Alexander Calder was visiting Jean Lipman, the editor of Art in America, when he noticed one of her keepsakes, a triangular stone. Grandpa asked her if he could have it, says his grandson, Alexander S. C. Rower, who directs the Calder Foundation. Taken aback, Lipman assented reluctantly, figuring her rock was gone for good. But soon after, he surprised her by returning it, transmuted into the jewel of a brass and silver wire brooch. Such deviltry was totally in character, Rower says: You could always count on the guy to do something surprising.

title: The Sputnik Effect
description: On the evening of Oct. 4, 1957, while millions of Americans settled into their sofas for the premiere of Leave It to Beaver, Soviet engineers thousands of miles away were celebrating a different sort of debut. Earlier in the day, they had successfully launched the worlds first artificial satellite  the antenna-strewn orb known as Sputnik  from a test center deep in the rugged Kazakh desert.

title: Heres the Show, the Works Are Elsewhere
description: Los Angeles

title: Middle East Peace Through Anxiety
description: Annapolis, Md.

title: The Shock of the Hue
description: When Grace Coddington, Vogues creative director, turned up at the Paris collections in a green dress this autumn, it might have seemed no cause for comment  except perhaps from the French, who think green is unlucky.

title: Food History
description: If the past is a foreign country, do they eat things differently there? Not as differently as youd think, to judge from the new anthology FOOD: The History of Taste (University of California, $39.95), a weirdly fascinating survey of dietary habits stretching from prehistoric barbecues right up to the molecular menu at El Bulli. Consider the Pueblo II civilization, an advanced agricultural community that lived in the American Southwest a thousand years ago. These days its fashionable to blame the farm bill for the gross amount of corn that Americans eat  but as it turns out, even without federal subsidies or Orville Redenbacher to influence them, the Pueblo II couldnt get enough of the stuff either.

description: POMONA, N.Y.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE MISSION SONG, by John le Carr. (Back Bay/Little, Brown, $14.99.) This novels hero, Bruno Salvador, a k a Salvo, is one of le Carrs outsiders, the son of an Irish Catholic missionary and a Congolese village woman. Now an interpreter living in London, Salvo is asked by British intelligence to translate at a secret meeting of Congolese officials and a mysterious syndicate of business and political interests bent on subverting Congos approaching elections. As he examines Salvos response through the lens of his past and of his affair with a Congolese nurse, le Carr remains preoccupied with how individuals, as they are forced to define their moral commitment, must attempt to defy the overwhelming political pressures around them, our reviewer, Neil Gordon, wrote.

title: Pout and Shout
description: ALL is not well in MileyWorld.

title: An Armory, and a Siege by Rebels Who Live Nearby
description: THE Seventh Regiment Armory, the massive, crenellated red-brick building that occupies a full square block on the Upper East Side, spent much of the 1990s falling apart. When we took it over, said Rebecca Robertson, president of the Seventh Regiment Armory Conservancy, it had rats, it had lead contamination, there was litter everywhere.

title: He Has Leverage
description: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif.

title: Rangers Start Fast and Add to Ottawas Woes
description: OTTAWA, Dec. 1  Before Saturdays game between the Ottawa Senators and the Rangers, fans of the Senators tried to manufacture enthusiasm. They warmed themselves on a brutally cold day by cheering their struggling team, which entered the day on a five-game losing streak.

title: Judging Eminent Domain
description: THE recent $12.4 million jury verdict against the Town of Branford for eminent-domain abuse signals the publics heightened sensitivity to the issue, said lawyers for both sides in the case.

title: Visuals
description: War is hell! Yet in James Aulichs WAR POSTERS: Weapons of Mass Communication (Thames & Hudson, $40), a lush catalog for a current exhibition at the Imperial War Museum in London, many of the posters produced in favor of armed conflict and in opposition to it during the 20th and early 21st centuries are so exquisitely conceived and rendered that they can be appreciated as art, not mere propaganda.

title: Fuel Bill Shows House Speakers Muscle
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1  The question has hung over Nancy Pelosi since she became speaker of the House: could she handle the powerful Democratic committee chairmen who stuck it out 12 years in the minority for the chance to wield authority once their party won control?

title: Few Priests? Papal Visit Seen as Help
description: YONKERS

title: Correction: Amid Affluence, the Hidden Homeless
description: An article and an accompanying picture caption last Sunday about homelessness on Long Island misstated the location of a National Wholesale Liquidators store at whose loading dock homeless people sometimes congregate. It is in the Village of West Hempstead, not Hempstead.

title: Calendar of Events
description: FILM

title: Where to Eat Before Hibernating
description: EVERY year about this time, I suffer the same disappointment. Its called winter, and somehow it always comes as a surprise.

title: Is Bulgaria Really Skiings Next Hot Spot?
description: THE morning sky outside my window was gray with rain  the last thing I wanted to see at Bansko, the biggest ski resort in Bulgaria. A dispiriting mist hid the half-built hotels and condos that lay beyond the ugly Glazne River, and the Pirin Mountains were all but invisible. The town had been warm and wet the past two days, and conditions up on the slopes below the roughly 9,000-foot Todorka peak hadn't been much better. I closed the curtains with a sigh and gave myself the day off.

title: Benefits of Immigration
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction: A Chicken Coop, but No Tigers
description: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about the film director Ang Lee misidentified the man standing beside Sihung Lung on the set of Pushing Hands. It was Chung Zen Chang, a tai chi instructor, not Mr. Lee.

title: Party Politics
description: By 2003, at the age of 33, the Alabama-born writer Michael Knight had written, and seen published, two collections of stories and a short novel. It was a promising start. Knights understated prose presented a quietly volatile world of tight Southern communities and families, a world defined by festering resentments, fumbling relationships, affairs, divorces, sudden furies. For all its dark insight into human entanglements, Knights fiction also contained surprising jolts of humor.

title: Tangled Up in Blue
description: LIKE nearly everyone in one corner of Ozone Park, Queens, Mary Ann Simulinas can tell you stories about the elusive inhabitant of the silvery blue house that sits opposite a cemetery on the corner of 107th Avenue and 84th Street.

title: Danielle Axelrod, James Magid
description: Danielle Sara Axelrod, a daughter of Margaret Golieb Axelrod and Jay G. Axelrod of New York, was married last evening to James Arthur Magid, the son of Caryn Magid and James I. Magid of New York. Rabbi Jonathan Stein officiated with Rabbi Sheldon Zimmerman at the Pierre in New York.

title: A Student Editor Finds Himself at the Center of the News
description: SOME day, Jason Braff, now a junior at Quinnipiac University in Hamden, could join Tom Brokaw, Ted Koppel, Peter Jennings and Leslie Stahl as a recipient of the colleges Fred Friendly Award  named for the former CBS News president and bestowed for showing courage in preserving free speech. But for now, Mr. Braff, in his first year as editor of the student newspaper, The Chronicle, is in a battle with the administration over what he and others say is his right, and that of the papers, to criticize the university.

title: Paraplegic Actor Sings for Stem Cell Research
description: MITCH LONGLEY, an actor on the NBC series Las Vegas, remembers that day in Rowayton 24 years ago when hundreds of friends, relatives and well-wishers from the community gave him a surprise 18th birthday party and presented him a Buick, wrapped in a bow, that he could drive on his own, with his hands.

title: New Rallying Cry: Save the Small Airports
description: NOT long ago, many of New Jerseys small airports were endangered because of opposition from local communities and pressure from developers interested in converting the land to more profitable use, like condos or shopping malls. These general-aviation airports, which cater to private pilots, flight schools and other nonairline operations, were closing at the rate of one a year, falling to 43 today from a high of around 100 after World War II.

title: The Road to Funny
description: In his often engaging new memoir, Born Standing Up, Steve Martin recalls an encounter in 1967, at a nightclub in Aspen, with his first serious heckler. See if you think this is funny, the man said, throwing a glass of red wine at him. The incident feels especially shocking because by this point in the book, almost halfway through, the reader is so sympathetic to Martin  the guy slaved for years analyzing comedians on television, studying them in clubs, torturing himself to deliver something radically new, all the while waiting for even the tiniest recognition  that you take the hecklers assault personally.

title: Colts Are Hobbled but Remain Potent
description: Contrary to popular belief, the Indianapolis Colts season did not end with a loss to New England. In fact, if not for a late rally by Tom Brady that day and a missed field goal late in a loss at San Diego a week later, the Colts (9-2)  not the Patriots  would be 11-0.

title: Raise a Glass to the Father of Energy Drinks
description: It was never about winning or losing with Dr. J. Robert Cade. From our first telephone conversation 41 years ago, it was always about helping others and solving problems, like the dozens of young football players across the country who were dehydrating and having strokes during practices and games.

title: Snow Men
description: Why cant the snowman get any respect? By Bob Ecksteins count, of the approximately 500 books with the word snowman in the title, 488 are either for children or about drug dealers. Of the some eight million pieces of art on record at the Royal Library in The Hague, only two contain images of a snowman. Consumer capitalism has pressed the snowman into service as a pitchman for everything from anti-dandruff shampoo to laxatives to tampons. Feminist professors have publicly denounced him as a fat white male who lolls on the lawn while the woman of the house is inside toiling. In Switzerland, there is even a national holiday dedicated to blowing him up.

title: The Jaws That Bite
description: To the Editor:

title: Hollywood Chronicle
description: HOLLYWOODS CENSOR Joseph I. Breen and the Production Code Administration. By Thomas Doherty. (Columbia University, $29.50.)

title: Connecticuts Interstate of Confusion
description: Norwalk

title: For East End, an Ideal Year
description: East End producers are virtually ecstatic about this years vintage. If someone asked us to describe what would be the ideal growing season on the North Fork, we would have to describe 2007, Charles Massoud, an owner of Paumanok Vineyards in Aquebogue, said in an e-mail message. Roman Roth, winemaker at the Wlffer Estate in Sagaponack on the South Fork, wrote: The 2007 vintage is turning out to be spectacular. It is a rare combination when high quality is also met by high yields and healthy clean fruit.

title: Statistics Pinpoint Problems in Paterson Schools
description: PATERSON, N.J.  Assistant school superintendents here are routinely summoned to a 10 a.m. Thursday meeting where they must answer for missing test scores, overdue building repairs and other lapses, which are presented in painful detail on PowerPoint slides. Excuses are not an option.

title: Bitter Pill
description: Harold Schechter seems an average sort. He teaches American literature at Queens College in New York City. His authors bio mentions a home in Brooklyn and a wife. His face, which stares out from the photo on his Web site, radiates middle-aged respectability. Beneath this placid exterior, however, thuds a dark and savage heart.

title: The Brando of Ballet
description: The Nureyev family of the small industrial town of Ufa in the Soviet republic of Bashkiria was so poor that at the age of 5 little Rudik had no shoes. He was carried to school by his mother on her back. He was called a beggar by the other children. One day he fainted from hunger. Fifty-two years later, at a packed auction at Christies in New York, a single pair of Rudolf Nureyevs used ballet slippers sold for more than $9,000. John Dryden called dancing the poetry of the foot, and rarely before had a pair of feet so defined, and symbolized, this poetry. Every male ballet dancer for the past five decades has been dancing in the space, the vast terra infirma, charted by Nureyevs well-worn shoes.

title: Is There a Bespoke Framer?
description: The framer Richard Ziello has a knack for complementing a canvas, from Motherwell to Matisse. (One collector calls him a rogue aesthetician.) Ziello will measure your art at home and then return to his Long Island studio to fabricate welded aluminum, wood and gold-leaf frames with molding of his own design. We can adjust the style and molding to fit the proportions of the picture, and the art never leaves the owners hands, he says. His couture approach stems from his trade as a sculptor (see his work at the Tribes Gallery through Dec. 7). Too busy with commissions from Ameringer Yohe Fine Art, the estate of Hans Hofmann and others, Ziello neglects his own art. Im like the shoemaker who couldnt afford his own shoes. E-mail rickybonzai@aol.com.

title: Neue Galleries
description: Berlins reputation as the next art capital was sealed this fall with the arrival of several new spaces, all outposts of established European galleries. Haunch of Venison (also of London and Zurich) opened a more than 5,000-square-foot branch in Mitte in September with a splashy concert by the fictional 70s band Lustfaust. Meanwhile, in Kreuzberg, Konrad Fischer Galerie (Dsseldorf) and Jablonka Galerie (Cologne) have joined Buchmann Galerie and Julius Werner Berlin (above) in the area around Checkpoint Charlie.

title: Manhattan Turns to New Jersey to Fulfill Its Need for Electricity
description: Manhattan already orders out to New Jersey for much of what it needs, from food to furniture to gasoline. Soon the list of imports from across the Hudson River may include electricity.

title: Anna Kneitel, Michael Gross
description: Anna Weber Kneitel, the daughter of M. Diane Weber and Dr. Alan Kneitel of San Francisco, was married yesterday to Michael Benjamin Gross, a son of Judith and David Gross of Sudbury, Mass. Rabbi Jay B. Heyman officiated at the Golden Gate Club in the Presidio in San Francisco.

title: Sand, Sea and Space to Roam on Horseback
description: BRIGANTINE BEACH

title: Defeating Hunger and Homelessness, Step by Step
description: Three and a half years after he was evicted, David Joseph still remembers the shock of coming home to a chain on his apartment door in the Bronx. He was 18. He had never lived on his own before.

title: In Preservation, Room for Growth
description: CHESTERFIELD

title: NFL Matchup
description: LIONS at VIKINGS

title: Simon Says
description: Any cookbook that has a chapter devoted entirely to cream is a book I cant do without. Add a chapter on custard, another on chocolate, and Ill order it from England for a small fortune in postage. No wonder, then, that I now have not one but two copies of Simon Hopkinsons Roast Chicken and Other Stories on my kitchen counter  the U.K. edition, already dog-eared and grease-and-gravy-stained, and an arguably more pristine copy of the new American edition, which came out in September. Roast Chicken is one of those rare cookbooks that, once opened, becomes indispensable  perhaps because it takes so many of the dishes you thought you had already mastered and, quite simply, does them that much better. Foodies know it as the winner of the 1995 Glenfiddich award for best food book, and publishers know it as the book that trumped Harry Potter on Amazon.coms British best-seller list. The British magazine Waitrose Food Illustrated named it the most useful cookbook ever, but here I must disagree. Roast Chicken and Other Stories  is far too idiosyncratic to be labeled useful. Rather, it is deliciously random and highly opinionated.

title: Silly Putting
description: The Heat and the Dolphins had better make way for Miamis new sporting obsession: miniature golf. Back 9, a new course where every hole is designed by a local artist, began as an installation on the Albion hotel roof during last Decembers Art Basel Miami Beach. The owner, Peter Rozek, 29, cobbled it together, calling in a few favors from creative friends like Cristina Lei Rodriguez, Hernan Bas and Daniel Arsham. Rozeks folly is now a campy landmark inside a garden center on the mainland. Art fans play spot-the-masterwork  Ali Proschs black arbor is a current standout  while sipping a free rum cocktail. The best day to play is the last Saturday of the month, when an over-the-hill hole is retired and its replacement makes its debut at a dance party. 7244 Biscayne Boulevard; (305) 984-3231; www.uppereastsidegarden.com.

title: Marie-Claude Wrenn, Robert Myers
description: Marie-Claude Palmieri Wrenn and Robert Anthony Myers were married yesterday in Manhattan. The Rev. Boniface Ramsey, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Holy Family.

title: Amy Bielefeld, Stephen ten Broeke
description: Amy Bielefeld, a daughter of Elizabeth and William Bielefeld of Dongan Hills, Staten Island, was married yesterday to Stephen ten Broeke, the son of Phyllis and John ten Broeke of Centerville, Mass. Michael Gleason, a Roman Catholic deacon and an uncle of the bride, will officiate at Our Lady of the Rosary in Manhattan. The Rev. Peter Meehan, a Roman Catholic priest, will also participate.

title: Masterpiece Home Theater
description: Dont worry. I wont get the Water Lilies. Although, to be honest, Id consider it, if the image werent still so scented with memories of Muzak and fluoride treatments. Its not a paintings fault when dentists like it. And maybe those tranquil Giverny colors are just what I need this winter on my monocle-size screen when Im alone, peering importantly at my BlackBerry for its little blinky company and moral support.

title: Art Fair Field Guide
description: Identifying Basel Miamis Indigenous Species.

title: Stefanie Schuman, Rory Weiner
description: Dr. Stefanie Gail Schuman and Dr. Rory Brett Weiner were married last evening by Rabbi Harry K. Danziger at Temple Israel in Memphis.

title: Correction: Review of Someday This Pain Will Be Useful to You
description: A review on Nov. 11 about Someday This Pain Will Be Useful to You, by Peter Cameron, omitted the Farrar, Straus & Giroux imprint that published the book. It is Frances Foster Books.

title: Spanish Policeman Is Killed in Attack in France
description: MADRID, Dec. 1  A Spanish policeman was shot dead in southern France on Saturday by members of the Basque militant group ETA, Spanish authorities said. Another policeman was seriously wounded in the attack.

title: Save the Date
description: Theres something a little bit infectious about the Dolphin Studios calendar ($50), silk-screened by the ceramic artist John Ffrench and his wife, Primm, who have been making these folksy, colorful prints from their home studio in Stockbridge, Mass., for 37 years. All of the family members, including their grandchildren, have been contributing artwork since they were old enough to hold a brush. I dont think weve ever said, Oh, no, that wont do,  Ffrench says. Production grows each year (theyre up to 1,500), since nearly every calendar giftee becomes a gifter. Heres an example: this writer gave one to Daily Candys Crystal Meers; Aimee Acord (the sister of the cinematographer Lance), who saw it at Meerss house, gave one to the designer Jane Mayle  who then produced sweaters bearing interpretations of the designs for Barneys Co-op. The images were so strong graphically and so very charming that it was hard not to do something with them, Mayle says. Looking at my calendar on the wall every day just seemed a little small and selfish. The family now has a Web site. Im the computer person, and Im a little wobbly, Primm says. Welcome to 2008. Go to www.thedolphinstudio.com or call (413) 298-3735.

title: The Days Best
description: Kevin Smith had 284 yards and 4 touchdowns as Central Florida beat Tulsa, 44-25, to win the Conference USA championship. Smith, a junior, is the nations leading rusher with 2,448 yards.

title: Strange Pairing on Hall Ballot
description: Having Marvin Miller and Bowie Kuhn on the same Hall of Fame ballot is like having Alex Rodriguez and Carl Pavano on the same players ballot. Yet there they are, Miller and Kuhn, together as candidates on the executives ballot of the newly constituted election format for the Hall of Fame.

title: Once Upon a Time in China
description: Heres a lesson in the graceful acceptance of defeat. In 1298, the Genoese navy bested the Venetian fleet at the Battle of Curzola. Unable to live with the disgrace, one Venetian commander, Andrea Dandolo, killed himself by beating his head against his ships mast. Another Venetian leader, Marco Polo, surrendered calmly, was taken prisoner and spent a few years writing his memoirs in comfortable captivity. Dandolos fame died on the deck; Polos will outlive our grandchildren. Few famous names have as much vagueness attached to their exploits, though. Marco Polo opened Asia to European trade, so were told, but we generally dont know much else. Laurence Bergreen remedies that by bolstering Polos reputation and arguing for his historical importance in a book as enthralling as a rollicking travel journal. Bergreen, who has written biographies of Louis Armstrong, James Agee and Irving Berlin, turned his attention to ancient explorers with Over the Edge of the World, which tracked Ferdinand Magellans circumnavigation of the globe. I was a fan of that book, but Marco Polo far outshines it, and not surprisingly. Marco Polo, unlike Magellan, left his biographers a masterpiece of a memoir to work with.

title: Giving You Christmas When You Want It
description: IS it that time already? Every year it gets earlier! Please! No tinsel! Not before December! These are just some of the comments I overheard recently as passers-by saw me and my colleagues installing the holiday windows at the emporium of style and fashion where we work.

title: Weather
description: Having spent a lot of time fleeing the hazards of erupting skies, slate-gray funnel clouds and flash floods while filming in remote locations (not to mention my twister-fearing Illinois youth), I have always been curious about someone who runs right at them, camera in hand.

title: Naama Ashkenazi, David Bloom
description: Naama Ashkenazi and David Andrew Bloom were married last evening. Rabbi David Adelson officiated at Loft Eleven, an event space in New York.

title: Marriage, by God or Government?
description: To the Editor:

title: Savoir Fair
description: As the public face of Art Basel, the worlds biggest trade fair for modern and contemporary art, Samuel Keller is a moving target  at once an organizer, strategist, friend, flack, booster, bouncer, Old World rou and entirely social animal. One minute hell be touring a biennial in Shanghai and the next will find him in Los Angeles, co-sponsoring a dinner for art dealers and collectors with Michael and Eva Chow. Twenty-four hours later, hell arrive in New York to table-hop at the Four Seasons after the opening of the Richard Prince retrospective at the Guggenheim.

title: Letters
description: Recycle the Holly

title: Now Sketching | James Jeans Prada Prints
description: If next season brings more ethereal changelings than can be counted in The Faerie Queene, blame Miuccia Prada. For her enchanting spring collection, the allusive Prada collaborated with the Los Angeles-based illustrator James Jean to create the woodland backdrop for the show, as well as the wallpaper for the Prada Epicenter stores in New York and Los Angeles. Versions of the prints then appeared in a fairylands worth of diaphanous fabrics printed with wood nymphs and flowers. For more examples of his work, go to www.jamesjean.com.

title: India
description: Flipping through INDIA SUBLIME: Princely Palace Hotels of Rajasthan (Rizzoli, $65), its easy to see why the post-backpack foreign set  not to mention Indias own increasingly affluent traveling class  has made this northwestern province a necessary pit stop on the countrys tourist itinerary. Not that any of the establishments in Melba Levicks elegant photographs could remotely be described as a pit. These ancestral properties, converted into luxurious heritage hotels, cater to all manner of aristo fantasies: drifting off to sleep in a giant silver bed, lulled by the sound of your own personal indoor fountain; contemplating the desert horizon from your pillared marble pleasure pavilion in the middle of your vast green lawn, sprouted from imported Kenyan seeds planted in two million donkey loads of dirt; admiring thousands of reflections of your very own self in the glass mosaic ceiling of a maharaja suite, an experience the books writers, Mitchell Shelby Crites and Ameeta Nanji, liken to being inside a huge glittering kaleidoscope.

title: Rock Portraits
description: One of the most striking pictures in ROCK AND ROLL (Abrams, $50), a collection by the music photographer Lynn Goldsmith, captures the symbiotic ties between fans and bands. It is 1978 in Anaheim, Calif., and Mick Jagger is alone on a stadium stage littered with fans shoes. He has a towel draped over his shoulder, but the audience is clearly not through with him yet. Hes looking away from the masses with a dark but unreadable expression on his face: maybe its exhaustion, or failure, or contempt. Or maybe hed just been hit in the face with a flip-flop.

title: Telluride, Colo.: Hongas Lotus Petal
description: Sushi restaurants in the Rocky Mountains are a little like Mexican joints in Minnesota: something about them just seems wrong.

title: Correction: Beckoned by Bivalves
description: An article on Nov. 18 about a culinary pilgrimage to Prince Edward Island for its shellfish referred incompletely to air service from the United States to the province. Although there are no direct flights in winter, there are direct flights in the summer from Detroit on Northwest and from Boston on Delta.

title: San Francisco Fleet Is All Biodiesel
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 30  Claiming it now has the largest green fleet in the nation, the city of San Francisco this week completed a yearlong project to convert its entire array of diesel vehicles  from ambulances to street sweepers  to biodiesel, a clean-burning and renewable fuel that holds promise for helping to reduce greenhouse gases.

title: Editors Cut
description: Ahh, the lure of the madman  the harrowed, sinewy figure with glowing eyes who approaches out of the shadows, burning to communicate his incommunicable truth. Think of Jack Nicholson in The Shining with his wild stare and lurking ax: Heeeeeeres Johnny! When such a person nears, do you step back? Do you linger, frozen in terror, compelled by his mesmeric gaze? Or do you, like Vikar, the cinautistic protagonist of Steve Ericksons latest novel, Zeroville, regard him quizzically, without fear, thinking only, I dont understand comedies?

title: Campaign for Sale
description: The sticker price for next years presidential and Congressional elections is rocketing toward $5 billion, shocking even political professionals who figure the ante in the opening Iowa round may cost out at $300 per caucusgoer. When you consider that the votes taken at those caucuses actually have no direct effect on who is nominated by either party, the cost should be ludicrous by the laws of economics, never mind politics.

title: Brooklyn, the Acropolis
description: Brooklyn, the Acropolis

title: Art vs. Life
description: Why Pay Six Figures for a Photo?

title: 400 Umbrellas That Spell Park Slope
description: THE line that snaked back from the cash registers at Tarzian Hardware on Seventh Avenue in Park Slope on a rainy Monday afternoon moved briskly enough, so most customers probably missed the plastic garbage can next to the counter by the front door. It wasnt raining very hard, either, or else they might have paid more attention to the contents of the can: a little yellow foldable umbrella, free for the taking.

title: A Righteous Recipe for Longevity
description: With bullets whizzing over his head in the Battle of the Bulge, Daniel Bukantz dug his foxhole and hunkered down because, as he freely admits, I was scared.

title: The Dealers Show Their Cards
description: The dealers recent vote to unionize at Foxwoods Resort Casino is potentially momentous for Connecticut. Dealers number 3,000 out of more than 10,000 employees at the casino, which the Mashantucket Pequot tribe opened in 1992. The casino, along with the nearby Mohegan Sun, run by the Mohegan tribe, are among the largest in the world. Although the two tribes employ more than 20,000 workers, none are unionized.

title: Stories Conflict, but Miles Says Hell Stay at L.S.U.
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 1  Les Miles barged in front of a microphone Saturday for an impromptu news conference, saying he was the Louisiana State coach and would be the L.S.U. coach, in response to a report that he had agreed to become the coach at Michigan.

title: The Kids Are All Right
description: To the Editor:

title: Political Cartoons
description: Tom Lehrer once remarked that political satire became obsolete when Henry Kissinger won the Nobel Peace Prize. He didnt know the half of it; in 2004, a little more than 30 years later, the Medal of Freedom, Americas highest civilian honor, was awarded to the major architects of the Iraq disaster, George Tenet, Tommy Franks and L. Paul Bremer. Yet far from being obsolete, political satire thrives, especially late nights on Comedy Central.

title: A Theatrical Work to Do Good Works
description: JOEL EHRLICH hated to admit it, but the Broadway stagehands strike may have worked to his advantage.

title: Jana Chapman Christopher Gates
description: Jana Michelle Chapman, the daughter of Karen Chapman and Jeff M. Chapman of Turlock, Calif., was married yesterday to Christopher Stanley Gates, a son of Sandy Gates and John V. Gates of New Providence, N.J. The Rev. Mark Robinson, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the Manhattan Penthouse, an event space in New York.

title: Travel
description: "Whereas the term adventurer suggests a passion for new frontiers, Alexandra Lapierre observes in the coffee-table book shes written with Christel Mouchard, WOMEN TRAVELERS: A Century of Trailblazing Adventures, 1850-1950 (Flammarion, $45), the term adventuress connotes ambitiousness, intrigue, mercenary sex. But the authors of six recent travel books  all men  suggest otherwise. These writers and their books traffic in ambitiousness, intrigue and mercenary sex. Could they be adventuresses too?

title: Robo Love
description: A few months ago I wrote a magazine article about scientists who are building robots capable of a rudimentary form of sociability. As part of my research, I spent a few days at the humanoid robotics laboratory at M.I.T. And I admit: I developed a little crush on one of the robots. The object of my affection was Domo, a man-size machine with a buff torso and big blue eyes, a cross between He-Man and the Chrysler Building; when it gripped my hand in its strong rubbery pincers I felt a kind of thrill. So I was primed for the basic premise of David Levys provocative new book, Love and Sex With Robots: that there will soon come a day when people fall in love with robots and want them for companions, friends, love objects and possibly even partners for sex and marriage.

title: NFL Matchup
description: BENGALS at STEELERS

title: Correction: A Time to Rethink AIDSs Grip
description: An article last week about the future of the AIDS epidemic misidentified the antibiotics that kill Yersinia pestis, the microbe that was one of the causes of the Black Death. Streptomycin, doxycycline and chloramphenicol are generally used against the bacterium, not penicillin. The article also misstated the percentage of AIDS sufferers in low- and middle-income countries who receive antiretroviral drugs. It is estimated that close to a third or more of those who need the drugs get them; not one-tenth.

title: Though Caucuses Loom, Democrats Tone It Down
description: DES MOINES, Dec. 1  Markedly shifting their tone of recent weeks, the Democratic presidential candidates had a largely friendly exchange Saturday night at a debate devoted to black and Hispanic interests, though they expressed some differences over Cuba, drug sentencing and health care.

title: Youre on the List
description: If youre an art-world heavy, only an original work can truly express seasons greetings. Its a tradition that started with Robert Indianas iconic Love sculpture, originally designed in 1965 as a holiday card for the Museum of Modern Art. If youre not on Peter Nortons list, however, try to get on these.

title: Dusting Off the Shelves of Hellenic Kitchen
description: IN the 1940s and 50s, the streets of Hells Kitchen were sprinkled with Greek businesses, so much so that the neighborhoods newsstands carried no fewer than three Greek-American dailies. Today, about all that remains of Manhattans Hellenic outpost is a spanakopita bakery, a restaurant, a grocery and a little collection of Greek books and artifacts in a dusty antique store at Ninth Avenue and West 43rd Street.

title: The Oligarchettes
description: The last Venice Biennale had its fair share of fabulous parties: the Gucci shindig at the Palazzo Grassi, the Scissor Sisters concert at the Lido, Franois Pinaults private dinner for Madonna, Elton et al. on San Giorgio Maggiore. But there was one especially lavish bash at the Hotel Cipriani that boasted not only the crooning of Paolo Conte, Italys Perry Como, but also a flashbulb-popping cameo from the noted art lover Naomi Campbell. It was thrown by the Moscow collector Stella Kesaeva to spotlight her foundations show, Ruin Russia. But Kesaeva threw a fit before she threw her caviar-accented party, more a face-saving gesture designed to be a spoiler as much as a stand-alone good time.

title: Food of Lands Touched by the Mediterranean
description: OF several dishes that stand out at Tapastre (pronounced tapestry), two are stellar.

title: Resorts Prepare for a Future Without Skis
description: THE sun was glaring down on the Swiss Alps. Bronzed 30-somethings in designer sunglasses and tight T-shirts were draped over extra-large lounge chairs that lined the deck. Euro-pop music played from multiple speakers as fetching young waiters served expensive bottles of Champagne and cheese plates. It might have been August at a Nikki Beach Club  except for the splotches of snow, mountain vistas and overworked snow machines.

title: The Originals
description: Provocateurs at heart, the artists featured here are no less stimulating when it comes to style. For some, the way they dress cannot be separated from their work; for others, its an independent vehicle for expression, one piece in a larger project of reflecting and interpreting the world around them. Untouched by stylists and fashion freebies, these Originals know only one way to get dressed: their own.

title: Now, a Nordic Trail the Length of Vermont
description: The Catamount Trail (www.catamounttrail.org), a 300-mile cross-country ski trail that traverses the length of Vermont  from the Massachusetts to the Canadian border  is now complete. In October, volunteers cleared and marked its final four and a half miles, in the Green Mountain National Forest, which makes up 80 miles of the trail. A combination of backcountry and groomed cross-country trails, snowmobile paths and old logging roads, the trail is divided into 31 sections, each of which can be skied separately and each of which has its own volunteer trail chief. It crosses both public land (about 135 miles) and private land, through arrangements with more than 200 landowners, many of whom have agreed to conservation easements that have permanently protected their portions of the trail.

title: Youngest McEnroe Sets Quieter Tone for Davis Cup
description: Portland, Ore.

title: For the 2008 Race, Google Is a Crucial Constituency
description: LAST century, General Motors assembly plants were a regular stop on the itineraries of presidential candidates. This election cycle, Google headquarters in Mountain View, Calif., has become a favorite destination.

title: To Reduce the Sewage in the Gowanus Canal (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters: Croatian Shellfish
description: To the Editor: Regarding Frank Brunis article Beckoned by Bivalves (Nov. 18), about his pilgrimage to Prince Edward Island for oysters and mussels:

title: An Imperfect Solution
description: IT was Jon Werbergs long commute that made him and his girlfriend, Helene Mattera, impatient to leave their apartment in Pelham Bay, the Bronx.

title: Art-Book Smarts
description: In their previous incarnation as Coromandel Express, the Parisian publishers Alexis Fabry and Olivier Andreotti put the edge back in the illustrated book. Beginning in 1996, their limited-edition tomes became a sort of passage oblig for artists, writers and designers. Vik Muniz, the Bouroullec brothers, William Klein and Martin Amis all obliged, and the Paris concept store Colette devoted windows to their works not once but twice.

title: Art by Writers
description: Imagine a favorite work of literature. Now imagine it unpinned from words. What is left? Anything? To what extent do works of art arise from the particular mediums of which they are composed, and to what extent are they molded from the primordial, formless soup of inspiration? Could a sonnet be a ballet? Could a novel find life as a melody, or a collage? These are some of the existential questions implicitly raised by Donald Friedmans book THE WRITERS BRUSH: Paintings, Drawings, and Sculpture by Writers (Mid-List Press, $40).

title: Correction: On the Tequila Trail in the Place Where Its Made
description: A picture on Nov. 18 with the Comings & Goings column was published in error. The photograph accompanying a report on a package offered by the Presidente InterContinental Hotel Guadalajara in Mexico was of the Casa Herradura, a distillery near Guadalajara; it was not of Mundo Cuervo, another distillery, which is included in the hotels tour package.

title: The Seer
description: When it came to building her personal collection, the legendary art dealer Ileana Sonnabend said she relied on a time-tested method. For years, after a show, Id buy what nobody else wanted, she once told an interviewer. They were always the most difficult pieces, but in the end they became the strongest.

title: Tahira Williams and James Copland IV
description: Tahira Aisha Williams and James Reuben Copland IV were married yesterday at Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in Manhattan. The Rev. Paul T. Rock, an associate pastor of the church, performed the ceremony.

title: Made in Japan
description: The artist Takashi Murakami is about much more than Louis Vuitton bags. This month, he is exporting his six-year-old art fair, Geisai, from Tokyo to Miami. Fresh on the heels of his Los Angeles museum show, Murakami is sponsoring and underwriting a satellite outpost inside the Pulse fair showcasing a clutch of gallery-less artists you wont see at Art Basel Miami Beach. He is tweaking the free-for-all flea market setup of the Tokyo fair: instead of 1,000 or so ad hoc participants selling work, Geisai Miami will have 20 jury-selected artists culled from thousands of online applicants who hope to become the next Shiro-A, a group that made its debut at Geisai No. 7 in 2005, then quickly bagged a spot at the Venice Biennale. Id like Geisai to be an opportunity for artists who are rather on the shy, quirky, geeky side, he said through a translator. Its an opportunity to pick up artists who arent marketable. No doubt Marc Jacobs will be prowling the aisles. Dec. 5 to 9; go to www.geisai.us.

title: The Good Fight
description: Trenton

title: Yahoo Betrays Free Speech
description: For a company that ostensibly believes in the Internets liberating power, Yahoo has a gallingly backward understanding of the value of free expression.

title: Two Workers Found Dead Inside Empty Chemical Vat
description: LINDEN, N.J., Dec. 1  Two workers were found dead Saturday afternoon in an empty 20,000-gallon chemical vat at an industrial dry cleaning plant here, the Linden police said.

title: Fitting End to a Tumultuous Season
description: MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Dec. 1 West Virginia Coach Rich Rodriguez stood before reporters Saturday night with a dazed look and cracked voice.

title: Study Puts Price Tag on Delays at Airports
description: The growing number of delayed flights at Kennedy International Airport and the regions other major airports has cost passengers nearly $200 million in lost productivity this year, according to a report to be released today by the New York City comptrollers office.

title: In a Progressive State, a City Where Gay Life Hangs by a Thread
description: NEWARK, Nov. 30  To live in Newark often means grappling with unrelenting poverty, the anesthetizing lure of drugs, murderous gangs, a lack of decent jobs.

title: My Sorority Pledge? I Swore Off Sisterhood
description: MY lifes greatest sorrow stems from my inability to feel close to other women. At 41, Ive cautiously cultivated a few cherished female friendships. But generally I feel a kind of skittish distrust and discomfort when dealing with most women, particularly women in packs.

title: Letters: The Stomach-Surgery Conundrum
description: In their excellent article about bariatric surgery, Stephen J. Dubner and Steven D. Levitt (Freakonomics, Nov. 18) mention that the procedure often produces complications  physiological ones, to be sure, but also perhaps psychological ones. As a psychiatrist, I have no doubt that a morbidly obese patient without other medical cause for obesity (i.e., thyroid disease) already has a severe psychiatric problem. Without treating the compulsion that underlies such behavior, it is no wonder that patients who have surgery but no psychiatric treatment may develop new psychiatric symptoms, like gambling, compulsive shopping and alcoholism.

title: Stephanie Stegich, Adam Treanor
description: Stephanie Anne Stegich was married yesterday to Adam Jude Treanor. The Rev. Thomason Newcomb, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of St. James the Less in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Talks Fail to Find Unity in Belgium
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 1 (Reuters)  Belgium plunged deeper into political uncertainty on Saturday when the would-be prime minister, Yves Leterme, abandoned his efforts to form a four-party center-right government after the collapse of marathon talks.

title: Romneys Words Testify to Threat From Huckabee
description: WEST DES MOINES, Iowa, Dec. 1  If there was any doubt that Mitt Romneys presidential campaign was seriously concerned about the threat posed to them by Mike Huckabee in Iowa, Mr. Romneys latest campaign swing through the state erased that.

title: Ashcan School
description: Of the countless attempts by visual artists to catch New York City on the fly, few have been as loving or warmly vibrant as those of the painter John Sloan. A native Pennsylvanian, Sloan (1871-1951) relocated from Philadelphia to New York in 1904, and in the next 15 years he took the sidewalks of his adopted city as his muse. A tireless walker, he did not paint outdoors but stored impressions in his mind to recreate later in the studio. He was particularly attracted to the area he had settled in, Chelsea, by Sixth Avenue and West 23rd Street, then a rather honky-tonk stretch with dance halls, movie houses and burlesque stages, which, he wrote, had a Coney Island quality in 1907.

title: The Dollar Is Falling, and Thats Good News
description: ANXIETY about the dollar continues to spread. The falling greenback is often seen as a sign of an impending recession or the fall of the United States from global leadership. A low dollar simply looks bad. We are, after all, used to judging ourselves against others  comparing our salaries with the earnings of our peers, and our homes with those of our neighbors. Were used to thinking it is a big advantage to stand at the top of a numerical list.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Page 32 of The Times Magazine today, about the Russian soprano Anna Netrebko, misstates the date of a concert she performed at Carnegie Hall. It was in May 2007, not June. (Go to Article)

title: Shades of Capote
description: Truman Capote ended as he began, writing sketches and mood pieces, but the later versions were a little skimpier and less promising than the earlier ones. Thats the sad conclusion to be drawn from Portraits and Observations, a collection of some 42 pieces spanning his career. The first, a remarkably stylish and assured autobiographical sketch about living in New Orleans, was written in 1946, when Capote was in his early 20s, working on his own after a brief stint as an editorial assistant at The New Yorker. (What is that? Harold Ross is reported to have said on first glimpsing the magazines new hire, and he fired him not long after.) Capote was working on the last piece in the collection, a recollection of meeting Willa Cather back in the early 40s, on the day before he died, in August 1984.

title: Is Hello Kitty Turning Feral?
description: HER image can be found on everything from sandwich makers to Swarovski crystal-encrusted laptops.

title: Correction: Review of For Love of Politics
description: A picture caption on Nov. 18 with a review of For Love of Politics, a book about Bill and Hillary Clinton by Sally Bedell Smith, misstated the location where the couple were shown, based on erroneous information from the photo agency. The picture, taken by Robert McNeely, was made in the Capitol building, not the White House.

title: Camera Ready
description: Leicas the first real relationship Ive ever had with a camera. Id always hated Leica men: I thought of them as really macho men who went to India and poor places in the world and thought they knew them without spending any time there. But my close friend Peter Hujar used one. (He used to tell me that if he didnt like the lens, he would take it back to the store and try them until he liked one.) So I got my first Leica in 1990. Since then, Ive dropped them, Ive broken them, Ive had them stolen on the subway, Ive lost them in taxis. When I was working on the Mira Nair film Monsoon Wedding, I fell almost 10 feet into an empty pool. As I was falling, I hallucinated that the Leica was my baby. I held it against my chest and landed with all my weight on my wrist and broke it into a million pieces. But I saved my Leica. Over the years, Ive learned that the lens is a very subjective relationship. The reason I use a Leica is because it actually has a subtext. It depends on what youre photographing, but the lens shows you not just the surface: the levels underneath are revealed. Somebody told me once how optically this was possible. I just thought it was magic.

title: 36 Hours in Park City, Utah
description: IF you haven't visited Park City in several years, brace yourself for discombobulation. Sure, Main Street hasn't gone anywhere, and it's still achingly picturesque under a confectioner's sifting of Utah's famously light snow. That is, when it's not jammed with smoking S.U.V.'s. In the last few years, thanks to several factors  the 2002 Winter Olympics, the Sundance Film Festival, a growing realization among wealthy skiing baby boomers that this former silver-mining town is in Utah but not of Utah  the area is booming so fast as to be nearly unrecognizable. The negatives to this classic New West story include traffic and unbridled second-home development across the mountainsides. But the upside is an infusion of ambitious new hoteliers and chefs in Park City proper, injecting new life and urban sophistication into the city of 7,400 people.

title: Coming Up Roses (and Weeds)
description: Couldnt dance. Couldnt, for all practical purposes, act. Couldnt sing with the kind of nuance we expect of singers today. Was only moderately good-looking early, and later became a bit of a fright. No wonder it takes two biographies to try to put across why Ethel Merman was one of the biggest and most enduring stars Broadway has ever known.

title: The Whole Story
description: Is your grasp of the Aurignacians artistic accomplishments not quite what it used to be? Worried that conversation at the office party will turn (yet again!) to the banganga spiritual mediators of the Congo and their anthropomorphic nkisi nkondi figures? Fear not. 30,000 Years of Art (Phaidon) covers world art history from 28,000 B.C. to today. A thousand works of art  including painting, sculpture, textiles, masks, ceramics and jewelry  are featured on 1,064 pages, putting you on par with even the most assiduous culture vulture. Even if art is not your thing, the tome could come in handy: weighing in at 13 pounds, it readily doubles as an erudite doorstop.

title: Putins Party Wins in Russia, but Leadership Is Still Clouded
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 2  President Vladimir V. Putins party secured a landslide in parliamentary elections on Sunday after a campaign in which the Kremlin persistently hobbled the opposition. Yet while the results represent a triumph for Mr. Putin, they also usher in a new era of political instability for Russia.

title: Let There Be Art
description: The earliest artworks originated in the service of a ritual  first the magical, then the religious kind, the philosopher Walter Benjamin wrote in the 1930s. Western culture changed, as Benjamin put it, when the secular cult of beauty developed during the Renaissance. Once liberated from its religious function, art gradually became its own theology  a negative theology in the form of the idea of pure art, Benjamin believed.

title: Solid Gold
description: All that glitters for the holidays.

title: A Fine Line
description: If all you knew of Kenneth Paul Block were his society portraits and fashion drawings, youd think hed spent his life clinking martinis with Gloria Vanderbilt and wheedling previews out of Yves Saint Laurent. If all you knew were the ascot he knots inside the turned-up collar of a black cotton shirt and the retired cigarette holder and opera cape, youd think he was too fastidious for words (which he is). But that picture of Block  the last in the line of great fashion illustrators; Eric, Ren Bout-Willaumez and Ren Bouch are the others  would not be complete.

title: New Tradition: Eat the Turkey, Then Go Online
description: Black Friday (the day after Thanksgiving) and Cyber Monday (the Monday after Thanksgiving) get all the publicity as busy holiday shopping days. But when it comes to online retail traffic, Thanksgiving itself outperforms both days  and has been the busiest day of the entire holiday season for the last four years, according to Hitwise, an online research firm.

title: A Sip for Aprs-Whatever
description: WE don't do winter sports all that well in Manhattan. Though skating is free in Bryant Park and comes with cool views in Central Park, and diehard snow fiends find ways to cross-country ski, play hockey and snowshoe, few visitors to New York arrive with such sporty ends in mind.

title: Cooking
description: Why are British cookbooks, circa 2007, so much better than American ones? By better I dont mean that they are larger or more comprehensive, that you would necessarily give them to a new bride and groom, or that they are in possession of lustier photographs or crisper layouts or even bolder or more exacting recipes.

title: More Talk of Sharing Services
description: FROM 1995 to 2005, total property taxes in Westchester increased by 67 percent while the countys population grew by less than 5 percent. Numbers like that have led the Tax Foundation, an organization based in Washington that favors lower taxes, to rank Westchester as one of the top three counties with the highest tax burdens in the country.

title: Correction: Review of The Pleasures of the Damned
description: Because of an editing error, a review last Sunday about The Pleasures of the Damned, a poetry collection by Charles Bukowski, misspelled the second word of a Latin phrase meaning we were smoke. It is fuimus fumus, not flumus. (The phrase, a version of a tomb motto, is quoted from Thomas Wolfes Look Homeward, Angel, where it is used to suggest lifes transitory nature.)

title: Grand New Party
description: Holiday party  two words that signal the beginning of a zombielike progression of eggnog and enforced cheer. But perhaps miracles are still possible, as evidenced by the fact that a handful of culinary artists are redefining what it means to eat and to socialize, and not necessarily in that order.

title: Now Serving | Tokyo Treats
description: Get your sugar high with an artsy pedigree. The Omotesando Hills shopping complex in Tokyo is home to S and O (for Sweets and Objects), a gallery and store devoted to artists confections. There are Gumi Girls by Yoshitomo Nara and pumpkin cookies by Yayoi Kusama, who also makes heart-shaped candy dishes filled with marble chocolate. Suck on Fuku Fuku, Ai Yamaguchis gumdrop balls, each with an adorable image of a sweetie pie. And who could be so sour as to not enjoy Ban Chinatsus ceramic elephant full of maple syrup? Get a peek online at www.macmuseumshop.com.

title: Sex, Science and Savings
description: President Bushs veto of Congresss main social spending bill has Democratic leaders looking for places to make trims to satisfy the presidents sudden zeal for fiscal discipline. A small, but sensible, place to begin would be to eliminate the bills $28 million increase for one of Mr. Bushs signature boondoggles  abstinence-only sex education.

title: Nia VonHockman and Christopher Chase
description: Nia Alexandra VonHockman was married yesterday morning to Christopher Raymond Chase at the Church of the Magdalene in Tarrytown, N.Y. The Rev. Joseph Dietz, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Revised Lineup Helps Nets Snap Home Skid
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 1  The Nets have a bad habit they cannot seem to break. They fall behind, then must try to climb back into the game. This time, they got away with it.

description: THERE was a time when being told that I would be spending New Years Eve in Des Moines would have, well, sobered me up in a New York minute.

title: When Bucs Went 0 for the Season
description: Toward the end of the 1976 season, as it became clear the Tampa Bay Buccaneers would not win a single football game, home fans held signs that read, Go for 0! Johnny Carson routinely roasted the expansion Bucs on The Tonight Show. Some even started calling the team the Yuckaneers.

title: L.A.C.M.A. is More
description: When you combine the talent and ambition of an inventive museum director like Michael Govan, a visionary architect like Renzo Piano and a Medici-like board of trustees (including the power philanthropist Eli Broad), youre guaranteed a blockbuster show. Transformation is the continuing expansion and renovation of the Los Angeles County Museum of Art (L.A.C.M.A.). The first part of the three-phase project opens this February. Visitors will pass through Chris Burdens Urban Light installation en route to the new Broad Contemporary Art Museum, which contains works from Broads vast personal collection. From here they can take in historical works by Thomas Eakins and Jacques-Louis David and a cache of ancient art. For a glimpse of even older artifacts, museumgoers can check out the neighboring La Brea Tar Pits.

title: Only Downtrend at Pump: Independent Stations
description: WHEN Bill Hands bought an unbranded gasoline station in Orient on the North Fork 21 years ago, it had three pumps  one for regular, one for premium and one for diesel. It still does.

description: LOS ANGELES

title: Down South, Singing the Indie Blues
description: WHAT shed really like, said the film producer Maggie Renzi, is a big check and a lot of help. So far, getting the help hasnt been a problem. The big check, however, may depend on how well she and her longtime companion, the director John Sayles, can counter all the changes in the independent film business, effect a few of their own and reinvigorate an audience that most movie distributors write off as AARP, if not R.I.P.

description: JUST 24 hours after Hillary Clinton mowed down a skeptical Katie Couric with her certitude that she would win the Democratic nomination  It will be me!  her husband showed exactly how she could lose it.

description: For most baseball fans, the Hall of Fame debate season runs about a month, from the mailing of the ballots in late November to the announcement of the inductees on Jan. 8. But for me and about 54 other aficionados of the sports history, scrutinizing the records of the games great and good has been a nonstop affair for five years.

title: 15 Going on 50
description: It is, I guess, one of the burdens of growing older that you walk around wishing you could talk to people who are gone. Something arises to make you miss the one person who would get the joke, give sage advice or sympathize, but death has thwarted the conversation. These days, if new books are any indication, it seems that were missing Andy Warhol. Even  or particularly  those of us who never knew Warhol in life.

title: A Cloudy Forecast for Commercial Market
description: MANY commercial real estate players may be ready to turn the page on 2007, in light of the continuing credit crisis and weakening economy. But they may not see a major turnaround throughout most of the country during the new year, according to one year-end industry report.

description: When collecting art, Theres more than meets the eye. Or is there? Art investment has its own set of rules, but it all comes back to what you love (and want). Learn the ways of the trade, from buying to restoring. Here, a guide to getting the good stuff.

description: Q. Between work and family, you have little time or energy left for hobbies, like crafts, painting or music. Without them, though, life feels mundane. What can you do about it?

title: Special Packages Whittle Away at Cost of Trips
description: SKI season has barely begun, but now is the time to scope out deals and cost-saving packages. This year, youll find a number of ways to skim dollars off the ever-growing expense of a ski holiday. Online travel agencies like Travelocity frequently tout packages that combine air, accommodations and ski tickets. Ski.com is a place to check for a constantly changing array of packages, and sites for specific ski areas often post special offerings. Here are some current deals at resorts in North America to get your ski trip search started.

title: A Place to Call Home: Preserving Middle-Class New Yorkers
description: Anybody who has tried to rent an apartment in New York City knows how expensive they are. At the same time, most pay packets in the city are not much thicker than they were a few years ago, unless you work and thrive on Wall Street. Gov. Eliot Spitzer and Deborah VanAmerongen, the commissioner of the states housing agency, eased the burden a little last week when they made it harder for the owners of apartments built under the states subsidized Mitchell-Lama program to evict their middle-class tenants.

title: Friending, Ancient or Otherwise
description: THE growing popularity of social networking sites like Facebook, MySpace and Second Life has thrust many of us into a new world where we make friends with people we barely know, scrawl messages on each others walls and project our identities using totem-like visual symbols.

description: Never miss a moment on the global art calendar with the Mrs. John L. Strong Collectors Diary and Directory. Hotel, restaurant, art transport and even gifting tips are included. $495; www.mrsstrong.com.

title: One Stop for Homey or Haute
description: If making dinner has become a chore  or you simply dont have time for it  then Annies Gourmet Kitchen in Westfield, which opened in June, can be a useful stop. Supper is served in three ways: you can take home heat-and-serve entrees, buy frozen meals or, for the ambitious, even assemble dinner in Annies on-site kitchen from already-prepped ingredients.

After all, you cant properly assess the merits and flaws of a drama before the curtain has come down. description: You have been working a lot: in the next few months, you are starring in the historical drama The Other Boleyn Girl and in My Blueberry Nights, which is a road-trip movie directed by Wong Kar-Wai. It was busy last year. I just had my dream job: for the Discovery Channel, I went into the jungle in Rwanda with the mountain gorillas. My mom came, too  I saw a whole new side of her. The silverback gorillas are massive  400 pounds  and they have 98 percent of the same DNA as humans, and it shows. They can be a little soap opera-ish in their behavior. The baby gorillas would start crawling toward our cameras. They thought the cameras were other monkeys.

description: When you think of Monty Pythons classic Ministry of Silly Walks sketch  and you really should, as often as possible  the first image that comes to mind is almost certainly John Cleese contorting his long legs in various outrageous ways. But take another look (its easy to find on YouTube) and pay particular attention to Cleeses interaction with the meek young man in search of a government grant whose walk, alas, is not particularly silly. Its the heart of the routine, and its a perfect example of Michael Palin at his most endearingly Palinesque.

But of the three, arguing that Buchanan should be up there on Mount Rushmore is by far the most fun, because if youre going to be a revisionist, you might as well swing for the fences.

description: PARIS, Dec. 1  In a sign that Iran has hardened its position on its nuclear program, its new nuclear negotiator said in talks in London on Friday that all proposals made in past negotiations were irrelevant and that further discussion of a curb on Irans uranium enrichment was unnecessary, senior officials briefed on the meeting said.

title: The Greeks
description: The 21 archaeologists who have contributed essays to GREAT MOMENTS IN GREEK ARCHAEOLOGY (J. Paul Getty Museum, $75) would have us know that their calling is much more than the unearthing of beautiful objects for the delight of public display. But the photographers and designers who have assembled this opulent large-format volume  to say nothing of the artistic genius of the ancient Greeks themselves  threaten to undermine this crucial scientific point at nearly every turn. For a generous share of the hundreds of color photographs that overflow its pages exhibit uncontested masterpieces of Greek art in all their glory. Some, just to scratch the lustrous surface, are as familiar as the bronze charioteer from Delphi or the Victory of Samothrace, which now stands atop the Daru staircase in the Louvre. Other objects amid the profusion of wall paintings, sculptures, vases, mosaics, furniture and metalworks on display here are less instantly recognizable but scarcely less breathtaking. These ancient treasures, together with historic photographs of the major excavations, aerial panoramas of splendid sites, old watercolors and lithographs, and 19th-century architectural renderings, are enough to leave a deep impression on anyone with a drop of philhellenic blood.

title: Fashion
description: Lets start, fashion lovers, with a quiz. When you hear the word bar, your first thought is of: (a) Leonardo DiCaprios supermodel girlfriend, Bar Refaeli; (b) that place you stumble into when youve been wearing your teetering Yves Saint Laurent platforms for too long and only alcohol will dull the pain; or (c) the wasp-waisted skirt-suit that, in 1947, formed part of Christian Diors trailblazing New Look in womens clothing. Obviously, there is a time and place for both (a) and (b). But those who answered (c) score bonus points for knowing that with confections like the Bar suit, Dior helped make high fashion what it is today: at once a bonanza of glossy worldwide press coverage and an artful, gloriously improbable celebration of the female form.
