title: Poetry of Protest
description: In my native Iran, choosing the wrong heroes can have frightening consequences. I chose my first hero (not counting my adored father) a decade ago when I was a university student in Tehran, studying Spanish. My teacher put before us a book of verse by the poet Federico Garca Lorca, who was killed by nationalist soldiers at the outbreak of the Spanish Civil War. Even reading his poems of dire prediction, I was thrilled by his bravery, facing life and its torments with no balm other than words. I remember the experience of reading one of his poems, The Weeping. A sympathy for my fellow men and women, no more than a seed before I read it, grew shoots above the soil by the time I finished.

Often the stars of their own pieces, the pair have explored taboo subject matter like bodily fluids and skinhead subcultures in their photography and performance art. (An image from their 2005 series Ginkgo Pictures shows them morphing into a sort of two-headed monster.) A retrospective of their work was shown this year at the Tate Modern and is making its way to the Brooklyn Museum in October 2008. Much like their sartorial habits, their work appears timeless.

title: Slater Bradley | Culture Vulture
description: As a child growing up in San Francisco, the multimedia artist Slater Bradley was obsessed with whom he wanted to be. I think its something we all do when were really young, he says. This search for identity still lingers in his work. Doppelgnger Trilogy, his 2004 lo-fi video series, showed his veritable double, Benjamin Brock, dressed as cultural icons from Bradleys youth like Kurt Cobain and Michael Jackson. I think the Doppelgnger piece was practically begging for YouTube to exist, Bradley says. He is now interested in moving toward sculpture but is aware that his alter ego wont stop haunting him anytime soon: I have had about 29 solo shows, but people mostly know me by that piece.

title: Grayson Perry | Subversive
description: Its not news that Grayson Perry loves to wear a frock. Im a transvestite, says Perry, who won the Turner Prize in 2003. It comes with the territory. But dont expect this self-described art tranny to be impressed by designer labels. He prefers to have his wardrobe custom-made. (For a summer course he taught at Central St. Martins, the students had five weeks to make him an outfit; he bought the ones he liked the best.) Perry, whose work ranges from ceramics to graphic novels, is currently designing a fabric for the English company Liberty; curating a show for the Arts Council England, Unpopular Culture; and crafting a medal for the British Museum that he promises will be anything but noble. Despite his own penchant for baby-doll dresses and ruffled socks, he says: I am terribly sick of the infantilization of everyday life. Whatever happened to things being subversive, slow and complex?

title: A Normal Family
description: It happened again  this time before Halloween  as we reached the cashier's station at The Party Store.  The clerk, who must have been about 18, took a long look at my daughters.  "Are they yours?" she asked.  "Yes," I said tersely, hoping my tone would dissuade further inquiry.  It didn't.  "Are they adopted?" she asked.  Now I was ready to give her a blast, a lecture about manners and boundaries.  "Yes, they are  "  But the young woman cut me off, interrupting with a perky, "I'm adopted, too!"  Oh. Um, never mind.  In the last year or so, I've noticed that I have these kinds of conversations more and more. People who once would have intruded with a boorish question seem to have been replaced by others who want to share their own abiding connection to adoption. They were adopted themselves. Or they're in the process of adopting  a "waiting family." Or their grown son or daughter is on his or her way back from overseas, about to make them a grandparent.  In fact it seems to me  dare I say it?  that adoption is becoming normal. Or least more normalized. Sure, it's taken 60-some years. But attitudes are changing. And that's not my imagination.  Ten years ago, 58 percent of Americans had a family member or close friend who had adopted a child, were adopted themselves, or had placed a child for adoption, according to a national survey by the Evan B. Donaldson Adoption Institute in New York. By 2002, that figure had risen to 63 percent. It's surely higher now.  The same studies found that the percentage of Americans who have seriously considered adopting a child rose from 36 percent to 39 percent  a 3 percent increase that's statistically insignificant, but which the institute believes may mark the start of a permanent change in the way people think about how to build their families.  Adoption is routinely in the news these days, and not just because Brangelina and Madonna have new children. The coverage reflects the sheer number of people who are adopting, particularly from overseas, and the way in which each individual adoption radiates outward, from nuclear family to extended family to friends and co-workers. In the last 15 years, nearly 62,000 children have arrived from China alone. Another 76,000 have come from Russia and Guatemala. Today more are coming from African nations like Ethiopia.  Most of those families couldn't hide their adoptions if they wanted to  and they don't. That's a big change from the 1950s and 1960s, when adoption was a secret so shameful it had to be kept even from the child.  When that clerk spoke up at The Party Store, my daughters paid no attention. Sure, Jin Yu, 7, was busy admiring her High School Musical cheerleader costume. Zhao Gu, 4, had her arms wrapped around her Dorothy of Oz dress, perhaps contemplating the most efficient means to dispose of unwanted witches. But it was more than that. Both of them know adoption as a common word in their household and a routine fact of their lives.  Four adopted children live on our street. Jin Yu's best friend is adopted. So is a boy in her first-grade class. And a teacher at her school. None see it as extraordinary. Which is not to say things are perfect.  Adoptive Families magazine recently carried the story of a Florida woman who was asked to prove that she was her daughter's mother before hospital personnel would treat the child. It's impossible to conceive of a biological parent being asked to verify the same relationship. And every adoptive parent I know has endured frustrations like my own: The woman who approaches our group at a restaurant, demanding to know who among our girls are the "real" children. The relative who laments that I never had "children of my own," oblivious to the little girls beside me. The strangers who feel free to ask why my wife and I adopted and how much it cost  as if the doctors and nurses who deliver babies work for free.  I wonder how these folks would feel if I turned the tables, if I were to tap them on the shoulder while they and their child waited in line for a movie or a seat at a restaurant. "Hey, was your daughter born by in-vitro? She looks in-vitro to me. Am I right or am I right?"  Last summer we were on vacation in Germany when Jin Yu tugged on my arm.  "Dad," she said, "those boys keep pointing at me. Why are they pointing at me?"  I knew why. But I didn't want to say. Because I hated that the rudeness of strangers should compel me to explain to my daughter  again  that some people see our family as different. So I didn't respond at first, and in that moment's pause Jin Yu answered her own question with the very words her father should have offered:  "It's not polite to point," she said.  No, it's not.  It's encounters like that one that make me brace for wounding questions  more and more to find that I needn't have worried. Not long ago, I was leading Zhao Gu along a beach at the Jersey shore.  "Excuse me," a woman said from her seat on a towel, "is your daughter from China?"  "Yes, she is," I said  and kept walking.  But in a moment the woman was on her feet, trying to catch up with me in the sand.  "We're a waiting family!" she called.  Oh. Why didn't you say so?

title: After Six Decades, a Jane Bowles Puppet Play Takes Flight
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J., Nov. 30  Bill T. Joness new Quarreling Pair may surprise those familiar with his work over the last 20 years. There are no overarching social themes or emotions. The tone is relaxed and instinctual. Based on a short play by Jane Bowles, A Quarreling Pair does not look at our time or the cultural history that shaped it. Instead, Mr. Jones and his scenic designer, Bjorn G. Amelan, delve into the central relationship and tone of this odd little four-page puppet play and then move through it, as through a magic mirror, into a complex, dreamlike world in which their imaginations run playfully, riotously wild.

title: Three Men Shot
description: A man was killed and two were wounded in a shooting in St. Albans early yesterday, the police said. The men were shot shortly before 5 a.m. at Baisley and Merrick Boulevards, the police said. The officers who responded to a call of gunshots fired found one man, David Alston, 22, dead at the scene. Mr. Alston, of 118th Avenue in Jamaica, was shot once in the head, the police said. The wounded men were Jonathan Stephens, 24, who was shot twice in the back, and Devon Robinson, 21, who was shot in the stomach, the police said. Both men live in Jamaica, according to the police. Mr. Stephens was in stable condition at Mary Immaculate Hospital, and Mr. Robinson was at Jamaica Hospital Medical Center, the police said. Ronald Alston, 50, an uncle of the dead man, said the family had no details on what led to the shooting. We want to pray for the killers, and we hope they find the strength to turn themselves in, he said. Not only did they take a life, they destroyed a family.

title: European Academy Honors Romanian Film
description: The 1,800-member European Film Academy, in 20th anniversary ceremonies in Berlin on Saturday, awarded its prize for the years best film to 4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days, which captured the Palme dOr at the Cannes Film Festival in May, Reuters reported. The film, by Cristian Mungiu, above, of Romania, who also won the prize for best director, tells of two student friends who are ruthlessly exploited when one seeks an illegal abortion. The accolade for best actress went to Helen Mirren for her Oscar-winning performance in The Queen, and the prize for best actor was awarded to Sasson Gabai of Israel for The Bands Visit, a comedy about a small Egyptian police band that finds itself in Israel as part of an awkward goodwill exchange. The Peoples Choice Award was won by the Italian director Giuseppe Tornatore for La Sconosciuta (The Unknown).

The song  which enjoyed brief success in the United States in 1955 and 1970  took last place in a test of 579 Christmas recordings, performed by Edison Media Research. Edison played the songs for a national sample of 200 women aged 30 to 49, recruited via e-mail, who said that they either liked or loved Christmas music.

title: Mayor Backs Judges Raises
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday in his radio address that he supported a proposal to increase the salaries of New York State judges. The Legislature is expected to consider the increase in a special session this month. The judges last received a raise in 1999. Mr. Bloomberg called an increase long overdue, according to a transcript provided by his office. Judges work for the public full time, all year round, he said. For that, they deserve not only our respect but also fair and just compensation.

title: Lottery Numbers
Mozart Manuscript Put Up for Auction
description: A single manuscript sheet from one of Mozarts greatest works, found in a private collection in England, is to be sold at auction tomorrow at Sothebys in London. The sheet covers the cadenza for the first movement of the Sinfonia Concertante in E flat for Violin, Viola and Orchestra, a 1779 masterwork that lifted the composer into the ranks of the great at the age of 23, The Times of London reported. The sheet is one of only two surviving leaves from the original score. On its reverse side it also carries, in Mozarts hand, the parts for two horns for two unidentified pieces. Simon Maguire, the senior specialist in Sothebys music department, said: What makes the survival of this sheet particularly noteworthy is the fact that cadenzas are perhaps the least likely part of any musical piece ever to be written down. Cadenzas were usually improvised, so there was no need for written guidance from composers. In this instance, because the concerto is a work for two instruments, Mozart worked it out in advance and wrote it out separately to avoid the two instruments improvising independently and clashing. The sheet is expected to sell for more than the estimate of $205,000.

title: Page From Romance by Napoleon Is Sold
description: A single, messily handwritten page from a short unpublished 1795 novel based on the authors brief romance with the sister of his brothers wife sold yesterday for $35,400 at auction at Fontainebleau, outside Paris, The Associated Press reported. The author of the work, Clisson and Eugnie, was Napoleon Bonaparte, who wrote it when he was a 26-year-old general. The 22-page novel was never published in Napoleons lifetime, and the page, thanks to Napoleons sloppy penmanship, was long believed to be from a text about a historical figure named Clissot. The Osenat auction house did not disclose the identity of the buyer of the page, which came from the private collection of a French family.

Second place went for a second straight weekend to This Christmas (distributed by Sony/Screen Gems), a family tale with Delroy Lindo and Chris Brown that took in $8.4 million. Beowulf (Paramount), at No. 3, gathered $7.8 million. The weekends sole newcomer to finish in the Top 5 was the medical thriller Awake (MGM). title: Officer Hurt on Expressway

Officer Gennaro Ferraro was parked on the shoulder of the expressway in Plainview, near Exit 48, when the patrol car was struck from behind about 5:44 a.m., the police said. Officer Ferraro suffered head and back injuries, and the driver and passenger of the car that struck the police officers vehicle were also injured, the police said. All three were taken to Nassau University Medical Center, where Officer Ferraro was in intensive care. The driver, who was identified as Paul V. title: Eldercare, an Inevitable Work/Life Issue

I have a 93-year-old grandmother who lives a remarkably independent life. She lives in and cares for her own home, prepares her own meals and does most of her own food shopping. Until two years ago, when she gracefully agreed not to use her car anymore, she also drove. What she wants and needs most is company, and she never fails to recognize how busy all of us young people around her are even as my mother, my two cousins and I do our best to visit each week. We are the lucky ones. My grandmother is relatively healthy and autonomous, and we are able to enjoy the time we spend with her. I also have a flexible working life, so if I visit her on a Tuesday, I can work on a Saturday to make up for it.

title: Brooks Brothers Migrates to the West
description: The new Brooks Brothers store on Broadway at 65th Street. (Photo: David W. Dunlap/The New York Times) Slide Show: Brooks Brothers on Broadway Even in an era of rampant brand extension, there is something incongruous about the sight of a Brooks Brothers store at Broadway and 65th Street, which was still West Side Story territory in the days when Brooks was outfitting John F. Kennedy in sack suits.  You could say, cynically, that this is merely a sign that the venerable clothier is now no more than a Banana Republic chain for the next-higher income bracket. Or you could say that Brooks Brothers is really returning to its roots, since it conducted business on Broadway from 1858 to 1915, moving steadily uptown all the while.  Lou Amendola, the chief merchandising officer for Brooks Brothers, can look at a map of Manhattan and see the 9,500-square-foot Lincoln Square branch, which formally opened today, as following naturally in a northwesterly migratory pattern going back to 1818 and the original store at Catharine and Cherry Streets.  Brooks Brothers first appearance on Broadway was at the corner of Grand Street. Abraham Lincoln shopped here. (What other customer would have needed an overcoat for his second inauguration with a quilted lining embellished by an embroidered eagle holding a One Country, One Destiny pennant in its beak?) The store then moved briefly to Union Square.  At 670 Broadway, on the corner of Bond Street, Brooks opened its next headquarters  a Victorian confection designed by George E. Harney. Externally it is an ornament to the street, The New York Times declared on April 11, 1874, and its internal arrangements are of the most perfect kind. The building is still an ornament in NoHo. Recent retail tenants have included the Top Tomato produce store and the Wet Seal clothing store.  Brooks moved up Broadway to 22nd Street in 1884. Here, it introduced Americans to the button-down polo collar shirt, the polo coat, the Shetland sweater and the silk Foulard necktie. Brooks moved to its current flagship, at Madison Avenue and 44th Street, in 1915. Though much altered, the 22nd Street building still stands. If you visit Domain Home Fashions today, you can still see the great cast-iron columns of the main selling floor, where mens suits were once piled high. (Thats how they displayed them, in piles, turned inside out so customers could see the fine linings.)  Are there more neighborhood Brooks Brothers to come? The potential is definitely there, Mr. Amendola said through a spokesman. The challenge, he added, is finding the right space to accommodate a full range of the stores offerings.  If the company is thinking about NoHo, it is worth noting that there is an 11,250-square-foot corner storefront now available. At 670 Broadway, on the corner of Bond Street.
