In happier news for the Bucs, Grudens decision to go for it on fourth down sealed the deal against the Saints.

title: Latest Strike Casualty: Press Tour?
description: The biannual Television Critics Association press tour, a staple of the television beat for writers and critics, will likely not be held in January as originally scheduled.

title: The Funny Side of Paralysis
description: The Diving Bell and the Butterfly, Julian Schnabels acclaimed adaptation of the late Jean-Dominique Baubys memoir of the same name, got its first American screening back in September, at the New York film Festival. The Baguette had the foresight to attend a Q&A with the director, where she learned that even Mr. Schnabels wife hadnt wanted him to make a movie about a man who is entombed in his own body, able only to blink one eye.

title: News Headlines
description: Articles from the world of real estate:

title: Unequal Treatment at the State Department
description: Retirement ceremonies for career American diplomats tend to be predictable, decorous affairs reflecting the skills of envoys who have spent years perfecting the fine art of defending often indefensible Washington policies abroad. But when Michael Guest, a former ambassador to Romania, closed out his quarter-century career recently he did what few people do  displayed uncommon courage and threw a rhetorical hand-grenade into his own party.

title: More Climate Fakery
description: In the timeless category of, If its too good to be true, it probably isnt, a remarkably sophisticated, but fake, news release and Web link went out to the media this morning proclaiming that the Climate Action Partnership - a whos who of big corporations, from Alcan to Xerox  had pledged essentially to turn off their emissions in the next 50 years (a 90 percent cut by 2050). They also supposedly called for an immediate freeze on new construction of coal-burning power plants.

title: Blank Checks Keep Getting Bigger
description: The private equity industry may be in hibernation, but another brand of buyout vehicle  known as the special-purpose acquisition company  is in overdrive.

title: Here Comes the World Junior Championship
description: This is one of our favorite times of year because the World Junior Championship starts the end of the month (Dec. 26 through Jan. 5 in the Czech Republic this year). The W.J.C. is an amazing showcase for the next crop of stars. This is when images of the players themselves fuse onto the one-dimensional listings of the Central Scouting rankings of prospects.

title: City Arms Police Recruits With iPods for Their Exams
description: The penetration of mandatory iPods in secondary and higher education has been growing. Duke University has issued the music players to incoming freshmen. The Brearley School, a private school for girls in Manhattan, has required iPods for homework and classroom assignments. And the school district in Union City, N.J., has issued 300 iPods to bilingual students with limited English skills to improve their English vocabulary and grammar.

title: Another Dubious Fashion Alliance
description: The news announcing Victoria Beckham as the latest celebrity to flog the Marc Jacobs brand has us wondering what outfit shell be modeling for Juergen Tellers lens. If you recall, the Spring/Summer 2008 collection was heavy on abstruse undies as outerwear, aggressive backward-is-the-new-forward pieces and neo-burlesque transparency  not exactly the unreflective lascivious gear Mrs. Becks usually wears. Until the photos are leaked, The Moment has worked up some composite shots of Posh in Marc Jacobs SS08

title: Big Boost in Energy Science and Technology Sought
description: [UPDATE, 6/6/08: The International Energy Agency has echoed the call from many climate and energy experts for big increases in energy research, development, and deployment of non-polluting technologies, saying that there is no way to curb greenhouse gases as human populations and economies swell in coming decades without an energy revolution. ]

title: The Great Glass Ceiling at Opryland
description: The Opryland Hotel, site of the baseball winter meetings, has always reminded me of the movie The Truman Show, where Jim Carrey exists in a self-contained universe in which even the sky is not real. The hotel is vast, with ballrooms, restaurants and trees everywhere, rivers flowing beneath your feet, and the open areas covered by giant glass ceilings.

title: The Video Lounge | The Neistat Brothers
Housewives Beat Sunday Night Football
description: Drawing 20.6 million viewers on Sunday, Desperate Housewives lifted ABC into first place for the nights ratings, according to Nielsens estimates. The 9 p.m. drama delivered the largest audience of the night, easily outperforming NBCs Sunday Night Football which averaged 13 million viewers.

title: Making a List
description: I have the kind of insomnia where, even though I fall right to sleep at bedtime, I then wake up at 2 a.m., my mind racing with things I need to do. Last night at 2 a.m., I kept thinking about all the decisions that remain to be made. After tossing and turning for a while, I got up to make a to-do list for Florida:

title: Two Choices for the Plus One
description: In the next few months, college football fans are going to be hearing a lot more about the Plus One system as an alternative for the college football postseason. In numerous conversations with college football power brokers over the past year, its become very clear that the Bowl Championship Series meetings this April in Miami will be a critical time to see whether or not the Plus One will be implemented in 2011. Mike Slive, the coordinator of the B.C.S., has nudged the issue to the forefront lately by asking the question: Is two enough? He means is having two teams with a shot at the national title enough anymore. Certainly a legitimate question this season.

title: What Buffetts TXU Play Doesnt Mean
description: Dont count on Warren E. Buffetts purchase of TXU bonds from Goldman Sachs as a sign of confidence in the high-yield debt market. The Oracle of Omaha himself doesnt see it that way.

title: Hawaiis Team Concept
description: Faithful readers of The Quad all know what Hawaii quarterback Colt Brennan thinks of his receivers, who are affectionately known as The Dread Heads. So after Hawaii completed its 12-0 season on Saturday, Brennan pulled aside Karl Benson, the commissioner of the Western Athletic Conference Commissioner, and asked if he could give one more shout out to his receivers and his offensive line.

title: Comptrollers Report Issues Warning About Citys Economy
description: The New York City comptroller, William C. Thompson Jr., warned today that the local economy is at a turning point, and predicted that the city could face a budget gap of more than $6 billion in the fiscal year that starts in July 2010  the first year that Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs successor will be in office.In a City Charter-mandated report on the citys economy and finances, Mr. Thompson warned: Turmoil in the nations housing and mortgage markets has reverberated through the financial sector, threatening to produce a marked slowdown in local economic activity. The principal threat to both the national and local economies is the unfolding subprime mortgage debacle and its collateral effects on credit markets. The resulting financial losses and layoffs are likely to fall disproportionately on New York firms and workers.

title: U.C.L.A. Fires Dorrell
description: U.C.L.A. fired Karl Dorrell today after the Bruins finished the regular season with a 6-6 record. The Bruins will face B.Y.U. in the Las Vegas Bowl on Dec. 22, though the university has not said who will be the coach of the team for that game. (Update: The defensive coordinator DeWayne Walker will coach the Bruins in their bowl game.)

title: Final Fixes of Some Scripted Series
description: Four weeks after the writers strike commenced, networks are showing the last original episodes of several popular television series.

title: The Making of an Audio Book
description: In all its glory.

title: A Family Affair, Staal Style
description: As the oldest of the three Staal brothers playing in the N.H.L., Carolina forward Eric Staal has an interesting perspective on his brothers budding careers. And it gets even more interesting when he gets to play against them.

title: Clinton Steps Up Attacks on Obama
description: MASON CITY, Iowa  Hillary Rodham Clintons spokesman may be crowing about a new Associated Press poll in Iowa that is somewhat better for her than Sundays Des Moines Register poll. But that doesnt mean Mrs. Clinton is lightening up on her attacks on one rival for the Democratic presidential nomination, Barack Obama.

title: Testing Chimps' Memory
description: Young chimps can outperform some adult humans in a memory test.

title: Heisman Watch: The Final Edition
description: Florida quarterback Tim Tebow: The vote will be close, but he becomes the first underclassman to win the award.

title: Bruno Wont Discuss His Other Job
description: The State Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, the states top Republican, was asked by City Room this afternoon about his other salaried position  his job at a Connecticut-based investment company, the Winthrop Corporation, which was the subject of a Times article on Saturday. The question came at the end of a news conference on negotiations over the states expiring horse racing franchise.

title: How Professional Is Your Doctor?
description: Nearly half of doctors in a recent survey admit to witnessing a serious medical error but not reporting it.

title: The Details Behind Verizons Announcement
description: Everyones e-mailing me to ask what I think of Verizons announcement.

title: An Ad for Ads
description: Generation Yonce and for all  refers to Americans born between 1981 and 1995. (Hey, Wikipedia is looking for an expert on you all; enlist today!) Its a dopey name, but with Greatest already taken, the rest of us are bound to be left with clunkers.

title: What Gov. Spitzer Gets This Holiday: Lumps of Coal from Leading Magazines
description: New Yorks Governor Eliot Spitzer has done something that nobody could have expected when he took office almost a year ago. He has made Albany and his stewardship of the state such big news that Vanity Fair and The New Yorker both have huge profiles on him in their big holiday issues that have just come out.

title: A Place in Our Hearts for Pay Phones
description: The pay phones long goodbye paused for an especially poignant moment today, when AT&T stopped believing after 129 years:

title: Pedestrians Struck as High Winds Buffet City
description: The National Weather Service has issued a wind advisory for the late afternoon and evening, warning of west winds between 23 and 28 miles per hour, with gusts as high as 45 m.p.h. There were reports of pedestrians struck by objects falling off Midtown buildings, including the new headquarters of The Times.There have been sustained winds from 25 to 35 m.p.h. throughout the five boroughs, with Kennedy International Airport reporting winds of up to 46 m.p.h. around 1 p.m. We do have a wind advisory out until 7 a.m. tomorrow, said Matthew Tauber, a meteorologist with the weather service. We are looking at these winds continuing throughout tonight.

title: Why I get mad at Obama about Social Security
description: So I just spent a fairly unpleasant 15 minutes on right-wing talk radio. And the host said  this is rough, not a verified quote  Look, everyone knows that Social Security is going bust, and wed all be better off if we could put out money in 401(k)s. Even Barack Obama says so!

title: Merrill Appoints Chai as New Finance Chief
description: On his first full day as Merrill Lynchs chief executive, John A. Thain has already poached someone from his old firm.

title: Dating-Related Violence Rises Among Teenagers
description: Fighting decreased by 20 percent in New York City schools from 2003 to 2005, but dating-related violence is on the rise. The new report, Teen Safety in New York City, described trends in youth violence and showed an association between violence and other health risks  both for victims and for aggressors.

title: The New (Old) Flyers Hockey
description: Lets review:

title: Romney Signals His Religion Speech
description: How will Mitt Romney handle the subject of his Mormon faith during a much-anticipated speech on Thursday? He gave some clues yesterday, dispelling notions that he would focus mainly on allaying any doubts about his Mormon faith.

title: Romneys J.F.K. Moment?
description: Mitt Romney has an impossible balancing act to maintain when he delivers a speech on his Mormon faith later this week, suggests conservative blogger Daniel Larison, a graduate student in Byzantine history at the University of Chicago. Romney cannot keep evading the issue so long as he wishes to define his campaign and his values in terms of being a person of faith,  Larison writes. He continues:

title: License to Hack
description: What we are reading elsewhere

title: Opening Santas Mail (and Answering It)
description: Santa Claus has set up shop in the 10001 ZIP Code, though addressing an envelope to Santa Claus New York, Santas Workshop, North Pole or just plain Santa is enough to land a letter in the hands of Santas helpers.

title: Short Squeeze?
description: For afficianados of NovaStar Financial, there is an eerie quiet. The bulls are loving it.

title: The Wimp Factor in Albany
description: The State Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, is not on good terms with the other two state leaders. Thats putting it mildly. This afternoon, he held a news conference to chastise Gov. Eliot Spitzer and Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver for stalling on an agreement over who will run the states three thoroughbred tracks when the New York Racing Associations contract expires at the end of the year. Mr. Bruno is at a disadvantage in the talks, because Saratoga Race Course is in the heart of his district and thus the issue is a far higher priority for him than the other two men who run the state.

title: Humans Test Their Memory
description: In some memory tests, humans perform worse than young chimps

title: Thompson Tackles Immigration Query
description: Henry from Mississippi, a conference call participant, put Fred D. Thompson on the spot today when he asked about illegal immigrants, saying they are needed to fill labor shortages in the construction, farming and poultry industries.

title: DARPA's Urban Challenge
description: Driverless vehicles make the rounds at the DARPA Urban Challenge. (Courtesy of DARPA)

title: The Spectrum Auction Secrecy Begins
description: A veil of mystery is about to descend over the auction of the 700-megahertz band, a useful swath of the electromagnetic spectrum that is being freed up by the move to digital television.

title: Adamss Dark Matter
description: The Education of Henry Adams is not really an autobiography. As the author himself confesses several dozen pages from the end, it is the modern omega to the medieval alpha (his book Mont-Saint-Michel and Chartres) in his project to contrast long-ago cohesion with latter-day multiplicity. The Education is a treatise, an elegant, patrician apogee to the fine American tradition of cranks putting forth literary explanations for the whole universe, of which their own country is a strangely exceptional precinct. Adamss Dynamic Theory of History, developed during a decade in which he was also playing with magnets and seeking revelation in the statistics of coal production, proceeds from a late-life awareness of himself a a conscious ball of vibrating motions, traversed in every direction by infinite lines of rotation or vibration. His discovery that, as of 1900, the world would not be a unity but a multiple freed him to write a memoir whose own ever-increasing entropy could be rationalized as a shape to suit the times.

title: A Case of Political Counter-Programming
description: DES MOINES  When one politician launches an attack at another politician, particularly in the closing month of a bare-knuckle presidential campaign, the recipient of the strike frequently responds with swift aggression. The cable television networks count on it, right?

title: Democracy Scorecard: Venezuela, Russia, Pakistan
description: Is democracy batting 1 for 3 in todays rush of election news? Heres a look at developments in Venezuela, Russia and Pakistan posted to NYTimes.coms homepage today.

title: Yahoo Shuffles Yet More Executives
description: After a 100-day strategic review of Yahoo, chief executive Jerry Yang declared that the company he co-founded in 1994 would focus on three things: become a starting point for the most consumers; become the must-buy for advertisers; and turn itself into a more open platform for publishers and developers.

title: Romney, Politics and Religion
description: Dampening our expectations (and perhaps trying to lessen the hype), Republican candidate Mitt Romney today dismissed the notion that he would offer up later this week a speech on religion akin to that given by John F. Kennedy on Sept. 12, 1960.

title: Oprah Overload Alert
description: There are no tickets left for Oprah Winfreys appearance in Columbia, S.C., on Sunday with Barack Obama. The event is to be held in the Colonial Center, the biggest arena in the state, seating 18,000 people.

title: Bloggingheads: Stem-Cell Semantics
description: Science writer Carl Zimmer, left, and biologist Lee Silver on whether a recent breakthrough will really end the stem-cell controversy.

title: China's Endangered Species
description: China's rapid economic expansion has jeopardized the nation's prized wildlife and biodiversity, such as the Yangtze turtle.

title: When Dirt Is Just as Good
description: A thin layer of snow did not last long in Riverside Park, but that did not stop children from taking a slide on Dec. 2.

title: Whos Going to Win the Harlon Hill?
description: If you think the Heisman Trophy race is close, check out the battle for the Harlon Hill Trophy.

title: 'A Look to the Future'
description: A conversation for the New York Times Building opening ceremony.

title: Toronto Station Retracts Report on Avery
description: The Toronto radio reporter who caused a stir by claiming that Rangers forward Sean Avery had made derogatory comments about Maple Leafs forward Jason Blakes recent cancer diagnosis before a game last month, retracted his report in a broadcast Monday.

title: More Trump
description: A week after Aberdeen officials rejected his plan for a $2 billion golf course and resort project, Donald Trump is threatening to take his project and go home.

title: Campus Voices: Granite State Impressions
description: Our band of undergraduate students at Harvard, under the umbrella of the Kennedy Schools Institute of Politics, is spending a lot of time in New Hampshire in the leadup to the states Jan. 8 primary. The students braved the chilly prelude to that Granite winter wonderland this past weekend, and filed these posts. (The snow is starting to fall in the Northeast and elsewhere, mind you.)

title: Would You Let These Cars Take You for a Ride?
description: Now that Ive hailed the coming age of self-driving cars in my Findings column, Id like to hear what Lab readers think of this prospect. But before you weigh in  and tell me how naively optimistic I am  take a look at these videos of driverless cars.

title: CBS Announces Revised Schedule, Including Winter Edition of Big Brother
description: On Monday, two broadcast networks, CBS and NBC, gave the clearest indication to date of how their programming schedules were being affected by the four-week writers strike. CBS said it would introduce several new reality shows and midseason replacements beginning in January, including the first winter season ever of the reality show Big Brother.

title: The Lingering Cullen Debate
description: The Rangers did not need Carolina center Matt Cullen to show them how good an offensive player he can be, but that is just what happened in Monday nights 4-0 loss to the Hurricanes. Cullen, whom the Rangers traded in the offseason for two players who may never play for them and a draft pick, had two assists, giving him 21 this season to go with six goals.

title: Are Words Worthless in the Climate Fight?
description: In Science Times this week, I have a story examining the limits of language. Can scientists or anyone else find new words sufficiently potent to inspire action on long-term challenges, like shifting from unfettered use of coal and oil to limit the odds of climate surprises?

title: Being Green: The Young Show the Way
description: To the Editor:

title: Tiny, Ordinary Movements Polished by Self-Awareness
description: Apparently we are back in the 1960s, but in a 2007 kind of way. In three works presented on Saturday night in Dance and Process, a program at the Kitchen organized by Dean Moss, the choreographers largely espoused the ordinary movement and neutral presentation of odd activities first deployed by artists like Yvonne Rainer and Steve Paxton. But I suspect that the polished, almost glamorous patina of at least two of these pieces is a manifestation of a more self-conscious age.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Turner Prize Winner

title: Clinton Aims for Anger Without Making People Mad
description: CLEAR LAKE, Iowa, Dec. 3  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton doesnt sound angry or look angry or act angry. But if you transcribe her recent speeches in Iowa and reread them, they do seem angry  or, at least, more negative toward other Democrats than she has been since the 1992 presidential primary campaign of her husband.

title: Cause and Effect: Images of Lung Damage From Secondhand Smoke
description: Researchers say that for the first time, they have been able to get an image of lungs apparently damaged by secondhand tobacco smoke.

title: Chimps Exhibit Superior Memory, Outshining Humans
description: Spend even a little time around chimpanzees, and you begin to realize how intelligent they are. But can they outshine humans in brain power? Most humans would scoff at that.

title: Britain: Muslims End Holocaust Day Boycott
description: The Muslim Council of Britain, the biggest Muslim umbrella group in the country, has voted to end its boycott of Holocaust Memorial Day, The Guardian reported. The organizations central working committee voted 18 to 8 on Saturday to end the boycott, which began in 2001, and to send representatives to the next Holocaust Memorial Day commemoration, on Jan. 27, in Liverpool. The Guardian said that those who voted to attend said the boycott had allowed the council to be accused of anti-Semitism. Those who supported the boycott argued for a more inclusive title like Genocide Memorial Day that they said could give greater recognition to recent genocides like those in Rwanda and Bosnia. The newspaper said there were concerns that the vote might lead some of the 500 organizations in the council to leave.

title: Akon Pleads Not Guilty in Fan-Tossing Case
description: The platinum-selling hip-hop star Akon, 34,  pleaded not guilty yesterday to criminal charges filed after he tossed a 15-year-old boy off the stage at a concert on June 3 at the minor league baseball stadium in Fishkill, N.Y., The Associated Press reported. Akon was released on his own recognizance after a brief appearance in court, where he was charged with misdemeanor endangering the welfare of a minor and second-degree harassment, a violation. He was accused after a fan, Abby Rosa, said she suffered a concussion when the boy thrown from the stage fell on her. Akon had no comment when he left the courthouse. His lawyer, Benjamin Brafman, said: It was never Akons intention to violate the law. This unfortunate incident was a spontaneous reaction during a live concert that Akon deeply regrets.

title: Pressure on U.S.C., and Spotlight on Mayo
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 3  Tim Floyd served as a technical adviser on Glory Road, the 2006 movie based on the story of Texas Western University and its colorblind mens basketball coach, Don Haskins. That team traveled the still-segregated road to the 1966 N.C.A.A. tournament championship, using an all-black starting five to beat an all-white Kentucky team in the title game.

title: Larry Wachtel, Market Analyst, Is Dead at 77
description: Larry Wachtel, a stock market analyst whose humor and trademark Brooklyn accent kept radio listeners attuned to the ups and downs of the markets for more than three decades in the New York area, died on Sunday in Valhalla, N.Y. He was 77 and lived in Yonkers.

title: MySpace Hoax Draws No Charges
description: No criminal charges will be filed in the case of an Internet hoax that ended in a teenage girls suicide in a St. Louis suburb last year, the local prosecutor said yesterday.

title: METRO BRIEFING | NEW YORK; Manhattan: Teachers Now Oppose Housing Plan
description: The United Federation of Teachers said yesterday that it would seek to withdraw from a $28 million effort to build 234 units of moderately priced housing for teachers because the city and the developer would not pledge to use union labor. Randi Weingarten, the unions president, said she would ask the Teachers Retirement System to end its participation in the project. The citys Housing Development Corporation and the developer, Atlantic Development Group, trying hold down costs, said they would not guarantee use of prevailing-wage workers.

title: Democratic Presidential Debate on NPR
description: The following is a transcript of the 2008 Democratic primary presidential debate hosted by National Public Radio. The participating were Senator Joesph Biden, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, Senator Christopher Dodd, John Edwards, Mike Gravel, Representative Dennis Kucinich, and Senator Barack Obama. The transcript is provided by CQ Transcriptions. The audio of the entire debate can be downloaded at npr.org.

title: F.D.A. Criticizes Avastin Use for Breast Cancer
description: Genentechs drug Avastin did not help women with breast cancer live meaningfully longer, and it caused significant side effects, including a few deaths, the Food and Drug Administration said yesterday in a review of the drug.

title: Lottery Numbers
Sudans President Pardons British Teacher
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Dec. 3  The British schoolteacher jailed in Sudan for allowing her 7-year-old pupils to name a class teddy bear Muhammad was pardoned Monday by the Sudanese president and left for England later in the evening.

title: Florida: Sears Tower Case Goes to Jury
description: A jury began deliberations in the trial of seven Miami men accused of plotting to blow up the Sears Tower in Chicago and wage a religiously motivated war against the United States government. Prosecutors, drawing on evidence collected in an eight-month investigation, have said the men were trying to get financial support from Al Qaeda to conduct an armed jihad. But defense lawyers have insisted their clients were entrapped by undercover F.B.I. agents and played along to raise money to build a construction business and a local religious mission..

title: Behavior: Even Babies May Be Good Judges of Character
description: Did that mean Square push that poor Circle down the hill? Yes  and Baby isnt about to forget it, either.

title: Stuck on Coal, and Stuck for Words in a High-Tech World
description: Human progress, Loren Eiseley wrote in 1954, has largely been a climb up the heat ladder from one energy source to the next. Each has been more convenient or potent or economical than the last. No one lugs firewood to warm a high-rise apartment building in Chicago.

title: Omitting Miller Not Surprising, but Still Embarrassing
description: The National Baseball Hall of Fame has become a national joke. Its latest electoral contrivance elected three former executives to the Hall yesterday, none named Marvin Miller. Making the committees decision even worse, one of the three is named Bowie Kuhn.

title: MySpace to Showcase Music and Sell Performance Videos
description: MySpace, the social networking site where people create home pages and embellish them as they would a dormitory room, plans today to start positioning itself as a top destination for buying exclusive musical performances.

title: Peter Lieberson Songs Win an Award
description: A song cycle inspired by love for a wife doomed to an early death has won Peter Lieberson the University of Louisvilles $200,000 Grawemeyer Award for outstanding works in music composition. The work, Neruda Songs, based on five love poems by the Chilean poet Pablo Neruda and written for the mezzo-soprano Lorraine Hunt Lieberson, who died of cancer last year at 52, was chosen from among 140 entries from around the world. Mark Satterwhite, a University of Louisville music professor who directs the award program, said: Each song represents a different stage of love, from first passion to the end of life. The piece has a beauty and surface simplicity but great emotional depth and intellectual rigor as well. Before her death Ms. Hunt Lieberson performed the work with the organizations that commissioned it: the Los Angeles Philharmonic and the Boston Symphony Orchestra.

title: Elizabeth Hardwick, Writer, Dies at 91
description: Elizabeth Hardwick, the critic, essayist, fiction writer and co-founder of The New York Review of Books, who went from being a studious Southern Belle to a glittering member of the New York City intellectual elite, died Sunday night in Manhattan. She was 91.

title: Citing Past Troubles at Indian Point, State Urges Panel to Deny License Extension
description: WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 3  Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo said on Monday that the state had asked the Nuclear Regulatory Commission to deny an application to extend the license of the Indian Point nuclear reactors, citing a long and troubling history of problems.

title: METRO BRIEFING | NEW YORK; Manhattan: Expansion of No. 7 Subway Line
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Gov. Eliot Spitzer spoke yesterday at a ceremony in the Times Square subway station to mark the start of work on a westward extension of the No. 7 subway line. The extension is intended to spur development on the west edge of Midtown, using what Mr. Bloomberg called the galvanizing power of the subway. The 7 train now runs from Flushing, Queens, to Times Square. The extension will take the line west to 11th Avenue, then south to 34th Street, where a station will be built at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center. At the ceremony, Deputy Mayor Daniel L. Doctoroff defended a decision not to build a station at 41st Street and 10th Avenue, saying that development had already been progressing in that area without the impetus of the new subway. The project is due to be completed in 2013.

title: W.T.O. Court Rejects Brazils Tire Ban
description: The World Trade Organizations highest court, backing a European Union complaint, upheld a ruling finding that Brazil illegally bans imports of retread tires for vehicles. Appellate judges agreed with a June 12 decision that the restriction was unjustified because Brazil imports used tires for making retreads, so it would be unfair to prevent imports of the finished retread product. Europe said Brazils September 2000 ban unfairly denied it a market expected to import three million used tires by 2003. Brazil had argued that Europe was trying to export its pollution problem of old tires, which cannot be used for making retreads more than once, and would therefore become a waste problem at the end of their second life.

title: Ceremonial Objects From West Africa With Blood in the Patina
description: Certain ceremonial objects from the Dogon and other cultures of West Africa are known for their dark patina. There is plenty of ethnological evidence that the thick coating on these wood sculptures, which are often in human or animal shapes, contains blood from animals sacrificed as part of the ceremonies. But the presence of blood had not been proved through chemical analysis.

title: Beethovens Sonatas as a Series of Dialogues
description: The 92nd Street Y is smitten with the idea of Beethoven cycles this season. In September the Kalichstein-Laredo-Robinson Trio played all the piano trios in chronological order in an all-day marathon. Now the violinist Christian Tetzlaff and the pianist Alexander Lonquich are playing the Sonatas for Violin and Piano. Mr. Tetzlaff and Mr. Lonquich are in less of a hurry: Having played the first four sonatas on Thursday, they picked up with the fifth  Spring Sonata  as well as the sixth and seventh on Sunday afternoon, and will play a concluding concert tonight.

title: Desperate Housewives Outscores Football
description: Drawing 20.6 million viewers on Sunday, Desperate Housewives lifted ABC into first place for the nights ratings, according to Nielsens estimates. The 9 p.m. drama delivered the largest audience of the night, easily outperforming NBCs Sunday Night Football which averaged 13 million viewers. NBC finished third overall among adults 18 to 49, just behind Fox, which got a boost early in the evening from an overrun of its afternoon football coverage followed by its half-hour special, Bowl Championship Series Selection Show, at 8 (10.8 million). ABCs Extreme Makeover: Home Edition remained the 8 p.m. time slot leader with 14.5 million viewers, and ABC finished first in the 10 p.m. hour as well with Brothers & Sisters (12.7 million). CBS, which ranked second over all in total viewers ahead of Fox and NBC, finished fourth in the 18-to-49 set. Following 60 Minutes at 7 (14 million) and The Amazing Race at 8 (11.2 million), CBSs Hallmark Hall of Fame movie Pictures of Hollis Woods attracted 11.5 million viewers from 9 to 11.

title: Jefferson DeBlanc, Honored World War II Fighter Pilot, Dies at 86
description: Jefferson J. DeBlanc, a World War II fighter pilot who was awarded the Medal of Honor for shooting down five Japanese planes on a single day while running out of fuel, died Nov. 22 in Lafayette, La. He was 86 and lived St. Martinville, La..

title: Bright Prospects for a Comfortable Ride
description: Those plump Lincoln Town Cars that provide a ride as soft as a pillow are clogging city streets and airport access roads these days  a sign that the $2.4 billion chauffeured transportation business in the United States is doing well, particularly with corporate customers.

title: Vulnerable Democrats See Fates Tied to Clinton
description: MANHATTAN, Kan.  Nancy Boyda, a Democrat who ran for Congress in this district last year, owed her upset victory partly to the popularity of the Democratic woman at the top of the ticket: Kathleen Sebelius, who won the governors seat. Now, with a tough re-election race at hand in 2008, Ms. Boyda faces the prospect that her electoral fate could be tied to another woman: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: Health Insurance for All, Only if Everyone Pays?
description: To the Editor:

title: Close to a Completed Club, the Mets Are Just Window Shopping for Now
description: NASHVILLE, Dec. 3  Mets General Manager Omar Minaya sounded like a man who did not expect to make a major trade for a pitcher at the winter meetings. Perhaps he was purposely lowering expectations, or maybe he did not want to disclose much about negotiations. Still, he offered a revealing anecdote.

title: For Democrats, a Strained Debate on Immigration
description: DES MOINES, Dec. 4  If there is one issue that has perplexed presidential candidates from both parties in Iowa this year, it is immigration. The Democratic presidential contenders were confronted with it an unusual way at a debate here this afternoon: Should an American citizen turn in someone they know to be an illegal immigrant?

title: Bringing an Energy Bill Home
description: Congress is now within reach of a breakthrough energy bill that would reduce both Americas dependence on foreign oil and its emissions of the greenhouse gases that cause climate change. House passage later this week is virtually certain. Senate approval depends on whether the majority leader, Harry Reid, and the minority leader, Mitch McConnell, can corral a half-dozen votes among moderate Republicans to resist a threatened filibuster.

title: A Farm Boy and a Mogul, and How They Changed the World
description: With billionaire parents now producing bar mitzvah celebrations and sweet-16 parties as if they were major motion pictures, its only a matter of time before this spare-no-expense approach is applied to their kids school projects. Imagine that Mr. Hedge Fund, with money to burn and many favors to call in, imports a crack combination of writer, director and actors to put across Juniors oral report with envy-making, A-worthy flair.

title: Justices Express Skepticism in a Discrimination Case
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3  Beneath the surface of a Supreme Court argument on Monday in a case of job-related age discrimination was a surprising question: has the Supreme Court drifted so far toward the employers side in job discrimination cases that it is now to the right of the Bush administration?

title: Tired of Corruption but Afraid of the Crackdown
description: HWASUNG, South Korea, Dec. 3  For Choi Hae-pyung, head of an electronics parts maker, running his business over the last year has been like steering a boat through a double storm: competition from China and the rising value of the Korean currency have squeezed his already thin profit.

title: A Frustrating Season Turns Sorrowful for Marbury
description: The final minutes of the first half were winding down Sunday night, and Stephon Marbury had settled into a steady, peaceful rhythm. His shots were falling, the Knicks were rallying and Madison Square Garden was again echoing with cheers instead of boos.

title: An Emotional Ceremony to Honor a Fierce Player
description: MIAMI, Dec. 3  One week after the Washington Redskins star Sean Taylor was shot and killed, about 3,000 people came to say goodbye to the man whose body now rested inside a mahogany-colored coffin.

title: Ford and G.M. Plan to Trim 2008 Output
description: DETROIT, Dec. 3  General Motors and Ford Motor Company, struggling to keep turnaround plans on track, both said Monday that they would cut production in the first quarter because of slowing sales.

title: Rutgers Upends Another Top Team
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Dec. 3  Rutgers was trailing an undefeated team by 5 points, and its leading rebounder and defensive stopper was on the bench with four fouls. It did not look good for the Scarlet Knights  that is, until Epiphanny Prince took over.

title: A Lurid Aftermath to a Hedge Fund Managers Life
description: JUPITER, Fla.  A life of private jets and black-tie balls ended with Seth Tobias, a wealthy investment manager and a familiar presence on CNBC, floating face down in the swimming pool of his mansion here.

title: One Last Ride to the Hubble
description: GREENBELT, Md.  Its the last roundup for the Peoples Telescope.

title: Life Was Lost in Maelstrom of Suspicion
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3  Friends of Charles D. Riechers, whose Air Force career took him from the back of a B-52 cockpit to the front of the services $30 billion procurement office, said something was telling in the fact that his suicide note to his boss was typed. They described it as an effort to set the record straight by a meticulous man who felt deeply misunderstood.

title: Florida Is Advised on Saving a State Fund
description: BlackRock, the asset management firm hired to advise Florida on a state pool whose subprime-tainted holdings led to withdrawal of almost half its $27 billion assets, recommended yesterday that the remaining holdings be split into two entities to ensure the funds survival.

title: Stayin Alive: An Era That Was Running on Empty
description: Hardly anyone has a good word to say about the 1970s, a decade associated with Nixon and Watergate and Vietnam, rising unemployment, growing gas shortages and soaring crime rates. On much of the cultural front, things were equally bleak: Rock n roll was giving way to disco and heavy metal; happy, psychedelic hippie clothes were being replaced by leisure suits and hot pants; the Beats and Black Mountain poets were losing ground to Jonathan Livingston Seagull and Love Story. It was a time when shag rugs and shag haircuts were shagadelic, a time when pet rocks, platform shoes and polyester were primo. Think of avocado-colored refrigerators, yellow smiley faces and silvery disco balls.

title: A Bouncer Tells Jurors Assassins Framed Him
description: On trial for three killings connected to a strip parlor in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, a bouncer told jurors yesterday that he was being framed by a squad of police assassins acting on orders from a corrupt detective who was out to shake down the bouncers private security business while his martial arts students conducted countersurveillance black ops against the Police Department.

title: Spice Girls Reunite
description: Singing, strutting, hugging and even pole-dancing to the delight of a screaming audience of more than 15,000, all five of the Spice Girls reunited in Vancouver, British Columbia, late Sunday in their first major appearance in about eight years, Agence France-Presse reported. The performers, now in their 30s and with a combined seven children, were embarking on a world tour. In their heyday the Spice Girls  Victoria Beckham (above, at right), Emma Bunton, Melanie Chisholm, Melanie Brown and Geri Halliwell (above, at left)  sold 55 million albums and had nine No. 1 singles in Britain.

title: A Tale of Two Strongmen
description: Voters on Sunday gave a split decision to two of the worlds most prominent and problematic authoritarian leaders. Russias president, Vladimir Putin, turned a parliamentary election into a referendum on himself and cynically manipulated a huge victory, undermining what was left of the independence of the Duma and Russian politics. In Venezuela, President Hugo Chvezs latest and most outrageous power grab was rejected at the ballot box, offering hope that political competition there will now flourish.

title: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
description: Previously recorded: $2,526,869.86

title: In Iran, Group of Mothers Criticizes Nuclear Policy
description: TEHRAN, Dec. 3  More than 500 Iranian women calling themselves mothers of peace have signed a letter to senior officials expressing their fear that there will be a war over Irans nuclear program.

title: Quick Fixes to Bring Back Damaged Voices
description: When Ray Boyer woke up from neck surgery last year, he felt fine  except he couldnt say so.

title: Skeletal Remains Are Found in a Brooklyn Home
description: The police found the skeletal remains of a woman in a home in Brooklyn yesterday. How long ago she died was unknown, but neighbors said they had not seen her for about two years.

title: Suicide and the Elderly (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Pakistani Rivals Threaten Boycott of Elections
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Dec. 3  Benazir Bhutto and Nawaz Sharif, the two former prime ministers who have long bitterly opposed each other, joined with an opposition alliance on Monday to denounce what they see as an unfair environment leading up to parliamentary elections planned for January.

title: In Alaskas Far North, Two Cultures Collide
description: BARROW, Alaska  Each summer and fall, the Inupiat, natives of Alaskas arid north coast, take their sealskin boats and gun-fired harpoons and go whale hunting. Kills are celebrated throughout villages as whaling captains share their catch with relatives and neighbors. Muktuk, or raw whale skin and blubber, is a prized delicacy.

title: Britain: Abdication Buick Fetches $205,429
description: King Edward VIIIs 1934 Buick, which he rode to Downing Street to announce his abdication from the British throne in 1936, sold for $205,429 at Bonhams auction house in London. Bonhams would not identify the buyer.

title: U.S. Finds Iran Halted Its Nuclear Arms Effort in 2003
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3  A new assessment by American intelligence agencies released Monday concludes that Iran halted its nuclear weapons program in 2003 and that the program remains frozen, contradicting a judgment two years ago that Tehran was working relentlessly toward building a nuclear bomb.

title: Magazine Voices Doubt Over Diary From Iraq
description: After months of accusations that reports written in The New Republic by The Baghdad Diarist, an American Army private, about the cruelty of ordinary soldiers in Iraq were false, the magazine says that as a result of its own investigation it can no longer stand by the articles.

title: METRO BRIEFING | NEW YORK; Manhattan: Renovation at Washington Square Park
description: City officials said that yesterdays decision by a justice in State Supreme Court in Manhattan has cleared the way for the renovation of Washington Square Park to begin. The work, including moving the parks fountain and decreasing the size of the plaza, had been challenged by neighborhood and environmental groups. The city won two previous lawsuits, and yesterdays decision, by Justice Joan A. Madden, found that the city had taken steps to ensure that the work would not significantly damage the environment, city officials said. The renovation is expected to begin by years end, city officials said. Daniel L. Alterman, a lawyer for the opponents of the renovation, said they were considering whether to appeal.

title: Ratatouille Leads the Annie Race
description: Ratatouille, the tale of a rodent chef, amassed 13 nominations, including best feature, when the Annie Awards, honoring animation, were announced yesterday, The Associated Press reported. In the competition for best animated feature film it was joined by Bee Movie, Surfs Up, Persepolis and The Simpsons Movie. The Annie Award winners in 25 film and television categories are to be announced in Los Angeles on Feb. 8. Since the category was added to the Oscars in 2001, the winner of the Annie for best picture has gone on to win the Academy Award for best animated feature every year but one. Last year the Annie Award-winning Cars lost to Happy Feet.

title: Tenor Turns His Focus to the Art of the Song
description: Not that many years ago voice buffs in New York who admired the American tenor Matthew Polenzani had to content themselves with hearing him in winning performances of supporting roles at the Metropolitan Opera. For the role of David, for example, the young apprentice to the shoemaker Hans Sachs in Wagners Meistersinger, the boy-next-door wholesomeness and awkward earnestness of his portrayal, not to mention his handsome singing, were ideal; he was the best David of my experience.

title: Trunk Line
description: Q. How keen is an elephants sense of smell, and where in the trunk is it handled?

title: Driver Piles Up Wins and Miles
description: The only hard part, Tim Tetrick said, was all the time in his car, driving on the New Jersey and Pennsylvania turnpikes, Interstate 95 and Route 13 in Delaware. The rest was easy, or at least he made it look easy.

title: Serving Life for Providing Car to Killers
description: CRAWFORDVILLE, Fla.  Early in the morning of March 10, 2003, after a raucous party that lasted into the small hours, a groggy and hungover 20-year-old named Ryan Holle lent his Chevrolet Metro to a friend. That decision, prosecutors later said, was tantamount to murder.

title: Mood Problems Prevalent After Katrina, Survey Finds
description: The first study to rigorously assess the mental health fallout from Hurricane Katrina has confirmed what many researchers and Gulf Coast residents predicted: that mood problems after the storm occurred about as often as in any natural disaster ever studied, and that the delayed government response almost certainly made the problem worse.

title: New Hampshire: Bail Set in Clinton Standoff
description: A man accused of taking hostages at Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons presidential campaign office in Rochester was arraigned on six felony charges, including kidnapping and criminal threatening. The man, Leeland Eisenberg of Somersworth, was ordered held on $500,000 cash bail by a Rochester District Court judge. Mr. Eisenberg walked into the office Friday, claimed he had a bomb and took people hostage.

title: Phoenix Mayor Shifts on Officers Asking for Immigration Status
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 3  Under pressure from advocates for stricter immigration laws, the mayor of Phoenix said on Monday that he no longer backed a Police Department order barring officers from routinely asking the immigration status of people it arrested and announced a panel to study a policy change.

title: Cecil Payne, Baritone Saxophonist Who Mastered Bebop, Dies
description: Cecil Payne, who in the 1940s was one of the first baritone saxophonists to master the intricacies of modern jazz and who for more than half a century was a leading exponent of his instrument, died last Tuesday  in Stratford, N.J. He was 84.

title: The Dictatorship of Talent
description: Shanghai

title: Robot Guitar Calls the Tune
description: The worlds first self-tuning guitar was introduced yesterday in London. The instrument, the Gibson Robot Guitar, above, automatically detects when a string has fallen out of pitch and corrects it, Agence France-Presse reported. Gibson, the Nashville-based manufacturer, promised that it would change the guitar world forever when it goes on sale worldwide on Friday. Using technology developed over 10 years the Robot will sell in Britain for $2,900.

title: Putin Basks in Election Win Despite Broad Criticism
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 3  President Vladimir V. Putin declared Monday that his partys imposing victory in parliamentary elections was a sign of trust that had conferred new legitimacy on the government. But European monitors and opposition parties harshly criticized the balloting, saying it had been neither free nor fair.

title: The Claim: Super Glue Can Heal Wounds
METRO BRIEFING | NEW JERSEY; Trenton: Anti-Death Penalty Bill Moves Forward
description: A bill that would abolish the death penalty in New Jersey easily passed the Senate Budget and Appropriations Committee yesterday by an 8-to-4 vote. The next stop for the bill is the floor of the Senate, where the Senate president, Richard J. Codey, has said he would like to see the bill voted on before the end of the year. In the State Assembly, an identical bill is scheduled for a committee hearing on Monday. That bill is expected to pass the committee easily, and then go before the full Assembly by the end of the week.

title: Late Gaffes by the Ravens Give Brady and Pats an Opening
description: BALTIMORE, Dec. 3  Don Shula sat in the stands, a reminder of everything that was on the line for the New England Patriots, and perhaps he was the same sort of good luck charm for the Baltimore Ravens that other members of the 1972 Miami Dolphins had provided when their latter-day brethren stood in the way of the Chicago Bears perfect run 22 years ago.

title: Bush Says Iran Still a Danger Despite Report on Weapons
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4  President Bush warned today that Iran remained a threat despite an intelligence assessment that it had halted a covert program to develop nuclear weapons four years ago, as the administration struggled to salvage a diplomatic process now in disarray.

title: 2 Are Hurt in New York by Debris From Towers
description: Wind gusts knocked glass or debris from two skyscrapers in Midtown yesterday afternoon, including the new building that houses The New York Times. In each case, a pedestrian was reported to have been injured.

title: Calculating Energy Bills Real Figures
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3  Gas mileage would go up under the compromise reached by Congressional leaders last week, but not as high as the trumpeted numbers. And despite the tougher 35 m.p.g. standard, a growing population of drivers would push up total fuel use, as well as greenhouse gas emissions  but not as rapidly as would occur without the legislation.

title: Forecasters Say Madison Avenue Will Escape a Recession, Just Barely
description: GROWTH in advertising spending in the United States is slowing considerably, according to several forecasters whose predictions are closely followed. But they believe the continuing strength of ad spending online  as well as the stimulative effects of the elections and the Summer Olympics  should keep the industry from suffering a recession in 2008.

title: Diocese in Iowa Settles With Abuse Victims for $37 Million
description: The Roman Catholic Diocese of Davenport, Iowa, has reached a $37 million settlement to compensate victims of sexual abuse by clergy members and let the diocese emerge from bankruptcy, the two sides announced yesterday.

title: China: Insurer Gets Approval for Offering
description: China Pacific Insurance Group, which is part-owned by the Carlyle Group and Prudential Financial, has received approval to sell a billion new shares in a Shanghai offering to bolster its finances and compete with domestic rivals. The listing committee of Chinas securities watchdog agency approved the share sale yesterday, the China Securities Regulatory Commission said on its Web site. China Pacific also plans to sell as many as 900 million shares in a Hong Kong public offering as soon as possible after the mainland initial public offering. The two offerings are expected to raise as much as $6 billion.

title: India Finds Mutated DNA Where Water Is Toxic
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 3  Toxic chemicals in the water in Punjab, Indias grain belt, could be causing genetic mutations in the population, a recent study suggests.

title: New Hall of Famer Stirs Both Sides in Brooklyn
description: Forgive? Perhaps not. Forget? Um, forget about it.

title: A Visit With Mother Russia and Her Children
description: Every literate Russian can quote Pushkin and hum a tune from Glinka. No Russian orchestra on the road is likely to leave either man at home. Valery Gergiev and the Kirov Orchestra of St. Petersburg, in two Carnegie Hall concerts over the weekend and a third scheduled for tonight, have been happy once again to leave other peoples music to other people. Patrons could be assured that Borodin or Rimsky-Korsakov or something kindred was on the way. No one seemed disappointed.

title: Pettitte to Return to the Yankees
description: NASHVILLE  The Yankees came to the winter meetings hoping to land a veteran left-handed starter for the top of their rotation. As the meetings began here on Monday morning, they got one. But it is not Johan Santana.

title: Respect in a Box: Giving John Ford the Major American Artist Treatment
description: Film culture in this country has long been in need of a paradigm shift, a way of saving old films from the swamp of nostalgia and seeing them as vital cultural products rather than quaint artifacts of another age. People dont read Faulkners Light in August to be reminded of their lost youth, but most studios continue to market their library titles (when they bother to market them at all) as so many trips down memory lane.

title: Santana Deal Is Still Alive, but Window May be Closing
description: NASHVILLE, Dec. 3  The Yankees pursuit of Johan Santana showed a flicker of life early Tuesday morning when the Minnesota Twins backed off their demand that the right-hander Ian Kennedy be added to the Yankees trade offer.

title: Ex-Ranger Shows Old Team What It Lost
description: Matt Cullen said he remembered all the good things about playing for the Rangers last season: the jazzed-up atmosphere at Madison Square Garden, the late-season push for the playoffs, scoring the game-winning and series-clinching goal against Atlanta in the first round.

title: Russia: Phone Company Offers to Buy Rival
description: VimpelCom, Russias second-largest cellphone company, has offered to buy a rival, Golden Telecom, for about $4.2 billion to create Russias first integrated mobile and fixed-line provider. VimpelCom offered $105 a share for the Internet, voice and data provider, 3.5 percent higher than the closing price Friday, the companies said. They are in discussions regarding the potential acquisition of all the outstanding common stock of Golden Telecom, according to the statement. VimpelCom, which had more than 61 million subscribers at the end of October in Russia, Armenia, Kazakhstan, Ukraine, Tajikistan, Uzbekistan and Georgia, wants to branch out in more markets and into services like broadband. Golden Telecom said Nov. 8 it had 394,900 broadband subscribers in Russia.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about favorite gadgets of executives referred incorrectly to the video game Gran Turismo 5. It has not yet been released, and thus is not a best-selling game. The article also referred imprecisely to the game Halo 3. It is the first game in the Halo series designed for the Xbox 360; the earlier games, though playable on the Xbox 360, were designed for the original Xbox. The chip in the Xbox 360 also was misidentified. It has a Xenon chip, not a Cell processor. And the article also misstated the price of the Sony PlayStation 3. The PlayStation 3 starts at $399, not $299. (Go to Article)

title: Inveterate Wanderer: An Intercontinental Salamander Family
description: The family of salamanders known as plethodontids are unusual in many ways. For one thing, they dont have lungs. Instead, they get their oxygen through moistened skin.

title: Tired of Corruption but Afraid of the Crackdown
description: HWASUNG, South Korea, Dec. 3  For Choi Hae-pyung, head of an electronics parts maker, running his business over the last year has been like steering a boat through a double storm: competition from China and the rising value of the Korean currency have squeezed his already thin profit.

title: Giulianis Firm Lobbied for Bill Considered Threat
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3  Although Rudolph W. Giuliani is campaigning as President Bushs staunch ally in the war on terror, his law office has lobbied Congress on behalf of legislation that the Bush administration calls a threat to antiterrorism efforts in the Horn of Africa.

title: Role for Actors Equity at American Girl Place
description: Broadway isnt the only place in town that can put on a theatrical labor dispute. On Saturday the adult actors and assistant stage managers who work at the theater in the American Girl Place store on Fifth Avenue at 49th Street voted, for the second time, to take on Actors Equity Association as their bargaining representative. The first election was held in November 2006 after a dramatic summer when 14 of the stores 18 actors, who appear in shows including Circle of Friends: An American Girl Musical and Bitty Bears Matinee: The Family Tree, went on a two-day strike. Though the actors voted to join the union in last years election, American Girl Place charged that Equity had unfairly influenced the voting. Both sides agreed to hold the election again, and the actors voted 9 to 6 in favor of Equity.

title: Council Plans Heftier Fines for Apartments Used as Hotels
description: Many New Yorkers complain that landlords are fleecing them with excessive rents.

title: U.S. Team on Adus Mind, Even in Portugal
description: The education of an American soccer player, Freddy Adu, continues in Portugal.

title: Bank of Canada Unexpectedly Cuts Key Rate
description: OTTAWA, Dec. 4  The Bank of Canada cut its key interest rate today by a quarter-point, to 4.25 percent, citing concerns about the global effect of the subprime loan crisis in the United States. While made for other reasons, the move may provide some relief for exporters that have been suffering from the recent sharp rise in the Canadian dollar.

title: Cracking the Code to the Memory Vault
description: I bless the day 3M invented Post-It notes. I dont think I could survive without them. They decorate my computer, reminding me how to do things like create a folder, undo an error or save an attachment without opening it. They adorn my refrigerator and kitchen cabinets to help me remember what to buy, what to order and when I have to be where.

title: Joseph L. Henderson, 104; Expanded Jungian Methods
description: Joseph L. Henderson, a psychologist and author who was an early practitioner of methods developed by Carl Jung to explore cultural influences on the unconscious mind, died on Nov. 17 in Greenbrae, Calif. He was 104.

title: In the Future, Smart People Will Let Cars Take Control
description: As the baby boomers cruise into their golden years, I have good news for them  and for everyone else in danger of being run over by these aging drivers. The boomers will not be driving like Mr. Magoo. An electronic chauffeur will conduct them on expressways, drop them at the mall entrance and then go park their cars.

title: Promising Season Is Bouncing Away From Saints Bush
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 3  Even a day later, the Saints could not turn away from televised replays of the trick play that seemed to startle no one but themselves. The result was a lost ball for Reggie Bush and perhaps a lost season.

title: Bruno Wont Talk About Role at Firm
description: ALBANY, Dec. 3  Joseph L. Bruno, the State Senate majority leader, declined on Monday to describe what he does for a Connecticut-based money management firm that has employed him for more than a decade.

title: Imus Is Back, Chastened but Still Proudly Obnoxious
description: Nearly eight months after being fired for making a racially and sexually disparaging remark about the Rutgers womens basketball team, Don Imus returned to the radio at 6 a.m. yesterday and vowed he would not say anything like it again.

title: METRO BRIEFING | NEW YORK; Staten Island: Fire Marshals Death Ruled Homicide
description: The death of a 38-year-old city fire marshal who was discovered shot to death in his Staten Island home over the weekend was ruled a homicide yesterday, the authorities said. Detectives were investigating the killing last night, but had made no arrests, the police said. An autopsy showed that the victim, Douglas Mercereau, above, died of gunshot wounds to his head, said a spokeswoman for the city medical examiners office. Mr. Mercereaus wife dialed 911 about 8:25 a.m. on Sunday, the police said, and emergency responders found Mr. Mercereau lying in bed in their home at 90 Tarrington Street. Mr. Mercereau, who joined the Fire Department more than 12 years ago, was promoted to supervising fire marshal last month, a Fire Department spokesman said.

title: How Did a 2005 Estimate Go Awry?
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3  In the summer of 2005, senior American intelligence officials began traveling the world with a secret slide show drawn from thousands of pages that they said were downloaded from a stolen Iranian laptop computer, trying to prove that Iran was lying when it said it had no interest in building a nuclear weapon.

title: Back on Air, Imus Vows to Play Fair
description: Redemption was in the air yesterday. In the air and on the airwaves. There hadnt been so much talk about redeeming since the heyday of S & H Green Stamps.

title: Huckabee Repudiates Groups Effort
description: Mike Huckabee, the Republican presidential candidate, distanced his campaign yesterday from an independent groups efforts to promote his candidacy through calls to the homes of caucusgoers in Iowa and through mailings.

title: Suicidal Gestures at Guantnamo Disclosed
description: GUANTNAMO BAY, Cuba, Dec. 4  A detainee at the military detention camp here cut his throat with his own fingernail, causing substantial blood loss early last month, but was not at risk of death, military officials said today.

title: German Bank Acts to Help Its Programs Tied to U.S. Mortgages
description: FRANKFURT, Dec. 3  In an effort to limit fallout from the subprime lending crisis in the United States, the German bank WestLB said on Monday that it would guarantee full liquidity to several of its investment vehicles that had put money into asset-backed securities.

title: Evolution and Texas
description: Is Texas about to become the next state to undermine the teaching of evolution? That is the scary implication of the abrupt ousting of Christine Comer, the states top expert on science education. Her transgression: forwarding an e-mail message about a talk by a distinguished professor who debunks intelligent design and creationism as legitimate alternatives to evolution in the science curriculum.

title: Memo Pad
description: DELAYS UP, LOST BAGS DOWN The airline delay rate has averaged 23.95 percent of all domestic flights this year through October, the highest in the 12 years since consolidated data have been compiled by the Transportation Departments Bureau of Transportation Statistics. Flight cancellations, at 2.13 percent, were the highest since 2001, when figures were affected by the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. But there was some good news in the data released yesterday. The rate of mishandled bags  bags that are delayed, damaged or lost by airlines  was 5.36 per 1,000 bags, down from 7.49 per 1,000 bags in the same period of 2006.

title: In Victory, Giants Sample Their Playoff Future
description: The Giants would like to think that their come-from-behind victory over the Bears in Chicago will come to represent a turning point, when the growing doubts about a teetering team were finally tucked away.

title: Congress Has a Way of Making Witnesses Speak: Its Own Jail
description: Congress and the White House appear to be headed for a constitutional showdown. The House of Representatives is poised to hold Joshua Bolten, the White House chief of staff, and Harriet Miers, a former White House counsel, in contempt for failing to comply with subpoenas in the United States attorneys scandal. If the Justice Department refuses to enforce the subpoenas, as seems likely, Congress will have to decide whether to do so. Washington lawyers are dusting off an old but apparently sturdy doctrine called inherent contempt that gives Congress the power to bring the recalcitrant witnesses in  by force, if necessary.

title: Politically Charged Prints Cause Talking in the Library
description: Controversy has erupted from the sleepy third-floor hallway galleries at the New York Public Library, where a modest exhibition of contemporary prints called Multiple Interpretations is on view.

title: The Birth of Creativity (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: New Map of Antarctica Brings Frozen Landscape Into Focus
description: A new map of Antarctica displayed last week at the NASA Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Md., combines 1,100 digital satellite images into a mosaic with the most geologically accurate, true-color, high-resolution views of the frozen continent now possible.

title: Brazilians Giving Up Their American Dream
description: Like hundreds of thousands of middle-class Brazilians who moved to the United States over the last two decades, Jose Osvandir Borges and his wife, Elisabeth, came on tourist visas and stayed as illegal immigrants, putting down roots in ways they never expected.

title: Unhappy? Self-Critical? Maybe You're Just a Perfectionist
description: Just about any sports movie, airport paperback or motivational tape delivers a few boilerplate rules for success. Believe in yourself. Dont take no for an answer. Never quit. Dont accept second best.

title: Trend Shows Bye Week Benefits Jets Defense
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Dec. 3  Dissecting the Jets defense requires dividing the past two seasons into segments: before bye and after bye.

title: Simulations of Ailing Artists Eyes Yield New Insights on Style
description: For Claude Monet, 1912-22 was a watershed decade. He was perhaps the most successful artist of his time, and his genius had already assured him a place in history.

title: ON THE ROAD; Bunking Up, Business Class
description: HERE is another depressing trend. With overall costs for business travel expected to rise 6 to 8 percent next year, more companies appear to be saving on lodging by having employees share hotel rooms on business trips, according to Orbitz for Business.

title: Getting Help When Fire Destroys Everything
description: The sound of a window bursting at 2 a.m. saved their lives.

title: Paulson Sees Limited Aid in Rate Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3  The Bush administrations effort to help borrowers in danger of defaulting on their subprime mortgages could help only a small number of those who took out such loans, industry analysts said Monday.

title: Education for Smokers
description: To the Editor:

title: Candidates Hold to Their Stances on Iran
description: MANCHESTER, N.H., Dec. 3  The campaigns of the leading Democratic candidates seized Monday on an intelligence report showing that Iran had halted its development of nuclear weapons, saying the findings justified their more cautious approach to Tehran.

title: Girls Make History by Sweeping Top Honors at a Science Contest
description: Girls won top honors for the first time in the Siemens Competition in Math, Science and Technology, one of the nations most coveted student science awards, which were announced yesterday at New York University.

title: As Clock Ticks, Congress and White House Stand Firm
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3  President Bush and Congressional Democrats were at a stalemate Monday over federal spending, taxes, domestic surveillance and the war in Iraq, and neither side made a move to negotiate, even though lawmakers have just a few weeks left to wrap up work for the year.

title: Indian Bloom in a Borough Nighttown
description: To some people Queens Boulevard means the sprawling road in the New York City borough, and to plenty of us Queens Boulevard is the title of the arty black-and-white film that Vince on the HBO series Entourage took to Sundance. Charles Mees Queens Boulevard (the Musical) is positioned halfway between the two. Trying to reflect an ordinary multicultural world while adding vague artistic pretensions, the play doesnt come through on either count.

title: Manhattan: 3 Charged in Identity Theft Scheme
description: A man and two women were arrested last Tuesday at a Bank of America on 97th Street and Broadway as they tried to withdraw money by using stolen identification, a police source close to the investigation said yesterday. The three, Charles Belim, 51, Crystal Velasquez, 30, and Kimberly Tucker, 30, all of Manhattan, have been charged with forgery and identity theft, the police said. The women were charged with wearing wigs, scarves and makeup to mimic the photographs on drivers licenses, the source said. Officers from the Manhattan North Grand Larceny Unit seized 11 stolen credit cards, three drivers licenses, wigs and sunglasses, the police source said.

title: Turner Prize Winner Is Announced
description: Mark Wallinger was named the winner yesterday of the Turner Prize, given annually to a British artist younger than 50 for an outstanding exhibition or other presentation of work in the 12 months preceding May 8, the BBC reported. The actor and director Dennis Hopper presented Mr. Wallinger, left, with the $50,000 award at the Tate Liverpool gallery, where the ceremony was held outside London for the first time since the prize was established in 1984. Mr. Wallinger was nominated for an exhibition at Tate Britain that featured banners and other material used by the peace protester Brian Haw during his six-year vigil outside the Houses of Parliament. Mr. Wallingers entry in the exhibition of nominees work in Liverpool was a video of himself dressed in a furry bear suit wandering as if in a daze around a modern art gallery in Berlin.

Four deaths were attributed to the bad weather.

The meetings came after talks on forming a government collapsed over the weekend, nearly six months after elections.

title: Accounting Errors Cause Plunge in VeriFone Shares

title: Staten Island: Charges in Drag-Racing Death
description: Two drivers who the police said were drag-racing when they had an accident that killed a 17-year-old passenger in one of their cars in July were indicted yesterday on manslaughter charges. The drivers, Anthony Reis, 18, and Joseph Donovan, 17, were both driving more than 80 miles an hour on Veterans Road West at the south end of Staten Island on July 25 when Mr. Donovans car struck Mr. Reiss, the Staten Island district attorneys office said. The crash killed one of Mr. Donovans passengers, Michelle Arout, 17, and injured several others. Both men were charged with second-degree manslaughter, which carries a sentence of up to 15 years in prison.

title: Red Crescent Says 25,000 Iraqi Refugees Have Returned

The figure represents a fraction of the estimated 1.5 million Iraqis who fled to Syria in recent years to escape the sectarian violence and ethnic cleansing in Iraq.

title: A Few Helping Hands With Eldercare
description: After my post yesterday about the challenges of eldercare, I wanted to suggest Web sites that caregivers can use for information and support on a variety of issues. Not surprisingly, the people behind these resources have firsthand experience with eldercare  just another one of the ways people are shaping their careers based on their own life experiences.AGIS is an online eldercare site founded by Kevin Sypniewski, who has spent a lot of time thinking about caring for those who need extra care. His developmentally disabled brother, who died at 31, needed care throughout his life. His sister is a special education teacher, and his mother worked as a nurse in a special education school district. Mr. Sypniewski helped care for his mother, his stepfather, and most recently for his father, who all died of cancer. My family was exposed to these issues through a train of close relatives needing care in the late 1990s and early 2000s, he told me. But it is something all baby boomers will be dealing with.

The table is in the modest, rent-stabilized apartment of Robert Plautz, 60, a tax lawyer and longtime Democratic activist. The Ravens certainly had the right personnel to follow up on the Eagles defensive strategy from last week, but who knew their offense would be able to help out, too? Willis McGahee, who said he was playing for his fellow Miami Hurricane Sean Taylor, kept Tom Brady off the field by grinding out 138 yards on 30 carries. It was only the third game this season the Patriots did not lead in time of possession. title: Blood Ties and Acts of Love
description: As I look at my ever-growing and protruding belly, I find myself fascinated by the biological processes at play: sperm, egg, and a baby being made. I imagine that any woman experiencing this process for the first time would find it, as I do, an exciting but mystifying and often uncomfortable journey. In my own first three months I wondered, Why does anyone go through this?   As an adopted person my context for the way babies come into the world is through adoption, not birth. Of course I understand birth, but that is not the way I came into my family. I did not grow up knowing the people who gave birth to me. But I do not doubt the labor my adoptive parents went through to get me. It consisted of mounds of paperwork and home studies that stretched over two years. I thank God pregnancy is just 9 months.   In anticipating the birth of my child, I feel like an explorer getting ready to delve into a foreign land that is also somehow familiar. I did not grow up in the culture of blood; I grew up in the culture of adoption. The ties that bind me to my family are not based in biology. They are based in relationship.   But for the first time, I and my husband - who happens to also be adopted from South Korea - will, through our child, know what it is to be connected with someone who also shares our genes. And I must admit there is something delicious about finally being a part of the majority.   But it could get complicated. Like when we have to make a family tree. And have to explain how our little Korean child came from Irish, German, English and Italian ancestry. Although our child will look at our faces and will see familiar curves and lines, the extended family will not look as familiar. And so we will have to explain our adoption so our child can understand why grandma has blond hair and grandpa has blue eyes and we don't.   Part of the legacy we will also give our child is the loss of genetic ancestry. We will have to explain why mommy and daddy did not grow up with the parents who gave birth to them and why we got new families. And even though I have met my birth family, I do not know the family history. And knowing the history is not just knowing one's genes, it's knowing the stories going back generations.   Even though I hope to someday bring our child to Korea to meet extended biological kin, my husband and I cannot provide all of the skills needed to be effective in that culture. We don't speak Korean in the home; nor do we cook Korean food regularly. Although we have become very knowledgeable about Korean culture and have connections to the Korean-American community, I wonder about our ability to nurture our child's racial and cultural identity.   I am relieved, though, that my child will not have to answer the question "Why were you born?" the way I had to answer the question, "Why were you adopted?" I am glad that my child will not be told by well-meaning strangers he or she is "lucky" to have been born. And I certainly won't tell my child to be grateful because I brought them into the world. And if my child feels any gratitude toward me I hope it is because I earned it.   It will be important to remind ourselves that it is because of our own needs, not theirs, that we bring children into our lives to parent. Being able to have the gift of a child born to me allows me to reconnect to that which I had lost as a consequence of adoption. But I also know that to also have the gift of a child adopted by me would allow me to continue the culture I most understand -- the culture of adoption.   I anticipate that generations and generations after me will slowly erase my history. They will most likely forget that their great-great-great grandmother had to learn to be Korean. That she came to America at 3 and a half years old in a little red pant suit and vest, and white sweater trimmed in red. That she cried to return to her motherland. And that the mothershe loved had blond hair and the father she loved was an Irishman. Ultimately I want generations after me to know this about the culture of blood and the culture of adoption: That blood is thicker than water, but love can be thicker than blood.
