description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 4  Cardinal Roger Mahony, the leader of the Archdiocese of Los Angeles, told fellow priests that he was assaulted last summer by a man who yelled angry statements about the sexual abuse of children by Roman Catholic priests.

title: Signs of New Life in Wi-Fi Cameras
description: THE camera world has periodically heralded the Wi-Fi revolution. Soon, we were told, cameras would download images effortlessly and quickly without wires or even a computer.

title: Inviting an Old Favorite to the Hanukkah Table
description: IT is probably impossible for many people to hear the word babka and not think of the Seinfeld episode in which Jerry and Elaine, desperate to bring a chocolate babka to a dinner party, angrily confront another customer at a bakery who gets the last one. They settle for cinnamon, even though Elaine calls it a lesser babka.

title: Correction: Recipe: Back Forty
description: A recipe with the Pairings column last Wednesday for a Back Forty cocktail misstated the amount of orange bitters that should be used. It is three to five dashes, not three to five ounces.

title: Edwards Takes Step Back as Two Others Slug It Out
description: DES MOINES, Dec. 4  As Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama exchanged frequent and increasingly personal jabs on the campaign trail this week, John Edwards found himself on the sidelines. And enjoying it.

title: A Blue Blood New in Name Only
description: London

title: Obama and Race: What Affects a Voters Choice?
description: To the Editor:

title: An Old Smoothie Turns Up a New Idea
description: WHEN my children were little, I fell into the habit of peeling and freezing overripe bananas, then using them to whip up a morning shake with yogurt, milk and maple syrup.

title: When It Looks at You, Its Done
description: OF all the exquisite, sultan-worthy delicacies that were arrayed before me during a recent trip to Istanbul, the last one I would have expected to fall in love with was a humble bulgur pilaf.

title: A Heart Stent Maker Decides the Way to the Patient Is Through the Patient
description: FOOTBALL fans who tuned in to watch the Dallas Cowboys crush the New York Jets on Thanksgiving Day saw at least one novel play: the first attempt by a medical device maker to market a heart stent directly to consumers.

title: NFL Network Prolongs a Disconnect With Fans
description: The only way I could watch the NFL Networks broadcast of the Green Bay-Dallas game last Thursday night was on NFL.com, which streamed parts of the game, but occupied users with extensive blather from a C-level, hyperbolic studio crew.

title: Cabrera and Willis May Join Tigers in Eight-Player Trade
description: NASHVILLE, Dec. 4  While most of the baseball world has been monitoring every detail of the Johan Santana sweepstakes, the Florida Marlins and the Detroit Tigers were operating in their own world as they worked to complete an eight-player trade.

title: Supreme Court Hears Medical Device Case
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4  Whether a federal statute pre-empts state law is a familiar issue at the Supreme Court, one the justices will face multiple times during the current term alone.

title: Canada Banks Rate Cut May Not Help Exporters
description: OTTAWA, Dec. 4  The unexpected decision by the Bank of Canada on Tuesday to cut its key interest rate by a quarter-point, to 4.25 percent, will probably do little to help exporters struggling to cope with a rising Canadian dollar, economists said.

title: Newark: Two Charged in Bank Robbery
description: Two men have been arrested and charged with brandishing handguns during a bank robbery in Piscataway on Nov. 10 in which they took more than $93,000, according to complaints filed with the United States attorneys office. One of the men, Ruben Rosado, pointed his pistol at bank employees and customers as they lay on the floor, while the other, Michael Green, vaulted over the tellers counter at Investors Savings Bank and dumped cash from the registers into a bag before the duo fled in a stolen car, the complaints charged. Mr. Green was arrested after a witness led the police to a barbershop in Perth Amboy, court papers said. Mr. Green identified his accomplice as Mr. Rosado, the papers said. He appeared in federal court on Monday and was being held without bail, said Michael Drewniak, a spokesman for the United States attorney in New Jersey. Mr. Green pleaded not guilty yesterday to one count of armed bank robbery and was being held pending a bail hearing, said his lawyer, Richard Verde.

title: Recipe: Chocolate Almond Paste Filling With Rum-Soaked Raisins
description: Adapted from Mrs. Londons, Saratoga Springs, N.Y.

title: Bomb Explodes in Pakistan, Killing Woman Carrying It
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan, Dec. 4  A woman who the police said was a suicide bomber was blown up in an explosion in a high security military cantonment here on Tuesday, police and security officials said.

title: Officer Arraigned in Bronx Shooting
description: A New York City Police officer pleaded not guilty today to a charge of first degree manslaughter in the fatal shooting of an unarmed building porter after a car accident in May, when the officer was off duty.

title: Romarios Defense
description: The Brazilian star Romario has attributed his failed drug test to a substance found in anti-balding medication. Romario, a 41-year-old striker who was FIFAs player of the year in 1994, said yesterday that he tested positive for the banned substance finasteride in October. He said he had been using the drug, whose active ingredient is Propecia, to prevent hair loss.

title: Crossing a Threshold on Energy Legislation
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4  A moment that has been a generation in the making arrives here this week, with Congress poised to act on the first bill to increase vehicle fuel efficiency significantly since 1975 and on the first economywide bill to address global warming since scientists raised the alarm in the late 1980s.

title: Activisions Chief Looks for Gamings Next Moves
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 4  Guitar Hero III, a video game sweeping the nation like a Top 40 tune, lets players strum along on a toy plastic guitar to rock songs played on a television screen. It is attracting a wide audience: children, teenagers, 40-somethings, even the elderly.

title: Precursor of the Constitution Goes on Display in Queens
description: The Flushing Remonstrance made a rare visit yesterday to the old neighborhood.

title: Curbing Junk Food
description: To the Editor:

title: Gift Cards Go Philanthropic
description: THIS year, the use of gift cards, many of which are bought and redeemed online, has merged with another venerable holiday tradition: charitable donations made in the name of gift recipients.

title: Top Officials Greet Gates in Kabul With Pleas
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Dec. 4  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates heard appeals on Tuesday from Afghanistans most senior government and military leaders for more money, weapons and security trainers as 2007 brought the greatest spike in insurgent violence since the Taliban and Al Qaeda were routed six years ago.

title: Calendar
description: Fish From Sicily

title: 37-Month Sentence for Priest Who Defrauded Parish
description: NEW HAVEN, Dec. 4  Telling him, Not even the collar can protect you from prison, Judge Janet Bond Arterton ordered a 37-month sentence Tuesday for the Rev. Michael Jude Fay, the Roman Catholic priest who admitted pilfering $1.3 million from the church he had led in Darien.

title: Freedom Just Ahead: The War Within the Civil War
description: The chaos of Civil War meant only one thing to Americas four million slaves: hope. With armies on the march, and the old social order crumbling, men like John Washington and Wallace Turnage seized the moment and made a break for freedom, issuing their own emancipation proclamations before the fact. They were quiet heroes of a war within the war to destroy slavery, as David W. Blight puts it in A Slave No More.

title: Socializing in the Digital Age
description: To the Editor:

title: In Japan, Rural Economies Wane as Cities Thrive
description: NOSHIRO, Japan  The only outward sign of conflict here is the red flags of protest, but this small logging city on Japans remote northern coast is seething.

title: Is the Entree Heading for Extinction?
description: THE entree, long the undisputed centerpiece of an American restaurant meal, is dead.

title: Ethanol Advocates Push for More in Regular Cars
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5  With ethanol production threatening to grow faster than the existing fleet of cars and complex of service stations can absorb it, lobbyists opened a push today to fuel ordinary cars to run on blends of 20 percent to 30 percent ethanol, compared with 10 percent now.

title: Teacher Tells of Time in Sudanese Jail Over Teddy Bear
description: LONDON, Dec. 4  Arriving back in Britain after more than a week in a Sudanese jail, the school teacher who allowed her seven-year-old students to name a class teddy bear Muhammad said today that she was "very upset to think that I may have caused offense to people.

title: Biking the Expressway? This Could Beat a Map
description: LIKE many vaguely serious cyclists, I view maps as one of the sports most important accessories. Part of it is self-preservation. One wrong turn on an exhausting ride that delays the trip home by an hour or two prompts anyone to study maps.

title: Heavyweights at the Garden
description: Madison Square Garden announced that it would stage a heavyweight title fight Feb. 23 between Wladimir Klitschko of Ukraine and Sultan Ibragimov of Russia. The 31-year-old Klitschko (49-3, 44 knockouts) is recognized as champion by the International Boxing Federation and the International Boxing Organization. Ibragimov (22-0-1, 17 knockouts), 32, is the 2000 Olympic silver medalist and the champion of the World Boxing Organization. Their fight will unify three of the five heavyweight titles.

title: Bush and Stem Cells
description: To the Editor:

title: A Ballet Love Story Comes to an End on an Icy Road
description: As sure as the weather grows cold and the holidays approach, dancers from American Ballet Theater and other major companies fan out to regional theaters for performances of The Nutcracker, a fixture in the world of dance and the minds of young ballerinas.

title: Shuttle to Put European Module in Space
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Dec. 4  The space shuttle Atlantis is poised for a Thursday launching to the International Space Station on an 11-day mission that will make the orbital outpost more international.

title: The Thin Line Between Civilian and Military Nuclear Programs
description: For years, American intelligence agencies contended that Iran had a clandestine nuclear weapons program. But even as Tehran continues to enrich uranium, which could fuel a bomb, the agencies have reversed themselves, saying the Iranians halted their weapons program in 2003.

title: Recipe: Cinnamon-Raisin Filling
description: Adapted from Katja Goldman

title: Pimp C, Southern Hip-Hop Rapper, Dies at 33
description: Pimp C, the rapper who helped define Southern hip-hop with his group, UGK, was found dead in a hotel room in West Hollywood, Calif., yesterday morning. He was 33.

title: Verizon Is Denied a Rate Request
description: Federal regulators yesterday denied a request by Verizon Communications to let it charge rival carriers higher rates to get access to lines in six East Coast markets.

title: Navigators Everywhere, Especially on Holiday Gift Lists
description: JUDGING from the holiday-season popularity of G.P.S. navigators, there are few gestures more satisfying than telling the person you love, You have no sense of direction, but dont worry  modern technology can help.

title: Bush Insists Iran Remains a Threat Despite Arms Data
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4  President Bush warned on Tuesday that Iran remained a threat despite an intelligence assessment that it had halted a covert program to develop nuclear weapons four years ago, as the administration struggled to save a diplomatic process now in disarray.

title: Canada: Trading System Is Delayed
description: The Instinet unit of Nomura Holdings has delayed the start of its Canadian stock trading system until the middle of the first quarter to give investors time to adjust to new equity markets. Instinet said in June that it planned to bring its alternative trading system to Canada by the end of December. Instinets Chi-X Canada platform is one of at least three alternative trading systems being developed in Canada in the next year to compete with the TSX Group, owner of the Toronto Stock Exchange. Perimeter Financial plans to start its Omega ATS on Dec. 6 and Alpha Trading Systems, owned by a group led by six banks, plans to start its trading platform in late 2008.

title: Plaza Hotels, Plain and Fancy, Spar on Name
description: LAS VEGAS, Dec. 4  One is to be a luxurious $5 billion complex that will evoke the cachet of its New York namesake in an increasingly posh part of the Strip. The other is a weathered 35-year-old joint in this citys decaying downtown core with $39 rooms and a buffet that always costs $7.77.

title: Businessman Details Payments to Former Canadian Premier
description: OTTAWA, Dec. 4  Karlheinz Schreiber, a former West German intelligence officer, lobbyist, arms dealer and political fund-raiser, used a parliamentary committee hearing Tuesday to both insult and support his onetime ally, former Prime Minister Brian Mulroney.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about operational changes at The Associated Press referred imprecisely to job cuts at Reuters, one of its competitors. The London-based company cut 3,000 jobs companywide over a three-year period starting in 2003; the layoffs were not aimed at the news wire service, which is only part of Reuterss operations. (The number of full-time journalists employed by Reuters has remained flat, at about 2,400, since 2000.) The article also referred imprecisely to revenue trends at Reuters. Since the annual loss that inspired the layoffs, revenue at both the overall company and in the media division, which includes the wire service, has grown; the revenue has not fallen over the last decade. (Go to Article)

title: Curtains Rise Again
description: TRAVERSE CITY, Mich., Dec. 1  When the director Michael Moore moved to northern Michigan from New York City in 2002, the marquee of the State Theater on Front Street here had been dark since 1978. It was a sullen space in this Great Lake citys central business district.

title: Church Sues New York City Over Its Catering Permit
description: A lawsuit against New York City is the latest volley in a yearlong battle between a Christian Science church on Park Avenue and its well-to-do neighbors, who do not want the church building rented out for social events.

title: Extension for Tommy Bowden
description: Clemson University gave Coach Tommy Bowden a contract extension after ESPN reported that Arkansas was focusing on Bowden to lead its program. Terms of the extension were not available, the team said in a news release. Bowden made $1.2 million this season. Bowden led Clemson to a 9-3 record and an appearance in the Chick-fil-A Bowl against Auburn on Dec. 31.

title: Aide Arrested in Sex Sting
description: A former aide to Senator Maria Cantwell, Democrat of Washington, is in federal custody after being arrested on a charge of attempting to sexually exploit a minor. Hours after his arrest on Friday, the aide, James M. McHaney, 28, was dismissed from his job as a scheduler for Ms. Cantwell. The F.B.I. said in a charging document that Mr. McHaney tried to set up a meeting with an undercover witness posing online as a 13-year-old boy. Mr. McHaney was being held without bail pending a hearing today, said Channing Phillips, a spokesman for the United States attorneys office for the District of Columbia.

title: Mitt Romney Is No Jack Kennedy
description: INEVITABLY, Mitt Romneys long-awaited speech on faith and religious freedom tomorrow at the George Bush Presidential Library at Texas A&M will be compared to John F. Kennedys 1960 speech to Protestant ministers in Houston, just 90 miles away. Like Kennedy, Mr. Romney faces questions about his religious beliefs and how they might affect his judgments as president. Also like Kennedy, Mr. Romney realizes  and polls demonstrate  that a sizable number of voters (again, mostly Southern white Protestants) oppose him because of his religion.

title: A Haven Becomes a Dilemma
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 4  When the Lebanese police caught him in a routine sweep earlier this year, Jaffar Sadiq al-Lami, an illegal Iraqi immigrant, figured he would spend a month or two in jail and be released with a warning, like the previous two times he had been arrested.

title: Wall Street Firms Subpoenaed in Subprime Inquiry
description: Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo of New York has subpoenaed major Wall Street firms including Merrill Lynch, Morgan Stanley and Deutsche Bank, seeking information about the business of packaging and selling subprime mortgages, according to people briefed on the subpoenas.

title: From Ireland, Love Songs in the Key of Desperation
description: The title character in Pumpgirl is a butch gas station attendant, described by a local lout as a woman who walks like John Wayne and looks like his horse. The louts friend and Pumpgirls sometime lover is an amateur race car driver called Hammy, who proudly announces, They dont call me No Helmet for nothing. One of the wonders of Abbie Spallens fiercely observed, unflinching play is that we can see how the utter lack of options  and imagination  in this Irish town could have driven Pumpgirl and Hammy into their affair, and Hammys wife, Sinead, to a one-night stand with a brute. Sometimes love is blind; sometimes its just this desperate.

title: 2 Airlines to Cut Back Plans for Increases in Capacity
description: Delta Air Lines and Southwest Airlines will scale back seating-capacity plans for next year on mounting concern over high oil prices and a weakening United States economy.

title: Europeans Toughen Line on the Dollars Weakness
description: PARIS, Dec. 4  European policy makers hardened their tone this week on the decline of the dollar, as economists trimmed their growth forecasts for the 13-nation euro area and major manufacturers like Airbus threatened to move factories overseas.

title: Free Universal Music Downloads on New Nokia Phones
description: LONDON, Dec. 4  Nokia, the telecommunications company, and the Universal Music Group, the recording company, said on Tuesday that they would offer unlimited free downloads of Universal songs to buyers of certain Nokia phones as a way to promote cellphones as media devices and to develop new revenue for a music industry struggling with piracy.

title: New Pact for Tuberville
description: Auburn Coach Tommy Tuberville reportedly agreed to a two-year contract extension yesterday that includes a $200,000 annual raise and ends speculation he might leave for another job.Tuberville told The Birmingham News and The Huntsville Times that he and Athletic Director Jay Jacobs reached an agreement that would run through the 2013 season. Tuberville, who had been mentioned as a candidate for the now-filled Texas A&M job and the Arkansas opening, will make $2.8 million next season, escalating to $3.8 million in the final year, the two newspapers reported.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Lou Dobbs Hears Radio Calling

title: Fund Crisis in Florida Worrisome to States
description: Top Florida officials moved yesterday to stabilize an investment pool for local governments after a multibillion-dollar run prompted the state to temporarily suspend withdrawals by cities and school districts.

title: White Helps the Devils Find the Right Edge
description: NEWARK, Dec. 4  Things are changing in the Devils world. They now practice at their new rink inside Prudential Center, next to cardboard boxes of nuts and bolts stacked on wooden pallets, and Colin White, their stoic defenseman, wears a face shield.

title: New Post for Archie Manning
description: Archie Manning succeeded Ron Johnson yesterday as chairman of the National Football Foundation and College Football Hall of Fame. Manning, an All-America quarterback at Mississippi, was inducted into the Hall in 1989. He played 14 seasons in the N.F.L., and his sons Peyton and Eli are N.F.L. quarterbacks. Johnson, a running back, was inducted into the Hall in 1992. He played for Michigan and then seven seasons in the N.F.L.

title: With New Data, U.S. Revises Its View of Iran
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4  How could American intelligence agencies have overstated Irans intentions in 2005 so soon after being reprimanded for making similar errors involving Iraq?

title: For Struggling Black College, Hopes of a Revival
description: MARSHALL, Tex.  When the light at University Avenue is green, drivers can pass Wiley College without a glance. There was a time, however, when this small black liberal arts college here caught the attention of a nation: in the 1930s, Wileys polished team of debaters amassed a series of victories over white competitors that stunned the Jim Crow South.

title: Monitoring Agency Praises U.S. Report, but Keeps Wary Eye on Iran
description: PARIS, Dec. 4  The International Atomic Energy Agency on Tuesday publicly embraced the new American intelligence assessment stating that Iran had halted its nuclear weapons effort, but in truth the agency is taking a more cautious approach in drawing conclusions about Irans nuclear program.

title: No Charges of Perjury for Ex-Aide
description: ALBANY, Dec. 4  The Albany County district attorney has decided not to bring a perjury case against a former top press assistant to Gov. Eliot Spitzer at this point, though he has not ruled out revisiting the case next year, according to several people involved in the case.

title: Legal Challenge to Rowling
description: The publisher RDR Books picked up an ally yesterday in its legal battle against J. K. Rowling for the right to publish the Harry Potter Lexicon, a reference guide to the Harry Potter books and films. The Fair Use Project of Stanford Law Schools Center for Internet and Society said it had signed on as co-counsel to defend RDR. Ms. Rowling sued in October to block publication of the lexicon, saying plans for the book, a print counterpart of a fan Web site (hp-lexicon.org), would interfere with her own intention to compile a Harry Potter encyclopedia.

title: Forget It, Jake, Its Koreatown
description: Undoing, by the writer and director Chris Chan Lee, buries a potentially haunting pulp thriller beneath flashy tics.

title: Afghan Bomber Hits NATO Convoy
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Dec. 4  A suicide car bomber crashed into a two-car NATO convoy on the Kabul airport road on Tuesday morning, wounding 22 Afghan civilians on their way to work.

title: Wheres the Stick?
description: Two weeks ago, in a major policy shift, Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. endorsed the notion that some at-risk mortgages should be modified en masse, rather than on a case-by-case basis. Common sense and the public interest drove the switch: With the subprime lending scandal portending up to 2 million foreclosures through 2008, too many troubled borrowers would be homeless before there was time to work out their loans individually, harming them and entire communities.

title: Seven Days in December?
description: WASHINGTON

title: Take Me to Starbucks if You Cant Amuse Me
description: IT was a normal trip home from Grandmas Thanksgiving feast, except that we had Emily in the back seat complaining, in British English and Brazilian Portuguese, that cucumber upsets my stomach. She also kept asking if anyone spoke Afrikaans and telling us that she was terrified of spiders. No, Grandma did not serve English tea and finger sandwiches instead of turkey and stuffing. And no, Emily is not a gastrically challenged, bilingual, arachnophobic exchange student. Instead, our 9- and 11-year-olds were passing the time by building the silliest phrases they could find from the translation software loaded on our Garmin Nuvi G.P.S. unit and delivered by Emily, a synthesized voice. The units Language Guide not only lets users translate a wide range of travel phrases  from transportation questions to accommodation issues  but it can amuse a carful of weary travelers.

title: Chinas Turtles, Emblems of a Crisis
description: CHANGSHA, China  Unnoticed and unappreciated for five decades, a large female turtle with a stained, leathery shell is now a precious commodity in this citys decaying zoo. She is fed a special diet of raw meat. Her small pool has been encased with bulletproof glass. A surveillance camera monitors her movements. A guard is posted at night.

title: Modernity Takes the Stage, Captured by Czech Cameras
description: Czech Vision at the Howard Greenberg Gallery pursues one of the many leads tossed out by Foto: Modernity in Central Europe, 1918-1945, the revelatory overview of interwar photography on view at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum. The photographers working in Czechoslovakia are especially tantalizing at the museum. At Greenberg, with 63 early prints by 21 of them, they seem to form a nearly complete microcosm of modernity.

title: Songs in the Street, Revolution in the Air
description: The tiny, tough, sneakily moving film The Violin wears its revolutionary romanticism on its sleeve, not far from its gun. Set amid the mountains of the southern Pacific Coast state of Guerrero, Mexico, home of both touristic pleasures and peasant revolt, it blends fablelike simplicity with documentary touches to tell the story of a near-primordial struggle between the haves and the have-nots. For the three generations of one indigenous family who travel to small, dusty towns, playing their music for coins, the struggle is written on their unsmiling faces and in their plaintive, haunting songs.

title: Dell to Resume Stock Buyback
description: Dell Inc., the personal computer maker, said yesterday that it would resume its stock-buyback program with a $10 billion repurchase, the first since it restated four years of earnings.

title: In a New Merger, Evidence of How Much the Gaming World Has Changed
description: As recently as three years ago, if you told a top game industry executive that your favorite genre was online PC games, you would almost invariably provoke a reaction akin to telling a television mogul that your favorite shows explain the migration patterns of obscure African fauna. In other words, you would get the verbal equivalent of a condescending pat on the head  Oh, thats nice  while the executive looked around for someone with something more relevant to say.

title: Justices Hear Arguments in Guantnamo Cases
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5  A lawyer for six detainees held at the Guantnamo Bay naval base in Cuba and the chief lawyer for the Bush administration waged a spirited argument before the Supreme Court today on whether the detainees have adequate means to challenge their captivity.

title: Gunman Kills 8 People, Then Himself at a Mall in Omaha
description: OMAHA, Dec. 5  A gunman dressed in camouflage and wielding a rifle opened fire inside a mall crowded with holiday shoppers today, killing eight people and wounding five others, before turning the gun on himself. The shooter, who was identified by authorities as Robert A. Hawkins, 19, was described by friends and family members as a troubled, depressed person who had struggled to hold a job.

title: Dining Briefs
description: NEW PLACES

title: Recipe: Strawberry-Yogurt Smoothie
description: Time: 5 minutes

title: South African Miners Strike for Better Safety Conditions
description: JOHANNESBURG, Dec. 4  South Africas crucial mining sector was hit Tuesday by its biggest strike in two decades, as tens of thousands of workers stayed home to protest poor safety conditions that contribute to the high death rate among miners.

title: Liquor Ads on TV
description: To the Editor:

title: Strong Report on Jobs Lifts Stocks
description: Stocks rose sharply today, erasing two days of declines, after investors cheered a surprisingly strong report on employment. But the Federal Reserve may face a more complicated landscape as it considers whether to cut interest rates again next week.

title: Lawsuit Winners Assured Payments Will Continue
description: As far as Eric Rabinowitz knew, there was no problem with the checks from an insurance company that he had been receiving since he was a teenager, for damage to his right eye. His limited vision prevented him from holding a regular job, and he depended on the insurance money to pay for his apartment and other expenses.

title: Crises Dull That New Prime Minister Shine
description: LONDON, Dec. 4  When he took office last summer, Prime Minister Gordon Brown presented himself as the anti-Tony Blair: colorless but capable, dour but trustworthy. The idea was that he would be a burst of cool Scottish forthrightness after the murky spin and dissembling that had come to characterize perceptions of Mr. Blairs played-out government.

title: City Names Six Schools to Close After Poor Grades
description: In the first fallout from the Bloomberg administrations controversial new school report cards, the city named six schools yesterday that will be shut down after earning Ds and Fs.

title: That Sound Upstairs Is Jam Master Junior
description: AS disc jockeys have morphed from the anonymous spinners of old into stars in their own right, the ranks of aspiring turntablists have increased exponentially.

title: One Eye on Opera, the Other on France
description: James Levines directorship in Boston has turned out to be a good thing for New Yorkers who admire his work outside the opera house. When the Metropolitan Opera was his main American podium, his symphonic appearances in New York were limited to his Carnegie Hall series with the Met Orchestra. Now he turns up regularly with the Boston Symphony as well, effectively doubling his appearances conducting nonoperatic work.

title: President of Brazilian Senate Resigns Over Corruption Scandal
description: BRASLIA, Dec. 4  The president of Brazils senate, Renan Calheiros, resigned his leadership post to avoid being expelled from Congress by his fellow senators because of a lengthy corruption scandal.

title: Junior Fear Abroad
description: Bologna, Italy

title: Intercepting Irans Take on America
description: There are two intelligence analyses that are relevant to the balance of power between the U.S. and Iran  one is the latest U.S. assessment of Iran, which certainly gave a much more complex view of what is happening there. The other is the Iranian National Intelligence Estimate of America, which  my guess  would read something like this:

title: Democrats Confront Immigration in Debate
description: DES MOINES, Dec. 4  If there is one issue that has challenged presidential candidates of both parties in Iowa this year, it is immigration, and the Democratic contenders were confronted with it again Tuesday, in a provocative way. Should American citizens, they were asked, turn in someone they know to be an illegal immigrant?

title: Lottery Numbers
A Liquor of Legend Makes a Comeback
description: EARLIER this year, when Lance Winters heard that absinthe was being sold in the United States again for the first time since 1912, he shrugged it off. Then he reconsidered. Hed spent 11 years perfecting an absinthe at St. George Spirits, the distillery where he works in Alameda, Calif., and considered it one of the best things hed ever made. Why not sell it?

title: Off the Menu
description: Open Now

title: Germany: Tempelhof Airport to Close Next Year
description: Tempelhof Airport in Berlin, known for one of the most important stories in aviation history, the Berlin Airlift of 1948 and 1949, will permanently close on Oct. 31, 2008, Germanys top administrative court ruled, ending legal challenges by airlines to keep it open.

title: Space Shuttle Widow Is Ready to Move on From Rituals of Loss
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 3  By now, nearly five years after her husband died when the space shuttle Columbia broke apart over Texas just 16 minutes before its scheduled landing at Cape Canaveral, the astronauts widow has a meticulous list of the things to pack for remembering him in public.

title: Ex-I.M.F. Director Is Named Lazard Investment Executive
description: Lazard, the investment bank run by Bruce Wasserstein, said yesterday that it had hired the former managing director of the International Monetary Fund as a top executive for its investment banking unit.

title: Good and Bad News About Iran
description: There is a lot of good news in the latest intelligence assessment about Iran. Tehran, we are now told, halted its secret nuclear weapons program in 2003, which means that President Bush has absolutely no excuse for going to war against Iran. We are also relieved that the intelligence community is now willing to question its own assumptions and challenge the White Houses fevered rhetoric. The president and his aides are apparently too worried about getting caught again shaving intelligence to stop that.

title: Latin Lessons: O Tempora! O Mores!
description: To the Editor:

title: Russell Crowe Takes Role Brad Pitt Left
description: Exit Brad Pitt. Enter Russell Crowe. Mr. Crowe, below, has agreed to star for Universal Studios as an investigative journalist looking into the murder of a lawmakers mistress in the film State of Play, Variety reported. Mr. Pitt abruptly bowed out of the production before Thanksgiving, when his representatives indicated that he was not happy with the script, a situation complicated by the writers strike. The decision by Mr. Crowe left State of Play on course to go before the cameras this year.

title: California: Water Plan Is Revived
description: San Diego took another step toward a pilot project that would purify treated sewage to increase the supply of drinking water in a reservoir. The City Council voted 5 to 3 to override a veto by Mayor Jerry Sanders, who had rejected the plan as costly, unnecessary and unpopular with the public. The citys Water Department will now write a plan for the project, which would make San Diego, confronting possible water shortages next year, one of the few places in the country that augments drinking water reservoirs with purified sewage.

title: More Time Given to Art Sales Opponents
description: Opponents have won more time to bar the financially pinched Randolph College from selling four paintings from its collection of American art. The Virginia Supreme Court extended until Feb. 15 their deadline for raising $1 million to keep in place an injunction against the auction, The Associated Press reported. Monday had been the cutoff date for raising the money, and Anne Yastremski, executive director of Preserve Educational Choice, said that opponents raised slightly more than $500,000 from 650 donations. Brenda Edson, a spokeswoman for the college in Lynchburg, Va., said the extension was not meaningful. We didnt have immediate plans to sell the artwork before the circuit court makes the decision on the merits of the case, she said. That doesnt mean the need to sell the artwork has gone away, but weve been concentrating on moving the college forward. The school had expected to realize at least $32 million by selling four paintings last month to increase its endowment.

title: Accord Tightens Control of Security Contractors in Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4  Gen. David H. Petraeus, the top United States commander in Iraq, and Ryan C. Crocker, the American ambassador to Baghdad, have agreed on the details governing the operations of Blackwater and other private security contractors there, American officials said Tuesday.

title: San Diego Takes Step to Merge Fire Services
description: SAN DIEGO, Dec. 4  A little more than a month after devastating wildfires swept through rural and suburban San Diego County, regional officials here have taken a step toward establishment of a consolidated countywide fire service.

title: A Church Is Divided, and Headed for Court
description: SAVANNAH, Ga.  For 274 years, there has been one Christ Church here, and it is a congregation with a proud history.

title: Never Mind the Wasteland. Were Just Talking Vast.
description: AT 50, can you be thinner, sharper and more popular than you were at 40? When talking about the size of television sets, electronics manufacturers say the answer is yes.

title: Elizabeth Hardwick, Critic, Novelist and Restless Woman of Letters, Dies at 91
description: Elizabeth Hardwick, who as a studious Kentucky belle set her ambitions on becoming a member of New Yorks glittering intellectual elite and then achieved them, as a critic, essayist, fiction writer and a co-founder of The New York Review of Books, died on Sunday in Manhattan. She was 91.

title: China: Vatican-Backed Bishop Installed
description: China ordained Joseph Gan Junqiu, a priest who has publicly declared his fidelity to Pope Benedict XVI, as a bishop of Guangzhou. The ordination, at the Sacred Heart Cathedral, occurred with the Vaticans backing and was held under heavy security. Last week, another priest, Lu Shouwang, was ordained as a bishop in Hubei Province, also with the Vaticans support. In Beijing, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said, We hope the Vatican can proceed from the overall picture of beneficial relations.

title: Mama Doesnt Feel Well, but Everyone Else Will Feel Much Worse
description: All happy families are alike, Tolstoy told us, and each unhappy family is unhappy in its own way. But Id bet the farm that no family has ever been as unhappy in as many ways  and to such sensationally entertaining effect  as the Westons of August: Osage County, the new play by Tracy Letts that blazed open last night at the Imperial Theater.

title: In Trial Run, City to Send Notification of Disasters
description: Julie Menin yesterday recalled the chaos in Lower Manhattan when the Deutsche Bank building began to burn on Aug. 18: Residents did not know whether to leave their apartments or stay inside, whether the air was safe to breathe or the fire was a result of another terror strike.

title: Venezuela: Raid on Jewish Center Condemned
description: Jewish leaders here and abroad condemned a police raid over the weekend at a Jewish community center in Caracas. The raid by about two dozen armed security agents, ostensibly a search for weapons, was carried out at about 1 a.m. on Sunday, just hours before the referendum that day on proposed constitutional changes backed by President Hugo Chvez. It failed to uncover any weapons.

title: Plan to Build Reactors Is Running Into Hurdles
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4  For the first time in three decades, companies are getting ready to build nuclear reactors in the United States. They intend to do so under streamlined procedures meant to avoid the long delays and cost overruns that crippled the industry last time around.

title: About a Boy, His Village and Time in the Spotlight
description: I know Im unique, announces Billy, an opinionated 10th grader and the willing subject of Jennifer Vendittis sly documentary, Billy the Kid. Delivered almost apologetically, the comment is without arrogance. But as one candid confession follows another, the cameras role in their solicitation becomes difficult to overlook.

title: Knicks Look for Next Option at Point Guard
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., Dec. 4  Having moved from shock to shared grief to quiet resolve, the Knicks will resume their season Wednesday evening with a point guard yet to be named.

title: U.S. Indictment for Fund-Raiser
description: Norman Hsu, the Democratic fund-raiser accused of bilking money from investors and putting pressure on some to contribute to campaigns, was indicted yesterday on mail and wire fraud charges and violating federal election law.

title: From the Bronx to Iraq to a Return Home, Too Soon
description: All afternoon, leaning into the wind, they trudged down Castle Hill Avenue in the Bronx, dressed in funeral parlor clothes. A car rolled up, and an older woman slowly unfolded from the front passenger seat, bracing her fingertips against the door frame, then pulling herself out deliberately, waving off a hand extended from the sidewalk. A young woman carried an infant seat out of a minivan. Soldiers from an Army honor guard, perfectly creased and practiced at their duties, had been among the first to arrive.

title: A Plan for the Presidio
description: A new museum proposed for the Presidio in San Francisco by Donald Fisher, who founded the clothing retailer the Gap with his wife, Doris, would be a two-story, 100,000-square-foot glassy structure, above, on the crest of the parade ground at the former military base and prison that became a national park in 1994. Resembling a stack of overlapping cubes, with white masonry walls broken by stretches of clear glass to reveal works by artists like Alexander Calder and Richard Serra, the proposed Contemporary Art Museum of the Presidio would also incorporate a network of terraces where sculptures could be exhibited, according to the Fishers. The planned building, designed by Richard Gluckman, faces competition from a proposal for a 48,000-square-foot History Center of the Golden Gate, exploring the culture of the American West. Directors of the Presidio Trust are expected to choose one of the museum proposals early next year.

title: OPEC Keeps Production Levels Steady
description: OPEC said today that it was leaving its production levels unchanged for the moment, signaling that it was more concerned with slowing economic growth than with high oil prices.

title: Russia: Two Groups Pull Out of Project
description: Tamir Fishman, an Israeli venture capital fund, and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development pulled out of a Russian investment project after a Russian partner boasted in a newspaper interview that he had backing from the F.S.B., the successor agency to the K.G.B., to force business owners in Russia to sell to him at below market rates. The Tamir Fishman Russian venture fund was intended for investment in high-tech start-ups, and would have received matching funds from the Russian government. In an interview with Kommersant newspaper, Oleg Shvartsman, a minority owner of the funds management company, described using ties to the F.S.B. to force private Russian business owners to sell out to companies with ties to Kremlin and F.S.B. insiders and members of their families. The European development bank said it was withdrawing from the project to protect its reputation.

title: NBC Leads Newscaster Horse Race by a Nose
description: NBC Nightly News With Brian Williams narrowly overtook World News With Charles Gibson on ABC to become the most-watched of the three network evening newscasts in November, a so-called sweeps month regarded by advertisers and the networks as a bellwether of the broadcasts fortunes.

title: Italian Court Summons Top Toons
description: Mickey Mouse, raise your right paw and swear that you will tell.... In a counterfeiting case before an Italian court in Naples, summonses were issued for the Disney rodent, as well as Donald Duck; his longtime sweetie, Daisy; and Tweety Bird, the Looney Tunes avian, right. According to The Associated Press, all were called upon to appear on Friday to testify against an unidentified Chinese man accused of counterfeiting Disney and Warner Brothers products. Instead of naming the companies and their legal representatives, court clerks listed as witnesses the cartoons that decorated the toys and gadgets that the defendant was said to have reproduced, said Fiorenza Sorotto, vice president of Disney Company Italia. Court officials did not answer telephone calls yesterday. The characters were summoned under their respective Italian names: Topolino, Paperino, Paperina and Titti. Of her three clients, Ms. Sorotto said, Unfortunately, they cannot show up, as they are residents of Disneyland.

title: Israel Insists That Iran Still Seeks a Bomb
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 4  Israel said Tuesday that it remained convinced that Iran was pursuing nuclear weapons and that it had probably resumed the weapons program the Americans said was stopped in the fall of 2003.

title: Supreme Court Reconsiders Pivotal Louisiana Case on Racial Selection of Juries
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4  It is just over two years since the Supreme Court sent a death-row inmates case back to the Louisiana Supreme Court with instructions to consider whether the jury selection had been infected with racial bias.

title: A G.P.S. Manufacturer With Precise Timing
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan

title: Precipitation Across U.S. Intensifies Over 50 Years
description: Across the United States, the number of severe rainfalls and heavy snows has grown significantly in the last half-century, with the greatest increases in New England and the Middle Atlantic region, according to a report released yesterday.

title: What You Get for ... $700,000
description: Stratton, Vt.

title: A Perfect Race, With Help From Above
description: ALEX MROSZCZYK-MCDONALD, a medical student at the University of Vermont, is normally pretty good at math. But he found performing mental gymnastics difficult when he ended up at the 22-mile point of a marathon in Austin, Tex., earlier in the year.

title: Ravens Say Late Calls Favored the Patriots
description: Controversy seems to follow the New England Patriots wherever they go, and their victory against the Baltimore Ravens on Monday night was no exception. A furor has ignited over the conduct of the officiating crew during the game-winning touchdown drive that saved the Patriots perfect season.

title: Brazil: Arcelor Buys Brazilian Unit
description: ArcelorMittal, the worlds largest steel maker, will spend up to $1.75 billion to buy the rest of its Brazilian specialty steel unit. The company also agreed to buy the British steel distributor NSD. Separately, ArcelorMittal said its chairman, Joseph Kinsch, 74, would step down in May to be succeeded by Lakshmi Mittal, who led Mittal when it made a bid to acquire Arcelor.

title: Yankees Say They Are Out of Chase for Santana
description: NASHVILLE, Dec. 4  The Yankees pursuit of Johan Santana is over, according to Hank Steinbrenner, the teams senior vice president, after the Yankees and the Minnesota Twins failed to agree on a deal Tuesday.

title: A Page of Mozart Sells for $228,000
description: One of only two surviving pages from Mozarts draft for his Sinfonia Concertante sold yesterday for $228,000 at Sothebys in London, the BBC reported. Bought by London-based dealers on behalf of a private client, the 1779 manuscript, part of a private collection, had not been seen in public for decades and was unavailable for scholarly scrutiny.

title: Lou Dobbs Hears Radio Calling
description: The way Lou Dobbs sees it, people shouldnt need basic cable to hear him sound off at length on issues like immigration and free trade. Mr. Dobbs, right, said yesterday that he was creating a daily three-hour talk radio show that would run in the afternoons and conclude an hour before his nightly program on CNN, which begins at 7 p.m. on the East Coast. My interest is in bringing a voice of reason, rather than the partisan and ideological poles that define talk radio right now, he said in a telephone interview. Mr. Dobbs vowed that neither the right nor the left would be able to lay claim to him, with some conservatives who support his hard-line take against illegal immigrants breaking ranks with his opposition to free trade. I consider both political parties to be tragic failures, Mr. Dobbs said. United Stations Radio Networks, a private company that syndicates one-minute financial updates by Mr. Dobbs, is producing the program. Asked if any station had committed to carry it, a company spokeswoman said that it was only now starting its outreach.

title: As U.S. Pop Wanes Abroad, Talent Scout Looks Wide
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 4  Leslie Feist, a former punk rocker from Calgary, Alberta, now known professionally as the indie torch singer Feist, recorded her 2004 album, Let It Die, in Paris. But if listeners detect any hint of French flavoring, she insisted, it is entirely imaginary.

title: No. 2 Memphis Shakes Off a Poor Night on Offense
description: Memphiss win did not come easily, nor was it a thing of beauty. The Tigers did not play well and their two offensive stars struggled all game. Somehow, though, they got the job done.

title: A Key Moment for Justice
description: The Supreme Court hears arguments today in a case that offers a chance to redress an enormous wrong done by President Bush and Congress when they denied justice to a group of prisoners. It is the latest phase of a battle over whether detainees held in Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, have the right to bring a habeas corpus challenge to their confinement. The narrow legal issues have changed since the court considered the question last year, but the principle remains the same: The detainees have a right to have a court determine whether the government has a valid basis for imprisoning them.

title: Taking Aim at Indian Point
description: In an extraordinary move, Gov. Eliot Spitzer and Attorney General Andrew Cuomo have placed themselves at the head of the group of federal, state and local officials who believe that the Indian Point nuclear power plant is unsafe and poorly run and should be closed. They should be given a chance to make their case.

title: Writers Find Haven on an Ivy Campus
description: PHILADELPHIA  College coaches have long scoured the country for supremely quick point guards who can transform a basketball team or fierce linebackers who can dominate a football game. Al Filreis is also perpetually on the lookout for talented high school students, although the ones he seeks do remarkable things with a pen or keyboard. He recruits writers.

title: Federal Suit Is Seeking to Expedite Citizenship
description: A federal lawsuit was filed yesterday in California against immigration authorities, seeking to help legal immigrants whose petitions for citizenship have been held up by delays in background checks performed by the F.B.I.

title: The Lounge That Ate a Restaurant
description: AFTER one meal that culminated in dishes of braised short ribs and cavatelli and another that involved duckling and red snapper, I was under the impression that Id been eating dinner at Grayz.

title: In Southern France, Renovating an Estate
description: UZES, France

title: A Calmer Iraq: Fragile, and Possibly Fleeting
description: BAGHDAD, Dec. 4  The reduced violence in Iraq in recent months stems from three significant developments, but the clock is running on all of them, Iraqi officials and analysts warn.

title: Mets Remain Interested in Livn Hernndez
description: NASHVILLE, Dec. 4  Omar Minaya, the Mets general manager, said Tuesday that he planned to speak with the representative of Livn Hernndez, a free-agent pitcher who played last season for Arizona.

title: Police Officer Is Indicted in Shooting
description: A Bronx grand jury indicted an off-duty police officer on a first-degree manslaughter charge yesterday in the fatal shooting of an unarmed building porter after a car accident in May, according to a person with direct knowledge of the case.

title: A Simple System, Superb at Math
description: IT may seem like a magical device, able to conjure its location from the ether. But at its heart, a G.P.S. unit is simply a radio receiver, picking up signals from satellites orbiting some 12,600 miles above earth.

title: FDA Panel Votes Against Cancer Drug
description: A federal advisory committee voted Wednesday that Genentechs drug Avastin should not be approved as a treatment for breast cancer. The drug is already on the market as a treatment for lung and colon cancer.

title: Ham From Spains Prized Pigs Ready for Debut
description: THE first Ibrico hams from Spain are ready to be sold in the United States, having passed government inspections. They will make their American debut tomorrow afternoon at Jaleo, in Washington, where the chef Jos Andrs plans to slice and serve jamn Ibrico to the Spanish ambassador, among others.

title: Seeking Mr. and Mrs. Right for a Baby on the Way
description: Juno MacGuff, the title character of Jason Reitmans new film, is 16 and pregnant, but Juno could not be further from the kind of hand-wringing, moralizing melodrama that such a condition might suggest. Juno, played by the poised, frighteningly talented Ellen Page, is too odd and too smart to be either a case study or the object of leering disapproval. She assesses her problem, and weighs her response to it, with disconcerting sang-froid.

title: Much of Suit Aimed at Indian Cigarette Sales Is Dismissed
description: A federal judge has dismissed all but one charge in a lawsuit, filed last year by a supermarket mogul who hopes to be the next mayor of New York City, that challenged two Long Island Indian tribes over their longstanding practice of selling tax-free cigarettes from reservation smoke shops.

title: Mexico: Popular Musician Killed
description: Sergio Gmez, the lead singer of the popular Nortea group K-Paz de La Sierra, was found dead along a highway on Monday, a day after he was kidnapped in the southern state of Michoacn. At least 14 other Nortea musicians, some of whom compose and sing ballads not only about love and loss, but also about bandits and narcotics traffickers, have been killed in the last two years.

title: Study Shows Why the Flu Likes Winter
description: Researchers in New York believe they have solved one of the great mysteries of the flu: Why does the infection spread primarily in the winter months?

title: Starbucks Picks Memoir
description: Starbucks has announced that its next book selection is Beautiful Boy: A Fathers Journey Through His Sons Addiction by David Sheff, a memoir of his sons methamphetamine addiction. The book, being published by Houghton Mifflin, is scheduled to go on sale in more than 6,500 Starbucks-owned stores on Feb. 26. Mr. Sheffs son, Nic Sheff, has also written a memoir, Tweak: Growing Up on Methamphetamines, which is being published in February by Ginee Seo Books, a Simon & Schuster imprint. Ken Lombard, president of Starbucks Entertainment, said Starbucks preferred the fathers book because of its unique parental perspective. This title is the fourth selected by Starbucks since it began its new book program last fall with For One More Day by Mitch Albom.

title: Force-Out Rule May Get Flagged
description: The force-out rule is where football meets figure skating. Cue the fuzzy criteria. Cut to the controversy.

title: There Are Ways to Help Lassie Come Home
description: WHO let the dogs out? And who is going to find them? Well, you can call off the hounds because a new breed of gadgets helps dog owners track their wayward pets.

title: Romney Faces New Questions on Illegal Workers at Landscaping Firm
description: Mitt Romney, who has relentlessly wielded the issue of illegal immigration against his rivals for the Republican presidential nomination in the past few months, is facing an embarrassing new revelation that the landscaping company at his home in Massachusetts was found for a second time to be employing illegal immigrants.

title: 76ers Fire Their General Manager
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 4 (AP)  The Philadelphia 76ers fired their general manager and team president, Billy King, on Tuesday and replaced him with the Nets general manager, Ed Stefanski.

title: Clinton Attack on Obama Overlooks Some Realities
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has been attacking Senator Barack Obamas health care plan, saying that while her proposal would provide universal coverage, his would leave out 15 million people.

title: Finally, a System That Will Listen
description: PORTABLE satellite navigation units for cars are becoming more sophisticated as the technology moves beyond just navigation, putting more control in drivers hands.

title: Something to Watch Over You
description: WILL it find bathrooms?

title: $21 Million Separates Contract Proposals By Studios And Writers
description: The Associated Press reports: On Tuesday bargaining resumed in Los Angeles after a four-day recess, with a relatively scant $21 million separating contract proposals by studios and striking Hollywood writers.

Comments on the New Assessment of Irans Nuclear Program
description: President Bush At a White House news conference Tuesday morning:

title: Dan Blackburn, Beyond Hockey
description: Before Henrik Lundqvist there was Dan Blackburn, the first-round pick (10th over all) of the Rangers in 2001 who made the N.H.L. at 18. He recorded his first victory in Montreal, beating Jose Theodore and the Canadiens, 2-1, with his mother cheering him on. The future was dazzling. But after two seasons, it was all over. A freakish injury while weight training caused nerve damage in his left shoulder. By way of James Mirtles blog comes this story from Scott Cruickshank , of The Calgary Herald. Blackburn is managing just fine in his life after hockey.

description: David Pogue puts nine cameras to the test on a recent trip to Miami. The following slides highlight some of their hits and misses.

description: As the World Motor Sport Forum opens in Monaco today, and the World Motor Sport Council prepares to judge the Renault spy scandal tomorrow, Max Mosley, the worlds motor sport leader, today made available through the FIA site an interview with himself that clearly attempts to prepare the world for tomorrows verdict.

title: Hong Kongs Jumbo Floating Restaurant
description: Boats heading to Jumbo. Photos by Joyce Hor-Chung Lau

title: General Motors Wants Stake in Russias AvtoVaz
description: General Motors is bidding for a stake in Russias largest carmaker as part of an effort to expand its presence in that rapidly growing market, a G.M. spokesman confirmed Tuesday.

title: Another Couple, Another Insider Trading Sentencing
description: In the latest case of pillow talk leading to a jail time, a former financial analyst at Morgan Stanley and her husband, a former hedge fund analyst at ING, were each sentenced yesterday to a year and half in prison for insider trading.

title: Fannie Mae Seeks to Raise $7 Billion in Stock Sale
description: Like her brother Freddie Mac, Fannie Mae, the mortgage finance company, said Tuesday that it would sell $7 billion of preferred stock and cut its dividend 30 percent to shore up its capital base through 2008 as the housing slump worsens.

title: MyStrands Adds $24 Million to Series B
description: MyStrands, social recommendation technology developer, has added $24 million to its Series B round that gives it $49 million in second-round financing.

title: CrossLoop Lassos $3 Million
description: CrossLoop, a desktop sharing software developer, announced Tuesday that it raised $3 million in a first round of funding led by El Dorado Ventures.

title: NexTone and Reef Point Dial Up Deal and Pull In Cash
description: NexTone Communications and Reef Point Systems, two well-funded, venture-backed telecommunications start-ups, have combined to form NextPoint Networks and have raised $20 million in new capital to advance converged opportunities in fixed-mobile and wireless interconnectivity products.

title: Maxim and Former Chief Settle Backdating Charges
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission filed civil charges Tuesday against legendary Silicon Valley entrepreneur Jack Gifford and the former chief financial officer of Maxim Integrated Products, alleging they were responsible for routinely rigging stock options to make them more valuable for workers, new hires and directors.

title: Pegasus Closes New $750 Million Fund
description: Pegasus Capital Advisors, the middle-market private equity firm, has closed its latest investment vehicle, capping the new fund at $750 million.

title: How Green are Rental City Bikes?
description: By Simon Marks

title: Has Cerberus Lost Its Nose for Bargains?
description: Cerberus Capital Managements recent decisions to walk away from a couple of traditional leveraged buyouts, namely its deal for H&R Blocks mortgage arm Option One and United Rentals, has taken some of the shine off the distressed investors, Breakingviews says.

title: Senate Delays F.C.C. Ownership Proposal
description: A Senate committee unanimously approved bipartisan legislation that would halt for at least six months a proposal to let companies own a newspaper and broadcast station in the same city.

title: Shares Slip Further on Fear of Bank Debt
description: Investors have entered December, usually a winning month on Wall Street, cautiously. Fears of further weakness in the financial sector helped push the stock market down for a second day Tuesday.

title: Is Malone Shopping for Dillers Ticketmaster?
description: When Barry Diller announced that he planned to split his IAC/InterActiveCorp into five parts, speculation arose that the dealmaker may finally get closure with media mogul John C. Malone by swapping the Home Shopping Network for Liberty Medias 24 percent stake in IAC.

title: Legg Masons Miller Offers Blueprint for Citis Next Chief
description: As reports surface that Vikrim S. Pandit is the top candidate to take the pole position at Citigroup, Bill Miller, the legendary Legg Mason Value Trust fund manager and Citigroup shareholder, has some ideas of his own for who should succeed Charles O. Prince III at the banking conglomerate.

title: Newspaper Spin-Off Has Yet to Enchant Street
description: Belo chairman and chief executive Robert W. Decherd launched a campaign Tuesday to sell Wall Street on his plan to spin off the companys newspapers  a sales pitch that was apparently met with skepticism.

title: Rocky Road for I.P.O.s in 2008?
description: As financial markets go, so go initial public offerings.

title: Sirius Optimistic About XM Deal
description: Sirius Satellite Radio remains hopeful that it can close its acquisition of XM Satellite Radio by the end of the year, as the Department of Justice has little left to do to complete its review of the proposed transaction, Sirius Chief Financial Officer David Frear told investors on Tuesday.

title: Judge Takes Milberg Weiss to Task Over Criminal Probe
description: Milberg Weiss cant seem to shake the shadow of its criminal probe.

title: Paul Hastings Names New Partners
description: Paul, Hastings, Janofsky & Walker, the Los Angeles law firm, said it elected 16 new partners, effective Feb. 1.

title: Citi Sells 2 Buildings for $1.58 Billion
description: Citigroup has agreed to sell two downtown Manhattan office buildings to SL Green Realty for about $1.58 billion, the companies said.

title: Banks Make Bets on Clean Energy
description: Morgan Stanley, Goldman Sachs and Lehman Brothers are just some of the Wall Street firms that are actively investing in renewable energy sources these days.

title: Fund Manager Said to Pay $46 Million for N.Y. Co-op
description: Real estate may be the source of Wall Streets woes at the moment, but the top of the market appears to be humming right along.

title: Standard Chartered SIV Sells Assets
description: Whistlejacket Capital, the structured investment vehicle managed by Standard Chartered, has sold assets to reduce the fund by 40 percent to $10.8 billion since August.

title: Lehman Pays Zero for Van der Moolen Assets
description: Lehman Brothers is getting into the floor specialist business at the New York Stock Exchange  at the attractive price of zero dollars.

title: Hedge Fund Manager Charged With Fraud
description: In a federal court action, the Securities and Exchange Commission charged that a Michigan hedge fund manager told investors that one of its funds had $2.1 million in assets, when the fund was down to only $200,000.

title: Clear Channel Delays $20 Billion Buyout
description: Clear Channel Communications said Tuesday that it now expects to close its $20 billion buyout by Bain Capital Partners and Thomas H. Lee Partners in the beginning of 2008, rather than the end of this year.

title: Morgan Stanley Said to Ready Sale of Spanish Unit
description: Morgan Stanley has put its private banking business in Spain up for sale with a price tag of up to 800 million euros ($1.2 billion), The Financial Times reported. The move is the latest sign that the investment bank is concentrating on super-wealthy clients.

title: Ackermann Said to Reject Citis Top Spot
description: Josef Ackermann, chief executive of Deutsche Bank, has turned down an approach from Citigroup about taking the top spot at the troubled financial giant, The Financial Times reported citing an unnamed source.

title: Wall St. Firms Said to Receive Subpoenas
description: Merrill Lynch, Bear Stearns and Deutsche Bank are among the Wall Street firms that have been sent subpoenas from the office of the New York state attorney general, which wants to know about how mortgages were sliced up and resold to investors, The Wall Street Journal reported.

title: More of Your Late Night Jokes
description: Can a late-night show without writers be funny? By crossing the picket line, Carson Daly seems to be demonstrating this week that the answer is no. Ah, who needs him anyhow? Heres some more reader-generated comedy:

title: Xstrata Bids $842 Million for Resource Pacific
description: Swiss mining group Xstrata on Wednesday made an $842 million cash bid for coal miner Resource Pacific, trumping an all-share offer by New Hope, as it seeks to grow in Australias booming resource sector.

title: More Nelson
description: Ryan Fleck and Anna Boden, the director/writing pair that was very much in the mix last year with Half Nelson, may be back next year after signing a deal with HBO for their film Sugar.

description: Does the specter of Amaranth Advisors still haunt its survivors?

description: In an intriguing, illuminating article by my colleague Kim Severson in Wednesdays Dining section, some very important chefs talk some very disturbing trash about the entree, which I would like to defend.

description: What went wrong for Bionic Woman?

title: Beyond the Romance of Wine
description: As you might guess I spend a lot of time reading about wine. Books, periodicals, web sites, blogs, you name it, Im often there. Today I want to focus on magazines, which if Im not careful start proliferating around my apartment like tribbles.

title: World Cup Update: Quarterfinalists Are Set; Kamsky Is One of Them
description: In the World Cup in Khanty-Mansiysk, three matches went to tiebreaker games today to decide the final three quarterfinalists. Dmitry Jakovenko of Russia, No. 19 in the world, upset Levon Aronian of Armenia, No. 9; Gata Kamsky of the United States, No. 17, also pulled an upset by beating Peter Svidler of Russia, No. 12; and Evgeny Alekseev of Russia, No. 14, held to form by taking care of Evgeny Bareev of Russia, No. 57, who was the lowest remaining player in the tournament. The results and the games can be found on the tournaments Web site.

title: A Copy Is Art. So What's the Original?
description: Images from the works of Richard Prince and Jim Krantz.

title: American Prankster
description: Every once in a while, the guests lists get crossed and the Bagger ends up at an event where he manifestly does not belong. Last night, Yvonne and Barry Cohen hosted Brian Grazer and his girlfriend Chau-Giang Thi Nguyen at their soaring apartment in the skies above the East River. The event was held to raise money for a Steinway piano, which is to be donated to Ms. Thi Nguyens music school in her native Vietnam. The evening featured an exquisite piano performance by Ms. Thi Nguyen.

title: Dying in Brooklyn, Alone and Unnoticed
description: On Monday, the police found the skeletal remains of Christina Copeman in her home in East Flatbush, Brooklyn. She had been dead for a year to 18 months, and was dressed to go out, in a coat and beret. It seems impossible for a person to fall through the cracks like that, to die in her own home and go undiscovered. New York is a big city, but it is impersonal only at a distance, Andy Newman writes. People have neighbors. They have relatives. But Christina Copeman, who would be 70 if she were alive today, managed to slip away almost by sheer force of will.

title: The Early Word: Immigration and Iran

Bloomberg and leaders of the City Council announced this morning that New York City will invest $2.8 million to start a nonprofit organization that will be dedicated to helping homeowners avoid foreclosure  the citys most tangible response so far to the crisis in subprime lending and the turmoil in the housing and mortgage markets.

title: Waiting for the Slipper to Drop
description: This afternoon at 2 p.m., the National Board of Review of Motion Pictures will announce its selections for the year. People love to slag on their choices, in part because they need to make picks that deliver high star wattage for their event. The NBR has not been super predictive in the recent past, but in a year cluttered with excellence, any heat is good heat. Check back this afternoon for the results.

description: Mark Zuckerberg has produced a symphony of contrition in a blog post today about Facebooks Beacon feature, which initially sent information on users Web purchases to their friends unless they specifically blocked the disclosure of each purchase.

title: Do New Roads Help or Hurt Global Warming?
description: If you read the column today, you know that France last month pledged an end to new highway construction. Environmentalists cheered the development, but they are watching the loopholes carefully. Even so, the tentative steps France is taking are in sharp contrast with developments elsewhere in the world. One of the biggest projects is the Asian Highway, a network of new and upgraded roads spanning 140,000 kilometers, or about 87,000 miles, and crisscrossing 32 countries from Southeast Asia to Central Asia.

title: Giuliani Ad Focuses on Iran

description: James Wolcott, in this weeks New Republic, delivers a status report on the health of book reviews, and writes that, in the digital age, book reviewing bears the social handicap of a dying trade, like typewriter repair or horseshoe mending. Its a piece worth reading  you can find it here.

title: Looking for the Weaknesses in United Rentals Lawsuit

In its lawsuit, the rental equipment operator is demanding that Delawares court of chancery force Cerberus to complete the $4 billion buyout, arguing that the specific performance clause in the deal agreement mandates just that.

title: Recipe: Fennel With Blue Cheese And Bread Crumbs
description: Gratin has come to mean a kind of macaroni-and-cheese affair, a gooey dish in which the main foodstuff  whether potatoes, noodles or vegetables  is dominated by a mass of white sauce, cheese and butter. But the word really refers to the crust that forms on the top and sides of a dish that has been browned under a fire. Although gooey, cheesy dishes can be enjoyable, you can make honest, simple, lean gratins with fewer ingredients to produce easy, interesting vegetable dishes.

Well, not really, according to meteorologists at Pennsylvania State University. Todd Miner, a meteorologist at the university, which supplies the information for The Timess daily weather reports, said the city is almost exactly on track for average snowfall this winter. So far in December, 1.4 inches have been recorded; November had 0.3 inch.

I think there is no better piece of writing about Washington than Adamss chapter on Grant. Like Adams, I found that some of the politicians and lobbyists I covered defied burlesque because they were more grotesque than ridicule could make them, and that senators (the esteemed Mr. Hart a notable exception!) were often comical in their egotism. Still, like Adams, I couldnt help but love the place. As he writes, one could not stay there a month without loving the shabby town.

Known as the Guennol Lioness, the limestone sculpture was part of a well-known collection formed by the New York collectors Alastair Bradley Martin and his wife, Edith Martin, and had been on loan to the Brooklyn Museum since 1948. Five bidders, three on telephones and two in the salesroom, competed for the work. The winner was standing in the back of the salesroom and said he was a British buyer who wished to remain anonymous.
