title: Corrections
description: The Talking Business column in Business Day on Saturday, about the hedge fund manager William Ackmans pursuit of MBIA Inc., a holding company whose main subsidiary is the nations largest bond insurer, misstated his forecast about the companys financial health. Mr. Ackman predicted the company could be bankrupt by the second quarter of 2008, not by February. The article also referred incorrectly to the companys liabilities. It has $80 million in annual debt service, not in corporate debt. (Go to Article)

title: Medicare to Cut Payment for Two Promising Cancer Drugs
description: New Medicare rules for a small but promising class of cancer drugs may cause thousands of lymphoma patients to lose access to the treatment, which in some cases is the only therapy available to them.

title: Charge That Tee on My Platinum
description: NEXT to the new Manhattan outlet of Billionaire Boys Club and Ice Cream is an antique store that is going out of business. Lost our Lease! and Everything 60% Off! is written in giant letters in almost every window.

title: Elections Official Wants to Help Troops at War Vote
description: Phil V. Donahue, director of personnel at the New York City Board of Elections, is not a typical city bureaucrat. He has a wild mane of white hair and a long flowing beard, and rides his Harley-Davidson lowrider to work at the boards downtown headquarters at 42 Broadway.

title: A Roomful of Sound, Not Wires
description: WHEN Bradley Partridge bought a sleek flat-screen for the living room of his Atlanta home, he did not want the clutter of speakers hanging from the walls or the trouble of running wires around the room.

title: Museum Leaders Named
description: Dorothy Kosinski, senior curator of painting and sculpture at the Dallas Museum of Art, has been appointed director of the Phillips Collection in Washington. In the spring she will succeed Jay Gates, whose retirement was announced in June. ... The former culture minister of Italy, Antonio Paolucci, an art historian and former superintendent of Florences museum system, has been named by Pope Benedict XVI to lead the Vatican museums, Agence France-Presse reported. He succeeds the archaeologist Francesco Buranelli, who will become inspector of the Pontifical Commission for Sacred Archaeology.

title: Institute Named for Sesame Creator
description: In their pioneering work with the preschool show Sesame Street, Joan Ganz Cooney and her colleagues created a much-copied model that made childrens television educational as well as entertaining. Today the programs producer, Sesame Workshop, will unveil a nonprofit research and production institute named after Ms. Cooney that will try to inject educational standards into digital media for older children.

title: Bush and Iran: A New Landscape
description: To the Editor:

title: Suicide Blast Kills 13 in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Dec. 5  A suicide bomber smashed his car into a bus carrying Afghan Army personnel here in the capital early Wednesday, killing 13 people.

title: Work With Me, Baby
description: FASHION is a stepchild, in photography no less than in other areas of the culture. The reach of the imagery it produces influences everything from trash television to presidential campaigns. Yet the slick work cranked out by the fashion machine is rarely taken seriously.

title: Two More Schools to Close for Bad Performance
description: The Department of Education announced yesterday that it planned to close Far Rockaway High School in Queens and Public School 220 in the Bronx, weeks after both schools received poor marks under the citys new school-grading system. P.S. 220, also known as the Mott Haven Village School, will shut its doors at the end of this school year, and Far Rockaway will stop accepting new students and be phased out over the next four years. The Mott Haven school has been plagued with problems for several years  in 2004, the city decided to restructure it by eliminating the middle school grades there. Both of the schools had already been on the states list of failing schools in danger of being shut down. Officials said they expect to announce within the next week up to 12 more schools to be closed.

title: Tip of the Week: Managing Bookmarks and Passwords
description: If you use Firefox and want to keep your bookmarks, cookies and passwords the same across the different computers you use, there is a far easier way than periodically exporting and importing a file composed of your bookmarks. The free Google Browser Sync can keep all your machines up to date. You need a Google account or a Gmail address for it to work. Google has complete installation and setup instructions at www.google.com/tools/firefox/browsersync, along with a link to download the application.

title: Battle Lines Drawn as Officer Is Arraigned in Killing
description: It took only about 10 minutes for Officer Rafael Lora of the New York City police to be arraigned yesterday on a charge that he illegally killed an unarmed man while investigating a car accident outside his home this spring.

title: A Movie and Protesters Single Out Henry Kravis
description: Bells will be ringing, and carolers will be greeting the Upper East Side neighbors of Henry Kravis this morning.

title: Justice Dept. Numbers Show Prison Trends
description: About one in every 31 adults in the United States was in prison, in jail or on supervised release at the end of last year, the Department of Justice reported yesterday.

title: Evel Knievel Funeral set for Montana
description: Evel Knievel will go out in a burst of fireworks and a funeral officiated by the televangelist Robert H. Schuller at the Civic Center in Mr. Knievels hometown, Butte, Mont., The Associated Press reported. Family members said the fireworks on Sunday night would be followed by a public viewing and memorial service on Monday morning. Were throwing a funeral, his son Kelly said. Its Evel Knievel. After the service, Mr. Knievels body will be driven along Evel Knievel Way, a six-mile loop in Butte. A private burial is planned. Mr. Knievel was 69 when he died on Friday.

title: B.C.S. = Bad. Choice. System.
description: After the season we just completed, only those people with a bcsfootball.org e-mail address can argue with a straight face that the postseason system in place for college football is even remotely acceptable. But lets ignore the ridiculousness of trying to determine the two best teams for a moment; take a look at how the other B.C.S. games were chosen.

title: Shares Rally on Surprisingly Strong Jobs Data
description: A promising employment report lifted stocks yesterday, with the main indexes erasing two days of declines on renewed optimism about the outlook for the economy. But the Federal Reserve may face a more complicated landscape as it considers its next move on interest rates.

title: Israeli Forces Kill 3 Palestinians
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 5  Israeli forces on Wednesday killed two members of Hamas and wounded four others as they prepared to fire a mortar into Israel, and killed at least one Palestinian security officer in Bethlehem after Israeli forces in civilian clothing were fired upon as they were attempted to carry out an arrest raid.

title: An Expedition That Explores Freedom and Control
description: The kinetic, episodic music of the Dave Douglas Quintet has plenty of precedent in the broad expanse of post-bop. Increasingly, though, the group has been sending signals from its own coordinates. At the Village Vanguard on Tuesday night it brushed against facets of modal jazz, nascent fusion and polyphonic funk  on the surface an index of styles from the early 1970s  but the mood was neither allusive nor retro. Mr. Douglas, the trumpeter and composer, led what felt like an expedition.

title: Marbury Thankful for Prayers and Support
description: Knicks guard Stephon Marbury was not with the team last night, remaining instead with his family to mourn the death of his father, Donald E. Marbury, who had a heart attack while watching his son play against Phoenix at Madison Square Garden on Sunday night.

title: Updated Fire Code Is Offered to Mesh With Revised Building Rules
description: New York City fire officials have prepared a proposed updated fire code that reflects a number of recent emergencies in the first major revision of the document in nearly a century.

title: House Panel Finds Conflicts in Executive Pay Consulting
description: Conflicts of interest are pervasive among executive compensation consultants, according to a Congressional investigation. Moreover, the inquiry found, consultants who do other work for companies while helping them devise executive pay recommended significantly higher pay packages than consultants who had no such additional relationships.

title: Pushed Out of Baghdad, Insurgents Move North
description: MOSUL, Iraq, Dec. 5  Sunni insurgents pushed out of Baghdad and Anbar Provinces have migrated to this northern Iraqi city and have been trying to turn it into a major hub for their operations, according to American commanders.

title: Revelation on Statement by Spitzers Ex-Aide Fuels Mistrust in Albany
description: ALBANY, Dec. 5  Senate Republicans charged on Wednesday that the Spitzer administration might have used a legal maneuver to make statements that top aides submitted to the attorney generals office appear to be sworn affidavits when they were not.

title: Super Favre
description: Hes 38 and graying, but that hasnt stopped Brett Favre from having a resurgent season, playing his way into contention for the Most Valuable Player award. Besides Tom Brady and Peyton Manning, is there a quarterback in the N.F.L. whom youd rather have leading your team in a big game? If so, whom?

title: Dont Dillydally, Darwin, Its Survival of the Quickest
description: The origins of Darwins Origin of Species might not seem a promising subject for a stage play. But then who could have imagined that New York audiences would flock to a three-part epic about the history of Russian thought in the 19th century?

title: Coles Is on a Mission to Be Ready for Sundays Game
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Dec. 5  On Nov. 4, Laveranues Coles was inactive against the Washington Redskins because of a concussion. The Jets lost.

title: Crimes by Juveniles Rise, China Says
description: BEIJING, Dec. 5 (Agence France-Presse)  The number of juvenile criminals in China has more than doubled over the past decade, as broken homes and a decline in social values have spurred youth delinquency, according to an article in a state-run newspaper on Wednesday.

title: Bhangras Ambassador, Keeping the Party Spinning
description: Most album-release parties dont include a multicourse Indian dinner, served on tables set with linen and take-home centerpieces of cookies and betel-nut digestifs assembled partly by the musician herself. And most dont involve shout-outs to Mom and Dad and aunties and uncles, let alone a moment when the whole family gets together on the clubs dance floor.

title: Stamp to Honor Sinatra
description: Ol Blue Eyes will be traveling first class. Frank Sinatra (1915-98) will be commemorated with a first-class stamp to be issued in the spring by the United States Postal Service, The Associated Press reported. The plan was announced yesterday by Postmaster General John Potter, who called Sinatra an extraordinary entertainer whose life and work left an indelible impression on American culture. The image that will appear on the stamp is to be made public on Wednesday, Sinatras birthday, at a ceremony in Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: C.I.A. Destroyed Tapes of Interrogations
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6  The Central Intelligence Agency in 2005 destroyed at least two videotapes documenting the interrogation of two Al Qaeda operatives in the agencys custody, a step it took in the midst of Congressional and legal scrutiny about the C.I.As secret detention program, according to current and former government officials.

title: Rudolph Shows the Way for CBS
description: The Christmas classic Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer, above, led CBS to a Tuesday night victory in the ratings as the special delivered 14.4 million viewers at 8 p.m., according to Nielsens estimates. Although CBS remained No. 1 at 9 p.m. with a rerun of NCIS (11.6 million), at 10 the network fell to third place with The Victorias Secret Fashion Show 2007 (7.4 million), which finished behind ABCs Boston Legal (8.6 million) and NBCs Law & Order: Special Victims Unit (11.7 million). For the night, NBC tied CBS for first among adults 18 to 49, earning solid results in that demographic from The Biggest Loser from 8 to 10 (8.3 million). ABC finished fourth for the night behind Fox, which broadcast all repeats. On Monday, ABC slipped into third place since Dancing With the Stars ended. NBC led that night among adults 18 to 49.

title: Queens: Two Killed in Highway Crash
description: Two teenagers died and three others were critically injured when their car struck a guard rail, became airborne for 100 feet and hit a concrete overpass pillar on a sharply curving exit ramp from the Van Wyck Expressway to the Nassau Expressway early yesterday, the police said. The car, a 2007 Dodge Charger, was being driven at a high rate of speed when the accident occurred at 12:45 a.m. near the northern border of Kennedy International Airport, investigators said. Two passengers, Devindra Harilall and Christopher Karan, both 18, were pronounced dead at Jamaica Hospital Medical Center. Both lived in Ozone Park. A 17-year-old and two 19-year-olds, the other occupants of the car, were taken to the same hospital. The police declined to identify them, but said that they had life-threatening injuries.

title: Union and Baseball Discuss Punishment in Drug Case
description: The possibility that players who received shipments of performance-enhancing substances will be disciplined by Major League Baseball moved forward yesterday when it was revealed that the commissioners office and players union officials were discussing a penalty for one of those players.

title: A Guide to Clients
description: HOW is a stylist to gauge whether a client wants their cut with a side of gossip?

title: Advisory Panel Rejects New Use for Cancer Drug
description: A federal advisory committee voted yesterday that Genentechs drug Avastin should not be approved as a treatment for breast cancer.

title: Recalling Iranian Hostage Crisis, Giuliani Invokes Reagan as a Model
Tebow May Break a Class Barrier
description: The finalists for the Heisman Trophy were announced yesterday, and the inclusion of the Florida sophomore quarterback Tim Tebow will be yet another opportunity to renew a very old argument. No freshman or sophomore has won the trophy, even though Heisman voters have been debating whether one should, with controversial results since the 1940s.

title: Lottery Numbers
CIRCUITS: Headset Kills the Noise for Both Sides of the Conversation
description: Its hard to use a mobile phone headset in noisy surroundings. Motorolas new Bluetooth headset, the Motopure H12, uses noise-canceling technology to filter out background noise so the user can hear the person on the other end. It also works in the opposite direction, so the other caller does not hear all the background noise.

title: Gunman at an Omaha Mall Kills 8 and Himself
description: OMAHA, Dec. 5  A gunman in camouflage and wielding a rifle opened fire on Wednesday in a department store at a mall here crowded with holiday shoppers, killing eight people and wounding five others, before turning the gun on himself.

title: Pulpit Was the Springboard for Huckabees Rise
description: In August 1980, as the conservative Christian movement was first transforming American politics, Ronald Reagan stood before a Dallas stadium full of 15,000 foot-stomping, hand-clapping evangelicals and pledged his fealty to the Bible. All the complex and horrendous questions confronting us at home and worldwide have their answer in that single book, said Mr. Reagan, the Republican presidential nominee.

title: A Memphis Freshman Needs No Orientation
description: In an instant six years ago, Reggie Rose realized his younger brother Derrick was not just another middle school basketball player.

title: A Holiday Medley, Off Key
description: WHEN her sons were toddlers, Amy Manata, a Jewish woman with a Catholic husband, began conducting a silent war. In the months leading up to Hanukkah, she would ask the boys, now 4 and 6, which toys they wanted most, then bestow them at Hanukkah to ensure that it was a better holiday than Christmas.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Science Times on Nov. 27 about a feud between two pioneering heart surgeons, Dr. Michael E. DeBakey and Dr. Denton A. Cooley, misstated the name of the medical school with which Dr. DeBakey has been affiliated. It is Baylor College of Medicine, not Baylor Medical College.

title: Santana on Mets List, but So Far Its All Talk
description: NASHVILLE, Dec. 5  Early Wednesday, Mets Manager Willie Randolph baited the hook and cast the line. He spoke specifically of Johan Santana of the Minnesota Twins, a left-handed starter and one of baseballs best pitchers, who is on the trade market.

title: A Tour of Russian Works, Led by the Locals
description: Valery Gergiev and his Kirov Orchestra, along with a planeload of choristers and soloists from the Maryinsky Theater in St. Petersburg, Russia, finished their short residency at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday evening. Their three concerts, part of Mr. Gergievs Perspectives series, offered a selective tour of the Russian opera and ballet repertory. Mr. Gergiev is the go-to guy for this music today. He has drilled his orchestra to produce a tremendous range of both sound and expressivity, from exquisite beauty and polish to terrifying ferocity.

title: Report Sees Danger in Delay on Kosovo
description: BELGRADE, Serbia, Thursday, Dec. 6 (Reuters)  The United Nations and European Union must guide Kosovo on a path to independence as soon as failed negotiations with Serbia officially end on Monday, an organization devoted to resolving conflicts said on Thursday.

description: Previously recorded: $2,569,692.73

title: L.S.U.S. Dorsey Wins Lombardi
description: Louisiana State defensive tackle Glenn Dorsey won the Lombardi Award as the nations top college lineman or linebacker last night, his third individual honor in three days.The 6-foot-2, 303-pound Dorsey won the Bronko Nagurski Award on Monday, given to the nations top defensive player. He was named the Southeastern Conference defensive player of the year earlier yesterday. Despite playing the last five games of the season with a sore right knee, Dorsey finished with 64 tackles, 6 sacks and 11  tackles behind the line.

title: Late-Night Hosts Calculate Their Losses
description: Few of the hosts of televisions late-night entertainment shows are turning up in their offices these days, because theres nothing for them to do.

title: Senate Passes Bill to Block Tax Increase
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6  Trying to find a way out of a sticky tax problem, the Senate voted overwhelmingly tonight to prevent the alternative minimum tax from hitting millions of middle-class Americans without replacing the $50 billion that would be lost.

title: Wary of Risk, Bankers Sold Shaky Mortgage Debt
description: As the subprime loan crisis deepens, Wall Street firms are increasingly coming under scrutiny for their role in selling risky mortgage-related securities to investors.

title: Kings Riches in a Chelsea Domain
description: THERE are designers who proudly haunt thrift shops and tag sales, but Thomas Hays, an investment banker turned interior designer who has just redone a boutique hotel in Marrakesh, Morocco, is not one of them. High-toned antiques dealers and his own far-flung travels are the source of the treasures in his Chelsea penthouse, and if youre curious about how much they put him back, Mr. Hays, a fellow who is clearly confident in his investment skills, doesnt mind telling you.

title: Retailers Post Gains, but They May Be Brief
description: Cold weather and deep discounts appear to have rescued retailers from what threatened to be a dreary November  but it may not be enough to save the entire holiday shopping season.

title: Bristol-Myers to Eliminate 4,800 Jobs
description: Bristol-Myers Squibb said yesterday that it would cut approximately 10 percent of its work force of 43,000 employees, continuing a year of pharmaceutical industry layoffs as drug makers adapt to a more competitive environment.

title: An Effort to Tempt Macys From a Century-Old Home
description: Is New York ready for a Miracle on 33rd Street? The developers behind the long-gestating plan to rebuild Pennsylvania Station and redevelop the surrounding neighborhood are trying to lure Macys from its 105-year-old landmark building in Herald Square to a glass-enclosed mall that would sit inside the new train station, public officials and real estate executives said.

title: Suppliers and Medicare
description: To the Editor:

title: Under a New Watch, Miramax Still Homes in on Awards
description: The SoHo headquarters of Miramax, with its high ceilings, hardwood floors and a 15th-floor view of Midtown, is lovely, if unassuming. A satellite office of the previous, much larger Miramax, the place doesnt exactly shout Hollywood, but rather whispers of the back-office functions it used to house.

title: Management of Subways to Be Split
description: Since the subways were unified into one system decades ago, New Yorkers have come to think of them as part of a single, vast, often unwieldy whole.

title: Lawyer Associated With Racing Association Is Subpoenaed
description: ALBANY, Dec. 5  A state investigations commission on Wednesday subpoenaed the lawyer who used to oversee New Yorks horse racing association, as part of an inquiry that comes amid strained negotiations between Gov. Eliot Spitzer and the State Senate over whether the association will continue to run the states thoroughbred franchise.

title: Hey Spot, Youve Got Mail
description: SOMETIMES I think Otto is a goat.

title: For Now, Yanks Stick With Their Farm Plan
description: NASHVILLE, Dec. 5  Hank Steinbrenner has not attended the winter meetings, but his voice is among the most powerful here. Absent from the Yankees media guide a year ago, he is now the final authority on matters related to the marquee team in the major leagues.

title: Boy Scouts Lose Philadelphia Lease in Gay-Rights Fight
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 4  For three years the Philadelphia council of the Boy Scouts of America held its ground. It resisted the citys request to change its discriminatory policy toward gay people despite threats that if it did not do so, the city would evict the group from a municipal building where the Scouts have resided practically rent free since 1928.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Q. My rabbits foot fern has grown too large for its hanging pot. The rhizomes are draped all over the outside. How do I re-pot without destroying the plant? I live in zone 10 and the plant stays outdoors year round.

title: Car Bombs Kill 22 as Gates Visits Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, Dec. 5  Car bombs in Baghdad and three northern Iraqi cities killed at least 22 people and wounded more than 60 others on Wednesday, as Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates arrived for an unannounced visit with senior Iraqi officials.

title: Designer of the Year: (Name Here)
description: IF you are a designer, this is your year.

title: A.M.D. Delays Energy-Efficient Chip Again
description: The energy-efficient chip that Advanced Micro Devices was counting to win customers away from Intel has been delayed again, the company said yesterday.

title: NASA Delays Shuttle Launch
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Dec. 6  NASA officials delayed the launch of the space shuttle Atlantis for at least 24 hours today following problems with a pair of fuel sensors.

title: A Watch Lets an Athlete Keep Track of a Workout and Control the Soundtrack
description: Athletes may have little control over things like the weather, the terrain, their energy levels. With the Timex iControl, they can at least control their music selection from their wrist.

title: Police Shoot Woman After Chase in New Jersey
description: Patrol officers shot a woman after a car chase in New Jersey last night, the police said. She collided with a police car, kept on driving, spun out of control and tried to hit another squad car, they said.

title: Gates Decides Against Marines Offer to Leave Iraq for Afghanistan
description: BAGHDAD, Dec. 5  Senior Pentagon and military officials said Wednesday that Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates had decided against a proposal to shift Marine Corps forces from Iraq to take the lead in American operations in Afghanistan.

title: Early Honors for No Country
description: The National Board of Review named No Country for Old Men its best picture yesterday as speculation season began shifting into the bestowing of actual awards. The board named Tim Burton best director for Sweeney Todd. In leading roles, George Clooney was cited for Michael Clayton and Julie Christie for Away From Her. Amy Ryan (Gone Baby Gone) and Casey Affleck (The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford) were honored for supporting roles, and Emile Hirsch (Into the Wild) and Ellen Page (Juno) were cited for breakthrough performances. The Diving Bell and the Butterfly was named best foreign film. The awards will be presented in a ceremony Jan. 15.

title: A Rewoven Black Flag, Raised for a New Audience
description: The years oddest musical tribute belongs to Dirty Projectors, the Brooklyn band that brought its lapidary, wayward constructions to the Bowery Ballroom on Tuesday night. David Longstreth, the bands leader, singer and guitarist, decided to reinvent from memory his favorite album as a teenager: Black Flags 1981 punk-rock manifesto, Damaged.

title: I'm Not Really Running, I'm Not Really Running...
description: BILL MORGAN, an emeritus professor of kinesiology at the University of Wisconsin, likes to tell the story, which he swears is true, of an Ivy League pole vaulter who held the Division 1 record in the Eastern region.

title: After Setbacks, Corzine Looks to Make Up for Lost Time
description: TRENTON, Dec. 5  Battered by a year of personal and political hardships, Gov. Jon S. Corzine is struggling to catch a second wind.

title: Manhattan: New Steps in Citys Energy Plan
description: The city will start implementing 132 energy-conservation projects in the next several months  the first in a series of steps aimed at reducing city energy consumption and greenhouse gas emission by 30 percent by 2017, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday. The projects, at a cost of $67 million, include installing energy-saving light bulbs and lamps in schools, police precincts and other municipal buildings and at landmarks including City Hall and the Brooklyn Bridge. The city will also upgrade the laundry system at Rikers Island to allow hot water to be filtered and reused, and will replace 200 of the most polluting vehicles in its 27,000-vehicle fleet with hybrid cars. Municipal government accounts for 6.5 percent of the citys total energy usage and 10 percent of its peak electricity demand.

title: E.P.A. Is Prodded to Require Cuts in Airliner Emissions
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5  Five states, New York City and several environmental groups filed petitions with the Environmental Protection Agency on Wednesday in an effort to force cuts in emissions of heat-trapping gases from airliners, a rapidly growing source.

title: Manhattan: Cyclist Killed in Accident
description: A bicyclist riding northbound on the Avenue of the Americas yesterday morning died after he struck an open car door, fell off his bicycle and landed in the street, where he was hit by a truck, the police said. The cyclist, David Smith, 63, of West Ninth Street, was taken to Bellevue Hospital Center, where he was pronounced dead, the police said. The accident happened shortly before 8:30 a.m. in front of 989 Avenue of the Americas, near 36th Street, the police said. Mr. Smith, who was riding in a designated bicycle lane, hit the cars door after someone on the passenger side opened it into his path, the police said. It was unclear if he was wearing a helmet. The police issued two summonses to the cars driver, Benjamin Siano, 52, of Staten Island, for parking at a fire hydrant and for blocking a bicycle lane. They also issued a summons to his passenger, Augustus Browne, 31, of Staten Island, for opening a door unsafely into traffic, the police said.

title: The Presidents Cynical Budget War
description: President Bushs lame-duck attempt to repair the Republican Partys threadbare fiscal reputation is an increasingly reckless game. In the latest exercise of irresponsibility for political gain, Mr. Bush reportedly wants to slash counterterrorism funding for front-line police and firefighters.

title: Diner Opens in Catskills After a Hells Kitchen Worth of Trouble
description: LIBERTY, N.Y.

title: Meat Processors Look for Ways to Keep Ground Beef Safe
description: LEXINGTON, Neb.  In the last decade, Tyson Fresh Meats has transformed its slaughterhouse here to combat a potentially deadly type of food poisoning, adding huge chambers to scald carcasses and wash them in acid, steam vacuums to suck away microbes and elaborate gear to test hundreds of meat samples a day.

title: Bolivia to Vote on Leaders Job
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Dec. 5 (Reuters)  President Evo Morales of Bolivia on Wednesday called for a nationwide referendum to decide whether he should stay in office as a way to resolve a deepening political crisis in the country.

title: Victims Urge Cluster-Bomb Ban
description: VIENNA, Dec. 5 (AP)  Victims of cluster bombs, many of whom had lost limbs, on Wednesday urged participants at an international conference to ban the weapons.

title: Post Office Drawback Cited in Dark Forecast for Netflix
description: When Netflixs seven million subscribers send their DVDs back to one of the rental services 47 distribution centers, the discs do not represent many happy returns for the Postal Service.

title: At Port Authority, Getting a Charge, at No Charge
description: The Port Authority Bus Terminal is all about lines. Lines of people waiting to buy tickets or waiting for their buses. Lines of buses waiting to leave or pull in. Then, there is another type of line  an electrical line.

title: In Iran We Trust?
description: Washington

title: Defense Challenges Status of Guantnamo Detainee
description: GUANTNAMO BAY, Cuba, Dec. 5  Challenging one of the central pillars of the Bush administrations detention policies, lawyers for a detainee who is charged as Osama bin Ladens driver argued here Wednesday that he should be treated as a prisoner of war and should not be tried by military commission.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,874 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:

title: Baseball Suspends 2 Over Banned Substances
description: Major League Baseball announced today that two players linked to shipments of banned substances had been suspended for 15 days, a template that will likely be used after George J. Mitchells report on performance-enhancing drugs is released. Those findings might be released late next week.The players  Jay Gibbons of the Baltimore Orioles and Jose Guillen, who played for the Seattle Mariners last season and has now joined the Kansas City Royals  were both suspended at the start of next season.

title: Reyes Is Back Home, and Not Going Anywhere
description: PALMAR ARRIBA, Dominican Republic, Dec. 4  Drive along the dusty, pothole-filled road, careful not to strike the roosters or stray dogs, until it dead-ends beside a stone staircase. Run up the steps, climb over the aqua-colored fence  or, for the less adventurous, slip through an open gate  and behold a field littered with avocado-size rocks and teeming with about 60 boys of all ages, many holding balls or gloves.

title: A Straight-Ahead Rock n Roll Juggernaut: Are Yall Having Fun Yet?
description: He stood onstage, bald and be-sideburned, facing a couple of thousand fans who seemed more pleased than thrilled to be there. He sang, he grimaced, he strummed a guitar, he sang some more. He angled for more applause. He pointed to one section of the crowd and asked, Yall having fun? Yeah, pretty much. To another section: Yall having fun? Sure they were.

title: A Tough Night for a Bernstein Baton
description: In the tradition-rich world of classical music, it was fitting that Gustavo Dudamel, the latest young lion of conducting, got to use one of Leonard Bernsteins batons in leading the New York Philharmonic as a guest conductor this week. Too bad for the baton. It broke shortly before the end of Tuesdays performance, said Barbara Haws, the orchestras historian. Ms. Haws, who had lent Mr. Dudamel the baton, right, said the broken tip was retrieved and two pieces were returned. She said she would reattach them. Its now taken on a new dimension, this little baton has, she said.

title: Germany: Berlin to Get Giant Ferris Wheel
description: Berlin officials broke ground this week for the construction of the Great Berlin Wheel, a 600-feet Ferris wheel that will top the London Eye by more than 160 feet to become the largest in Europe. It will be near the Berlin Zoo, on the western edge of Tiergarten Park. When it opens in about two years, it will have 36 air-conditioned cars, each capable of carrying 40 passengers. A ride around the wheel will take 35 minutes.

title: 10 Charged With Smuggling $200 Million in Fake Goods
description: Federal officials announced the arrests yesterday of 10 people they said were members of an international smuggling gang that illegally shipped millions of dollars worth of counterfeit apparel into the New York region from factories in China, often in falsely labeled shipping containers.

title: Knife at Taylors House Links Accused to Earlier Break In
description: MIAMI, Dec. 5  At least two of the four men charged with the murder of the Washington Redskins star Sean Taylor were involved in a burglary of his Miami-area home eight days before his shooting death, a law enforcement official and a lawyer involved in the case said Wednesday.

title: Born-Yesterday Candidates
description: The presidential campaign is sure getting hot. Mike Huckabee is inching ahead of Mitt Romney in Iowa, precipitating a fascinating national debate about whether Mormons or Baptists love Jesus more. Meanwhile, on the Democratic side, Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama are engaged in a battle over who has wanted to be president longer  or rather, less long.

title: A Coachs Tough Start at Duke, With an Eye Toward the Finish

title: Footnotes
description: The British government has granted $101 million toward a $435 million extension of the Tate Modern in London, the BBC reported. Designed by the Swiss architects Herzog & de Meuron, the 11-floor structure may open in time for the 2012 Olympics. ... Matthew Bucksbaum, a real estate magnate, and his wife, Kay, have donated $25 million to the Aspen Music Festival and School. The money will help establish a new 23-acre campus named after them, the festival said. It is the festivals largest gift. ... Stephen Hough has been named the winner of the $50,000 Jean Gimbel Lane Prize in Piano Performance. The award, given every two years by the Northwestern University School of Music, was established in 2005. Mr. Hough was a recipient of a MacArthur Fellowship in 2001.

title: CIRCUITS: A Fashion-Conscious Smartphone, Cloaked in a Mirror
description: Many cellphones feature high-resolution cameras, powerful processors and full keyboards. This one offers a screen that turns into a mirror, essentially making the pocket compact obsolete.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Saturday about an advisers report critical of the Food and Drug Administration misstated the date that the report was made public. It was posted on the agencys Web site last Thursday, not on Friday.

title: Apologetic, Facebook Changes Ad Program
description: Mark Zuckerberg, founder and chief executive of the social networking site Facebook, apologized to the sites users yesterday about the way it introduced a controversial new advertising feature last month.

title: Home & Garden Calendar
description: Building Sensors

title: 8 Victims in Omaha Shooting Are Identified
description: Police Chief Thomas Warren of Omaha identified the eight people who were killed in a shooting spree at a shopping mall on Wednesday. They included five women and three men who ranged in age from 24 to 66 years old. Six of the victims were employees of the Von Maur department store and two were customers:

title: Turning Kitchens Into Laboratories to Find Treats for the Allergy-Prone

title: As Death Hit His Family, Responsibilities Grew
description: When he is at church, Kenneth Williams fills his soul by singing gospel. When he is at home, dancing with his children, Kenyetta Kathleen Reaves, 16, and Lamont Ali Reaves, 17, and his brother, Russell, 37, lifts his spirits. Recently, at a friends house, he also discovered that rap could relieve his stress.

title: Bush Announces Mortgage Agreement
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6  President Bush announced an agreement with the mortgage industry today to freeze interest rates for up to five years for some of the two million homeowners who bought houses recently with subprime loans.

title: Tracing Business Acumen to Dyslexia
description: It has long been known that dyslexics are drawn to running their own businesses, where they can get around their weaknesses in reading and writing and play on their strengths. But a new study of entrepreneurs in the United States suggests that dyslexia is much more common among small-business owners than even the experts had thought.

title: Fordham Opens Its Gift: An Antiquities Museum
description: For some four decades, William D. Walsh browsed auction catalogs in search of the ancient artifacts that would gratify his passion for classical antiquity.

title: Guide to Student Loans
description: A college education may be the most important investment in a child's life and has become one of the most costly, too. The publicly reported tuition charged by private colleges and universities for the 2007-2008 can reach $50,000 a year. The trends are alarming, too. And while tuition at public universities is generally lower, costs there have been growing even more steeply in recent years as government support has lagged.

title: Has-Beens From Olympus Downgraded to Mortals
description: A tree meets a dog walker at the start of Gods Behaving Badly, Marie Phillipss flossy, high-concept comic novel. Im Kate, the tree says. I work in mergers and acquisitions for Goldman Sachs. And then: Could you dial my bosss number and hold the phone to my trunk?

title: Carlos Valds, a Conga King of Jazz, Dies at 81
description: Carlos Valds, better known as Patato, whose melodic conga playing made him a giant of Latin jazz in Cuba and then for more than half a century in America, died on Tuesday in Cleveland. He was 81 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Smoothing Out Web Video

title: Knicks Persevere for Marbury
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 5  Misfortune of varying degrees forced the Knicks to revamp their starting lineup and their mind-set, and to push aside several days worth of tough emotions Wednesday. The evening ended with their first good feelings of the week.

title: A Bundle of Joy Isnt Enough?
description: WHEN Jena Slosberg of Bedford, N.H., gave birth in March, she endured a labor that lasted 17 hours. But her discomfort was ultimately worth it, quite apart from the arrival of her daughter, Marin. In the recovery room, her husband, Paul, presented her with a pair of diamond earrings.

title: A Highly Visible Reminder of Your Houseplants Needs
description: This season, gifts are going green, so the Thirsty Light fits right in. Actually, this digital plant monitor, available from www.thirstylight.com, is colored green to blend in with your favorite houseplants leaves. If you neglect the plant, this $9.95 device berates you by blinking.

title: Old Havana Gets a Lift, but Cubans Dont Benefit
description: HAVANA  These days, when Eusebio Leal Spengler walks the streets of Old Havana, people treat him like a rock star. Ladies kiss him on the cheek and whisper that they love him. Children point at him.

title: Britain Cuts Rates; European Bank Stands Pat
description: FRANKFURT, Dec. 6  The European Central Bank, caught between fears of rising inflation and subsiding economic growth, walked a middle ground today, leaving interest rates unchanged.

title: Jefferson DeBlanc, Hero Pilot, Dies at 86
description: Jefferson J. DeBlanc, a World War II fighter pilot who was awarded the Medal of Honor for shooting down five Japanese planes on a single day while running out of fuel, died Nov. 22 in Lafayette, La. He was 86 and lived St. Martinville, La..

title: Reactor Shutdown Causing Medical Isotope Shortage
description: OTTAWA, Dec. 5  Medical treatments are being delayed or deferred at hospitals worldwide because of the extended shutdown of a Canadian reactor.

title: Bush Writes to North Korean Leader
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6  President Bush, directly engaging the man he publicly called a tyrant and privately called a pygmy, wrote a letter to the North Korean leader Kim Jong-il in which he held out the prospect of normalized relations with the United States if North Korea fully disclosed all nuclear programs and got rid of its nuclear weapons, administration officials said.

title: Opposition Candidate Cleared in Time for Korean Vote
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 5  South Korean prosecutors cleared the main opposition partys presidential candidate of stock manipulation charges on Wednesday, an outcome expected to increase his already high chances of restoring a conservative government to power.

title: Greece and Macedonia to Restart Talks on Name
description: ATHENS, Dec. 5  Greece and Macedonia on Wednesday agreed to hold a new round of talks on a festering dispute over Macedonias name that threatens to undercut its chances of joining NATO.

title: A Dead Man Has Some Explaining to Do
description: LONDON, Dec. 5  John Darwin was declared dead some four and a half years ago, so it was a surprise when he walked into a police station here on Saturday, claiming to have no idea what he had been doing all this time.

title: Springtime, Wrapped and Beribboned
description: I SAY this every year, and Ill say it again: Dont give cute presents to your gardening friends. Avoid stones engraved with the words Love or Peace. Instead, think about whats practical. A Shaker basket my sister, Martha, gave me is not only one of my favorites, but every time I carry it to the garden and fill it with cut flowers or fresh greens, I think of her.

title: Pessimism Is Growing in Executive Suites
description: The chiefs are getting worried.

description: BEIJING, Dec. 6  After pressing China for a new effort to police the safety of its food and other exports, the Bush administration is finding Chinese leaders pushing back, with demands for American commitments to insure the safety of American food and goods, administration officials say.

title: The Perks of a Faster Phone
description: Q. What is the advantage of a 3G phone?

title: Cecil Payne, Baritone Saxophonist, Dies at 84
description: Cecil Payne, who in the 1940s was one of the first baritone saxophonists to master the intricacies of modern jazz and who for more than half a century was a leading exponent of his instrument, died Nov. 27 in Stratford, N.J. He was 84.

title: Official Urges Arrest of 2 Darfur Suspects
description: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 5  The lead prosecutor of the International Criminal Court urged the Security Council on Wednesday to put pressure on Sudan to arrest and surrender two men indicted by the tribunal last spring for war crimes in Darfur.

title: Straight As, With a Burger as a Prize
description: FAST-FOOD chains often post nutritional report cards about their product ingredients on restaurant walls. Now one is using childrens report cards to help stimulate sales.

title: A Souped-Up Wireless Connection for Faster Web Browsing
description: Most jaded Wi-Fi users have moved beyond being awestruck that wireless networking works at all and have started complaining about the times when it fails to deliver a dependable connection. HField technologies (www.hfield.com) is going after this problem with Wi-Fire, a $79 antenna that connects to a U.S.B. port on either a Mac or Windows computer (XP and Vista).

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: China Cracks Down on Food Safety Violators
description: SHANGHAI, Dec. 6  China said today that it had demolished the facilities of more than 2,800 rural food makers as part of its effort to crack down on shoddy, fake or substandard food, according to the official Xinhua news agency.

title: Pakistan: Judges Involuntarily Retired
description: The government formally retired 37 judges who opposed President Pervez Musharrafs imposition of emergency in the country last month and refused to take a new oath of allegiance to him. They were 24 High Court judges and 13 Supreme Court justices, including the ousted chief justice, Iftikhar Muhammad Chaudhry. They will be denied pensions and other benefits, according to local reports. The forced retirements are expected to further shake up opposition parties, as well as rights groups that have been campaigning for an independent judiciary.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article by The Associated Press in Business Day last Thursday about the settlement of class-action lawsuits involving the Ford Explorer misstated the extent of the settlement. The agreement ends lawsuits brought by Explorer owners who said their vehicles had lost value because of the perceived hazard of rollovers. It does not end pending personal injury and wrongful death lawsuits stemming from Explorer rollovers.

title: House Boosts Fuel Economy Standards
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6  The House, brushing aside a veto threat from the White House, today passed a package of energy measures that includes a 40 percent increase in fuel economy standards for cars and light trucks sold in the United States.

title: Sleek Lines and Fat Cigars (if You Got Em)
description: Pedro Ruizs Club Havana has become a signature work for Ballet Hispanico, and on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater it was easy to see why. Hot and cool, the ballet takes Latin ballroom dances brought to the United States since the 1920s and artfully sews them together in choreography that could be performed only by classically trained dancers.

title: In Sonata Finale, Tension Gives Way to Introspection
description: In the landmark 1971 book The Classical Style, Charles Rosen wrote that Beethovens Kreutzer Sonata (Op. 47) has a first movement unequaled in formal clarity, grandeur and dramatic force by anything that Beethoven had yet written.

title: Room to Improve
description: Q. How do I replace the built-in metal hamper in my 1950s bathroom?

title: Other Mind Games
description: No matter how high you jump, how fast you run or swim, how powerfully you row, you can do better, Gina Kolata writes today in The Times. But sometimes your mind gets in the way. Since most people can do better, no matter how good their performance, the challenge is to find a safe way to push a little harder.

title: Everton Advances
description: Everton, Atletico Madrid, Villarreal, Hamburger SV and FC Basel won yesterday to advance to the UEFA Cups Round of 32. Everton became the first English club to advance past the group stage when Tim Cahill scored in the 85th minute for a 1-0 victory over Zenit St. Petersburg.

title: Tax Stalemate Threatens Chaos as Filing Nears
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5  President Bush and lawmakers of both parties are finally in full agreement on something. All proclaim that middle-class taxpayers should be spared a surprise bill in the coming months posed by the alternative minimum tax.

title: Noel Rings Up Sales
description: Josh Grobans album Nol (Reprise) held onto the top spot on the Billboard 200 chart for a second consecutive week with sales of 539,000 copies, compared with the 405,000 it tallied last week, according to Nielsen SoundScan. If Mr. Grobans sales were increased by a recent appearance on The Oprah Winfrey Show, an appearance on 60 Minutes may have helped elevate the Eagles Long Road Out of Eden to second place from fifth, with sales of 313,000 copies. The Alicia Keys album As I Am (J) slid into third place, with 257,000 copies sold, followed by the compilation Now Thats What I Call Music Vol. 26 (127,000 copies) and Garth Brookss Ultimate Hits (Pearl), with 112,000 copies sold.

title: Coke Names an Insider as Its New Chief
description: For Coca-Colas heir apparent, the time has come.

title: Robert O. Anderson, Oil Executive, Dies at 90
description: Robert O. Anderson, an oilman whose Stetson-size accomplishments included building Atlantic Richfield into an industry giant; discovering oil in Alaska; becoming Americas largest rancher, and giving generously to environmental causes, died on Sunday at his home in Roswell, N.M. He was 90.

title: Teenage Birth Rate Rises for First Time Since 91
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5  The birth rate among teenagers 15 to 19 in the United States rose 3 percent in 2006, according to a report issued Wednesday, the first such increase since 1991. The finding surprised scholars and fueled a debate about whether the Bush administrations abstinence-only sexual education efforts are working.

title: Details in Military Notes Led to Shift on Iran, U.S. Says
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5  American intelligence agencies reversed their view about the status of Irans nuclear weapons program after they obtained notes last summer from the deliberations of Iranian military officials involved in the weapons development program, senior intelligence and government officials said on Wednesday.

title: Theres Sunlight in Albany?
description: So seldom is there good news out of New Yorks state capital that when something like the new Project Sunlight Web site emerges, the instinct is to wonder how soon before the forces of darkness will try to kill it. Until they do, the new site from Attorney General Andrew Cuomos office gives ordinary New Yorkers the ability to see information about their state that should have been easily accessible in the first place.

title: Task Force on N.Y. Flight Delays Issues Report
description: Trying to head off threats by the federal government to reduce flights at the three New York airports, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, along with airline industry executives and local transportation officials, unveiled 100 recommendations today that are meant to unlock congestion at the airports and allow them to handle more traffic.

title: Arrest in Nightclub Killing
description: A Brooklyn man has been arrested in connection with the killing of a nightclub patron in Manhattan two weeks ago, the police said yesterday. The man, Anthony Taylor, 26, of 141 East 21st Street, in Brooklyn, was arrested yesterday in Atlanta and will be returned to New York, investigators said. The fatal attack, on Nov. 23, occurred about closing time at Duvet, a bar and club at 45 West 21st Street, in the Flatiron district. The victim, Shamel G. McKinney, 25, of Brooklyn, was stabbed once in the chest. A knife was recovered in a nearby trash bin, but investigators have not said whether it was the weapon used in the killing. They also have not commented on a motive.

title: OPEC Finds Price Range to Live With
description: When oil prices were approaching the milestone of $100 a barrel a few weeks ago, OPEC, the global oil cartel, expanded production and sought to jawbone prices down. In January, when prices were near $50 and falling, OPEC cut supplies to stem the decline.

Post-Xena, of course, the rules for jewels changed. Now rings with the structure (and punch) of brass knuckles are giving the old diamond solitaire a poke in the eye.

description: East Rutherford, N.J.

description: KUALA CENAKU, Indonesia, Dec. 1  Here on the island of Sumatra, about 1,200 miles from the global climate talks under way on Bali, are some of the worlds fastest-disappearing forests.

description: ASPEN, Colo., Dec. 5  Haunted by the memory of a violent accident in a race early last year, the 2006 Olympic mens downhill champion, Antoine Dnriaz of France, announced his retirement from skiing Wednesday.

description: Bears at Redskins

More recently, the region has been relatively peaceful, but many of its problems have merely been kicked down the road. Now, one of the most dangerous is coming to a head, with a United Nations deadline on Monday for resolving Kosovos political status.

Corzine plans to go to Iowa on Thursday to campaign for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, but when it comes to governing he is actually following a path blazed by another presidential candidate who lived in the Arkansas governors mansion: former Gov. Mike Huckabee.

title: Young Sanjaya and Pals Go Caroling
What Did You Do in the War, Henry?

The Vice President currently lives inside the gates of the new Observatory  an 1890s improvement that took the astronomers to higher ground. This older one sprang from the vision of John Quincy Adams, who called for it in his 1825 State of the Union message. It wasnt his fault that the choice of a site  a malarial patch of land so often fogged over that the astronomers couldnt see anything  fell to one of his successors, John Tyler, more than fifteen years later.

title: Mississippi Lawyer Pleads Guilty in Bribery Case
description: A lawyer has pleaded guilty to conspiracy to bribe a judge and is assisting federal prosecutors in a case involving one of the nations wealthiest trial lawyers, according to court documents.

title: What the Gen Y Worker Wants
description: When I finished law school in the recession of 1991, jobs were scarce. I didnt have a job upon graduation and that was fairly common. Young people entering the job market today face a far more welcoming workplace. And as increasing numbers of baby boomers retire, the newest members of the work force will have even more choices. This anticipated shortage of skilled labor has been called the war for talent, and even if there is some dispute as to its grounding in fact, employers are behaving as if its real. Last week one of the most e-mailed articles on The New York Times Web site was about a law firm employing a happiness consultant to make sure that everyone was feeling properly fulfilled. I expect to see more of this type of thing.

title: Former Brocade Executive Convicted of Options Fraud

description: Pelikan Technologies, which makes a device for electronically extracting blood samples for glucose monitoring in diabetics, raised $69 million in venture funding. title: Calculating the CO2 Cost of Al Gore and Bali
description: A few days ago, I was sent Al Gores schedule for December. He (and his family and his aides) are flying first to Norway to pick up his Nobel Prize on the 10th, and then flying on to Bali for the climate conference there. OK, Al Gore is a real hero of the environmental movement, and has admirably helped galvanize the world to action.

Among the shopping: Hans Ulrich Obrist and Beatrix Ruf Anne McNally and Anh Duong were laughing at being punkd by the fake ATM created by Elmgren & Dragset for the Massimo De Carlo booth. title: Miramax 2.0
description: The Weinstein boys, Harvey and Bob, may not be in the house, but the logo is the same and the presence of same in the Oscars race remains a big factor. The Bagger happened to read something about how Daniel Battsek, a quiet Brit and the anti-mogul, has teamed up with Scott Rudin, the producer behind The Queen, No Country for Old Men and a million other movies, to keep the awards machine stoked. If the National Board of Reviews taste in movies is at all predictive, should be a nice little year at the Disney division.

title: Will Competition Improve Subway Performance?
description: New York City Transit is to announce an overhaul today of how the subway system is managed. As William Neuman reports, the changes will give individual subway lines a greater degree of autonomy by putting each one under the direction of a manager who will be responsible for almost everything that happens on the tracks, in the trains and in the stations. The goal is to have each subway line operate, in many ways, as a self-contained railroad. The 24 lines will compete against one another and be rated on service, cleanliness, on-time performance and other measures.

title: B.C.S. = Bad. Choice. System.
description: Imagine if other sports had such rampant disregard for their postseasons, Will Leitch writes about the B.C.S. system in this weeks Play newsletter. The Cubs would make the playoffs every year; the Packers would host a wild-card game even if they were 8-8; heck, the N.B.A. might even find a place for the Knicks. For all the talk of the B.C.S. being impartial, the selection process for the non-title game bowls is steeped in the same cronyism and back-scratching weve been mired in for years.

title: A Lost Fight Over Washington Square Parks Renovation
description: It seems appropriate that the renovation of Washington Square Park would involve six years of planning, arguing and fighting. After all, a spot that has played host to marching suffragists, picketing workers and protesting beatniks should not ease into changes without a brickbat or two, even if they are only rhetorical. But after all the shouting, the citys proposal to shift the parks fountain into direct line with the Washington Square Arch, add more lawn and spruce up the statues and fixtures finally seems about to move forward. In a decision issued on Monday, a judge dismissed two remaining claims against the renovation plan. Filed on behalf of community activists, the lawsuits claimed that the citys Department of Parks and Recreation plan would violate environmental rules and alter the nature of the park.

title: A Privy for the Privileged
description: Nature designed me for a big chair, one more than 31 inches from the chair in front of me. Im pretty tall, perhaps more than adequately wide, and jumbo-footed. My feet, egads! The front-seat overhang of a taxi traps my foot every time. I thus prefer the bus or the subway. When I fly, I want my shoes parallel, north and south, not in an X shape. In addition, I dislike having to win an elbow rest through combat. Sounds like first class should suit me.

These two have been on the road for three months for CSTV.com (with weekly dispatches for The Quad), checking out the wacky happenings on the college football landscape. Their final stop was the Big 12 title game in San Antonio, where they encountered some excited Missouri alums and a singing Lee Roy Selmon. Its been quite a trek for these two and were glad they shared their adventures with The Quad.

title: Art Basel Miami | The Novel Place to Stay
description: Scoring a room at the writer Brian Antonis house is possibly the ultimate stay in town. Just ask the German painter Anselm Kiefer, who described Antonis hodgepodge of quirky objets trouve mixed with pieces like a classical self-portrait bust by Antonis sister, Janine, as the best art in America. Not only is the house enlightening, but Antoni, whose book South Beach: The Novel is due out from Grove Atlantic in February, is just the kind of tour guide you want. His reserve of gossip from Miami days past is perfect breakfast fodder. Just ask regulars like Jeffrey Deitch, Ellen Barkin or Patrick McMullan (who, we hear, has been sporting a bed-head look at Antonis all week). Take that, Andre Balazs!

title: Art Basel Miami | Patriot Games
description: Richard Princes mega-retrospective at the Guggenheim may be called Spiritual America, but the artist does not necessarily have God on his side. I mean, could it really be coincidental that just as the exhibition was coming together this summer, his Guggenheim-owned installation in upstate New York, Second House, was struck by lightning and burned to the ground? Meanwhile, here in Miami Beach, the intersection of Booth C-13 (White Cube Gallery) and Booth C-16 (Hauser & Wirth) at Art Basel marks an interesting nexus of un-American activity. On one corner, Christoph Buchel weighs in with Training Ground for Training Ground for Democracy, a raucous two-story kindergarten cum internment camp that is simultaneously a prequel and a riposte to the Swiss artists ill-fated Mass MoCA show. On the opposite corner, White Cube throws a double punch with Tracey Emins tri-color neon wall sculpture Red, White and [f-bomb deleted] Blue, and Liza Lous bewitching Black Flag, which gives new meaning to the words Star Spangled Banner.

title: Regrets Only

Ms. Kanes departure represents a significant loss for the department; she was one of the officials hired by the chancellor and gained a reputation for being extremely hard working and an important behind-the-scenes organizer of the department.Kristens contribution to our city and schools has been incalculable, Mr. Klein said in a statement. She helped to shape and manage virtually every significant initiative of recent years, and her skill and dedication made her a model of public service. I am deeply grateful to Kristen for her work and wish her the best.

title: How Would You Run These Subway Lines?

Arkansass Darren McFadden won the Walter Camp Award honoring the best player (given out by the Walter Camp Foundation) and the Doak Walker Award, given to the top running back. description: Holiday Tree Farms in Oregon prepares for the holidays.

title: Writers Talks Get Dose of Reality
description: As wrangling over a new contract for striking Hollywood writers focused on digital media, other issues abruptly emerged as potential stumbling blocks, the Associated Press reports.

title: Accessorizing a Catskills Farmhouse With a Past
description: THE first thing that might surprise a visitor to Bruce Littlefields Catskill retreat in Marbletown, N.Y., is the relative restraint he has shown this year in decorating for the holidays.

description: JAZZ
