title: Its Busy at the Top in the Hawaii Luxury-Home Market
description: WHILE real estate transactions continue to slump in many places on the United States mainland, the strength of Hawaiis international pull has propelled its luxury sales ahead of last years and has increased speculative development.

title: A Devotion to Film Binds Two Loners
description: In Man in the Chair Christopher Plummer, an actor typecast nowadays as a suave, smiling cobra slithering through the corridors of power, sheds his scales to play a tippling old curmudgeon raging against the dying of the light. His fierce portrayal of Flash Madden, a long-retired Hollywood studio gaffer, is the knot that ties together this sentimental intergenerational drama.

title: C.I.A. Destroyed 2 Tapes Showing Interrogations
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6  The Central Intelligence Agency in 2005 destroyed at least two videotapes documenting the interrogation of two Qaeda operatives in the agencys custody, a step it took in the midst of Congressional and legal scrutiny about its secret detention program, according to current and former government officials.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: ART

title: Holiday Sounds, Traditional and Otherwise
description: How should a musician celebrate Christmas? Plunge into the holiday bustle or reconnect to tradition; savor the comfort of familiarity or seek a new personal twist; pay attention to family, to faith or, perhaps, to food. All those choices are part of this years notable holiday albums, reviewed here by the music critics of The New York Times.

title: Congressional Maneuvering Dooms Hate Crime Measure
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6  Congressional Democrats on Thursday dropped their effort to tie a Pentagon policy measure to an expanded definition of federal hate crimes covering sexual orientation, ending chances that the long-stalled hate crime measure would clear Congress this year.

title: Moving on From City Hall, a High-Level Relationship That Was Built on Trust
description: Not until the penultimate sentence does the 21-paragraph City Hall news release announcing Daniel L. Doctoroffs departure as deputy mayor mention his new job.

title: Ex-I.R.S. Agent Says Tax Evasion by Real Estate Partners Is Huge
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6  Investors in real estate partnerships evade billions of dollars in federal taxes each year, even though detecting this type of cheating is easy, a former specialist in partnerships for the Internal Revenue Service said Thursday.

title: Aspen Skiing Company
description: Updated: December 2008

title: Chief of Coke to Step Down After Steering Its Recovery
description: In the annals of Coca-Colas history, E. Neville Isdell may well be remembered as the man who stopped the bleeding and sutured the wounds.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions on Nov. 28 about a hearing on whether WWOR, a New Jersey-based TV station owned by Fox Television Stations, covers New Jersey sufficiently to merit renewal of its broadcast license referred incorrectly to a WWOR video camera that recorded the proceedings. Although there was a piece of masking tape on the camera, it was not in fact covering the letters NY. Fox says that the stations cameras are labeled My9 and do not have the letters NY on them. (Fox uses My9NY as a slogan and as part of its Web site address.)

title: Senate Backs Freeze on Tax Without Cost Offsets
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6  Trying to find a way out of a sticky tax problem, the Senate on Thursday voted overwhelmingly to prevent the alternative minimum tax from hitting millions of middle-class Americans without replacing the $50 billion that would be lost.

title: Women on the Verge of a Fiery Afterlife
description: Beneath its theatrical little flourishes and a philosophy of East-West accommodation, The Gate is modest in both its materials and its ambitions. The fourth installment of Tan Duns Orchestral Theater series, The Gate, which opened on Wednesday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, gathers three women from different cultures to tell their stories at the gates of hell.

title: Duke Erases a Bitter Taste and Ends Skid
description: DURHAM, N.C., Dec. 6  About two minutes into the second half of one of the more frustrating performances of the season by the Rutgers womens basketball team, Coach C. Vivian Stringer apparently had seen enough.

title: Gates Leaves Iraq Encouraged
description: MANAMA, Bahrain, Dec. 6  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said Thursday that security progress in Iraq was significant yet still fragile, an assessment echoed by the senior American commander in Baghdad, who strongly cautioned against a premature declaration of victory.

title: The Essence of Mormonism
description: Joseph Smith founded Mormonism in the 19th century in upstate New York as a restoration of what he considered to be the true Christian church.

title: Russian Court Orders Release of a Journalist, Group Says
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 6 (AP)  A Russian court has ordered the release of a reporter committed to a psychiatric hospital for nine months after writing articles critical of the military campaign in Chechnya, Reporters Without Borders said Thursday.

title: U.S. to Pressure China on Food and Product Safety at Coming Trade Talks
description: BEIJING, Dec. 6  When Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. started his strategic economic dialogue with China a year ago, he was seeking greater access for American goods and services and hoping to persuade the Chinese to let the value of their currency rise against the dollar.

title:
Democrats Call for Inquiry in
Destruction of Tapes by C.I.A.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7  Angry Democratic lawmakers called for investigations today into the Central Intelligence Agencys destruction in 2005 of at least two videotapes documenting the interrogation of two Qaeda operatives in the agencys custody.

title: Medicare Cuts Payout on 2 Cancer Drugs
description: New Medicare rules for a small but promising class of cancer drugs may cause thousands of lymphoma patients to lose access to the treatment, which in some cases is the only therapy available to them.

title: Automakers Change Course on Fuel Standards
description: DETROIT  Just six months ago, an auto industry trade group warned that consumers could be forced to buy vehicles they did not want if Congress went too far in raising fuel economy standards.

title: Hunter Mountain
description: Updated: December 2008

title: Extension for Miles
description: Louisiana State Coach Les Miles has signed a contract extension that will keep him with the Tigers through 2012. The deal was approved yesterday by the L.S.U. boards athletic committee, apparently ending any chance of Miles leaving for Michigan to replace Lloyd Carr, who retired last month.

title: A Leading Asian Utility to Cut Carbon Emissions
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 6  CLP, one of Asias largest power utilities, plans to commit itself on Friday to sharply reducing its emissions of carbon dioxide.

title: Faith vs. the Faithless
description: Jon Meacham is the editor of Newsweek and the author of American Gospel, which describes the history of religious liberty in the United States. Richard John Neuhaus is the editor in chief of First Things and the author of The Naked Public Square, which is about efforts to banish religion from public conversation.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 29 about the Nixon administrations alarm over Israels nuclear weapons program described incorrectly the process that prompted the Richard Nixon Presidential Library and Museum to release previously classified documents. The release was the result of declassification requests by researchers at the National Security Archive of George Washington University and elsewhere; it was not because of a regulation requiring review and possible declassification of documents after 25 years.

title: Scout Leader in California Accused of Abuse
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 6  A scout leader who once sued the City of Berkeley for challenging a national Boy Scout ban on members who are gay or atheist has been arrested on felony charges that for at least five years he sexually abused young males in the troops he led.

title: Feathers Are Shed in Logo
description: The College of William and Marys new logo sheds the two feathers that the N.C.A.A. deemed offensive to American Indians. The logo, revealed yesterday, updates the familiar W&M monogram and uses the schools more traditional colors of green and gold instead of the more recent green and yellow. Last year, the N.C.A.A. ruled William and Mary could keep its Tribe nickname but could not display its athletic logo with feathers at N.C.A.A. championship events or play host to N.C.A.A. tournament games at which the logo would be shown.

title: The Crisis of Faith
description: Mitt Romney obviously felt he had no choice but to give a speech yesterday on his Mormon faith. Even by the low standards of this campaign, it was a distressing moment and just what the nations founders wanted to head off with the immortal words of the First Amendment: A presidential candidate cowed into defending his way of worshiping God by a powerful minority determined to impose its religious tenets as a test for holding public office.

title: The Hills Are Still Alive, Just Look Past the Strings
description: Perhaps youve suffered through the clip-clop-clunk of a mediocre marionette performance, one in which there is no effort to invest the wooden stars with flexibility or personality. At the remarkable Sound of Music created by the Salzburg Marionette Theater, youll know youre seeing an entirely different level of artistry as soon as the curtain goes up. Its the nun down on her hands and knees scrubbing the floor, with a very convincing floor-scrubbing motion, who tips you off.

title: Despite Report, France and Germany Keep Pressure on Iran
description: PARIS, Dec. 6  The leaders of France and Germany said Thursday that Iran remained a danger and that other nations needed to keep up the pressure over its nuclear program despite a United States intelligence reports conclusion that Tehran was no longer building a bomb.

title: Under a Microscope, Bush and His Presidency
description: The story of how the Bush administration took the United States to war in Iraq is such a complicated tale with so many plots and subplots, so much misinformation and spin, so many missteps and outrageous misjudgments that reporters in countless newspaper and magazine articles, television documentaries and dozens of books have struggled to piece together the narrative. It is a continuing process, as more and more information comes to light and needs to be sifted and weighed and connected.

title: Spare Times
description: AROUND TOWN

title: Brooklyn: Girls Death Ruled Homicide
description: The death of a 3-year-old girl late Wednesday in Bedford-Stuyvesant was ruled a homicide yesterday by the city medical examiner. Police investigators were questioning the girls parents, and her three siblings were placed with the Administration for Childrens Services. The police said they found the girl, identified as Tkai Marcelle, unconscious when they went to the familys apartment late Wednesday in response to a 911 call. The girl was pronounced dead at Interfaith Medical Center in Brooklyn. An autopsy yesterday determined that the cause of death was multiple injuries from blunt impact.

title: Eye Candy, Noses, Beauty and Ugliness, Illustrated
description: Just as there is more to art than pretty pictures, there is more to art books than gorgeous illustrations. When the art and architecture critics of The New York Times were asked to choose their favorite books of 2007, their selections included a collection of essays on the museum in the age of globalization, two pessimistic studies of the modern city, a volume of poetry and an anthology of ugliness. But rest assured: the list still includes plenty of provocative, powerful and just plain knockout pictures, from Rembrandt's soulful noses to Martn Ramrez's visionary paintings.

title: Web Access and E-Mail on Flights
description: Passengers may soon hear a new in-flight announcement: You can now log on.

title: With Miles Staying Put, Michigan Talks to Schiano
description: Rutgers Coach Greg Schiano interviewed for the coaching vacancy at Michigan on Wednesday, according to a person who was briefed on the meeting but was not authorized to speak about it. Schiano met with Bill Martin, the Michigan athletic director, in New York, but has not received a job offer.

title: Unfinished Business Marks Winter Meetings
description: NASHVILLE, Dec. 6  A blizzard of major league executives marched through the spacious Opryland Hotel, stopped in the packed lobby and then bolted for the airport. The winter meetings ended Thursday, but for most of these suitcase-toting officials there was still work to be done in molding their teams.

title: French Leader Urges Guerrilla to Free Woman
description: PARIS, Dec. 6  It was an unusual message from a president to a guerrilla. But the televised appeal by President Nicolas Sarkozy of France to the Colombian rebel leader Manuel Marulanda to release a woman who has been held hostage for nearly six years was only the latest episode in a tale of human endurance.

title: Big Foot Follies
description: Theres precious little to laugh at in The Sasquatch Gang, a sad attempt to board the loser-nerd comedy bandwagon. Boasting a writer and director, Tim Skousen, who was an assistant director on Napoleon Dynamite, the movie affirms its pedigree with a near-subliminal cameo by that films star, Jon Heder. As if the stoned line delivery and moronic behavior werent enough to give the game away.

title: German Design for an Industrial Age
description: Tomorrow Sothebys begins the presale view of the 114 lots in the Dec. 14 auction Deutscher Werkbund to Bauhaus: An Important Collection of German Design, devoted to industrial design by architects and craftsmen working in Germany from the late 1890s to the early 1930s.

title: Plans for Le Massif: Fame and Fortune
description: DESPITE its spectacular setting high above the St. Lawrence River, Le Massif is a remote ski destination that has attracted little attention outside Quebec since it opened 25 years ago.

title: Dolls Village: Some See Restoration as Too Cutesy
description: AURORA, N.Y.  After a five-year makeover at the hands of the founder of the American Girl doll collection, this village of white clapboard and faded brick on Cayuga Lake practically glows, with freshly painted homes, refurbished inns and markets selling dried organic cranberries and cheese made from sheeps milk.

title: Philippine Court Convicts 14 in Kidnapping Case
description: MANILA, Dec. 6  A Philippine court on Thursday convicted 14 members of the Abu Sayyaf terrorist group in the 2001 kidnapping of 20 people off an island resort, including three Americans, two of whom were eventually killed.

title: China Reports Progress in Food Safety
description: SHANGHAI, Dec. 6  China said on Thursday that it had demolished the facilities of more than 2,800 rural food makers as part of its effort to crack down on shoddy, fake or substandard food, according to the official Xinhua news agency.

title: Personal Responsibility Underground
description: Veterans of many seasons navigating New York Citys intricate subway network had to smile at the latest idea for improving their daily commute. Howard Roberts Jr., president of New York City Transit, wants to decentralize and make the various lines  there are 23 or 24 depending on how you count  compete against each other like separate railroads.

title: The Young Bob Dylan, Charismatic and Electric
description: These days, and not for the first time, it seems as if everyone wants to be Bob Dylan. There are the half-dozen impersonators in Todd Hayness Im Not There, soon to be followed by John C. Reilly in a few scenes of Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story, and behind them there are several generations of guitar strummers and harmonica blowers Dylanizing in the streets and subway tunnels of every major city in the world.

title: Dance Listings
description: DANCE

title: U.S. Agencys Slow Pace Endangers Foreign Aid
description: The Millennium Challenge Corporation, a federal agency set up almost four years ago to reinvent foreign aid, has taken far longer to help poor, well-governed countries than its supporters expected or its critics say is reasonable.

title: Megans Parents Ask Trenton Not to Abolish Death Penalty
description: TRENTON, Dec. 6  Four days before the State Senate is to vote on a bill that would make New Jersey the first state in a generation to abolish the death penalty, the parents of the young girl whose rape and murder led to Megans Law urged legislators to oppose the measure.

title: A Collector Gives the Gift of Modern Art
description: Until his death in March, Richard S. Zeisler kept such a low profile that few people in the art world beyond museum circles knew his name. A private investor who lived in Manhattan, he quietly amassed more than 110 works by 20th-century masters like Mir, Magritte, Max Beckmann and Francis Bacon.

title: Romney Seeks to Defuse Concerns Over Mormon Faith
description: COLLEGE STATION, Tex., Dec. 6  In a heavily anticipated speech addressing the religion issue that has dogged the campaign of Mitt Romney, the Republican candidate mentioned the word Mormon only once today in asking the nation not to reject his presidential candidacy based upon his faith.

title: Crisscrossing the Stage, Highly Charged Moves From Familiar Pieces
description: How easily the memory plays tricks. Or does it? The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater made a nearly abstract piece of Talley Beattys classic Road of the Phoebe Snow on Wednesday night at City Center. And the company performed Aileys River as if it were anything but the sometimes pallid-seeming exercise in choreographing for a ballet troupe. Still, on Saturday afternoon Aileys Night Creature looked like its sly familiar self, even with Alicia J. Graf giving the work a slightly unfamiliar twist.

title: Holding the Hungry Hostage
description: It is a travesty that the fates of some 35 million Americans who need food aid are tied to the farm bill, which comes up every five years. The House passed an inadequate version last summer, and the Senate has failed to advance its own. It is time to ask why feeding the hungry must include a trough for multibillion-dollar agribusiness.

title: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
description: Previously recorded: $2,603,086.73

title: An Imax and AMC Venture Will Expand 3-D Theaters
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 6  Imax and AMC Entertainment are teaming up to open 100 Imax theaters, doubling the number of large-format 3-D outlets in the United States and adding momentum to Hollywoods growing interest in the genre.

title: Islams Silent Moderates
description: The woman and the man guilty of adultery or fornication, flog each of them with 100 stripes: Let no compassion move you in their case, in a matter prescribed by Allah, if you believe in Allah and the Last Day. (Koran 24:2)

title: Smugglers Build an Underground World
description: TECATE, Calif., Dec. 6  The tunnel opening cut into the floor of a shipping container here drops three levels, each accessible by ladders, first a metal one and then two others fashioned from wood pallets. The tunnel stretches 1,300 feet to the south, crossing the Mexican border some 50 feet below ground and proceeding to a sky-blue office building in sight of the steel-plated border fence.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article yesterday about the sluggish start of the Duke womens basketball team under a new head coach, including a rare three-game losing streak, misstated the last time the Blue Devils lost four games in a row. It was 1994, not 1995.

title: Murdoch Said to Have Plan for Shake-Up at Dow Jones
description: With a week to go before the News Corporation takes control of Dow Jones & Company, there are already management changes under way at the top of Dow Jones.

title: From the Archives, Old Hits Dressed Up for the Season
description: Holidays are for memories, and for recording companies theyre also good reason to plunge into archives in order to rediscover and repackage hits, rarities, live recordings and thematic collections. Here the music critics of The New York Times review some of this years compilations and anthologies.

title: Kidd Denounces Fuss Over a Sick Day and Says He Is Not Unhappy
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 6  About 30 reporters formed a semicircle in front of Jason Kidd at the Nets practice facility Thursday afternoon. Kidd surveyed the scene for several seconds and then raised an eyebrow.

title: A-Rods Properties and Charity Suggest Some Stinginess
description: The veneer of Alex Rodriguezs real estate empire of working-class housing is staged to disguise his inner Mr. Potter.

title: Recorded on a Suspects Hidden MP3 Player, a Bronx Detective Faces 12 Perjury Charges
description: A veteran New York City police detective was arraigned on perjury charges in the Bronx yesterday after a suspect in an attempted murder case secretly recorded his interrogation with an MP3 player.

title: With Family
description: Dirty Laundry, the second feature by the writer and director Maurice Jamal, is a back-to-your-roots film about a gay African-American named Sheldon (Rockmond Dunbar) who meets a young son (Aaron Grady Shaw) he didnt know he had, and revisits his extended family in an intolerant Southern town he once fled in the name of self-respect.

title: Bill Would Give Tax Break to Exonerated Prisoners
description: Seven months after his release from prison in 2001, after serving 15 years for a rape he did not commit, David Pope received $385,000 in compensation from the State of Texas and set out to rebuild his life: He rented an apartment, bought a car, helped his mother pay bills and traveled overseas for the first time.

title: China Media Less Aggressive in Foreign Coverage
description: SHANGHAI  For the second time in as many months there was big trouble in an important allied country that sits on Chinas borders, with huge crowds demonstrating, bombs exploding, opposition leaders being arrested and demonstrators killed.

title: Murray Klein, Who Helped Build Zabars Into Food Destination, Dies at 84
description: Murray Klein, who helped transform Zabars from a typical Jewish delicatessen on the Upper West Side of Manhattan into a culinary and cultural landmark, died yesterday in Manhattan. He was 84.

title: The Staggering Cost of a Long War
description: To the Editor:

title: A Video Posted Online Poses a Riddle for Police
description: The amateur video lasts just a few minutes. It shows a group of young people standing over a man seated in a New York subway car, taunting him, waving a plastic bottle in his face and eventually striking him with their hands as he cowers under their blows.

title: Britain: Terror Detention Plan Draws Fire
description: The government again sought the power to jail terrorism suspects without charge for up to 42 days, and the proposal brought immediate pledges of defeat from opposition parties and outrage from civil rights groups. Home Secretary Jacqui Smith, left, said the existing 28-day limit did not give the authorities enough time to investigate terrorism cases, which can involve unraveling false identities, tracking evidence in multiple languages and deciphering links to international terrorist networks. She also said, There is a serious and sustained threat from terrorism. The proposed new limits must go through Parliament.

title: A New Bush Tack on North Korea
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6  President Bush, directly engaging the man he publicly called a tyrant, wrote a letter to North Koreas leader, Kim Jong-il, in which he held out the prospect of normalized relations with the United States if North Korea fully disclosed its nuclear programs and dismantled its nuclear reactor, administration officials said Thursday.

title: Congress Drops Measure on Hate Crimes
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6  Congressional Democrats today dropped their effort to tie a Pentagon policy measure to an expanded definition of federal hate crimes covering sexual orientation, ending chances that the long-stalled hate crime measure would clear Congress this year.

title: Panama: Move for Chinese in Schools
description: The National Assembly has taken a step toward making the teaching of Mandarin compulsory in all schools, the BBC reported. Supporters of the bill, which has received conditional approval in the first of three debates, say increasing the number of Chinese speakers would help increase Panamas competitiveness in the world, the report said. It said the proposed legislation set out a time frame of 10 years for Mandarin to be taught in all schools. Chinese teachers would be allowed to immigrate to help train local teachers.

title: With Bonds Set to Appear Today, Former Prosecutor Expects a Trial
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 6  Kevin V. Ryan, the former United States attorney here who helped lead the investigation into steroids in sports, said he expected Barry Bonds to push his defense all the way to a trial, where he would face an array of former associates, ballplayers and medical experts.

title: Passaic: Police Defend Shooting
description: The police said yesterday that they were justified in shooting 20 times at an unarmed woman who led them on a car chase through northern New Jersey. The woman, Michelle M. Moleti, 34, was at St. Josephs Regional Medical Center in Paterson, recovering from six gunshot wounds, said James Avigliano, the Passaic County prosecutor. He said officers fired at the woman when she tried to run them over. The officers who fired the shots were from Clifton, where the chase began, according to Clifton Detective Capt. Robert Rowan. Mr. Avigliano said charges would be filed against Ms. Moleti.

title: The Props Can Burst, and Thats the Point
description: This much might be said for the Gazillion Bubble Show: It is unusual.

title: 105 Killed in China Mine Explosion
description: SHANGHAI, Friday, Dec. 7  A gas explosion at a coal mine in northern China late Wednesday killed at least 105 people in one of the countrys worst mining accidents this year, the official Xinhua news agency said Friday.

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: The Gospel of Judas: A Word From the Translators
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about health care proposals offered by some presidential candidates referred incorrectly to Massachusetts residents who might be exempt from the states mandated health insurance plan. The state has estimated that up to 20 percent of all uninsured residents could be exempt  not 20 percent of all residents. (The percentage of residents who have no insurance is estimated at between 6 and 10 percent.)

title: Strike Costs Become Test for Hosts of Talk Shows
description: The strike by the Writers Guild has shut down televisions favorite late-night shows, leaving the hosts to spend their days calling their agents to check out the latest rumors  and calling their financial advisers to determine how much the strike is costing them.

title: A Devil of a Christmas
description: Do you know how you behave when youre drunk, I mean, really drunk? If the answer is yes, then youve never been that drunk, since the curse and kindness of vast quantities of alcohol is that they obliterate self-awareness.

title: Searching for Clues to a Young Killers Motivation
description: OMAHA, Dec. 6  The authorities on Thursday scoured surveillance tapes and studied text messages, voice mail and letters that a gunman sent before he stepped from a third-floor elevator in a shopping mall here and killed eight people.

title: Strangers in a Land Thats Not So Strange
description: Stranded in the Israeli desert, the eight Egyptian members of the Alexandria Ceremonial Police Orchestra look a bit like a joke in search of a punch line. If The Bands Visit were any other kind of film  a little more pat, say, and rather less knowing  these eight souls might quickly transform into mere props in a small-scale sermon about Middle East mans humanity to Middle East man, minus the politics of course.

title: Obstacles to Changing Old Ways of Subways
description: The Wet Paint signs were still up yesterday at the 14th Street station of the Eighth Avenue subway line. Work crews had given the stations orange columns a fresh coat, in time for subway honchos to hold a news conference there to announce an experiment in making the trains run on time.

title: Stylish Surroundings Are Shattered by Killings
description: OMAHA, Dec. 6  To many people who live around Omaha, the Von Maur department store is a special destination for shopping, a retailer and respite at once, offering serenity along with its upscale goods in the Westroads Mall, the largest and busiest in Nebraska.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts yesterday about the photographer Jim Krantz and his views on the use of some of his pictures made for Marlboro advertisements by the artist Richard Prince referred incorrectly to the copyrights for his pictures. While the copyrights for his Marlboro photographs are owned by Philip Morris, Mr. Krantz retains the copyrights to most of his work; his clients do not generally own the rights.

title: As Knicks Comfort Teammate, They Grow Closer
description: On an icy December morning in Coney Island, in an old brick church, the Knicks stood shoulder to shoulder across the pulpit, a fractured team no more.

title: Arapahoe Basin Ski Area
description: Updated: December 2008

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Sunday about improvements in Malawis agricultural production, using erroneous information from a study by researchers at Imperial College London and Michigan State University, misstated the size of recent corn harvests. (Because of an editing error, the article also included the wrong figures.) The increase in production was in millions of metric tons, not billions. (Estimates show that corn production rose to 2.7 million metric tons in 2006 and 3.4 million in 2007 from 1.2 million in 2005.)

title: Electoral Revision Misses June Ballot
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 6  A Republican-sponsored ballot measure that would have changed the way the state apportions its 55 electoral votes will not be eligible for the June primary ballot, its sponsors said on Thursday, in spite of promises a few weeks ago that the initiative would get enough money and signatures to do so.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions on Nov. 28 about a hearing on whether WWOR, a New Jersey-based TV station owned by Fox Television Stations, covers New Jersey sufficiently to merit renewal of its broadcast license referred incorrectly to a WWOR video camera that recorded the proceedings. Although there was a piece of masking tape on the camera, it was not in fact covering the letters NY. Fox says that the stations cameras are labeled My9 and do not have the letters NY on them. (Fox uses My9NY as a slogan and as partof its Web site address.) (Go to Article)

title: Corrections
description: A music review in Weekend last Friday about the contemporary-classical ensemble Tactus, at the Manhattan School of Music, misstated the date of composition of a piece that was performed, Alban Bergs Chamber Concerto for Violin, Piano and 13 Winds. It was completed in 1925, not 1935. (Go to Article)

title: Port Authority and Airlines Offer Ways to Ease Delays at New York Airports
description: Trying to head off threats by the federal government to reduce flights at the three New York-area airports, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, along with airline industry executives and local transportation officials, unveiled 100 recommendations yesterday that are intended to unlock congestion and accommodate more traffic.

title: Corzine Seeks End to Monitoring of N.J. Troopers
description: TRENTON, Dec. 7  Gov. Jon S. Corzine said Friday that he would ask the federal government to halt its oversight of the New Jersey State Police because of sufficient reforms made in the eight years since its troopers were found to be engaging in racial profiling at traffic stops.

title: Under Early Quebec Snow, a Jewel for Skiers
description: IT was the day after Thanksgiving but it was no time for leftovers. There was fresh powder to be had, untracked remains of a 15-inch snowfall. The evergreens were heavy with snow, making a dash through the glades a challenge of both reflexes and planning. Brush against the wrong tree limb and a cascade of snow cloaked jacket, hat, gloves and goggles.

title: Romney, Eye on Evangelicals, Defends His Faith
description: COLLEGE STATION, Tex., Dec. 6  Mitt Romney asked the nation on Thursday not to reject his presidential candidacy because of his religion, assuring evangelical Christians and other religious voters that his values matched theirs in a speech that used the word Mormon only once.

title: Employers Added 94,000 Jobs in November
description: The economy added 94,000 jobs last month, the Labor Department said today, a sign of resilience that may ease fears of a recession but open the door for more rate cuts from the Federal Reserve.

title: Senate Blocks Energy Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7  Brushing aside a veto threat from the White House, the House passed a package of energy measures on Thursday that includes a 40 percent increase in fuel economy standards for cars and light trucks sold in the United States. But the measure stalled today in the Senate, as expected.

title: Christmas in Times Square, With Buses in the Manger
description: What would Jesus say about Black Nativity, the Classical Theater of Harlems new variation on Langston Hughess malleable 20th-century retelling of the original Christmas story? With Christian and seasonal generosity, lets begin by pointing out the unmistakable spirit of joy at the heart of this production, which takes the 1961 work that Hughes called a gospel song play and transplants it to Times Square in 1973, a change that allows Mary and Joseph to wander through the neighborhood at its seediest, taking shelter in the Port Authority Bus Terminal instead of a manger.

title: Stiff Penalty Recommended
description: The Southeast Missouri State womens basketball team should lose all 79 of its victories during the four-year tenure of the former coach B. J. Smith, an N.C.A.A. committee has ruled. The Committee on Infractions also decided that Southeast should have its 2006 N.C.A.A. tournament appearance taken away, according to a letter released yesterday. The university is appealing the ruling and has asked for a full hearing.

title: 2 Players Suspended for Acquiring Steroids and HGH
description: Major League Baseball yesterday suspended two players linked to the acquisition of performance-enhancing drugs, perhaps creating a template for players who could be named by George J. Mitchell when he issues his report on the use of banned substances in baseball, likely by the end of next week.

title: All the Makings of a Carnival, Except the Fun
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6  As if there was any doubt that Congress was on the verge of devolving into a carnival atmosphere, Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the Democratic majority leader, on Thursday proposed doing cartwheels down the center aisle of the Senate chamber to draw attention to Republican efforts to block legislation.

title: Park City Mountain Resort
description: Updated: December 2008

title: Lies, Guilt, Stiff Upper Lips
description: Joe Wrights Atonement begins in the endlessly photogenic, thematically pregnant interwar period. The setting is a rambling old British country estate where trim dinner jackets and shimmering silk dresses are worn; cigarettes are smoked with sharp inhalations that create perfect concavities of cheekbone; and the air is thick with class tension and sexual anxiety. Heavy clouds are gathering on the geopolitical horizon, which lends a special poignancy to the domestic comings and goings. This charged, hardly unfamiliar atmosphere provides, in the first section of the film, some decent, suspenseful fun, a rush of incident and implication. Boxy cars rolling up the drive; whispers of scandal and family secrets; coitus interruptus in the library, all set to the implacable rhythm of typewriter keys.

title: Not Just a Summer Romance
description: SUE AND JOE CANALES new beach house in Ocean City, N.J., handsomely sided in gray shingles and just steps from the Boardwalk, rises four floors above sea level. The view, they say, is always changing. Sometimes, whitecaps churn. Sometimes, the ocean is a fuzzy pink blanket. Sometimes, lightning flashes above the sea and reflects on the water.

title: A Former Soprano Makes Her Singing Debut
description: IT is Wednesday afternoon, but things are doornail dead in Aida Turturros empty dressing room at the Ambassador Theater, where she is, at a robust 45, one shaky week into her Broadway musical debut as the prison matron Mama Morton in Chicago.

title: Crimes of the Nave, Superficial Heart
description: Nothing in Paul Schraders film The Walker can quite match its delicious opening scene of sniping repartee over canasta among three Washington grandes dames and their pet gay playmate. Lynn (Kristin Scott Thomas), Natalie (Lauren Bacall) and Abigail (Lily Tomlin) constitute what may be the screens most formidable threesome of jaded, dirt-dishing socialites since The Women.

title: Winning Over Portland With One of Its Own
description: When they knew each other in the San Francisco Bay Area, and later worked together at the N.B.A. office in New York, Mike Golub could not muster up the courage to ask Cheri White for a date. Last June, he did the next best thing. He recruited her to help the once-revered and recently reviled Trail Blazers win back the city of Portland.

title: Lack of Donated Copters Harms Darfur Effort, U.N. Leader Says
description: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 6  Secretary General Ban Ki-moon said Thursday that the refusal of countries to donate helicopters for the joint African Union-United Nations peacekeeping force in Darfur was endangering the scheduled start of operations three weeks from now.

title: Six to Enter Hall
description: Robert Byron, the first driver to win a Nascar points championship, is among a diverse group to be inducted into the International Motorsports Hall of Fame. The six-person class of 2008 also includes Art Arfons, Bill Jenkins, Frank Kurtis, Everett Owens and Ralph Seagraves.

title: Corrections
description: A theater review on Nov. 13 about The Runner Stumbles, at the Beckett Theater, misspelled the surname of the composer of the plays music. He is Joseph Trapanese, not Trapenese.

title: A Volleyball Vision 14 Years in the Making at St. Johns
description: The St. Johns womens volleyball team was losing more than a match in front of its home crowd last weekend. The Red Storm appeared to be squandering an opportunity to reach the Round of 16 in the 64-team N.C.A.A. tournament for the first time.

title: The Dreams and Horrors of the Ties That Bind
description: The supple team of enchanters who inhabit Au Revoir Parapluie, James Thirres loving performance piece about the circus that is the human family, never reaches the end of its rope. In this artful and affecting hybrid of dance, slapstick, music and acrobatics, which runs through Dec. 16 at the Harvey Theater of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, rope is an endlessly mutable medium, as fluid and surprising as life itself.

title: STS-122: An Eclectic, Multinational Crew
description: The all-male crew for the current shuttle mission to the International Space Station is remarkably international in its composition  and has remarkably little experience in space. The mission commander, Cmdr. Stephen N. Frick of the Navy, has flown just once before, in 2002. Col. Rex J. Walheim also has just one mission under his belt  the same Atlantis mission in 2002 as Commander Frick. The other three Americans on board are rookies.

title: A Career Circling Fame and the Drain
description: As much the chronicle of an era as of a band, The Holy Modal Rounders ... Bound to Lose casts an affectionate eye on the kind of hedonism no one is meant to survive.

title: Postcard Perfection in the Cascades
description: DOWNTOWN Sisters, Ore., with its 1880s-style buildings, resembles the Old West. But most of its horses are embroidered on shirts, and if the goods sold behind its swinging doors are any indication, stagecoach stops once sold French pastries.

title: Lund Triumphs Again
description: Zach Lund edged his fellow American Eric Bernotas to win the skeleton event on the first day of the Bobsleigh and Skeleton World Cup in Park City, Utah. Lund finished in 1 minute 38.41 seconds, beating Bernotas by .25 of a second. Lund has won the event in Park City two straight years. Michelle Kelly of Canada won the womens event in 1:40.43.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about an attack by Israel on Hamas as the militant group prepared to fire a mortar shell into Israel included incorrect statistics from the Israeli military in some editions about the number of rockets and mortar shells fired into Israel by Hamas so far this year. The monthly average before June, when Hamas took over the Gaza Strip, was 108, not 48. The monthly average after June was 248, not 240. The article also described incompletely the attacks for the year to date. The total of more than 2,000 is for attacks with rockets and mortars, not just with rockets.

title: Some Gains, but Stores Are Worried
description: Cold weather, deep discounts and a quirk in the calendar rescued retailers from what threatened to be a dreary November, but it might not be enough to save the holiday shopping season.

title: Some Needing Mortgage Aid Wont Get It
description: When Jirina Koy heard that President Bush was announcing a freeze yesterday on mortgage interest rates, the Stockton, Calif., homeowner felt a flicker of hope.

title: Some Airlines to  Offer In-Flight Internet Service
description: Passengers may soon hear a new in-flight announcement: You can now log on.

title: Amy Winehouse Draws 6 Grammy Nominations
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 6  Amy Winehouse, the British soul singer whose battles with addiction have turned her into a tabloid regular, drew six Grammy nominations, including nods for the four marquee categories, today as the contenders for the 50th annual awards ceremony were announced.

title: Mental Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: A Very Late Comeback
description: Part tribute, part musical mystery,  Tis Autumn: The Search for Jackie Paris shines an overdue spotlight on a great who got away.

title: Lottery Numbers
A River Town That Grant Once Called Home
description: THE route to Galena, Ill., can twist through steep hills and ravines strewn with the bones of lead-mining boomtowns on shoulderless roads that change names at a whim  when they have names at all.

title: Coke Promotes Itself in a New Virtual World
description: COCA-COLA lovers will have a new place to hang out starting today, and it is an island on the Internet that is shaped like a Coke bottle.

title: Bigger Cars, Flip-Up Seats, Poetry: How Riders Would Run a Subway
description: The bubble. Doing something to keep the bubble from ruining peoples days would be the first thing on Melanie Muccios to-do list if she were in charge of the No. 7 line.

title: Age of Splendor Expands
description: The galleries of 19th-century European painting and sculpture are the Metropolitan Museums most popular attraction. And after they were closed for renovation in August, some very sad scenes ensued. Tourists expecting Monets and Renoirs by the roomful left the museum distraught, hopes dashed. Met regulars who count on having certain things just so  Czannes Card Players right there, in that gallery, on that wall, forever  wandered about in a daze, their coordinates thrown off.

title: The Name Game
description: YOUVE found the right area for your vacation home. Youve finally found the right property and have gone through the purchase process. Your household is in agreement that the porch needs new screens and that the kitchen must be updated. One decision remains: Should you give your charming beach cottage, farmhouse or mountain chalet a name? Or, if it already has one, should you keep it?

title: Giants Find 3rd Receiver to Be an Elusive Catch
description: David Tyree has been a Giants receiver for five years. He caught his first pass of 2007 against the Chicago Bears on Sunday, during the final drive of the seasons 12th game. He caught his second pass four plays later, helping the Giants toward a game-winning touchdown.

title: Lawmakers Back Limits on Interrogation Tactics
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6  In a sharp rebuke to White House counterterrorism policy, a Congressional conference committee has voted to outlaw the harsh interrogation techniques used by the Central Intelligence Agency against suspected high-level terrorists.

title: Two More Schools to Close
description: The Department of Education said yesterday that it would close two elementary schools  Public School 156, the Benjamin Banneker School, in the Bronx, and Public School 304, Casimir Pulaski, in Brooklyn  after both received Fs on the school report cards released last month. The announcement brings to 10 the number of schools scheduled to close so far, with a handful of additional closing announcements expected by early next week. The schools will close at the end of the school year.

title: Grammy Nominations Include Six for Winehouse
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 6  Amy Winehouse, the British soul singer whose continued troubles with substance abuse have turned her into a tabloid regular, drew six Grammy nominations, including nods in the four premier categories, as the contenders for the 50th annual awards ceremony were announced here on Thursday.

title: Getting Help for Bullpen Moves to Yankees Front Burner
description: NASHVILLE, Dec. 6  The Yankees left the winter meetings Thursday with one new relief pitcher and a lot of public optimism about their pitching prospects. But young starters need to be supported by strong relievers, and the Yankees bullpen is a free-for-all before closer Mariano Rivera.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,877 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Chamberlain Says Prospect of Starting or Pitching Relief is Win-Win
description: Pitcher Joba Chamberlain is reaping the rewards of his sensational first season with the Yankees. He is doing nothing, or almost nothing.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings
description: CLASSICAL

title: When a Public Offering Goes Bad Down Under
description: The founder of the company took in more than half a billion dollars by selling most of his stock to the public. Three weeks later, the company fell apart.

title: Uganda: Ebola Outbreak Kills Medics
description: Health workers are among the dead in an Ebola outbreak, spreading panic among doctors and nurses needed to help treat victims of the highly contagious disease, officials said. Experts say that the Ebola strain in the outbreak is a new one and that the typical Ebola symptoms were not always present, slowing diagnosis. Doctors and nurses did not know at first what they were facing, so they failed to protect themselves, according to Jane Alisemera, the lawmaker who represents Bundibugyo District, the center of the outbreak. We are facing a crisis in health care here, she said. According to the Ministry of Healths latest figures, Bundibugyo has 93 suspected cases of Ebola virus, among them 22 deaths. Four health workers were among the dead. The outbreak began Aug. 20, but the disease was not confirmed as a new strain of Ebola until Nov. 29. Infection control doctors from the World Health Organization and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recently arrived to help local officials contain the outbreak.

title: Another New York Attorney General Starts a Wall Street Crusade
description: ITS beginning to feel a lot like Spitzer.

title: Elevation of a Murdoch Son Suggests Plan of Succession
description: In the clearest sign yet of a succession plan at the News Corporation, Rupert Murdochs younger son, James, will step down as chief executive of British Sky Broadcasting to take on a broader role within his fathers media empire, executives said last night.

title: No Penalty for Renault
description: Renault was not penalized despite being found guilty of having confidential information about its Formula One rival McLaren. In September, McLaren was fined $100 million for using confidential data from Ferrari. In the latest allegations in Formula Ones spy scandal, the World Motor Sport Council summoned Renault officials to face accusations that the team had unauthorized access to details on McLarens cars.

title: Medicare Oxygen Benefit
description: To the Editor:

title: Manhattan: Judge Awards Legal Fees
description: Ending a long fight over legal fees for administering a $1.25 billion settlement to Holocaust survivors, United States District Court Judge Frederic Block awarded $3,095,325 yesterday to a lawyer in the case, Burt Neuborne. He and other lawyers had worked pro bono in the 1990s litigating a suit against Swiss banks, accusing them of looting millions of dollars of Jewish assets. A judge placed Mr. Neuborne in charge of follow-up litigation. In 2005, Mr. Neuborne submitted the hours he worked in that phase for payment without setting a price. When two other lawyers in the case opposed any payment to him, Mr. Neuborne valued his services at $5.7 million but discounted the bill to $4.1 million. Later he withdrew the discount. A court magistrate recommended the final figure, Judge Block said.

title: Philippine Court Convicts 14 in Kidnapping Case
description: MANILA, Dec. 6  A Philippine court convicted 14 members of the Abu Sayyaf terrorist group today in the 2001 kidnapping of 20 people off an island resort, including three Americans, two of whom were eventually killed.

title: Shuttle Mission Is Delayed by Problems With Fuel Sensors
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Dec. 6  NASA officials delayed the launching of the space shuttle Atlantis at least until Saturday after canceling Thursdays attempt because of problems with a pair of fuel sensors.

title: Preppy Killer Companion Is Released From Jail to Get Drug Treatment
description: The companion of the convicted murderer Robert E. Chambers Jr. was released from jail to a drug treatment program yesterday, with a promise from prosecutors that if all went well, she would be spared additional jail time for her October arrest on drug charges.

title: White Plains: Kerik Lawyer on Offense
description: The defense lawyer for Bernard B. Kerik, the former New York City police commissioner, has accused federal prosecutors of trying to taint the jury pool in his case and said they irreparably harmed his ability to get a fair trial. The federal prosecutors, Perry A. Carbone and Elliott B. Jacobson, called the allegations by the lawyer, Kenneth M. Breen, entirely baseless and unfounded. The exchange came out in court papers filed by Mr. Breen on Wednesday. In the papers, he asked the judge in the case, Stephen C. Robinson of United States District Court, to order the prosecutors to give him more information so he could respond to the governments request that Judge Robinson consider disqualifying him from the case. The prosecutors asked the judge to consider the move because they said Mr. Breen could be called as a witness to testify about what the government contends was obstruction by Mr. Kerik in an earlier state case. Judge Robinson ruled yesterday that Mr. Breen was not entitled to the additional information, but he has not ruled on whether to disqualify him.

title: Heavenly Ski Resort
description: Updated: December 2008

title: Bless the Beasts and Children
description: A fantastic bestiary inhabits The Golden Compass, prowling and flapping and slithering and fluttering. The animals, most of which are called daemons and are manifestations of the human soul, hover at the side of their people and near the storys edge, where their coos and barks mix with the ambient clatter and clang. Every so often, an animal leaps forward, its fur raised in alarm, its feathers fanned in flight. And because these are no ordinary animals, they also offer words of comfort, advice, warning. In this otherworldly realm, humans have no dominion over these creatures, yet they are not merely equals, either. They are one.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a subheading in some editions on Monday about the retrial of David Lemus in connection with a 1990 homicide at the Palladium nightclub referred imprecisely to the prosecutions case. The theory that there were three gunmen is not in fact a new one. The transcript of Mr. Lemuss 1992 trial shows that the prosecution referred to a possible third gunman in closing arguments.

title: Former Chief Will Forfeit $418 Million
description: In one of the largest corporate pay give-backs ever, William W. McGuire, the former chief executive of UnitedHealth Group, has agreed to forfeit at least $418 million to settle claims related to back-dated stock options.

title: Help Buying Clothes for Her Children, After She Saved Herself
description: The scent of marijuana greeted visitors as they entered the hallway leading to Samonia Malloys apartment in a Brooklyn housing complex. That environment is not the most appropriate one for Ms. Malloy, 25, who recently graduated from a drug rehabilitation program, as she tries to stay drug-free and raise her children. But she is determined to persevere.

title: Package Bomb Kills 1 in Paris
description: PARIS, Dec. 6  An explosion from a bomb in a package delivered to a law office in the heart of Paris killed one person and seriously wounded another on Thursday, the police said.

title: Poll Finds Hispanics Returning to Earlier Preference for Democrats
description: Gains made by Republicans among Hispanic voters in the presidential elections of 2000 and 2004 have been erased over the past year, with Hispanics returning to earlier levels of strong preference for the Democratic Party, a survey released yesterday by the Pew Hispanic Center in Washington shows.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Tuesday about the death of Donald Marbury Sr., the father of Knicks guard Stephon Marbury, misstated his age. He was 68, not 69. (An article in some copies yesterday about Marburys thanking his fans for their support repeated the error.)

title: Pop and Rock Listings
description: POP

title: From Jail to Dreamland, With Its Sadist in Briefs
description: By turns clever, impassioned, incoherent and silly, Revolver, the fourth film by the writer and director Guy Ritchie, is a macho parable of a fallen man striving for grace.

title: Art in Review
description: PAUL MCCARTHYS

title: Murray Klein, Long the Public Face of Zabars, Dies at 84
description: Murray Klein, who helped transform Zabars from a typical Jewish delicatessen on the Upper West Side of Manhattan into a culinary and cultural landmark, died today in Manhattan. He was 84.

title: Detainees Loyalty to bin Laden Is at Issue in Hearing
description: GUANTNAMO BAY, Cuba, Dec. 6  For several years, a slight Yemeni detainee with a wispy beard, Salim Ahmed Hamdan, has been at the center of legal battles challenging the Bush administrations Guantnamo policies. He was a driver for Osama bin Laden in Afghanistan, and his lawyers have cast him as little more than a low-level employee, a simple man who was just trying to support his wife and daughters.

title: In Mortgage Plan, Lenders Set Terms
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6  At least one thing is clear about President Bushs plan to help people trapped by the mortgage meltdown: it is an industry-led plan, not a government bailout.

title: Movie Guide and Film Series
description: MOVIES

title: Lundqvist Lets His Guard and Team Down
description: The bounces looked unusual all game to Rangers goalie Henrik Lundqvist. Shots were careening off his pads, directly to Torontos goal scorers. On top of his game until last weekend, Lundqvist watched everything turn on its head last night and then watched the third period from the bench, a baseball cap shading his sullen expression.

title: Riverhead: Brothers Convicted
description: The third of three brothers was convicted yesterday of gang assault in the beating of a veteran city firefighter returning from a Sept. 11 memorial service last year. On Wednesday, Darrell and Darian Taylor, 26, who are twins, were found guilty of first-degree assault in the attack in Mastic Beach on Firefighter Richard Berkhout, a 13-year veteran. Yesterday, their half brother, Christopher Robinson, who was tried separately, was found guilty in Suffolk County Supreme Court. Firefighter Berkhout, 47, was walking with his wife in Mastic Beach on the evening of Sept. 11, 2006, and yelled to the men to slow their car. The men got out and beat him, prosecutors said.

title: Many Children Struggling After '05 Storms
description: At least 46,600 children along the Gulf Coast are still struggling with mental health problems and other serious aftereffects of 2005 hurricanes, according to a new study by the Mailman School of Public Health at Columbia University and the Childrens Health Fund.

title: International Law Matters
description: To the Editor:

title: Shubert Considers a Deal to Sell Theaters Air Rights
description: Now that Broadway shows have gone on again, theater owners in Midtown Manhattan have turned their attention back to another way of making money: selling the rights to the air above their roofs.

title: Forgotten Suitcases, Emotional Baggage
description: TO a child a forgotten trunk in an attic opens the door to a beguiling fantasy world where a castoff shawl can be transformed into a kings robe, a superheros cape or a genies flying carpet.

title: House Sets Higher Goal for Vehicle Fuel Efficiency
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6  Brushing aside a veto threat from the White House, the House passed a package of energy measures on Thursday that includes a 40 percent increase in fuel economy standards for cars and light trucks sold in the United States.

title: Queens: Man Arrested in Killing
description: A 23-year-old man suspected in the 2004 shooting death of an off-duty correction officer has been arrested in Ecuador, where he was in a hospital being treated for a gunshot wound, the authorities said yesterday. The man, George Saravanos, who the police said would be brought back to New York today to face charges, is suspected in the killing of the correction officer, Richard Ross, who was shot in a botched robbery attempt outside a hotel in Flushing at 2:30 a.m. on Dec. 4, 2004. Investigators began to suspect Mr. Saravanos was hiding in Ecuador after they learned in 2005 that his father, Andonas Saravanos, was wiring money there. George Saravanoss arrest by United States marshals in Ecuador was disclosed by the police in New York City.

title: Cellphones Challenge Poll Sampling
description: With more American households giving up their old-fashioned land lines and using cellphones for all calls, public opinion researchers are facing a challenge of how to make sure they are getting representative samples when conducting polls.

title: Vinokourov Is Sanctioned
description: Alexandre Vinokourov was barred from cycling for one year for doping. Vinokourov, from Kazakhstan, was barred by his countrys cycling federation, Vinokourovs former Astana team said in a statement on its Web site. Vinokourov and his Astana teammates were forced out of this years Tour de France when he tested positive for a banned blood transfusion.

title: Detained Pakistani Seeks to Revive Judiciary Cause
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan, Dec. 6  The leader of the lawyers movement here, worried that the cause of an independent judiciary is foundering as elections approach, has written to his colleagues from detention outlining a strategy to keep the flame alive.

title: Man Convicted in Club Death Is Acquitted at Second Trial
description: A man who spent nearly 14 years behind bars for killing a bouncer at the Palladium nightclub in Manhattan was acquitted yesterday by a jury at a second trial, in a case in which he claimed that he and another man had been wrongly convicted while the real killers went free.

title: Mets Prospects Maturing in the Dominican Republic
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Dec. 6  After being frisked by pistol-toting security guards, fans passing through the turnstiles at Estadio Quisqueya are greeted by vendors selling the essentials of any authentic baseball experience: empanadas, cold Presidente and breath mints.

title: The Mandate Muddle
description: Imagine this: Its the summer of 2009, and President Barack Obama is about to unveil his plan for universal health care. But his health policy experts have done the math, and theyve concluded that the plan really needs to include a requirement that everyone have health insurance  a so-called mandate.

title: Distorted, Distorting and All-Too Human
description: The newborn with the shuffling eyes and bulbous wet head lies on a table, cooing and cackling. Less a bundle of joy than an emblem of dread, the baby arrives in David Lynchs first feature, Eraserhead (1977), like the misshapen question mark it vaguely resembles. Could it really be the spawn of Henry Spencer (Jack Nance), the sad-sack factoryworker with the finger-in-the-socket shock of hair? The baby, nominally the result of Henrys liaison with Mary X (Charlotte Stewart), haunts this amazing, still mysterious work as a manifestation  and apparent consequence  of distorted, distorting all-too human desires.

title: Europe Holds Key Rate Steady, but Britain Opts for a Cut
description: FRANKFURT, Dec. 6  The European Central Bank, caught between fears of rising inflation and subsiding economic growth, walked a middle ground on Thursday, leaving interest rates unchanged.

title: Three Stars Embracing One Sun-Warped Vision
description: The problem with most all-star aggregations is a clash of competing egos or mismatched agendas. Not so with the trio appearing at the Blue Note this week. Composed of the guitarist Bill Frisell, the bassist Ron Carter and the drummer Paul Motian, this is an all-star group that inhabits an atmosphere of accord. Instead of sparks it emits a soft, warm glow.

title: California: Cardinal Wont File Attack Report
description: The Roman Catholic Archbishop of Los Angeles told the police that he was assaulted by a man who shouted angry statements about the scandal of sexual abuse by members of the clergy but does not plan to file a report. The archbishop, Cardinal Roger Mahony, first reported the attack to fellow priests at a gathering in October, but not the police. After new reports of the alleged attack came out this week, the police contacted him. A spokeswoman for the Los Angeles Police Department, Lt. Roger Mora, said Cardinal Mahoney told the police by telephone that he had been dressed in a sports shirt and slacks on an evening in July when a man walked toward him outside Our Lady of the Angels Cathedral downtown, asking in a threatening tone if he was the cardinal. Cardinal Mahony, 71, told the police that the man pushed him to the ground and kicked him before running away.

title: City Keeping Water Rate From Rising
description: Water customers in New York City got a break yesterday when Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Christine Quinn, the City Council speaker, announced an agreement that would allow the city to forgo a midyear water rate increase that could have been as high as 18 percent.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Turner Watercolor Fetches Millions

title: Seasonal Debate Rages Over Loveliest Branches
description: DALLAS, Ore.  A battle is being waged for the heart of the American Christmas tree customer, pitting the real evergreen against the once-lowly artificial tree.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Week in Review on Sunday about an increase in the Senates use of the filibuster referred incorrectly to the American Enterprise Institute, one of whose members commented on the filibuster. The institute is a conservative research group based in Washington; it is not a nonpartisan group. (The error was repeated on Wednesday in an article comparing the health care proposals of Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama.)

title: Putting Off the Pain of Grief by Starting on a Journey
description: For most of its 85 minutes Grace Is Gone, a small, tender film about contemporary parenthood in wartime, carries off a delicate balancing act. How do you portray the tragic effects of the Iraq war on the home front without sounding shrilly partisan or evasively neutral? How do you avoid jingoism, cynicism or mawkishness?

title: Deputy Mayor Leaving to Run Bloomberg L.P.
description: Daniel L. Doctoroff was to have been the Robert Moses of the Bloomberg era, a bold visionary who would guide a sweeping revitalization of New York and put to rest the notion that the age of building big had ended.

title: Somerville: Coach Guilty of Sex Assault
description: Jurors in Somerset County yesterday convicted the former coach of a high school girls basketball team of sexually assaulting a player but acquitted her of the most serious charge, aggravated sexual assault. Pamela Balogh, the former coach at Immaculata High School in Somerville, was found guilty on four counts: aggravated criminal sexual contact, sexual assault, child endangerment and criminal sexual contact. Ms. Balogh faces up to 10 years in prison when she is sentenced. A sentencing date was not set. According to prosecutors, Ms. Balogh had a relationship with a student that went on for more than nine months, beginning in 2004 when the girl was 15. Ms. Balogh resigned in 2005.

title: Passionate Punches
description: Not since his nice-guy turns in Thelma & Louise (1991) and Free Willy (1993) has Michael Madsen, ever the designated heavy, played someone as huggable as Sean Kelleher, the Irish ex-boxer and tragic hero of Strength and Honor.

title: Theater Listings
description: 500 CLOWN Think of Buster Keaton and Chaplin, not Bozo, said Adrian Danzig, the producing artistic director of 500 Clown, describing the performance style of his Chicago-based company. Clown is a totally dirty word  no one uses clown in their title, he said. It sets you up to defend that youre not doing childrens work.

title: Chip Reese, High-Stakes Card Champion, Is Dead at 56
description: Chip Reese, whose mix of intellect, poise and nerve propelled him to renowned eminence among the minuscule club of humans who convene to wager millions on poker games, died Tuesday at his home in Las Vegas. He was 56.

title: Does King Henrik Need a Break?
description: There are always a few games during the course of a season that need to get filed into the Please Disregard, Move on to Next Game folder. And make no mistake, the Rangers game last night against the Maple Leafs fits that description. Team wide, there were breakdowns or a lack of spark in virtually every area, and Toronto seemed to pounce on every opportunity.

title: Developing Dialogue
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Tanker Spills Oil Off South Korea
description: SEOUL  A Hong Kong-registered oil tanker leaked 10,810 tons, or 66,000 barrels, of crude oil off South Korea's stormy west coast on Friday, in what was estimated to be the nation's largest maritime oil spill, officials said.

title: Art Basel Miami
description: Serious art lovers can still find moments of transcendence at the contemporary art fair.

title: Sabres Shellacked in L.A.
description: Playing in front of a goaltender making his N.H.L. debut, the Los Angeles Kings, challenged for offense since their big line went dry, erupted for an octet of goals in an 8-2 win over Buffalo. Mike Cammalleri opened the scoring, with his second in two games. Cammalleri had had the early goal-scoring lead in the N.H.L., but hit a drought and was switched off a line with Dustin Brown and Anze Kopitar. Now he appears to be back, and the line is coming back to life. Brown had two goals in the beat-down of Buffalo.

title: Week 14 Fantasy Advice: Your Direct Pipeline
description: While I wish that all I did 24/7 was write about fantasy football, sadly, I have another real job (advertising creative director), one that, because they pay me actual American currency, often requires more attention than Id like to give it. Translation: Ive been living at work night and day this week and, therefore, am unable to give you good people a Week 14 Playoff start-bench edition.

title: Delta Financial to File for Bankruptcy
description: The subprime mortgage lender Delta Financial said Thursday that it planned to file soon for bankruptcy protection, after losses mounted and an agreement to obtain financing fell apart.

title: Art Murmur | Update from Art Basel Miami
description: For the second year in a row, the pool at The Raleigh is proving too inviting to resist. At Jeffrey Deitchs late-night party, there were so many skinny-dipping galleristas that the scene resembled a Spencer Tunick photo Turns out the ripped-from-the-Colosseum Roman soldiers clanking around town are not here for a sword-and-sandals convention but to hype a freshman fair, Roma Contemporary, making its debut in February It seems theres safety in numbers at this years fair. More and more dealers are sharing spaces, forging Survivor-like alliances to avoid being voted off next year, when the fought-after spots are reassessed by the new regime. Mary Boone and Rafael Jablonka from Cologne have the smartest set-up: a room each to do with as they will and a third make-nice space for Eric Fischl, the one artist the two galleries share Massive steroid-charged artwork is not limited to the main fair. It also gets a workout at Pulse, where there is a courtyard stocked with jacked-up sculptures by Jurgen Mayer, Chris Larson and the tattooist-cum-fine artist Duke Reilly. Reillys work is a replica of a revolutionary war submarine called the Turtle, which in truth looks more like an old whisky barrel. The larkish Reilly submerged his work in the Hudson River early this year and attacked the QM2, an offence which got him arrested (the $120,000 tag for the piece includes a video of his capture) Its not just the wholesale appropriation trend that is trying the patience of gallerists. As the circuit hits 23 fairs and counting, FedEx and other couriers cannot handle the volume of art thats zipping round the world. Galleries will soon have to find alternative methods, with many acknowledging that delivery delays have been worse than ever. Some shipments failed to arrive. For the first day, Berlins Galerie Michael Schultz had to make do with a minimalist set up of two canvases (the rest of the booth showed up last night); while a Danish gallery canceled completely when they received word that its shipment wouldnt make it in time. That was good news for on person at least: the booth-less Aussie art collective The Glue Society was promoted into the space to exhibit its waggish light boxes, which show satellite images of what appear to be ancient Biblical scenes. Divine intervention?
