description: Talk is swirling that New York City Opera may shut down for the 2008-9 season so its home, the New York State Theater, can undergo acoustical renovations and other fixes desired by Gerard Mortier, the incoming general manager. Further, Mr. Mortier is said to want to discard all the companys older productions, clearing the decks for new ones. In truth, Mr. Mortier has long said the State Theater will have to close for a few months and has promised all new productions, at least for his first season in charge, 2009-10.

title: Living in Tompkinsville, Staten Island
description: The Staten Island Railway station at Tompkinsville is one stop from the ferry.

title: Stop-Time
description: Paper Cuts is on hiatus  out raking leaves  until Monday, December 17.

title: Expert Help In A Disastrous Deal
description: A reader writes to complain that my column today did not give the underwriter of the Rams Home Loans offering the credit it deserved for bringing this deal to investors.

title: Picking a Successor for Doctoroff
description: Several names are being floated at City Hall as possible successors to Daniel L. Doctoroff, the deputy mayor for economic development, who is leaving the government at the end of the year to become president of Bloomberg L.P.

title: Video: Romney on the Trail
description: A day after his speech addressing concerns about his Mormon faith, Mitt Romney held a press conference in Des Moines. He received a variety of questions from the two dozen or so reporters in attendance. Some were about the speech but some of the most notable exchanges were over the immigration issue.

title: Your Tax Dollars at Work
description: Would you pay kickbacks to a supposed hedge fund manager whose fund bought shares through an E*Trade account?

title: Drawing From New Sources
description: Ways to save and generate energy from The New York Times Magazine's Year in Ideas.

title: Democrats More Likely to Get a Real, Live Caller
description: Youre inundated with calls from campaigns if you live in Iowa or New Hampshire right now. But if youre a Democrat, it might be harder for you to hang up without feeling guilty. A new survey by the Pew Research Center and The Associated Press found that while the vast majority of likely voters in those states have received automated voice messages, or robo-calls, registered Democrats are significantly more likely to have received a campaign pitch from a real, live person.

title: More on WDs Hard Drive That Wont Share Video
description: BoingBoing today posted about a networked hard drive from Western Digital that blocks access to music and video files. The blogosphere started a chorus of outrage. And I referred to it in a post about the dark side of Macrovisions acquisition of Gemstar TV Guide.

title: Francis Ford Coppola  Indie
description: Winning an Oscar is not the end all, be all of life, Francis Ford Coppola told the Baguette Wednesday night after the premiere of Youth Without Youth, his first new film in a decade. The end all and be all of life is to follow your dreams.

title: UrbanEye: A Week of Broadway
description: As Broadway stagehands returned to work, the Great White Way saw a marathon week of openings.  Melena Ryzik of The Times reports.

title: On Basketball: The Heels Have a Need for Speed
description: North Carolina is supremely talented. I found that out last season in Chapel Hill when the Tar Heels beat my tournament-bound Penn team by 38. They confirmed it again this season, coming into a sold-out Palestra earlier this week and beating Penn by 35.

title: Radars Taken Out by Arctic Warming
description: The continuing warming and summertime retreats of sea ice around the North Pole are making life difficult for seal-hunting polar bears, eroding Inuit coastal villages and now, evidently, eroding Arctic defenses (although not weakening them, the Pentagon insists).

title: Blogger Roundup: The C.I.A. Tape Affair
description: The New York Timess report on the C.I.A.s destruction of two videotapes showing interrogations has taken on a life of its own across the blogosphere, where writers raised new questions, recalled to old ones and cross-referenced each other to create a fascinating, complex stew of opinion and analysis.

title: Circle Squared
description: During the holiday season, an imaginary animal kingdom puts the Golden Rule to the test.

title: McCain on the Destroyed C.I.A. Tapes
description: NASHUA, N.H.  We have yet to hear the other Republican presidential candidates weigh in on the news that the C.I.A. destroyed two videotapes showing interrogations of terrorism suspects, but Senator John McCain made it clear that he was not happy about it.

title: From Alcatraz to Vegas on the Hudson
description: The pilot of Freedom, a ferry that served Alcatraz, blogs about his journey from San Francisco to New York, where the ferry will be used for transportation to Liberty Island starting in 2008. Circle Line lost the contract to Hornblower Cruises and Events. [Ferry Pilots Blog]

title: Notes on the News: Strategic Threats and Thrill Rides
description: Further developments came this week on two news stories that caught The Ledes attention over the summer:

title: Art Basel Miami | Artist Shorts, Take Three
description: In conjunction with Ts art-themed holiday issue and our ongoing coverage of Art Basel Miami Beach, The Moment has selected short films by artists who will be showing at A.B.M.B. Use the video player in the right-hand column to watch the films mentioned below as well as many others, including exclusive work by artists Dan Graham and Phyllis Baldino. While youre at it, tour the tripped-out home of Miami-based art collector Rosa de la Cruz.

title: Tomorrows Oscar Hopefuls, Today
description: The Black List, Frankin Leonards ranking of the top screenplays that have yet to make it into theatres across the land (and not the Hollywood 10 version), has become a Hollywood phenomenon. Its also become a pretty good indicator of Oscar buzz a few years down the line. David M. Halbfinger, the Baggers colleague on the West Coast, has the hot-off-the-press details of the 2007 version.

title: Restructuring Shop to Acquire CompUSA
description: CompUSA, the electronics retailer that has struggled amid pressure from rivals like Best Buy and Wal-Mart, said Friday afternoon that it will be acquired by Gordon Brothers Group, an investment and advisory firm specializing in restructuring. Financial terms were not disclosed.

title: Dropping of Roses Marks Pearl Harbor Anniversary
description: Joseph S. Hydrusko was a 22-year-old Navy seaman, working on board a hospital ship, the U.S.S. Solace, at Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, on Dec. 7, 1941. He was helping to paint the vessel when six planes flew overhead; he assumed they were American planes flying ahead of a carrier. Instead, the planes began to drop bombs. Hundreds of Japanese planes followed them. Mr. Hydrusko rowed over to save wounded and dying men from the U.S.S. Oklahoma, a battleship that was sunk that day.

title: Update: Talk Off | Cologne
description: Earlier this week, in The Moments Talk Off column, Bruce Pask, the magazines Mens Fashion Director, battled Alex Hawgood, a Features Associate, over the merits of mens fragrances. Readers voted by leaving comments. The results are in: Alex, who argued the negative position, has won the Talk Off with approximately 80 percent of the votes. Men who prefer leau naturale can breathe easy.

title: A Wing Suit Landing Quest
description: Wing suit flier Jeb Corliss is on a quest to land a wing suit without a parachute.

title: Adams on Trial?
description: Things are heating up in the Reading Room. In his very witty post, Gary Hart wonders what benefit Adams might have derived from experiencing the outer ring of fear and loathing known to conservatives as The Bureaucracy  not to mention two intense years in the closest thing to bloodless civilian warfare, a presidential campaign. Senator Hart certainly knows whereof he speaks. But Adams, who grew up assuming he would be president someday, never entered electoral politics.

title: US Trust TV Spot
description: A US Trust commercial centers on a vintage VW bus.

title: Total Cereal TV Spot
description: An ad for General Mills' Total cereal is filled with  psychedelic imagery.

title: Geico TV Spot
description: An ad for Geico salutes those who lived through the 1960s.

title: A Mutual Disinterest for Michigan and Harbaugh
description: As Michigans coaching search continues to spiral, dont expect the name Jim Harbaugh to come up. Harbaugh is a former Michigan quarterback and has had success both at San Diego and Stanford, where he beat both Southern California and California this season. He would certainly be a logical candidate for Michigan, as hes both a graduate and his father, Jack, coached there.

title: Facebook Members Sell Their Own Ads
description: More than 1,500 Facebook users have started placing advertisements on their own profile pages  despite the social networking sites rule against such ads.

title: Traffic Jam in the Sky
description: In case you havent noticed, flying has become more delay-prone than ever. So far, 2007 has been the most delay-plagued year since the government began keeping records, punctuated by a disastrous summer in which millions of people around the country were stranded. How we got to this point, and what can be done about it, arent always understood.

title: Bloggingheads: Writers' Strike
description:
Mickey Kaus of Slate's Kausfiles, left, and Rob Long, a (conservative) comedy writer, debate the goals and tactics of the screenwriters' labor action.
Go to Bloggingheads.tv

title: The Week That Was
description: Lets talk about the week that was; bookended by its beginnings with the Clinton campaign cheekily trying to trace Barack Obamas presidential ambitions back to kindergarten  (just joking!!) and by its end, anticipation of the upcoming Oprah-fest abutting a dueling late-entry by Bill Clinton. (At least in South Carolina.)

title: Oy, Obama
description: Ill just outsource this to Ezra Klein.

title: Citi Is Close to Picking New C.E.O.
description: Citigroup is scheduled to hold its year-end board meetings early next week, where its directors could decide on a new chief executive, according to people briefed on the search process.

title: The Oprah-Obama Tour
description: The highly anticipated combination of Oprah and Obama descends upon Des Moines Saturday, and there are still tickets available for the rally. And they are free.

title: Vows: Amy and Brian
description: Amy Pamela Weil and Brian Raphael met on a blustery night in Central Park.

title: Holtz Gets No Help From Dad
description: The name of East Carolina Coach Skip Holtz has come up in connection with the Arkansas job recently. But dont expect his famous father, the former Notre Dame coach and current ESPN announcer Lou Holtz, to call in any favors. At least without prompting.

title: Clinton Deploys Mom
description: DES MOINES  Tonight, Dorothy Rodham made her debut on the 2008 presidential campaign trail.

title: Teenagers and Cars
description: Many states are trying to find ways to fight high fatality rates in car accidents that involve teenage drivers. What are your thoughts about teenage driving, driving laws and safety programs? Read the Article

title: Respond to Todays Column: Everythings Perfect, Except
description: We invite you to leave your responses to the Saturday, Dec. 8 column.

title: Joyful Noise and Charity to Celebrate the Season
description: HOBOKEN, N.J., Dec. 5  When Yo La Tengo plays covers of 60s and 70s rock songs, the members of the band almost take the meanness and grubbiness out of record fetishism: The way they feel about old or obscure or outer-edges rock n roll comes through with affection, generosity, positive energy, even safety. They are not testing you.

title: China Directs Banks to Raise Reserves
description: SHANGHAI, Dec. 8  China said today that for the 10th time this year, it would order banks to raise the amount of cash they set aside, in order to curb inflation and prevent the economy from overheating.

title: A Solemn Milestone
description: Manchester United will mark the 50th anniversary of the plane crash that wiped out its famed team with a Premier League match against Manchester City. United has been given special permission by the league and its sponsors to wear the teams old-style plain red jerseys and baggy shorts for the Feb. 10 home matchEight players were among 23 people killed on Feb. 6, 1958, when a plane carrying United home from a match at Red Star Belgrade crashed in Munich after refueling.

title: Looking Back to Eddie Bauer to Rescue Eddie Bauer
description: BEFORE McNeil S. Fiske Jr.  or Neil Fiske, as he prefers  was named to the top spot of the struggling retailer Eddie Bauer in June, he was better known as an author. His book Trading Up told the story of how Americas secretaries were rushing out to buy Godiva chocolates, seeking in other words, to own a piece of the luxury market at a (relatively) cheap price.

title: Record-Holder Has Modest Expectations With Jets
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Dec. 7  The Jets signed David Ball to their practice squad last week and the Jerry Rice jokes followed, as if in Balls slipstream. Ball tries to be a good sport when he is teased about his historical connection to Rice. It is an icebreaker.

title: Give Officials Access, Landowners on Border Are Told
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7  Federal officials are warning landowners along the southern border that they have to give the government access to their property as it considers where to build a fence intended to block illegal immigration.

title: Everythings Perfect, Except ...
description: The peak of my sympathy for Mitt Romney came when he was being battered on one side by Christian fundamentalists who think his faith is a cult and on the other by fellow Mormons, who were irate when he fudged the fact that they believe Jesus will return to earth and build a new Jerusalem in Jackson County, Mo.

title: Macrovision Agrees to Buy Gemstar-TV Guide for $2.8 Billion in Stock and Cash
description: Macrovision, in an effort to position itself at the forefront of the digital platform business, has agreed to buy the television listings provider Gemstar-TV Guide International for $2.8 billion in cash and stock.

title: Authoritarians in the Andes
description: Venezuelan voters stunning rejection of President Hugo Chvezs power grab provided a welcome reminder that there is a limit to what citizens will hand over, even to a popular leader with gargantuan oil wealth to spread around. Unfortunately, Mr. Chvezs authoritarianism is spreading in the Andes, where his allies, Presidents Evo Morales of Bolivia and Rafael Correa of Ecuador are also trying to pass constitutional amendments that would greatly consolidate their power.

title: Democracy Is Alive and Well in Venezuela
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about the C.I.A.s destruction of two videotapes documenting the interrogations of agents of Al Qaeda rendered incorrectly a quotation from Gen. Michael V. Hayden, the director of intelligence, in which he explained to C.I.A. employees why he was informing them of the destruction. General Hayden said, The press has learned that back in 2002, during the initial stage of our terrorist detention program, C.I.A. videotaped interrogations, and destroyed the tapes in 2005. He did not say he was informing them because the press has learned about the episode. (Go to Article)

title: A Challenge for Churches: Adulthood Takes Its Time
description: At some point during the 20th century, the United States invented adolescence. Where once there had merely been youth, there were now teenagers, with their own dress, music, magazines, books, economy, culture and expected patterns of behavior. It was enough to get organized religion, in the words of the bard, all shook up.

title: Trump Irate Over Rules for Restaurant on Ocean
description: WANTAGH, N.Y., Dec. 6  Donald J. Trump exercises his usual restraint in describing Trump on the Ocean, the 100,000-square-foot restaurant and catering hall he is building at Jones Beach State Park. It exists at the best corner of Jones Beach, or, for the more citified, at the 57th and Fifth of Jones Beach.

title: Season Ends for St. Johns
description: The St. Johns womens team dropped a five-game match against Southern California yesterday and was eliminated from the N.C.A.A. tournament in the Round of 16 in Gainesville, Fla.The defeat ended the best season in the 14-year history of the program. After losing the first two games, the 12th-seeded Red Storm (33-4) battled back behind the senior Hui Ping Huang, who had a match- and career-high 29 kills. Asia Kaczor led fifth-seeded U.S.C. (28-4) with 25 kills. U.S.C will next face Texas, which beat Florida in four games.

title: Looking Back to Eddie Bauer to Rescue Eddie Bauer
description: BEFORE McNeil S. Fiske Jr.  or Neil Fiske, as he prefers  was named to the top spot of the struggling retailer Eddie Bauer in June, he was better known as an author. His book Trading Up told the story of how Americas secretaries were rushing out to buy Godiva chocolates, seeking in other words, to own a piece of the luxury market at a (relatively) cheap price.

title: Franchione Buyout Approved
description: The Texas A&M regents approved a contract buyout yesterday for the former coach Dennis Franchione that is worth up to $4.4 million over three years. A spokesman for the athletic department said Franchione, who resigned Nov. 23, would be paid up to $1.7 million for each of the next two years. He would receive another $1 million in the third and final year of the agreement. Before he resigned, Franchiones contract had five years remaining at $2 million a year.Franchione went 32-28 at A&M, far short of the expectations when he replaced R. C. Slocum in December 2002. Off the field, Franchione was reprimanded for selling inside information about the team to boosters.

title: U.N. Report Finds 31 Killed in Myanmar Crackdown
description: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 7  At least 31 people were killed in Myanmar during the military governments crackdown on protests this fall, and arrests of and nighttime raids on suspected demonstrators are continuing, a United Nations human rights expert who visited the country last month said on Friday.

title: A Message to Borrowers
description: To the Editor:

title: Union-Busting at the Hall of Fame
description: Vero Beach, Fla.

title: A Tie for the Shootout Lead
description: Woody Austin and Mark Calcavecchia shot an eight-under 64 in modified alternate-shot play for a share of the first-round lead with Fred Funk and Jeff Sluman in the Merrill Lynch Shootout in Naples, Fla. The tournament host Greg Norman and Bubba Watson were a stroke back, and the defending champions Jerry Kelly and Rod Pampling opened with a 66 on the Norman-designed Tiburon Golf Club course.

title: Success Without Ads
description: YONKERS  It makes no sense for publications to charge readers on the Web  at least, thats the conventional wisdom. But conventional wisdom does not carry much weight at Consumer Reports, that detailed guide to buying everything from prescription drugs to pickup trucks.

title: Alternate-Side Parking Regulations Suspended Saturday
description: Because of the Feast of the Immaculate Conception, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations in New York City will be suspended today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: 6 Arrested Over Plots to Pump Up Share Prices
description: What began with an undercover F.B.I. agents posing as a corrupt hedge fund manager led to the indictments of six people yesterday on charges of fraud in the shadowy world of penny stocks, federal prosecutors said.

title: Do Something Decent, and Satan Gets Mad
description: It may seem odd that the composer of contemporary classics like Time Cycle, Echoi and Baroque Variations lists a childrens opera as one of his favorites among his own scores. But Lukas Foss has always had a soft spot for Griffelkin, his tale of a child devil who spends his 10th birthday walking among mortals and ends up banished from hell for the twin crimes of shedding a tear of compassion and doing a good deed. Granted, the deed is major: Seeing two children grieving over their mothers death, he brings her back to life.

title: Former Strip Club Bouncer Convicted of 2 Murders
description: A bouncer who studied sword fighting and ninjitsu, adopted a Japanese surname and urged himself to become a monster in the most positive way was convicted yesterday of two 2005 murders but acquitted of a third.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The Advertising column in Business Day on Monday, about a campaign for Dr. Martens boots, referred incorrectly to one designers use of the footwear and to the fashion show at which they were featured. While the designer Yohji Yamamoto used actual Dr. Martens shoes, the designer Chlo featured boots that were inspired by Dr. Martens; both showed their designs at the ready-to-wear show in Paris in February this year, not during New York Fashion Week in September. The article also misstated the headquarters of Dr. Martenss advertising agency, Exposure Communications. It is based in New York, not London. (Its parent company, Exposure Promotions, is based in London, and the campaign was photographed there.)

title: Rating Your Doctor, Fairly
description: The drive to give consumers more information about the quality of their doctors has gotten an important shove forward by New Yorks attorney general, Andrew Cuomo. That could be good for patients in dozens of states across the country that are served by some of the major health insurance companies.

title: Resisting Michigan, Schiano Is Staying Put
description: Rutgers Coach Greg Schiano has rejected overtures to become the next coach at Michigan, providing another public blow to that universitys search for a successor to Lloyd Carr.

title: Father in Brooklyn Is Held in Beating Death of Girl, 3
description: A 33-year-old Brooklyn man was charged yesterday with killing his 3-year-old daughter, who died Wednesday night after being beaten and severely burned, officials said.

title: Corrections
description: A Spare Times listing in Weekend yesterday about a winter festival at Riverside Church today misstated the churchs address. It is 490 Riverside Drive, not 91. (The entrance for todays event is at 91 Claremont Avenue, between 120th and 122nd Streets.)

title: Tanker Spills Oil Off South Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 7  A Hong Kong-registered oil tanker leaked 10,810 tons, or 66,000 barrels, of crude oil off South Koreas stormy west coast today, officials said, in what was estimated to be the nations largest maritime oil spill.

title: The Roles Blur for the Mayor and the Mogul
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has frequently turned to Deputy Mayor Daniel L. Doctoroff to handle city matters that the mayor should avoid, given his extensive business interests.

title: Australias Oscars
description: A film about migrants in Australia has won that countrys top movie award, while Eric Bana and Joan Chen, above, won the top acting honors, Reuters reported. The Australian Film Institute Awards named Romulus, My Father as best film, and its star, Mr. Bana, as best lead actor. The film tells the story of a post-World War II migrant family in Australia. Ms. Chen won for her role in The Home Song Stories, in which she plays a former Shanghai singer struggling to survive in 1970s Australia with two young children.

title: Talks on Kosovo Hit a Dead End, Rice Says
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 7  Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice affirmed Friday that international negotiations over the future of Kosovo had reached a dead end, even as its probable new prime minister said that Kosovo would not seek independence from Serbia until early next year.

title: Ships Pilot Is Charged in Oil Spill
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 7  A California maritime agency has filed misconduct charges against the American captain at the helm of a Chinese container ship that hit the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge on Nov. 7, spilling 58,000 gallons of fuel and fouling 40 miles of shore.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in Weekend yesterday about the Grammy nominations omitted part of the title of an album, by the Foo Fighters, that was nominated for the album of the year award. It is Echoes, Silence, Patience & Grace, not Echoes, Patience & Grace.

title: Germany: Move to Ban Scientology
description: The interior ministers of the nations 16 states as well as the federal interior minister, Wolfgang Schuble, consider Scientology to be an organization that is not compatible with the Constitution and will work to ban the organization, Berlins interior minister, Erhart Krting, told reporters after a meeting. They gave no specific examples, but the most recent annual report on extremism compiled by their agencies criticized the organization for disregarding basic and human rights, such as the right to develop ones personality and the right to be treated equally. Officials estimate there are 6,000 members of the Los Angeles-based Church of Scientology in the country.

title: More Schools Being Closed for Low Score
description: City education officials said yesterday that they planned to close three additional schools: Franklin K. Lane High School in Brooklyn; the Bronx Coalition Community High School; and P.S. 183, the Daniel Chappie James Elementary School in Brooklyn. They join 10 others that the Department of Education has decided to close after they received poor marks on the new A-through-F report cards.

title: Bigger Bear Sterns Stake
description: Joseph Lewis, a billionaire investor who bought 7 percent of the investment bank Bear Stearns three months ago, has increased his stake to 8 percent, according to a regulatory filing.

title: Your Team: Coming to More Cities Not Near You
description: Pittsburgh Penguins center Sidney Crosby, the N.H.L.s unofficial torch-bearer, is expected to reach a milestone of sorts tomorrow in Vancouver. Crosby will have needed 189 games, but he will have finally played in all 30 N.H.L. cities.

title: Pakistan: Gunmen Kill 3 in Bhutto Office
description: Gunmen attacked a party office of Benazir Bhutto, a major opposition leader, in southwestern Pakistan on Saturday, killing three of her supporters, the police said. The police were still trying to identify the assailants and their motive for the attack, in Naseerabad, about 150 miles east of Quetta. Violence has been common in past elections.

title: Diversity on Cable TV
description: To the Editor:

title: Offer for Northern Rock
description: The British investment group Olivant outlined details of its rescue offer for the mortgage lender Northern Rock as the American investment firm J. C. Flowers reportedly pulled out of the bidding process.

title: NASA Delays Shuttle Launching Again
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Dec. 7  NASA officials on Friday again postponed the launching of the space shuttle Atlantis as they continued to discuss how to deal with a fuel sensor problem.

title: The Obituary Bach Wrote for Himself
description: More than 250 years after Bachs Art of Fugue was posthumously printed, the work still poses questions that have only conditional answers. Was this unfinished collection of 20 increasingly complex fugues and canons meant to sum up a lifes work? Probably, given Bachs failing eyesight during the 1740s.

title: Tomorrows Oscar Hopefuls Today
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 7  Two years ago a young executive at Leonardo DiCaprios production company, hungry for some good scripts to read over the holidays, asked 100 peers to send him their 10 favorite new screenplays that would not make it into theaters before the New Year. He whipped up a spreadsheet ranking the responses, titled it The Black List," e-mailed it around and then watched it become a Hollywood phenomenon, the kind of underground document that writers with projects stuck in development pray will mention their script.

title: Attacks in Iraq Kill 25 People
description: BAGHDAD, Dec. 7  Twenty-five people were killed Friday in the tumultuous Iraqi province of Diyala, northeast of Baghdad, when a suicide attacker detonated a bomb near the headquarters of a local committee of former insurgents working with American forces and a car bomb exploded at a checkpoint in Baquba.

title: A Place for the Erotic, Slid Within the Sacred
description: Christian tradition holds that the Song of Solomon in the Old Testament is an allegorical representation of Gods relationship with Israel as that of man and wife. That interpretation, as well as later efforts to find correspondences between the life of Jesus and older Scripture, allowed a Latin translation of an early passage from Solomon, Nigra sum sed formosa (I am black but comely, spoken by a sun-darkened woman) to be adopted into Roman Catholic services celebrating the Virgin Mary.

title: Romney and the Religion Question
description: To the Editor:

title: In Photos and Notes, New Details on Shootings
description: OMAHA, Dec. 7  The authorities on Friday released photographs taken from a store surveillance video and notes written by a gunman as they continued to piece together what led the man to kill eight people and himself in a mall rampage this week.

title: Alinghi Proposes Changes to Americas Cup
description: With his plans for the next Americas Cup scuppered by a loss in court, Alinghis president, Ernesto Bertarelli, has expressed interest in making radical changes to the competition, the worlds oldest major sporting event.

title: Giants Blackburn May Get Chance to Solve the Eagles
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 7  Chase Blackburn of the Giants certainly had more pressing things to do, but he could not help himself. Football and math are his two passions.

title: The Body Image War, Battle of Britain Edition
description: If you followed the news closely this week, you know that the National Intelligence Estimate has determined that Irans nuclear threat is overblown, and you probably also know that Jennifer Love Hewitt is angry. When photographs of that actress during a beach holiday surfaced on the Internet recently, accompanied by ungenerous commentary about weight gain (We know what you ate last summer), Ms. Hewitt retaliated, writing on her blog that she was proud of her body and saddened that so many other women obviously didnt like theirs. A size 2, she declared, just isnt fat!

title: Peter Davi, Renowned Surfer, Is Dead at 45
description: Peter Davi, a renowned big-wave surfer from Monterey, died Tuesday while riding giant waves at a spot he had helped pioneer off Pebble Beach, Calif. He was 45.

title: New Jersey Suburbs Fear a Drop in Special Education Aid
description: New Jerseys support of special education in the public schools has been so generous that parents from all over the country have moved to the state to take advantage of the programs and services it offers.

title: Special Payout At UAL
description: The UAL Corporation, parent of United Airlines, said it would pay shareholders $250 million, or $2.15 a share, in a special distribution. The payout will be made on Jan. 23 to shareholders as of Jan. 9, UAL said.

title: On the Road Again, but to Where?
description: Many Americans harbor a mythical California of the mind: not the ephemeral Hollywood world of tabloid trash and tans, but an idea of open space and giant natural forms, of dust-wreathed taco stands and endless highways running along the Pacific.

title: France: Suspect in Paris Office Bombing
description: The police were holding a 45-year-old architect as a suspect in the package bomb explosion at a Paris law office on Thursday, a judicial police official said. The official said the suspect had had a past romantic relationship with the head of the law firm that was the target of the bombing. An office secretary was killed. The former law firm of President Nicolas Sarkozy is in the same building, but officials said there was no suggestion of a link.

title: Tuning In to a New Winter Sport: Extreme Decorating
description: The Vatican broadcasts a Christmas Mass for shut-ins; HGTV offers a tour of the nations most elaborately lighted and decorated houses.

title: Karlheinz Stockhausen, Influential Composer, Dies at 79
description: Karlheinz Stockhausen, an original and influential German composer who began his career as an inventor of new musical systems and ended it making operas to express his spiritual vision of the cosmos, died on Wednesday at his home in Kuerten-Kettenberg, Germany. He was 79.

title: Seymour Benzer, Geneticist, Is Dead at 86
description: Seymour Benzer, a geneticist who made scientific history by discovering that genes were structured like words and who went on to do pioneering work on the ties between genes and behavior, memory and longevity, died on Nov. 30 in Pasadena, Calif. He was 86.

title: Efforts to Harvest Oceans Energy Open New Debate Front
description: NEWPORT, Ore.  Chris Martinson and his fellow fishermen catch crab and shrimp in the same big swell that one day could generate an important part of the Northwests energy supply. Wave farms, harvested with high-tech buoys that are being tested here on the Oregon coast, would strain clean, renewable power from the surging sea.

title: Defying Critics, Italys Leader Endures
description: ROME

title: When Doris Lessing Meets Lady Mary Wortley Montagu
description: This past week, Ive been reading two books side by side, coincidentally at first and then more and more intently. They are the letters of Lady Mary Wortley Montagu, perhaps the most accomplished Englishwoman of the 18th century, and Shikasta, the first volume of Doris Lessings science fiction series called Canopus in Argos: Archives.

title: Strings, Hip-Hop and Not a Little Randiness
description: Diane Coburn Brunings Chamber Dance Project clearly wants to bring ballet into the contemporary world. No buns, no tights, no tutus, John Wright, a classically trained urban vocal artist (as his program biography states), said in his semi-rapped, slightly squirm-inducing introduction to the company on Thursday night at the Ailey Citigroup Theater.

title: Crossing a Continent by Water to Another City by the Bay
description: The tourist-laden ferries shuttling between Manhattan and the Statue of Liberty cover about three miles in the round trip. But one boat that may soon be plying that short circuit is traveling almost 8,000 miles to do so.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: A Nobelists Acceptance Speech

title: Ventures In China
description: Credit Suisse has signed a memorandum of understanding to establish a strategic relationship with Founder Securities of China. The venture, which is subject to regulatory approval, expects to underwrite domestic initial public offerings of shares by local Chinese firms and to offer corporate advisory and research services. Morgan Stanley also has reportedly signed an agreement to set up an investment banking venture with China Fortune Securities of Shanghai. (REUTERS)

title: NATO Seeks to Retake Taliban Haven
description: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan, Dec. 7  Residents fled their homes in southern Afghanistan on Friday as NATO forces mounted an offensive to retake the town of Musa Qala, which has been a haven for Taliban fighters since British forces abandoned it in October last year.

title: In Denver, Former City Officials Death Prompts Promise of a Lawsuit
description: DENVER, Dec. 7  As its city attorney, Larry Manzanares was one of Denvers most prominent public officials, a rising star in Colorados legal community, when he resigned abruptly in February amid well-publicized accusations that he had stolen a state-owned laptop computer. The authorities later announced that pornographic files had been downloaded on and erased from the computer while it was in Mr. Manzanaress possession.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption on Tuesday with the continuation of a theater review of The Farnsworth Invention, at the Music Box Theater, misidentified the actor standing at the left. He is Spencer Moses  not Kyle Fabel, another actor in the play.

title: With a High-Powered Hand, Leap-Frogging to the Title
description: Over the final three days of the Fall North American Bridge Championships, which ended in San Francisco on Sunday, there was another major event apart from the Reisinger: the Keohane North American Swiss Teams. The winners were Larry Mori of Clearwater, Fla.; Kelley Hwang of New York; Rick Kaye of Bingham Farms, Mich.; Leonard (Bill) Melander Jr. of West Bloomfield, Mich.; and Kazuo Furuta and Hiroki Yokoi from Japan.

title: Two Museums Go to Court Over the Right to Picassos
description: In a legal strategy that is spreading in the art world, the Museum of Modern Art and the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation jointly asked a federal court yesterday to declare them the owners of two Picasso paintings that a claimant says were sold under duress in Nazi Germany.

title: Amgen Shares Fall on Safety Concerns
description: Shares of Amgen had their biggest decline in seven months on Nasdaq yesterday after the company reported it might revise the safety information on its biggest product, the anemia drug Aranesp.

title: Appalachian State Advances
description: Quarterback Armanti Edwards rushed for 313 yards and 4 touchdowns and threw for 182 yards and 3 more scores to help Appalachian State advance to the Football Championship Subdivision title game with a 55-35 victory over Richmond last night in Boone, N.C.Edwards dominated on the ground as the Mountaineers built a 21-point lead. After Richmond (12-3) rallied to tie the score, Edwards threw two passes for touchdowns in the final 10 minutes. His yards rushing were the most by a quarterback in the F.C.S.  formerly Division I-AA. Appalachian State (12-2) will play the winner of todays Delaware-Southern Illinois game next Friday in Chattanooga, Tenn.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption with an article in some editions on Tuesday about a charity project called the Penny Harvest Field, to be unveiled on Monday in Rockefeller Plaza, reversed the identities of the two leaders of the project. Teddy Gross, of the nonprofit education group Common Cents, was second from left, and James S. Polshek, an architect, was at the right.

title: A Switch Is Flipped, and Justice Listens In
description: On Christmas Day 2005, Erik Crespo was given a small red MP3 player as a gift. That night, he got on an elevator in the Highbridge section of the Bronx and shot a man in the face.

title: Analysts Cut Credit Firms
description: A Merrill Lynch analyst, Kenneth Bruce, cut American Express, Capital One Financial and Discover Financial Services to sell from neutral, predicting a deterioration in consumer spending.

title: Credit Card Settlement
description: Some 30 million people across the nation are receiving notices that they may be eligible for $25 or more from the settlement of a class-action suit over foreign currency conversions on credit and debit cards.

title: A Sneak Preview Online
description: The first 10 minutes of Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story, a new comedy co-produced by Judd Apatow, will be available online this weekend on four popular Web sites: MySpace.com, IGN.com, Rottentomatoes.com and walkhard-movie.com. The footage went up yesterday afternoon. The preview coincides with the Cox Across America Tour, a seven-city concert series featuring the films star, John C. Reilly, as Dewey Cox, a hard-living musician. The film opens Dec. 21.

title: Settlement for Torture of 4 Men by Police
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 7  The City of Chicago is preparing to pay nearly $20 million to four men who were once sent to death row after interrogations that they say amounted to torture by the Chicago police, the citys law department said on Friday.

title: Huckabee Immigration Plan Emphasizes Security
description: Mike Huckabee, the Republican presidential candidate, released a plan for tougher immigration enforcement and border security yesterday, pledging to complete a border fence between the United States and Mexico by July 2010 and ruling out a pathway to citizenship for illegal immigrants unless they returned first to their country of origin.

title: Free Speech on the Web
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Delicate Singing and a Cow Call, Too
description: In the decade since the Trio Mediaeval was formed in Oslo, it has built a reputation, in contemporary as well as ancient repertory, for impeccably refined vocalism.

title: Spies Like You and Me
description: Let the witch hunt begin. Are you now or have you ever been an illegal immigrant?

title: CBS Survives
description: CBS earned the most viewers in every hour of prime time on Thursday, but ABC ranked first among viewers 18 to 49. CBS kicked off with Survivor: China, which dominated the 8 p.m. hour with 14 million viewers, Nielsen estimated. At 9, CBSs CSI delivered the nights largest audience (18.3 million), but ABCs Greys Anatomy (17.6 million) stayed No. 1 among the 18-to-49 set. ABC also led at 10 in that age group with Barbara Walterss 10 Most Fascinating People of 2007 (11.7 million). CBSs Without a Trace finished first in total viewers at 10 (12.7 million), while NBCs ER drew 8.1 million. NBC ranked third and Fox fourth among viewers 18 to 49.

title: Golds Quirk: Its Volatile, but Holders Feel Secure
description: On Nov. 7, the market price of a troy ounce of gold bullion briefly touched $845.50, the top so far in golds current eight-year bull market and a 28-year high in New York trading. The news made headlines and became a hot topic on radio talk shows.

title: WHATS OFFLINE; Growing Big, Staying Fresh
description: THE law of large numbers is frustrating for big companies.

title: Slowing Job Growth Seen as Ominous Sign for Economy
description: The nation gained a modest 94,000 jobs in November, the Labor Department reported yesterday, pulling back considerably from the previous month in the clearest sign yet that the American economy was headed for a substantial slowdown.

title: Construction Worker Dies in the Bronx
description: A worker was killed yesterday at a construction site in the Bronx after he was pinned between two pieces of heavy equipment and then fell into an eight-foot-deep hole, the authorities said.

title: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
description: Previously recorded $2,689,769.55

title: Special Payout at UAL
description: The UAL Corporation, parent of United Airlines, said it would pay shareholders $250 million, or $2.15 a share, in a special distribution. The payout will be made on Jan. 23 to shareholders as of Jan. 9, UAL said.

title: Young Israelis Resist Challenges to Settlements
Facing Up to the Reality of Losing a Teenage Son
description: Wana Joseph sometimes looks toward the front door of her home in East New York, Brooklyn, as if waiting for her son Terrell Bradley to enter. She still expects to see his head peering into her room to check on her. And when she hears rap music, she cant help thinking of the dances he taught her.

title: With Heisman a Dream, Defenders Take Solace in the N.F.L.s Embrace
description: On Monday, Louisiana State defensive tackle Glenn Dorsey won the Bronko Nagurski Award for the nations top defensive player. On Wednesday, he was named the Southeastern Conferences defensive player of the year. Later that evening, he claimed the Lombardi Award as the top college lineman or linebacker, and on Thursday he was awarded the Outland Trophy as the countrys top interior lineman.

title: Holiday TV Is Devoted to Lightness (and Yes, Lots of Lights)
description: Two American inventions, the holiday marketing season and the made-for-television movie, collide every December, scattering tears and tinsel across the weekends leading up to Christmas. Theres a five-film pile-up tonight and tomorrow night, which means that with judicious use of a DVR, you could spend 10 hours (minus commercials, about seven and a half) having your heart tugged and your tear ducts massaged. No sane person would do that, of course, which is where I come in.

title: Americans Held in Iraq Draw Justices Attention
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7  Expanding its inquiry into the role of the courts at a time of armed conflict, the Supreme Court accepted two cases on Friday that test whether federal judges have the authority to prevent military officials in Iraq from turning United States citizens over to the Iraqis for criminal prosecution or punishment.

title: Bonds Pleads Not Guilty to Federal Charges
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 7  Barry Bonds, baseballs home run king and the most prominent target of a five-year federal investigation into performance-enhancing drugs in sports, stood in a hushed federal courtroom Friday morning with his hands clasped behind his back and pleaded not guilty to five felony charges of perjury and obstruction of justice.

title: Kazakh Leader Suggests Way to End Oil Standoff
description: ALMATY, Kazakhstan, Dec. 7  Kazakhstan wants to raise its stake or receive compensation for cost overruns and delays in the gigantic Kashagan offshore field, the largest oil find in more than three decades, the countrys president said on Friday.

title: Britain to Take Back 3 From Guantnamo
description: LONDON, Dec. 7  Three former British residents detained at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, whose release had long been negotiated by the governments of Britain and the United States, are about to be freed, their lawyers said Friday.

title: In Russia, Ford Hurt by Strike and Rising Pay
description: VSEVOLOZHSK, Russia, Dec. 7  A strike at the Ford Motor Company assembly line has slowed production and cost the company, the pioneer of foreign car manufacturing in Russia, millions of dollars in lost production. Workers walked off the job on Nov. 22 at the Ford plant in this outlying district of St. Petersburg.

title: Warming and the Right
description: LAST June, Jim Manzi, a longtime software executive, laid out a case in The National Review for the need for conservatives to accept the reality of global warming (nationalreview.com). It is, he wrote, no longer possible, scientifically or politically, to deny that human activities have very likely increased global temperatures; what remains in dispute is the precise magnitude of the human impact.

title: Canadian Retailer Bans Some Plastic Bottles
description: OTTAWA, Dec. 7  A line of water bottles that had become a symbol of environmental responsibility has been removed from the shelves of Canadas leading outdoor gear retailer over concerns about a chemical used in its manufacture.

title: Winners and Losers of the Week in Foreign Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7  For the Democratic presidential hopefuls on the campaign trail, this week has been like Christmas in, well, December, all gift-wrapped and delivered straight from Washington in the form of three foreign policy bombshells.

title: Plea In Inside-Trading Case
description: Juan Renteria, a former worker at a Wisconsin plant that printed BusinessWeek magazine, pleaded guilty for his role in an insider trading scheme that netted more than $6.7 million.

title: Stocks, Sure, but Trading Places Can Be Enriching, Too
description: I AM in my own little fantasy land right now.

title: From Troubled to Killer, Despite Many Efforts
description: OMAHA, Dec. 7  As the twig is bent, so grows the tree. A sign bearing these severe but hopeful words marks the entrance to Cooper Village, a residential treatment facility for teenagers along the rural northern edge of Omaha.

title: A Nobelists Acceptance Speech
description: In her acceptance speech for the 2007 Nobel Prize in Literature, Doris Lessing lamented a fragmenting culture in which it is common for young men and women who have had years of education to know nothing about the world, to have read nothing, knowing only some specialty or other, for instance computers. Ms. Lessing, 88, was unable to attend the awards ceremony in Stockholm yesterday because of ill health. Her British editor, Nicholas Pearson, read her speech. Ms. Lessing, who grew up in Africa, wrote of poverty-stricken schools in Zimbabwe where students yearn for books, while students at a privileged London school that she once visited read little. She criticized the Internet for having seduced a whole generation into its inanities and ended with an anecdote about a pregnant mother of two somewhere in southern Africa who must travel to procure scant water for her family and yet craves a copy of Anna Karenina. Ms. Lessing concluded: I think it is that girl and the women who were talking about books and an education when they had not eaten for three days, that may yet define us.

title: Buyer to Close CompUSA
description: CompUSA, the consumer-electronics retailer owned by the Mexican billionaire Carlos Slim, said it was acquired by the restructuring firm Gordon Brothers Group, which plans to close or sell its 103 stores.

title: Like Subprime Mortgages, Some Construction Loans Are Delinquent
description: BANKS across the United States, particularly the smaller ones, have become dependent on construction lending just as that area of the economy is weakening and the number of bad loans is growing.

title: Two Window Washers Fall 47 Floors
description: Two brothers who worked together as window washers plunged 47 stories yesterday morning with their scaffold from the roof of an Upper East Side apartment building. One was killed, cut in half by a wooden fence in an alley below, and the other was gravely injured but somehow survived.

title: Officials Defended; 4 Ravens Are Fined
description: The National Football League fined four Baltimore Ravens players yesterday for violating rules prohibiting verbal abuse of game officials during the Ravens loss to the Patriots on Monday night.

title: New Details on Opera Renovation
description: Interviews with Gerard Mortier, the incoming general manager of the New York City Opera, and Susan L. Baker, its chairwoman, have yielded new details in response to reports that the opera may shut down for the 2008-9 season so its home, the New York State Theater, can undergo acoustical and other renovations. Mr. Mortier has long said that the State Theater will have to close for a few months and has promised all new productions for at least for the 2009-10 season, his first in charge. In an interview, he said it was likely that the theater would go dark for the spring of 2009, with work done in time for rehearsals to begin in August. However, he and Ms. Baker said that no decision on a closing had been made, and that none would be until after a board meeting on Wednesday. In response to reports that he wanted to discard all the companys older productions, Mr. Mortier, reached by telephone in Luxembourg, said he would probably keep some of them, especially those of American works. He also mentioned Jonathan Millers Rigoletto, which he called a famous production, adding, I dont see why I should throw it away. Final planning for the 2008-9 season has been held up, he said, by uncertainty over the theaters fate.

title: Months After Protests, Myanmar Junta in Control
description: BANGKOK, Dec. 7  The streets are quiet in Myanmar. The destructive elements are in jail. The international outcry has faded. The juntas grip on power seems firm.

title: Norval Morrisseau, Native Canadian Artist, Is Dead
description: Norval Morrisseau, also known as Copper Thunderbird, one of Canadas most celebrated painters and an important influence in the development of North American indigenous art, died Tuesday in Toronto. He was thought to be 75, though his birth year has been listed as both 1931 and 1932.

title: Alois Kracher Jr., Austrian Winemaker and Advocate, Is Dead at 48
description: Alois Kracher Jr., a visionary winemaker whose luscious sweet wines and forceful personality were instrumental in restoring the Austrian wine industrys international reputation after a 1985 scandal, died Tuesday at his home in Illmitz, in the Burgenland region of Austria. He was 48.

title: C.I.A. Was Urged to Keep Interrogation Videotapes
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7  White House and Justice Department officials, along with senior members of Congress, advised the Central Intelligence Agency in 2003 against a plan to destroy hundreds of hours of videotapes showing the interrogations of two operatives of Al Qaeda, government officials said Friday.

title: Playing With Momentum in a Range of Physical Tests
description: Jennifer Nugent and Paul Matteson formed their professional partnership in 2005 with the creation of Nugent & Matteson Dance. Both are also former members of David Dorfman Dance, where their personalities emerged: Ms. Nugents as the tough, no-nonsense woman, and Mr. Mattesons as the probing, sensitive man. Pieced Apart, their new collection of four works being performed at Danspace Project, seems to be an attempt to move beyond the myths, real or imagined, but it doesnt entirely succeed.

title: Lottery Numbers
Opera in the Armory
description: Die Soldaten, an opera by the German composer Bernd Alois Zimmermann, was first performed in Germany in a former power plant. In July it will be presented in the Park Avenue Armory, in a joint production of the Lincoln Center Festival and the armory. This will be the North American premiere of a 2006 German production, featuring a 110-piece orchestra and a cast of 40 singers, actors and dancers. It will be staged in the armorys vaulted former drill hall for five performances from July 5 to July 12. Die Soldaten was staged twice in the United States before this production; it had its premiere at the Cologne Opera in 1965. Tickets will become available in mid-March.

title: Supreme Court to Review Courts Wartime Reach
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7  The Supreme Court, expanding its inquiry into the role of federal courts at a time of armed conflict, today accepted two cases testing whether federal judges have authority to prevent military officials in Iraq from turning United States citizens over to the Iraqis for criminal prosecution or punishment.

title: A Separate Union, of Athletes, for Athletes
description: The need for an association of professional athletes was never more apparent than in the aftermath of the murder of Washington Redskins safety Sean Taylor.

title: Trucks Power Chinas Economy, at a Suffocating Cost
description: GUANGZHOU, China  Every night, columns of hulking blue and red freight trucks invade Chinas major cities with a reverberating roar of engines and dark clouds of diesel exhaust so thick it dims headlights.

title: Liberia: Ex-President Arrested
description: Gyude Bryant, left, a businessman who led the transitional government that operated from the exile of Charles Taylor in 2003 to the inauguration of Ellen Johnson Sirleaf last year, was arrested for violating conditions of his bail while on trial on charges of embezzling $1.3 million from the government. The arrest was ordered after Mr. Bryant failed to show up in court twice this week. He was taken to Monrovias central prison.

title: Budget Makers Plan Tradeoff for War Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7  Congressional leaders are assembling a $500 billion package to try to resolve an impasse by providing President Bush with unfettered money for the Iraq war in exchange for new spending on popular domestic programs.

title: Writers Talks Collapse Amid Acrimony
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 7  Talks between Hollywoods striking writers and producers collapsed amid acrimony on Friday night, even as the sides braced for the likely appearance of a third party  the Directors Guild of America, whose own contract is up next June.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about the C.I.A.s destruction of two videotapes documenting the interrogations of agents of Al Qaeda rendered incorrectly a quotation from Gen. Michael V. Hayden, the director of intelligence, in which he explained to C.I.A. employees why he was informing them of the destruction. General Hayden said, The press has learned that back in 2002, during the initial stage of our terrorist detention program, C.I.A. videotaped interrogations, and destroyed the tapes in 2005. He did not say he was informing them because the press has learned about the episode.

title: Marbury Returns as Knicks Come Up Empty
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 7  The Knicks game against the Philadelphia 76ers on Friday night began like any other for Stephon Marbury. Moments before tip-off, he bumped chests with Nate Robinson and shook hands with Mardy Collins. The whole time, he was smiling.

title: Authorities Investigate a Watchdog of the Docks
description: The Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor, an agency created more than 50 years ago to root out corruption on the docks that was immortalized by Marlon Brando, is itself now at the center of a wide-ranging investigation.

title: Harsh Treatment for Youthful Offenders
description: The Justice Department has the authority to sue juvenile detention systems that allow detainees to be abused or that fail to provide safe conditions. The department, which has invoked this authority many times in the past, should take a hard look at Texass notoriously troubled juvenile justice system.

title: An Emerging Conductor in a Program of Re-emerging Works
description: During the Kurt Masur years, the New York Philharmonic was fairly criticized for not trying hard enough to bring young conductors to its podium. But under Lorin Maazel, the orchestra has done much better at showcasing todays emerging maestros.

title: Elite Lawyers Anchor the Defense
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 7  Barry Bonds has spent the last couple of weeks interviewing top defense lawyers in the Bay Area. By all accounts, he ended up with an all-star lineup.

title: At Fairs by the Beach, the Sands of Creativity
description: MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 7  Last week the art world descended on the New Museum of Contemporary Arts new building on the Lower East Side, where the art was fragmentary, improvisational and defiantly down-to-earth. This week the same crowd has massed here in Miami Beach for the sixth installment of Art Basel Miami Beach, a fair that celebrates everything the New Museum has made an effort to avoid.

title: Maybe a Way to Get Rich Off the Rich
description: WHEN times get tough, people with an abundance of disposable income are inclined to keep disposing of it while the rest of us are forced to keep our thinner wallets in our pockets.

title: Candle Power
description: MY family came to America from Egypt in 1963. We arrived during Hanukkah, and I remember being unable to take my eyes off the electric menorahs glowing in the windows of houses in Brooklyn, where we set out to hunt for our first apartment.

title: At the Shore, Although the Water Is Shallower
description: Imagine how much sleep future musicologists will lose over Philip Glass. Throughout his career he has changed his scores to suit the circumstances, trimming them for recordings, for example, because he believes that nonvisual performances benefit from (relative) concision. The notion of an immutable, sacrosanct urtext  the very thing musicologists sift historical evidence hoping to establish  is entirely alien to him.

title: Looking Back on the Year That Sums Up the 60s
description: A theory on documentaries that strip-mine the 1960s: The less fresh insight the program has to offer, the earlier the Buffalo Springfield song For What Its Worth will turn up on the soundtrack. Written by Stephen Stills, that astonishing song (Theres something happening here/What it is aint exactly clear) came to encapsulate 60s turmoil so perfectly that resorting to it is a subconscious admission by a documentarian: I have nothing to say that Stephen Stills didnt say better in 2 minutes 41 seconds.

title: Kidd Is Slow to Start in Return, as Are the Nets
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 7  Jason Kidd returned Friday night from, depending upon whom you believe, his bout with migraine headaches or his one-game protest, but he was of little help to the struggling Nets. With Kidd unable to get untracked until late in the fourth quarter, the Nets lost, 96-89, to the Houston Rockets.

title: Under Fire, State Dept. Watchdog Quits
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP)  Howard J. Krongard, the embattled State Department inspector general who has been accused of impeding a Justice Department investigation of Blackwater Worldwide and other inquiries, announced his resignation on Friday.

title: Congress Looks Into Obstruction as Calls for Justice Inquiry Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7  The Central Intelligence Agency faced the threat of obstruction-of-justice investigations on Friday from both the Justice Department and Congressional committees over the destruction of videotapes of interrogations of Qaeda operatives.

title: Monitoring of Police Should End, Corzine Says
description: TRENTON, Dec. 7  Gov. Jon S. Corzine said on Friday that he would ask the federal government to halt its oversight of the New Jersey State Police because of sufficient reforms made in the eight years since its troopers were found to be engaging in racial profiling at traffic stops.

title: Britain: Light From Once-Dead Kayaker
description: The police continued to question John Darwin, the man who suddenly reappeared more than five years after he was thought to have drowned after a kayaking accident. He originally said he could not remember anything but is now putting forward some sort of account, a police official said. He is being held on suspicion of fraud. His wife, Anne, who moved to Panama six weeks ago and originally claimed to be surprised that her husband was not dead, has now admitted to several British tabloids that she had known for some time that he was alive. She is said to be on her way back to England, where she is likely to face arrest. The couples two sons said they had no idea of what their parents were apparently up to. If the papers allegations of a confession from our mam are true, then we very much feel that we have been the victims of a large scam, they said in a statement.

title: Court Rules Against Same-Sex Divorce
description: BOSTON, Dec. 7  The Rhode Island Supreme Court ruled Friday that same-sex couples who marry in Massachusetts, the only state that allows same-sex marriage, may not divorce in Rhode Island.

title: The Week in Pictures for Dec. 8
description: Here is a slide show of 11 photographs that tell the story of the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the first night of Hanukkah, Venezuelans voting in absentia and a 61-year love affair sparked in a concentration camp during World War II.

title: Gates Says Iran Remains a Threat
description: MANAMA, Bahrain, Dec. 8  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said Saturday that Iran is a grave threat to regional security even without nuclear weapons, and called on Tehran to account for American intelligence that describes its support for terrorism and instability around the world.

title: Clinton and Her Mother
description: At an event in Des Moines, Dorothy Rodham, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's mother, made her debut on the 2008 presidential campaign trail.

title: The Early Word: Tense Times for Huckabee and Romney
description: When Kate Phillips wrote about the rapist who murdered a woman after he was released on parole during Mike Huckabees tenure as govenror in Arkansas, she said, We can guarantee you that this will not go away. It hasnt. Today, The Los Angeles Timess Richard A. Serrano examines today whether his deep Christian faith  what on the stump he says defines me  colored his view of Wayne DuMonds case.

title: 35 M.P.G., Until You Read the Fine Print

description: Actor/Director/Controversy Magnet Mel Gibson is reportedly focusing on Costa Rica for his future endeavors. According to the Associated Press, Gibson was inMel Gibson

title: Art Murmur: Day Three at Art Basel Miami
description: Nadja Swarovski doesnt bruise easily. She laughed when told that Light Sock, the new work for the Swarovski Crystal Palace created by Diller, Scofidio + Renfro, resembles a scrotumEven among the slew of artists celebrating appropriation, Eric Doeringer stands out like a ham at Hanukkah. Doeringer, who used to sell his irreverent knock-offs on the Chelsea sidewalks, was the breakout star at Geisaidespite the fact that his new enabler, Takashi Murakami, once sent him a cease-and-desist letterPharrell Williams popped in to the pop-up tattoo parlor at Design Miami and offered to create a design, joining the likes of Vito Acconci, Yves Bhar and Tord BoontjeWhat is the fate of two large-scale pieces by the hotter-than-Hades L.A. artist Dave Muller? Sources at Barbara Gladstone and Blum & Poe, in whose booths Muller spent days painting a stop sign and disco ball directly onto the walls, said the ideas have been sold, but once the fair is over, the actual works will most likely be destroyed. So much for ars longa.

description: Talks between Hollywoods striking writers and producers collapsed amid acrimony on Friday night, Michael Cieply reports in todays Times.

description: How are we going to get through the first Saturday without college football games? Well, luckily for us, the Heisman Trophy will be handed out tonight. No matter which of the four finalists wins, there is likely to be some moaning and groaning. The arguments for and against all of them have been made, so well start off with a little Heisman history lesson from the Kansas City Stars Joe Posnanski.

title: Hes Ba-aack

title: Bill Clintons South Carolina Pitch
description: CHARLESTON, S.C. _ While the presidential candidates are traipsing across Iowa today, South Carolina became the staging ground for a battle of their most prominent surrogates.

title: Hydrogen Car Is Here, but Wheres the Hydrogen Economy?
description: In the Greentech column of this weekends Autos section in The New York Times, Norman Mayersohn has a nice overview of Hondas new hydrogen-fueled FCX Clarity, a (very) limited-edition sedan powered by fuel cells that, Mayersohn writes, Honda will begin leasing to a handful of private customers next summer.

title: Long-Term Care a Focus for Clinton
description: WINTERSET, Iowa  In a frigid airplane hangar here, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton announced her plan for tax breaks for long-term health care, pledging a $3,000 tax credit for caregiving and a long-term care insurance tax credit.

title: Personnel File: Being Third Option Works for Crayton
description: There are few advantages to being a teams third option in its passing attack, but for Dallas Cowboys wide receiver PATRICK CRAYTON, that does not mean that he does not get his chances to dance in the end zone.

title: Week 14 In Preview: A Distant Chance of Finding a Weakness
description: The Patriots do so many things well that searching for a weakness can be as futile as guaranteeing a victory against them, which Steelers safety Anthony Smith did on Wednesday.

title: Winners and Losers of the Week in Foreign Policy
description: In her Web column today, Helene Cooper examines which presidential candidates benefit politically from three major developments in foreign policy over the past week and finds that Democrats come out on top. Go to column

description: What exactly do men do in their tricked-out electronic hideaways? You know, when theyre working.

title: Oprah in Des Moines
description: DES MOINES  Oh my goodness, Oprah Winfrey said. At last, Im here.

title: Martial Cuisinarts: Will Chuck Norris Blend?
description: In his new campaign ad with Chuck Norris, Mike Huckabee says that when the celebrity tough guy does a pushup, the earth goes down. But will Chuck Norris blend?

Weekend Explorer: Upper East Side
description: John Strausbaugh explores a neighborhood that was never as exclusive as some  of its residents had hoped.

title: The Islanders Special Coach
description: In a move that will be tough to top as the classiest of the season, Islanders Coach Ted Nolan invited Al Arbour back to try to reach 1,500 coaching victories. The Isles got Arbour his milestone. Roy MacGregor, the captivating columnist with The Globe and Mail, has a revealing and poignant profile of Nolan here. Nolans 10-year banishment from the N.H.L., is surely one of the leagues bigger embarrassments.

title: Its Official: Tebow Wins the Heisman
description: The waiting ended tonight when Florida quarterback Tim Tebow was announced as the winner of the Heisman Trophy. Tebow is the first sophomore to win the Heisman.

description: Des Moines, Iowa

title: Sundays Breakfast Menu, Dec. 9
description: After Mitt Romneys major speech about faith in America, the other G.O.P. contenders have a chance to get some airtime on this Sundays shows.

title: CBS Executive Roger M. King Dies at 63
description: Roger M. King, the CBS and King World Productions executive who helped bring stars including Oprah Winfrey, Alex Trebek and Dr. Phil McGraw to television, died Saturday of a stroke, a CBS spokesman said. He was 63, the Associated Press reports.

title: A Gordie Howe Hat Trick, Nashville Style
description: Jordin Tootoo, the 5-foot-9 battering ram for the Nashville Predators, recorded a Gordie Howe hat trick (goal, assist, fight) against Anaheim on Saturday. Tootoo scored the first goal of the game in the opening period, dropped the gloves with defenseman Joe DiPenta five minutes later and assisted on a Ryan Suter goal in the second period. The Predators beat the Ducks, 4-2.

title: Grabbing an Opportunity With Both Gloves
description: Tommy Gainey vividly remembers what his days were like 10 years ago, when he made $8.75 an hour on an assembly line wrapping insulation around water heaters.

title: Biodegradable Coffins
description: This July, when Jorgi Wu was laid to rest in central California, she became the first American to be buried in an Ecopod  a 100 percent biodegradable coffin made of recycled paper. The seedpod-shaped coffin is designed to be planted in the ground, dissolve and replenish the earth with its nutrient-rich contents. Who needs embalming, cement vaults or herbicide-based lawn care?

title: A Very Old Zen Master and His Art of Tough Love
description: JEMEZ SPRINGS, N.M.  What would Buddha do?

description: To the Editor:

title: Moral Uncertainty Never Looked So Good
description: At the start of Doubt, Father Flynn, the earnest central figure in John Patrick Shanleys play, begins a sermon by asking: What do you do when youre not sure?

title: In One Village, Making a Balanced Display for Two Celebrations
description: Briarcliff Manor

title: Getting a Handle on Taxes
description: The cover article in this section last Sunday explored the many ways Westchester is grappling with its tax burden, which has been steadily encroaching on peoples bank accounts like some unstoppable mold from outer space. Property taxes here rose 67 percent from 1995 to 2005, giving Westchester at least the bronze medal among all United States counties in the high-tax Olympics.

title: At Historic Synagogue, a Congregation at Last
description: Milford

title: Letters: Rock of Ages, Ages of Rock
description: Hanna Rosins article (Nov. 25) reveals much about the current state of young earth creation science.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE BEST INTENTIONS: Kofi Annan and the UN in the Era of American World Power, by James Traub. (Picador, $16.) In 2004, James Traub, a contributing writer for The New York Times Magazine, scored the kind of coup journalists dream of: he persuaded Kofi Annan, then the secretary general of the United Nations, to give him unparalleled access. Traub wound up talking to Annan 18 times, as well as to his closest aides. The result is an incisive, meticulously researched study of the problems of collective action at the post-cold-war U.N. Although this benevolent and somewhat cryptic sovereign, as Traub calls him, had the best intentions, he was no match for the power politics and scheming he encountered. Our reviewer, Josef Joffe, called the book the best guide to the United Nations in recent memory.

title: Next Violin, The
description: The music sounded glorious: like the rich, sweet notes of a lovely old violin or cello. Yet it came from five weirdly shaped wooden objects, which served as resonators for vibrations coming from an electric violin. It was the first performance, at the Serpentine Gallery in London this fall, of the prototype of an entirely new stringed instrument.

title: Left-Hand-Turn Elimination
description: It seems that sitting in the left lane, engine idling, waiting for oncoming traffic to clear so you can make a left-hand turn, is minutely wasteful  of time and peace of mind, for sure, but also of gas and therefore money. Not a ton of gas and money if were talking about just you and your Windstar, say, but immensely wasteful if were talking about more than 95,000 big square brown trucks delivering packages every day. And this realization  that when you operate a gigantic fleet of vehicles, tiny improvements in the efficiency of each one will translate to huge savings overall  is what led U.P.S. to limit further the number of left-hand turns its drivers make.

title: A War to End All Campaigns
description: Kansas City, Mo.

title: Correction: In Colombia, a War Zone Reclaims Its Past
description: An article on Nov. 11 about Tayrona National Park in Colombia misstated the extent to which kidnappings have been reduced since the Colombian president, lvaro Uribe, initiated his new security policy in late 2003. According to the Vice Presidency and Ministry of Defense of Colombia and the U.S. State Department, kidnappings have been reduced from about 2,000 in 2003 to 687 last year and 393 from January to September 2007. The number of kidnappings was not brought down from 3,000 in 2003 to 100 a year.

title: Correction: Review of Mafia
description: A review on Nov. 18 about Mafia: The Governments Secret File on Organized Crime, by the United States Treasury Department, Bureau of Narcotics, misstated the surname of a Hemingway character whom the book called to the mind of the reviewer. It is Ole Andreson, not Anderson.

title: A Mormons Ultimate Doorbell
description: IT is probably not to his advantage that Mitt Romneys clean-scrubbed, youthful presence so readily reminds voters of those earnest Mormon missionaries knocking on their doors.

title: Brothers Concerned About Scaffold, Relative Says
description: Two brothers who plunged 47 stories from a Manhattan building when their window-washing platform collapsed  killing one and gravely injuring the other  knew their scaffold had a mechanical problem before they ascended the tower, but were assured by a boss that it had been fixed, a family member said yesterday.

title: Letters: High-Def at High Noon
description: Martin Scorsese is right: If you havent seen The Searchers in VistaVision on a giant screen, then you havent seen it at all (The Medium, Nov. 11). Ten years ago, while visiting Jackson Hole, Wyoming, my husband and I, with two friends, got to see the film in the towns historic local theater. We knew this was a rare opportunity to step out of the West (as tourist resort) and see Fords film the way he intended. The brutal force of John Waynes performance, in bas-relief against Monument Valley, took my breath away.

title: Fatalities in Connecticut Brought Restrictions
description: ON the afternoon her teenage son hit a patch of black ice and lost control of his car while on his way home from school, Connie Jascowski rushed to the scene. A passenger in her 16-year-old sons car who was hurt had managed to ask a witness to call her.

title: Letters
description: Youve Got Humor

title: The Suburban Life: Stuck in a Penn
description: We are well into mating-walrus season on the Long Island Rail Road, when herds of riders in bulky winter coats shuffle and snuffle and sometimes snap at one another as they jockey for space on station platforms and in train aisles.

title: College Loans by States Face Fresh Scrutiny
description: DES MOINES  When Iowa set up a corporation to make student loans more available, it hoped to expand access to college. Now state officials are investigating whether the corporations aggressive practices to get business help explain why Iowas college graduates have the nations second-highest debt burden per student.

title: Hong Kong Shows Examine Fashion and Jewelry Design
description: The Hong Kong Heritage Museum is offering a lesson in local fashion and jewelry design this year. Through March 31, Fashion Attitude  Hong Kong Fashion Design will feature the works of nine Hong Kong fashion designers, including Barney Chang, Lu Lu Cheung, Peter Lau, and Ika, whose work is pictured below. Starting May 18 and running through Jan. 5, 2009, is Jewelry for Life  Meaning and Adornment. This exhibition will explore the history of jewelry, specifically Hong Kongs history in manufacturing jewelry for global export. Approximately six manufacturer brands and four designer brands will show representative works in the forms of photographs, sketches and film footage. Admission: 10 Hong Kong dollars, or about $1.25 at 7.9 Hong Kong dollars to $1. (www.heritagemuseum.gov.hk).

title: Self-Righting Object, The
description: The Gomboc is a roundish piece of clear synthetic material with gently peaked, organic curves. It looks like a piece of modern art. But if you tip it over, something unusual happens: it rights itself.

title: Up Front
description: In this issue we present our selection of the 10 Best Books of 2007, split evenly, once again, between fiction and nonfiction. We chose two novels in translation, The Savage Detectives and Out Stealing Horses, by justly admired foreign masters; two first novels, Man Gone Down  a paperback original  and Then We Came to the End, by gifted young Americans; and, in Tree of Smoke, a major work by a third American writing at the peak of his formidable powers.

title: Clubs Bloom in the Desert
description: SIX years ago, Dion Mavath, an Australian D.J., flew to Dubai to take up residency at an upstart local nightclub. Dubai, a fledgling metropolis, was still mostly known as an airport hub and a shipping port, and the local night-life scene, he quickly found, was nearly as sterile and undistinguished as the flat Middle Eastern desert landscape.

title: The New Needy, Outpacing Charity
description: Huntington Station

title: Artistically, Light Years Ahead
description: THE way people talk about the art bubble, as some fragile thing about to pop, you would think it was made of money. But though there is plenty of green around, as this weekends enormous Art Basel Miami Beach juggernaut clearly proves, the artisphere is forged of sterner stuff than junk bonds. It is so much about connections  aesthetic, intellectual and, above all, social  that the real art bubble is more like a rarefied world under glass, where you can look at, buy, talk about and live with art, all while breathing some exclusive art fumes.

title: John Strugnell, Scholar Undone by His Slur, Dies at 77
