description: When editors at the New Oxford American Dictionary recently announced that their word of the year was locavore, which means someone who eats locally grown food, they also became the very definition of publicity.

title: Rule on Shots Forces Some Students Off Maine Campuses
description: PORTLAND, Me., Dec. 7  Hundreds of students at the University of Southern Maine have been barred from its campuses here and in nearby Gorham over mumps vaccinations.

title: Ang Lees Lust, Caution Wins Prizes in Taiwan
description: Taiwans native son Ang Lee, below, and his spy thriller Lust, Caution won seven prizes, including best film and best director, when the 44th Golden Horse Film Awards, regarded as the Chinese-language Oscars, were bestowed in Taipei on Saturday, Agence France-Presse reported. Mr. Lee won the Academy Award for best director for Brokeback Mountain in 2006. ... LEnnemi Intime, the French director Florent Emilio Siris  account of the savagery of Frances war against National Liberation Front rebels in Algeria in the 1950s, won the Golden Pyramid for best film on Friday at the 31st Cairo International Film Festival, Agence France-Presse reported.

title: Herodotus Now: Omnivorous Curiosity and Double Vision
description: Egypt, Herodotus tells us in The Histories, is a land with more marvels and monuments that defy description than any other. Not only is the Nile unlike any other river in the world, overflowing its banks in summer not in the early spring, but Egypts inhabitants also have manners and customs that in most ways are completely opposite to those of other peoples. Women go to the marketplace to sell goods, while men stay home to weave cloth; men carry loads on their heads, while women bear them on their shoulders; and women urinate standing up, men sitting down.

title: What to Do About Indian Point?
description: To the Editor:

title: Abba Museum Planned
description: A museum dedicated to the Swedish disco group Abba is to open in Stockholm in June 2009, Agence France-Presse reported. The museum, a short walk from the city center in a waterfront heritage site that was once a customs hall, will fill three floors and more than 43,000 square feet. Initiators of the project said all four members of Abba  Bjorn Ulvaeus, Benny Andersson, Agnetha Faltskog and Anni-Frid Lyngstad  have given their backing to the museum and will provide clothing, instruments and music. Despite breaking up a quarter of a century ago, Abba still sells two million to three million albums a year.

title: Jets Thicken Plot Against Browns, but the Ending Is the Same Old Story
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 9  Steady rain pelted the pockets of fans midway through the fourth quarter. Trailing by 17-6, in a drenched and almost empty stadium, the Jets needed a defensive stop. They needed to score at least 12 points. And they needed to recover an onside kick.

title: Emeralds, Rubies and Diamonds Reveal Facets of a Companys Style
description: LONDON, Dec. 8  All leading stage performers seem to give off their own light; thats why theyre called stars. But ballet dancers, catching it, refract it prismatically, like jewels. Hence the name of Balanchines triple bill, Jewels, new 40 years ago and sometimes billed as the worlds first plotless, or abstract, full-length ballet. Balanchine was notably wary of the star system, which emphasized who was dancing more than what was being danced, but he was perpetually fascinated by the connections among dancers, music and light.

title: Flying Humans, Hoping to Land With No Chute
description: Jeb Corliss wants to fly  not the way the Wright brothers wanted to fly, but the way we do in our dreams. He wants to jump from a helicopter and land without using a parachute.

title: G.O.P. Voters Are Uninspired by Candidates
description: Three weeks before the Iowa caucuses, Republicans voters across the country appear uninspired by their field of presidential candidates, with a vast majority saying they have not made a final decision about who to support, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: Campaign of Note on Campus
description: College students may be the targets of more marketing efforts than any other group of consumers. Thats why one recent campaign aimed at them took a nontraditional approach with a pitch that at first glance seems to be personal, hand-written notes rather than advertising.

title: Philharmonic Agrees to Play in North Korea
description: Adding a cultural wrinkle to the diplomatic engagement between the United States and North Korea, the New York Philharmonic plans to visit Pyongyang, the North Korean capital, in February, taking the legacy of Beethoven, Bach and Bernstein to one of the worlds most isolated nations.

title: Yankees Find Bullpen Help, Landing Hawkins for a Year
description: The Yankees added a veteran to their young bullpen yesterday, agreeing to terms with the right-hander LaTroy Hawkins on a one-year contract worth about $3.75 million. Hawkins, who turns 35 this month, will take a physical this week to make the deal official.

title: Giant Moon Wins at Aqueduct
description: Giant Moon held off Spanky Fischbein by one and three-quarter lengths to win the $78,950 Damon Runyon Stakes for New York-bred 2-year-olds at Aqueduct.The colt, trained by Rich Schosberg, remained unbeaten in three starts by pulling clear in the deep stretch. His time was 1 minute 46.07 seconds for a mile and a sixteenth.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes todays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.

title: South Korea Cleans Up Big Oil Spill
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 9  Thousands of fishermen, soldiers and volunteers struggled on Sunday to clean up an oil spill that has caused an environmental disaster in South Korea. It has blackened once scenic beaches, coated birds and oysters in sludge and driven away tourists with its stomach-churning stench.

title: Unlikely Ally Against Congo Republic Graft
description: BRAZZAVILLE, the Congo Republic  The main teaching hospital here is in such disrepair that many patients have to pay freelance porters for piggyback rides up and down the stairs to get X-rays. It costs $2 a flight, each way.

title: A Starring Role for Drivers Who Drink
description: PHOENIX, Dec. 4  A conviction for driving under the influence of alcohol is something many people try to conceal, even from their families. But now the bleary-eyed, disheveled and generally miserable visages of convicted drunken drivers here, captured in their mug shots, are available to the entire world via a Web site.

title: No Longer the City of Bonfire in Flames
description: Twenty years ago, the acid-penned journalist Tom Wolfe unleashed his first novel, The Bonfire of the Vanities. Skewering everyone from self-absorbed Wall Street millionaires to hucksterish street politicians, the sprawling satire painted a picture of a New York declining inexorably into racial conflict, crime and greed.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Allison Price Arden, associate publisher at Advertising Age, New York, part of Crain Communications, was promoted to publisher, overseeing print, digital and event operations for Ad Age and a sibling Crain publication, Creativity. She succeeds Scott Donaton, who joined Time Inc., New York, part of Time Warner, as publisher at Entertainment Weekly magazine and its Web site, ew.com.

title: As Orthodox Population Grows, So Do Tensions
description: LAKEWOOD, N.J.  A fault line runs through Dr. Martin Luther King Drive in Lakewood, dividing the black families that have lived here for years, many in run-down apartment complexes at one end of the street, from their new neighbors, the Orthodox Jewish families who mostly occupy a row of two-story houses on the other side.

title: Masterpiece Theater, Now in 3 Flavors: Classic, Mystery, Contemporary
description: Gillian Anderson, best known to American audiences as Agent Dana Scully of the F.B.I., from the Fox television show The X-Files, will be one of the new hosts of Masterpiece Theater on PBS when it begins its new season on Jan. 13, the programs producers plan to announce today.

title: Rookie Safeties Help Stop McNabb
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9  Craig Dahl had last started a game when he played for North Dakota State. But in the Giants locker room after the 16-13 defeat of the Eagles, the rookie sounded as if he had played  ho-hum  just another game.

title: Patriots Send a Message by Spoiling a Guarantee
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass., Dec. 9  A few hours before the New England Patriots became only the fifth team in N.F.L. history to win its first 13 games, a plane trailing a banner flew over Gillette Stadium bearing a none-too-subtle message: Bonds  756*, Belichick  3 Super Bowl wins*.

title: Yahoo to Start Internet Program for Technology Investors
description: Yahoo, which already owns one of the most successful financial sites on the Web, is putting the final touches on a new online program for technology investors that is scheduled to begin next month.

title: The Eagles Are Undone by Mistakes at Key Moments
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9  The Giants were already scampering to a celebration near their bench late in the fourth quarter when Philadelphia receiver Jason Avant raised his arm to make a last-ditch appeal for an official  any official  to pull out his yellow flag and fling it.

title: Obama Pins Hopes on Oprah Factor in South Carolina
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.  If you check out Oprah Winfreys Web site today, there is no evidence that she was part of a gigantic political spectacle over the weekend as she barnstormed across Iowa, South Carolina and New Hampshire for Senator Barack Obama.

title: Roger M. King, 63, TV Syndicator, Dies
description: Roger M. King, a television syndication executive who helped make national stars of talents like Oprah Winfrey, Alex Trebek and Dr. Phil McGraw, died on Saturday. He was 63.

title: 72 Dolphins Unbeaten, Unbowed, but Sweating
description: I reached Marlin Briscoe yesterday morning just as he was preparing to tee off on a golf course in Cypress, Calif. Golf is part of a Sunday ritual that ends with Briscoe settling down to watch football. This season the ritual includes watching a New England Patriots team that poses the greatest threat yet to a legacy Briscoe holds near and dear.

title: The Bronx: 26 Injured in Fire
description: Twenty-six people were injured last night in a fire in an apartment building at 2334 Boston Road in the Bronxdale neighborhood, fire officials said. Most of the injuries were from smoke inhalation and were minor. But three people were seriously injured. One had a life-threatening heart attack, fire officials said. Of those affected, 14 were occupants, 11 were firefighters and one was an emergency medical technician. The cause of the fire was under investigation.

title: Satellite TV on the Move, at Fox News
description: As the beginning of primary season approaches, Fox News Channel is introducing a pair of satellite reporting units capable of broadcasting live video while on the move. The vehicles, two retrofitted sport utilities, had an early debut on Nov. 30 during a hostage incident at Hillary Rodham Clintons campaign office in Rochester, N.H., and are already raising interest and questions about their potential influence on live television news reporting.

title: Muckraking Pays, Just Not in Profit
description: Last Friday, the city of Chicago agreed to pay out $20 million to settle lawsuits filed by four former death-row inmates who said they had been tortured by police officers and subsequently wrongly convicted. The four men were among dozens of black men who said they were tortured, beaten with phone books and suffocated with plastic typewriter covers while in police custody in the 1970s and 1980s, according to special prosecutors.

title: Western States Agree to Water-Sharing Pact
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 9  Facing the worst drought in a century and the prospect that climate change could yield long-term changes on the Colorado River, the lifeline for several Western states, federal officials have reached a new pact with the states on how to allocate water if the river runs short.

title: A Rube Takes on the City and Falls for a Woman
description: Jaradoa Theater is off to a promising if not very pithy start with Serenade, a new musical that is the companys first full production. What the show lacks in plotting depth, which is a lot, it makes up for in sheer energy and a fearless mix of musical and choreographic styles.

title: Lottery Numbers
Compass Cant Cure What Ails Box Office
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 9  Hollywood is counting on the impending arrival of a naughty chipmunk, a treasure hunter and Will Smith to reverse a lingering box office malaise that deepened over the weekend with disappointing sales for The Golden Compass.

title: Canadian Is Convicted in 6 of a Suspected 50 Killings
description: OTTAWA, Dec. 9  After a 10-month trial marked by horrific and often grisly evidence, Robert William Pickton, a pig farmer, was convicted Sunday of second-degree murder in the deaths of six women.

title: Opposition to Take Part in Pakistan Elections
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Dec. 9  The two main opposition parties led by Benazir Bhutto and Nawaz Sharif said they would participate in Jan. 8 parliamentary elections, despite deep misgivings about whether the vote could be free and fair.

title: UBS Sells Stake After Write-Down
description: FRANKFURT, Dec. 10  UBS became the latest Western bank to seek a financial lifeline from the cash-rich East today, selling a stake of more than 10 percent to investors from Singapore and the Middle East as it wrote down $10 billion more in mortgage-related assets.

title: Massapequa: Womans Body Identified
description: The body of a woman found floating in the Narrasketuck River on Saturday morning has been identified, the Nassau County police said yesterday. The Nassau County medical examiner identified the woman as Yvonne Boykin, 46, of Lake Street, Massapequa, the police said. The body was discovered by a dog walker about 11 a.m., and the cause of death remained under investigation yesterday evening. Compiled by John Sullivan

title: Cops Wife Spiraling Out of Control in Chicago
description: A young man walks into a Chicago flower shop at the start of Person of Interest, a smart, propulsive, tightrope-walking mystery novel by Theresa Schwegel. His name is Niko Stavrakos. Hes confident and handsome. He says hes buying roses for his mother.

title: Delay, Obstruction and Darfur
description: The worlds leaders say they care desperately about Darfurs suffering, until they get distracted. It took years of international hand-wringing before the United Nations Security Council passed a resolution to send in 26,000 peacekeepers to replace a current force of 7,000, to try to halt the killing. With the deployment now set for Jan. 1, major countries are ignoring the U.N.s appeals for essential aircraft, and Sudans government  which unleashed the genocide  is again reneging on its promises to cooperate.

title: Junking Fat Foods in Schools
description: As Americas youth have grown fatter and the number with adult diabetes continues to rise, there is one obvious way to help. Public schools should stop selling students so much unhealthy food. A worthy but imperfect amendment pending in Congress would help curb junk foods sold in too many of the nations schools.

title: Paying for Free Web Information
description: NEWSPAPER publishers and other content producers have a complicated relationship with giant search engines like Google and Yahoo. They simultaneously try to curry favor with these sites, hiring people known as optimizers with magical incantations to make articles show up high on the results pages and drive traffic, all the while grumbling that maybe, perhaps, it isnt fair for the search engines to make copies of their material  so that it can be searched or appear on aggregation sites like Google News  without compensation.

title: Help Me Spy on Al Qaeda
description: Washington

title: Henry Paulsons Priorities
description: By Bush administration standards, Henry Paulson, the Treasury secretary, is a good guy. He isnt conspicuously incompetent; and he isnt trying to mislead us into war, justify torture or protect corrupt contractors.

title: A Growing Source of Fear for Migrants in Malaysia
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  When his turn comes to stand watch, Kang Long posts himself at a window, peering into the dark streets outside the tiny apartment where his fellow migrant workers sleep 10 to a room.

title: A Crime Buster, With His Eye on the Future
description: He was, to the popular eye, Eliot Ness reincarnated, an unsparing prosecutor for a crime-shadowed age. And when the United States attorney in Manhattan resigned in January 1989, he earned a tabloid salute:

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Wheelchair Van Drivers Strike at 4 Transportation Companies
description: Drivers went on strike today at four companies that provide van rides for up to 9,000 passengers a day across New York City.

title: Slot Machines for the Young and Active
description: The venerable slot machine is undergoing a generational shift. For more than a century, since its invention by a German immigrant named Charles Fey in the 1890s, slot machines have required little more than cash, faith and an ability to pull a lever or push a button.

title: TiVo Shifts to Help Companies It Once Threatened
description: TiVo may be getting a second chance by thinking outside the box that made it famous in the first place.

title: Gene H. Golub, an Innovator in Early Computing, Dies at 75
description: Gene H. Golub, a computer scientist who developed early techniques for using computers to solve scientific and engineering problems, died on Nov. 16 in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 75.

title: Stagehands Vote to Ratify New Contract
description: Members of the stagehands union voted yesterday to ratify the agreement reached on Nov. 28 between union officials and the League of American Theaters and Producers. That agreement brought an end to a strike by the stagehands that left most of Broadway dark for 19 days. With the ratification vote, the terms of the new agreement will go into effect today.

title: Arsenal Beaten for First Time
description: Arsenal lost its first game of the English Premier League season, falling at Middlesbrough, 2-1. Arsenal still has a one-point lead in the standings.Stewart Downing and Tuncay Sanli scored to give Middlesbrough its first win in any competition since Sept. 1. Tomas Rosicky scored in injury time for Arsenal.Arsenal leads the league with 37 points, followed by Manchester United with 36 and Chelsea with 34.

title: Chocolate in Beta Testing, Offered by a Wired Founder
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 9 -- In a vast refurbished warehouse on one of this citys historic pier, Louis Rossetto, the co-founder of Wired magazine, is at it again. Only this time, his project has nothing to do with media or high technology. It is hand-crafted chocolate.

title: Deloitte Agrees to Pay $1 Million Fine
description: Deloitte & Touche, one of the Big Four accounting firms, agreed today to pay $1 million to settle accusations that it botched an audit of a pharmaceutical company by entrusting it to a partner it knew to be a poor auditor.

title: Italian Villagers Sue Culture Ministers
description: The town of Monteleone di Spoleto, Italy, is suing three successive Italian culture ministers in its latest effort to recover a 2,600-year-old Etruscan chariot, above, from the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Italian news agency Ansa reported. The artifact is part of our towns perpetual and inalienable heritage, said the suit, filed in Monteleone courts against the incumbent minister, Francesco Rutelli, and his predecessors Rocco Buttiglione and Giuliano Urbani. The suit contends that the ministers did not do enough to secure the return of the chariot, which was discovered in Monteleone, in Umbria, in 1902 and sold to the Met the next year. Monteleone officials say it was illegally whisked out of the country. The Met says that because the chariot was bought more than a century ago, the statute of limitations has expired.

title: 6 Characters in Search of a Dimension, in Different Operatic Tempos
description: Though Elliott Carter is an indisputably towering figure in contemporary music, few would have pegged him as a composer with a knack for opera. He attended operas for decades, but selectively. He did not pay heed to La Bohme until he was nearly 70 and left the show unimpressed.

title: C.I.A. Official in Inquiry Called a Hero
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9  At a conference in El Paso in mid-August, Representative Silvestre Reyes of Texas, the Democratic chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, heaped praise on a man whose exploits, he joked, had been the inspiration for the television show 24.

title: Its Not Life on the Mississippi, Jean-Franois Honey
description: What might have been a wheeze turns out to be a giggle.

title: Caving In on Hate Crimes
description: Congressional leaders, who have disappointed frequently this year, have done it again. This time, the House leadership has failed to find a way to get a bipartisan law against hate crimes passed and signed into law. Racial, religious, sexual and other minorities have waited long enough. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi has to do more than just express her support for the bill; she must find a way to make it the law.

title: In a Cast
description: Victoria Clark, who won a Tony Award in 2005 for best actress in a musical for her performance in The Light in the Piazza, will star when Encores! presents the Marc Blitzstein and Joseph Stein musical Juno for five performances from March 27 to 30 at City Center. ... David Hyde Pierce, who won the 2007 Tony Award for best actor in a musical for his performance as the theater-loving detective in Curtains, has extended his engagement in the show at the Al Hirschfeld Theater for six months, through Aug. 31.

title: 2 Fatal Shootings at Colorado Religious Sites
description: A gunman and four people were killed and four others wounded yesterday in two apparently unprovoked shootings that unfolded about 12 hours and 70 miles apart at a missionary training center and a church in Colorado, law-enforcement authorities reported.

title: Screenwriters Dig In for an Extended Brawl
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 9  Eight months ago, in a contemplative moment, Patric M. Verrone, president of the Writers Guild of America West, sketched out what could have been a script for the collision that wrecked talks between Hollywoods producers and striking writers on Friday.

title: Looking Ahead
description: FED MEETING The chief news of the week will be the Federal Open Market Committee meeting on Tuesday. A quarter-point interest rate decrease is expected, but there are calls for a half point.

title: Monthly Fare for Transit to Rise 6.6% in Proposal
description: Subway and bus riders who use monthly unlimited-ride MetroCards would be hit the hardest under a revised proposal to increase transit fares, which is to be announced today by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: Richard Nolte, Diplomat Who Got Caught Up in Mideast War, Dies at 86
description: Richard Nolte, a Middle East expert whose three-week tenure as American ambassador to Egypt in 1967 ended when the country expelled him during the 1967 Middle East War, even though he had sympathized with the Arab cause, died Nov. 22 at his home in Hanover, N.H. He was 86.

title: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
description: Previously recorded: $2,689,769.55

title: Homemade YouTube Video Lands Singer in a Web Ad
description: If, as the song goes, video killed the radio star, then homemade YouTube heroes like Tay Zonday have put a hit out on traditional advertising.

title: Nokia Pushes to Regain U.S. Sales in Spite of Apple and Google
description: ESPOO, Finland  When Google announced plans in October to revolutionize the software of cellular phones, few were more eager to hear the details than the industry veterans at Nokia. They still are.

title: At a Theater
description: Ethan Coen, whose credits as a filmmaker range from Blood Simple and Raising Arizona to O Brother, Where Art Thou? and No Country for Old Men, will make his debut as a playwright when the Atlantic Theater Company presents the world premiere of his Almost an Evening. Directed by Neil Pepe as the first production of the Atlantic 2 season, the production will consist of three short plays. F. Murray Abraham, Jonathan Cake, Mark Linn-Baker and Mary McCann are among the cast. Previews begin on Jan. 9 ... The Public Theaters world premiere presentation of the Richard Nelson history play Conversations in Tusculum will begin previews on Feb. 19 and run through March 23. Examining those entangled in Julius Caesars manipulations and power, it has a cast that includes Brian Dennehy, David Strathairn and Maria Tucci. ... Samuel Becketts Endgame, featuring John Turturro, has been added to the spring season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The one-act play will be presented at the Harvey Theater in 24 performances from April 25 through May 18. ... The run of Cyrano de Bergerac has been extended for two weeks, through Jan. 6, at the Richard Rodgers Theater.

title: Austin and Calcavecchia Win
description: Woody Austin made a 35-foot birdie putt on the 18th hole to win the Merrill Lynch Shootout with his teammate Mark Calcavecchia in Naples, Fla. The two won by a shot over the tournament host, Greg Norman, and Bubba Watson.The putt gave the team a final-round nine-under-par 63 in the scramble format and a 29-under 187 total.Norman and Watson barely missed birdie tries from 25 feet after Austin made his putt. Normans ball ended up inches right of the hole, and Watsons putt faded and broke in front of the hole to the left.Norman was trying to win for the first time since the 2001 Skins Game. Watson has not won as a professional.

title: Ramapo: Chase Ends in Suspects Arrest
description: Four suspects were arrested yesterday after an early-morning robbery at an Applebees restaurant and a car chase that ended at the George Washington Bridge, the police said. Police officers began chasing the car after a robbery was reported at the restaurant, on Route 59 in Airmont, about 7:20 a.m., the Ramapo Police Department said. Officers from several departments joined the pursuit, which ended when the suspects car crashed into another car as it entered the upper deck of the bridge. One suspect was injured when he tried to escape by leaping to the bridges lower deck; a second was hit by a police car while trying to carjack another vehicle, the police said. Two other suspects were arrested in Fort Lee, N.J., one while hiding inside a trash bin, the police said. None of the suspects were identified yesterday evening.

title: Nets Unable to Stop Washingtons Butler
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP)  Caron Butler scored 20 of his 28 points in the second half Sunday night, leading the Washington Wizards to a 104-89 victory over the Nets.

title: South Korea's Blackened Beaches
description: Thousands of fishermen, soldiers and volunteers struggled on Sunday to clean up the worst oil spill in South Korea's history.

title: The Gay 80s, 90s and 00s
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Children Hurt in Pakistan Bombing
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Dec. 10  A suicide bomb attack on a military truck carrying schoolchildren outside a Pakistani Air Force base in northwestern Pakistan injured five children and two adults early today, military officials said. The attack came a day after a separate suicide bombing in northwestern Pakistan killed six civilians and one police officer.

title: Bobby Orr, in the Nude
description: If youre in Soho this week and feel like seeing larger-than-life nude portraits of Bobby Orr and Derek Sanderson, you can. Kurt Kaupers realistic figurative paintings of the two Bruins icons of the early 70s are on exhibit at the Deitch Projects gallery on Grand Street through Dec. 15, and theyre well worth the visit. But be forewarned: a couple of the paintings are full frontal nudes.

description: Although there are signs of life in the nation's 11th-largest city, there has been no end to the job cuts at automakers.

title: UBS to Write Down $10 Billion as It Prepares Stake Sales
description: UBS said on Monday that it would write down its subprime mortgage investments by $10 billion but would replenish its capital by selling stakes worth 13 billion Swiss francs to the Singapore government and an unnamed Middle Eastern investor.

description: Madison Square Garden's Statement

title: Deadlines Loom Over Spending Bills
description: When it comes to the Congressional end game, one lawmakers compromise is anothers extortion.

title: Blodget May Get a Job Picking Stocks for Yahoo
description: Henry Blodget, who was barred from the securities industry for the misdeeds he committed as a research analyst at Merrill Lynch, may be getting another shot at picking hot tech offerings for a big firm. But instead of using his experience to enrich an investment bank, this time Mr. Blodget would be working for Yahoo.

title: Japans Eisai to Cough Up $3.9 Billion for MGI Pharma
description: A Japanese drugmaker, Eisai, said on Monday it would buy a biotech firm in the United States, MGI Pharma, for $3.9 billion to expand in the United States and strengthen its pipeline in cancer treatments.

title: NeuroVasx Takes $8.5 Million in New Funding
description: A medical device developer, NeuroVasx, raised $8.5 million in follow-on investment from previous backers to support completion of regulatory trials and a commercial introduction of implant technology to treat strokes in patients with brain aneurysms.

title: Conduit Capital Unloads Stake in Inelec
description: Conduit Capital Partners said Friday that it had sold its stake in Inelec, a portfolio of three hydroelectric power plants in Mexico, to a Dutch subsidiary of the Italian utility Enel in a deal valuing the facilities at $193 million, including debt.

title: Gander Mountain Deals for Overtons
description: Gander Mountain, an operator of outdoor sports supply stores, said it will acquire a boating gear retailer Overtons for $70 million in cash.

title: Investors Push Entropic Up 40% in Debut
description: Although weak demand forced Entropic Communications, a semiconductor company based in San Diego, to cut the size of its initial public offering, its stock rose 40 percent in its Nasdaq debut on Friday.

title: Conrad Black to Be Sentenced
description: The former newspaper mogul Conrad Black, convicted of swindling shareholders in his Hollinger International media empire out of millions of dollars, is due to learn just how steep a price he must pay.

title: U.S. Must Get Tougher on Deal Compliance, Lawyer Says
description: An antitrust lawyer and former Federal Trade Commission official said that the Department of Justice should get tougher if it wants more timely compliance with merger divestiture orders.

title: Tribune Appeals F.C.C. Ruling on Divestitures
description: Tribune is asking a federal appeals court to strike down an order by the Federal Communications Commission that would eventually require the company to break up newspaper-TV station combinations it operates in four markets.

title: Coty Buys Kelsos Del Labs for $800 Million
description: Kelso & Company, a private equity firm, said it would sell Del Laboratories, which makes Sally Hansen nail care products, to the fragrance giant Coty in a deal valued at about $800 million, according to The Deal.com.

title: V.C. Investments May Hit 6-Year High
description: Venture capital investments in the United States, Europe, China and Israel this year have passed the $30 billion mark and the industry is on course to post its highest investment total since 2001, according to a new report.

title: Societe Generale Takes on $4.2 Billion to Bail Out SIV
description: Societe Generale, the French bank, will bail out its structured investment vehicle by taking on $4.3 billion of assets to avoid a fire sale.

title: A Bullish Look at JPMorgan
description: Barrons apparently likes the looks of JPMorgan Chases prospects. In a bullish feature on Chase, the nations third-largest bank, the publication noted that JPMorgan avoided most of the losses suffered by other investment banks and its growth could now really accelerate.

title: Buyout Firms Put More Cash Into Deals

title: Adams in the 21st Century
description: My erudite colleagues have disclosed certain Adamsian qualities that would greatly disturb a student of Adams and yet would be difficult to refute. He was a mid-19th-century equivalent of a Vietnam-era draft dodger, hiding behind his fathers diplomatic frock coat during a war whose outcome had to do with nothing less than the character and destiny of his nation. He all too casually adopted crude stereotypes, especially where Jews were concerned, and evidenced a detachment from the colossal moral issue of slavery unbecoming to an enlightened and perceptive mind. He occasionally revealed himself to be, or to seem to be, an elitist, self-absorbed twit callously indifferent to the cares and woes of lesser mortals. And his outlook on the phenomenon and intricate operation of democracy itself was languid, to say the least, as if previous Adamses had said all that needed to be said on the subject and anything that might follow was mere froth.

title: Screening Dreams
description: If you are someone who suspects that what is billed as aviation security is often more show than substance, you are not alone. In fact, you are part of what Nixon aides used to call the silent majority. The security bureaucracy seems to think that as long as it is seen as doing something, and so long as another terror attack does not occur, the public will at least feel secure enough not to insist that it do whatever needs to be done actually to make us secure.Any number of examples could be cited to support this proposition, but lets focus first on the foiled plot in the summer of 2006 to blow up several jetliners over the United States with liquid explosives. Because no technology had been developed to detect or thwart liquid explosives, the Transportation Security Administration was forced to take, for a time, the draconian step of banning all liquids and gels. We were told at the time that even liquids and gels that are harmless in and of themselves could become incendiary when combined in sufficient quantity.

title: Shes Been Baking!
description: I love the morning after a party and the girlfriends call to discuss the food, the conversation, the clothes and, of course, the men folk. I gave a little party on Saturday night  Im sorry I didnt invite yall  and the guests trooped through the darkness and the muddy snow, with bottles of wine, cakes and a bunch of white roses. I had brought together two separate worlds, friends and cousins, city and country people, and everyone got along and stayed until midnight. I cooked a fresh ham (thanks to James Beard, the calmest and funniest of authorities, I think), and my brother sent scallops from Nantucket, which I turned into a kind of pie. We had a potato gratin and a tossed salad. I dug out my mothers recipe for chocolate pot de crme, and I used her old Good Housekeeping Picture Cookbook for the coconut layered cake. I cooked a batch of the Swedish ginger cookies, the ones made with bacon fat. Freddy the Jack stayed close to the ham all night, and Toby the Lab gave every pair of gray flannels a nice comet of hair. It was fun, the girlfriends said, sounding almost surprised.

title: In the Lab: Gene Study Helps Explain Link to Breast Cancer
description: More than 10 years ago, scientists discovered that mutations in a gene called BRCA1 lead to a particularly deadly type of breast cancer. Now an international group of researchers has found at least one reason why. BRCA1 inactivates a tumor suppressor gene known as PTEN.

title: China Said to Block U.S. Films
description: SHANGHAI, Dec. 11  China has stopped granting permission for American films to be shown in its cinemas in an apparent trade dispute with the United States, according to several Hollywood executives and United States government officials.

title: Washington Mutual Cutting Dividend and Jobs
description: Washington Mutual, one of the countrys largest lenders, said yesterday that it would exit the subprime lending business, cut its dividend and eliminate 3,150 jobs.

title: A Post-Thatcher Crime Fighter in a Pre-Thatcher England
description: The return of Life on Mars for a second season on BBC America tonight seems as good a time as any to ask why time travel has become such a popular theme on television recently. Is it that we cannot get enough of the retro aesthetic these trips backward occasion? The flesh-tone nylons, the lima-bean-green telephones with cords and dials and earpieces like coasters? Or is that writers see in bygone navet as dependable an opportunity for comedy as they do in a 6-year-old spouting off about deflated global currencies?

title: How to Defuse Iran
description: Washington

title: New York Film Critics Pick Winners
description: The New York Film Critics Circle chose  Ethan and Joel Coens latter-day western No Country for Old Men yesterday as the years best film. The Coen brothers, above (Ethan is at left), were also honored for their direction and adaptation of this film of Cormac McCarthys novel of the same title. Javier Bardem, who plays a serial killer in the film, was designated best supporting actor. Honors for best actor went to Daniel Day-Lewis for his portrayal of an oil magnate in There Will Be Blood, adapted from the Upton Sinclair novel Oil! (There Will Be Blood was also named best picture by the Los Angeles Film Critics Association.) Julie Christie, who plays a woman with Alzheimers disease in Away From Her, was named best actress. Sarah Polley, that movies director, was honored for best first film. Amy Ryan was designated best supporting actress for her portrayal of the mother of a vanished child in Ben Afflecks Gone Baby Gone. Already the winner of this years Oscar for best foreign-language film, The Lives of Others, from Germany, was named best foreign film; and Persepolis was chosen as best animated film. The New York Film Critics Circle, comprising 29 writers for New York publications, is also honoring Sidney Lumet for lifetime achievement.

title: Segui Admits Steroid Use
description: The retired first baseman David Segui said yesterday that he used steroids and purchased shipments of the drug from the former Mets clubhouse attendant Kirk Radomski, The Baltimore Sun reported on its Web site last night.Segui also repeated his June 2006 admission to ESPN that he used human growth hormone with a prescription. He told The Sun that he refused to talk to George J. Mitchell, the former senator whose report on performance-enhancing drugs in baseball is expected soon. Segui said he did not want to betray the trust of other players.I have nothing to hide. I have no problem talking about what I have done, said Segui, who spent eight of his 15 major league seasons with the Baltimore Orioles. But I never want any other players to think I was out there talking about their business.

title: Boeing Says 787 to Meet Delayed Schedule
description: The Boeing Company said today that it was on track to deliver the first 787 Dreamliner at the end of next year after improving supply chain problems that had led to a six-month delay in its original production schedule.

title: Destruction of C.I.A. Tapes Cleared by Lawyers
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10  Lawyers within the clandestine branch of the Central Intelligence Agency gave written approval in advance to the destruction in 2005 of hundreds of hours of videotapes documenting interrogations of two lieutenants from Al Qaeda, according to a former senior intelligence official with direct knowledge of the episode.

title: Doping Experts Find Loopholes Beyond Baseball
description: Game days are a day of rest for the National Football Leagues drug-testing program. The testing schedule is so regimented that players know they will not be required to offer a urine sample on those days.

title: Defending School Report Cards, Over a Chorus of Boos
description: The architect of the citys new system that assigns grades to public schools faced fierce criticism yesterday at a hearing before the City Councils Education Committee, whose members blasted the evaluations as unfair, reductive and a maze of statistics.

title: Lottery Numbers
Citigroup Deliberating on Choice for Top Job
description: Citigroups board was locked in debate over its new leader yesterday, with no clear consensus over who would be tapped.

title: Another Study Finds Heart Risks in a Diabetes Drug
description: An independent analysis of thousands of older people with diabetes found that those treated with the widely used drug Avandia had significantly elevated risks of heart attack and death.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Monday about the conviction of a Canadian pig farmer in the deaths of six women in Vancouver misstated the neighborhood from which they and other women who worked as prostitutes had vanished over a 19-year period. It is the Downtown Eastside, not the Lower Eastside. (Go to Article)

title: weeks notables
description: PLAYER In Spain, reports that Barcelona will sell Ronaldinho during the January transfer period were dismissed by the clubs president, Joan Laporta. We are not going to sell Ronaldinho, he told the news media before Sundays 2-1 win over Deportivo la Corua. We are not in contact with Chelsea, Milan or any other team.

title: In New Ad, Romney Attacks Huckabee on Immigration
description: Mitt Romneys presidential campaign plans to begin running a negative television advertisement today in Iowa highlighting Mike Huckabees record on immigration, escalating the warfare between the two Republican candidates as they scramble for support in the nations first nominating state.

title: Dmitri A. Medvedev: Young Technocrat of the Post-Communist Era
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 10  Dmitri A. Medvedevs quick ascent owes much to Vladimir V. Putin, the man who endorsed him as his successor on Monday. Critics dismiss Mr. Medvedev as a colorless bureaucrat who got lucky, saying he was chosen by Mr. Putin as a man easily manipulated so Mr. Putin can remain a power behind the throne.

title: Fin Whale at Feeding Time: Dive Deep, Stop Short, Open Wide
description: The word big doesnt do justice to whales. Humpback whales can weigh up to 40 tons. Fin whales have been known to reach 80 tons. Blue whales, the biggest animals to have ever lived, reach 160 tons  the same mass as about 2,000 grown men or 5 million grown mice.

title: Danny Newman, 88, Musical Publicity Expert, Is Dead
description: Danny Newman, longtime director of press and public relations at Lyric Opera of Chicago and an influential thinker on the art of selling classical music to the public, died on Dec. 1 at his home in Lincolnwood, Ill. He was 88.

title: Troubled Citigroup Names Pandit as Chief Executive
description: Citigroup, the countrys largest bank and one of the biggest casualties of the turmoil in the credit markets, appointed Vikram S. Pandit as its chief executive today.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article yesterday about Rudolph W. Giulianis tenure as the United States attorney in Manhattan referred incorrectly in some editions to the United States attorney general in 1987, who was then Mr. Giulianis boss. He is Edwin Meese III, not Edward.

title: Emergency Antidote, Direct to Addicts
description: Among the growing numbers of researchers and public health officials advocating a daring new strategy to put an injectable antidote for heroin overdoses directly into the hands of addicts, few have the credibility of Mark Kinzly.

title: Attacks in Baghdad Kill 9 and Damage a Refinery
description: BAGHDAD, Dec. 10  A spate of bomb, rocket and mortar attacks rocked areas of Baghdad on Monday, killing at least nine people and exploding part of a major oil refinery, sending up a thick column of smoke that dominated the citys skyline for much of the day.

title: Lining Up Bobby Bowdens Successor
description: Jimbo Fisher will succeed Bobby Bowden as Florida States next coach  someday. Bowden, who has the most victories in major college football, has agreed to a deal for next season, his 33rd, with options to stay longer. But T. K. Wetherell, the university president, designated Fisher, the offensive coordinator, as head-coach-in-waiting, then skipped out of a somewhat unusual news conference without answering questions about the contracts, which are not yet completed.

title: New Music Director for Vienna Opera
description: The Austrian conductor Franz Welser-Mst, below, signed on as music director of the Vienna Opera, Agence France-Presse reported. Mr. Welser-Mst, 46, music director of the Cleveland Orchestra and the Zurich Opera, will succeed Seiji Ozawa for five years, beginning on Sept. 1, 2010, according to the Austrian Federation of National Theaters.

title: Deloitte Agrees to Pay $1 Million Fine
description: Deloitte & Touche, one of the Big Four accounting firms, agreed yesterday to pay $1 million to settle accusations that it had botched an audit of a pharmaceutical company by entrusting it to a partner it knew to be a poor auditor.

title: Senate Will Consider More Restrictive Rules on Mortgages
description: Christopher J. Dodd, the chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, will introduce a bill today that would impose new regulations on mortgage brokers and investment banks and restrict certain aggressive lending practices, Congressional aides said yesterday.

title: Measures Considered to Curtail Fan Behavior
description: Three weeks after Richard J. Codey, the president of the New Jersey Senate, condemned a ritual of harassment at Gate D of Giants Stadium during halftime of Jets games, he offered stadium security a vote of confidence, even though the abuse has not been stopped.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An obituary yesterday about Richard Nolte, a diplomat and geographer, misstated the number of his surviving grandchildren. There are 10, not 9.

title: Prosecutor Says Serbia Blocked Arrests in Killings
description: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 10  The chief prosecutor of the international war crimes court for the former Yugoslavia accused Serbia on Monday of blocking the arrests of the two suspected leaders of a violent campaign of ethnic expulsions and killings, including the 1995 massacre of Muslims in the Bosnian enclave of Srebrenica.

title: Fed Cuts Rate a Quarter Point; Stocks Dive
description: The Federal Reserve cut a key short-term interest rate today by a quarter of a percentage point, to 4.25 percent, signaling its concern that the credit crisis might be gradually damaging the broader economy beyond housing.

title: China and U.S. in Food Safety Accord
description: BEIJING, Dec. 11  China and the United States, seeking to ease the furor over the safety of food exports, signed an agreement today calling for a greater United States role in certifying and inspecting Chinese food exports, including an increased presence of American officials at Chinese production plants.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A report in the National Briefing column on Friday about a decision by Cardinal Roger M. Mahony not to file a police report after he was assaulted misstated his title. He is the archbishop of Los Angeles, not the bishop.

title: Tough, Rewarding Days Caring for Four Children
description: Patricia Velasco was having a tough day. It was a Tuesday, but it could have been any day of the week.

title: Memo Pad
description: MAXJET HALTS TRADING Holding tickets or planning travel on MaxJet? The airline says it continues to accept bookings and has no plans to change its schedule after temporarily suspending trading in its shares in London on Friday. The two-year-old all business-class carrier is reported to be seeking new financing. Like all airlines, MaxJet is struggling with soaring fuel costs. Based at Washington Dulles International Airport, MaxJet is one of four international discount all business-class discount airlines to start up in the last two years. It flies from New York, Las Vegas and Los Angeles to London Stansted Airport. In a note to investors yesterday, Douglas McNeill of Blue Oar Securities in London said MaxJet was in trouble partly because punctuality statistics and anecdotal evidence suggest that customer service is well short of the required level. Meanwhile, British Air said it planned to start new all premium-class service in May between various European cities and cities in the United States, using 757 aircraft configured with business-class and premium-economy seats only.

title: Mortgage Crisis Forces the Closing of a Fund
description: Losses on investments weakened by the deepening housing crisis have forced Bank of America to close a multibillion-dollar high-yield fund, the largest of its kind, after wealthy investors withdrew billions of dollars in assets.

description: To the Editor:

title: Poll Finds G.O.P. Field Isnt Touching Voters
description: Three weeks before the Iowa caucuses, Republican voters across the country appear uninspired by their field of presidential candidates, with a vast majority saying they have not made a final decision about whom to support, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: A 17-Year-Old Legal Case and a $5.4 Million Fine Shadow DAmatos Hometown
description: ISLAND PARK, N.Y., Dec. 6  Most people here in the Long Island village where Alfonse M. DAmato grew up do not even know about the $5.4 million fine in a federal civil rights case that has been hanging over their heads for 10 years. Those who do know about it seem unconcerned, as if the flood of tax bills that the judgment represents  more than $1,000 for every man, woman and child in a community of two- and three-job families  were safely contained behind some invisible levee.

title: Putin Backs Deputy Prime Minister as Successor
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 10  President Vladimir V. Putin on Monday endorsed as his successor Dmitri A. Medvedev, a protg with no background in the state security services and virtually no power base in the Kremlin.

title: Winning When They Shouldn't
description: The Boston Celtics already have the look. They have championship talent, in the franchise players Kevin Garnett, Ray Allen and Paul Pierce, and a cornucopia of effective role players. They flexed their muscles at the start of the season and showed the N.B.A. they were a team to be reckoned with.

title: U.S. Panel Cuts Jail Time for Crimes Tied to Crack Cocaine
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11  The United States Sentencing Commission voted unanimously today to lighten punishments retroactively for crimes related to crack cocaine, a decision that could affect some 19,500 federal inmates.

title: Israelis Brief Top U.S. Official on Iran
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 10  Adm. Mike Mullen, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, made an unusual visit to Israel and got a polite earful on Monday about Israels gloomy assessment of Irans nuclear ambitions.

title: Risk Taking Is in His Genes
description: KYOTO, Japan  Inspiration can appear in unexpected places. Dr. Shinya Yamanaka found it while looking through a microscope at a friends fertility clinic.

title: European Automakers Likely to Build Plants in United States
description: DETROIT, Dec. 10  The dollars falling value is making European automakers eager to build more vehicles in the United States, even as American car companies continue to shift production to other, lower-cost countries.

title: In Midwest Duck Blinds, Visions of Global Warming
description: RICH HILL, Mo.  After 32 years of hunting ducks here in the wetlands of west-central Missouri, Chuck Geier knows when temperatures will drop and waters will freeze. That means he also knows when the birds will fly and hunting will be best.

title: Equity Firm Makes $1 Billion Investment in MBIA
description: MBIA, the nations largest bond insurer, said yesterday that it would receive a $1 billion investment from the private equity firm Warburg Pincus to shore up its finances and safeguard its top-flight credit rating.

title: When a Big Tip Turns Into Big Trouble
description: IN my job, I travel about 200,000 miles a year. After a while every city starts to look alike. But I can always tell what part of the world Im in by its drivers. Growing up in Boston, I figured I could handle any type of problem the gods of driving threw at me. I met my match in Singapore, a place known for its law-abiding citizens.

title: Lost Prokofiev Scoregets a Second Life
description: An unfinished Prokofiev score, written for a film that was never made and all but forgotten for 70 years, will be the music for a ballet to be performed by the Royal Ballet in the spring at Covent Garden in London in a production featuring Carlos Acosta, Zenaida Yanovsky and Alina Cojocaru, The Times of London reported. Said to be reminiscent of Prokofievs Romeo and Juliet and his Fifth Symphony, the score was completed by Michael Berkeley, a British composer. It was discovered by Kim Brandstrup, a Danish choreographer in London, who said he encountered a reference to it in a Prokofiev biography and unearthed a photocopy in the department of music at Goldsmiths, University of London. He proposed to the Royal Ballet that it be turned into a dance piece, and Monica Mason, director of the company, suggested that Mr. Berkeley, as he put it, arrange and elaborate the score. The score was commissioned in 1936 for The Queen of Spades, to be directed by Mikhail Romm, but when the production was called off, the music was left in a fragmentary state.

title: Militant Attacks in North Africa
description: Here is a chronology of militant activity in the Maghreb region of North Africa over the past year, including attacks in Algeria, Morocco and Tunisia, as compiled by Reuters.

title: Dozens Die as Migrant Boat Sinks in Aegean
description: At least 51 would-be migrants drowned trying to cross from Turkey to Greece and the European Union when their boat sank in rough weather early Sunday, officials said. The boat was carrying about 70 Palestinians, Iraqis and Somalians when it sank off Seferihisar, in the Aegean province of Izmir, said Orhan Sefik Guldibi, a local official. The boats origin was unclear. Rescuers saved six people. The death toll was expected to rise.

title: Black Given Prison Term Over Fraud
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 10  In the months since his convictions in July on fraud and obstruction of justice charges, Conrad M. Black, the fallen press baron who once presided over the worlds third-largest newspaper empire, was not above poking fun at himself as he waited to see how long he would spend in prison.

title: Oprah Movie Takes on Football
description: Football lifted CBS and NBC into first place in the ratings on Sunday, while ABC remained competitive, thanks to its made-for-television movie Oprah Winfrey Presents: Mitch Alboms For One More Day. Benefiting from an overrun of its afternoon football broadcast, CBS attracted the most viewers over all, averaging more than 24 million during the first half of the 7 p.m. hour, Nielsen estimated. Directly after the game, CBS remained No. 1 with 60 Minutes (15.9 million), although the networks ratings slipped as the night wore on, with The Amazing Race (11.9 million), followed by Cold Case (11.2 million) and then, finally, Shark (9 million). NBC, meanwhile, with its live Sunday Night Football coverage, finished third over all in total viewers but ahead of CBS in a close race for first among adults 18 to 49. ABC ranked third in that demographic, buoyed by Extreme Makeover: Home Edition at 8 (12.8 million) but also benefiting from For One More Day, which averaged 12.5 million viewers from 9 to 11 while finishing second only to football in its time slot in the 18 to 49 set. Fox was fourth for the night with a lineup mostly of repeats.

title: Inflation Picks Up in China; Trade Gap Grows
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 11  Inflation accelerated further in China last month, government statisticians announced today, as rising costs for food and fuel together with government currency policies are sending prices up briskly across Asia.

title: Mayo Clinic Study Links Anemia Drugs to Leukemia Risk
description: Anemia drugs from Amgen and Johnson & Johnson may raise the risk that patients with a bone marrow disease will later develop leukemia, according to an analysis of 30 years of patient records.

title: Following a Mosaic Path to Chart a Neighborhoods History
description: When Jim Power created his first mosaic on a lamppost on Astor Pace in 1987, a concrete band shell still stood inside Tompkins Square Park, admission to the CBGB club cost $5, and about the same amount could buy a nights lodging in the Bowery.

title: From Irans Fiery Leader, a Slightly Tamer Blog
description: TEHRAN, Dec. 10  Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, president of Iran, is not the first name that comes to mind when thinking of net surfers and instant messages. Yet, it turns out, the man is a blogger.

title: As a Nation Was Born, They Wrote and Wrote
description: He was her Lysander, after the Spartan hero. She was his Diana, after the Roman goddess of the moon. She called him My Dearest Friend. He called her Miss Adorable and his Heroine, who sustained with so much Fortitude, the Shocks and Terrors of the Times.

title: Central U.S. Reeling From Ice Storms
description: Ice, sleet and freezing rain beset much of the central part of the United States today, causing deaths in traffic accidents on slippery roads and cutting power to hundreds of thousands of homes and businesses.

title: Flu Shots for Children Grow Near in New Jersey
description: TRENTON, Dec. 10  Despite opposition from numerous parents and childrens rights advocates, a public health advisory panel voted on Monday to require all children in New Jersey who attend preschool or are in day care to get annual flu vaccinations.

title: The Giants May Win, but They Dont Dazzle
description: The Giants are rounding into a playoff team, in the standings and in their personality. At 9-4, they can clinch a postseason spot by defeating the Washington Redskins on Sunday night, although they are likely to clinch one even if they do not win another game.

title: Bloodshed in 02 Shadows Indian Politician in Race That Tests Nationalist Party
description: AHMEDABAD, India  Five years after more than 1,000 people, most of them Muslims, were killed as riots swept through the Indian state of Gujarat, the man censured by the courts for failing to stop the violence is in a tight race to keep his job as the states chief minister.

title: Drugs Pass Review
description: Nexium and Prilosec, AstraZenecas top-selling acid-reflux drugs, do not increase heart risks, regulators concluded after a six-month review.

title: Black Is Sentenced to 6 1/2 Years in Prison
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 10  Conrad M. Black, the flamboyant former press baron, will spend more than six years behind bars for fleecing shareholders of Hollinger International out of millions of dollars, a judge decided today.

title: Unhappy Investors Send Shares Lower
description: Stocks fell sharply and Treasuries rallied this afternoon after the Federal Reserve cut interest rates less than some investors were hoping for and indicated that it would be measured in its response to the tighter credit market.

title: No Videos as Patriots Set Sights on the Jets
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass., Dec. 10  Now, lets go back to the videotape.

title: A New Leader Guides His Fledgling Group
description: A change in leadership is cause for nervous anticipation at any institution, and the New York Youth Symphony is no exception. The orchestra opened its 45th season on Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Hall with a concert conducted by Ryan McAdams, its newly appointed music director.

title: Ways to Cut City Traffic? Well, Maybe
description: You wouldnt be able to hail a cab in Manhattan below 86th Street, where cabs would be allowed to pick up passengers only at taxi stands scattered throughout the area.

title: Pakistans News Media No Longer Silent, but Musharraf Has Muted His Critics
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Dec. 10  Nearly all private television channels blacked out last month by President Pervez Musharrafs emergency decree are back on the air. But the countrys once-thriving television news media remain largely muzzled by sweeping new restrictions that journalists and Western diplomats say stifle criticism of the government.

title: Insights: Anorexia May Be Tied to Hormones in Womb
description: Anorexia is 10 times as common in women as in men, and a new study suggests that female sex hormones in the womb may play a part.

title: The Gene That Tells Planaria Worms Which End Is Up
description: The flatworms known as planaria have long amazed scientists with their capacity for regeneration. Cut off the head end of one, and it regrows a head. Cut off the tail end, and it regrows a tail. As little as one three-hundredths of a worm can regenerate a complete organism.

title: A Network for Blacks With Sense of Mission
description: SILVER SPRING, Md.  Fortified by caffeine and good will, the volunteer construction crew at Love Fellowship Tabernacle in Brooklyn worked long hours to transform a dingy storage area into the Kingdom Cafe. The hammering and plastering created a restaurant and gathering spot for young people at this Pentecostal church in the struggling East New York neighborhood. As for the lights and camera, they were there for Divine Restoration, a TV One program that finds black churches needing a makeover and turns the process into television.

title: Mediator to Enter Talks With Drivers of Wheelchair Vans
description: A federal mediator will arbitrate talks between four companies that provide 8,000 daily van rides for disabled and frail passengers in New York City and the union that represents their drivers.

title: The Postwar Election
description: The 2008 presidential election has fundamentally shifted, but it hasnt been because of events in Iowa and New Hampshire. Its because of events everywhere else.

title: War vs. Terrorism Debate in Embassy Bomb Appeal
description: The national debate over Guantnamo and the way the government has pursued its fight against terrorism since the 9/11 attacks was a presence yesterday as a federal appeals court in Manhattan considered the cases of three operatives of Al Qaeda convicted in the last major terrorism trial in the United States before 9/11.

title: Counting Calories, but Not to Shed Pounds
description: We stood in front of the freezer case at the grocery store, my 16-year-old daughter, Kitty, and I. It was late, and I was tired, but we had come out for a few items that couldnt wait until morning. One of them was ice cream.

title: Mr. Johnsons Unused Authority
description: When President Bush plucked him from civil service obscurity in 2005 to run the Environmental Protection Agency, Stephen Johnson probably never imagined that he would someday find himself at the center of the policy struggle over global warming. But that is where he is now, courtesy of the Supreme Courts ruling in March that greenhouse gases could be regulated under the Clean Air Act, a law administered by the E.P.A. Unfortunately, Mr. Johnson and the agency have not done anything meaningful since.

title: UBS Records a Big Write-Down and Sells a Stake
description: FRANKFURT, Dec. 10  UBS became the latest Western bank to seek a financial lifeline from the cash-rich East on Monday, selling a more than 10 percent stake to investors from Singapore and the Middle East, as it wrote down a further $10 billion in the value of its mortgage-backed assets.

title: Canada: Ottawa Mayor Charged
description: The police filed criminal charges against Mayor Larry OBrien of Ottawa. Mr. OBrien, a multimillionaire, is accused of offering an opponent cash and help with a federal appointment if he dropped out of the 2006 election. Legal scholars said Mr. OBrien appeared to be the first mayor in modern Canadian history to face criminal charges related to his office.

title: Police Tie Colorado Church Shootings to One Gunman
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, Dec. 10  Two deadly church shootings in Colorado over the weekend, 12 hours apart in different cities, were committed by the same man, though his motives remain unclear, the police said Monday.

title: How a Higher Fare Affects Riders Choices: Not Much
description: As it sometimes does to commemorate the holiday season, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority is getting ready to vote on a slate of fare increases.

title: Court Restores Sentencing Powers of Federal Judges
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10  The Supreme Court today restored federal judges to their traditional central role in criminal sentencing.

title: For a Few Dollars More, Dining Improves on Longer Flights
description: Now that the airlines have had a few years of experience selling food in the coach cabin instead of including it in the price of a ticket, they are applying the lessons they have learned to a new round of buy on board options.

title: Australia Shocked by Case of Raped Indigenous Girl
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Tuesday, Dec. 11  Australia has been rocked by the case of a 10-year-old indigenous girl who was gang raped in her home community, and the revelation that her nine rapists had not been given prison sentences, in part because the judge found that the victim probably agreed to have sex.

title: U.S. to Limit Flights at Kennedy
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10  The Transportation Department plans to announce next week that it will impose limits on the number of flights landing and taking off at Kennedy International Airport in an effort to ease congestion and delays, according to officials involved in the deliberations.

title: Voyager 2 Continues Its Trek
description: Nearly eight billion miles away, the Voyager 2 spacecraft has passed through a sonic boom of solar wind particles in the outer part of the solar system, NASA scientists said. On Aug. 30, the craft detected the speed of charged particles from the Sun passing it abruptly slowing from 700,000 miles per hour to 350,000 miles per hour. Over the next two days, the spacecraft passed through the boundary four more times as the solar systems termination shock bubble expanded and contracted. Voyager 2s twin, Voyager 1, passed through the boundary three years ago, in the opposite hemisphere and about a billion miles farther from the Sun. The new data confirm a squashed shape for the magnetic bubble enveloping the solar system, which has been pushed inward in the southern hemisphere. Both spacecraft will eventually exit the solar system, perhaps as soon as 7 to 10 years from now.

title: Children Hurt in Pakistan Bombing
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Dec. 10  A suicide bomb attack on a military truck carrying schoolchildren outside a Pakistani Air Force base in northwestern Pakistan wounded five children and two adults early on Monday, military officials said. The attack came a day after a suicide bombing in northwestern Pakistan killed six civilians and a police officer.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about the merger of the video game developer Activision with the Vivendi Games unit of Vivendi Universal referred incorrectly to one of Activisions game franchises. It develops games based on the Spider-Man movies, not the Superman movies.

title: Somalia: Islamists Take Town
description: Bule Burte, a strategic town in central Somalia, has fallen out of government hands, residents said, and a militia allied to the Islamist movement is in control. The militia forced out government troops after a clan-related dispute. Somalias Islamist movement was defeated a year ago by Ethiopian troops but has been making a resurgence recently. Somalias 72-year-old president, Abdullahi Yusuf Ahmed, left a hospital in Kenya on Sunday for treatment in London.

title: A Battle Fought in the Factories
description: WEIFANG, China, Dec. 8  When the aging state-owned Weifang East Steel Pipe factory here in Chinas northern coastal plains fell into insolvency a few years ago, unpaid workers at first responded by blocking the factory gates and marching angrily on a nearby municipal building.

title: A Satirical Spin on Stereotypes, at Home, Abroad and on Broadway
description: Form follows function so closely that it trips itself up in Yellow Face, David Henry Hwangs lively, messy and provocative cultural self-portrait of a play. This exploration of one mans personal and social identity crisis, which opened last night at the Public Theater, suffers from its own artistic identity crisis.

title: New Jersey Moves to Abolish Death Penalty
description: TRENTON, Dec. 10  The New Jersey Senate voted Monday to make the state the first in the country to repeal the death penalty since the United States Supreme Court allowed executions to resume in 1976 and established the nations current system of capital punishment.

title: Paris Flocks to a Cunningham Revival: Works That Remain Fresh
description: PARIS, Dec. 10  Among the American cultural phenomena that the French have taken to their collective heart (le jazz hot, le film noir, etc.), surely nothing is more surprising than the success of the choreographer Merce Cunningham over several decades. His company visits Paris more often than any other city in the world, gives more performances here than anywhere else and tours extensively around the French provinces. In his home city, New York, empty seats are not unusual; in London it is only occasionally impossible to obtain a ticket for a Cunningham performance.

title: One Family Man vs. Another
description: This television advertisement for Mitt Romney, his first that directly takes on a Republican rival  in this case, Mike Huckabee  will start running in Iowa on Tuesday.

title: Arsenal, the One in Argentina, Wins a Title
description: Arsenal has finally won a major continental competition. No, not that Arsenal, the fabled Gunners who call north London home. But Arsenal de Sarand of Avellaneda, Argentina.

title: Britain: Missing Mans Wife Charged
description: John Darwin, the 57-year-old man who walked into a London police station this month claiming amnesia, more than five years after he was presumed to have drowned in a kayaking accident in the North Sea, appeared in court on fraud charges and was remanded into custody. The charges involved obtaining an insurance payout by faking his death and obtaining a British passport in an assumed name. At the court in Hartlepool, his wife, Anne, 55, was charged separately with two counts of deception involving more than $330,000 in insurance claims. She flew back to Britain on Sunday after leaving the couples hideaway apartment in Panama. Before her arrest at Manchester Airport, she gave The Daily Mail a tearful account of their secret life. She said that her husband went missing after talking of clearing heavy debts by faking his death and that she believed him dead until he reappeared at their home 11 months after his smashed kayak was found on a beach near Hartlepool. She said she then joined him in an elaborate scam, rejoining him at home on the day she persuaded an inquest to declare him formally dead. You tell one lie and you had to tell another one to cover up for the first one, and it all just snowballed, she said.

title: Canadian Exchanges Plan to Merge
description: OTTAWA, Dec. 10  A proposed merger announced Monday between the parent of the Toronto Stock Exchange and the Montreal Exchange, valued at $1.3 billion, was quickly questioned by a large institutional investor in Quebec.

title: Choreographers Stretch Visions in and Out of the Box
description: Showcases can be deadly, but the selection of choreographers for the NuDance Festival on Saturday night at Theater of the Riverside Church was unusually good. The artists came from a wide range of backgrounds, including Broadway, mainstream modern dance and hip-hop. Nearly everyone had something distinctively personal to say, for the most part stylistically. The festival, a platform for new and midcareer artists, summoned memories of the theaters history as a major presenter of dance.

title: Patterns: Parkinsons Raises Risk of Depression in Relatives
description: First-degree relatives  parents, siblings and children  of people with Parkinsons disease are about 50 percent more likely than relatives of healthy people to suffer depression or anxiety, a new study reports.

title: Germany: Broadcaster Stake Sold
description: Axel Springer, the European newspaper publisher, agreed to sell its 12 percent stake in the broadcaster ProSiebenSat.1 Media to the private equity firms Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Permira Advisers for 509.4 million euros ($749.5 million). Kohlberg Kravis, based in New York, and Permira, based in London, are paying an average of 19.40 euros a share for the Springer stake. The two companies agreed last December to acquire 50.5 percent of ProSiebenSat.1 for 3.1 billion euros. Axel Springer is based in Hamburg, Germany.

title: Commuter Jet and Boeing 747 in Near Miss
description: A 37-seat commuter jet arriving at Kennedy Airport nearly collided with a Boeing 747 cargo jet on Sunday afternoon when the Boeing, which was supposed to land on a perpendicular runway, failed to do so and continued across the smaller jets path, controllers at the airports tower said yesterday.

title: Still Fighting Cancer, Yow Is Back on the Court
description: RALEIGH, N.C.  The hair that fell out during chemotherapy treatments has grown back and now Kay Yow has a short gray look as she coaches the North Carolina State womens basketball team.

title: A Place to Play With Your Old Friends
description: The holidays are a time for nostalgia. For film buffs that inevitably means Its a Wonderful Life. For romantics that may mean reminiscing about an old flame. For a gamer, that could mean a wistful recollection of that time when your mastery of Centipede made you the king of the arcade or the winter of 1982 when your skills at Pitfall! on your buddys faux-wood-paneled Atari 2600 made you the lord of the shag-carpeted living room.

title: New Jersey Nears Repeal of Death Penalty
description: TRENTON, Dec. 10  The New Jersey Senate voted Monday to make the state the first in the country to repeal the death penalty since 1976, when the United States Supreme Court set guidelines for the nations current system of capital punishment.

title: Nationals Replace Schneider With Lo Duca
description: Catcher Paul Lo Duca may want to find out if Brian Schneider left any shin guards or chest protectors behind with the Washington Nationals. Ditto for Schneider with Lo Duca and the Mets.

title: Excerpts From an Interview With Dmitri A. Medvedev
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 10  Last month, First Deputy Prime Minister Dmitri A. Medvedev, who was endorsed today by President Vladimir V. Putin to be Russias next president, met with foreign journalists. Here are excerpts from his comments during the meeting, as translated by The New York Times:

title: Starting the Peace Process
description: Israelis and Palestinians are supposed to begin serious negotiations tomorrow after last months long-on-optics, short-on-specifics Annapolis peace meeting. Despite all the smiles and handshakes, both sides went home and fell back into some familiar, counterproductive patterns.

title: Hong Kong Exchange Looks to Trade Smog Rights
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 11  As this city struggles under a daily cloud of noxious fumes from local traffic and nearby factories in mainland China, the Hong Kong Stock Exchange is considering using its financial muscle as part of a solution.

title: For Tortured Russian Poet, a Life of Drama and Despair
description: The Russian poet Marina Tsvetayeva endured and indulged in a life of high drama. One of her young daughters died of starvation during the famine that followed the Russian Revolution. A lover of both men and women, she followed her White Russian husband into exile in Europe, then returned after he was accused of changing sides and spying for the Soviets. Impoverished and spied on by Soviet secret agents, she hanged herself in 1941.

title: Stop Stalling on Judicial Raises
description: New York was once a national leader in judicial compensation. Now, it ranks 49th among the 50 states when salaries are adjusted for the cost of living, and the last pay increase was in 1999.

title: Gazans Passage to Mecca Seen as an Insult to Abbas
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 10  What appeared to have been a decision by Egypt and Saudi Arabia to cooperate with Hamas rather than with the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, in allowing 2,000 people to leave Gaza last week for a pilgrimage to Mecca is causing friction in Palestinian, Israeli and Western circles.

title: Always On
description: Q. Many devices that are always on while seemingly off draw power so that they can spring into action on demand. How much electricity does a television, for example, use when plugged in but not turned on?
