description: To the Editor:

title: Divided, France Welcomes and Condemns Qaddafi
description: PARIS, Dec. 10  Redemption, at last, seems to have come for Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

title: How the Poll Was Conducted
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Dec. 5-9 with 1,133 adults throughout the United States. Of these, 1,028 said they were registered to vote.

title: Ask.com Puts a Bet on Privacy
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 10  Will privacy sell?

title: Bush Adviser Is Seen as Force in Spending Impasse
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10  Ed Gillespie made a name for himself in 1994 as a sharp-tongued pitchman for the Contract With America, the conservative Republican manifesto that catapulted his boss, Dick Armey, to power. But when Republicans shut down the government in a spending clash with President Bill Clinton, Mr. Gillespie warned it was the wrong battle to pick.

title: An 8-Second Ride Lures Sponsors Beyond the Rodeo
description: JUSTIN McBRIDE and Adriano Moraes are hardly household names, but advertisers are betting that these bull riders  who compete for prize money by trying to stay on a bucking bull for eight seconds  could represent the next big thing in sports sponsorship.

title: Stanton Wheeler, 77, a Yale Law Professor, Dies
description: Stanton Wheeler, a professor at Yale Law School who made notable studies of white-collar crime, prison systems and the way judges think but who was not a lawyer, died on Friday in New Haven. He was 77 and lived in Branford, Conn.

title: El Salvador: Iraq Mission Renewed
description: President Elas Antonio Saca said El Salvador would send a 10th contingent of 280 soldiers to Iraq next year to help with aid and reconstruction efforts there, according to The Associated Press. El Salvador, which has had troops in Iraq since 2003, is the only country in Latin America that has maintained such a deployment.

title: When Employees Sue
description: Yes, it is a clich. And no, the boss does not always act as if it were true, but employees really can be a companys most important asset.

title: In Duck Blinds, Visions of Global Warming
description: RICH HILL, Mo.  After 32 years of hunting ducks in the wetlands of Missouri, Chuck Geier knows when temperatures will drop and waters will freeze. That means he also knows when the birds will fly and hunting will be best.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The About New York column in some editions on Saturday, about the ways that digital technology has transformed crime investigations, gave an incorrect spelling in some copies for the given name of a man who used an MP3 player to secretly record his interrogation by a city police officer after a shooting in the Bronx in 2005. He is Erik Crespo, not Eric.

title: Jailed Rapist Confesses to Murders 30 Years Ago
description: CAPE GIRARDEAU, Mo., Dec. 10  A convicted rapist who has been in and out of prisons for decades has confessed to nine murders, including those of five women that terrorized this city along the Mississippi 30 years ago.

title: Caution: Art Afoot
description: LONDON, Dec. 8  As contemporary art often does, the giant crack in the floor at the Tate Modern here inspires different responses from different people.

title: Another Movement of Musical Diplomacy
description: If North Korea keeps its promises, potentially millions of its isolated, tightly controlled citizens are likely to hear their national anthem played on the radio by the New York Philharmonic. And then they will hear The Star-Spangled Banner, a quintessential American symbol, in a place long subjected to anti-American propaganda.

description: To the Editor:

title: Freelancers Walk Out at MTV Networks
description: Scores of workers from MTV Networks walked off the job yesterday afternoon, filling the sidewalk outside the headquarters of its corporate parent, Viacom, to protest recent changes in benefits.

title: OSHA Investigates Ballet Dancers Fall
description: The Atlanta Ballet is under investigation by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration of the United States Department of Labor after a 17-year-old dancer wearing a panda costume fell about 12 feet into the orchestra pit last week during a performance of The Nutcracker at the Fox Theater in Atlanta, The Atlanta Journal-Constitution reported. The dancer, Leah Boresow, a high school senior, plunged into the empty orchestra pit and suffered serious injuries. She underwent spinal surgery on Wednesday and was reported to be in critical but stable condition at the Atlanta Medical Center, the Atlanta Ballet said in a statement. Andre Richards, director of the Atlanta West Office of OSHA, said, Anytime we see a high-profile situation such as that, normally what we do is initiate an inspection. He added, We will probably take a look at the costume to see what level of vision that person had. He said a week or two might pass before the inspectors report would be available and any citations might be issued. Jeff Al-Mashat, a spokesman for the ballet, said precautions would be taken to keep the panda dancers safe for the remaining run of the ballet, continuing through Dec. 29. The Journal-Constitution reported that two days before her fall, Ms. Boresow told friends at Chattahoochee High School that she was concerned that she might fall off the stage because of the costume, which offered limited sight through a hole in the nose of the panda head.

title: Scientists Blend Materials to Create Oil-Repellent Surfaces
description: Water has many remarkable properties, not the least of which is its high surface tension. That makes water-repellent materials fairly common. The surface tension makes water bead up.

title: The Soul of a New Vaccine
description: ROCKVILLE, Md.  The sign on the wall reads Emergency Response Procedures for a Mosquito Release.

title: From a Japanese Satellite, Here Comes the Sun
description: Telescopes aboard the Hinode satellite, launched by the Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency in September 2006, have been returning some of their first results, featured in the current issue of Science. Left, a photo in visible light shows threadlike features in a prominence on the Sun's surface. Right, an image of Mercury in transit across the disk of the Sun.

title: Gas Terminal Proposed Off New Jersey
description: Exxon Mobil said today that it plans to build a $1 billion floating natural-gas terminal about 20 miles off the New Jersey coast, a move it thinks could help deflect potential opposition because of the projects distance from shore.

title: Another Loss, but a New Scapegoat: The Fans
description: They played a meaningful fourth quarter at Madison Square Garden on Monday, and given the current ill state of affairs, this counted as progress.

title: Killer Who Escaped From Mental Hospital Commits Suicide After Recapture
description: A mentally disturbed killer who escaped from a troubled New Jersey psychiatric hospital on Sunday and was captured hours later killed himself early yesterday, while he was supposed to be under the supervision of the hospitals staff, state officials said.

title: Taliban Loses Grip on Last Major Town
description: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan, Dec. 10  Afghan and NATO troops retook the town of Musa Qala in southern Afghanistan on Monday, forcing the Taliban to withdraw from the only sizable town they hold in the country, Afghan and NATO officials said. There was no clear picture of casualties, but the Taliban and civilians said there had been heavy bombardment overnight.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Monday about the conviction of a Canadian pig farmer in the deaths of six women in Vancouver misstated the neighborhood from which they and other women who worked as prostitutes had vanished over a 19-year period. It is the Downtown Eastside, not the Lower Eastside.

title: Onscreen Villain Makes Doctors Wince
description: The most horrifying moment in the new movie Awake occurs 34 minutes into the film, when the protagonist (Hayden Christensen) feels the scalpel cutting into his chest. As his surgeon (Terrence Howard) deepens the incision, the audience can hear the patients screams of agony, while the characters onscreen see only a man lying on an operating table, seemingly unconscious.

title: Text of Federal Reserve Statement
description: Here is the text of the statement from the Federal Reserves policy-setting committee, announcing a quarter-point reduction in benchmark interest rates.

title: Concert Dates
description: The seventh annual Bonnaroo Music and Arts Festival will take place from June 12 through 15 on its usual site, a 700-acre farm in Manchester, Tenn., 60 miles southeast of Nashville. ... Bruce Springsteen and his E Street Band will promote his new album, Magic, in concerts on July 27, 28 and 31 at Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., Reuters reported. Tickets go on sale on Dec. 15.

title: Worker Who Fell 47 Stories Still Critical
description: The window washer who survived a 47-story plunge when his scaffold collapsed on Friday remained in critical condition yesterday as relatives gathered to mourn his younger brother, who was working with him and died in the fall.

title: U.S. Joins Overseas Adoption Overhaul Plan
description: The United States, the world leader in international adoptions, will join more than 70 nations committed to standardizing policies, procedures and safeguards to reduce corruption in the largely unregulated adoption marketplace.

title: Rising Food and Fuel Costs Spur Inflation in China
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 11  Inflation accelerated further in China last month, government statisticians announced on Tuesday, as rising costs for food and fuel are now sending prices up briskly across Asia.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A music review on Saturday about a concert version of Philip Glasss Einstein on the Beach, at Carnegie Hall, misdentified the tenor saxophone soloist in the Building/Train section. It was Andrew Sterman  not David Crowell, another saxophonist who performed in the concert.

title: 2 Singapore Funds Invest and Recruit Talent Abroad
description: SINGAPORE, Dec. 10  From its birth in 1981 with just two employees, the Government of Singapore Investment Corporation has become one of the worlds largest sovereign funds, managing more than $100 billion in assets, with 900 employees in eight offices around the world. It is larger even than Temasek Holdings, the governments better-known fund.

title: Rehab Plan Announced for N.F.L.s Ex-Players
description: The National Football League and the players union announced a program yesterday that will pay part or all of the costs for joint-replacement surgery for former players.

title: Walter Mosleys Three-Book Deal
description: The novelist Walter Mosley has signed a three-book deal with Riverhead Books, a unit of Penguin Group, to publish a literary novel and two books in a new mystery series featuring Leonid McGill, an African-American detective in New York City who first appeared in a short story included in Best American Mystery Stories of 2006. In an interview Mr. Mosley, right, said that the new character couldnt get more different from Easy Rawlins if you tried. (He was referring to the detective who has appeared in 11 of his 27 books.) The new series, Mr. Mosley said, would be very noir and contemporary and New York. He has already completed the literary novel Last Days of Ptolemy Grey, about the relationship between an old African-American man with dementia and a 17-year-old girl. Sean McDonald, executive editor at Riverhead, acquired world rights to the three books from Gloria Loomis, Mr. Mosleys agent. The first book in the new mystery series will be published in 2009.

title: Bodies Twisting Into Pretzels, and Human Stacking Blocks
description: The New Shanghai Circus has a neat trick of cutting the music during its most astonishing feats, so that the soundtrack becomes the oohs, ahs and Oh, my Gods! from the stunned audience. At least that was how it went on a Sunday afternoon at the family-oriented New Victory Theater, where the company is performing.

title: Michael Shaheen Jr., Top Justice Dept. Official, Dies at 67
description: Michael E. Shaheen Jr., who spent 22 years as head of the Justice Departments internal investigations office, sometimes issuing rebukes of perceived ethical lapses by the nations highest officials, died Nov. 29 at his home in Falls Church, Va. He was 67.

title: Justices Restore Judges Control Over Sentencing
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10  The Supreme Court on Monday restored federal judges to their traditional central role in criminal sentencing.

title: Defendants Son on Stand in Killing of L.I. Teenager
description: RIVERHEAD, N.Y., Dec. 10  A young man at the center of a racially charged manslaughter case on Long Island took the stand Monday in Suffolk County Criminal Court here and told a jury that on Aug. 9, 2006, a group of white teenagers screeched up to his house and screamed profanities and anti-black epithets.

description: It is one thing to have power, and another to use it.

description: In Harlem yesterday, a long way from a federal courthouse in Richmond, Va., the news on Michael Vick reached a former N.F.L. wide receiver named Duke Fergerson, who immediately did the depressing math.

title: Roles Swap in Argentinas Palace as First Lady Takes Over
description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 10  Nstor Kirchner, Argentinas most popular president in decades, draped the light-blue-and-white sash over the shoulder of his wife, Cristina Fernndez de Kirchner, on Monday, officially passing power to the first woman to be elected Argentinas leader in its 191-year history.

title: When Removing One Predator Harms the Prey
description: The predator-prey relationship is simple, right? If a predator is around, that is bad for the prey, and if the predator is removed, that is good for the prey.

title: Office-Building Workers Threaten to Strike on New Years Day
description: With the citys office-building market booming year after year, the janitors, doormen and elevator operators who keep those buildings running want their share.

title: Cuba: U.N. Rights Pacts to Be Signed
description: Foreign Minister Felipe Prez Roque said Cuba would sign the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights, in force since 1976. Yesterday was International Human Rights Day, which he said Cuba celebrated holding its head high, according to Agence France-Presse. In a nearby Havana square, government supporters were shoving and shouting at about a dozen dissidents who had held a protest calling for improved human rights on the island.

title: Vick Receives 23 Months and a Lecture
description: RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 10  Michael Vick, the former Atlanta Falcons star who has traded his No. 7 jersey for a black-and-white-striped jail uniform, stood expressionless in a federal courtroom Monday and apologized to the court and his family for his involvement in a dogfighting ring. But for the judge about to decide Vicks fate, those words were not enough.

title: Garden Settles Harassment Case for $11.5 Million
description: Three days before a federal judge was to hear testimony on Anucha Browne Sanderss claim for compensatory damages against Madison Square Garden, the parties settled the sexual harassment case yesterday and ended all appeals.

title: In the Crowded Sky, Change Is Approaching
description: ITS a challenging time to be writing about air travel. Its an even more challenging time to be reading about it.

title: An Ancient Medicine (Enjoy in Moderation)
description: Every year, the average American adult drinks the equivalent of 38 six-packs of beer, a dozen bottles of wine and two quarts of distilled spirits like gin, rum, single malt Scotch, or vodka that aspires to single malt status through the addition of flavors normally associated with yogurt or bubble bath.

title: China: An Oil Deal With Iran
description: The China Petrochemical Corporation, known as Sinopec, signed a $2 billion agreement to develop Irans Yadavaran oil field. The field would produce 85,000 barrels a day in four years and an additional 100,000 barrels a day three years after that, Chinas official Xinhua news agency reported, citing the Iranian oil minister, Gholam Hossein Nozari, above.

title: C.I.A. Chief Says Others Decided Fate of Video
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11  Gen. Michael V. Hayden, director of the Central Intelligence Agency, distanced himself today from the decision to record and subsequently destroy hundreds of hours of video footage taken during the interrogations of senior Al Qaeda captives.

title: Harvard to Aid Students High in Middle Class
description: BOSTON, Dec. 10  Harvard University announced on Monday that it would significantly increase the financial aid it offered to middle-class and upper-middle-class students, seeking to allay concerns that elite colleges are becoming too expensive for even relatively well-off families.

title: David H. Shepard, 84, Dies; Optical Reader Inventor
description: David H. Shepard, who in his attic invented one of the first machines that could read, and then, to facilitate its interpreting of credit-card receipts, came up with the near-rectilinear font still used for the cards numbers, died on Nov. 24 in San Diego. He was 84.

title: Disabled, and Waiting for Justice
description: We know what is behind President Bushs sudden enthusiasm for fiscal discipline after years of running up deficits and debt: political posturing, just in time for the 2008 election. But one should not forget the damage that his administration has also inflicted by shortchanging important domestic programs in favor of tax cuts for the wealthy and his never-ending Iraq war.

title: Mental Reserves Keep Brains Agile
description: My husband, at 74, is the baby of his bridge group, which includes a woman of 85 and a man of 89. This challenging game demands an excellent memory (for bids, cards played, rules and so on) and an ability to think strategically and read subtle psychological cues. Never having had a head for cards, I continue to be amazed by the mental agility of these septua- and octogenarians.

description: Researchers analyzing variation in the human genome have concluded that human evolution accelerated enormously in the last 40,000 years under the force of natural selection.

description: POTRERO, Calif.  The scandal in Iraq involving Blackwater, the private security firm, is a world away from this tiny town near the Mexican border. But five members of the communitys planning group are expected to lose their posts on Tuesday for approving a Blackwater training camp on an old chicken farm here.

title: Making Art Onstage Near Art on the Walls
description: Choreographers are enamored of museums and art galleries, and while such envy can seem regressive, their outlook is certainly understandable. Its about wealth and sustainability, two obvious qualities dance will probably never achieve. Money is always in short supply, and theres no such thing as sustainability in dance; that elusiveness is what makes it so fascinating.

title: Gore Urges Bold Moves in Nobel Speech
description: OSLO, Dec. 10  He has said it again and again, with increasing urgency, to anyone who will listen. And on Monday, former Vice President Al Gore used the occasion of his 2007 Nobel Peace Prize lecture here to tell the world in powerful, stark language: Climate change is a real, rising, imminent and universal threat to the future of the Earth.

description: PRISTINA, Kosovo, Dec. 10  As the deadline for a negotiated agreement on Kosovos future expired Monday without a settlement, several thousand protesters took to the streets of this war-ravaged capital, waving Albanian and American flags and chanting, Independence now!

description: * The Chargers were particularly banged up on Sunday. Linebacker Shawne Merriman (sprained knee) and fullback Lorenzo Neal (broken leg) will miss at least Sundays game against Detroit. Quarterback Philip Rivers also has a sprained knee and his status for Sunday is uncertain.

description: A Canadian fertilizer and seed producer, Agrium, will raise $1.25 billion in an equity financing to support the companys $2.65 billion takeover of UAP Holding.

description: It looks like Libya is gearing up to join the sovereign wealth party sweeping Asia and the Middle East.

description: The steelmaker ArcelorMittal added another purchase to its South American buying spree on Tuesday, acquiring Argentinas largest steel distributor M.T. Majdalani.

description: Maus Frres, Switzerlands fourth largest clothes retailer and the owner of the Lacoste brand, began a hostile 5.2 billion Swedish kroner ($813 million) takeover bid on Tuesday for Gant, a Swedish clothes retailer with more than 300 stores around the world.

description: Xstrata, the worlds sixth-largest mining company, is open to discussions with potential suitors, including Vale of Brazil and Anglo American, The Financial Times reported.

title: The Dangers of Generalizing About the Generations
description: When I wrote last weeks post What the Gen Y Worker Wants, I expected to get a lot more criticism than I did for making generalizations about different demographic groups. I got some. I also got criticism for even suggesting that it is a strong job market. One commenter, who identified himself as a business professor at a mid-range college, questioned the very idea students feel they have a lot of choices in todays job market by saying that most of his students really just want to get a job so they can start paying for their crushing student loans.

title: TPGs Bonderman, Still Reluctant to Go Public

title: Energy, an Ingredient in Local Food and Global Food
description: When I find time to read instead of report and write, Im usually catching up on the fine work of my colleagues and other journalists days behind the datelines. As an editor for The Times once said, you can either write for the paper or read it, but you cant do a good job of both.

title: FFSA prize ceremony  and a homecoming for Bourdais
description: There has been a lot of coverage in the English language of the Autosport awards last weekend, and rightly so. But an exotic alternative  if you live on the continent and dislike taking the Eurostar  was the ceremony last night for the French automobile racing federation (the Federation Francaise du Sport Automobile, or FFSA). It took place in the plush 18th Century concert hall called the Casino de Paris, and was attended by hundreds of people, including racers and team members from every level in France from go-karting up to Formula One.

title: The Early Word: Storming Iowa
description: DES MOINES  Were using split-screens today, one watching an ice storm as it moves its way through the Midwest and possibly complicates the travel plans of candidates, and the other attuned to the presidential campaign as it pops up and down on the television during the early morning news here. The Republican candidates are beginning to return here in preparation for their debate on Wednesday; the Democrats turn comes on Thursday  and its the last debate in this state before the Jan. 3 caucuses.

title: Choice Picks
description: The nominations for the Critics Choice Award  the annual bonbons bestowed by the Broadcast Film Critics  were announced this morning. The by-now usual suspects make an appearance, although Amy Adams of Enchanted, the much attended but little recognized fairy tale, gets some love as well.

title: Dont Like Congestion Pricing? Consider These Alternatives
description: In a front-page article, William Neuman examines some of the more unusual ideas being considered by the state commission studying how to mitigate traffic congestion in Manhattan. The ideas include banning the hailing of cabs in Manhattan below 86th Street, and instead installing taxi stands where cabs would be allowed to pick up passengers only at these stands scattered throughout the area; imposing license-plate rationing, under which, say, drivers with a license plate ending in 5 would be prohibited from entering the busiest parts of Manhattan on the 5th, the 15th or the 25th of every month; and significantly raising the cost of street parking, which could cost as much as parking in a garage.

title: In Papers, Russias 2008 Campaign Is Already Over
description: The Russian presidential campaign has ended before it began. That seems to be the dominant opinion of the Russian news media, a day after President Vladimir Putin endorsed the candidacy of his slight, soft-spoken protg, Dmitri Medvedev, to succeed him in the countrys top office.

title: No Pain, No Gain
description: A leader of the CIA team that captured the first major Al Qaeda figure, Abu Zubaydah, says subjecting him to waterboarding was torture but necessary, reports ABC News, in a pretty substantial scoop. In the first public comment by any CIA officer involved in handling high-value al Qaeda targets, John Kiriakou, now retired, said the technique broke Zubaydah in less than 35 seconds.

title: Fine Print | Richard Avedon Monograph
description: Bob Dylan, 1965, and Avedon in a 1980 self-portrait.

title: Defending the Honor of the Globes

We pay slavish attention to the Golden Globes, teasing apart their nominations, which will be out this Thursday, for any hint of heat or light. But at the same time, the Globes become a piata, whacked over and over for alleged hackery and excessive fanboy tendencies.

title: The First Orders Arrive for Chocolate Beta Bars

Movies that won over critics and fans alike, like Judd Apatows Knocked Up and Superbad, get bupkes, while There Will Be Blood is showered with praise. No wonder the Oscars are posting rugged audience numbers, he says:

Sure, there are days when it can read like you got trapped on a small boat with the all-knowing grad student from hell, but he and his gang know their stuff and strut it. Nothing is sacred and all cows are in danger. The Bagger, incidentally, has been hailed as the Father of the Reeler, but his paternity has not entitled him to much consideration.

title: Red Bulls Closing In on New Coach

Rex Reed made a vomiting noise the first time there was a vote for Francis Coppolas Youth Without Youth, which prompted NYFCC chief Stephen Whitty to quip, And a special award to Rex for sitting through it.  Jeffrey Wells on the New York critics award discussion.

Being on Oscar patrol is like being part of a national political campaign; incremental data comes in day after day and is beaten to a pulp by far too many prognosticators. But when it is all done, what pops out is a best picture, not a leader of the free world.

The site, which officially launches Tuesday, is called Cellware, and it was founded by John Ferber, who started Advertising.com with his brother Scott.

title: Universals Imeem Deal May Unlock More Free Music

Universal had been the last holdout among major labels in supporting Imeem, which offers users what no other site has before: they can choose as many songs as they want to listen to on their computers  streaming, not downloading  without paying anything for the privilege. The music is paid for by the advertising on the site.

title: A Different American Education
description: In 1948, Sayyid Qutb began his unhappy education in the United States. He arrived at a hinge moment in the evolution of American power, the dizzying, go-go, post-World War II days. Modernity  in the form of rising affluence, movies and sexually liberated women  hit Qutb in the face, and the sheer godlessness of the place overwhelmed him. He came on a scholarship to study at the Colorado State College of Education in Greeley, but during his two years there he also traveled to New York and California, the coastal pillars of American dynamism and technological progress. By the time he left in 1950 to return to Egypt, he had had his fill of American depravity  and had concluded that Islam and modernity were completely incompatible. He was brimming with rage.

description: The Fifth Downs contributors are Andrew Das, Benjamin Hoffman, Naila-Jean Meyers, John Woods and Toni Monkovic.

title: Suspicions in U.S. That China Has Put Ban on Hollywood Films
description: SHANGHAI  China has stopped granting permission for American films to be shown in its theaters in an apparent trade dispute with the United States, according to several Hollywood executives and United States government officials.

title: Bucking for Their Eight Seconds of Fame
description: Carl Franois tossed a kiss into a crowd of urban cowboys gathered round a bullring on Monday night.

title: Footnote
description: The cast of the all-black Broadway revival of Cat on a Hot Tin Roof was announced on Tuesday. The play will star Terrence Howard as well as Phylicia Rashad, Anika Noni Rose and James Earl Jones. Debbie Allen is directing the production, which is to begin performances at the Broadhurst on Feb. 12.

title: In Special Education Cases, City Is Fighting Harder Before Paying for Private School
description: New York City, at the suggestion of private consultants, is significantly ramping up its effort to challenge cases in which it pays for private school tuition of children with disabilities whose parents say they are ill-served by the public schools.

title: So Little Time, So Many Charities to Feed
description: WHEN casting about for ways to spend on others at this time of year, people whose hearts are as big as their appetites turn to food-related charities. But figuring out where to direct help can be complex, especially in an era when tens of thousands of such programs exist.

title: Wary of Protests, Exxon Plans Natural Gas Terminal in the Atlantic
description: Exxon Mobil said Tuesday that it would like to build a $1 billion floating terminal for liquefied natural gas about 20 miles off the coast of New Jersey, a move meant to deflect safety and environmental concerns about proximity to populated areas.

title: Cocaine Caused Singers Death
description: An accidental cocaine overdose caused the death of Kevin DuBrow, below, lead singer for Quiet Riot, a heavy metal band popular in the 1980s, The Associated Press reported. The announcement was made by Samantha Charles, a spokeswoman for the Clark County, Nev., coroner, after toxicology results were received on Monday. Mr. DuBrow was 52 when he was found dead in his home in Las Vegas last month.

title: My Roommate Is My Enemy, Though We Do Like to Sing
description: A musical comedy about the Israeli-Palestinian conflict sounds more like a punch line than like a pleasant night at the theater. (What yuks!) But the creators of West Bank, UK, Oren Safdie (book) and Ronnie Cohen (music and lyrics), do an excellent job of avoiding the most obvious pitfalls  partisanship, preachiness and political navet  even if they get bogged down in allegory.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A report in the Extra Time soccer roundup on Tuesday about Arsenal de Sarands championship last week in the Copa Sudamricana misidentified the team it defeated for the title. It was Club Amrica, not Chivas of Guadalajara. (Arsenal defeated Chivas in the quarterfinals.)

title: Rape of Girl, 15, Exposes Abuses in Brazil Prison System
description: BRASLIA  The police jail at Abaetetuba could not be torn down soon enough for Mrcia Soares, a lawyer and federal human rights official here. To her, the jail has come to symbolize everything that is wrong with Brazils efforts to safeguard women and children from violence.

title: President Pick Would Name Putin Premier
description: MOSCOW  The longtime aide tapped by Vladimir V. Putin to be his successor as president of Russia declared Tuesday that he wanted Mr. Putin to be his prime minister, offering the clearest indication yet of how Mr. Putin plans to maintain firm control over the Kremlin after his term ends next spring.

title: White House Is Confident of Broad Support on Iran
description: WASHINGTON  A week after American intelligence agencies reported that Iran halted work on a covert nuclear weapons program in 2003, the Bush administration expressed confidence on Tuesday that it had rallied international support to intensify diplomatic and economic pressure on Irans government.

title: Texas: Two Boys Are Charged
description: Two boys ages 11 and 14 have been charged with trying to rape a 60-year-old woman in her Austin home. The boys wore bandanas when they broke through a window in July, and one tried to sexually assault the woman but stopped when her heart device was set off, the police said. They were charged with burglary with intent to commit sexual assault. Detective Scott Stanfield said the attack was deemed premeditated because the boys had a rape kit that included items to restrain the victim.

title: Fed Leads Drive to Strengthen Bank System
description: A day after the Federal Reserve disappointed investors with a modest cut in interest rates, central banks in North America and Europe announced on Wednesday the most aggressive infusion of capital into the banking system since the terrorist attacks of September 2001.

title: British Library Buys Pinter Papers
description: The British Library has bought the papers of Harold Pinter, the 2005 Nobel laureate in literature, for $2.3 million, Reuters reported. The collection of Mr. Pinter, below, includes letters from Samuel Beckett and the poet Philip Larkin. It comprises more than 150 boxes of manuscripts, scrapbooks, letters, photographs, programs and e-mail messages, as well as a draft of an unpublished memoir of his youth, The Queen of All the Fairies. Jamie Andrews, head of modern literary manuscripts at the library, said, This is a wonderful collection that sheds new light on each stage of Harold Pinters unparalleled career over the past 50 years. A small temporary exhibition, His Own Domain: Harold Pinter, a Life in Theater, will be presented at the British Library from Jan. 11 to April 13.

title: Bush Vetoes Childrens Health Bill
description: WASHINGTON  President Bush vetoed a childrens health measure on Wednesday afternoon, effectively killing Democrats hopes of expanding a popular government program aimed at providing insurance to children in lower-income and middle-income families.

title: Inflation Picks Up in China; Trade Gap Grows
description: HONG KONG  Inflation accelerated in China last month, government statisticians announced Tuesday, as rising costs for food and fuel together with government currency policies are sending prices up briskly across Asia.

title: Yahoo Deal Adds Content From CNBC
description: Yahoo Finance, the most popular business news Web site, will begin distributing content from the business news channel CNBC on Wednesday.

title: Israeli Forces Move Into Gaza
description: JERUSALEM  Israeli troops accompanied by about a dozen tanks moved into southern Gaza on Tuesday, a day before Israelis and Palestinians were due to hold their first talks on a comprehensive peace following the American-led conference in Annapolis, Md.

title: Veto of Energy Measure Is Raised as a Possibility
description: WASHINGTON  The White House has raised last-minute concerns over regulation of automobile emissions and fuel economy that aides said Tuesday could lead to a presidential veto of the energy bill now before Congress.

title: Shares Fall on a Rate Cut Considered a Disappointment to Fed Watchers
description: In the last couple of weeks, Wall Street grew hopeful that the Federal Reserve was poised to ease the tight credit market with an aggressive intervention. Tuesday, investors reacted as if policy makers had trampled on those expectations.

title: Wholl Get to Start Is Anyones Guess
description: It has been the year of the backup quarterback and at least three more will get a chance this week. Fifty-six quarterbacks have made starts this season, including the newcomers Brock Berlin (Rams) and Chris Redman (Falcons) in Week 14. Kyle Orton, who has not thrown a regular-season pass since 2005, has already been announced as the Bears starter for Monday nights game against the Vikings. Shaun Hill appears to be the last man standing for the 49ers, and Todd Collins, No. 15 at right, will get the start for the Redskins in place of the injured Jason Campbell. San Francisco and Chicago will become the sixth and seventh teams to use three starting quarterbacks this season.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Jeopardy! Host Has Heart Attack

title: C.I.A. Director Speaks to Senate Committee
description: WASHINGTON  Gen. Michael V. Hayden, director of the Central Intelligence Agency, distanced himself on Tuesday from the decision to record and subsequently destroy hundreds of hours of video taken during the interrogations of senior Qaeda captives.

title: An Island in the Hudson, Plundered in Search of Indian Artifacts
description: MAGDALEN ISLAND, N.Y.  For more than 3,000 years, this alluring isle of stone in the Hudson River north of present-day Kingston has beckoned strangers. Over the millennia, Indians stopped at its graywacke shores  and at least one was laid to rest here. They took shelter in a west-facing sandstone rock shelter. They pulled mounds of shellfish from the river. And they shaped countless arrowheads in the high, flat belly of the island before setting out to hunt or fight.

title: Another Study Finds Heart Risks in a Diabetes Drug
description: An independent analysis of thousands of older people with diabetes found that those treated with the widely used drug Avandia had significantly elevated risks of heart attack and death.

title: Putting Stadium Site to Full-Time Use
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  On a recent Sunday afternoon outside Gillette Stadium, home of the undefeated New England Patriots football team, the parking lot was jammed with so many cars that attendants wearing fluorescent vests were on hand to direct traffic.

title: Immigration Moves to Front and Center of G.O.P. Race
description: Mike Huckabee wrote a book this year in which he lamented the seething anger surrounding the immigration debate, advocated giving illegal immigrants a path to citizenship and concluded that in the debate some of the rage is fueled by prejudice.

title: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
description: Previously recorded $2,740,154.05

title: Betting That a Suburb Wants a Taste of the City
description: NAPERVILLE, Ill.  One of the Chicago areas richest men, John P. Calamos Sr. of Calamos Investments, is making an ambitious attempt to gain a foothold in the world of commercial real estate by building a 1.2-million-square-foot development in this western suburb of Chicago.

title: The Uptowning of the Lower East Side
description: SOMETIMES life happens in reverse. At least it did for Neil Ferguson, a chef whose move to his current restaurant from his previous one seems like some sort of cosmic snafu, like a perversion of the correct chronology.

title: Trial of Cholesterol Drug Gets House Scrutiny
description: A Congressional committee is investigating Merck and Schering-Plough for their handling of a critical clinical trial of Zetia, their blockbuster cholesterol-lowering drug.

title: Venezuela and Guyana to Improve Alerts After Border Incursion
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Guyana and Venezuela agreed on Tuesday to establish ways to prevent Venezuelan military activities in Guyanese territory, after reports that Venezuelan soldiers had entered Guyana in November and destroyed two gold-mining dredges.

title: Recipe: Foie Gras With Baked Quince
description: 1 tablespoon Champagne vinegar

title: Glide, Swoosh, Splat: Mexico Tries Out an Ice-Skating Rink
description: MEXICO CITY  Ice-skating ranks low on the list of sports in Mexico, somewhere far below bullfighting and slightly above croquet. So it was with some bemusement, wonder and trepidation that residents of this capital have been flocking this month to an enormous ice rink that Mayor Marcelo Ebrard has constructed in the historic central square.

title: Lottery Numbers
Recipe: Kumquat-Clementine Cordial
description: Time: 10 minutes, plus one weeks macerating

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an Agence France-Presse report in the Arts, Briefly column on Tuesday about the next music director of the Vienna Opera, Franz Welser-Mst, misstated the most recent action with regard to his appointment. He signed his contract on Sunday; he was not named to the post (that occurred in June). The report also misidentified the man Mr. Welser-Mst is succeeding. He is Seiji Ozawa, not Ioan Holender. (Mr. Holender, the general director of the opera, will be succeeded by Dominique Meyer.)

title: Nets Dangle $10 Ticket Lure, but Fans Dont Bite
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Four young men formed a line at the turnstiles inside the Izod Center about two hours before the Nets game Tuesday night against the Los Angeles Clippers.

title: Support for the Arts in New York
description: To the Editor:

title: Politics, Putin-Style
description: The Soviet-style guessing game over Russias presidential succession seemed all but decided this week when President Vladimir Putin endorsed the candidacy of his loyal protg, Dmitri Medvedev, and then Mr. Medvedev announced that, once elected, he would appoint Mr. Putin to be his prime minister.

title: Calendar
description: Holiday Markets

title: At the Heart of Truffles, Adaptable Ganache
description: IF the word ganache intimidates you, you are not alone. Maybe if the stuff were called basic, simple and entirely superior chocolate sauce, more people would make it.

title: China Agrees to Post U.S. Safety Officials in Its Food Factories
description: XIANGHE, China  China and the United States, seeking to ease the furor over the safety of food exports, signed an agreement Tuesday calling for a greater American role in certifying and inspecting Chinese food products, including an increased presence of American officials at Chinese production plants.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Sunday about a 100-year-old Zen master in New Mexico misspelled the name for a Zen meditation hall. It is zendo, not zenda.

title: Twin Bombs Kill Dozens in Algiers
description: ALGIERS  Twin car bombs near United Nations offices and an Algerian government building killed dozens of people Tuesday in what may have been the deadliest attack here in more than a decade.

title: Surveillance Court Declines to Release Secret Opinions
description: WASHINGTON  In a rare publicly issued opinion, the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court said Tuesday that it would not release documents related to the National Security Agencys program of wiretapping without warrants.

title: System Failed Young Rape Victim
description: Heads began to roll as outrage and disbelief continued to spread across Australia over the decision of a local judge, Sarah Bradley, left, to allow nine Aborigines who pleaded guilty to the gang rape of a 10-year-old Aboriginal girl last year to walk free from a court in Queensland. Officials acknowledged that girl had been raped before, in 2002, when she was 7, by several juveniles who did not face court, in the Aboriginal community of Aurukun, where she lived. She was then sent to live with a non-indigenous foster family in Cairns before being returned to Aurukun in April 2006, where she was gang-raped a second time. One welfare officer responsible for sending the girl back has been fired and two others have been suspended, said the Queensland premier, Anna Maria Bligh. The system clearly failed this little girl, she said. Local reports said the state had asked the prosecutor in the gang rape case to stand aside after a court transcript disclosed that he had characterized it as consensual sex. Calls grew for the removal of Judge Bradley, who said the girl had probably agreed to sex. The girl, now 12, is with another foster care family.

title: Recent Arrival at Citi Now Runs It
description: Vikram S. Pandit joined Citigroup six months ago to oversee one part of the giant bank. Now, he confronts a far more daunting task: shoring up the entire company, which has been pummeled by the mortgage crisis and the recent turmoil in the credit markets.

title: Credit Crisis Prompts Fed to Roll Back Rates Again
description: The Federal Reserve cut its benchmark short-term interest rate Tuesday by a quarter of a percentage point, to 4.25 percent, and suggested that it would lower rates again if the credit crisis continued to damage not just housing, but the rest of the economy as well.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A jazz entry in the Listings pages of Weekend on Friday about the Jim Hall Trio, at the Village Vanguard this week through Sunday, misidentified the sidemen who are playing with him. The bassist and drummer are Scott Colley and Lewis Nash  not Steve LaSpina and Terry Clarke, who also play with Mr. Hall.

title: In India, a Rare School Shooting Leaves 14-Year-Old Dead
description: NEW DELHI  A simmering feud among a group of eighth graders exploded Tuesday in an upscale suburb south of this capital city in a rare school shooting that killed one student.

title: Colorado: Gunman Killed Himself
description: The gunman who killed four people in two church-related attacks on Sunday committed suicide after being shot multiple times by a volunteer security guard at a church in Colorado Springs, the El Paso County coroner said. The man, Matthew Murray, 24, was confronted by the guard, Jeanne Assam, a former police officer and member of the New Life Church, as he entered the building. He fired a single bullet into himself as he lay wounded, the corner said. Mr. Murray killed two people early Sunday at a missionary training center near Denver and had just killed two teenage sisters in the parking lot at New Life, about 12 hours later, before facing Ms. Assam.

title: New Jersey to Reconsider Paid Leaves
description: WOODBRIDGE, N.J.  Bowing to pressure from business leaders in New Jersey, Gov. Jon S. Corzine and the states top two legislators promised on Tuesday to scale back to 6 weeks from 10 a proposal that would give employees the right to take paid family leave to care for a newborn or a sick relative.

title: After a Window Washers 47-Floor Plunge, the Big Question Is: How Did He Survive?
description: A 29-year-old man plunges 17 stories in the atrium of a hotel in Minneapolis, landing on an overhang.

title: Wait Until 2010, Nets Say of New Brooklyn Arena
description: The Nets, who had hoped to move into a new arena near downtown Brooklyn in time for the 2009-10 season, have acknowledged that construction will not be finished until sometime in 2010.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: The Personal Health column on Tuesday, about the mental reserves that might help ward off symptoms of dementia, misstated the name of the medical center with which two researchers who study the issue are affiliated. Dr. Nikolaos Scarmeas and Yaakov Stern are at Columbia University Medical Center, not Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. (The name was changed in 2003.)

title: Thomass Courtside Monologue Was Search for Sixth Man
description: Mara Altschulers courtside tickets to Knicks games have been in her family for more than 40 years, offering her a ringside seat to listen in on coaches from Red Holzman, Hubie Brown and Don Nelson to Rick Pitino, Pat Riley and Larry Brown.

title: S.E.C. Planning to Delay Accounting Rules for Small Companies
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission plans to delay for another year the requirement that small companies report on the state of their internal financial controls, the agencys chairman, Christopher Cox, is expected to tell lawmakers on Wednesday.

title: First Israeli Resolution Accepted
description: A committee of the General Assembly for the first time passed an Israeli resolution, one dealing not with the Middle East conflict but proposing that developed countries make their agricultural know-how more available. The measure attracted 118 votes, and Dan Gillerman, the Israeli ambassador, said, It is not easy for Israel to garner so many votes, to have its resolution and its point of view adopted, but today it happened.

title: A Las Vegas Gym Faces a Ladies Night Bias Case
description: LAS VEGAS  During a tour of a Las Vegas Athletic Club gym, a prospective member, Todd Phillips, was struck by the fact that his wife was offered a cheaper sign-up rate than he was and that there was a special workout area for women.

title: The Led List
description: The set for Mondays Led Zeppelin reunion:

title: Guatemala: U.S. Adoptions to Go Through
description: Lawmakers endorsed an overhaul of the countrys adoption system, ending what critics called a largely unregulated business in which poor mothers were paid to turn over their children to American couples. The new law, pushed by the United States government, allows thousands of pending adoptions, most to Americans, to proceed. Guatemala sends more adopted children to the United States than any other country except China; this year it has sent 4,700. The new law also creates a government authority to handle future adoptions, bringing Guatemala in line with the Hague Convention on Intercountry Adoption and wresting the system away from lawyers who charge as much as $30,000 per child.

title: Steroid Report Expected to Cite About 50 Players
description: The headquarters for George J. Mitchells investigation into the use of performance-enhancing drugs in baseball has been the DLA Piper law offices in Midtown Manhattan, right next to Rockefeller Center and only blocks from the Park Avenue offices of Major League Baseball. On Tuesday, as Mitchells 20-month investigation drew to a conclusion, it was Major League Baseball that was on the move, as officials from the sport went to the DLA Piper offices to get a look at the report.

title: Checks and Balances for Our Spies
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction: For the Record
description: The Well column in Science Times on Dec. 4, about Heather Kuzmich, a former contestant on Americas Next Top Model who has Aspergers Syndrome, misidentified the city in which she got lost in one episode. It was Shanghai, not Beijing.

title: Weapons of War at the Mall and Church
description: Barely touched on in the coverage of the two latest gun rampages is how the disturbed shooters could so easily obtain assault rifles  weapons designed for waging war. In separate random massacres, eight people were slain at an Omaha shopping mall last Wednesday and four were more shot dead Sunday at two Colorado churches. The Omaha killer took his stepfathers rapid-fire rifle from a closet to pick off Christmas shoppers. In Colorado, the gunman, leaving behind an Internet screed referenced to the 1999 Columbine massacre, was equipped with two assault rifles, three handguns and 1,000 rounds of ammunition.

title: Bill and Hillary Clintons Pitch in Iowa: I Love the 90s
description: Grinnell, Iowa

title: Honors for Woods
description: Tiger Woods swept the three biggest annual awards for the seventh time. He received the Jack Nicklaus Trophy for player of the year, the Arnold Palmer award for leading the money list ($10.8 million) and the Byron Nelson award for lowest-scoring average (67.79). Jay Haas was voted Champions Tour player of the year, and Nick Flanagan won the Nationwide award. The other PGA Tour awards went to Steve Stricker, the first player to win comeback player of the year in consecutive seasons, and Brandt Snedeker, who was the rookie of the year.

title: Some Used Football Helmets Under Scrutiny
description: More than 200,000 amateur football players in the United States wore used helmets this fall that were returned to the field without proper testing, and the F.B.I. is investigating.

title: Bubbly Enthusiasm, Personified
description: THE names Champagne. Ros Champagne.

title: At Bronx Court, Elevator Woes Slow Justice
description: There are many longstanding, seemingly intractable shortcomings in the citys family court system that might delay a parent in getting a child back from foster care: unprepared lawyers, overcrowded dockets and long waiting lists for drug treatment and mental health services.

title: For a Single Mother, Mr. Claus Is Mr. Right
description: In The Perfect Holiday Nancy (Gabrielle Union), a divorced mother of two boys and a girl, glumly faces Christmas in New Jersey without a man in her life. Rubbing salt in her wounds is her ex-husband, J-Jizzy (Charlie Murphy), a preening rap star with whom she is locked in a custody battle. Swathed in chinchilla, he is stymied on his current project, a Christmas album that includes gems like I Love the Ho Ho Hos.

title: Text of the Fed Statement
description: Following is the text of a statement released by the Federal Reserve on Tuesday after the Feds monetary policy panel, the Federal Open Market Committee, decided to lower interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point:

title: Recent Arrival at Citi Now Runs It
description: Vikram S. Pandit joined Citigroup six months ago to oversee one part of the giant bank. Now, he confronts a far more daunting task: shoring up the entire company, which has been pummeled by the mortgage crisis and the recent turmoil in the credit markets.

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening This Week

title: Deaths From Icy Weather Rise to 20 in Central States
description: CHICAGO  A surge of moist and shallow arctic air swept through the central Plains states and Midwest on Tuesday, dropping freezing rain and snow. The storm knocked out power to hundreds of thousands of homes and businesses, closed schools and compounded the hazardous conditions that have left at least 20 people dead since the weekend.

title: Humane Society Traces Expensive Pups to Pet Mills
description: LOS ANGELES  A pet store in the Bel-Air neighborhood deceived customers, including Hollywood celebrities, about the origin of their puppies, many of which come from unlicensed pet mills, according to a Humane Society of the United States investigation released Tuesday.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a sports article on Tuesday about the Giants development into a solid, if unspectacular, team misstated their potential for playing at home in the postseason. They could do so if they are the top wild-card team in the National Football Conference championship game and face the second wild-card team; they would not necessarily play all of their postseason games on the road.

title: Rare Look Inside Baghdad Museum
description: BAGHDAD  For a few brief hours Tuesday, three dozen spectators  journalists, local politicians and their guards  gathered at the National Museum of Iraq here, their voices echoing through its vast, darkened halls. It was one of the few times outsiders had been allowed inside since Baghdad fell, looters stripped the galleries of some 15,000 Mesopotamian artifacts, and the museum became a wrenching symbol of the losses of the war.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An Associated Press report in the N.B.A. roundup in some editions on Friday about the Knicks status as the leagues most valuable franchise misstated a Forbes magazine assessment of the clubs worth. It is $608 million, not $604 million.

title: A New Chapter in the Tale of the Dinnertime Bandit
description: STAMFORD, Conn.  The dinnertime bandit shuffled in just before lunch.

title: Stop! In the Name of Liebestod: Wagner Meets Pop
description: Shoppa loppa shoop shoop. Hes sure the boy for me. Funny, it doesnt sound much like Wagner, does it?

title: Strike Touches a Ritual for Wooing
description: UNLESS something happens quickly to restart stalled talks between entertainment producers and the Writers Guild of America, one of the oldest rituals of the television business, the May network upfront presentation, is likely to fold its tent, possibly forever.

title: Seeking Leaders, U.S. Companies Think Globally
description: The corner offices of corporate America are increasingly being filled from every corner of the world.

title: From China, Only in a Bottle, a Berry With an Alluring Name
description: YUMBERRY sounds more like the creation of an advertising agency than of nature  like Cherry Garcia or Juicy Fruit. But while the name was dreamed up a few years ago to help sell the fruits juice, which is just now appearing in stores around the country, the fruit has been grown for 2,000 years in China. Its so popular there that about twice as many acres are devoted to growing it as the number devoted to apple orchards in the United States.

title: C.I.A. Chief Admits Failure to Inform Congress
description: WASHINGTON  Gen. Michael V. Hayden, the director of the Central Intelligence Agency, acknowledged Wednesday that the C.I.A. had failed to keep members of Congress fully informed of the facts that the agency had videotaped the interrogations of Al Qaeda detainees and destroyed the tapes three years later.

title: The Eccentricities of Iowa
description: Come caucus night in Iowa, some unknown number of voters will show up in their neighbors living room, or in a church basement, a VFW hall or a school auditorium to show support for a candidate. On their way in, they might stop and let one of the 160 entrance poll takers who work for the television networks and the Associated Press know who they are going to support and why. But once they get inside  especially if they are at a Democratic party event where people have to publicly state their preference  they could be persuaded to change their mind. If their first choice candidate doesnt get 15 percent of the vote, they will have to change their mind.

title: Canadian Government Seeks to Reopen Medical Reactor
description: OTTAWA  Overriding the safety concerns of its regulator, the Canadian government is rushing through legislation to reopen a nuclear reactor that produces most of the worlds supply of an important diagnostic isotope.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,878 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Monday:

title: Petrino Quits the Falcons to Coach the Razorbacks
description: A miserable year for the Atlanta Falcons took a stunning turn Tuesday night with the resignation of Coach Bobby Petrino, who left Louisville less than a year ago to take what he called the best job in the N.F.L.

title: A Film Producer Guided More by His Heart Than by His Calculator
description: LOS ANGELES  Talk to Me, a sharp-tongued urban bio-pic, fell on deaf ears at the box office. The British farce Death at a Funeral staggered through American theaters. Lars and the Real Girl, that love story involving a life-size sex doll? Lets just say it, um, deflated on arrival.

title: Sounds of the New, Arrayed to Enliven a Nordic Night
description: Composers from the north put their exports in the hands of Americans on Monday night. Speculum Musicae, the New York new-music group, played pieces by the Finnish composers Kaija Saariaho and Magnus Lindberg, and by two Danes, Bent Sorensen and Poul Ruders. The small auditorium in the basement of Scandinavia House on Park Avenue was as appropriate a place as any.

title: The Capital of Slumping Home Sales
description: Just south of Los Angeles, there is a small city called Paramount where houses have all but stopped selling.

title: Bankers Face Grim Truth: Worst Is Yet to Come
description: AS the credit crisis sweeps wildly through Wall Street, major investment banks face a grim truth about their already-slumping profits: the worst is yet to come.

title: Dinner Theater Served With Odd Conversations
description: Its not easy, on a Saturday night in this maddening city, to feel that you have landed exactly where you want to be, and even, perhaps, where you need to be. But No Dice, performed by the Nature Theater of Oklahoma and commissioned by Soho Rep, is that rare, wondrous type of theatrical sustenance: You leave blissful and sated, yet wanting more.

title: Student Lender to Stop Using College and Team Names in Marketing
description: A student lender that paid students as much as $50 for referring classmates for loans and paid dozens of universities to use the institutions names, athletic team names, logos and mascots on advertising material sent to student borrowers has agreed to stop these marketing tactics, the New York attorney general announced Tuesday.

title: Trial Witness Said to Cast Doubt on Part of Testimony
description: A principal witness in the stock-options backdating trial that ended in a conviction of Gregory L. Reyes, the chief executive of Brocade Communications Systems Inc., has told associates her testimony may have been untrue, according to court documents.

title: Judge Backs California Rules on Greenhouse Gases
description: WASHINGTON  A federal judge in Sacramento on Wednesday upheld a California law regulating greenhouse gas emissions from cars and trucks, another in a string of legal defeats for the auto industry this year.

title: Welless Kane Oscar No Rosebud
description: The Oscar statue awarded to Orson Welles for the best original screenplay of 1941 for Citizen Kane, left, did not attract a bidder and failed to sell on Tuesday at auction at Sothebys in New York, Bloomberg News reported. The Academy Award statue, its finish worn from years of handling, had been expected to fetch $800,000 to $1.2 million for its seller, the Dax Foundation, a Los Angeles charity that had planned to use the proceeds for philanthropy. However, a 1940 copy of Welless 156-page script for Citizen Kane, carrying a presale estimate of $120,000, sold for $97,000, including fees, to an unidentified telephone bidder. The seller was a private collector whom the auction house declined to identify. Welles co-wrote, directed and starred in Citizen Kane, his first film, and was also nominated for Academy Awards for best director and best actor in the title role. He won only the prize for screenwriting, which he shared with Herman L. Mankiewicz. In 1982 Sothebys sold Rosebud, the sled that figured significantly in the story, for $60,000.

title: What You Get for ...$1.6 Million
description: Gatlinburg, Tenn.

title: Rights Group Says Egypt Used Torture in Terror Case
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  An American human rights group issued a report on Tuesday accusing the Egyptian government of using torture and false confessions in a recent high-profile terrorism case.

title: Remaking The Journal
description: In the last few months, Rupert Murdoch has moved into an office at Dow Jones & Company, publisher of The Wall Street Journal. He has pushed the papers editors for shorter articles and more hard news. He has personally wooed reporters he wants to keep out of his competitors hands.

title: Mexico: Cannibal Suspect Found Hanged
description: A 38-year-old man accused of killing a girlfriend and eating parts of her body was found dead in his cell in Mexico City, apparently a suicide, prison officials said. Guards found the man, Jos Luis Calva Zepeda, hanging by his belt. He was arrested in October when the police discovered the dismembered body of his girlfriend in his apartment and human flesh in a frying pan.

title: Journeyman Scuttles NBCs Night
description: A two-hour edition of Deal or No Deal put NBC on top of the ratings for much of Monday night, but a low-rated episode of Journeyman at 10 p.m. meant the network earned a second-place finish over all. CBS ranked first for the night, thanks largely to CSI: Miami, the nights top rated show, which dominated the 10 p.m. hour with 14.1 million viewers, Nielsen estimated. By comparison, NBCs Deal or No Deal averaged 12.7 million while leading the 8-to-10 p.m. time slots. Journeyman, however, drew just 5.6 million. CBS remained solidly in second place earlier in the night even though its 9 p.m. comedies were in repeat. CBSs 8 p.m. comedies, How I Met Your Mother (8.4 million) and The Big Bang Theory (7.5 million), finished roughly even with ABCs special in the hour, I Want a Dog for Christmas, Charlie Brown! (7.8 million). ABC tied Fox for third over all, getting little help in the ratings from October Road at 10 (5.2 million) or from its 9 p.m. comedies, Samantha Who? (6.7 million) followed by Notes From the Underbelly (4.6 million).

title: House Votes to Raise Pilot Retirement Age
description: The House voted unanimously to extend the retirement age for commercial pilots to 65, changing a 1960 Federal Aviation Administration regulation forcing pilots to leave the cockpit at age 60. The bill, if approved by the Senate, would put the retirement age in line with international standards. The International Civil Aviation Organization adopted a retirement age of 65 in November 2006. The House measure would require pilots ages 60 and above to have a medical certificate renewed every six months and to take a flight test known as a line check every six months.

title: Stolen Statues Anger Indonesian Lawmaker
description: More than 100 ancient artifacts, including ancestral statues, have been stolen from Central Sulawesi province in Indonesia and are being sold at galleries on Bali, an Indonesian legislator said on Tuesday, Agence France-Presse reported. These various artifacts have been stolen from the Lore Lindu plateau since 2000, and we have seen ourselves about 100 of them being offered for sale in galleries in Bali, said Asmir Podungge, a lawmaker from the Poso district. They were sold at high prices, including one stone ancestor statue known as Batu Nongko, which is said to have been sold for five billion rupiah, or $537,000. Mr. Podungge said that the district parliament had alerted the local authorities but that they seemed to not be too excited about this. The Lore Lindu plateau holds many megalithic remains, including huge boulders carved into ancestral figures, stone burial jars, plates and game boards, whose origins remain unclear. Mr. Podungges complaints followed the arrest of four people on Java, Indonesias main island, in connection with the theft of five ancient statues from a museum in the historic city of Surakarta. A routine inspection of the Radya Pustaka museum found that the works had been stolen and replaced by fakes. The police found them in the home of a prominent businessman in Jakarta.

Mr. Trebek became the host of Jeopardy! in 1984, when he replaced Art Fleming, and has won two Emmy Awards for his role.

title: Elliott Carter at 99
description: Now heres a way to celebrate your birthday: Gather hundreds of affectionate fans in a theater, sit as they watch a rare performance of your only opera and bathe in their applause.So it was for the Elliott Carter, who turned 99 on Tuesday and is one of the most eminent living composers. He was attending the final showing in a run of his opera What Next? The work, a sort of musical Waiting for Godot with six singers, was being staged for the first time in New York, Mr. Carters city of origin and his home for many years.The opera is just 40 minutes long, and occupied the second half of the program, which took place at the Miller Theater. The first half consisted of Carter chamber works, ranging from an unaccompanied violin solo to a six-member ensemble.At intermission, a stream of people came up to Mr. Carter, who was seated in an aisle seat in the third row. Many wished him a happy birthday. He signed a compact disc of his music. He accepted an organic chocolate bar from a female admirer, and took a bite. He greeted each person amiably, sometimes leaning forward to hear better.Seated around him were his friends and supporters in the music world, including the bass clarinetist Virgil Blackwell, a musical collaborator and close friend. Charles Rosen, the pianist and scholar who recently wrote about his connection to Mr. Carter in The New York Times, was there. So were other musical satraps, including Joseph Polisi, the president of the Juilliard School, and Ara Guzelimian, the schools dean and a former administrator of Carnegie Hall.After the opera performance, the cast took its bows in a row on the stage. The conductor, Jeffrey Milarsky, a busy specialist in contemporary music, was up there too. Then he gestured for the audience to rise, which it did, and the whole house began singing Happy Birthday to Mr. Carter, who approached the stage, turned and waved to the audience and clapped one hand against the other, which was holding a cane. He had a big smile on his face. Many people cheered.

title: Clintons Gore Moment
description: The big question you hear right now if you cover politics for a living  and thus no one thinks youre really good for talking about more interesting things, like, say, the celebrity version of The Apprentice  is just whats happening to Hillary Rodham Clinton. A month ago Washington had moved on to speculating about her running mate (my guess if she wins Iowa: Tom Vilsack); now shes in a three-way tie in Iowa and losing her lead in New Hampshire faster than Mitt Romney changes positions. Is she seriously in danger of coming undone? Is she still in command of the race? There is an appropriately Clintonian way to answer these questions, which is yes to both.The first presidential campaign I covered was Bill Bradleys 2000 run against Al Gore. (I met my wife on that campaign, so it wasnt a total loss.) People forget this now, but there was a moment, at about this time in 1999, when Mr. Bradley came stunningly close to stealing the Democratic nomination. Mr. Gore was a sitting vice president, with all of the institutional support in the party, as well as the labor unions and the interest groups and the big-money bundlers and the bulletproof limo and, of course, the prosperity and relative peace of the Clinton years at his back. And yet here was Mr. Bradley, three years removed from his last public office, surging to a lead in New Hampshire and gaining so much ground in Iowa, a state in which he hadnt even planned to compete, that his campaign decided to send dozens of staff there. (It was, in retrospect, a huge tactical blunder, but Iowa is like that, tantalizingly within reach one minute and 56,000 square miles of pure quicksand the next.) In those tense weeks, you could almost hear the monstrous machinery of the Democratic establishment squeak as it teetered away from Gore.

title: Reading Room
description: Somehow, around 5 tonight, I ended up on Fifth Avenue, in the thick of holiday shoppers. I saw a man carrying a large cream Jimmy Choo bag, his fingertips lightly extended as though it were a basket of eggs; whatever was in the box, it had cost him enough to feel proud and, I suppose, pleased with himself. All those crisp, pleated shopping bags and the sense of having bought something special for someone, or at least having made a decisionit throbbed along the avenue. I was armed myself, with a large silvery white book, appropriately called Be Dazzled! Norman Hartnell. The 268-page book (Pointed Leaf Press) had come into my office, among others, and as I cracked it open, out came, it seemed, the froth of the British Empire. Its a stunning book, full of information and surprise. Bill Cunningham, as cheery as Santa Claus, stopped by my desk and immediately took notice. He was at his best for the Queen Mother, Billy said of Hartnell, who began making clothes in the 1920s and died in 1979 (with few material possessions, apparently).

title: Arctic Update: Resilient Bears, Shrinking Ice
description: The warming Arctic is again making news, with a heap of findings unveiled at the fall meeting of the American Geophysical Union in San Francisco. Theres new evidence that polar bears have squeaked through past Arctic warm spells. And there are fresh findings on why the sea ice around the North Pole has seen dramatic summer retreats lately. Thats a subject dear to my heart ever since I got to spend three days with a climate team near the North Pole.Bear Facts[UPDATED below, 12/13]The BBC reported Monday on the discovery in Norways Svalbard archipelago of a polar bear jawbone that appears to be at least 110,000 years old. This is significant because it could confirm genetic hints that the species has lived through at least a couple of protracted warm spells in which Arctic temperatures were likely several degrees warmer than at present. (Polar bear remains are rare because they spend so much time patrolling far from land.) The bone was discovered by Olafur Ingolfsson of the University of Iceland.
