Negotiators for the building owners say that the workers are already the nations highest paid and that the industry could be hurt by the shaky economy.

title: A Great Pretender in Great Demand
description: Well, you can tell by the way Brian Bergdoll walks, hes a womans man, no time to talk. Also, in this particular instance, he was very late.

title: Survey Points to Tensions Among Chief Minorities
description: Distrust and racial tension among Hispanics, Asians and blacks in the United States are pressing concerns for all three groups, a new national poll conducted in English, Spanish and five Asian languages has found.

title: Who Invited the Dog?
description: IT was a dark and stormy night  actually four stormy nights  when Jayme Otto, 31, and her husband, Ryan Otto, 33, drove 1,200 miles from their home in Boulder, Colo., to her parents house in Cleveland for Christmas.

title: Blue Dog Democrats Try to Keep Pay-as-You-Go Promise
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Dennis Moore of Kansas held up a photo of his eight grandchildren on Wednesday and promised not to saddle them with any more debt.

title: Central Bankers to Lend Billions in Credit Crisis
description: A day after the Federal Reserve disappointed investors with a modest cut in interest rates, central banks in North America and Europe on Wednesday announced the most aggressive infusion of capital into the banking system since the terrorist attacks of September 2001.

title: Focus of Climate Talks Shifts to Helping Poor Countries Cope
description: NUSA DUA, Indonesia  With little progress on the primary goal of United Nations climate talks here  preventing further climate change  a secondary quest to help poor countries cope with the effects of a warming world has now become a central theme of the gathering.

title: Cane Hobbles CBS
description: Back-to-back episodes of Cane, with Jimmy Smits, below, dragged CBS down to a fourth-place finish in the ratings on Tuesday among adults 18 to 49. NBC led the night over all, thanks mainly to its weight-loss competition, The Biggest Loser, which delivered the nights best results in that demographic and 9.8 million total viewers, Nielsen estimated. NBC also got a boost at 8 from Deal or No Deal (11.3 million), although CBSs NCIS rerun led that time slot with the largest audience (11.8 million). CBS ranked second for the night in total viewers, but fourth in the 18-to-49 set, as its two episodes of Cane at 9 (8 million) and 10 (7.8 million) continued to fare poorly in that age group. ABC was third over all, leading the 10 p.m. hour with Boston Legal (9 million). In the 8 p.m. hour, ABC broadcast two animated specials, an encore showing of Shrek the Halls (10 million) followed by A Winnie the Pooh Christmas (8.5 million). Repeats on Fox put that network in fourth place in total viewers, but second in the 18-to-49 group.

title: Extra Spacewalk for Astronauts on Space Station
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13  American astronauts aboard the International Space Station said Thursday that they will perform an extra spacewalk next week to examine a malfunctioning joint that turns a set of solar power panels.

title: Groban No. 1 for Third Week
description: Josh Groban has tied Elvis Presley for the most consecutive weeks on the top of the Billboard chart for a Christmas album. His Nol (Reprise) is at No. 1 for the third week in a row, selling 581,000 copies in the week that ended on Sunday, an 8 percent increase over the previous week, Nielsen SoundScan reported. Total sales for Nol are 2.1 million. The only new album in the Top 10 this week is Audio Day Dream (Arista) by the American Idol runner-up Blake Lewis, which opens at No. 10 with 98,000 sales. Otherwise, the Top 10 is a slight reshuffling of familiar recent hits: Alicia Keys is No. 2, the Eagles No. 3, the compilation Now Thats What I Call Music! Vol. 26 is No. 4, Hannah Montana 2/Meet Miley Cyrus (Disney) is No. 5, the High School Musical 2 soundtrack is No. 6, Carrie Underwood No. 7, Garth Brooks No. 8 and Taylor Swift No. 9.

title: Freddie Fields, Hollywood Talent Agent, Dies at 84
description: Freddie Fields, a retired Hollywood producer, studio executive and agent who helped found Creative Management Associates, one of the industrys most influential talent agencies in the 1960s and early 70s, died on Tuesday at his home in Beverly Hills. He was 84.

title: 3 Big Banks See No Relief as Write-Offs Mount Up
description: The Bank of America Corporation, the Wachovia Corporation and PNC Financial Services Group said on Wednesday that losses tied to bad debt would be worse than expected, the latest indication that the credit markets are not returning to normal.

title: As Woods Enters Prime, Time Is on His Side
description: THOUSAND OAKS, Calif.  The face of the man is still boyish, unlined and smooth, with no hints of age around the eyes or cruelty at the corners of the mouth. The famous smile is quick and ready to light up any room. On this day, as with most, it is a room with a view  of the golden foothills of the Santa Monica Mountains, dotted with mansions above the impossibly manicured Sherwood Country Club, where Tiger Woods will end his 2007 season this week by playing host to the Target World Challenge.

title: Parasites in Fish Farms Threaten Salmon, Researchers Say
description: Parasites that breed in fish farms kill so many juvenile wild salmon that they threaten the survival of fish populations in some rivers and streams, Canadian researchers are reporting.

title: Swiss Parliament Deals Setback to Leader of Far-Right Party
description: GENEVA  Less than two months after the controversial justice minister, Christoph Blocher, led the far-right Swiss Peoples Party to a comfortable election victory, parliamentarians ejected him from the Federal Council, which runs the government by consensus.

title: Birthday Greetings for Elliott Carter at 99
description: Now heres a way to celebrate your birthday: Gather hundreds of affectionate fans in a theater, sit as they watch a rare performance of your only opera, and bathe in their applause. So it was for the composer Elliott Carter right, who turned 99 on Tuesday. He was attending the final showing in a run of his opera, What Next?, at the Miller Theater. The work was being staged for the first time in New York. The first half of the concert consisted of chamber music by Mr. Carter, followed by the opera after the intermission. During the break a stream of people came up to him. Many wished him a happy birthday. He signed a CD of his music. He accepted an organic chocolate bar from a female admirer, and took a bite. After the opera performance and bows by the cast members, they joined with the audience in round of Happy Birthday.

title: Kasparov Says He Was Forced to End Bid for Presidency
description: MOSCOW  Garry Kasparov, the opposition leader and former chess champion, said Wednesday that he had been forced to withdraw his candidacy for president of Russia because his political movement had been unable to rent a hall in Moscow for a nominating convention, a requirement under Russian law.

title: Rosanne Cash Is Recovering
description: The singer and songwriter Rosanne Cash was reported to be recovering at her New York home after brain surgery last month at New York-Presbyterian Hospital to correct what was called a rare but benign condition. Her record label, Manhattan Records, deemed the surgery successful. It added that Ms. Cash, 52, a Grammy Award winner and the eldest of the five children of Johnny Cash, is expected to resume recording her debut album for Manhattan in the spring. She also plans live performances and a book to be published by Viking early in 2009.

title: Carried Away With Imitation Luxury
description: LOOK sharp! Waving a passer-by to his cart at Madison Avenue and 67th Street, Omar, the vendor, pointed to the logo on one of his most popular items, a canvas tote bag patterned in a familiar-looking interlocking chevron. This one is the wrong writing, he murmured.

title: For Los Angeles Museum, a Transformative Gift of Modernists
description: LOS ANGELES  The Los Angeles County Museum of Art announced Wednesday that it had been promised a gift of 130 mostly Modernist works, including 20 by Picasso, a group of 21 watercolors and paintings by Paul Klee and Wassily Kandinsky and sculptures by Alberto Giacometti. The museum described the gift as a transformative addition to its collection that in many cases represents Lacmas first major work by that artist.

title: Canada: Mounties Urged to Restrict Taser Use
description: In a report, the watchdog commission that oversees the Royal Canadian Mounted Police recommended that Taser stun guns be used only on people who are combative or posing a risk of death or grievous bodily harm, much like a conventional firearm rather than a nightstick or pepper spray. The report was ordered by the government after a confused and angry Polish immigrant, Robert Dziekanski, left, died at the airport in Vancouver after being stunned at least twice by Mounties. The report found that Tasers were increasingly being used against people who were merely resistant rather than dangerous.

title: Express Track to a Fare Increase
description: Next week, the board of the state Metropolitan Transportation Authority is scheduled to vote on raising tolls and fares for mass transit. But the real decision seems to have been made already. Gov. Eliot Spitzer, who wants the increase and approves the appointments of board members, won the support of Mayor Michael Bloomberg, who controls 4 of the boards 14 members. It is unlikely that the board, really independent in name only, would defy them.

title: Many Paths but One Goal
description: JUST as varieties of yoga exist, so do styles of facial acupuncture, each with a different emphasis.

title: A Chapter of Jackass as Web Test
description: LOS ANGELES  Paramount Pictures is lurching onto the Web with its Jackass franchise, with what it says will be the first studio-backed feature film to have its premiere online. And the studio hopes the result will be considerably more pleasurable than the old MTV shows trademark shot to the groin  perhaps by paving the way for more profit-making Web-only material.

title: Postpartum Impression
description: PARIS

title: Smithsonian Money Woes
description: Addressing maintenance and security expenses at the Smithsonian, representatives of that institution and the Government Accountability Office testified before a Senate committee Wednesday about its financial challenges. The government estimated that the Smithsonian would have $2.5 billion in unmet maintenance and security needs through 2013, including deferred projects. That amount did not account for structural problems at its 1881 flagship Arts and Industries building, which has been closed and empty since January 2004. Cristin Samper, above, acting secretary of the Smithsonian, said $100 million is needed to repair the roof and other parts of that building, while another $100 million is needed to update and maintain its collection. Further, he said, about $400 million is needed for the planned National Museum of African American History and Culture. Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California and chairwoman of the Senate committee, said she and appropriations subcommittees are working toward creating a $45 million public and private matching program for maintenance and revitalization projects at the Smithsonian. If established, the fund would appropriate $15 million in matching federal money once the Smithsonian raises $30 million in private funds.

title: Fames Demands, and the Flights of Fancy to Escape
description: Alvin Ailey had a love-hate relationship with fame. He began his career in dance as a take-charge young artist whose performing and fledgling choreography were fueled more by apparent self-confidence than by deep knowledge of the art form. He had started under the tutelage of Lester Horton, a charismatic dance mentor in Los Angeles, where Ailey grew up. But Horton died, in 1953, too soon to give the would-be dancer much sense of continuity and tradition. Ailey left for New York in 1954 and never stopped, achieving what passes for acclaim in the humble world of dance. That was a burden he both accepted and felt oppressed by. And he eventually identified with artists for whom fame became notoriety.

title: Drive Maker in China to Be Sold to Iomega
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Iomega, an American distributor of computer data storage equipment, said Wednesday that it was entering into a complex $310 million deal to acquire ExcelStor, a Chinese contract maker of disk drives.

title: Little Headway With China on Finance
description: XIANGHE  China and the United States ended three days of intense economic talks on Thursday with new accords on food safety, energy and environmental cooperation but making what Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. conceded was only modest progress in opening Chinas financial markets.

title: Fever Promotes Assistant
description: The Indiana Fever hired the assistant Lin Dunn to replace Coach Brian Winters on Wednesday. Dunn, who spent four seasons as a Fever assistant coach, succeeds Winters, who was 78-58 in four seasons and guided the W.N.B.A. team to three playoff appearances. Winters was let go in October with a year left on his contract. Dunn will be the Fevers fourth coach in their eight-year history. Dunn went 33-63 as the coach and general manager of the expansion Seattle Storm from 1999-2002. With the Storm, she drafted Lauren Jackson, the eventual league most valuable player, and Sue Bird.

title: Determining Whether a Turbine Will Work
description: BEFORE buying a wind turbine, a homeowner should learn how much electricity he uses (utility companies can provide a usage history), and assess local wind speeds.

title: An Appeal for Calm After Suicide Bombings in Algeria
description: ALGIERS  A day after suicide terror attacks rocked Algerias capital, the countrys foreign minister urged calm on Wednesday, saying that the bombings did not portend civil war.

title: Lawyer Who Showed Producer Around Wants a Cut From The Sopranos
description: TRENTON  It is a tale of influence, of promises, favors and made men, not unlike an episode of The Sopranos.

title: A Voice to Guide You on the Road
description: G.P.S. didnt always stand for Global Positioning System, you know.

title: Power Loss From Storm Is Lingering
description: Hundreds of thousands of homes and businesses in the nations midsection remained without electricity on Wednesday after being hit by an ice storm that pulled down power lines, cracked tree limbs and closed schools, highways and airports.

title: China: Retail Sales Show Big Jump
description: Chinas retail sales increased at the quickest rate in at least eight years on rising incomes, helping government efforts to curb the economys dependence on exports and investment to achieve growth. Sales climbed 18.8 percent, to 810.5 billion yuan ($110 billion), in November from a year earlier, the statistics bureau said, after rising 18.1 percent in October. That was the biggest gain since 1999, according to Bloomberg data.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Birthday Greetings for Elliott Carter at 99

title: Adult Contemporarys Darling Shows Off His Range
description: Its easy to like the trumpeter Chris Botti. Its easy not to like him, too. Since the release of his first solo album in 1995, Mr. Botti has burnished an image of pensive romance, achieving stardom in the realm of adult-contemporary pop. His faintly jazz-inflected style  traceable to the Miles Davis of late-1950s vintage, around Porgy and Bess and Kind of Blue  luxuriates in melody and mood. Hes Sting-endorsed and Oprah-approved, with brooding looks that any camera seems to love.

title: Australia: Casino Chain Expands in Las Vegas
description: Australias largest casino company, Crown Ltd., said it agreed to buy Cannery Casino Resorts for $1.75 billion, expanding its business in Las Vegas. Cannery Casino, which is privately held, operates three Las Vegas casinos, including the Cannery Casino and Hotel and the Nevada Palace casino, and the Meadows Racetrack and Casino south of Pittsburgh. This month, Publishing and Broadcasting Ltd. split into separate listed companies, Crown and Consolidated Media Holdings Ltd. A private company led by James D. Packer, above, Consolidated Press Holdings Ltd., owns 38 percent of Crowns stock.

title: Durant: A Sweet Tooth and a Sweet Jumper
description: During the final minute of Seattles 117-110 victory over the Knicks Wednesday night at Madison Square Garden, the Seattle rookie Kevin Durant had the ball with a 4-point lead and drove the lane against two defenders to try to secure the victory.

title: Baseball Braces for Steroid Report From Mitchell
description: George J. Mitchells report on performance-enhancing drugs in baseball, to be unveiled Thursday afternoon, will be highly critical of the commissioners office and the players union for tolerating the presence of drugs throughout years of abuse, a person who has read the closely guarded report said Wednesday.

title: Still Life With Parties and Hedge Funds
description: Miami Beach

title: Selected Studies: Infertility in Women
description: Government agencies, universities and corporations frequently enroll patients in studies designed to test the effectiveness of new drugs, procedures and medical devices. Participants may benefit by gaining access to experimental therapies, and they make an important contribution to scientific research. For more information, please visit ClinicalTrials.gov, a service of the National Institutes of Health.

title: Britain: Microsoft Buys Map Service
description: Microsoft said it had agreed to acquire MultiMap, an online map service based in London, in an attempt to compete more effectively with the search services of Google and to collect more revenue from online and mobile advertising. The MultiMap Web site aids consumers in finding elusive addresses throughout Europe and the United States and in much of the rest of the world. It also offers services for business customers, allowing them to include maps on their Web sites. The acquisition, for an undisclosed amount, is part of a race by Microsoft and its competitors online to further develop their digital mapping abilities.

title: Hungry Caterpillar in the Florida Keys
description: LIKE the butterfly-to-be in his most famous book, The Very Hungry Caterpillar, Eric Carle is changing.

title: At a Yiddish Cabaret, Hope, Despair and Song
description: Across an emotional spectrum from saucy irreverence, high spirits and nostalgia to the bitterest despair and back to hope, Kleynkunst! revisits the little-known but vibrant Yiddish cabaret that flourished in Warsaw from the early 1920s until it disappeared by Nazi design in the ghetto of that city, where Jews in 1928 constituted 30 percent of the population.

title: Mideast Teams Begin Peace Talks
description: JERUSALEM  Israeli and Palestinian negotiators on Wednesday held their first meeting in what was supposed to begin a final peace process as envisioned by the American-sponsored conference in Annapolis, Md., last month, but the talks were marred by conflicting agendas and overshadowed by a sharp escalation of hostilities in and around the Gaza Strip.

title: Crossover Dreams: Turning Free Web Work Into Real Book Sales
description: Three years ago Diary of a Wimpy Kid, a childrens novel illustrated with cartoons, was published online, where anyone could read it free. To this day anyone still can, at Funbrain.com, an educational Web site.

title: Teenage Birth Rates
description: To the Editor:

title: C.I.A. Chief Cites Agency Lapse on Tapes
description: WASHINGTON  Gen. Michael V. Hayden, the director of the Central Intelligence Agency, acknowledged on Wednesday that the C.I.A. had failed to keep members of Congress fully informed that the agency had videotaped the interrogations of suspected operatives of Al Qaeda and destroyed the tapes three years later.

title: U.S. Links Smuggled Cash to Venezuela
description: BUENOS AIRES - A Miami man who brought $800,000 in a suitcase into Argentina was trying to deliver a campaign contribution from the Venezuelan government to the Argentine presidential candidate Cristina Fernndez de Kirchner, American prosecutors said Wednesday.

title: Charitys Share From Shopping Raises Concern
description: Shopping has become virtuous, especially at this time of year. Buy a Better World scarf at American Eagle Outfitters, and the retailer says $10 of the $19.95 price will go to one of three charities. Buy or lease a BMW this month, and participating dealers say they will give $25 to the Make-A-Wish Foundation.

title: A Flock of Shows, Touched by Faith
description: It is almost certainly true that no person, regardless of religious commitment, has ever taken to the freeways with a bumper sticker that reads, Who took Christ out of the Christmas special?

title: At Sallie Mae, a Rejection and a Downward Forecast
description: The parent company of Sallie Mae, the student lender, cut its profit forecast for 2008 on Wednesday and said that its offer to strike a new deal with a group of investors had been rejected.

title: Shareholders Back Dow Jones Sale
description: Rupert Murdoch won control on Thursday of a long-coveted prize, The Wall Street Journal, one of the worlds most-respected and powerful newspapers, when shareholders of The Journals publisher, Dow Jones & Company, gave their blessing to a takeover by Mr. Murdochs global media empire, the News Corporation.

title: G.O.P. Debate Sheds Little New Light
description: The last Republican presidential debate before the Iowa caucuses, a sleepy affair, was nearly over on Wednesday when one of the less-known candidates, Representative Tom Tancredo, decided to launch an attack on one of the leading candidates. I have to say it, because youre leading the pack now, and congratulations to you, governor ... he began.

title: Media Analyst Takes Post at Time Warner
description: Time Warner has quietly hired a prominent media analyst as it reshuffles its executive ranks in the weeks before Jeffrey L. Bewkes takes over as chief executive from Richard D. Parsons.

title: Short, Unhappy Union of Petrino and Falcons Reaches a Bitter End
description: FLOWERY BRANCH, Ga.  A copy of the letter Bobby Petrino left for his players informing them he was resigning as the Atlanta Falcons head coach was lying on the carpet of the locker room late Wednesday. It was crumpled as if it had been thrown to the floor in disgust.

title: Performing Arts Library Awarded Major Grant
description: A $1 million grant has been awarded to the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts by the Doris Duke Charitable Foundation. The grant, beginning on Feb. 1 and continuing until Jan. 31, 2010, will enable the library to record about 25 live jazz, contemporary dance and theater performances, as well as about 45 histories with personalities related to those performances. In addition, the library will preserve 70 hours of oral histories concerning the life and work of the dancer and choreographer Martha Graham (1894-1991). These tapes, housed in the library, were described as being extremely fragile and deteriorating.

title: Federal Judge Upholds Law on Emissions in California
description: WASHINGTON  A federal judge in Sacramento on Wednesday upheld a California law regulating greenhouse gas emissions from cars and trucks, another in a string of legal defeats for the auto industry this year.

title: How to Thaw an iPhone
description: Q. When my iPhone locks up, is there any way to get out of the situation besides powering it off and on again?

title: A Source Takes the Day Off as the Heat Builds
description: Kirk Radomski had the day off Wednesday. Radomskis black chair inside the office of Pro Touch Detail Center in St. James, N.Y., was empty. Vinny Greco, Radomskis business partner, stressed that Radomskis absence had nothing to do with the impending release of George J. Mitchells steroid report Thursday.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A television review in Weekend on Nov. 30 about Tin Man, a mini-series on the Sci Fi Channel based on The Wonderful Wizard of Oz by L. Frank Baum, referred imprecisely to an interpretation of Baums having Dorothy wear silver shoes on the yellow-brick road. While the juxtaposition of the colors has been seen by some as indicating Mr. Baums support for the monetary system of bimetallism, he is not known to have advocated that system.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A theater review on Tuesday about Yellow Face by David Henry Hwang, at the Public Theater, misidentified the nationality of the actor Jonathan Pryce, whose starring role as a Eurasian in the New York production of Miss Saigon was criticized by Mr. Hwang. (The dispute is used as the taking-off point for Yellow Face.) Mr. Pryce is Welsh, not English.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Plumeria in Winter

title: Canada Acts to Reopen Reactor Producing Medical Isotope
description: OTTAWA  Overriding the safety concerns of its regulator, the Canadian government is rushing through legislation to reopen a nuclear reactor that produces most of the worlds supply of a medically important diagnostic isotope.

title: Rockland County Family Pleads Guilty in Fraud Case
description: After 18 years of selling investments in a fictitious Brazilian gold mining operation and using the Internet to sell wholesale merchandise they never delivered, a Rockland County family of five pleaded guilty on Wednesday to charges of defrauding victims across the nation and in Europe of millions of dollars, federal prosecutors said.

title: Winter Storm Blows Into Northeast
description: The Northeast hunkered down as the first major winter storm of the season descended on the area, bringing visions of snow plows and shovels and the possibility of having to make alternate plans for the children if school is canceled on Friday.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Sunday about ethnic tensions in northern Iraqs oil-rich city of Kirkuk over its uncertain political future misstated the capital of neighboring Turkey, which opposes a desire by Iraqi Kurds to control Kirkuk and wants to safeguard Kirkuks Turkmen minority. It is Ankara, not Istanbul. The article also misidentified the area of Turkey where most of its ethnic Kurdish population lives. It is the southeast, not northeast. And the article misstated the ethnic background of Tahsin Kahya, a member of the Kirkuk Provincial Council, who said that a constitutional referendum on Kirkuks future, which is supposed to be held before Dec. 31, should be delayed for years. He is a Turkmen, not an Arab. (Go to Article)

title: Writers Guild Grants a Waiver
description: What would screen actors be without screenwriters? Rather than let the world learn the answer, the striking Writers Guild of America granted a waiver to let the Screen Actors Guild hire a writer to provide material for the 14th annual SAG Awards in Los Angeles on Jan. 27, Reuters reported. Nominations are to be announced on Dec. 20. The guild, on strike since Nov. 5, also granted waivers for the recent Kennedy Center Honors in Washington and a charity event on the Paramount lot in Hollywood.

title: An Inspiring Life, Built on a History of Pain
description: Diana Martin says she has lived through so much drama that she could write a book. Themes would include abandonment, loss of a son, the murder of her one true love and perseverance through years of difficulty.

title: A Holiday Helper for the Computer Savvy
description: Are you the computer-savvy member of your family, the one who goes home for the holidays only to find yourself in front of multiple computers, trouble-shooting instead of celebrating?

title: A Little Silver Is as Good as Gold
description: ON Oct. 22, Alaska Airlines flight 345 from San Francisco to Portland, Ore., was a sea of shell-pink T-shirts and plum-colored sweatshirts, worn by rows of stiff-legged participants from the Nike womens marathon and half-marathon. Around each finishers neck was a dainty Tiffany sterling silver pendant. In the first row of coach, one woman told her seatmate in hushed tones that she had spotted a woman in first class wearing pendants from all four years of the race (one is pictured at left).

title: Florida Court Rejects Claim, a Boon for Morgan Stanley
description: The Florida Supreme Court on Wednesday rejected an appeal by the financier Ronald O. Perelman, who asked the court to restore a $1.58 billion verdict against the investment bank Morgan Stanley.

title: A Beloved Spanish Gypsy Returns to Frances Arms
description: PARIS  Although the Paris Opera is the place where Romantic ballets like La Sylphide (1832) and Giselle (1841) had their world premieres, it isnt where they survived. When Diaghilev and the Ballets Russes brought Giselle to Paris in 1910, the French had to be reminded that this ballet was a chunk of their own cultural history.

title: You Wont Find Me in My Office, Im Working
description: IF youre looking for Bryan Judkins, you wont find him at his desk. I use it as a coat rack, he said of his work space at Young & Laramore, an advertising agency in Indianapolis, where he is the associate creative director. People see my coat and know Im in the building.

title: A Monster and Fireworks Let You Know Someone Nearby Is Using a Cellphone
description: In a twist on the Webkinz model  pairing a password-tagged toy with an online world  Moshi Monsters (www.moshimonsters.com) are a family of six monsters that live in a light-up cellphone charm and, virtually, in an online home you create.

title: Hold the Chemicals, Bring on the Needles
description: JANE BECKER, a composer and solo pianist, celebrated her 50th birthday at the dermatologist, paying $1,500 for shots of Restylane and Botox. But three months later, their wrinkle-smoothing effects wore off. So, she turned to a less-artificial youth tonic: facial acupuncture.

title: Tolerable Wearable Artwork
description: IS there any expression in fine jewelry more noxious-sounding than a necklace or bracelet that is described as wearable art?

title: The Best Doctors: The Elusive Best Standard
description: To the Editor:

title: Markets Still Uneasy After Loan Plan
description: A day after the Federal Reserve disappointed investors with a modest cut in interest rates, central banks in North America and Europe on Wednesday announced the most aggressive infusion of capital into the banking system since the terrorist attacks of September 2001.

title: On Central Park Benches, Inscriptions Remember the Dead and Celebrate Life
description: In this city, known for its writers, even Central Parks benches have stories to tell. From marriage proposals and deaths to cast members celebrating a Broadway success, each adopted bench is maintained for life and engraved with a personal message. Michelle, will you marry me? Love, John, reads a brass plaque on a bench near the zoo. She said yes.

title: Looking Through Lens of Time, Mangini Did the Right Thing
description: Hempstead, N.Y.

title: U.S. Presses China on Economic Issues
description: XINGHE, China  A delegation of senior American economic officials led by Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. churned through a long day of meetings Wednesday with their Chinese counterparts, picking and poking at many economic issues but encountering arguments from the Chinese on several fronts.

title: Small Businesses Oppose Mandates for Health Plans
description: The small-business lobbying group that had a big role in derailing Hillary Rodham Clintons effort to overhaul health care in the early 1990s has staked out its position for the 2008 political season.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Monday about long delays in the resolution of Social Security disability claims misspelled the surname of the legislative director of the National Council for Social Security Management Associations, who commented on the delays. He is Rick Warsinskey, not Warsinsky. The article also misidentified the North Carolina city in which Walter Patterson, a disability lawyer, has his practice. It is Statesville, not Charlotte.

title: After Clashes, Fear of War on Congos Edge
description: SAKE, Congo  A major confrontation between the Congolese Army and a renegade general is plunging the country back toward war, threatening to undermine the fledgling democratic state and set off a new regional conflict on a scale not seen here in years.

title: Buying Postage From Your Desk
description: Buying Postage From Your Desk

title: Traffic Panel Keeps East River Bridge Tolls on Table
description: The chairman of the state commission studying ways to reduce traffic in Manhattan is increasingly pushing a measure certain to prompt opposition in the rest of the city: charging tolls on the four East River Bridges.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Sunday about ethnic tensions in northern Iraqs oil-rich city of Kirkuk over its uncertain political future misstated the capital of neighboring Turkey, which opposes a desire by Iraqi Kurds to control Kirkuk and wants to safeguard Kirkuks Turkmen minority. It is Ankara, not Istanbul. The article also misidentified the area of Turkey where most of its ethnic Kurdish population lives. It is the southeast, not northeast. And the article misstated the ethnic background of Tahsin Kahya, a member of the Kirkuk Provincial Council, who said that a constitutional referendum on Kirkuks future, which is supposed to be held before Dec. 31, should be delayed for years. He is a Turkmen, not an Arab.

title: After Eulogies, Years of Litigation for Police Widow
description: When Officer John M. Kelly crashed his police car during a chase on Staten Island in 2000, thousands of officers attended his funeral, where Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani declared: John Kelly is a hero. Nobody can take that away.

title: ESPN Will Take on Army With Its Own High School Game
description: On Jan. 5, two high school postseason games will be played, each intended to show off a passel of future college football stars. NBC will broadcast the U.S. Army All-American Bowl at 1 p.m., to be followed an hour later by the Under Armour High School All-American Game on ABC.

title: Lawyer Says Confession in Linda Stein Homicide Was Coerced
description: The woman accused of killing Linda S. Stein, the punk rock manager turned Fifth Avenue real estate broker, was coerced into confessing and should be released on bail, her lawyer told a judge on Wednesday at a hearing that ended with an angry confrontation between the families of the defendant and the victim.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the sentencing of Conrad M. Black, the former media mogul who was convicted of fraud, misspelled the name of the town where he bought his first newspaper. It is Sherbrooke, Quebec  not Sherbooke. The article also misstated, in some editions, the proximity of the federal prison camp at Eglin Air Force Base, where Mr. Black is likely to serve his sentence, to his Palm Beach, Fla., home. It is 500 miles away, it is not near.

title: The E-Mail Fix at 10,000 Feet
description: Q. Do any airlines offer wireless broadband Internet connections?

title: Hong Kong Leader Presses China for Vote
description: HONG KONG  Facing widespread demands from the public for full democracy to be introduced within five years, the Hong Kong government urged the Chinese government on Wednesday to set a firm timetable for direct elections for the regions leader and legislature.

title: The Hague: General Who Besieged Sarajevo Gets 33 Years
description: The International Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia sentenced Dragomir Milosevic, left, a former Bosnian-Serb general, to 33 years in prison. He ordered the relentless shelling and sniper campaign that wounded and killed thousands of civilians in the besieged Bosnian capital, Sarejevo, for 15 months in 1994 and 1995. There was no safe place in Sarajevo, said the presiding judge, Patrick Robinson. One could be killed and injured anywhere and anytime.

title: The Other Atonement Love Story
description: ONIBURY, England

title: Countrywide Subpoenaed by Illinois
description: The Illinois attorney general is investigating the home loan unit of Countrywide Financial as part of the states expanding inquiry into dubious lending practices that have trapped borrowers in high-cost mortgages they can no longer afford.

title: Shootings Test Limits of New Self-Defense Law
description: PASADENA, Tex.  Joe Horns home was his castle, but what about his neighbors home?

title: Jurors Deadlock on 6 of 7 in Sears Plot
description: MIAMI  One of seven indigent men accused of plotting to blow up the Sears Tower in Chicago as part of an Islamic jihad was acquitted on Thursday, but a mistrial was declared against the other six after the jury said it was hopelessly deadlocked.

title: Ike Turner, Musician and Songwriter in Duo With Tina Turner, Dies at 76
description: Ike Turner, the R&B musician, songwriter, bandleader, producer, talent scout and ex-husband of Tina Turner, died on Wednesday at his home in San Marcos, Calif., a San Diego suburb. He was 76.

title: Senate Approves Energy Bill Without Tax Increase
description: WASHINGTON  Pared-down energy legislation cleared the Senate by a wide margin on Thursday evening after the oil industry and utilities succeeded in stripping out provisions that would have cost them billions of dollars.

title: China: High-Rise Fire Kills 21
description: Twenty-one people were killed in a fire that tore through a 28-story apartment building in eastern Wenzhou. The Xinhua news agency said more than 200 firefighters battled the fire for three hours. About 200 residents were rescued or evacuated, it said. The cause of the fire was under investigation.

title: Bangladesh: Sundarbans Devastated by November Cyclone
description: Unesco said that the cyclone that struck southern Bangladesh last month and killed 3,000 people also destroyed 40 percent of the Sundarbans, one of the worlds largest mangrove forests and a World Heritage site. The Sundarbans, on the delta of the Ganges, Brahmaputra and Meghna Rivers, is home to several endangered species, including the Bengal tiger, and is a source of livelihood for hundreds of thousands of people who subsist on fishing and shrimping. Unesco estimated that regeneration of the Sundarbans ecosystem would take 10 to 15 years.

title: Final Debate Before Iowa Caucuses Shows Uncertainty at Top of Republican Field
description: The last Republican presidential debate before the Iowa caucuses, a sleepy affair, was nearly over on Wednesday when one of the less-known candidates, Representative Tom Tancredo, decided to mount an attack on one of the leading candidates.

title: A Universe of Gadget Advice
description: BUYING a book online is easy, but buying electronics can be intimidating. Is it a good gift? Are you getting the right model? Are you getting a good deal, or getting taken?

title: MTV to Let Freelancers Stay on Its Insurance
description: Acknowledging the concerns of hundreds of freelance workers, MTV Networks on Wednesday reversed some of the cuts it had intended to make to benefits packages.

title: Gene Therapy, Revisited
description: In decisions followed closely by experts in performance-enhancing drugs, the Food and Drug Administration and the National Institutes of Health both ruled in the past two weeks that the death of an Illinois woman receiving gene therapy to treat her rheumatoid arthritis was not related to the therapy itself. The woman had developed a life-threatening infection that the regulators decided was due to other drugs she was taking.

title: Italy Struggles Under Truck Strike
description: ROME  Gasoline became nearly impossible to find and supermarket shelves grew barer on Wednesday, the third day of a nationwide strike of heavy trucks in Italy that threatens deep paralysis by its planned end on Friday.

title: Unearthing a Spy Who Couldnt Keep Up With a Cop
description: Watchman represents a road not taken by Ian Rankin, the immensely popular Scottish mystery writer. This book, first published in Britain in 1988 but only now arriving in the United States, was the second crime novel written by an author who, whether or not he knew it at the time, was in search of an enduring antihero. If he had clung to the main character in Watchman, Mr. Rankin might have devoted two decades to the cloak-and-dagger adventures of a mildly James Bondian figure named Miles Flint.

title: What to Ask About Infertility
description: Confronting a new diagnosis can be frightening  and because research changes so often, confusing. Here are some questions you may not think to ask your doctor, along with notes on why theyre important.

title: Correction
description: An Op-Ed article on Sunday, about the presidential race in California, incorrectly described the vessel that spilled 58,000 gallons of oil in San Francisco Bay on Nov. 7. It was a container ship, not a tanker.

title: Lennons Hair Fetches Thousands
description: A lock of John Lennons hair attracted a winning bid of $48,000 on Wednesday at an auction in Worthing, England, The Associated Press reported. Carrying a presale estimate of $4,000 to $6,000, the hair, inside an autographed copy of Lennons book A Spaniard in the Works, above, went to an unidentified telephone bidder at a sale of Beatles memorabilia. Its astonishing that there is still so much interest in the Beatles, and the sale goes to prove that John Lennon is still an icon, said Francesca Collin, a spokeswoman for the auction house, Gorringes. Lennon gave the hair and the book to Betty Glasow, the Beatles hairdresser in their heyday, who offered those items and others for sale. Nick Muston, a director of Gorringes, said Ms. Glasow decided to sell the material because she wanted fans to have it.

title: Bomb Kills Lebanese General Who Battled Militants
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  A powerful car bomb killed one of Lebanons top generals and his bodyguard in a suburb of Beirut on Wednesday, striking an unexpected blow at the countrys most widely respected institution and further undermining Lebanons precarious stability.

title: Room to Improve
description: Q. How much patterned wallpaper is too much?

title: The N.F.L.s Not-So-Perfect Season
description: Here's the conundrum for the National Football League: Two teams are on the brink of perfection -- the Patriots, as they march toward 19-0, and the Dolphins and their diametrically opposed slog to 0-16.

title: Groups Refile Suit Over Immigration Law
description: Civil rights groups filed a new federal lawsuit challenging an Arizona law that would cancel the business licenses of employers found guilty of hiring illegal immigrants more than once in three years. An earlier suit by the groups, including the American Civil Liberties Union, was dismissed on Friday by Judge Neil V. Wake of Federal District Court, who said they had sued the wrong government officials. The groups said they expected the new lawsuit would address the judges concerns. The law is to take effect Jan. 1.

title: Three Blasts Kill at Least 27 in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  At least 27 people died and 150 were wounded Wednesday when three car bombs ripped through a southern Iraqi city where the local authorities had recently taken over security responsibility from the British military and rival Shiite groups had been battling for control of oil and power.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, the On Education column on Wednesday, about the debate over allowing illegal immigrants to pay in-state tuition at public universities, referred incompletely to the legal status of Ysaira Paulino, an immigrant from the Dominican Republic. Although she indeed overstayed her visa when she was enrolled at the City College of New York, she now has a work permit, and has a petition pending to become a permanent resident.

title: A Shameful Presidential Threat
description: The Senate should ignore an incredibly mischievous last-minute veto threat from the White House and vote resoundingly in favor of an energy bill that could come before it as early as today. The bill represents a historic opportunity to ease Americas dependence on foreign oil and to take steps in the battle against global warming, and its passage would send a message to the worlds negotiators in Bali that Washington is at last getting serious about climate change.

title: Lottery Numbers
Giving Names to Souls Forgotten No Longer
description: THIELLS, N.Y.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,879 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:

title: Knicks, Still Falling Apart, Lose to a Rebuilding Team
description: Kevin Durant has phenomenal talent, very little experience and not much help in the lineup that surrounds him. But it does not take much to beat the Knicks, and Durants considerable skills  combined with a former Knicks heady play  was enough to send the Knicks to another humiliating defeat.

title: Turning Points on the Road to Conception
description: Dr. Zev Rosenwaks is director of The Center for Reproductive Medicine and Infertility at New York-Presbyterian Hospital.

title: Racing to Beat the Maternal Clock
description: In the nearly 30 years since Louise Brown made history as the first test-tube baby, more than one million infants have been conceived by means of in vitro fertilization. Assisted reproductive technologies continue to advance, but increasingly they are pushing against one of natures great barriers to fertility: maternal age.

title: Cheers in Newark for a Housing Projects Downfall
description: NEWARK  A green-spangled marching band shimmied and lunged to a crash of cymbals. Inside a giant tent, a five-piece band serenaded the crowd, which was dining on a Southern-style catered lunch. Save for the overcast skies, it was a glorious day for the destruction of a building.

title: In a Funk, Italy Sings an Aria of Disappointment
description: ROME  All the world loves Italy because it is old but still glamorous. Because it eats and drinks well but is rarely fat or drunk. Because it is the place in a hyper-regulated Europe where people still debate with perfect intelligence what, really, the red in a stoplight might mean.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Tuesday about an imprisoned rapist who confessed to nine decades-old murders in Missouri, Illinois and Kentucky, misstated the age of one victim in some editions. Deborah Sheppard was 23 at the time of her murder, not 21.

title: New York Frees Oldest Inmate
description: Charles E. Friedgood, who at 89 had been the oldest inmate in a New York State prison, was released on Tuesday and granted permission to live with a sister in Florida, where a daughter also lives, the State Parole Board said on Wednesday.

title: Men in Pelts (but Not Too Many Pelts)
description: FIVE years ago, Spencer Levy would have recoiled from the thought of wearing fur. But last year, Mr. Levy, a real estate broker in New York, spotted a Juicy Couture hoodie lined with rabbit (his wife, Michelle Wohlers, works in sales for the line) and, just like that, he changed his tune.

title: How Dyslexics Think
description: To the Editor:

title: Jets and Patriots Say Its Just a Game. Its Not.
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y.  The latest twist in the feud between the Jets and the New England Patriots involves another video camera. The Jets insist the latest installment in their bitter rivalry filled with spies, lies and alibis differs from the Spygate saga.

title: Spines, Made Extra Curvy for Women
description: Pregnant women do not tip over, and the reason has a lot to do with an evolutionary curve, researchers say.

title: Increases in Education Aid Range From 2 to 20 Percent Under Corzine Plan
description: Each of New Jerseys 615 school districts would receive 2 percent to 20 percent more in state aid next year under a new financing formula officially unveiled by Gov. Jon S. Corzine on Wednesday, nearly two weeks after parts of the proposal were revealed by state lawmakers and state education officials.

title: The Tax Debate That Isnt
description: If theres one issue on which Republican presidential hopefuls should feel vulnerable, its taxes. The Bush tax cuts, more than any other policy, are crippling the government financially.

title: Secular Europes Merits
description: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland

title: U.S. and Chinese Officials Duel on Economic Issues
description: XINGHE, China  A delegation of senior American economic officials led by Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. churned through a long day of meetings Wednesday with their Chinese counterparts, picking and poking at many economic issues while encountering arguments from the Chinese on several fronts.

title: Most Want Musharraf to Quit, Poll Shows
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The first comprehensive public opinion poll conducted in Pakistan since President Pervez Musharraf declared a state of emergency last month has found that 67 percent of Pakistanis want him to resign immediately and that 70 percent say his government does not deserve re-election.

title: Come Back, Barney, Come Back
description: WASHINGTON  President Bush may call the shots around the White House. But now there is video proof that his dog Barney doesnt listen to him.

title: India, a Stirring Giant, Is the New Place to See and Be Seen
description: NEW DELHI  If its Monday, it must be Romania  and Finland and Minnesota.

title: A Close Call on the Way to a Trophy
description: The Herman Trophy is awarded to the winner of the most master points at the Fall North American Championships, which ended 11 days ago in San Francisco. The winner was Lew Stansby of Castro Valley, Calif., with 375.28 points. He finished second in the Reisinger Board-a-Match Teams, but the diagramed deal occurred during the Edgar Kaplan Blue Ribbon Pairs, in which he finished 14th with his wife, JoAnna Stansby, who was on the winning Venice Cup team in Shanghai in October.

title: California: Board Members Recalled Over Blackwater Plan
description: Residents of Potrero, a rural community in east San Diego County, voted to oust five members of the towns planning board who endorsed a bid by Blackwater Worldwide to build a training camp. Three of the boards nine members have already been removed because Blackwater opponents revealed that they had been improperly appointed. Election officials counted the recall ballots Tuesday night, said Deborah Seiler, registrar of voters for San Diego County. The five board members elected to fill the seats of the recalled board members oppose Blackwaters development of an 824-acre tract of land near Potrero, close to the Mexican border, people on both sides of the debate said.

title: Flu Vaccinations: Protect Our Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Warehouse Workers Quit in Immigration Inquiry
description: Fresh Direct, the online grocery delivery operation that caters to affluent and overworked New Yorkers, lost dozens of employees this week after federal immigration officials notified the company that its employee records were under investigation.

title: Racing to Be in Step With the Green Movement
description: OF all the ways manufacturers are rushing to jump onto the environmentally friendly bandwagon, inserting a biodegradable midsole into an otherwise everlasting running shoe seems like a fairly minuscule step.

title: The Rangers Normally Stingy Defense Rests
description: WASHINGTON  The Rangers wild 5-4 overtime loss Wednesday night to the Capitals would have been stunning even if the Rangers had not beaten the Devils, 1-0, three days earlier.

title: Will 2008 Be a Postwar Election?
description: To the Editor:

title: Shares Hold on to Part of Early Gains
description: Shares rose on Wednesday, led by technology and energy stocks, in another volatile day on Wall Street.

title: Deal Governing Development in the Catskills Does Not End a Battle
description: HIGHMOUNT, N.Y.  Gov. Eliot Spitzer and his environmental team appeared to have won a big victory in September by brokering a deal to reduce the size of a proposed Catskill Mountains megaresort while protecting 1,200 acres of woodland from development.

title: Airline Trade Group Predicts a Further Drop in Profit Next Year
description: Soaring fuel prices and slowing economic growth are likely to wipe out much of the airline industrys profits next year, despite steady increases in global demand for air travel, the International Air Transport Association, a leading trade group, said Wednesday.

title: Giants Counting on Jacobs to Get a Grip
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The glummest face in the winning locker room last Sunday belonged to Brandon Jacobs. He had started against the Philadelphia Eagles after missing the previous two games with a strained hamstring. He ran the ball 22 times for 70 yards and caught 3 passes. The Giants won.

title: Manhattan: School Official Charged
description: An employee of the citys Department of Education was charged on Wednesday with taking cash bribes from at least five school bus companies in exchange for giving them advance notice about city inspections and for granting them favorable bus routes. In a complaint filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan, the employee, Geoffrey Berger, a borough supervisor in charge of city school bus routes in Westchester County and the Bronx, was charged with taking thousands of dollars of bribes for at least five years. The charges against him arose from a federal investigation into Mafia influence over the city school bus drivers union, Local 1181 of the Amalgamated Transit Union.

title: With Writers Out, Directors Offer Their Own Talks
description: LOS ANGELES  Movie and television directors said Thursday that they were prepared to begin bargaining toward a new contract with production companies after the New Year holiday, a move that could realign Hollywoods troubled labor front.

title: Home & Garden Calendar
description: Silver Anniversary in the Round

title: Democrats to Spend Bushs Limit Their Way
description: WASHINGTON  Stymied by Republican opposition to their spending proposals, Congressional Democrats said on Wednesday that they would finance the federal government at roughly the amount insisted on by President Bush but shift more money to their favored causes.

title: Shift Away From Ad-Free Has a Price
description: WHEN children log onto Webkinz.com, the popular virtual world for children who buy Webkinz stuffed animals, they can send messages to their friends, decorate their virtual rooms and take trivia quizzes.

title: Albany: Nominee for Waterfront Commissioner
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer has nominated Ronald Goldstock to be New York States commissioner on the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor, a bistate agency that certifies dockworkers and polices the waterfront. Mr. Goldstock previously worked as managing director at Kroll Associates, a private security firm, and was director of the New York State Organized Crime Task Force for more than 13 years. If approved by the State Senate, Mr. Goldstock would succeed Michael C. Axelrod. On Oct. 15, Mr. Spitzer issued an executive order instructing the states inspector general, Kristine Hamann, to look at allegations of misfeasance and nonfeasance by personnel of the Waterfront Commission, including allegations of misconduct, conflicts of interest, abuse and waste.

title: Mexico: Counterfeit Million Seized
description: The authorities said that federal agents raided a house in Tonal, a suburb of Guadalajara, this week and seized more than $1.1 million in counterfeit $100 bills. Twelve people were arrested. The investigation that led to the raid also involved the United States Secret Service and was begun in 2005 after millions of counterfeit $100 bills started showing up in southern California.

title: Tip of the Week: Online Meeting Planners
description: The Meeting Planner link on the World Time Server site (www.worldtimeserver.com) lets you pick a date and add in the locations of all the participants from around the globe so you can narrow down a time that works for everyone. (It is useful for online game players, too.)

title: Get Them Hooked and Theyll Reel Themselves In
description: ARE your arms tired yet?

title: Fire Ravages a Historic Block in New Haven and Displaces at Least 100
description: NEW HAVEN  A three-alarm fire ripped through a historic block near the New Haven Green early Wednesday, closing a section of downtown and displacing at least 100 residents before it was contained, the authorities said.

title: Whos Imitating Whom?
description: VISITORS loitering along the palm-lined streets of Miami Beach during Art Basel last week appeared to pattern themselves after the most disparate of fashion role models. Some chose to emulate the dissolute preppiness of Wes Anderson, the film director, while others aped the calculated depravity of the photographer Terry Richardson. A few even managed to fuse the styles of both, combining the supersize, mauve-tinted eyewear and stubble affected by Mr. Richardson (and certain 1970s pornographers) with canvas sneakers or white bucks, trim bow ties and seersucker.

title: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
description: Previously recorded: $2,831,660.89

title: Ted Corbitt, a Pioneer in American Distance Running, Dies at 88
description: Ted Corbitt, who began running as a child on his fathers cotton farm in South Carolina and virtually never stopped, becoming a pioneer of ultramarathon running in the United States, died Wednesday in Houston. He was 88 and lived in Manhattan.

title: In Twilight of Life, a Former Moonshiner Finds Mercy
description: Daniel Freeman was getting old, he was out of work and poverty was pressing in. Before his life ended, he wanted to clear his name of a 1963 conviction for a liquor-law felony.

title: The Hallelujah Chorus Continues Its Attraction
description: Religious art operates under the principle that God wants the best. St. Thomas Church does its best to oblige. Its Messiah performances are near the top of New Yorks many Christmas attractions. Handels beloved oratorio returned to St. Thomas on Tuesday evening and will repeat Thursday.

title: New Yorkers Are in a Fiery State of Mind
description: These are red-pepper days in New York. Not red-letter but red-pepper, as in the bright hieroglyphics that pop up automatically when an e-mail gets way too salty.

title: Fury Rising Over Lenience in Gang Rape of Aboriginal Girl, 10
description: SYDNEY, Australia  Mounting anger over the handling of the gang rape of a 10-year-old indigenous girl has pushed the plight of Australias Aboriginal minority to the top of the countrys political agenda, leaving the new government of Prime Minister Kevin Rudd scrambling for solutions to one of the countrys most intractable problems.

title: An Enthusiast Entrepreneur Kicks Off a T-Shirt Business
From a Critic of Tribunals to Top Judge
description: Back in 2002, a masters degree candidate at the Naval War College wrote a paper on the Bush administrations plan to use military commissions to try Guantnamo suspects, concluding that even a good military tribunal is a bad idea.

title: Britain: Unemployment Is Down
description: Unemployment in Britain declined to 3.2 percent in November, the lowest level since 1975, as the strength of the economy encouraged companies to take on more workers. Claims for unemployment benefits dropped 11,100 from October, to 813,000, according to the Office for National Statistics. Average earnings including bonuses rose at an annual rate of 4 percent in the three months through October, down from 4.1 percent in the three months through September, the statistics office said. With bonuses excluded, wage growth slowed to 3.6 percent from 3.7 percent in the third quarter.

title: Dubai Court Sentences Two in Rape
description: A Dubai court sentenced two men on Wednesday to 15 years in prison for the rape of a French-Swiss teenager whose case became a rallying point for critics of the way the United Arab Emirates treats victims of sexual assault.

title: National Finals Rodeo Adds Bucks to the Bucking
description: LAS VEGAS  Nascars drivers have long distanced themselves from their sports moonshine-running past, and millionaire Major League Baseball players compete in cathedrals that bear little resemblance to their games origins in dusty sandlots. In rodeo, the sport of Americas original extreme athletes, not a whole lot has changed.

title: Patients Wonder Whether to Replace a Wire That Might Fail
description: MORRISTOWN, N.J.  For one heart patient, there will be no more agonizing over whether the implanted device meant to save his life might kill him instead.

title: Immigration, and Its Politics, Shake Rural Iowa
description: STORM LAKE, Iowa  Along the main thoroughfare of this small meatpacking town, the transformation of a single shop, once known as the Ken-A-Bob restaurant, tells the story of the town itself.

title: The Man From Target
description: Huckabee! Huckabee! The man of the hour! What is it that voters love so much about this guy? Is it a hitherto inchoate yearning for a president who knows less about international affairs than they do? Hope that a man who can lose 100 pounds could also get rid of the federal deficit?

title: Officials See No Public Health Threat in Shortage of a Meningitis Vaccine
description: A developing shortage of vaccine against childhood meningitis is expected to inconvenience some pediatricians and parents, but should not become a public health threat, officials from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the Food and Drug Administration said Wednesday.

title: Marit Allen, Costume Designer for Movies, Dies at 66
description: Marit Allen, a British fashion writer and editor in the miniskirted 1960s who went on to design costumes for film characters as varied as the frumpy cross-dresser in Mrs. Doubtfire, the cowboys of Brokeback Mountain and the purple stretch-panted creature in Hulk, died on Nov. 26 in Australia. She was 66 and lived in London.

title: Blaze Kills Four in a Much-Loved Family in New Jersey
description: UNION, N.J.  Whether holding summer parties, playing host at events for their daughters swim team or welcoming fellow Filipino immigrants to New Jersey, Edgardo and Digna Aguas had an address that was familiar to nearly everyone in their wide social circle.

title: Russia Tells Britain to Shut Cultural Offices
description: Russias Foreign Ministry ordered Britain to close the cultural offices of the British Council outside of Moscow by Jan. 1, saying it had repeatedly broken tax laws as well as the Vienna Convention by operating out of British consulates. Britain said it would ignore the order, which it considers a violation of international law. The countries have been embroiled in a dispute over Russias refusal to hand over Andrei K. Lugovoi, the former K.G.B. official accused of fatally poisoning Alexander V. Litvinenko in London last year with a radioactive isotope. In July, Britain expelled four Russian diplomats, setting off a tit-for-tat response in Moscow.

title: Manhattan: Fire Inspection Report
description: Response times have not increased since the Fire Department adopted new rules last month requiring fire companies to devote an additional three hours each week to the inspection of high-rise buildings under construction and demolition, Fire Commissioner Nicholas Scoppetta, said at a City Council hearing on Wednesday. The companies now dedicate nine hours a week to inspections. Between Nov. 5 and Dec. 11, firefighters inspected 97 percent of the 468 such high-rise buildings. The average response time for citywide emergencies stood at 4 minutes 46 seconds last month  5 seconds less than in November 2006 and 13 seconds less than in November 2005, Mr. Scoppetta said.

title: Aiming to Translate Politics Into Hope for Palestinians
description: BETHLEHEM, West Bank  Tony Blair had that practiced politicians half grin, his eyes in semi-focus, as the Palestinian minister of tourism, Khouloud Daibes, showed him around a display of Palestinian products at the Chamber of Commerce here Tuesday night. Mr. Blair, the former British prime minister and now the Western envoy for Palestinian development, posed for photos with businessmen and praised the quality of the local marble tiles.

title: Homespun Electricity, From the Wind
description: WHEN Rena Wilson Jones and her husband, Drew, were building a house 10 years ago in a subdivision near the edge of Urbana, Ill., they knew the property was likely to be windy, bordered as it was by open fields to the north and west. But they did not realize how fierce the winds would be until construction of their house was under way. In the decade that followed, the wind drove Ms. Wilson Jones crazy from November through April, she said, whipping across her yard and making it difficult to work in the garden. At times, it was hard to walk outside.

title: Uncloaking the Plight of an Aging Woman
description: You have to hand it to Judith Malina. At 81 the co-founder of the Living Theater is still dancing around the stage, taking off her clothes, doing her best to shake up the world. She is a sympathetic match for the 88-year-old Doris Lessing, who made the invisibility of aging women a major theme decades before talk-show guests started chatting about hot flashes. In Maudie and Jane, based on a Lessing novel, Ms. Malina makes the dirty, aged Maudie defiantly visible and strangely charming.

title: Biogen Takes Itself Off the Block After Failing to Sell High, and Shares Plunge 28%
description: Big pharmaceutical companies may be desperate for new products, but they apparently are not ready to obtain them at any price.

title: Wake Up to Birds or Music or Pictures of a Favorite Pal
description: Its nice to wake up to the sound of twittering birds, but in many places that experience is hard to come by in December.

title: Clinton Aide Sees Problem for Obama
description: DES MOINES  A top adviser to Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton said Wednesday that Senator Barack Obamas admission of illegal drug use as a young man could threaten his electability and be seized on by Republicans if he won the Democratic presidential nomination.

title: C.I.A. Agents Sense Shifting Support for Methods
description: WASHINGTON  For six years, Central Intelligence Agency officers have worried that someday the tide of post-Sept. 11 opinion would turn, and their harsh treatment of prisoners from Al Qaeda would be subjected to hostile scrutiny and possible criminal prosecution.

title: Contempt Vote in Panel for Bush Aides
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate Judiciary Committee voted on Thursday to hold a present and a former aide to President Bush in contempt of Congress, but it is by no means clear that they will be dragged before the lawmakers anytime soon.

title: Congressman Says Google Is Resisting Deal Inquiry
description: Representative Joe Barton of Texas said on Wednesday that Google had rebuffed requests by his staff for a meeting as part of an investigation into the companys $3.1 billion acquisition of DoubleClick.

title: Animal Instincts Most Costly
description: THOUGH it seems impossibly abstract from the vantage point of Madison Avenue, armed conflicts are taking place between powerful aggressors and their enemies across the globe. The fighting seems unimaginable, light-years away.

title: A Phones Makeover Goes Beyond Cosmetics
description: On the face of it, the differences between Samsungs popular BlackJack smartphone and the upgraded BlackJack II are superficial. The screen is bigger, the numeric keys embedded in the qwerty keyboard are positioned closer together and the unit is slightly heavier. There are additional keys for quick access to the Internet, e-mail, online video and the camera.

title: Work Believed a Gauguin Turns Out to Be a Forgery
description: When The Faun, a stoneware sculpture, was bought by the Art Institute of Chicago a decade ago, it was hailed as one of the museums most important acquisitions in 20 years.

title: Lehman Earnings Fall, but Not as Much as Expected
description: Lehman Brothers, one of a handful of Wall Street banks to avoid large losses related to subprime mortgages, reported better than expected earnings for the fourth quarter, on the back of two one-time gains and in spite of a month  November  that Lehman executives called the worst single month in the credit markets, ever.

title: Foundation Testing Potential of Philanthropy via Internet
description: The Case Foundation is embarking on an effort to test the potential of citizen-led philanthropy via the Internet.

title: A World Consumed by Guilt
description: LET us set aside the clichs about green fashion, ye cynical Kermits, and presume that everyone is now on board with saving the world by doing our holiday shopping at Barneys, where even the window displays promote eco-friendly clothing.

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: President Vetoes Second Measure to Expand Childrens Health Program
description: WASHINGTON  President Bush vetoed another childrens health bill on Wednesday, effectively killing Democrats hopes of expanding a popular government program aimed at providing insurance to youngsters in lower- and middle-income families.

title: Movement With Mystery and Efficient Athleticism
description: Many dancers have walked slowly across many stages, their faces bathed in a slanting light, their eyes focused on a middle distance. The viewers imagination rushes toward whatever unseen entity the dancer approaches: a lover, an uncertain future, death.

title: Special Session in Albany, Where Gridlock Never Left
description: ALBANY  The State Senate plans to return here Thursday for a special session, but it appears that lawmakers will accomplish little. Senate Republicans have been negotiating with Gov. Eliot Spitzer and Assembly Democrats over largely the same set of issues for more than six months, but have yet to achieve much in the way of results.

title: WPP Says, Veni, Invidi, Vici

title: Huckabees Compassionate Conservatism
description: The cover of the Times Magazine this Sunday is a profile of Mike Huckabee by Zev Chafets, a writer whose work Ive always liked. Its a great portrait, rendered skeptically but without cynicism, and I highly recommend it. Whats occurred to me as Ive read stories about Mr. Huckabee over these last few months  Ive not yet met him  is that you can already see how, should he manage to win the nomination, he would deftly steer himself back toward the political center in time for the convention. The outlines of the post-primary Huckabee storyline have already emerged: he raised some taxes over his own partys objections, he refused to deny scholarships to illegal immigrants (a decision he has refused to back away from even if it costs me he election), he came off as too liberal and secular for a lot of his fellow Baptist preachers. These lines from the Huckabee resume have earned him the scorn of some Republican interest groups, most notably the anti-tax Club for Growth, whose idea of state government consists of a couple of prisons and a paving machine, but they would serve him nicely in a general election, where independent voters might shrink from electing another rigid conservative. Campaign reporters always line up to write stories like this, not because they care about making the Mike Huckabees of the world seem kind and gentle, which he may well be, but because we in the media are trained to look for the contradiction of stereotypes  and no one is more gleefully stereotyped in America than the religious conservative. Thus we in the media have historically embraced the story of the Republican governor who, it turns out, isnt as much of a crazy conservative as you might think. Hey, look, the Tin Man has a heart! George W. Bush was a compassionate conservative who worked amiably across the aisle with Democrats. Mitt Romney passed a landmark, bipartisan bill to provide healthcare. Even Ronald Reagan enacted a huge tax increase while governor of California. And so on.

title: Discovery Will Be Spun Off
description: The owners of Discovery Communications John Malones Discovery Holding Co. and Advance/Newhouse  have agreed in principle to combine their stakes and turn the cable company into a stand-alone publicly traded company.

title: Wrong Number From Sprint
description: One of the more obnoxious practices of the cellphone business is the various fees carriers tack on to bills that are meant to look like taxes, but in fact are just more money you are supposed to pay them. So for half a second I was delighted to see a post on DSL Reports that Sprint was eliminating such mumbo jumbo as the Federal Programs Cost Recovery Fees.

title: Golden Globes and Solidarity
description: When the Baguette asked James L. Brooks, the screenwriter of The Simpsons Movie, how he was celebrating his Golden Globe nomination, he replied, On the picket line. I dont know if you call it a celebration but it happens to be my next stop.

title: Will That Be Skim in Your CAFE?
description: The Senate and White House are fussing over the enforcement details of the latest energy bill, which passed the House last week. The bill aims to raise the Corporate Average Fuel Economy standards to 35 miles a gallon by 2020. Meanwhile, and despite a veto threat from the White House, automakers are also warming to the heightened standards. The trouble is, despite their stated purpose of reducing Americas energy consumption, CAFE standards are a poor method of achieving that goal.

title: Citis Druskin to Retire
description: Only two days after announcing its new chairman and chief executive, Citigroup has lost one of its top executives.

title: A Frosty Reception for Murdochs Dow Jones Celebration
description: It was sweet victory at last for Rupert Murdoch. Thursday morning, Dow Jones & Company shareholders in New York approved the News Corporations $5.6 billion purchase of the company. But a spate of flashy, full-page ads touting the historic media merger has drawn some unexpectedly sour responses.

title: Vintage Ike Turner
description: Ike Turner died Wednesday at 76. Mostly he will be remembered as the violent, abusive husband of Tina Turner. But it should not be forgotten that he was an idiosyncratic, influential musician whose fundamental contributions to rock-and-roll would probably never have been noticed had it not been for the eventual pop success of Ike and Tina Turner.

title: Vegansexuality
description: Forget homo-, bi- or even metro-: the latest prefix in sexuality is vegan-, as in vegansexual. In a survey of vegan and vegetarians (most women), the questions ranged from attitudes about eating meat to to wearing possum fur to, yes, cruelty-free sex  that is, rejecting meat eaters as intimate partners. Some of the survey respondents volunteered their reluctance to kiss meat eaters. I couldnt think of kissing lips that allow dead animal pieces to pass between them, a 49-year-old vegan woman said. For some, the resistance is the squeamishness factor. Nonvegetarian bodies smell different to me, a 41-year-old vegan woman said. They are, after all, literally sustained through carcasses  the murdered flesh of others. Read more in the Times Magazine

title: Carbon Dioxide Is Double Threat to Reefs
description: While scouring the halls of the American Geophysical Union meeting in San Francisco, my colleague Kenneth Chang had time to summarize a new paper in the journal Science on the double-barreled risk carbon dioxide may pose to coral reefs. I first wrote about this in 2004. The issue kind of crept up by surprise, perhaps because it has mainly been climatologists, not oceanographers and chemists, who have focused on impacts of greenhouse gases. Heres his dispatch:

As an example, the report heralded the benefits that we will from one much ballyhooed new program, an air-navigation initiative called the Wide Area Augmentation System.

title: Can Things Get Worse?
description: Since the subprime crisis erupted, the repeated hope has been that it would get no worse, and spread no further. Three things I read this week  two essays and a report from the European Central Bank  help us to understand how we got into this mess, and why it could get worse. The essays are by Martin Wolf in The Financial Times and Ted Seides in Peter L. Bernsteins Economics and Portfolio Strategy.

That unit of the South Korean electronics giant makes the panels used by sister company Samsung Electronics and other TV makers to build televisions, computers, cellphones and an expanding array of other gizmos.

description: Only 18 percent of the roughly 8,000 items that riders leave behind on New York Citys subways and buses each year are eventually claimed by their owners, but that recovery rate is needlessly low because of poor security, inefficient management and inadequate staff, according to a blistering report released by the Metropolitan Transportation Authoritys inspector general.

description: Lawmakers like to say they are motivated by a sense of civic duty, or to right wrongs, or to better the lives of their fellow man. But forState Senator Eric Adams, a Brooklyn Democrat, it comes down to cash.

description: The big research houses have been trimming their 2008 forecasts for global technology spending lately, mainly because they see a weaker United States market next year. IDC, for example, reduced its growth projection for 2008 last week to between 5.5 percent and 6 percent, down from an earlier forecast of 6.6 percent.

description: MBIA, the bond insurer, just filed its 8-k report with the Securities and Exchange Commission, concerning the equity investment promised by Warburg Pincus.

It was only when vast numbers of American families woke up to the fact that they were not being valued at all  that, in fact, they were being fleeced  that non-conservatives shook themselves into a sentient state and began to talk about replacing empty words with substantive promises about health care, child care and college aid.

title: Ron Villone: Its a Serious Situation
description: One of the joys of being a beat writer is the downtime in the clubhouse when you really get to know the players. No tape recorders, no notebooks, just talk. You learn things this way, and develop trust, but you also simply enjoy the company of certain guys as people.

description: NASA officials scrambled this year to decide how to handle the legal and public relations fallout surrounding Capt. Lisa M. Nowak, an astronaut who drove from Texas to Florida to confront a romantic rival, according to e-mail messages released Wednesday by the space agency.
