description: Alex Rodriguezs decision to opt out of his contract partly upstaged the final game of the World Series. When Rodriguezs 10-year, $275 million Yankees contract was completed Thursday, it happened on another day of big news.

title: Giuliani Firm Stood to Benefit From U.S. Deals, Florida Companys Files Show
description: WASHINGTON  Rudolph W. Giulianis consulting firm was hired in 2002 to help a Florida company build its business under a contract that called for Mr. Giulianis firm to be paid in part for lining up work with the federal government and other clients, company records show.

title: Abbass Premier Tells Israel to Reopen Gaza
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank  The moderate Palestinian Authority government based in the West Bank, in a departure from past policy, on Thursday publicly called on Israel to lift economic restrictions on the Gaza Strip, which is ruled by the Islamic group Hamas.

title: Campaigns Like These Make It Hard to Find a Reason to Believe
description: As I watched Mitt Romney tie himself into a constitutional knot as he argued that religion should provide a guide for public policy but not be used to choose a president, it made me suspect that all the candidates in the race  Republican and Democratic  must believe that I lack some essential virtue.

title: The Republicans Expensive Tax Promise
description: For decades, ever since Ronald Reagan was elected in 1980, promising to cut taxes has been an essential element of every successful Republican campaign for the presidency. Republican politicians still vividly remember that George H.W. Bush lost to Bill Clinton after agreeing to a modest tax increase as part of a broad budget deal  and most have vowed never to make that mistake again.

title: Queens: Man Charged With Rape
description: A Queens Village man has been charged with abducting and raping a college student after she left a party celebrating her birthday on Saturday night, prosecutors said on Thursday. The suspect, James Moye, 19, was arraigned on Thursday on charges of rape, second-degree kidnapping and sexual assault, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Prosecutors charge that Mr. Moye and an accomplice chased the woman after she left the party and forced her into a van at gunpoint. After raping the woman in the van, prosecutors said, the two men drove to Jamaica Center and told her to get out.

title: Perhaps Theres Some Life in the Old Corpus Yet
description: Latin might be dead, but it continues to twitch. Long after its disappearance as the common tongue of Europe, it survives as a remarkably successful brand, exuding dignity and permanence. Its numerals add prestige to luxury cars, the dials of expensive watches and every new edition of the Super Bowl. A Latin inscription, like nothing else, indicates lofty purpose and high culture, even when it appears on celebrity flesh. Quod me nutrit me destruit (What nourishes me destroys me), proclaims the stomach of Angelina Jolie. Much more impressive than the now effaced Billy Bob.

title: Man Who Admits 6 Killings Is Tied to More
description: Law enforcement officials said Thursday that there was strong evidence that the imprisoned rapist who confessed this week to murdering six women more than 25 years ago in Cape Girardeau, Mo., and Carbondale, Ill., also killed women in as many as three other jurisdictions.

title: Leaping Borders, Stylistic and Global
description: The Lyric Chamber Music Society of New York is celebrating its 10th anniversary with a season built around the notion of music as a universal language, with programs focusing either on a single country or region, or on the interplay among several. Concerts have been devoted to French and American music, and explorations of German, Austrian, Cuban and Russian works are scheduled through the spring. But the societys program at the Kosciuszko Foundation on Wednesday evening was about crossing boundaries, geographical as well as stylistic.

title: Pop and Rock Listings
description: POP

title: Ogres for All Ages
description: Children may know William Steig as the creator of Shrek, but their grandparents can trace the ornery green ogres roots through a body of childrens books, New Yorker cartoons and drawings dating back to the Depression. Neither group will be disappointed by the Jewish Museums exhibition From The New Yorker to Shrek: The Art of William Steig. The show is a child pleaser that does not stint on the adult biography of the thrice-divorced, periodically depressed Steig (pronounced with a long i and a hard g).

title: Lice in Fish Farms Endanger Wild Salmon, Study Says
description: Parasites that breed in fish farms kill so many passing juvenile wild salmon that they threaten the survival of fish populations in some rivers and streams, Canadian researchers are reporting.

title: After the Moneys Gone
description: On Wednesday, the Federal Reserve announced plans to lend $40 billion to banks. By my count, its the fourth high-profile attempt to rescue the financial system since things started falling apart about five months ago. Maybe this one will do the trick, but I wouldnt count on it.

title: Songs for a Brighter Tomorrow
description: Can singing change history? The Singing Revolution, a documentary by James Tusty and Maureen Castle Tusty about Estonias struggle to end Soviet occupation, shows that it already has.

title: Queens: School Locked After Threat
description: Students at the Glen Oaks School campus were confined to their classrooms for about two hours and kept beyond their normal 2:30 p.m. dismissal after a note threatening seven students was found on Thursday, the police said. Two girls in 11th grade at the High School of Teaching, Liberal Arts and Sciences, one of five public schools on the campus, in Bellerose, were arrested Thursday night in connection with the note, but investigators declined to identify them and said that the exact charges were still being determined. The police said the note, signed Anonymous, included a suicide threat and was found about 1:45 p.m. in a mailbox outside the office of an assistant principal. The police were immediately called, and all students were ordered to remain in place until they were dismissed without incident at 3:50 p.m.

title: Crash Victims Remembered
description: A memorial service Thursday marked the 30th anniversary of an airplane crash that killed 29 people, including the entire Evansville mens team. A wreath with purple and white flowers was placed at a crash memorial monument on a campus plaza.The team plane, a twin-engine DC-3, crashed in rain and heavy fog on Dec. 13, 1977, after takeoff from Evansville Dress Regional Airport to Murfreesboro, Tenn..

title: Figure Skaters Can Fly
description: To the Editor:

title: Say It Aint So, Roger, and Barry, and . . .
description: Yesterdays report from the former Senator George Mitchell makes it inescapably clear that major league baseball is permeated with a win-at-all-costs drug culture that has spread far beyond a handful of all-star performers. Most everyone knew that Barry Bonds, holder of the career home-run record, was being tried for perjury after denying that he used steroids. But it is dismaying to find that dozens of other players were also implicated in the report as users of performance-enhancing drugs, including the redoubtable Roger Clemens, who won the Cy Young award a record seven times, and seven winners of baseballs most valuable player award.

title: Yes, Gamers, There Is Holiday Fun Without a Wii
description: Hanukkah is over. Christmas is less than two weeks away. This is the big time for all kinds of businesses, but for no mode of entertainment (except maybe the Rockettes) is the holiday season more frenzied than video games. The last months of the year are when game companies throw open their warehouses and when even nongamers get caught up trying to find the latest must-have title or system for a player they know and love.

title: Roars of Argentinas Past, Murmurs of Its Present
description: The man in the photograph attacks a giant egg with a pickaxe. He is the sculptor Frederico Manuel Peralta Ramos, and he is destroying his own creation in a 1965 museum exhibition on the cover of the catalog for Beginning With a Bang! From Confrontation to Intimacy, an exhibition about contemporary Argentine art at the Americas Society.

description: TRENTON  It could have been a lot worse.

title: New Jersey Assembly Votes to End Death Penalty
description: TRENTON  The death knell for New Jerseys death penalty was sounded on Thursday as the General Assembly approved a bill eliminating capital punishment, a move that clears the way for Gov. Jon S. Corzine to sign the measure as early as Monday.

title: Out of Warhols Inner Circle Into the Void
description: Twenty years after his death, Andy Warhol continues to exert a powerful, almost queasy fascination, not only because of his work  which has proven more durable and interesting than it may have seemed before  but also because of the enigma of his personality. He has become a recurrent figure in movies, documentary and otherwise, where he is often inscrutable and vaguely sinister, a watchful predator in relation to the young people who surrounded him in the 1960s Factory days.

title: JetBlue Sells Stake to Lufthansa for $300 Million
description: JetBlue, the struggling discount carrier, sold a 19 percent stake in its business to Lufthansa of Germany for $300 million Thursday, the first major investment by a foreign airline in an American rival since British Airways took a stake in American Airlines in the early 1990s.

title: Albany: Special Session for Senate
description: The Senate convened Thursday for a special session, but accomplished little beyond reinforcing how far apart state leaders remain on a number of issues. The Senate, dominated by Republicans, passed a largely symbolic bill granting state judges their first raises in nearly a decade, but Senate officials privately acknowledged that the move was made largely to antagonize Democrats. Lawmakers have not had a raise since 1999, and Assembly Democrats in particular have insisted that they receive a raise along with judges. The issue, however, has become tied up among a number of measures being negotiated between the houses and Gov. Eliot Spitzer. Lawmakers earn a base salary of $79,500 but often make much more from stipends for leadership and committee positions.

title: Argentine Leader Faults U.S. on Inquiry
description: BUENOS AIRES  Argentinas new president, Cristina Fernndez de Kirchner, lashed out at the United States on Thursday for meddling in Latin American affairs after American prosecutors in Miami alleged that a suitcase stuffed with $800,000 was intended to be a secret contribution to her campaign.

(Unless noted, church choirs are featured in church concerts.)

description: Less than three months after Microsoft lost a landmark antitrust case in Europe, a Norwegian software company filed a new complaint Thursday, challenging the software giants bundling of its Web browser with its Windows operating system.

title: Catching a Break and Throwing Down With Imus
description: A MIDCAREER comedian in the touchy process of resigning himself to not making the comedy A-list in this lifetime, Tony Powell was minding his own business, teaching high school in Coney Island and picking up the odd stand-up comedy gig, when he received the glad tidings. Seductive tidings, that is.

title: Albany: Grant for Tracking Students
description: The New York State Board of Regents announced on Thursday that it had been awarded more than $6 million in grants from the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation and the Wallace Foundation to improve the way it keeps track of graduation rates from high schools and colleges. A new system will track student progress through college. The system is intended to streamline the way school districts and state and city colleges keep track of student success. Currently, each district and college keeps track of its own statistics, making it difficult to make comparisons or know how well each student is performing after elementary, middle or high school. The grants will also finance a $3 million contract to study the effectiveness of the State Department of Education.

title: Ex-Premier of Canada Admits Error
description: OTTAWA  Former Prime Minister Brian Mulroney acknowledged to a parliamentary committee on Thursday that he had accepted large cash payments from a German-Canadian arms dealer and lobbyist beginning in 1993 and that his action showed an error in judgment. But he strenuously denied that the action was illegal.

title: Switzerland: Right-Wing Party Leaves Government
description: The popular right-wing Swiss Peoples Party, Switzerlands biggest, pulled out of the coalition cabinet, ending nearly a half-century of consensus government. The partys announcement that it would place itself in opposition came a day after Parliament voted to deny the partys leader, Christoph Blocher, re-election to a seat in the cabinet in favor of a more moderate member.

title: From Memories, Theres No Escape
description: Much like the best-selling novel on which its based, The Kite Runner tells the story of an Afghan refugee who, long after arriving in America, sifts through memories of his cosseted childhood, his emotionally remote father, his devoted best friend, the kites they flew and the stories they shared. The back of my paperback copy of this Khaled Hosseini novel is sprinkled with words like powerful and haunting and riveting and unforgettable. Its a good guess that this film will be rolled around in a similarly large helping of lard.

title: A President Gets His Way, but There May Be a Cost
description: WASHINGTON  With Democrats beginning to give in to the White House on energy and spending bills, and with their hopes of expanding a popular childrens health program all but dashed, President Bush has scored three political victories this week on Capitol Hill.

description: TRY this, said Martha Clyde, manager of the Sculpterra Winery and Sculpture Garden in Paso Robles, Calif., as she poured a garnet 2005 cabernet sauvignon on a golden autumn afternoon. It was the first vintage we released. Neil Young sang beseechingly in the background as a dozen amateur tasters sniffed and swirled and swallowed. The tasting room was brand new, Ms. Clyde said, completed only in late October.

title: Treaty on Running European Union Is Signed
description: BRUSSELS  Gathering in a 16th-century monastery in Lisbon, European Union leaders signed a new treaty on Thursday that changes the way the 27-member bloc is run. Those changes include the creation of a permanent post of European Union president to represent Europe on the world stage.

title: Jets Feel They Can Beat Patriots, Even if Oddsmakers Dont

title: In the Mansion Land of the Fifth Avenoodles
description: THIS time of year one of Manhattans signature pleasures is a stroll up Fifth Avenue from 59th Street on a crisp, clear weekend morning. To your left, the trees of Central Park stubbornly clutch fistfuls of green and yellow leaves. To your right, doormen in long coats and matching caps stamp their feet at the discreet entrances to the citys most exclusive residential buildings. And strung like pearls all up the avenue are fine mansions built by captains of industry and robber barons around the turn of the 20th century.

title: Steroid Report Cites Collective Failure
description: Former Senator George J. Mitchell released a blistering report Thursday that tied 89 Major League Baseball players, including Roger Clemens, to the use of illegal, performance-enhancing drugs. The report used informant testimony and supporting documents to provide a richly detailed portrait of what Mr. Mitchell described as baseballs steroids era.

title: Lottery Numbers
Man About Town, and Very Alone
description: Not if you were the last man on earth! Plenty of guys have heard that line at some point in their lives, but its unlikely that Will Smith is one. His irresistible charm has been proved, above all, by his ability to attract audiences to bad movies like Hitch and Wild Wild West, as well as to better ones like Ali and The Pursuit of Happyness. In spite of its third-act collapse into obviousness and sentimentality, I Am Legend  in which Mr. Smith plays somebody with every reason to believe that he really is the last man on earth  is among the better ones.

title: Probation for Trader in Oil-for-Food Fraud
description: Ludmil Dionissiev, an oil trader, was sentenced in New York to two years of probation and a $5,000 fine for his role in a conspiracy to defraud the United Nations oil-for-food program in Iraq during Saddam Husseins rule. He pleaded guilty in August to federal fraud and conspiracy charges after admitting that he had negotiated purchases of Iraqi oil for a Texas oil company, Bayoil USA, at illegally inflated prices.

title: As Their Scoring Decreases, the Giants Concern Increases
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Giants are winning games and are scoring less, and no one seems sure why.

title: Lucian Freud Stripped Bare
description: The achievement of the strenuously lionized British realist painter Lucian Freud has not so much been to break new ground as to dig incessantly deeper into the old. By doing so he has intensified our understanding of figurative paintings familiar landmarks to the point of discomfort.

title: Mozart, Dickens and a Visit From St. Nicholas
description: A sampling of holiday celebrations, including dance and theater events, in New York City. Admission is free unless otherwise noted. (Churches accept donations.)

title: In Rebel Region, Ethiopia Turns to Civilian Patrols
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The Ethiopian government, one of Americas top allies in Africa, is forcing untrained civilians  including doctors, teachers, office clerks and employees of development programs financed by the World Bank and United Nations  to fight rebels in the desolate Ogaden region, according to Western officials, refugees and Ethiopian administrators who recently defected to avoid being conscripted.

title: Directors Offer Talks, Compounding Writers Plight
description: LOS ANGELES  Movie and television directors said Thursday that they were prepared to begin bargaining toward a new contract with production companies after the New Year holiday, a move that could realign Hollywoods troubled labor front.

title: Saying Tests Are Working, Fehr Awaits Change
description: Four hours after George J. Mitchell released his report on baseballs steroids culture and recommended sweeping changes to the sports antidoping effort, and 90 minutes after Commissioner Bud Selig proclaimed a desire to follow those suggestions, Donald M. Fehr, the executive director of the players union, responded to the report with a far more measured tone.

title: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
description: Previously recorded: $2,855,998.89

title: Agency Approves Drug to Treat Genetic Disorder That Can Lead to Retardation
description: The Food and Drug Administration on Thursday approved the first drug to treat a rare genetic disorder that can lead to mental retardation, possibly allowing some people to relax a regimented diet now used to control the disease.

title: Arizona: Sheriff Sued Over Possible Profiling
description: A Mexican citizen legally in the United States has sued the Maricopa County Sheriffs Office, claiming its aggressive immigration enforcement has led to ethnic profiling. The lawsuit, filed Wednesday in federal court, outlines several instances where Sheriff Joe Arpaio and his deputies are accused of overstepping their authority. Sheriff Arpaio called the suit frivolous and said it was an effort to intimidate him before his office begins enforcing a new law on Jan. 1 that threatens employers with penalties if they hire illegal workers. The suit seeks a judgment that Sheriff Arpaios actions are unconstitutional and the disbanding of the Illegal Immigration Interdiction unit. The suit is based on the claims of Manuel de Jesus Ortega Melendres, a retired teacher, who was stopped by deputies on Sept. 26 in suburban Cave Creek.

title: Muslim Moderates Do Speak Out Against Extremism
description: To the Editor:

title: On the Trail of No-Cover Music
description: 1. Lucilles at B. B. King Blues Club & Grill

title: Frank O. Braynard, Ship Maven, Dies at 91
description: Frank O. Braynard, the organizer of Operation Sail, the historic 1976 gathering of tall ships in New York Harbor that heralded the start of the citys recovery, died Monday in Glen Cove, N.Y. He was 91 and lived nearby in Sea Cliff, N.Y.

title: Acquittal in Hiring for Mob Murder
description: A pizzeria operator charged with hiring assassins to kill a Genovese crime family associate in Brooklyn in 1994 was cleared of the charges Thursday night for a second time.

title: Stories of Vietnam Veterans, Aloud
description: The line between an exhibit and who comes to see it blurred on Thursday in the man with the blue pinstripe suit standing quietly in the Brooklyn Historical Society. The Purple Heart they gave him is in a glass case, and he cherishes it, but he carries a lot more metal than that in his 59-year-old back and hands. Part man, part artifact.

title: Long Underwear and Other Cool Gifts
description: LETS talk thermal underwear. Once it was the last thing people thought about when it came to snow sports fashion. These days, there is status in what you wear for a base layer.

title: Brazil: Tax Blow for Da Silva
description: In a major legislative defeat for President Luiz Incio Lula da Silva, the Senate refused to renew an unpopular tax on financial transactions like checks and A.T.M. withdrawals. The tax accounts for $22 billion of government revenue and fuels Mr. da Silvas programs for the poor.

title: Industry Flexes Muscle, Weaker Energy Bill Passes
description: WASHINGTON  Pared-down energy legislation cleared the Senate on Thursday by a wide margin after the oil industry and utilities succeeded in stripping out provisions that would have cost them billions of dollars.

title: No Delay on F.C.C. Vote
description: The Federal Communications Commission chairman, Kevin J. Martin, has rejected a senators request to delay a vote on a change in media-ownership rules.

title: Movie Guide and Film Series
description: MOVIES

title: Foreign Aid Effort
description: To the Editor:

title: Lives Are Growing Harder, Hispanics Say in Survey
description: After a year of stepped-up enforcement against illegal immigration and polarized debate on the issue, about half of the Hispanics in the United States now fear that they or a relative or close friend could be deported, a report released Thursday by the Pew Hispanic Center found.

title: News Corp. Completes Takeover of Dow Jones
description: Rupert Murdoch won his long-coveted prize Thursday when shareholders of Dow Jones & Company gave their blessing to a takeover by Mr. Murdochs global media empire, the News Corporation.

title: U.S.-China Trade Talks Conclude With Modest Deals and Mutual Wariness
description: XIANGHE, China  The United States and China ended three days of intense economic talks Thursday with accords on food safety, energy and environmental cooperation, but with what Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. acknowledged was only modest progress in opening Chinese financial markets.

title: Senate Panel Votes to Cite 2 Bush Aides
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate Judiciary Committee voted Thursday to hold Joshua B. Bolten, the White House chief of staff, and Karl Rove, former chief political adviser to President Bush, in contempt of Congress for refusing to comply with subpoenas in the panels inquiry on the dismissals of nine federal prosecutors.

title: For China and Vietnam, a Highway Link Means Speedy Growth
description: HONG KONG  On a frontier where Vietnamese and Chinese soldiers exchanged bullets in a short but bloody war nearly three decades ago, construction workers from the two countries will soon join forces to build a highway that promises to bring new wealth to their once heavily guarded border regions.

title: Jazz Listings
description: JAZZ

title: After Long Layoff, Woods Shows Midseason Form
description: THOUSAND OAKS, Calif.  For a limited-field event in December, the Target World Challenge that began Thursday at Sherwood Country Club had a decidedly regular-season feel. It mattered not that the first-round leader, Jim Furyk, was coming off a 57-day break, or that Tiger Woods, tied with three other golfers for second place, had not been inside the ropes for 74 days.

title: California: Ruling Against Marijuana Clubs
description: A federal appeals court in San Francisco upheld an 2002 injunction barring three California marijuana clubs from giving the drug to medical patients with a prescription. The ruling by judges on the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit sided with the Justice Department, which first sued the dispensaries in 1998 to stop sales of medical marijuana to patients with a doctors approval, as allowed under a California law approved by voters in 1996. The law has been at the heart of a series of legal battles over state and federal drug laws, which categorize marijuana as illegal. The ruling was likely the last legal recourse for the clubs. In 2001, the United States Supreme Court heard the case and ruled against the California cooperatives.

title: A Jazz Trio Big Enough to Tackle David Bowie
description: The first tour de force came strategically late in the game on Wednesday night, in the first Zankel Hall appearance by the Bad Plus. It began with a delicate flourish: Ethan Iverson at the piano, announcing a major chord. There was a moment of ceremonial silence, and then the outline of a melody, expressed by the bassist Reid Anderson in his deeply resonant tone. Soon Mr. Iverson added a shimmer of reflective atonality, suggesting a hint of Debussy. David King, the drummer, fluttered his brushes against a cymbal.

title: 5 Soldiers Killed in Pakistan Suicide Attack
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  At least five soldiers and two suicide bombers were killed Thursday in Quetta, a city in southwestern Pakistan, when the bombers struck a military checkpoint, military officials said.

title: Site That Tracks Brokers Questioned on Erased Cases
description: As part of a new campaign to educate American investors, Finra, the private regulator for securities firms and stockbrokers, points people to its huge database that tracks brokers who have run into trouble with customers.

title: Bush Says He Hopes Steroid Era Ends Soon
description: WASHINGTON  Revisiting a subject he addressed nearly four years ago, President Bush said Friday that he was troubled by the report linking many prominent baseball players to performance-enhancing substances and that he hoped the steroid era of baseball would soon be history.

title: Money Rubs Off for City Aides Close to Mayor
description: Working for Michael R. Bloomberg, even in the public sector, can be rewarding.

title: Up From the Mines in Tennessee
description: LOOKING down from the hilltop cemetery, Barbara Beaver remembered that when she was a girl growing up in the Tennessee mountains, Copperhill was a blighted but starkly beautiful moonscape. It would kind of make you think of Moab, Utah, she said.

title: Huckabee Is Not Alone in Ignorance on Mormonism
description: Mike Huckabee insists he spoke out of ignorance, not malice against the faith of a Republican rival, Mitt Romney, when he asked, Dont Mormons believe that Jesus and the devil are brothers?

title: Critics Say Labor Board Favors Business
description: Senate and House Democrats attacked the Republican-led National Labor Relations Board at a Congressional hearing on Thursday, saying its recent decisions had favored employers over workers.

title: Commissioner Vows to Act Swiftly on Mitchell Report
description: The way an old, reliable relative never misses a family function, Bud Selig has always been there for baseball. As a longtime fan of the game, a team owner and, eventually, as the commissioner of Major League Baseball, Selig has shown his plain, Midwestern face at every notable low and high moment of the game for several decades.

title: Louisiana: Grants for Schools
description: Three philanthropic groups plan to give $17.5 million for public schools in New Orleans. It is the largest donation by private groups since the system was reorganized after Hurricane Katrina. The grants, from the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, the Doris and Donald Fisher Fund and the Broad Foundation, will be given over three years. They will go to three nonprofits, New Schools for New Orleans, New Leaders for New Schools and Teach for America-Greater New Orleans. New Schools for New Orleans will get $10 million, mainly to support and bolster charter schools. New Leaders for New Schools will get $1 million to train and support 40 principals. Teach for America, which pairs recent college graduates and professionals to urban or rural schools in need for two years, will get $6.5 million to attract teachers for the city.

title: Live Rock on a Small Bankroll
description: THE name on the marquee was Air Supply, and the line went halfway down the block. It was Saturday night at the B. B. King Blues Club & Grill on 42nd Street in Manhattan, and I had no ticket. But I walked right in.

title: Panama: Noriega Gets New Hearing on Extradition
description: The deposed dictator of Panama, Manuel Antonio Noriega, will get a new hearing in Miami to try to avoid extradition to France from the United States, which American officials prefer to sending him home. France wants him on money-laundering charges. Judge Paul C. Huck of Federal District Court in Miami did not immediately set a date but indicated that the hearing would occur later this month.

title: School Recess Gets Gentler, and the Adults Are Dismayed
description: MONTVILLE, Conn.  Children at the Oakdale School here in southeastern Connecticut returned this fall to learn that their traditional recess had gone the way of the peanut butter sandwich and the Gumby lunchbox.

title: Space Station Plans an Inspection Spacewalk
description: WASHINGTON  American astronauts aboard the International Space Station said Thursday that they would perform an extra spacewalk next week to examine malfunctioning joints that turn a set of solar power panels.

title: Integrity of the Judiciary
description: To the Editor:

title: Bolivia Leader Is Mobilizing Armed Forces
description: SANTA CRUZ, Bolivia  President Evo Morales put this nations armed forces on a state of alert on Thursday as four of Bolivias provinces prepared declarations seeking greater autonomy from the central government.

title: Privation and Despair Colored an Algiers Bombers Life
description: ALGIERS  Larbi Charef grew up in a tough neighborhood in Algiers alongside other suicide bombers, with none of the advantages of the university students he killed on Tuesday. A former convict, he was 30 years old when he detonated the explosives packed in his car on an Algiers street.

title: Russia Settles Issues on Iran Nuclear Power Plant
description: MOSCOW  Russia and Iran have resolved a dispute over payments for Irans Bushehr nuclear power plant, the Russian contractor on the project said Thursday, adding that a schedule would soon be set for completing the long-delayed job.

title: Boston Scientific Sells 2 Businesses
description: The Boston Scientific Corporation, the maker of medical devices, said on Thursday that it had agreed to sell its fluid management and venous access businesses for $425 million to the private equity firm Avista Capital Partners.

title: The Folks You Meet on the Border Between Consciousness and Dreams
description: In recent years Francis Ford Coppola has been most famous for the wines hes made, for the legacy hes fiddled with  he released restored versions of two of his earlier films, Apocalypse Now and The Outsiders  and for the female director he sired. Its been 10 very long years since Sofia Coppolas father released a new feature, but now here he is with Youth Without Youth, a narratively ambitious, visually sumptuous surrealist enterprise in which he has tried to bend time and space together as neatly as the folds in an origami swan.

title: Humpty Dumpty Dies, and Jack Is on the Case
description: In this age of Shrek and Enchanted comes The City That Cried Wolf, a theatrical take on fairy tales that conjures its own magic. A mash-up of genres faintly redolent of Who Framed Roger Rabbit, the play takes film noir conventions and thrusts them into Rhyme Town, which is populated by the inhabitants of nursery verse.

title: The Deep-Fried Truth
description: THIS Christmas will probably be greener than any holiday in recent years. The Rockefeller Center tree is now illuminated by energy-efficient bulbs. Greeting cards will be sent online. Carbon offsets might be fashionable seasonal gifts. So what should we be doing about Christmas dinner?

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Saturday about two brothers who plunged 47 stories while preparing to wash windows on a Manhattan building misspelled, in some editions, the surname of a neighbor of the brothers in Linden, N.J., who described the men as industrious and family-oriented. She is Iwona Roszkowska, not Rosckowski.

title: The Road Trip of 2 Lifetimes, and Still Going
description: WHEN Roberta and Rowena Wright first started traveling together, their father had to use a crank to get the car going. But once they got moving, they never stopped.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: The Pasadena Journal article on Wednesday, about a Texas homeowner, Joe Horn, who killed two men breaking into a house next door, misstated the surname of Mr. Horns lawyer. He is Charles T. Lambright, not Lambrecht.

title: Now You See Me
description: Look, an unsettling, rudely funny but not entirely credible feature by the writer and director Adam Rifkin, is an ensemble narrative for the age of public surveillance.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article in The Arts on Thursday about a promised gift of 130 artworks from Janice and Henri Lazarof to the Los Angeles County Museum of Art included an outdated reference to tax law governing partial donations. (The museum now owns a small percentage of each work, and the remainder is to be transferred over time.) Under the current law, the tax deduction for partial gifts does not rise from year to year if works appreciate in value. Thus donors no longer benefit from bigger deductions for such appreciation.

title: House Passes Restrictions on Interrogation Methods
description: WASHINGTON  Defying a veto threat from President Bush, the House of Representatives voted Thursday to prohibit waterboarding and other harsh interrogation methods used by the Central Intelligence Agency against high-level prisoners from Al Qaeda.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: The Saturday Interview column in Business Day last week, about the turnaround efforts of the retailer Eddie Bauer, misstated one achievement, based on a comment by its chief executive, McNeil S. Fiske Jr., of the companys founder. While Eddie Bauer was an outdoorsman and athlete, he did not climb Mount Everest.

title: Shut It Mostly, or Shut It All?
description: YOUVE waited for as long as possible. But the days are shorter, the shadows longer and the weather frigid. Its time to face the cold, hard facts: winter is here, and its time to close down your warm-weather vacation home.

title: For Appalachian State, a Bigger Game Looms
description: BOONE, N.C.  When Appalachian State of the supposedly lesser Football Championship Subdivision opened its season by winning at mighty Michigan, it was called the upset of the century in college football.

title: Notes From the Global War on Terror
description: During the presidential campaign, candidates from both parties will warn of the risk of another terrorist attack on this country. Americans should insist that they also explain how they will repair the damage President Bush has done to Americas intelligence-gathering capabilities in the name of fighting terrorism.

title: U.S. Falters in Terror Case Against 7 in Miami
description: MIAMI  One of seven indigent men charged with plotting to blow up the Sears Tower in Chicago as part of an Islamic jihad was acquitted on Thursday, and a mistrial was declared in the prosecution of the six others after the jury said it was hopelessly deadlocked.

title: Finding Their Own Way on Christmas
description: NOTHING gives you the No Chair in the Great Musical Chairs Game of Life quite like being a Jew on Christmas Day. Yes, you can horn in on a friends celebration. As a child, I remember pricking many a finger as I strung together pieces of (bloody) popcorn. In general, though, my family spent Christmas at a Chinese restaurant outside Boston. A dumpling is a celebration  that niggling point about pork aside  and I could suffer the 24 hours of the holiday with the help of my board-game-playing siblings.

title: Nevada: Western States Sign Water Pact
description: Seven Western states have signed an interstate water-sharing agreement that officials hail as a way to blunt the impact of drought on states that draw from the Colorado River. Interior Secretary Dirk Kempthorne also signed the agreement at a ceremony at the Colorado River Water Users Association meeting in Las Vegas. Mr. Kempthorne called the pact the most important agreement since the states began sharing water from the river in 1922. The 20-year operations plan involves Arizona, California, Colorado, Nevada, New Mexico, Utah and Wyoming.

title: Michigan: Settlement in Students Death
description: Eastern Michigan University will pay $2.5 million to the family of a student raped and killed in her dorm room a year ago, university and family representatives said. The settlement does not include any admission of liability on the part of the university. The slaying of student, Laura Dickinson, 22, of Hastings, drew attention to security at the university in Ypsilanti. The universitys president was fired in the wake of a cover-up of information about the slaying. Ms. Dickinson was found dead on Dec. 15, 2006. A fellow student, Orange Taylor III of Southfield, was charged, but his first trial ended in a hung jury. He is awaiting a second trial.

title: A Rascal Among Them: Puritan Piety, Shaw Style
description: George Bernard Shaw loved to play devils advocate, which was never more apparent than in this early comedy that provides a defense for a rascally drinker who announces in a Puritan New Hampshire household that hes at the service of Lucifer.

title: Manhattan: Scaffold Had 10 Violations
description: The scaffold that collapsed atop an Upper East Side building last week, sending two window washers plunging 47 stories in an accident that killed one of them, was cited in the summer for 10 violations by a State Labor Department inspector. The 10 violations were relatively minor, a department spokesman said on Thursday, and the inspector did not have to order the scaffold shut down. A spokesman for the Solow Management Corporation, which owns the building at 265 East 66th Street, said the violations had been corrected and had nothing to do with the accident. The window washer who survived, Alcides Moreno, remained in critical condition at NewYork-Presbyterian/Weill Cornell hospital.

title: Haunted by a Muse Under an Unsheltering Sky
description: Racial identity, feminism, literature, sexuality and Elizabethan history combine in a provocative rumination in On the Way to Timbuktu, a solo show, written and performed by Petronia Paley at the Ensemble Studio Theater. It is no small feat to sustain for about 80 minutes a monologue incorporating such heady ingredients, and harder still to keep it compelling. But Ms. Paley, an actress of striking range, authority and stamina, largely manages it.

title: Theater Listings
description: PETER AND THE WOLF Lots of holiday shows rope in their victims with false promises of fun for all ages. But its hard to see how a theatrical event that includes miniature paper sculptures of animals, George Manahan conducting the Juilliard Ensemble and (this is important) Isaac Mizrahi could fail to delight anybody.

title: A Worrisome New Wrinkle in Bailouts
description: The financial market crisis of 2007 may be remembered as the beginning of the nationalization of a large part of the financial system. This week, it took a government bailout to shore up UBS. Last month, it was Citigroup that got government aid to help recover from its bad investments.

title: Lehmans Earnings Fall 12% in a Season That Could Have Been Worse
description: Lehman Brothers ushered in a bleak earnings season for Wall Street on Thursday by saying quarterly profit fell 12 percent, reflecting a slump in its core fixed-income business.

title: Opposition Leads South Korean Polls
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The candidate of South Koreas conservative opposition party in next weeks presidential election, a hard-driving former chief executive of Hyundai Construction & Engineering, South Koreas best-known builder and icon of its breakneck industrialization, has surged far ahead of his rivals in the last opinion polls allowed before the balloting.

title: Exiled to a War Zone, for His Safety
description: When Augustus Massalee walked through the arrivals gate at Kennedy International Airport, he seemed to have shrunk two sizes. Layers of muscle had disappeared from his shoulders, and his face had thinned so much that the customs official did not recognize him from his passport photo. His accent, which once identified him as a tough kid from Staten Island, was now unmistakably African.

title: Carbon Dioxide Threatens Reefs, Report Says
description: Carbon dioxide in the air is turning the oceans acidic, and without a reduction in emissions, coral reefs may die away by the end of the century, researchers warn in Fridays issue of the journal Science. Carbon dioxide dissolves into ocean water, changes to carbonic acid, and carbonic acid dissolves the calcium carbonate in the skeletons of corals. Laboratory experiments have shown that corals possess some ability to adapt to warmer waters but no ability to adapt to the higher acidity. Unless we reverse our actions very quickly, by the end of the century, reefs could be a thing of the past, said Ken Caldeira, a scientist at the Carnegie Institutions department of global ecology and an author of the Science paper.

title: Former Trainer Puts Yankees Stars Under Microscope
description: Roger Clemens has long been known for his intense workouts, sessions that helped him pitch effectively into his mid 40s and receive acclaim as one of the most dominant pitchers ever. Andy Pettitte, Clemenss close friend and Yankees teammate, adopted those workouts. But both pitchers may have been harboring secrets about an unsavory aspect of their regimen.

title: British Inquiry of Failed Plots Points to Iraqs Qaeda Group
description: This article is by Raymond Bonner, Jane Perlez and Eric Schmitt.

title: Final Iowa Debate Is Mostly Placid for Democrats
description: In the final Democratic presidential debate of the year on Thursday, both Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and Senator Barack Obama were put on the spot about leadership: Whether she tended to be too secretive and insular, and whether he could mold a new foreign policy when many of his advisers worked in Bill Clintons White House.

title: At 89, She Steps Lively in the Name of Volunteerism
description: Mary Shalo has some sage advice for those seeking the fountain of youth: Volunteer.

title: So Many Presidential Debates, So Little Concern Shown for Cities
description: In mid-October, I noted that the Democrats and Republicans had held 17 or so presidential debates (the number can vary, depending on whos counting), but that with all the gabbing they managed not to focus on Americas cities.

title: Familiar Faces With a Digital Makeover
description: Hollywood continues its tired milking of old television properties with Alvin and the Chipmunks, a slick updating of the musical-cartoon franchise created by Ross Bagdasarian Sr. in 1958. Remodeled over the years on television and recordings, the munks have been given a digital coat of paint this time out, but the movie doesnt skimp  lasso those nostalgic parents!  on the memories of old.

title: Campaign on Childhood Mental Illness Succeeds at Being Provocative
description: We have your son. We will make sure he will no longer be able to care for himself or interact socially as long as he lives.

title: Arizona Is Split Over Hard Line on Immigrants
description: PHOENIX  A new Arizona law against employing illegal immigrants has shaken businesses, scared workers, delighted advocates of stricter immigration controls and added to tensions in a state split over who belongs here and who does not.

title: The Fine Art of House Dismantling
description: John Harris, a British architectural historian, has an unusual specialty. Rather than focusing on the creation and construction of architects designs, he looks at them once theyve been taken apart.

title: Biden Campaigning With Ease After Hardships
description: IOWA CITY  Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware, a back-in-the-pack Democratic candidate for president, was answering a voters question last week about negative campaigning when he abruptly began talking about his first, euphoric run for the Senate, in 1972, and the personal tragedy that nearly destroyed his life afterward.

title: Not Yet Winter, but Starting to Look a Lot Like It
description: Maybe, just maybe, the New York region is going to have a real winter.

title: Violent Day in Iraq Begins With Liquor Store Bombings
description: BAGHDAD  Homemade bombs hit two Baghdad liquor stores early Thursday, and attacks in several other parts of the city killed two people and wounded at least seven others. Eleven more deaths were reported from attacks outside Baghdad, and 19 bodies were found in Baghdad and elsewhere.

title: Manhattan: Extradition on Drug Charge
description: A man who prosecutors claim led an international heroin-smuggling operation has been extradited from Austria to face charges in Federal District Court in Manhattan, prosecutors said Thursday. The man, Hussein Karimi, an Iranian then living in Romania, was arrested in March as he tried to enter Azerbaijan, said Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney in Manhattan. Mr. Garcia said Mr. Karimi was charged after a joint investigation between the Drug Enforcement Administration and Romanian law enforcement officials into a smuggling operation that sent millions of dollars of heroin to Europe, Canada and the United States.

title: Port Lawrence and Cocoplum Resort Community
description: Port Lawrence

title: Rhode Island: Insurer to Pay Millions
description: Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Rhode Island will pay $20 million but avoid criminal charges after a federal investigation into improper lobbying of state legislators by its executives. Under an agreement, Blue Cross will cooperate with prosecutors in a continuing investigation, accept increased oversight for two years and acknowledge responsibility for the conduct of its executives. Four Blue Cross executives left the company on Tuesday. The agreement says Blue Cross executives lobbied three former state lawmakers for favors, in total, paying them hundreds of thousands of dollars.

title: David Maybury-Lewis, Who Studied Native Tribes, Dies at 78
description: David Maybury-Lewis, an anthropologist whose studies of native tribes in Amazonia pushed him, as the learned visage of a popular series on PBS, to advocate for the preservation of other indigenous groups, died on Dec. 2 at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 78.

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article on Nov. 29 about the diplomatic style of Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice, including her handling of the Middle East, referred incorrectly to President Bushs position on the fate of Palestinian refugees in his remarks on Nov. 27 at the Middle East peace conference in Annapolis, Md. While Mr. Bush called Israel a homeland for the Jewish people, this was an implicit support for Israels view that Palestinians should not be guaranteed a right of return to their former homes inside Israel. Mr. Bush did not explicitly take on that issue and side with Israel.

title: Gore Joins Chorus Chiding U.S. at Climate Talks
description: NUSA DUA, Indonesia  Amid growing frustration with the United States over deadlocked negotiations at a United Nations conference on global warming, the European Union threatened Thursday to boycott separate talks proposed by the Bush administration in Hawaii next month.

title: Crimes Against Children Set Off a Debate About Care
description: BERLIN  In recent weeks Germany has been flooded with tales of the neglect, abuse and even murder of children. What would be shocking anywhere has been a particularly hard blow in a rapidly aging country with an anemic birthrate.

title: Economy Holding Up, Reports Find
description: Maybe the American economy is not going to keel over just yet, after all.

title: Teachers United
description: In Arranged two devout Brooklyn schoolteachers clutch hands across the religious divide as their respective families prepare to marry them off.

title: Democrats Soften Tone for Final Debate in Iowa
description: In the final Democratic presidential debate of the year Thursday, both Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama were put on the spot about leadership: whether she tended to be too secretive and insular, and whether he could mold a new foreign policy when many of his advisers had worked in Bill Clintons White House.

title: A Cloudy Forecast for UMass's Survival Turned Out to Be Wrong
description: AMHERST, Mass.  When Sam Koch was hired in 1991 to coach mens soccer at the University of Massachusetts, he was viewed less as a savior than an undertaker.

title: Art in Review
description: TINO SEHGAL

title: Clinics That Offered Antifat Injections Close
description: A national chain of cosmetic medical clinics that popularized antifat injections denounced by medical groups shut its doors last week in the wake of dozens of complaints from consumers asking for their money back.

title: Does Free Speech Give a Fan the Right to Heckle?
description: A spectator who heckled Knicks Coach Isiah Thomas on Wednesday night received a printed warning card from a security guard to stop what he was doing or face ejection from Madison Square Garden.

title: Democrats Eye 'Freedom's Watch'
description: As Representative Chris Van Hollen of Maryland left a Capitol leadership meeting on the Congressional spending mess last Tuesday afternoon, he quickly ducked past reporters pressing him for details of the Democratic budget strategy.

title: French Officials Hounded by Criticism Over Qaddafi Visit
description: PARIS  During his five-day sojourn in Paris, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi has tooled around the city in a white Mercedes limousine, paralyzing traffic as he has stopped by places like the presidential lyse Palace, the National Assembly, the Ritz and the Louvre.

title: New Jersey Moves to End Its Death Penalty
description: TRENTON  The New Jersey General Assembly approved a bill eliminating capital punishment on Thursday, clearing the way for Gov. Jon S. Corzine to sign the measure as early as Monday.

title: Attorney General Rejects Demand for Information
description: WASHINGTON  Attorney General Michael B. Mukasey has firmly rejected Congressional demands that he provide information about the Justice Departments investigation into the Central Intelligence Agencys destruction of videotapes showing interrogations, a stance that inflamed a feud between Capitol Hill and the administration this afternoon.

title: A Year Later, the Same Scene: Long Lines for the Elusive Wii
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Linda Beattie is trying desperately to pay Nintendo $250, but the company is not cooperating.

title: Discovery Holding to Become Public in 2008 Offering
description: The owners of Discovery Communications, Advance/Newhouse and Discovery Holding, have agreed in principle to combine their stakes and turn the company, an operator of cable TV channels, into an independent, publicly traded company.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings
description: CLASSICAL

title: Harsh Realities and Mystical Power
description: For his poetic fourth feature, Half Moon, the Kurdish-Iranian writer and director Bahman Ghobadi returns to the breathtaking desolation of the Kurdish borderlands and the enduring optimism of his people.

title: Lost an Item in a Subway? Good Luck for Its Return
description: Cellphones. Cameras. Keys. A jacket. A wristwatch. A Walkman. A womans pocketbook. An electric shaver. Those are some of the 26 items that a team of investigators turned over to subway and bus workers last year, explaining that they had found them on buses and trains.

title: 5 California Men Are Charged in Fire That Burned 53 Homes in California
description: LOS ANGELES  Five men were charged on Thursday in connection with a brush fire that destroyed dozens of homes in Malibu in November.

title: In New Orleans, Plan to Raze Low-Income Housing Draws Protest
