title: Ask Ming Hung Wong a Question
description: Welcome back to our expert roundtable discussion of Chinas environmental crisis. To ask a question or make a comment on the issues raised by the eighth article in the series on the problems caused by Chinas booming aquaculture industry, write to us using the comments box below.

title: 2007, Year of the Proposed Ban
description: What were reading elsewhere

title: Life by WindLight
description: On The Medium, were resolving in 2008 to spend more time with our freaky friends who have forsaken good old Real Life for good new Second Life.

title: Thug Snacks? This Councilman Wont Bite
description: Remember Cocaine, the highly caffeinated soft drink whose name was changed after a storm of negative publicity?

title: Show of Hands: Was This a Defining Moment?
description: When Fred Thompson refused to answer a question during Wednesdays debate about whether climate change was real and caused by human activity, we thought it livened up a rather dull affair but hardly considered it a defining moment.

title: Rollins Joins Huckabee Campaign
description: CONCORD, N.H.  Mike Huckabee announced Friday that the G.O.P. political strategist Ed Rollins, who helped craft the partys appeal to working class Democrats during the Reagan years, would assume the role of Mr. Huckabees national campaign chairman.

title: M.T.A. Expands Service on No. 7 and L Lines
description: Certain Queens and Brooklyn commuters can rejoice. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced this afternoon that service will expand on the No. 7 and L subway lines next week.

title: ABC Announces New Year Line-Up (And Prays)
description: ABC will roll out a series of scripted and unscripted shows this winter, with the premiere of Cashmere Mafia and new episodes of Lost in January and the return of Dancing With the Stars and The Bachelor in March.

title: Strike: When Will The Late-Night Hosts Return?
description: The strike-sidelined stars of late-night may return to television just in time for Januarys primary election season.

title: Touring the House
description: After a week of showing family, plumbers, contractors and other workers the house, we have become professional tour guides. So I am going to try to give you, the readers, a virtual tour. Youll see where the windows are and how the bathrooms are shaping up, and I hope youll get a better sense of how spacious the rooms are and their orientation.

title: The Week in Pictures for Dec. 14
description: Here is a slide show of 11 photographs that tell the story of the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include SantaCon, the Metropolitan Operas production of War and Peace and the Frank Viola Homing Pigeon Club on Stillwell Avenue in Coney Island.

title: Giuliani: Tested. Ready. Now.
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani never gave a formal announcement speech when he began running for president. Now, after a rocky month, he is planning to give an address in Tampa on Saturday where he will lay out his vision of a Giuliani presidency.

title: Week 15 Fantasy Football Picks
description: Rats!

title: An Armed Resistance
description: Guerrillas from a separatist movement and the Ethiopian government are fighting for control of the Ogaden region, whose residents are starting to flee.

title: Nitkowski Is Glad He Said No to Steroids
description: C.J. Nitkowski was a free agent after the 2001 season, and the drug culture in baseball was rampant. C.J. was interested in taking steroids, and he asked his friend Brian McNamee for his opinion.

title: Kevin Bacon Has Landed
description: DES MOINES  Kevin Bacon is next up in the line of stars rotating through Iowa for John Edwards. Already, the actor has set hearts a-fluttering.

title: Saturday Matchup: Bengals at 49ers
description: The first Saturday night game of the year (8 p.m., NFL Network) is a matchup between two of the most disappointing teams of the season, teams whose players have had more fight among themselves than against opponents.

title: Back in the Air
description: Kite-flying was banned in Afghanistan during Taliban rule, but it is again out in the open, over the hills of Kabul.

title: The Friendliest Country, and the Unfriendliest Skies
description: Most visitors to the Unites States will tell you that service in American restaurants and hotels is generally as friendly and as unpretentious as you will find anywhere. I know that because I grew up in England, where every waiter in a rundown cafe greeted me as I were a summons to the police and every worker in an upscale place as if I were a fly that had landed on the duck  lorange. In Japan, where I now live, service in even a convenience store is efficient, quick and impeccably polite, but you wont get the genuine laughs or banter that you often find in even a bank in New York. Democracy finds its vindication, I often think, in the cheerful, ungrudging attention you get across what is perhaps the worlds most open nation.

title: A Lasso for Listeners: Part Oslo, Part Oklahoma
description: Rune Grammofon, an independent record label based in Oslo, traffics in music of unconventional detail and assiduous design. Its stable of artists, almost exclusively Norwegian, includes electronic programmers, jazz-tangential confabs and some curiously captivating vocalists. What they seem to have in common, besides the endorsement of Rune Kristoffersen, the labels founder and operator, is an ethos of attraction. However opaque or experimental their music becomes, they want to draw you in.

title: 7 Killed by Bomb Blasts in Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD  A rash of bomb blasts and ambushes across Baghdad left seven people dead on Saturday, including three members of American-backed security patrols that were trying to rout insurgents. The attacks came as people across the country were deep in preparations for the holy Muslim holiday of Eid ul-Adha, which follows the annual Islamic pilgrimage to Mecca and begins on Wednesday.

title: Sticker Shock a Hazard, Even When the Artists Are Only Potential Stars
description: I PLOTTED my executive pursuit of starting a contemporary art collection from a supercaffeinated base camp in the Empire Diner at 10th Avenue and West 22nd Street in Manhattan. It was dark and early on a wintery Thursday morning. The sky outside the diners Art Deco-style windows looked like an ominous gray abstraction. But my guide, Simon Watson, a 52-year-old art consultant with close-cropped silver hair and indigo clothes, was in a sunny mood.

title: A Little Here, a Little There and Its Gone
description: WHERE does the money go? As I tallied up our familys income and expenses for the year, I was baffled.

title: Britain Overtakes U.S. as Top World Bank Donor
description: BERLIN  The World Bank, overcoming misgivings about its direction and leadership, said Friday that it had raised $25.1 billion in aid for the worlds poorest countries, a record sum that includes donations by China and Egypt, nations that were once recipients of such aid.

title: Piggybacking on Buybacks
description: SOMETIMES the simplest investing strategies are also the best.

title: Retirement at RBS
description: RBS Greenwich Capital Markets, the American securities unit of Royal Bank of Scotland, said its chief executive, Jay Levine, would leave in March. He is retiring because the subsidiary, based in Greenwich, Conn., will be reorganizing as a result of Royal Banks purchase of ABN Amro Holding. It was really something Jay wasnt interested in, a company spokesman, Peter Ward, said. He really wanted to get to a smaller, more entrepreneurial endeavor.

title: Criticism of Curry Comes From a Big Fan
description: CHICAGO  Eddy Curry came home Friday, only to find humiliation instead of hugs, indignities instead of affection. The ball was still on the rack when it all began. Matters only got worse when the game started.

title: Algeria: U.N. Death Toll Raised to 17
description: The United Nations confirmed that 17 of its staff members died in the bombing of two of its buildings in Algiers on Tuesday, which the government said killed 37 people. Marie Okabe, a spokeswoman for Secretary General Ban Ki-moon, said the earlier toll of 11 dead had risen after more bodies were dug out from the rubble. The United Nations said that all but three of the dead  a Dane, a Filipino and a Senegalese  were thought to be Algerians.

title: Paid in Dollars, Some Americans Are Struggling in Europe
description: PARIS  Erica Nevinss faith in the dollar was shaken the moment she pressed a crumpled $1 bill into the hand of a little girl begging for money on the streets of Marrakesh, Morocco.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about billionaires who push for social change in poorer countries misspelled the surname of one such entrepreneur. He is Warren E. Buffett, not Buffet.

title: Iconoclasm and a Hint of Stalins Heavy Hand
description: Shostakovich wrote his D minor Cello Sonata in 1934 as the terrible Soviet purges of the next five years were about to begin. Its Bolshevik-friendly tone represents a U-turn from the in-your-face iconoclasm of The Nose in 1928 or the seedy verismo of another, just-finished opera, Lady Macbeth of Mtsensk, soon to receive its famous pan from the Soviet Unions critic in chief. Indeed, a bit of Stalin seems to hover behind the sonatas sweetly singing melodies and frantic, dancelike energies, Shostakovichs unique voice notwithstanding.

title: Gazans Rally on Hamas Anniversary
description: GAZA  About 200,000 Gazans rallied in support of Hamas on Saturday, the 20th anniversary of its founding.

title: Politeness of China Talks Cant Disguise the Discord
description: BEIJING  In three days of talks on economic issues this week, a half-dozen Bush administration cabinet members and their aides sat in rows of tables facing their Chinese counterparts in an ornate conference room. The talk was polite, the atmosphere convivial and the pledges of cooperation profuse.

title: The Condition of Faith vs. State in America
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Thursday about a visit to Bethlehem by Tony Blair, the former prime minister of Britain and now an international envoy for Palestinian development, described incompletely Israels policy about the presence of its citizens in the West Bank. While Israeli citizens cannot freely visit Palestinian towns there, tens of thousands of Israelis do live in settlements in the territory.

title: Adding to the List of Worries, Signs That Inflation Is Bubbling Up
description: Economists and central bankers have worried for months that soaring food and energy costs could lead to higher inflation, but investors had shrugged off those concerns, preferring to focus on the slowdown in growth.

title: Ethiopians Said to Push Civilians Into Rebel War
A Star Who Plays Second Fiddle to Music
description: When a star pianist comes into a huge hall wearing a three-piece orange suit, self-effacing is not the description that comes to mind. But when Yefim Bronfman lumbered into Grand Central Terminal in October for a free morning concert to benefit the Food Bank for New York City wearing the organizations colors, he presented a contradictory image: that of a virtuoso making a striking public entrance and that of someone who would have preferred not to be drawing so much attention to himself.

title: Building a Greener Cardboard Box
description: AMERICANS are using more cardboard in different ways each year. But tree replanting and technological advances in making cardboard are easing the environmental impact, says Patrick J. Moore, chairman and chief executive of the Smurfit-Stone Container Corporation, the largest maker of paper-based packaging products, with $7.2 billion in sales in 2006. Mr. Moore, who is based in St. Louis, says recycling programs are also improving the environmental impact of all the packaging that Americans consume. Here are excerpts from a conversation:

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about plans by the Securities and Exchange Commission to delay requiring small companies to adhere to some auditing requirements under the Sarbanes-Oxley Act left the incorrect impression that the S.E.C. chairman, Christopher Cox, was leaving the door open for an indefinite stay of the requirements. As the article noted, testimony prepared for Mr. Cox to deliver to a Congressional panel did not explicitly say that he wanted the commission to require small companies to obey the law after the delay. His testimony, however, did include a reference to a time when, eventually, smaller public companies do come into full compliance with the law.

title: California: Guilty Pleas in Attack Plot
description: Two men accused of plotting in prison to attack military sites, synagogues and other targets pleaded guilty to conspiring to wage war against the United States. The men, Kevin James, 31, and Levar H. Washington, 28, pleaded guilty to seditious conspiracy charges. Mr. Washington also pleaded guilty to using a firearm to further that conspiracy. The authorities say Mr. James, Mr. Washington and two others were part of a California prison gang cell of radical Muslims. The police said they uncovered the plot in July 2005 while investigating gas station robberies that they say were committed to finance the attacks.

title: Prosecutor in DeLay Case Says He Wont Seek Re-election Next Year
description: HOUSTON  Ronnie Earle, the long-serving Texas district attorney who has been leading the criminal prosecution of the former House majority leader, Tom DeLay, said Friday that he would not seek a ninth four-year term next year. Instead, he said, he may run for governor in 2010.

title: Pass Is No Help for Declarer, but One Club Gives the Clue
description: Bridge is a bidders game, or so the modern mantra goes. But overbidders ignore one reality: If you make a bid and become a defender, you have given declarer extra  often vital  information in the quest for his contract.

title: The Cabby Takes Plastic, or at Least Is Supposed To
description: More than half the citys yellow cabs are now fitted with devices to accept credit cards for payment. Drivers fought the credit card plan with an unexpected fury  and it was at least partly responsible for their decision to go on strike twice.

title: Cautiously, Big Labels Confront the Mixtape
description: LOS ANGELES  Early this year, DJ Drama, a mixtape producer who made his name spotlighting new rap talents on his own line of compilation CDs, found himself in a Georgia jail cell after being arrested on charges of racketeering in connection with his recordings. This week, less than a year after authorities raided his studio, and with the case still pending, he found himself in a more agreeable setting: the Billboard album chart.

title: A New Emphasis for the Ministry: Management Skills
description: CHESTNUT HILL, Mass.  For the last four years, Wendy Samuels has worked in a remote village in Jamaica for Mustard Seed Communities, a Roman Catholic nonprofit group that helps disabled children.

title: Robert Kulicke, 83, Artist and Frame Maker, Is Dead
description: Robert M. Kulicke, a painter, goldsmith, teacher, businessman and designer who changed the look of postwar art by modernizing frame design, died on Friday in Valley Cottage, N.Y. He was 83 and had lived in Manhattan until about 18 months ago.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The Weekend Explorer column on Friday, about the Upper East Side, referred imprecisely to the architectural style of the mansion Andrew Carnegie built at the corner of Fifth Avenue and 91st Street and of the town house Woody Allen bought on East 70th Street between Lexington and Park Avenues. They were built after the death of the last King George of Britain in 1830, and thus are Georgian style, not Georgian. The column also misstated the year Carnegie moved into the mansion. It was 1902, not 1901.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A subheading in the NYC column on Friday, about the absence of urban and suburban issues as a topic in the Democratic and Republican presidential debates, referred incorrectly to the type of community that is home to more than 80 percent of the nations population. That proportion lives in metropolitan areas, which include cities and suburbs; the 80 percent figure does not represent urban dwellers only. (About 50 percent of the population is in the suburbs and 30 percent in cities.)

title: Some Charges Dropped Against Former Curator
description: Two years into her criminal trial on charges of conspiracy to acquire looted artifacts, Marion True, a former curator for the J. Paul Getty Museum in California, was dealt a break Friday when lawyers for the Italian state and the region of Sicily dropped civil charges against her regarding 40 artifacts the museum has returned to Italy. Civil claims involving some other artifacts the museum has not returned are still pending against Ms. True, said Maurizio Fiorilli, the lawyer representing the Italian state, at a hearing in Rome. The dismissal of the claims involving the objects was required under an accord between the Getty and Italy signed in September. All of the 40 objects except for a renowned statue of Aphrodite have been returned. They are to go on view next week at the Quirinale, the presidential palace, along with artifacts returned by other American museums and dealers. The Aphrodite is to be handed over in 2010.

title: Going Out, Gervais Picks Bang Over Whimper
description: LOS ANGELES  Ricky Gervais says he decided to make an 80-minute finale to his HBO series Extras because he had a few things left to say about the wages of fame, and the people who pay them.

title: Report Says That the Rich Are Getting Richer Faster, Much Faster
description: The increase in incomes of the top 1 percent of Americans from 2003 to 2005 exceeded the total income of the poorest 20 percent of Americans, data in a new report by the Congressional Budget Office shows.

title: Hamas Arrests Aide to Palestinian Prime Minister
description: JERUSALEM  The Hamas police in Gaza arrested an aide to the Ramallah-based Palestinian prime minister on Friday and held him for questioning, a Hamas spokesman said.

title: Delay Is Sought by Justice Dept. on C.I.A. Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department asked the House Intelligence Committee on Friday to postpone its investigation into the destruction of videotapes by the Central Intelligence Agency in 2005, saying the Congressional inquiry presented significant risks to its own preliminary investigation into the matter.

title: The Enemy at the Gates of Going Undefeated
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  He has been the feared nemesis in the hoodie for so long, with a career wound tightly around his poisoned relationship with the Jets, that it is difficult to pinpoint exactly how Bill Belichicks image crossed the Rubicon from envied champion to football villain.

title: Campaigns Woo 3 Iowans for Papers Endorsement
description: DES MOINES  The other day, as his sport utility vehicle idled outside, former President Bill Clinton held forth on a sofa in the publishers suite at The Des Moines Register, explaining why he believed Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton should win the newspapers coveted endorsement.

title: Player Cooperated, and His Name Was Left Out of Report
description: One active major league player was able to keep his name out of the former Senator George J. Mitchells report on performance-enhancing drugs in baseball, even though Mitchell had evidence that he bought them, Mitchell said in an interview Friday.

title: In Two Nights of Mixed Choreography, a Dancers Star Remains a Constant
description: In 1962, Alvin Ailey choreographed Reflections in D to Duke Ellingtons music as a vehicle for himself. At only three minutes, it was meant as a transition dance, allowing time for other dancers to change their costumes between pieces. But innocent tasks can produce enlightening results, as this work proves. Clifton Brown, making his debut in the solo on Wednesday night at City Center, dived inside the music, providing voluminous breadth to his curving arms as he fluidly moved from one grounded position to the next.

title: Siemens Reverses Decision
description: Siemens, the German engineering giant, revoked the appointment of a finance executive on suspicion that he might have links to a bribery investigation facing the company. Siemens announced a week ago that the executive, Hannes Apitzsch, would become chief financial officer of its industry sector. That sector is a recently created grouping of business lines including automation machinery, building technologies and light bulbs.

title: Plant Will Tour,but Not With Zeppelin
description: Robert Plant will tour with Alison Krauss, dashing the hopes of those who expected Led Zeppelin to mount a reunion tour, BBC News reported. Ms. Krauss and Mr. Plant, above, who released the album Raising Sand in October, will perform across Europe in May and are expected to come to the United States in the summer. Tickets for the tour, which begins in Birmingham, are now on sale. Led Zeppelin, with Mr. Plant as lead singer, played its first concert in 19 years in London on Monday, sparking rumors of a tour.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption on Thursday with an obituary of the musician Ike Turner, using information provided by Getty Images, misstated the date of the photograph of Ike and Tina Turner. While Getty says it does not know the precise date of the picture, it says that it is from 1970 or later, not around 1960 and thus not from the early days of the Ike and Tina Turner Revue.

title: In Kansas, Top Official Announces Resignation
description: Kansas attorney general said Friday that he would resign, less than a week after admitting to an affair with a former employee who says the attorney general also sought information from her about a political rival.

title: An Opera, Unloved by Its Creator, Finds Some Devoted Friends Onstage
description: A few years after the 1844 premiere of I Due Foscari, one of his early (and now seldom heard) operas, Verdi disparaged it as a deadly bore. This gloomy three-act work is certainly dark but not dull, especially given the emotive performances by the soloists when Eve Queler conducted the Opera Orchestra of New York and the New York Choral Ensemble in a concert performance at Carnegie Hall on Thursday night.

title: New York State Theater to Close for Repairs in 2008
description: The New York State Theater will go dark during New York City Operas 2008-9 season so that it can be renovated, the opera said Friday in a joint announcement with New York City Ballet, which shares the stage. But construction will be periodically suspended so that the ballet can proceed with its lucrative holiday Nutcracker and then its winter and spring seasons.

title: Investors Sell on Inflation Data
description: Stocks fell Friday after accelerating inflation spurred concern that higher prices will curb consumer spending and give the Federal Reserve less leeway to cut interest rates.

title: Estranged Londoners, Waist-Deep in Trouble
description: Flood, in which London is largely underwater for four hours, is the kind of disaster movie that when you meet an estranged father and son early on, you know that they will have a wet scene of redemption and reunion by the last act.

title: McQuarters Not Fazed by Threat of Harsh Weather
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  A northeaster is predicted to pound Giants Stadium this weekend, and R. W. McQuarters would seem to be facing the trickiest challenge of any Giants player on Sunday night against the Redskins. One of his jobs is to catch wind-blown punts.

title: Staff Reductions at Nbc News and CBS
description: NBC is replacing the senior producer in charge of the newly created fourth hour of Today as part of a staff reduction at the networks news division. Amy Rosenblum, who joined NBC News after a long stint as executive producer on the syndicated talk show Maury, with Maury Povich, will be leaving Today, where she has worked for two years. Today, the most successful news program on television, this week celebrated its 12th year of winning every week in the morning news competition. Ms. Rosenblum was one of about 15 news employees who will be leaving NBC News, either through buyouts or layoffs. NBC executives said that the reductions were limited and that the news division had added staff members in other areas, such as its education initiatives. But money was a factor in the reductions. Many of those leaving were long-time staff members at high salaries. CBS also announced staff reductions Friday, all at its interactive division, including some news employees. CBS executives would not provide a number but said it would likely be fewer than 20 people.

title: Musharraf Lifts State of Emergency in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  President Pervez Musharraf lifted the six-week-old state of emergency and restored the Constitution on Saturday, after passing a flurry of constitutional amendments and decrees to ensure his recent actions would not be challenged by any court.

title: With Color and Panache, Afghans Fight a Different Kind of War
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The kites appear suddenly, whimsical flashes of color that kick above the beige landscape here of relentless dust and desperation.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about a hearing on a claim by death row inmates in Connecticut that the states death penalty discriminates against minorities misstated the timing of the last execution in the state. Michael Ross, a serial killer, was executed by lethal injection in May 2005; it has not in fact been decades since the state executed anyone. (Go to Article)

title: Letterman Pursuing a Deal With Writers
description: In what may be the first break in the Hollywood writers' strike, David Letterman is pursuing a deal with the Writers Guild of America that would allow his late-night show on CBS to return to the air in early January with the usual complement of material from his writers, even if the strike is still continuing.

title: Wikipedia Competitor Being Tested by Google
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Google is testing a new Web service intended to become a repository of knowledge from experts on various topics, one that could turn into a competitor to Wikipedia and other sites.

title: North Korea Replies to Bush With an Offer and a Condition
description: WASHINGTON  Responding to a recent letter from President Bush, North Korea agreed on Friday to follow through on its pledge to denuclearize the Korean Peninsula, provided the United States reciprocates by normalizing relations between the countries.

title: Ground Zero Health Program Hits a Setback in Washington
description: The future of a national program to provide medical treatment to ground zero workers outside the metropolitan area is in doubt after the federal government abruptly halted the search for a contractor to process medical reimbursements.

title: Strike Ends in Russia
description: The Ford Motor Company and a union representing part of its Russian employees agreed to end a strike that was corroding Fords profit in one of Europes hottest markets. Already, two-thirds of Fords assembly line employees at a plant in Vsevolozhsk, outside St. Petersburg, had broken ranks with the union and returned to work since the strike began Nov. 22. On Friday, the remaining union employees also agreed to return beginning with the late shift on Sunday, though negotiations on salaries and benefits in the 2008 contract continue, according to a statement from Ford. Russia, awash in oil money, is projected to surpass Germany as the largest car market in Europe by the end of the decade.

title: Working on a Degree, and Trying to Learn From Mistakes
description: When he found himself in jail at 18, Jonathan Rosario knew it was time to turn his life around.

title: ABCs Lost Is to Return, and Greys Will Move
description: LOS ANGELES  ABC announced on Friday that it would increase the reality programming on its schedule by more than 50 percent, beginning next month. The shake-up of the networks ratings-leading prime-time schedule is a result of the extended writers strike.

title: Iowas Student Vote
description: College students are legally entitled to vote where they attend school. That makes perfect sense given that they often live in their college communities for four years or more and become eligible to vote for the first time while living there. But not everyone likes this arrangement, and political operatives often try to suppress the student vote. We recently got a glimpse of this process in Iowa, where the presidential caucuses are just weeks away.

title: Senegal Bars a Singer
description: Senegal has barred the reggae star Tiken Jah Fakoly from entering the country after he criticized President Abdoulaye Wade, Agence France-Presse reported. The singer, who is from the Ivory Coast, criticized Mr. Wade during a news conference and afterward at a concert on Wednesday, urging the president to leave office for the good of his country. Senegals interior ministry said Thursday evening that Mr. Fakoly was persona non grata in Senegal for his insolent and discourteous remarks and would be barred from entering the country. The singer had been in Senegal for the International Hip-Hop Awards in Dakar. The independent Senegalese newspaper Sud Quotidien said he was a victim of state xenophobia. Last month the Senegalese government faced protests that were seen as the countrys most violent since the late 1980s.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Book Seller Is a Buyer

title: Project Enlists Computers to Help Fight Wildfires
description: FRASER, Colo.  Nobody on Michael E. Hutts team has illusions that wildfire can be tamed. The blazes in Southern California in October were lesson enough for that.

title: Giuliani, Very Open? Theres Always a First Time
description: A few years back, a man named Russell Harding held a City Hall patronage job that came with a government credit card, which he used to steal more than $250,000.

title: Woods Shows Off His Skills, but Not as a Host
description: THOUSAND OAKS, Calif.  Tiger Woodss contract to play host to the Target World Challenge clearly contains no clause obligating him to be nice to his 15 invited guests  at least not during play. Because on a perfect day for scoring at Sherwood Country Club on Friday, six golfers shot a 67 only to discover that their rounds of five under par were only good enough to put them five shots further behind their genial host.

title: Musharrafs Rural Support Seems Less Than He Claims
description: BADAR RANJHA, Pakistan  In an interview last month, President Pervez Musharraf challenged Western journalists to journey to rural Pakistan to gauge public opinion. The mood of voters could be best gauged in the villages of Punjab, he said, the densely populated eastern province that holds 55 percent of the countrys population.

title: Huckabee Faces Old Queries in New Spotlight
description: When Mike Huckabee became lieutenant governor of Arkansas in 1993, he complained of being burdened by college tuition bills for his son, the expenses of two residences  one in Texarkana and the other in Little Rock  and the cost of commuting between the two.

title: Arizona: Suspect in Killings Sentenced
description: A man accused of being the Phoenix Baseline Killer was sentenced to 438 years in prison for the sexual assaults of two sisters. The man, Mark Goudeau, 43, a former construction worker, still faces trial in the killings of eight women and a man in 2005 and 2006. He has pleaded not guilty. Mr. Goudeau was convicted in September on charges of raping one woman and sexually attacking another as they walked home from a park. During the two-month trial, both sisters identified Mr. Goudeau as their attacker, and DNA evidence also linked him to the rape.

title: Book Seller Is a Buyer
description: A book of fairy tales handwritten and illustrated by J. K. Rowling sold for nearly $4 million at Sothebys auction house in London on Thursday. One day later, the identity of the winning bidder was revealed: Amazon.com. The company now owns one of seven copies of The Tales of Beedle the Bard, which is hand-bound in leather with silver mounts, The Associated Press reported. Proceeds from the sale will benefit the Childrens Voice, an organization that campaigns for childrens rights in Europe founded in 2005 by Ms. Rowling and Baroness Nicholson, a member of Britains House of Lords. Amazon has posted photographs of the book and says it will review the tales on its site. The company has also created a discussion board to answer questions about the books contents. Craig Berman, a spokesman for Amazon, said the company plans to put the book on a tour of libraries and schools. Ms. Rowling wrote the Beedle tales after finishing the Harry Potter series. She said the other six copies of the book had been given to people who were closely connected to the creation of the series.

title: Static on the Dream Phone
description: SEBASTOPOL, Calif.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption with the continuation of a front-page article on Thursday about a collective malaise in Italy misspelled the name of the city where Beppe Grillo, a performer who has given voice to the countrys mood, was shown preparing for a performance. It is Novara, not Novarra.

title: Warning for Drug
description: The European health regulator said Pfizers Champix, a stop-smoking aid, should carry a warning about the risk of suicide attempts among patients. In urging the warning, the regulator, the European Medicines Agency, followed the lead of American health officials who said last month doctors should monitor patients for mood shifts and patients should tell their doctors of changes.

title: Senate Passes Bill Easing Home Loan Rules
description: WASHINGTON (Bloomberg News)  The Senate passed legislation on Friday that would make more Federal Housing Administration loans available to subprime borrowers facing foreclosure.

title: Villone Allegations Difficult to Process
description: One of the joys of being a beat writer is the downtime in the clubhouse when you really get to know the players. No tape recorders, no notebooks, just talk. You learn things this way, and develop trust, but you also simply enjoy the company of certain guys as people.

title: The Mac Crowd Mourns
description: IN part because CompUSA has been a large seller of Macs, the news last week that the electronics retailer plans to close its remaining stores early next year has drawn lots of attention online, much of it presented in an elegiac tone.

title: Separatists in Philippines Agree to Reconcile
description: MANILA  Two rival Islamic separatist groups in the Philippines have agreed to reconcile by September, a pledge that has raised hopes here that the insurgency in the south of the country where the separatists have been fighting for self-determination since the 1970s might finally come to an end, officials said Friday.

title: Schwarzenegger to Declare an Emergency Over Budget
description: LOS ANGELES  With several costly policy problems awaiting a legislative repair, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger said Friday that the states budget deficit had grown to between $10 billion and $14 billion and that he would call for a state of fiscal emergency next month.

title: Bolivians Now Hear Ominous Tones in the Calls to Arms
description: SANTA CRUZ, Bolivia  Against narco-communism, reads one line of graffiti in this city in the lowlands of Bolivia. To arms, Cruceos, reads another, calling on residents to fight the government of President Evo Morales, who put the armed forces on alert this week as four eastern provinces move toward greater autonomy.

title: Taxi TV, Brisk as the Traffic Youre Stuck In
description: Where once there was only peeling vinyl, printed fare rates and the cabdrivers ceaseless cellphone chatter, there is now a television screen.

title: Happy Hour With the Centaur Lady
description: You have to feel favorably disposed toward Andrew Dinwiddie and Jeff Larson, the curators of the well-liked Catch performance series. Not only do they make the safety announcements themselves (the exits are, um, over there), they are also endearingly enthusiastic about their offerings. And they managed to get Singha beer as a sponsor for Catch 27, a mini-festival that features a bunch of talented artists over two weekends at Performance Space 122.

title: Anglican Archbishop Faults Factions
description: The archbishop of Canterbury, the Most Rev. Rowan Williams, sent a lengthy letter to the members of his warring Anglican Communion on Friday, saying that both sides had violated the Communions boundaries and put the church in crisis.

title: Ethanols Issue: Getting Acquainted With Drivers
description: LIMA, Ohio  If Americas great ethanol fuel experiment is ever going to work, Bill Timmermeister will be among the first to know.

title: In China, Farming Fish in Toxic Waters
description: FUQING, China  Here in southern China, beneath the looming mountains of Fujian Province, lie dozens of enormous ponds filled with murky brown water and teeming with eels, shrimp and tilapia, much of it destined for markets in Japan and the West.

title: Capitol Pas de Deux: One Party Leads, and the Other ...
description: WASHINGTON  When Republicans had the House majority, party leaders used to game out tactics that they thought the Democrats might use to gum up the legislative works. To their surprise, one of them recounted recently, they always came up with more devious ideas than anything the Democrats actually tried.

title: Several Children Are Injured When Their Van Collides With a City Bus in Queens
description: A private van that the police said was illegally carrying a group of young children to school collided with a city bus in Queens on Friday, critically injuring a 9-year-old girl and sending six other children to hospitals.

title: Buying Into Lloyds
description: Japans largest insurer, Millea Holdings , said its Tokio Marine and Nichido Fire Insurance unit would buy Kiln Ltd. for 442.2 million ($902 million) to gain a seat at Lloyds of London.

title: Ohio Elections Official Calls Machines Flawed
description: CINCINNATI  All five voting systems used in Ohio, a state whose electoral votes narrowly swung two elections toward President Bush, have critical flaws that could undermine the integrity of the 2008 general election, a report commissioned by the states top elections official has found.

title: Let Baseball Players Police Themselves
description: Kennesaw, Ga.

title: A Baseball Lover, Key to Tarnishing a Yankee Era
description: Brian McNamee is a former New York City police officer from Queens who has cherished the game of baseball since he was a youngster in the Rockaways and who twice found himself in the employ of the Yankees. But today he stands as the man who delivered a rattling blow to the team by linking two famous Yankees  Roger Clemens and Andy Pettitte  to the use of illegal, performance-enhancing drugs.

title: Report to Urge Sweeping Change for SUNY System
description: Warning that New York has slipped in stature and that its once-powerful position in national research has faded, a commission set up by Gov. Eliot Spitzer is recommending that the state free its public colleges and universities to raise tuition without the Legislatures approval and to charge different prices from campus to campus.

title: Baracks Blast From the Past
description: There are lots of different ways for a presidential candidate to deal with the question of drug use. You can admit it, deny it or say you didnt inhale. That last one, I think we can agree, is a choice we wont be seeing again any time real soon.

title: Huckabee Camp Shifts Focus for New Hampshire
description: CONCORD, N.H.  Mike Huckabee, who surged in Iowa polls with an appeal to religious and social conservatives, returned Friday to New Hampshire, where he is still an also-ran for the Republican presidential nomination, and opened a newly focused campaign for the votes of working people and economic conservatives.

title: Onstage and Off, a Group Inspired by Rivalries, Loves and Triumphs
description: I get asked the same question over and over, which is to talk about the Steppenwolf aesthetic, said Anna D. Shapiro, director of the Steppenwolf Theater Companys production of August: Osage County, now playing at the Imperial Theater on Broadway.

title: A Sale for Boeing
description: The Boeing Company said AWAS, an airplane leasing company in Ireland, has ordered 31 of its single-aisle 737-800 jets. While specific deal terms were not disclosed, Boeing said the order was worth $2.3 billion at list prices, although airlines typically negotiate discounts. AWAS owns and manages 315 airplanes.

title: Small Shops See Smallness as Their Big Selling Point
description: Predictions of a weak holiday shopping season have led the big department stores to slash prices and stretch their advertising budgets. But most small retailers, which cannot afford either the price cuts or the expensive advertising, are doing something else this year: making a virtue of their size.

title: Advocate Sentenced in Lobbying Probe
description: A Republican environmental advocate who arranged the lobbyist Jack Abramoffs entree to the Interior Department was sentenced to two months in a halfway house and four years of probation. The activist, Italia Federici, who pleaded guilty in June to tax evasion and obstructing a Senate investigation, was spared prison only because she has become a key witness in the Justice Departments continuing corruption investigation. Ms. Federici has admitted acting as a link between Mr. Abramoff and J. Steven Griles, the former deputy Interior Department secretary who for five years was her boyfriend. Mr. Griles provided Mr. Abramoff with advice and internal information, sometimes directly and sometimes through Ms. Federici.

title: On Retainer in Pakistan, to Ease Military Rulers Path
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan

title: Resignation at Credit Suisse
description: The United States head of asset management at Credit Suisse, Keith Schappert, left the company, the bank said. He has resigned, a spokeswoman, Suzanne Fleming, said. She declined to comment on whether a successor was being considered.

title: Illinois: Security at Nuclear Plants
description: The Exelon Corporation said it would replace the Wackenhut Corporation with an in-house security force at its 10 nuclear power plants after the discovery about two months ago that guards at a Pennsylvania plant were sleeping on the job. Exelon, based in Chicago, said it was acting even though a review of security at its other plants found no significant deficiencies. The change is to be made by July. Exelon has 17 reactors at 10 plants, including in Illinois, Pennsylvania and New Jersey. Officials at Wackenhut have characterized the apparent lapses as an anomaly.

title: Lost the Battle,won the War
description: He may not have won American Idol, but Chris Daughtry is king of the album charts this year, according to Billboard magazine, The Associated Press reported. His band, Daughtry, sold 3.2 million copies of its self-titled debut, making it the most popular album of the year. The group was followed by Akon, whose Konvicted sold 2.7 million; The Dutchess, by Fergie, which sold 2.4 million; the Hannah Montana soundtrack, with 2.5 million copies sold; and 2005s American Idol star Carrie Underwood, whose Some Hearts sold 2.3 million. Beyoncs Irreplaceable was the No. 1 single of the year, followed by Rihannas Umbrella. The top tour of the year, Billboard said, was that of the Police, whose reunion concerts took in at least $212 million.

title: In a Familiar Spot, Wake Forest Makes Up for a Loss
description: CARY, N.C.  Without a traditional national power in this years mens College Cup, and with three of the top four seeds already ousted, the N.C.A.A. soccer championship offered only one guarantee.

title: I Am Not a Health Reform
description: Cambridge, Mass.

title: Arizona: Three Bodies Found in S.U.V.
description: Three bodies were found in a sport utility vehicle in Phoenix, and the police are investigating the case as homicide. An officer who thought the Ford Explorer looked suspicious found the bodies in the back of the vehicle, which had been parked in front of an apartment complex, Sgt. Andy Hill said.

title: Steroid Era Is No Longer Only About Bonds
description: A day after issuing his strongly worded report on steroid use in Major League Baseball, George J. Mitchell sat in the conference room of his Manhattan office discussing the public reaction.

title: Dean Says Firing Came After Query on Finances
description: The dean of the highly ranked medical school at the University of California, San Francisco, was fired this week, and he suggested on Friday that the move came as a result of questions he had raised about the institutions financial accounting.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about a hearing on a claim by death row inmates in Connecticut that the states death penalty discriminates against minorities misstated the timing of the last execution in the state. Michael Ross, a serial killer, was executed by lethal injection in May 2005; it has not in fact been decades since the state executed anyone.

title: Money Goes Far in New York, if Youre European
description: Margaret Dragonette arrived in New York last week  three nieces, a cousin and loads of empty luggage in tow. By the time Ms. Dragonette, an administrative assistant for a nonprofit in Liverpool, was heading home, her group had filled six large suitcases and five carry-on bags. The bags were so stuffed with Juicy Couture T-shirts, Guess watches and Croc sandals that her nieces would have to wear the Ugg boots she was giving them for Christmas on the plane.

title: Justice Attempts to Clear His Name
description: When wildfires devastated Southern California in October, David Justice was one of hundreds to lose a home. He did manage to save his World Series rings from Atlanta and the Yankees, reminders of a 14-year career punctuated by postseason highlights.

title: One Player Who Spoke With Mitchell Wonders Why So Few Others Did
description: Toronto Blue Jays designated hitter Frank Thomas was surprised when he discovered that several major league players had declined to meet with George J. Mitchell for his investigation into the use of performance-enhancing substances in baseball. So Thomas made sure that Mitchell would not pitch a shutout.

title: 7-Ton Load Falls Near Ground Zero
description: Seven tons of metal studs that were being hoisted by crane at the new Goldman Sachs office tower near ground zero plummeted to the ground on Friday when a nylon sling failed, seriously injuring an architect who was in a construction trailer that was crushed.

title: Scientists Move Closer to Reliable H.G.H. Test
description: Shipments of human growth hormone arrived at players doorsteps by mail and by package couriers. They were purchased via the Internet, through antiaging centers and through dealers like Kirk Radomski, a former Mets clubhouse attendant who sold it more than any other illegal substance he supplied to his Major League Baseball clients.

description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Nets have done at least one thing well during this disappointing season: beat Cleveland.

title: Balancing the Somber and the Sparkling
description: Conductors must devote a lot of thought to their debut programs with major orchestras, and the works they choose say a lot about them before they conduct the first note. Andrey Boreyko, a Russian conductor who directs orchestras in Hamburg, Germany, and Bern, Switzerland, made his New York Philharmonic debut on Thursday evening at Avery Fisher Hall with a program that proclaimed him to be deadly serious but also to have a light-spirited side.

title: Some Familiar Support on the Run to the Wire
description: The Des Moines Register has a 20-year history of issuing endorsements for presidential candidates running in the Iowa caucuses. And while the effect of those endorsements is hard to gauge, it is nonetheless true that in all but one instance, the candidates who have received them went on to either win the caucuses or finish a strong second.

title: Jury Rules One Way, Judge Another in Mob Killing
description: The pizza man was charged with hiring assassins to kill a Genovese crime family associate. The evidence was robust. The baker was charged with helping him. The evidence was less robust.

title: Lottery Numbers
Class Acts: Paris Ballet Student Exhibitions
description: PARIS  No ballet company or ballet school is older than that of the Paris Opera. The two are intimately linked. Former company dancers have often become teachers at the school; its current director is lisabeth Platel, an eminent ballerina of the 1980s and 90s. Many students appear beside the adult dancers in the companys productions at both the Palais Garnier (as in the current Paquita) and the Bastille (as in Casse-Noisette).

description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y.  When Darrelle Revis played for the University of Pittsburgh, the Panthers traveled to the winter wonderland of West Virginia.

description: AMERICAN consumers may finally be showing some restraint. At least that is the indication from the trade figures released this week, which provide another indication of a slowing economy.

title: Clinton Advises, Stay Tuned, Despite Campaigns Recent Rough Weeks
description: DES MOINES  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton on Friday would not rule out running campaign advertisements that criticized her opponents by name, telling journalists to stay tuned to what her campaign had planned.

title: Bird in the Brush
description: In 2004, the United States Fish and Wildlife Service decided that it did not need to list the sage grouse  whose habitat and diet are defined by sagebrush  as threatened or endangered. Ranchers, developers and the petroleum industry all breathed a sigh of relief. Now, Federal District Judge B. Lynn Winmill has ordered the Fish and Wildlife Service to review its conclusions about the sage grouse. We hope that the agency will remember that its responsibility is to reach an impartial decision based on the best science  something it forgot the first time around.

title: Climate Treaty Deal Seems Close, but Is Elusive
description: NUSA DUA, Indonesia  The worlds countries, trying to wrap up two weeks of intense and at times emotional talks here on a two-year timetable for reviving an ailing, aging climate treaty, appeared close to a final agreement on Saturday but divisions remained.

title: Huckabee Strikes at Arrogant Bush Foreign Policy
description: TAMPA, Fla.  As Rudolph W. Giuliani tried to refocus his presidential campaign with a rare formal address here Saturday, Mike Huckabee gave the first detailed look at his foreign policy, sharply criticizing what he called the Bush administrations arrogant bunker mentality.

title: A Long Time Coming
description: It took 31 years, but the moral bankruptcy, social imbalance, legal impracticality and ultimate futility of the death penalty has finally penetrated the consciences of lawmakers in one of the 37 states that arrogates to itself the right to execute human beings.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Wednesday about the abuse of women in Brazils prison system described incorrectly the origin of a study about the subject. It was a report to the Organization of American States by a group of private organizations in So Paulo that formed the Study and Working Group on Women in Prison that led to increasing public and government attention to the problem. It was not a study commissioned by the government.

title: Hirotaka Ono, Auto Executive, Is Dead at 52

title: Up With the New
description: Facing mostly repeat competition, new episodes of CBSs regular lineup dominated Thursday night, leading every hour of prime time. CBSs CSI at 9 p.m. delivered the nights largest audience (19.8 million), Nielsen estimated. No other network show got even half that many. Leading the 8 p.m. hour, CBSs Survivor: China attracted 14.5 million viewers. At 10, CBSs Without a Trace (15.1 million) was well ahead of ABCs Private Practice rerun (4.8 million) and the last hour of NBCs Saturday Night Live Christmas special encore, which averaged 5.7 million viewers from 9:30 to 11. Fox ranked No. 2 in total viewers thanks to Are You Smarter Than a 5th Grader? at 8 (9 million), followed by Dont Forget the Lyrics at 9 (7.5 million). NBC edged past Fox for second place among adults 18 to 49. ABC was fourth over all.

title: On Trial, L.I. Man Recalls Lynch Mob
description: RIVERHEAD, N.Y.  The black man accused of shooting a white teenager last year in a racially charged manslaughter case on Long Island took the stand here on Friday in Suffolk County Criminal Court.

title: The Court That May Not Be Heard
description: The Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court, the special court that reviews government requests for warrants to spy on suspected foreign agents in the United States, seems to have forgotten that its job is to ensure that the government is accountable for following the law  not to help the Bush administration keep its secrets.

description: A Spare Times listing in Weekend on Friday about events at the 92nd Street Y misstated the date for a dance party with instruction. It is tonight; it was not Friday night.

title: Questions Linger About Why N.F.L. Destroyed Patriots Tapes
description: The N.F.L. reacted swiftly to the spying scandal in September. Commissioner Roger Goodell promised on national television that there would be a full investigation of the New England Patriots covert filming of Jets defensive signals. He ordered the Patriots to send any videotapes filmed in violation of N.F.L. rules to the league office.

title: Valdosta State Wins Title
description: Michael Terry scored a touchdown with 22 seconds left and Valdosta State beat Northwest Missouri State, 25-20, for the N.C.A.A. Division II championship in Florence, Ala. Terrys 1-yard touchdown run capped an eight-play, 37-yard drive fueled by Willie Copelands four straight completions for 27 yards. Valdosta (13-1) overcame a 14-3 halftime deficit in dropping Northwest Missouri to 12-2.

title: Burned Bungalows, and an Iffy Market
description: RESIDENTS of the bungalow district of Brighton Beach, a 10-block stretch of wooden single-family houses in Brooklyn that stand cheek-by-jowl along narrow lanes, are accustomed to feeling embattled. Since the late 1990s, developers have been snapping up these bungalows, which are half a mile from the ocean, and replacing them with beige concrete apartment buildings.

title: Life of Roses? No, but Shes Doing Fine
description: MARY J. BLIGE was in black and bling when she stepped into Legacy Recording Studios on the West Side of Manhattan to videotape a Yahoo Webcast. Her black knee-high Yves Saint Laurent boots had five-inch heels, leading up to black pants, a ribbed black Michael Kors top and a black cap; her Herms belt had gleaming metal studs and her hoop earrings glittered with diamonds. After the bands equipment was set up, she started to run through Just Fine, the first single from her new album, Growing Pains (Geffen). Ms. Blige looked into the camera as she delivered its spoken intro and about 20 seconds of a verse, then waved the band to a stop. Im ready, she said. Rehearsal over. No more rehearsing. Now were ready to do it for real.

title: The Newest Mandarins
description: Lei Bo is a philosophy graduate student in China whose faith is in history, and by habit he considers the world using the thousands of classical passages that live in his head. Three years ago he was studying in an empty room in the School of Management at his university in Beijing when students began to amble in for their class on Sun Tzus Art of War, a work from either the fifth or the fourth century B.C. Lei Bo decided to stay. He had taken two courses on The Art of War in the philosophy and the literature departments, and was curious to see how students in business and management might approach the same subject. The discussion that day was on the five attributes of a military commander. Sun Tzu said in the first chapter of the book, An able commander is wise (zhi), trustworthy (xin), humane (ren), courageous (yong) and believes in strict discipline (yan).

title: When Lily Left Us: Tough to the End
description: ONE of the running gags passed from one smirking generation to another around my big extended family was that our seemingly mild-mannered mother was one tough cookie to have outlasted our less-than-mild, often unmannered father. After his death at 93 she called herself, without a hint of irony, the Last Man Standing.

title: Frustration With Charities and U.N. in Congo
description: GOMA, Congo  Frustration at the United Nations peacekeeping force and the dozens of aid organizations working in North Kivu Province, in eastern Congo, is rising as violence increases, the number of displaced people here creeps toward one million, and the pace of assistance lags, especially to those fleeing the fighting in the past few weeks.

title: A Semi-Nude Minor? In The Times?
description: IN an otherwise depressed newspaper world, where revenues are stagnant and layoffs and buyouts are frequent, T, the fashion magazine of The New York Times, is a spectacular success. T, published 15 times a year, is a glossy, unabashed tribute to the good life, as defined in its pages by Hstens mattress and box spring sets starting at $4,475, Swiss coffee centers topping $3,600, and a Roger Vivier satin clutch with silver sequins going for $15,000.

title: Remember the Milkman? In Some Places, Hes Back
description: STEPHANIE MONAHAN fondly recalls having milk delivered to her front door by the local milkman when she was a young girl growing up on the outskirts of Boston. So, a few months ago, when she saw an old-fashioned milk truck chugging up the hill of her new neighborhood in Milton, Mass., she chased after it to find out if it made home deliveries.

title: Jennifer Kunin, Sidney Reitzfeld
description: Jennifer L. Kunin and Sidney P. Reitzfeld are to be married Sunday at the Foundry, an event space in Long Island City, Queens. Rabbi Lisa J. Grushcow is to officiate.

title: Philharmonic Gets Its Music Man
description: GENERALLY, the path for a conductor goes like this: start with a small local orchestra, maybe take an assistant conductors job at a bigger one, make a mark at a summer festival, hope to break into the top rank at a Philadelphia Orchestra or Berlin Philharmonic.

title: Not if Exports Save Us
description: LOOKING only at standard macroeconomic statistics, you would think the economy was in very good shape. Gross domestic product has grown at a 4.4 percent annual rate in the last six months, well above the historical average. The price index for personal consumption expenditures, excluding the volatile food and energy components, rose at a 1.6 percent annual rate over the same period, well below the historical average.

title: It Was a Very Organic Year
description: LOOKING back at the restaurants I reviewed this past year in the eastern part of Connecticut (including New Haven and Hartford Counties), I remember many that I would enjoy eating at again. Too many to revisit here. So I have limited my choices to those that are representative of a culinary trend, offer especially good value for the money or have a very distinctive style.

title: First the Wedding, Then the Real Show and Razzle-Dazzle Begins
description: THE beachside fireworks display had begun to wind down at Lulu de Kwiatkowskis and Alfredo Gilardinis wedding reception on Nov. 10 in the Bahamas when suddenly whistles began to blow and drums began beating. As their 160 guests looked on, a junkanoo, a traditional Bahamian Mardi Gras-style band with 30 men and women in colorful traditional costume, wound its way from the beach toward those assembled at the Lyford Cay Club.

title: Letters to the Editor: Where Did Service Go?
description: To the Editor: Thank you for Aboard Planes, Class Conflict; (Nov. 25) on the woes of travelers in economy class. We dont expect elaborate meals or lay-down seats, and I dont think most expect gracious service. But travelers do have a right to expect attentive treatment, space that permits medically sound space and movement, adequate and clean bathrooms and like amenities. Many wags have noted that the absence of food service represents an improvement, so thats not the issue.

title: Special District Elections Raise Concerns
description: VOTERS went to the polls Tuesday to cast ballots in 154 special taxing districts on Long Island that approve budgets that total hundreds of millions of dollars for services like firefighting, water, sanitation and parks.

title: Climate Plan Looks Beyond Bushs Tenure
description: NUSA DUA, Indonesia  The worlds faltering effort to cut greenhouse gas emissions got a new lease on life on Saturday, as delegates from 187 countries agreed to negotiate a new accord over the next two years  pushing the crucial debates about United States participation into the administration of a new American president.

title: Rebecca Strauss, Benjamin Handler
description: Rebecca Ilse Strauss, the daughter of Nancy B. Strauss and Albrecht B. Strauss of Chapel Hill, N.C., was married Saturday evening to Benjamin Joseph Handler, the son of Leslie Handler and Dr. Martin Handler of Kings Point, N.Y. Rabbi Michael Strassfeld officiated at the Angel Orensanz Foundation for the Arts in New York.

title: A Local Son (and Chef) Livens His Hometown
description: YOU know the story: local boy leaves town, makes good and, in this case, brings back to his undernourished neighborhood the culinary riches of the wider world. Thats the story of Peter Xavier Kelly, who, after six years of planning and an investment of several million dollars, has brought his latest triumph, the impressive X2O Xaviars on the Hudson, home to Yonkers.

title: Those Summer Nights
description: Its the summer of 1981, a mere week before Diana Spencer and Prince Charles are to be married. Lara, just turned 17, is embarking on a trip from London to Tuscany with her scholarly, travel-phobic father, Lambert, whom she has seen only sporadically since her early childhood. They are off to stay with one of Lamberts oldest friends. The expectation is obvious: this girl will come to know her elusive father; she will break out from her troubled, tentative girlhood and become a confident woman. Will she find a fairy-tale love as well? While Esther Freuds sixth novel, Love Falls, follows this all-too-familiar arc, her depiction of Lara is so charming and observant, her writing so dynamic, that all the clichs of a youthful summer of self-discovery are transcended.

title: Plenty of Blame for Afghanistan
description: It was not a pretty sight: Defense Secretary Robert Gates, last week, accusing NATO allies of not doing nearly enough in Afghanistan. But beyond the finger-pointing, there is a much more serious issue. Unless the United States and Europe come up with a better strategy  and invest more money, attention and troops  the good war will go irretrievably bad.

title: Laura Gilman, Donald Springer
description: Laura Dwyer Gilman and Donald Scott Springer were married Saturday evening at the Surrey Hotel in Manhattan. Harold Silverman, a retired State Supreme Court justice in the Bronx, officiated.

title: Snowstorms Delay Air Travel
description: Snow overnight gave way to rain on Sunday in the New York City area, even as much of the Northeast was hit by snowstorms that delayed air travel and caused traffic accidents.

description: With all the infinity pools and wet bars around, it was only a matter of time before an infinity bar was conceived and installed. And now it has  at the Grace Bay Club in the Turks and Caicos.

description: Margaret Elizabeth Stowers and Arthur James Peponis were married Saturday evening at Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York. The Rev. Dr. Fred R. Anderson, the pastor of the church, performed the ceremony.

description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y.  Ask the Hofstra senior Antoine Agudio why he works so hard, and he says it is because he is lazy.

title: Correction: A New Kind of Diva
description: An article on Dec. 2 about the Russian soprano Anna Netrebko misidentified an opera in which she is scheduled to perform in 2012. It is Manon, by Massenet, not Manon Lescaut, by Puccini.

title: Dont Go Near Those Shark Clichs
description: Over the last three seasons, the San Jose Sharks have appeared in seven playoff rounds  more than any other team. But the 17-year-old team with the snazzy teal jerseys has never appeared in the fourth and final round, the one in which the Stanley Cup is won or lost.

title: A Feast for the Eyes

But on a late-fall afternoon, downtown notables gathered for the First Postapocalyptic Christmas Dinner at the Chinatown loft of Agathe Snow. As prepared by Snow and her kitchen collaborators, the artists Marianne Vitale and Anne Apparu  together known as the catering-as-performance company Chop Shop  the rambling feast was somewhere between Judy Chicago and Judy Rodgers.

title: Today, Would Tartuffe Have His Own Show?
description: The period that tends to be forgotten when we look at period drama is our own. Were well aware, for example, that Julius Caesar is about Elizabethan England as well as ancient Rome. And if the director happens to set the play in Fascist Italy, that adds yet another historical layer to the proceedings.

title: Connecticuts Poor
description: Connecticut is a wonderful place to live  for those fortunate enough to make a living wage. Ask Debbie Kievits, 46, of Norwich. She is well-known for her selfless community activism, but a year ago, rheumatoid arthritis made it impossible for her to hold a job. She spent her savings supporting her family. Now she and her two teenage children make ends meet with the help of friends and fund-raisers while Ms. Kievits waits to qualify for Social Security disability payments.

title: No Child Left Behind? Say It in Spanish
description: AS school enrollment for Hispanic children declines in New York City and in other urban areas around the metropolitan region, school districts in dozens of outlying suburbs are adding seats and bilingual programs to address a sharp increase in the number of Hispanic students whose parents are immigrants.

title: Obama Showing New Confidence With Iowa Sprint
description: WATERLOO, Iowa  Senator Barack Obama is seeking to capitalize on a moment of opportunity in the weeks before the Iowa caucuses to challenge Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons long dominance of the Democratic field, and in doing so, he now faces intensified questions about his vulnerabilities in a general election.

title: Our Decrepit Food Factories
description: The word sustainability has gotten such a workout lately that the whole concept is in danger of floating away on a sea of inoffensiveness. Everybody, it seems, is for it whatever it means. On a recent visit to a land-grant universitys spanking-new sustainability institute, I asked my host how many of the schools faculty members were involved. She beamed: When letters went out asking who on campus was doing research that might fit under that rubric, virtually everyone replied in the affirmative. What a nice surprise, she suggested. But really, what soul working in agricultural science today (or for that matter in any other field of endeavor) would stand up and be counted as against sustainability? When pesticide makers and genetic engineers cloak themselves in the term, you have to wonder if we havent succeeded in defining sustainability down, to paraphrase the late Senator Moynihan, and if it will soon possess all the conceptual force of a word like natural or green or nice.

title: Independent Streak
description: After enjoying one of the most celebrated careers in Hollywood, youve decided to go the art-house route and make Youth Without Youth, a Romanian fable about an age-defying linguist and his lover who is reincarnated as a seventh-century Indian. Is the film intended for a mass audience? No, not at all.

title: Nobody Knows the Tribbles Hes Seen
description: BY any reasonable definition David Gerrold is a major figure in science fiction. He has published some 50 books and won many of his genres highest awards, including the Hugo and the Nebula. John Cusack and Amanda Peet starred in Martian Child, which was inspired by his novella The Martian Child and opened last month.

title: Jennifer Leach, Jeffrey English

English, the son of Roberta English of Summit, N.J., and Bruce English of Brooklyn. The Rev. Harold E. Masback III performed the ceremony at the Congregational Church of New Canaan.

By day, their life resembled that of any young couple in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn: coffee from a patisserie on Court Street and commutes on the F train to entry-level jobs in Manhattan.

description: ON a cold Saturday night last fall, two of my closest friends and I ate dinner and watched a movie in an old town house on West 11th Street. While I was there, I had an experience I had been wanting for more than 25 years.

title: Wilson Ahead by a Shot

Wilson was at four-under 212 heading into the final round, with the halfway leader, James Kingston, in second place. Garth Mulroy was two shots back after a 64, the days best round. Greg Norman shot a 72 and was at 217. The defending champion, Ernie Els, was at 224.

title: Blast Kills Five at Headquarters of Kabul Police
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A vehicle packed with rockets exploded across the street from the Kabul police headquarters on Saturday, killing five civilians and wounding at least 24 others, Afghan officials said. Three policemen were among the wounded.

On this day, 275 million first-class cards and letters are expected to be mailed, according to the United States Postal Service. Over the entire holiday season, from Thanksgiving to Christmas, about 20 billion cards, letters, packages and other pieces of mail (especially catalogs) will be mailed, the Postal Service projects.

To help solve the problem, a group at M.I.T. was asked to find a solution. It designed a folding electric scooter that can be placed throughout cities for rental, much like the bicycle rental system in some European cities.

description: CARDINALS AT SAINTS

title: Often a Swan, Rarely a Queen
description: SHE (more rarely, he) is the most talented student in the local dance school. Her legs are long, her feet arched; her neck looks suitable for a potential swan. Her teacher encourages her parents to have her audition for the School of American Ballet, or the Royal Ballet School, or the Paris Opera Ballet School. There are hundreds of children at the audition, but she gets in.

title: Letters to the Editor: Greater Strife in Oaxaca
description: To the Editor: Regarding 36 Hours in Oaxaca, Mexico; (Nov. 25): Beth Greenfield writes, Although its known as a hotbed for social justice rallies (including a large-scale teachers strike in 2006), the citys infectious zeal goes far beyond the political. This characterization underrepresents the political reality of Oaxaca, and tourists should know this when they decide to travel.

title: Waltrip Hires New Crew Chiefs

description: In his opening paragraph, Daniel Bergner (Dec. 2) describes Booth Gardner walking along the beach, his grandchildren exploring the waters edge. Gardner says, I cant see where anybody benefits by my hanging around.

title: Southern California Art? Look It Up
description: IN Los Angeles, Lyn Kienholz is known within the art world as a hostess extraordinaire. Since 1974, the year after her divorce from the Pop sculptor Ed Kienholz, she has entertained and connected countless California painters, sculptors, writers, politicians, and museum curators at her home in the Hollywood Hills.

title: H (as in Humming) Street
description: ITS been almost 40 years since riots ripped through Washington in the wake of Martin Luther King Jr.s assassination, and few areas were hit harder than the H Street Northeast corridor. Running from just north of Union Station toward the Anacostia River, H Street never fully recovered, even as other riot-scarred neighborhoods began picking up in the 1990s.

title: The Stranded Elf of Second Avenue
description: IT has long been an immutable fact of New York life that the holiday season begins with the arrival of the Christmas trees  and the French Canadians who sell them. Each neighborhood has its own familiar team, which appears year after year on Dec. 1, when New Yorkers discover heretofore hidden reserves of small-town bonhomie and offer showers, food and other niceties.

title: Lisa Goldstein, Jeffrey Manheim
description: Lisa Ellen Goldstein, a daughter of Fredda and Edward Goldstein of New York, is to be married Sunday to Jeffrey Ira Manheim, a son of Barbara and Michael Manheim of Lake Worth, Fla. Rabbi Israel C. Stein is to officiate at the Westin Diplomat in Hollywood, Fla.

title: 36 Hours in New Orleans
description: WHAT other city, after being half-drowned and left to starve, foiled by bureaucracy and attacked by the auto-immune disease of rampant crime, could stagger to its feet to welcome visitors with a platter of oysters on the half shell and a rousing brass band? What place, barely two years after Hurricane Katrina, could provide streetcar rides and impromptu parades, riverboat calliopes and sidewalk tap dancers? When chroniclers look back, the city's ability to be itself  a place that embraces sorrow and joy with equal gusto  in this hardest of times will become part of its legend.

The scrappy Nittany Lions even found a way to stun top-seeded Stanford Saturday night in Sacramento, getting 26 kills from Megan Hodge and 19 from Nicole Fawcett against the same university they beat for their first title in 1999.Fawcett served on match point and Penn State capped its 26th straight victory on another powerful kill by Hodge, the tournaments most valuable player, winning by 30-25, 30-26, 23-30, 19-30, 15-8 exactly three months to the day after losing a five-game thriller to the Cardinal  the last defeat for the Nittany Lions.

title: Editors Choice

title: Paperback Row
description: WHAT TERRORISTS WANT: Understanding the Enemy, Containing the Threat, by Louise Richardson. (Random House, $15.95.) Richardson, a Harvard scholar, views Al Qaeda in the context of other terrorist organizations and finds that it is neither unique in its organization nor unprecedented in its reach. Terrorist movements require alienated individuals, a complicit community and a legitimizing ideology, Richardson argues; their troops are motivated by a desire for revenge, renown and reaction from the enemy. The Bush administration has given Al Qaeda the great renown and huge reaction it desires. A successful campaign against terrorism, like those in Peru, Turkey and Britain, she says, requires an effort led by police intelligence units and other arms of the states to isolate the terrorists by empowering nonviolent moderates. Our reviewer, Martin Walker, called the book an overdue and essential primer on terrorism and how to tackle it.
