description: From a bunch of complaints in the Travel section about flying:

title: The Unrepentant
description: Neoconservative foreign policy  which is to say bellicose nationalism crossed with an idealistic faith in Americas capacity to transform the world for the better  is dead. Iraq was its Frankensteins monster, and the beast has turned on its creator. Our central task today is to devise a new way of thinking about the post-9/11 world. In the meantime, we can learn something of how we reached this pass by reflecting on the doctors who carried out the experiment.

title: The Chris Simon Stomp: You Decide
description: Youre Colie Campbell, and this bit of tape comes across your desk. What do you decide? A bit of background: the offender tried to hit an opponents head out of the ballpark last season with his stick.

title: Answers from Ming Hung Wong
description: Today we have answers to reader questions from Ming Hung Wong, a professor of biology at Hong Kong Baptist University.

title: A Portrait of Pettitte
description: The first substantive conversation I ever had with Andy Pettitte took place in April 1995 in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. I still remember how worried Pettitte seemed about the future. His arms were resting on his thighs and he peered straight ahead as he spoke in spring training about making the Yankees for the first time.

title: Open Caucus: On the Issues
description: Several of our Open Caucus voters from around the country have been closely following the presidential races, as candidates campaign intensely in the early nominating states of Iowa and New Hampshire.

title: Letterman Seeks Deal With Writers Union
description: Bill Carter and Michael Cieply report:

title: Russert to Romney: Are You A Flip-Flopper?
description: Mitt Romney endured withering questioning about his shifting positions and tone on a range of issues in his first appearance on Meet the Press this morning but perhaps the most memorable moment came when Mr. Romney grew unusually emotional while responding to a question about the Mormon Churchs decision to finally grant full rights to blacks in 1978.

title: Edwards Sticks to the Positive
description: John Edwards appeared on Sunday political talk shows this morning and put forth a consistently positive demeanor, declining easy opportunities to hammer his Democratic opponents.

title: Breaking News (O.K., Not Really): Pats Fans Loathe Mangini
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  Braving the snow-rain mixture blown sideways by the wind, I made my way down the stands toward the Jets sideline to take an informal Eric Mangini public opinion poll. Not surprisingly, the folks in the front row were not big Mangini fans.

title: Illness, Sloppiness Prompt Rangers Lineup Shuffle
description: Whether the flu bug or their mid-December playing funk is causing more woes among the Rangers, it was clear before Sundays game against Phoenix at Madison Square Garden that Rangers Coach Tom Renney was in no mood to sit around and wait for either to simply pass.

title: Crossing Party Lines, Lieberman to Endorse McCain
description: Senator Joseph Lieberman, the Connecticut independent who was the Democratic nominee for vice president in 2000, plans to endorse Senator John McCain, the Arizona Republican, for president tomorrow, according to both Democrats and Republicans knowledgeable about the move.

title: Clinton Endorsed by Bob Kerrey
description: COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa - One of Bill Clintons political headaches during his 1992 campaign and his first years as president was Bob Kerrey, the Democratic senator and Vietnam veteran from Nebraska, who also ran for the 1992 nomination and was a tough critic of some of Mr. Clintons personal and policy choices.

title: Clinton Hits Iowa With New Energy
description: COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa  A couple of quick observations from Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons first Every County Counts tour of Iowa, which will have her and her surrogates campaigning in all 99 counties of Iowa over the next five days.

title: Candidates Feeling the Pressure, and Showing It
description: You can tell when time is getting short in the nominating season. Tempers get short, too, personal attacks increase and, of course, the candidates start looking drawn and a bit grayer around the edges.

title: Giants Bubble Not Burst, but Flattened
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  In what the Giants hope is not a bit of foreshadowing, the practice bubble adjacent to Giants Stadium  the white one easily visible for a couple of miles away and from passing planes overhead  collapsed under the weight of the teams expectations.

title: Two Aesthetics
description: I spent the month of November in New York, and for part of that time I hung out at the Museum of Television and Radio (now the Paley Center for Media), doing research for a book Im writing on the 60s TV show The Fugitive. When I wasnt reading reviews and cover stories in old issues of TV guide, I was going to galleries, listening to concerts and seeking out movies that would probably not make it up to Delaware County. The movie I found was Starting Out in the Evening, described in the reviews as a small film, which means not only that there are no special effects, but that almost nothing happens (a point of criticism on the part of some reviewers).

title: A Context for Those Complaints
description: After five-plus years of fielding air travel questions from the general public, Ive pretty much heard it all. Certain subjects I expected to be popular  questions about the use of cell phones during flight, for instance  and I continue to be amazed at the number of fliers petrified by turbulence. But more than anything else, I have learned to never, ever underestimate how much people simply hate to fly.

title: News Headlines
description: A roundup of stories from the world of real estate:

title: Michigan Gets Its Man
description: Michigans long football nightmare is over. The Wolverines have hired West Virginias Rich Rodriguez, a move that brings to a close a drawn-out search that included Les Miles and Greg Schiano both deciding against coming to Ann Arbor.

title: No Long-Term Contract Extension for the Bunker
description: Mike Richards probably has every hockey commentator wishing that they had spent more time learning how to play the game than collecting cards or setting up a hockey bunker.

title: Following Death of Mother, Tyree Heads to Florida
description: The mother of Giants receiver David Tyree died of a heart attack Saturday night. Tyree was at the team hotel when his wife, Leilah, came to tell him about the sudden death of his mother, Thelma Tyree.

title: Polling the Youth Factor
description: Taking a cue from Howard Deans 2004 campaign, many of this years candidates for the Democratic presidential nomination are courting the younger set.

title: Reinventing the Revolution
description: Updated | 12:30 a.m. The revolution, it seems, will be televised. Or at least streamed live over the Web.

title: Whos on the List, Mr. Edwards?
description: OTTUMWA, Iowa  How confident is John Edwards about winning the Democratic presidential nomination? Well, consider this: Mr. Edwards, speaking at a forum in this small Iowa community, said that he has already begun thinking about who he would want as a running-mate. Maybe even more than just thinking about it.

title: The Forgotten Soldiers
description: Four decades after the C.I.A. hired thousands of warriors to fight in the Vietnam War, men who say they are veterans of that operation are still hunted by their government.

title: Whos Advertising on the Tube
description: Mitt Romney, the Republican presidential candidate, ran campaign advertisements on television more frequently than any other candidate through mid-November, according to the television tracking company Nielsen. He ran his first TV advertisement in February and mounted the costliest early advertising push in a presidential campaign. His rivals Rudolph W. Giuliani and Mike Huckabee began running television advertisements in November. The leading Democrats have stepped up their TV campaigns since October, running nearly as many advertisements as Mr. Romney.

title: Even Iowa Voters Get a Holiday Break
description: In the well-tested playbook for presidential campaigns, there is no entry for this question: How do you keep momentum alive during the holidays without alienating  or annoying  voters?

title: Dubai Rx : Conduit for Fake Drugs
description: Massive free trade zones like those in Dubai are being used by counterfeiters to smuggle fake drugs from China to Europe and the United States.

title: Are There We Cant Score Shots?
description: First of all, the Rangers latest debacle raises the annual flu shot debate, as in, why did Henrik Lundqvist not get one?

title: Man Faces Federal Charges in a Sex Ring in Minnesota
description: MINNEAPOLIS  A man suspected of luring 100 Asian women into a sex ring here has been charged in federal court with transporting women across state lines to engage in prostitution.

title: Leadership Battle Grips South Africas Dominant Party
description: POLOKWANE, South Africa  In South Africa, the African National Congress is the unchallenged political machine, the partys leader is its kingmaker and the conference to select that person, which began Sunday, is not unlike an American presidential primary.

title: Pakistan Says Terrorism Suspect Has Escaped
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A man who was arrested in Pakistan last year on suspicion of plotting to blow up trans-Atlantic airplanes, and who faced extradition to Britain in another case, escaped from his guards Saturday after a court hearing here, officials said Sunday.

title: A Quicker Resort This Year to Deep Discounting
description: KMART made a generation of bargain hunters react like starving dogs to a ringing bell. Now Internet companies want to bring the blue-light special to the cellphone  only this time, the bells are text messages telling shoppers that Valentino clutches, Christian Dior sunglasses and other luxury items are selling at more than 50 percent off.

title: Commercials Bask in a Shows Glow
description: As everyone knows, advertisers pay for time on television shows according to the number of viewers. But they should care about more than ratings, according to data newly released by the Nielsen Company, the audience measurement firm; it also matters how much the viewers like the show.

title: Kosovo Struggles to Forge an Identity
description: PRISTINA, Kosovo  When Kosovo recently held a contest to design a flag, the organizers insisted that it reflect the multiethnic population, shunning the nationalist symbols of the past.

title: Arsenal Edges Chelsea
description: William Gallas headed in a corner from Cesc Fabregas during injury time in the first half and Arsenal beat Chelsea for the first time in three years, 1-0. The victory kept Arsenal atop the Premier League standings with 40 points, ahead of United with 39 and Chelsea with 34.

title: Disappointments on Climate
description: A week that could have brought important progress on climate change ended in disappointment.

title: A Jilted Mentors Small Measure of Revenge
description: Foxborough, Mass.

title: No Stranger to Trouble, Artest Finds a New Perspective
description: Ron Artest and the Sacramento Kings were greeted by a cold, pelting sleet when they arrived in Philadelphia on Thursday afternoon.

title: A Multi-Voiced Warbler With an Electric Ukulele
description: Nellie McKay, 25, may be the sole member of her generation  musician or not  to cherish the sustained, warbling soprano style that was once a staple of Hollywood and Broadway musicals. It was one of the voices she deployed on Saturday night at the Concert Hall at the New York Society for Ethical Culture, singing the 1930s standard Prisoner of Love. At various times she also had a sultry jazz croon, a singer-songwriters naturalism, a crisp operetta declamation and a rappers fast rhymes. And she sang Dont Fence Me In with an electric ukulele, then got the audience to whistle along with her.

title: A Warning From Behind the Curtain
description: The Golden Globe nominations were announced on Thursday, glimmering tributes to the likes of Tom Hanks, Denzel Washington and Cate Blanchett. But on the same day, all that glitters in Hollywood was buried beneath a blizzard of arcane initials.

title: Working Hard to Give Others a Better Beginning
description: PHILADELPHIA  Lorenzo Compton did not have a promising start. His parents kicked him out at 17 for refusing to obey, he dropped out of the 12th grade when he got a girl pregnant, he served almost two years for drug dealing and he carries a bullet in his thigh.

title: Disabled Need Help Now, Not Later
description: To the Editor:

title: Dont Stand a Ghost of a Chance With You
description: Its too bad that Paranormal State, a new series on A&E, is unlikely to find a mass audience, because the parodies it would inspire on shows like Saturday Night Live, if it had the requisite level of public recognition, would be delicious.

title: In 08 Race, the Other Clinton Steps Up Publicly
description: DUNLAP, Iowa  When Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons campaign advisers laid out their new political strategy in a private conference call with allies last Tuesday, Bill Clinton was not on the line. He did not need to be. The message being delivered was his.

title: Retailers Face an Ominous Holiday Sign
description: Sales of womens clothing, a traditional pillar of the holiday shopping season, are unusually bleak so far this year, according to a major credit card company, an ominous sign for the retail industry.

title: Suspect in Bomb Plot Escapes in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A man who was arrested in Pakistan last year on suspicion of plotting to blow up trans-Atlantic airplanes and who faced extradition to Britain in another case, escaped from his guards Saturday after a court hearing here, officials said Sunday.

title: A Focused, Slimmer Marbury Returns
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  With a heavy heart and a lighter frame, Stephon Marbury returned to work Sunday.

title: Country Music Is Still Calling
description: With 2,054 radio stations, country music dominates the airwaves in the United States, Reuters reported. The total, reported by M Street, which tracks radio statistics, was an increase of five from a year earlier but 450 fewer than a decade ago. News-talk stations, which have swelled by nearly 500 in the last 10 years, totaled 2,026, an increase of 18 from 2006. Among stations with music-driven formats, country was followed by contemporary Christian stations (numbering 920); Spanish (917); adult contemporary (666); and Top 40 (495). The number of contemporary Christian and Spanish language stations increased in the last year, while adult contemporary remained flat, and Top 40 declined by 15.

title: Kyrgyzstan Leaders Party Wins in Landslide
description: BISHKEK, Kyrgyzstan  The party of the president of Kyrgyzstan, Kurmanbek Bakiyev, stormed to an overwhelming victory in early parliamentary elections Sunday, preliminary results announced on Monday showed. But opposition candidates have already accused the government of rigging the voting and warned of further instability.

title: Counterfeit Drugs Path Eased by Free Trade Zones
description: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates  Along a seemingly endless row of identical gray warehouses, a lone guard stands watch over a shuttered storage area with a peeling green and yellow sign: Euro Gulf Trading.

title: G.O.P. Candidates Scrambling to Cope With Rise of Huckabee
description: This article was reported by Michael Cooper, Michael Luo, Marc Santora and Paul Vitello and written by Mr. Cooper.

title: Police in Iran Shut 24 Internet Cafes
description: TEHRAN (Reuters)  The Iranian police have closed down 24 Internet cafes and other coffee shops in as many hours, detaining 23 people, as part of a broad crackdown on immoral behavior, official news media said Sunday.

title: Chance for Victory Slips Through Fingertips
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  So, which was the worst incomplete pass by the Giants during their miserable 22-10 loss to the Washington Redskins on Sunday night in the cold and bitter winds of Giants Stadium?

title: Once Broke, GameStop Moves Up to S.&P. 500
description: Just over a decade ago, the company now known as GameStop was bankrupt, and analysts in the video game industry predicted that people would buy games online rather than in its mall stores.

title: Dolphins Celebrate Their 1972 Season by Winning First Game
description: MIAMI  The Miami Dolphins commemorated the anniversary of their 1972 perfect season Sunday, in a season that has been anything but perfect. And for long stretches of the game against the Baltimore Ravens, it seemed as if Larry Csonka, Nick Buoniconti and Bob Griese, ensconced in a luxury box with their Hall of Fame blazers, would have given the Dolphins a better shot at avoiding a perfectly awful 0-16 season than anybody the Dolphins had on the field.

title: 300 Inmates Break Out of Indian Jail
description: NEW DELHI  In the epicenter of the Maoist rebellion in central India, 300 prisoners who were apparently led by Maoists broke out of jail on Sunday evening, the police said.

title: A Year for Quick Hits and Fast Flops as Campaigns Broke New Ground
description: THEY say the older you get, the faster the years seem to go by. But you could be the president of the Gossip Girl fan club or the newest cast member of High School Musical 3 and still believe that times flight is on fast-forward.

title: In Northeast, a Storm of Inconvenience
description: Barrages of snow, sleet and wind-driven rain delivered a wintry blow across the New York region and the Northeast on Sunday. It delayed air travelers, caused minor traffic accidents, washed out a million weekend plans and frustrated all but the most hardy mall crawlers and Christmas shoppers.

title: Big Table Fantasies
description: Broadly speaking, the serious contenders for the Democratic nomination are offering similar policy proposals  the dispute over health care mandates notwithstanding. But there are large differences among the candidates in their beliefs about what it will take to turn a progressive agenda into reality.

title: Palestinian Rocket Injures Child in an Israeli Kibbutz
description: JERUSALEM  A rocket fired at Israel on Sunday afternoon by Palestinian militants from Gaza landed near a house in Kibbutz Zikim, lightly wounding an Israeli toddler inside, an army spokesman said.

title: A Pro Athlete With Spare Millions? Lenny Dykstra Has Your Magazine
description: Lenny Dykstra had a busy last week. He was named in the Mitchell report into performance enhancing drugs in baseball as someone who received steroids. He was also helping to start a magazine.

title: Turkey Bombs Kurdish Militants in Northern Iraq
description: ISTANBUL  Turkeys military said it bombed Kurdish militant targets in northern Iraq before dawn on Sunday, as part of an American-sanctioned effort to weaken the Kurdish guerrilla group that hides there. An Iraqi official said one woman had been killed.

title: Leno and OBrien to Resume Their Shows
description: NBC officially announced yesterday that its two late-night stars, Jay Leno and Conan OBrien, will return to the air on Jan. 2 even if the strike against networks and studios by entertainment writers is not resolved by then.

title: Ingersoll to Buy Climate Control Maker
description: Ingersoll-Rand, the industrial conglomerate, agreed on Monday to buy Trane, the air-conditioning company that is the successor to American Standard, for $10.1 billion.

title: Two Wins in 24 Hours for Paerson
description: The Olympic slalom champion Anja Paerson won a womens World Cup super-G in Switzerland on Sunday for her second victory in 24 hours.Paerson finished the Corviglia course in 1 minute 15.06 seconds to edge Canadas Emily Brydon by 0.04. Renate Goetschl was third.Its just amazing, Paerson said. Yesterday, I was just thinking about getting across the finish line because this is such a tough super-G course.Julia Mancuso lost half a second in the final interval but still posted the top American result, tying for 10th with Canadas Britt Janyk in 1:15.57.

title: A Lesson From New Jersey
description: For years people of color who traveled New Jerseys highways knew that they were at a higher risk of being pulled over by state troopers. In 1998, this shameful policy of racial profiling was revealed  but only after troopers fired 11 shots into a van carrying black and Latino men  and New Jerseys state police were placed under federal oversight. Now a special advisory committee to Gov. Jon Corzine has concluded, persuasively, that the State Police have changed their ways, and the governor has asked for an end to federal monitoring.

title: On Facebook, Scholars Link Up With Data
description: Each day about 1,700 juniors at an East Coast college log on to Facebook.com to accumulate friends, compare movie preferences, share videos and exchange cybercocktails and kisses. Unwittingly, these students have become the subjects of academic research.

title: Telecom Industry Wins a Round on Eavesdropping
description: WASHINGTON  Telecommunications companies won a skirmish in the Senate on Monday as a bill to protect them from lawsuits for cooperating with the Bush administrations eavesdropping programs easily overcame a procedural hurdle.

title: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
For Giants, Shockey Is Biggest Loss
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Faced with a big halftime deficit against the Redskins in September, the Giants mounted a stirring comeback to help reverse their season.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: A Woman in Control Sings Soul, Classically
description: The huge sign behind the Nokia Theater stage displayed the name of the radio station  98.7 KISS-FM  and also its slogan: The Best Variety of Old School and Todays R&B. The occasion was the Kiss Holiday Concert on Friday night, and the star was a doubly appropriate singer.

title: A New Look at a Caravaggio
description: Bought last year for $103,000, and now believed to be worth $100 million, a painting newly authenticated as a Caravaggio has gone on public display for the first time, at the Museo Regionale Conte Agostino Pepoli in Trapani, Sicily, Agence France-Presse reported. The painting is The Card Sharps, an early version of a 1594 work by the Italian Baroque master that is on display at the Kimbell Art Museum in Fort Worth. The painting on display in Sicily was declared a Caravaggio after the British art collector and historian Denis Mahon, 97, bought it at a Sothebys auction.

title: Looking Ahead
description: EARNINGS REPORTS The big Wall Street banks will continue to report their fourth-quarter results, with Goldman Sachs on Tuesday, Morgan Stanley on Wednesday and Bear Stearns on Thursday.

title: Candidates Collect Endorsements in Final Days in Iowa
description: DES MOINES  The Democratic presidential candidates pressed across Iowa on Sunday as they began to make their closing arguments to voters before the holidays, with Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton clearly buoyed by her endorsement Sunday from The Des Moines Register.

title: N.Y. Couple Convicted in Slave Case
description: CENTRAL ISLIP, N.Y.  The so-called Muttontown Slave Trial has involved a wild barrage of testimony by two Indonesian domestic workers employed  and according to prosecutors, enslaved and tortured for years  by an affluent Long Island couple. The verdict on Monday made for no less of a wild scene.

title: New CDs
description: LUPE FIASCO The Cool (Atlantic)

title: Death Penalty Repealed in New Jersey
description: TRENTON  Gov. Jon S. Corzine signed into law a measure repealing New Jerseys death penalty on Monday, making the state the first in a generation to abolish capital punishment.

title: Old U.S. Allies, Still Hiding in Laos
description: VIENTIANE PROVINCE, Laos  They call themselves Americas forgotten soldiers.

title: Huckabee Draws Support of Home-School Families
description: DES MOINES  Christine and Chuck Hurley have raised and home-schooled their 10 children here, and five of those children will be eligible to vote in the Iowa caucus on Jan. 3.

title: Duck Beware: A Hungry Wolf Prowls a Miniature World
description: Peter and the Wolf, Prokofievs 1936 musical fable about a plucky boy who resourcefully captures a fierce predator, might seem too slight to be called a masterpiece. But what other term applies to a piece of such seemingly effortless invention, or one that so readily appeals to listeners of any generation? The works narrative, also written by Prokofiev, has been delivered by all manner of celebrity storytellers, from Boris Karloff and John Gielgud to Captain Kangaroo and Dame Edna.

title: What Next, Having the Office Christmas Party at Home?
description: For years, equipment once normally found only in the office has been migrating into the home, from answering machines and water coolers to laser printers and PCs. Now, in a quirky new campaign, Microsoft is hoping to sell America on the idea of bringing servers in-house.

title: United Tops Liverpool
description: Manchester United extended its six-year unbeaten streak at Anfield by defeating Liverpool, 1-0, in an English Premier League match. Carlos Tevezs goal in the 43rd minute off a corner from Wayne Rooney also sent Liverpool to its second consecutive league defeat after an unbeaten start.

title: The Italian Malaise
description: To the Editor:

title: German Skater Sets World Record
description: The German speedskater Jenny Wolf broke her world record in the womens 100 meters with a time of 10.22 seconds at a World Cup race in Erfurt, Germany. That broke the mark of 10.28 she set in Calgary, Alberta, on March 4. Xing Aihua of China was second in 10.59, followed by Judith Hesse of Germany in 10.62.

title: In a Battle for the Gold Cup, a Slam Opportunity Missed
description: The premier bridge event in Britain is the Gold Cup. The final, played on Dec. 9 at the Peebles Hydro Hotel in Scotland, was won by Alexander Allfrey, David Bakhshi, Andrew Robson and Tony Forrester. Their opponents  Paul Bowyer, Duncan Happer, Ben Green, Jim Mason, Dick Pathan and Nick Stevens  conceded defeat after 48 of the 64 scheduled boards, down 126 international match points to 28.

title: For Recipients of Medicare, the Hard Sell
description: COLUMBUS, Miss.  Dorothy K. Barksdale, a 70-year-old seamstress, vividly remembers the day an insurance agent visited her home and signed her up for a private Medicare health plan.

title: Sorenstam Repeats in Dubai
description: Annika Sorenstam of Sweden shot a two-under-par 70 Sunday to win the Dubai Ladies Masters by two strokes and collect her first victory since she won here in 2006.I am so happy to have finally won again, said Sorenstam, who finished at 10-under 278 at the season-ending tournament of the Ladies European Tour. The third-round leader, Iben Tinning of Denmark, had a double bogey at the last hole and finished with a 73, tying for second with Laura Davies of England, who shot a 72.

title: The Early Years of Rock, Later Than Previously Thought
description: Any documentary series about the history of rock music that manages to get through its first show without mention of Elvis Presley, Buddy Holly or Chuck Berry, and only a passing reference to the Beatles  well, you have to admire its assertiveness.

title: A Tale of Two Nutcrackers, With More Than a Chunnel Between Them
description: One of the refreshing things about the original 1892 Nutcracker is that, unlike most narrative ballets, it isnt a love story. But that hasnt stopped theorists, directors and choreographers from deciding that the scenario Marius Petipa drew up in 1891 for Tchaikovsky to set to music and what remains of the choreography created by Lev Ivanov (when Petipa fell ill) would all be improved by turning it into, yes, another love story.

title: Greenspan Urges U.S. to Help Those Facing Foreclosure
description: Alan Greenspan, former chairman of the Federal Reserve, said Sunday that the government should provide direct financial assistance to homeowners who are threatened by foreclosure in the worsening credit crisis.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Dave Barber, senior vice president for newspaper relations at Parade, New York, part of Advance Publications, will now lead the newspaper relations group. He assumes duties from Lamar Graham, general manager, who was recently promoted to executive editor.

title: A Surreal State
description: BRUSSELS

title: Used to Taking Charge, but Finding Herself in Need
description: Armed only with a stick, Eilene Rockette stood outside wearing rain boots, a sweatshirt and sweat pants while being drenched by what felt like buckets of water. She yelled to others peering out from their apartments to help her clear debris that had clogged several drains on the street.

title: Tweaking a Definitive Moment in History
description: CHICAGO  John Adamss Doctor Atomic enjoyed a major success during its premiere production two years ago at the San Francisco Opera. Yet even among the works champions, the consensus was that this ambitious opera  about the physicist J. Robert Oppenheimer, who presided over the Manhattan Project to build the first atomic bombs  needed some tweaking.

title: Faster Chips Are Leaving Programmers in Their Dust
description: REDMOND, Wash.  When he was chief executive of Intel in the 1990s, Andrew S. Grove would often talk about the software spiral  the interplay between ever-faster microprocessor chips and software that required ever more computing power.

title: Election in South Korea Is Missing Its Suspense
description: SEOUL, South Korea  South Koreas presidential elections have tended to be bruising, down-to-the-wire contests that exposed voters ideological schisms and raw emotions over the countrys tortured relations with North Korea and the United States.

title: Talk of an Exit, but Not From Morgenthau
description: Last year, Robert M. Morgenthau presided over an office with roughly 96,000 cases, 500 assistant district attorneys, and some of the most high-profile trials in the nation, and he is on track to do the same this year.

title: Diane Wood Middlebrook, Biographer, Dies at 68
description: Diane Wood Middlebrook, a biographer, poet and critic known for her best-selling, controversial life of the poet Anne Sexton, died on Saturday in San Francisco. She was 68.

title: McCain Seeks to Capitalize on New Endorsements
description: CONCORD, N.H.  Senator John McCain, seeking to capitalize on a string of highly sought newspaper endorsements, is making an aggressive push to attract independent voters, who helped drive his victory here eight years ago.

title: Celine Dion, She Went On and On
description: LAS VEGAS  For the final performance of A New Day, Celine Dions show at Caesars Palace here last weekend, M J Wylie, 49, a health-care consultant from Denver, decided to go formal. She wore a floor-length black gown and a sparkly white shawl; around her neck was a silver pendant in the shape of the shows first logo, an elongated figure of a woman. Inside her $3,400 Judith Leiber clutch, bought at the gift shop adjacent to the theater and also bedazzled with the logo, were several autographed photos of Ms. Dion with Ms. Wylie. It was an undeniably elegant ensemble; the only problem, Ms. Wylie said, was that her dress hid her commemorative New Day tattoo.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,882 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Friday:

title: Inmates Chip Away Jails Walls and Leap From Roof to Freedom
description: Jose Espinosa and Otis Blunt hail from different towns and very likely were strangers until they wound up in the same jail, a drab building of sealed windows rising 14 stories behind the courthouse in downtown Elizabeth, N.J.

title: At Web Site for Journalists, Criticism of a Campaign Article Becomes a Melee
description: A usual round of media self-criticism turned into a schoolyard brawl last week, as editors, reporters and bloggers traded insults over a front-page article in The Washington Post, all at the very online water cooler where they usually get their news about the industry.

title: Managing a Post-Feb. 5 Campaign
description: COLFAX, Iowa  For most of the year, two working assumptions have guided the strategic decisions of the major presidential campaigns. The first was that a Republican and Democratic nominee would for all and intents purposes be known after Feb. 5, when there are primaries and caucuses in more than 20 states. The second was that there will only  as the line goes  be three tickets out of Iowa; just three candidates from each party would survive the caucuses here on Jan. 3 and move on to New Hampshire, with the rest of the field being eliminated.

title: Group to Ask for Expanded Inquiry of the Power Markets
description: Customers are paying unjust and unreasonable rates for electricity because wholesale markets favor large generating companies, according to a broad coalition of industrial, governmental and consumer groups that says it will ask the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission to expand its investigation into the marketing of power.

title: Gretzkys Presence, Even as a Coach, Stops the Rangers Cold
description: As Wayne Gretzky looked around Madison Square Garden on Sunday night at the end of the Phoenix Coyotes 5-1 victory over the Rangers, he let himself soak in the atmosphere he remembered so fondly as a player. He was battling the flu, laboring to walk and struggling to talk, but he left the rink with a smile.

title: Facebook, the Place People Go to Meet Other Scrabble Players
description: Like most fanatical Scrabble players, devotees of Scrabulous, a Scrabble-like application on Facebook, hate to be interrupted. So players are breathing easier since an upgrade last week intended to ensure that matches load more quickly.

title: Case Lays Bare the Medias Reliance on Iraqi Journalists
description: Bilal Hussein, an Iraqi photographer who had a hand in The Associated Presss 2005 Pulitzer Prize for photography before being jailed without charges by the United States military, finally had a day in court last week. But his story, which highlights the unprecedented role that Iraqis are playing in news coverage of the war, is really just beginning.

title: Changing Courses at the Food Network
description: You can find chef Emeril Lagasses name and face all over a dozen cookbooks, 10 restaurants, lines of pots and pans, knives, Wedgwood dishes, spices, salad dressings and pasta sauces, and even a deep fryer.

title: I Am Legend Has a Healthy Start
description: I Am Legend (distributed by Warner Brothers), starring Will Smith, right, in a postapocalyptic vision of a zombie-infested Manhattan, hauled in an estimated $76.5 million in its debut to capture first place in the weekend box-office rankings compiled by the tracking company Media by Numbers. Second place went to another newcomer, Alvin and the Chipmunks (Fox), a resurrection of the musical-cartoon franchise, which took in $45 million. Dropping to third place from second last week, the fantasy The Golden Compass (New Line) had $9 million in sales. Enchanted, Disneys revisionist fairy tale, took in $6 million, bringing its total gross to $92.2 million in its fourth week in release, and the Coen brothers latter-day western, No Country for Old Men (Miramax), finished fifth, with $3 million in its sixth weekend.

title: Vexing Questions of Jewish Identity
description: Are you Jewish? is a question often lobbed at Jamie Kastner, a Toronto filmmaker and writer. Why do you want to know?, he asks in a film that flings the question back as he moves around the globe  New York, London, Jerusalem, Paris, Berlin  to engage a widely varied cast of characters about the meanings of Jewishness. With the deliberately provocative and potentially offensive title Kike Like Me, his documentary is to have its television premiere in this country Monday night at 10 on the Sundance Channel.

title: Advertising Accounts
description: Heineken USA, White Plains, named Wieden & Kennedy, Portland, Ore., to create English-language campaigns for its Heineken and Heineken Premium Light beer brands, which had been handled by Berlin Cameron United, New York, part of the United unit of the WPP Group. Spending was estimated at more than $100 million. The Vidal Partnership, New York, continues to create Spanish-language campaigns.

title: A Young Shepherds Ageless Trek
description: Few composers in the 20th century devoted more time and craft to opera than Gian Carlo Menotti, who died in February at 95. Yet from a sizable body of work that includes two Pulitzer Prize-winning works (The Consul and The Saint of Bleecker Street), only one of Menottis operas can truly be said to have achieved lasting popularity: Amahl and the Night Visitors, a brief, modest work created for NBC television and first performed in a live broadcast on Christmas Eve in 1951.

title: Facing a Challenge, a Tar Heel Responds
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J.  After two seasons in which Danny Green made only modest contributions, North Carolina Coach Roy Williams figured Green was capable of more. So he challenged Green and told him it was time for him to become a key figure for the Tar Heels.

description: To the Editor:

title: Rare U.S. Victory in Cross-Country
description: Kikkan Randall became the first United States woman and the second American to win a World Cup cross-country race when she defeated the world sprint champion Astrid Jacobsen of Norway in the final meters of a 1.2-kilometer freestyle race in Demino, Russia.Randall is the first American to win a World Cup cross-country race since Bill Koch in 1983. She finished in 2:48.7  seven-tenths of a second ahead of Jacobsen.

title: South African Prevails at South African Open
description: James Kingston shot a one-under 71 to beat Oliver Wilson by one stroke at the South African Open on Sunday.Kingston, of South Africa, finished at four-under 284 as darkness set in after an earlier rain delay at the Pearl Valley Golf Estates course in Paarl. Greg Norman shot a 71 and finished tied for seventh. Ernie Els had a 69 to finish in a tie for 16th with Retief Goosen, who shot a 75.

title: Woods Adds Another Victory to a Season Full of Triumphs
description: THOUSAND OAKS, Calif.  In a near-perfect ending to a spectacular 2007 season, Tiger Woods tied up a lot of loose ends Sunday in the Target World Challenge at Sherwood Country Club. With a final-round 68 for a 72-hole total of 22-under-par 266 that was not quite as easy as it looked, he beat Zach Johnson by seven strokes, Jim Furyk by eight and the rest of the field by a mile.

title: A Book Signing With the Author a World Away
description: Many people know that Conrad M. Black, the media baron who was sentenced last week to six and a half years in prison, is also a serious author, with weighty biographies of Richard M. Nixon and Franklin D. Roosevelt under his belt.

title: You Can Go Home Again, but Youll Pay the Consequences
description: First of all, it really is that good. You would expect it to have shrunk over the years, the way buildings that loomed large in your childhood seem smaller when you revisit them. But as the first-rate revival that opened Sunday night at the Cort Theater makes electrifyingly clear, The Homecoming is every bit as big as its reputation.

title: Alex Trebek Leaves Hospital
description: Alex Trebek, below, the host of Jeopardy!, has been released from Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles where he was treated after suffering what was described as a minor heart attack last Monday. He plans to spend the holidays at home and has promised to return to the studio on Jan. 14 to tape the quiz shows Teen Tournament. In a statement relayed by the shows publicity representative, Jeff Ritter, Mr. Trebek, 67, said, Im truly overwhelmed by the great show of support and compassion expressed in the past few days to me, my family and my co-workers.

title: Crossing Europe, Packing Menace, Sex and Secrets
description: Darcy Arlen, straight out of Indian Bend, Ohio, is taking a six-week European tour courtesy of her parents, who gave her the trip to celebrate her high school graduation. As Craig Holdens Matala begins to spread its dark wings, Darcy is an accident waiting to happen, despite her squeaky-clean schedule full of museums, opera, architecture and ruins.

title: She Aided Victims of Shootings, and She Became One
description: It was about 5:30 p.m. when, while taking her 9-year-old son to a Saturday evening swimming practice in Brooklyn, Carol Simon-Hayes realized she had forgotten something at her apartment. She left her son, Kieron, with friends at a gas station and approached her building, just down the block on Eastern Parkway.

title: Democrats, Staying Within Spending Limit, Draft Budget with Domestic Emphasis
description: WASHINGTON  Congressional Democrats on Sunday readied a $516 billion budget that grudgingly sought to meet President Bushs overall spending target while shifting money into domestic Democratic priorities like health care and education.

description: I Am Legend Has a Healthy Start

description: The University of Michigan will introduce Rich Rodriguez as its coach Monday, ending an awkward monthlong search with the hiring of one of college footballs most respected offensive minds.

description: There was an avalanche of sentencing news last week. The Supreme Court gave trial judges more power to show mercy, the United States Sentencing Commission gave almost 20,000 prisoners doing time on crack cocaine charges a good shot at early release, and even President Bush commuted a crack sentence.

title: Boycotted Radio Host Remains Unbowed
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The humbling of Don Imus last spring over his remarks about the Rutgers womens basketball team has done nothing to quiet Michael Savage, a radio host with a far bigger following and far more checkered track record.

title: Wake Forest Gets Title Satisfaction While Ohio State Cant Find Any
description: CARY, N.C.  Zack Schilawski grew up in this small bedroom community outside Raleigh, playing youth league soccer and occasionally getting a chance to watch college and professional teams compete at SAS Soccer Park.

title: Chilling Day a Challenge for Player and Fan Alike
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  When it snows or rains or the wind blows furiously, sensitive sports like baseball, golf and tennis yield to the elements and wait for another hour or another day. Football keeps going, as the New England Patriots and the Jets did on this dreadful Sunday.

She is Kia Vaughn, not Kim. (Go to Article)

title: After 100 Years, Caruso and Melba Sing Again
description: A century after they were sealed, two urns containing 24 discs representing the best of French and Italian opera, as sung by artists like Nellie Melba and Enrico Caruso, will be put on display on Wednesday by the Paris Opera and the French National Library, Agence France-Presse reported. During 2008 the recordings, which feature works by Bizet, Gounod, Donizetti and Rossini, will be extracted from their protective covering, and EMI, the successor to Gramophone, which donated the discs, will issue them on CD. The records were sealed on Dec. 24, 1907, in a solemn ceremony in the basement of the Palais Garnier opera house in Paris as a gift from Alfred Clark, the head of Gramophone in France. He stipulated that they remain unopened for 100 years, so men of that epoch can hear what the leading voices of our time sounded like. The urns were exhumed in 1989 and entrusted to the library for safekeeping. Because of danger from the asbestos used to protect the records, the urns will not be opened when they are displayed this week.

title: The World Is Flat, and Chocolatiers Want to Coat It
description: ZURICH  When the cold winter wind blows off Lake Zurich, the people who live around this sprawling factory, a 10-minute ride from the center of town, can smell the chocolate in the air. It is especially pungent this time of the year, when the factories are humming to meet holiday demand, the chocolate-makers bonanza.

title: Niemeyer Plans Cultural Center in Spain
description: Leaders of seven major cultural institutions, including Lincoln Center, gathered over the weekend in Avils in northwest Spain, where the Brazilian architect Oscar Niemeyer, left, who turned 100 on Saturday, is designing a center for them, Agence France-Presse reported. March is the anticipated start date for construction of the Niemeyer Cultural Center, featuring a 1,000-seat auditorium, a 43,000-square-foot gallery and a multiplex movie theater to be shared by the seven institutions. Besides Lincoln Center, the principal participants in the weekend discussion of new ways to work together were the Sydney Opera House, the Barbican Center of London, the Hong Kong Cultural Center, the Pompidou Center of Paris, the Alexandria Library of Egypt and the Tokyo International Forum.

title: Tough Love, Conveyed With Nails and a Cross
description: In one of the strangest scenes from Hard as Nails, a documentary that will be shown Monday night on HBO, an unordained Roman Catholic minister named Justin Fatica stands before a teenager and shouts, Jesus loves you! as an assistant slams a metal folding chair against the ministers back. And that is not even the most painful scene in this intimate and disturbing film.

title: The Office I Left Giuliani
description: ON Meet the Press a week ago, Rudolph W. Giuliani attempted to deflect criticism of his close relationship with his former police commissioner, Bernard Kerik, by saying that his misjudgment of Mr. Kerik had to be weighed against his other accomplishments. How can I not have pretty good judgment about the people who work for me and not been able to turn around the United States attorneys office? he asked. But Mr. Giulianis claim to have turned around the Manhattan United States attorneys office is not only untrue, it is an insult to the outstanding men and women who have served in that office over the last 50 years.

title: Flawed Media Plan
description: Decades ago, when most Americans relied on just a few news outlets, it made sense to bar companies from owning a newspaper and a broadcaster in the same city and limit the number of TV stations a single company could own. That was the best way to ensure that Americans had many different sources of information and the diversity of views needed for a healthy democracy.

title: M.T.A. Rapid Response Plan for Elevators and Escalators
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority plans to spend $1.3 million to hook up more than 300 elevators and escalators in the subways to a computerized monitoring system that would allow it to respond more quickly to breakdowns. The plan is to be submitted this week to the authoritys board for consideration.

title: Holidays Find Loan Crisis Spreading to Businesses and Neighbors
description: Marcia is not in the holiday mood this year. She is not putting any Santas, reindeer or lights outside her house. She is probably not going to have many presents inside. There will be no home improvements anywhere. The fact is, she does not know how long she can even call the place hers.

description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  In what the Giants had hoped would not be foreshadowing for their game Sunday night against the Redskins or for their fortunes for the rest of the season, the practice bubble next to Giants Stadium collapsed during the ice and wind storm that struck the area early Sunday.

title: Patriots Undefeated and the Jets Have New Intrigue
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  Patriots linebacker Junior Seau peeled himself off Chad Pennington as time expired, celebrating his sack by raising his arms and pointing toward the cloudy sky. Few in Gillette Stadium noticed the celebration.

title: Footnotes
description: Renzo Piano has been named the winner of the American Institute of Architects 2008 Gold Medal, the organizations highest honor. He will receive the award at its gala on Feb. 22 at the National Building Museum in Washington. Mr. Piano designed the New York Times building in Manhattan. ... The Lilly Foundation is donating $44 million to the Indiana University Jacobs School of Music for the construction of a state-of-the-art studio building. The gift is the largest ever received by the university to support the arts. ... In ceremonies at the Royal Academy of Music in London last week Queen Elizabeth II presented the composer Judith Weir with the Queens Medal for Music for 2007. The award, established in 2005, is intended to raise the general profile of music in Britain.

title: An Iran Gig for Chris de Burgh?
description: The Irish singer Chris de Burgh, below, best known for his hit The Lady in Red, is to perform in Iran in the summer with the Iranian rock band Arian, Agence France-Presse reported, citing the bands manager. Arian is a founder of modern Iranian pop and the first group in the Islamic republic to receive an official permit to perform. Mr. de Burghs appearance, which has not been confirmed by his Web site (cdeb.com), would be the first by a major Western pop star in Iran since the 1979 Islamic revolution, which regarded rock music as decadent.

title: Russian Bobsled Is Fastest in World Cup Race
description: Alexandr Zubkov of Russia drove his sled to victory in the four-man World Cup bobsled race, a year and a day after crashing on the course at the Olympic Sports Complex in Lake Placid, N.Y.His two-run time of 1 minute 48.79 seconds was 0.05 seconds faster than the American sled piloted by Steven Holcomb of Park City, Utah, who leads the standings with 660 points. Pierre Lueders of Canada, winner of the two-man race Saturday, was third.

title: Finn Is Fastest; Ligety Fifth
description: Kalle Palander of Finland got his third career giant slalom victory on the Gran Risa course in Alta Badia, Italy, and the American Ted Ligety skied the fastest second run to finish fifth.Palander led the first run and his two-run combined time of 2:30.92 was enough to hold off Austrias Benjamin Raich, the Olympic giant slalom champion, by 0.42 seconds.Ligety, who leads the giant slalom standings, was penalized by the International Ski Federation for showing up four minutes late to Saturdays public draw. By rule, he was forced to start 46th instead of within the top 15 and was fined $867. (AP)

title: The Election Watchdogs Going Missing
description: The Senate is ducking its responsibility to keep the Federal Election Commission stocked with qualified appointees to police the already booming election season. If a nasty partisan standoff is not soon resolved, the six-member regulatory panel could be left with just two commissioners remaining and unable to work. This is a ridiculous prospect  and an invitation to even more scheming and corner-cutting  in what is sure to be a multibillion-dollar campaign.

When I got to his site, it was easy enough to e-mail him since his site is well organized and there is a clear about page that leads you to a page with information about him. But when I got to that page, I learned that he isnt reading e-mails at the moment because he is on paternity leave until the end of December.

description: Given the vast repertory composed to celebrate Christmas, its mystifying that such a tiny slice of it is heard year after year. Most ensembles stick to traditional carols, Handels Messiah or a few relevant Baroque works. But Christmas is also a time when early music specialists like Frederick Renz and his Early Music New York are in their element. Mr. Renz has always taken the view that forgotten favorites of Christmas past  long past  are worth revisiting, and he invariably assembles engaging, well-researched programs that lift the holiday out of the modern hyper-commercial world.

title: Hazards: Football Head Injuries, Not So Cut and Dried
description: Those bone-jarring collisions on the football field that make fans wince and players tumble like rag dolls may not always be the real ones to worry about.

title: Laws of Nature, Source Unknown
description: Gravity, goes the slogan on posters and bumper stickers. It isnt just a good idea. Its the law.

title: Dancers Bring New Life to Scores Banned by Nazis
description: Much of the history of dance lies in the history of music. Now and again something happens to make us reconsider that history. One such event occurred over the weekend when, in a brilliantly enterprising program at the Juilliard School, the conductor James Conlon, the Juilliard Orchestra and Juilliard Dance presented three world premieres choreographed to long-forgotten scores, written from 1911 to 1935 by German composers whose work the Nazis had banned.

title: Iraq Leaders Denounce Bombings by Turkey
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqi leaders criticized Turkey on Monday for bombing Kurdish militants in northern Iraq with airstrikes that they said had left at least one woman dead.

title: Keeper of an Unlikely Trove, Gutenberg to Warhol
description: NEWARK  It is difficult to say which is more surprising: that the Newark Public Library owns prints by Picasso and Rauschenberg, a page of the Gutenberg Bible and a 1493 printed tome known as the Nuremberg Chronicle, or that William J. Dane, a dapper, refreshingly irreverent art scholar from New Hampshire, has been tending to this astounding collection for six decades.

title: As Ethanol Takes Its First Steps, Congress Proposes a Giant Leap
description: Congress is on the verge of writing into law one of the most ambitious dictates ever issued to American business: to create, from scratch, a huge new industry capable of converting agricultural wastes and other plant material into automotive fuel.

title: Sequoyah Highs Success Energizes Tribe
description: TAHLEQUAH, Okla.  If not for basketball, Angel Goodrich and her school, Sequoyah High, would be as easy to overlook as the dusty farming towns that freckle northeast Oklahoma. Goodrich, a shy sliver of a guard, is the face of the Lady Indians, who are the three-time defending state champions in their classification and a rising force on the national scene.

title: $7.4 Billion Pledged for Palestinians
description: PARIS  Eighty-seven countries and international organizations pledged $7.4 billion in aid to the Palestinians on Monday, in the most ambitious fund-raising effort in more than a decade to help Palestinians create a viable, peaceful and secure state of their own.

title: Weak Eyes, Strong Eyes
description: Q. Most people I know believe that its better to order weaker glasses than were prescribed because the correct prescription weakens your eyes even more and results in your needing a stronger prescription down the line. Is that true?

title: Lawyer in Pornography Case Is Spared Jail
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn.  Heaping blame on a church in Greenwich for trying to hide the fact that its longtime musical director had child pornography on a computer, a senior federal judge on Monday sentenced a lawyer who took part in the cover-up to home confinement for six months.

title: Long Island Couple Convicted of Enslaving 2 Domestic Workers for Years
description: CENTRAL ISLIP, N.Y.  The so-called Muttontown slave trial involved a wild barrage of testimony by two Indonesian domestic workers who were employed  and, prosecutors say, enslaved and tortured for years  by a well-to-do couple on Long Island. And the verdict Monday morning made for no less wild a scene.

title: Iowas Undemocratic Caucuses
description: Des Moines

title: The Hoops Star, the Movie Star and the Size 22 Feet
description: HAVING played professional basketball for 14 years in the National Basketball Association, Ive spent a great deal of time on airplanes over the last three decades.

title: Memo Pad
description: CHRISTMAS HOLIDAY AIR TRAVEL About the same number of people as last year, 47 million passengers, are expected to travel on domestic airlines during this Christmas holiday period, the Air Transport Association says. The four busiest air travel days in the period, which began last Thursday and continues through Jan 2, are expected to be, in decreasing order, Jan. 2, Dec. 21, Dec. 27, and Dec. 26. The least busy travel days are expected to be Christmas Day and Dec. 24, the airline trade group said.

title: Secret War in the Skies Over Korea
description: The Korean War has been called the forgotten war, and Missing in MIG Alley, on PBS on Tuesday night, illustrates a little-known chapter. It describes the rivalry in the sky between two types of fighter jets then on the cutting edge of military aviation: the Soviet MIG-15, used by the North Koreans, and the F-86 Sabre, flown by the Americans and the British.

title: Amid Strike, 2 NBC Hosts Will Return to the Air
description: NBC announced on Monday that its two late-night stars, Jay Leno and Conan OBrien, would return on Jan. 2 even if the strike against networks and studios by writers was not resolved.

title: Higher Wages at Harvard
description: To the Editor:

title: Goldman Beats 4th Quarter Estimates
description: Goldman Sachs topped estimates for fourth-quarter earnings on Tuesday, rounding out another record year despite the turbulence in the financial markets.

title: New Police Radio System in New York State Draws Scrutiny
description: A $2 billion emergency radio network intended to connect all emergency agencies and local police and fire departments in New York State has failed its first major test, prompting concerns from some state officials and causing the states second largest city, Buffalo, to opt out of the system.

title: A Grandfathers Suicide Bombing Puzzles Algerians
description: ALGIERS  As a suicide bomber, Rabah Bechla was most unusual. But the story of Mr. Bechla, a 63-year-old grandfather of seven who rammed an explosives-packed truck into a United Nations office here on Dec. 11, killing at least 17 people, is in many ways the story of Algeria itself.

title: San Francisco Opera, Coming to Theaters
description: Its an arms race out there in opera land.

title: Chamber Works Conclude a Pianists Busy Weekend
description: A musician learning solo repertory might spend many hours perfecting a single phrase and years honing an interpretation. Chamber music needs similar dedication, and as in any burgeoning relationship, new musical partners need time to discover each others quirks.

title: Signs of TB in Ancient Skull Support Theory on Vitamin D
description: In the disease-scarred bones of a Homo erectus from Turkey, scientists have found evidence of a peril that human ancestors encountered in their migrations out of Africa: tuberculosis.

title: Tests Negative on L.I. Man Whose Relatives Had Avian Flu
description: Avian flu in Pakistan nearly touched the United States this month when a 38-year-old Nassau County resident returned from visiting family members who were later confirmed to be part of Pakistans first cluster of human infections.

title: Newborn Found in Queens Trash Bin
description: A newborn girl was found Monday night  one of the coldest nights so far this year  in a commercial trash bin in Queens, the police said. She was wrapped in a blanket and stuffed in a paper bag.

title: A Clearer Muddy Story: Fast-Flowing Water Can Form Deposits
description: Much of the earth is little more than glorified mud. That is, something like two-thirds of the sedimentary rock at or near the earths surface is mudstone, shale or other rock formed by the deposition of clays and other fine particles.

title: Airlines to Use Courts to Thwart a Movement
description: DOMESTIC airlines are not happy about a New York State law, the first of its kind, that will require airlines to provide certain services to passengers who sit for three hours or more on airplanes stuck on the tarmac.

title: For Sports Fans, a Season of Foul Play
description: The sports world is giving New Yorkers more than their usual quotient of agita, and that includes people who think a full-court press is a legal maneuver and a hat trick part of David Copperfields act.

title: A New Deal to Develop Ground Zero
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is expected to approve a deal Tuesday that would bring an international shopping center operator back to ground zero to help build retail space in the buildings and tunnels under construction on the 16-acre site.

title: Weeks Best
description: PLAYER Paolo Maldini, 39, who won his third FIFA Club World Cup with A.C. Milan on Sunday in a 4-2 victory against Boca Juniors in Japan, said he would retire at the end of the Italian season in June. Maldini, who has played for Milan since the 1984-85 season, has won many major titles with the club, including seven Serie A titles and five European Champions League titles.

title: House Passes Sprawling Spending Bill
description: WASHINGTON  The House approved a sprawling $516 billion budget bill Monday night in an effort to end a spending standoff with President Bush and free money that federal agencies have been awaiting since Oct. 1.

title: Putin Agrees to Be Protgs Prime Minister
description: MOSCOW  President Vladimir V. Putin formally declared Monday that he intended to become prime minister next year, all but ensuring his dominance of the Russian government even after his term ends.

title: Bank Robbed Twice, Maybe by Same Man
description: A man who robbed a bank in Brooklyn on Monday morning may have not only returned to the scene of the crime, but he may also have robbed it again.

title: Brought on by Darkness, Disorder Needs Light
description: In a few days, the winter solstice will plunge us into the longest and darkest night of the year. Is it any surprise that we humans respond with a holiday season of relentless cheer and partying?

title: Start-Up Sells Solar Panels at Lower-Than-Usual Cost
description: SAN JOSE, Calif.  Nanosolar, a heavily financed Silicon Valley start-up whose backers include Googles co-founders, plans to announce Tuesday that it has begun selling its innovative solar panels, which are made using a technique that is being held out as the future of solar power manufacturing.

title: Rethinking Afghanistan: Were We Sidetracked in Iraq?
description: To the Editor:

title: F.C.C. Eases Media Ownership Rule
description: WASHINGTON  By the narrowest of margins, the Federal Communications Commission adopted proposals by its chairman to tighten the reins on the cable television industry while loosening 32-year-old restrictions that have prevented a company from owning both a newspaper and a television or radio station in the same city.

title: Iran Receives Nuclear Fuel in Blow to U.S.
description: WASHINGTON  The United States lost a long battle when Russia, as it announced on Monday, delivered nuclear fuel to an Iranian power plant that is at the center of an international dispute over its nuclear program. Iran, for its part, confirmed on Monday plans to build a second such plant.

title: Bus and Subway Service Improvements Planned
description: To sweeten the pill of a proposed fare increase, New York City Transit said on Monday that it was planning a series of subway and bus service improvements that would go into effect in the second half of next year.

title: Kyrgyzstan: On the Path to a One-Party State
description: With 95 percent of the ballots counted, the Ak Zhol party of President Kurmanbek Bakiyev had captured 49 percent of the votes in the parliamentary elections on Sunday, while the second-place finisher, the opposition party Ata Meken, had 9 percent. But under Kyrgyzstans election rules, parties must surmount two electoral barriers in order to enter Parliament: support from 5 percent of the countrys 2.7 million registered voters, and 0.5 percent of the total electorate in each of the countrys nine voting regions. As of Monday, just one party of the 12 running had qualified for any seats in Parliament  the presidents.

title: Holiday Specials
description: For anyone who has to travel for work while everyone else is celebrating the holiday season, there is a silver lining: hotels that cater to business travelers are charging deeply discounted rates.

title: The Mourning After
description: London

title: Ingersoll to Buy Climate Control Maker
description: Ingersoll-Rand, the industrial conglomerate, agreed on Monday to buy Trane, the air-conditioning company that is the successor to American Standard, for $10.1 billion.

title: The Claim: A Little Alcohol Can Help You Beat a Cold
description: THE FACTS

title: Petrinos Departure Is Particularly Disturbing
description: The last several months have seen a brutal assault on our faith in the redemptive power of sport. Michael Vick. Marion Jones. Madison Square Garden. The Tour de France. Last week, the Mitchell report named names and soiled reputations.

title: WORLD BRIEFING | MIDDLE EAST; Lebanon: Presidential Vote Postponed Again
description: The Syrian-backed opposition boycotted a vote to elect a new president, delaying Parliaments decision for the ninth time. The election is now scheduled for Saturday. The presidency has been vacant since Nov. 23.

title: Teenage Risks, and How to Avoid Them
description: Last January in Freehold Township, N.J., a car driven by a 17-year-old high school student, with two fellow students as passengers, passed a car being driven by another teenager at 70 miles an hour in a 50-mile zone. The passing vehicle crashed into an oncoming van. Three boys and the 68-year-old van driver were killed.

description: To the Editor:

title: Scholastic Plans to Put Its Branding Iron on a Successor to Harry Potter
description: With the Harry Potter series now completed, Scholastic, the United States publisher of those wildly successful books by J. K. Rowling, is moving forward with what it hopes will be its follow-up blockbuster series.

title: Bernstein Returns in the Form of Festival
description: Leonard Bernstein, once a prominent presence on New York's music scene in the era of student protest, black-and-white television and classical music's cultural relevance, will once again loom large in the city.

title: Democrats Delay a Vote on Immunity for Wiretaps
description: WASHINGTON  In a setback for the White House, Senate Democrats on Monday put off until at least next month any decision on whether to give legal protection to the phone carriers that helped with the National Security Agencys eavesdropping program.

title: Housing Starts Decline 3.7%
description: The housing market, in its deepest rut since the early 1990s, showed little sign of stabilization in November, and economists expect conditions to worsen in the near term.

title: Knicks Ugly Night Capped by Coachs Frank Words
description: Isiah Thomas seemingly has a built-in mute button that self-activates every time he feels the impulse to blast his players. The device either went dead or shorted out Monday night after Thomas again watched his team collapse.

title: Britain: Data on Would-Be Drivers Lost in U.S.
description: The transport minister, Ruth Kelly, left, told Parliament that personal information on three million candidates for British drivers licenses was missing after an Iowa subsidiary of the government contractor for the written part of the learners permit test mislaid a computer hard drive. No financial information was among the details. The disclosure was the latest in a series of blunders involving data submitted to government departments, including the loss in the mail in October of two computer disks carrying confidential data, including bank details, on 25 million people in families receiving government child benefits. Banks have found no evidence of fraud from that loss, according to the finance minister, Alistair Darling. Ms. Kelly said that the drivers data had been specially formatted for the Iowa subsidiary of Pearson Driving Assessments Ltd., a contractor of the Driving Standards Agency, and that it was not readily usable by outsiders.

title: Coughlin Tells Giants It Is Time to Refocus
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Tom Coughlins face is so telling that it may as well be made of neon. Coughlin, the Giants coach, does not mask his emotions well, and usually does not care to. In that way, he is a refreshing presence in an N.F.L. coaching fraternity increasingly adept at providing bland answers and calculated personas.

title: Going Public Caps Dream for a Maker of Software
description: SAN MATEO, Calif.  If the initial public offering for NetSuite shares goes as planned later this week, Evan Goldberg will have come a long way from the overcrowded Silicon Valley apartment that served as the companys first office nearly 10 years ago.

title: Bold Escape Not First Try for Inmate
description: ELIZABETH, N.J.  There was a gnawing familiarity to the daring weekend escape of two inmates from the most secure part of the Union County jail.

title: Fashion and Faith Meet, on Foreheads of the Pious
description: CAIRO  There is a strong undercurrent of competition in Egypt these days, an unstated contest among people eager to prove just how religious they are. The field of battle is the street and the focus tends to be on appearance, as opposed to conviction.

title: A Recruit for Tintin
description: Andy Serkis, who provided the human expression and movements for the computer-generated characters in two Peter Jackson projects  he was Gollum in the Lord of the Rings trilogy and the giant ape in King Kong  will reunite with Mr. Jackson in the DreamWorks trilogy Tintin, Reuters reported. Although DreamWorks offered no confirmation, it was believed that Mr. Serkis, above, will play Captain Haddock, a temperamental seafarer, in the adaptation of the comic strip created by Herg (1907-83) and dealing with the adventures of the young reporter Tintin. Steven Spielberg and Mr. Jackson will each direct one film; the third director is to be determined.

title: A True Outsider Joins Michigans Ranks
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich.  So much for the idea that only a Michigan man can coach at the University of Michigan.

title: Corzine Signs Bill Ending Executions, Then Commutes Sentences of Eight
description: TRENTON  Few other issues have prompted the kind of intensity and conviction that Gov. Jon S. Corzine shows when he talks about preventing even one more execution.

title: California Moves Closer to Expanding Health Care
description: SACRAMENTO  California moved significantly closer to enacting a broad expansion of health insurance coverage on Monday when the Democratic-controlled Assembly passed legislation that has the backing of the Republican governor, Arnold Schwarzenegger.

title: St.Clair Bourne, Filmmaker, Dies at 64
description: St.Clair Bourne, a documentary filmmaker who recorded American black culture, produced portraits of eminent African-Americans and, in one stark film, drew a parallel between the civil rights movement and the troubles in Northern Ireland, died on Saturday in Manhattan. He was 64 and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Belgium: Loser to Lead Interim Government
description: After a meeting with King Albert II, Guy Verhofstadt, left, the liberal ousted by voters in June, accepted the job of forming and leading an interim government because of the gravity of the situation in which our country finds itself. But he said he did not want to remain in power beyond March. Mr. Verhofstadt, who had been prime minister since 1999, conceded defeat after the June election but has stayed on because the conservatives who won proved unable to form a coalition. But he has lacked power to act on major issues, and on Saturday thousands of union members marched through Brussels to protest the half-year political impasse and rising fuel and food prices. At the heart of the deadlock are disputes among parties from Dutch-speaking Flanders and the French-speaking area, Wallonia. Those tensions engulfed even the countrys annual beauty pageant on Saturday, when the new Miss Belgium, Alize Poulicek, a blond 20-year-old from the French-speaking part of the country, was booed when she disclosed that she could not speak Dutch. The contest was held in Antwerp, a stronghold of Flemish nationalism, before an audience of 3,500. Ms. Poulicek, who besides French speaks English and Czech, told the Flemish television broadcaster VRT that she would try to learn more Dutch.

title: The Second Avenue Deli, Now in Midtown, Reopens
description: The clear matzo ball soup was the same, the blue and brown tile floors were the same, even much of the kitchen staff was the same.

title: Survivor Lifts CBS
description: Todd Herzog, above, a 22-year-old flight attendant from Utah, became the latest champion of the Survivor series on Sunday as the final episode of the shows 15th edition gave CBS a modest boost in the ratings. Attracting 15.1 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m., the Survivor: China finale achieved ratings slightly better than the shows average this season, Nielsen estimated. Compared with last falls Cook Islands finale, however, Sundays finale was down more than 10 percent among adults 18 to 49. CBS averaged the most viewers for the night, although the network did rank second at 10 with its Survivor: China reunion special (12.2 million), which trailed NBCs Sunday Night Football coverage. NBC and Fox shared second place for the night, but Fox led over all among the 18-to-49 set, largely because of an overrun of its afternoon football coverage, which delivered more than 21 million viewers as prime time began at 7 p.m. A new episode of The Simpsons (10.1 million) also put Fox on top at 8 p.m. among adults 18 to 49. ABC was fourth for the night with a lineup of repeats after Extreme Makeover: Home Edition at 8 (11.8 million).

title: Food and Fuel Compete for Land
description: Shopping at a Whole Foods Market in suburban Chicago, Meredith Estes said food prices have jumped so much she has resorted to coupons. Charles T. Rodgers Jr., an Arkansas cattle rancher, said normal feed rations so expensive and scarce he is scrambling for alternatives. In Oregon, Jack Joyce, the owner of Rogue Ales, said the cost of barley malt has soared 88 percent this year.

title: Boy, 9, Dies in Staten Island House Fire
description: A 9-year-old Staten Island boy died Monday after a fire raced through his familys home in Princes Bay, despite desperate rescue attempts by his father, firefighters and several neighbors.

title: The Obama-Clinton Issue
description: Hillary Clinton has been a much better senator than Barack Obama. She has been a serious, substantive lawmaker who has worked effectively across party lines. Obama has some accomplishments under his belt, but many of his colleagues believe that he has not bothered to master the intricacies of legislation or the maze of Senate rules. He talks about independence, but he has never quite bucked liberal orthodoxy or party discipline.

title: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
Zoologist Gives a Voice to Big Cats in the Wilderness
description: Among zoologists, Alan Rabinowitz is known as the Indiana Jones of wildlife conservation. But he is actually more the Dag Hammarskjold of biology.

title: California Moves Toward Universal Health Care
description: SACRAMENTO  California moved significantly closer to enacting a broad expansion of health insurance coverage Monday when the Democratic-controlled Assembly passed legislation that has the backing of the Republican governor, Arnold Schwarzenegger.

title: Wanted: A Defender of the Census
description: At a confirmation hearing this afternoon, senators will question Steve H. Murdock, President Bushs nominee to be the next director of the Census Bureau. Mr. Murdock, the official state demographer of Texas, has impressive academic and professional credentials and a reputation for integrity and objectivity. What the senators will most need to figure out is if Mr. Murdock also has the political fortitude for the job.

title: White House Visitor Logs Are Public, Judge Rules
description: WASHINGTON  A federal judge ruled Monday that White House visitor logs were public records and ordered the Bush administration to stop withholding them from scrutiny by outside groups.

title: Darwins Era, Modern Themes: Science, Faith and Publication
description: Given the furor he feared it would unleash, it is not surprising that Charles Darwin sat on his great idea, refusing to publish The Origin of Species until 1859, more than 20 years after he first devised the theory of evolution.

title: Insouciance Recaptured
description: Isabelle Dinoire, the Frenchwoman who received the worlds first partial face transplant, regained nearly full use of her facial muscles within 18 months and is satisfied with the aesthetic result, according to her surgeon.

title: South Africa: Two-Man Fight on for Tuesday
description: Delegates of the governing African National Congress scheduled the election of party president for Tuesday, ending two days of partisan warfare between supporters of the only candidates to be voted on, Thabo Mbeki, the current party leader and president of the country, and his onetime government deputy, Jacob Zuma. The delegates at the party conference in Polokwane nominated the two and scheduled the vote after agreeing on restrictions on the balloting, including a ban on electronic voting. Mr. Zumas supporters argued that anything but ballots counted by hand would open the bitterly fought election to fraud. Mr. Mbeki, who is seeking a third term as the partys president, appears to trail Mr. Zuma.

title: Senior Executive of Fidelity to Lead Morgan Stanley Unit
description: Morgan Stanley said on Monday that it had hired a senior executive from Fidelity Investments to lead its retail brokerage division. The executive, Ellyn A. McColgan, will take over from James P. Gorman, the former Merrill Lynch executive who currently heads the retail unit.

description: TWO-LANE BLACKTOP

title: Fair Pay for Judges
description: The rancid political quagmire that is Albany these days produced a rare breakthrough last week on a matter of great importance to New Yorks justice system  a pay raise for judges. There is at last a chance that the states woefully underpaid judiciary will get a raise this year. But that will require Sheldon Silver, the Assembly speaker, to step up and make it happen.

title: Footnotes
description: La Scalas opening night performance of Wagners Tristan und Isolde, directed by Patrice Chreau and led by Daniel Barenboim, will be shown at theaters across the United States and abroad by Emerging Pictures, beginning on Jan. 27 at Symphony Space. ... Mamie Gummer, Kristine Nielsen, Benjamin Walker, Rosie Benton and Derek Cecil have joined Laura Linney and Ben Daniels in the cast of the Roundabout Theater Company production of Les Liaisons Dangereuses, beginning previews on April 11 at the American Airlines Theater. ... Ann Hampton Callaway will appear Tuesday night through Monday in her new holiday show at Jazz at Lincoln Centers Dizzys Club Coca-Cola.
