title: BioShock Triumphs at TV Video Game Awards
description: BioShock, the moody, elegant adventure from Take-Two, continued its romp through the year-end video game awards season on Monday as it took the top prize in the awards presented by the G4 television network.

title: Patterns: In the Upper Great Plains, Lower Mortality Rates
description: Minnesota is to die for  unless you are in a hurry to expire.

title: Obama and Edwards Engage, Gently, on Special Interests
description: DAVENPORT, Iowa  Senator Barack Obama and former Senator John Edwards, two Democratic presidential candidates courting many of the same undecided Iowa voters, added to their efforts Monday to distinguish between each other on the issue of reducing special-interest influence in Washington.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,883 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:

title: WORLD BRIEFING | EUROPE; Greece: Labor Minister Fired
description: The government appointed a new labor and welfare minister after dismissing her predecessor over the weekend after a series of scandals that included an accusation that he illegally employed foreign workers. Fanni Palli-Petralia, a former tourism minister, replaces Vassilis Magginas, who held the post for just seven months. He had been under attack over the governments plan to overhaul the troubled social security system. Unions have been staging strikes in opposition to the plan.

title: Iran Suggests It Is Building 2nd Nuclear Plant
description: TEHRAN, Dec. 17  Iran confirmed Monday that it had received the first fuel shipment for its nuclear power plant at Bushehr, but also indicated for the first time that it was building a second nuclear power plant.

title: After Latest Incident, Isles Simon to Get Help
description: SYOSSET, N.Y.  A black stocking cap pulled low on his shaved head, the troubled Islanders forward Chris Simon silently walked out of the teams practice facility Monday. It is uncertain when  or even if  Simon will return to the team.

title: In a Thickly Textured Maelstrom, Nothings Left to Chance
description: Dillinger Escape Plans music is arranged down to the millisecond and always has been. But watching its shows is like cranking the handle on a jack-in-the-box. You know whats coming, but youre startled anyway, and then you do it again.

title: Rayovac Batteries in a Partnership With the World of Disney Characters
description: BEWARE, Energizer bunny, wherever you are. Some familiar Disney characters are leading an assault by a rival brand on the battery market.

title: A Big Gift for the Met: The Arbus Archives
description: Two years ago gallerygoers had a chance to discover the personal side of Diane Arbus in a retrospective at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. In addition to the portraits that made her famous  powerfully unsettling photographs of dwarfs, transvestites and everyday people  the Met filled librarylike rooms with her photographic equipment, pages from her diaries, books from her home and studio and family pictures.

title: Questions on Illegal Immigrants Lead to Raid on Nonprofits Office
description: NEW HAVEN  As Connecticut grapples with the remnants of a weekend storm and shivers in sub-freezing temperatures, a nonprofit group that helps many poor residents pay their heating bills is reeling after federal agents raided its offices on Thursday.

title: Tinsley Is More Careful Since Escaping Attack
description: Indiana Pacers guard Jamaal Tinsley knows he is a lucky man. He knows that only a few inches separated him from a terrible fate. Less than two weeks after the former Washington Redskins safety Sean Taylor was shot and killed by an intruder in his home, Tinsleys car was sprayed with bullets from an assault rifle outside an Indianapolis hotel.

title: Overhaul Proposed in Accounting Standards Board
description: The Financial Accounting Foundation, the body that decides who will set accounting rules in the United States, plans on Tuesday to propose an overhaul aimed at enabling the Financial Accounting Standards Board to act faster while increasing the power of its chairman, Robert H. Herz.

title: Real-Life Superheroes to a Bunch of Comics Geeks
description: At a recent performance of Comic Book Club, a weekly stage talk show at the Peoples Improv Theater in Chelsea, an audience member declined to give his name. I have family and friends, he explained. Im a closeted geek.

title: 31 Accused in Florida of Falsifying Home Loans
description: MIAMI  Federal prosecutors on Monday announced the indictment of 31 people in connection with a mortgage fraud scheme involving at least 28 properties in South Florida and fraudulent loans totaling more than $14.2 million.

title: Reggae Honors for Marley Family
description: Dead more than 26 years, Bob Marley still casts a spell, topping Billboards year-end ranking of top reggae albums, Reuters reported. Not only did he occupy the first, ninth and tenth places, but his sons, Stephen and Damian Marley, have captured the No. 2 and No. 3 positions on the chart. The senior Marley took first place with Forever Bob Marley (Madacy Special Products/Madacy), above, a collection of songs from his pre-Island Records days; and Bob Marley & the Wailers had the No. 9 and No. 10 best sellers with Africa United: The Singles Collection (Tuff Gong/Island/UMe/IDJMG) and Gold (Tuff Gong/Island/Chronicles/UMe). Stephen Marley finished just behind his father with Mind Control (Ghetto Youths/Tuff Gong/Universal Republic/ URMG), followed by Damian Marley with Welcome to Jamrock on the same label. The brothers also took third and fourth place on Billboards year-end list of top reggae artists, headed for the second consecutive year by Matisyahu, a New Yorker who attracts fans with his mix of hip-hop and reggae and lyrics about his Hasidic Jewish background.

title: The Cruelty in Bull Riding
description: To the Editor:

title: House Passes Sweeping Energy Bill
description: WASHINGTON  Legislation that will slowly but fundamentally change the cars Americans drive, the fuel they burn, the way they light their homes and the price they pay for food cleared the House on Tuesday by a large margin. President Bush said he would sign the hard-fought energy bill on Wednesday.

title: Romney Takes On a Rising Huckabee, Comparing Records
description: This television advertisement for Mitt Romney, his second going after his Republican rival Mike Huckabee, will start running in Iowa on Tuesday.

title: E.C.B. Makes $500 Billion Infusion
description: FRANKFURT  The European Central Bank on Tuesday pumped 348 billion euros ($500 billion) into the financial system, easing conditions in credit markets grappling with both a global lending squeeze linked to the United States housing downturn and traditional year-end demands for cash.

title: Campaign Song 2008? Strike Up the Broadband

Delivered to Downing Street by some of the 545 signatories, the letter said in part: As authors, we are deeply concerned at the low levels of childhood literacy across Britain. In a complex world, reading has become increasingly important  if not crucial. A government spokesman said there was a commitment to bring a sharper focus to the basics of reading.

title: English Arts Council Gives and Takes
description: Nearly 200 arts organizations across England are being informed that beginning in April they will no longer receive financing from Arts Council England as it imposes its biggest cuts since its establishment 50 years ago, The Guardian of London reported on Monday. But of the 990 organizations that receive money from the $2 billion available to the council, three-quarters will receive increases to match or exceed inflation, and about 80 groups are being added to the roster of recipients. The Royal Opera House and the Royal Shakespeare Company will receive increases to match inflation. Among those told to expect an end to financing are two chamber orchestras, the City of London Sinfonia and the London Mozart Players. The Pop-Up Theater company for children, based in London and in business for more than 25 years, has been told that it is likely to lose its $392,000 grant. Admitting that the holiday-season timing was bad, the Arts Council said tough decisions had to be made. Louise Wylie, its spokeswoman, said the criteria for financing included breadth of audience and excellence of work. Peter Hewitt, the chief executive of the Arts Council, told Arts Industry magazine, Yes, some organizations will be unhappy with our decisions, but the majority will have a stronger, better future. Organizations facing reduction or withdrawal of their grants have an opportunity to appeal.

title: Ethanol and the Energy Bill

title: Dumbo Is Now Protected as a Historic District
description: Like SoHo and TriBeCa before it, Dumbo has now made its way from neighborhood acronym to historic treasure. Dumbo  the name once stood for Down Under the Manhattan Bridge Overpass but now hardly requires an explanation  was designated New York Citys 90th historic district by the Landmarks Preservation Commission. (The first historic district, designated in 1965, was Brooklyn Heights.)The new historic district is bounded by John Street to the north, York Street to the south, Main Street to the west and Bridge Street to the east, and includes 91 buildings that reflect the industrial heritage of the Brooklyn waterfront.

description: Juan Carlos Osorio said Tuesday he had landed his dream job. The New York Red Bulls said they have landed their dream coach. But as so many others have found, the mystical force that seems to surround the MetroStars/Red Bulls has often turned those dreams into night terrors.

title: Aiming to Put More Carts and Better Food on the Streets
description: Adhering to the philosophy that an apple a day may help keep the doctor away, city officials are trying to increase the availability of fresh fruits and vegetables in poor and minority neighborhoods through a sharp increase in vending carts, which they hope will combat the citys obesity epidemic.The proposal, introduced by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and City Council Speaker Christine C. Quinn, calls for 1,500 new permits for fruit and vegetable carts in neighborhoods where consumption of fruits and vegetables is low. Currently, fewer than 10 percent of the 4,100 mobile food carts serve fruits and vegetables. (About half serve processed foods like kabobs and gyros, while most of the remaining serve things like coffee and pretzels.)

title: Frances New Old Way of Limiting CO2
description: PARIS  France has come up with an ingenious way to get consumers to buy more fuel-efficient cars: by giving a rebate to high-mileage cars and charging a surtax on gas hogs. The system is called a bonus-malus approach, such as exists in auto insurance. Translated from the Latin, it is a Peter-Paul approach, in which the state robs Peter of 2,600 euros ($3,800) when he buys a Porsche Cayenne Turbo and pays Paul 700 euros ($1,025) when he buys a Mini Cooper D.

title: Rangers-Pens Pregame: For Jagr, a New Center and New Teeth
description: Among the new things you will see in the Rangers game tonight against the Penguins: a new set of front teeth for Jaromir Jagr, who had them knocked out (again) against Phoenix. He smiled to show them off outside the locker room at Madison Square Garden before the game when asked if he had been to the dentist. They love me there, he said.

title: Smoking May Be Hazardous to Your Bar

description: I dont know how you all feel this holiday season, but I must say the spirit hasnt gripped me yet. Maybe thats because Im trying to get as much work done as I can so I can enjoy a couple of weeks of vacation, which means, by the way, that Im going to take a brief hiatus from The Pour. So, have a great holiday and a happy New Year, and Ill see you sooner than you know in 2008.

title: Housing Starts Decline 3.7%
description: The housing market, in its deepest rut since the early 1990s, showed little sign of climbing out in November, and economists said that they expected conditions to worsen in the near term.

title: Poland: Online Auction Trader Sold
description: The South African media group Naspers agreed to acquire Tradus, which operates the largest online auction trader in Poland, for 946 million, or $1.9 billion, adding to its Internet businesses in emerging markets like Eastern Europe. The deal extends Nasperss reach as it seeks to diversify its revenue, largely dependent on newspapers and magazines. Tradus, based in London, has online auction businesses in Eastern Europe, specifically in the Czech Republic, Bulgaria, Hungary, Romania and Slovakia  and beyond, to Ukraine and Russia.

description: The comedian Jimmy Kimmel will resume his late-night show on ABC on Jan. 2, the network said Tuesday.

title: 75 Years Later, Survivor Helps Commemorate Ukrainian Famine
description: Seventy-five years ago, in a small village in eastern Ukraine, Daria Schulha Kira recalls huddling with her three siblings as Communist Party officials ransacked their home looking for grain. Your government needs your food, she remembers the armed men shouting. Then they took iron bars and poked in the walls and the floors looking for anything they could find.

title: Living to 100, and Looking Back on a Legacy of New York Jazz
description: Lawrence Lucie no longer has the jet-black hair, the stylish suits or the dexterity that made him one of the pre-eminent rhythm guitarists in the jazz world. But he can still draw a crowd.

title: Reids Relationship With Bush Enters Deep Freeze
description: WASHINGTON  Harry Reid, the Senate majority leader, has called President Bush a loser and a liar and has referred to him derisively as King George. Mr. Reid has also apologized  but only, he likes to point out, for the loser line.

description: MARSEILLE, France  The other day, a dozen or so teenage rappers in baggy jeans and hoodies gathered outside a community arts center called Le Mille-Pattes in Noailles, a poor immigrant neighborhood here, hard by the Old Port.

description: Frank Morgan, a jazz saxophonist whose promising career was derailed by drug problems in the 1950s but whose triumphant comeback 30 years later led to an unexpected taste of midlife stardom, died on Friday in Minneapolis. He was 73.

description: ISTANBUL  Turkish military authorities arrested the leader of the countrys Kurdish political party on Tuesday, saying he had illegally avoided military service. The arrest capped weeks of attempts to shut down the party, and his supporters said it was political.

title: Morgenthau Says Rumors of His Quitting Are False
description: Robert M. Morgenthau, facing a swirl of rumors that he was retiring after 33 years as Manhattan district attorney, met with reporters on Tuesday and said the speculation was untrue.

title: Bush Signs Broad Energy Bill
description: WASHINGTON  Legislation that will slowly but fundamentally change the cars Americans drive, the fuel they burn, the way they light their homes and the price they pay for food was signed by President Bush Wednesday after having been adopted by the House on Tuesday by a large margin.

description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pakistans election commission has upheld an earlier ruling barring the former prime minister Nawaz Sharif from running in general elections scheduled for next month.

title: Strong Turnout for Fed Auction
description: The Federal Reserve said Wednesday that it collected bids from 93 financial institutions on $20 billion in loans in its first auction of short-term credit, a strong turnout that suggests banks may be more inclined to borrow from the Fed under the new auction-based system.

description: WASHINGTON--Congress gave final approval on Wednesday to a plan that will spare millions of middle-class taxpayers from paying higher taxes in the coming months. The White House welcomed the development and said President Bush would sign the bill.

title: U.S. Acts to Ease Crunch at New York-Area Airports
description: HERNDON, Va.  Travelers going through Kennedy and Newark Liberty airports next summer may find somewhat fewer flights at the hours they most want to travel, but they are far more likely to leave on time or arrive in time to make connections, federal transportation officials said Wednesday.

title: Terrorism Damage Bill Is Passed by House
description: The House approved a government insurance program on Tuesday that commits Washington to paying for most of the damage in the event of a terrorist attack in the next seven years. The vote was 360 to 53.

title: Bail Is Denied in 5th Ave. Killing
description: A state judge on Tuesday denied bail for Natavia S. Lowery, a personal assistant accused of killing her boss, Linda Stein, a real estate broker and former punk rock manager, in Ms. Steins Fifth Avenue apartment in October.

title: Resolving Crisis in Congo Hinges on Foreign Forces
description: RUTSHURU, Congo  Word spread quickly of the surrender of four Interahamwe, members of the Hutu fearsome youth militia that carried out the Rwandan genocide in 1994 and has been hiding in the eastern Congo jungles since. A crowd of people in their Sunday best soon gathered to gawk at the young men as they marched through town.

title: As Campaign Season Nears, Spitzer Seeks New Help and Eyes Republican Seats
description: ALBANY  As he revs up his political operation for the coming year, Gov. Eliot Spitzer may bring aboard a prominent financier and Democratic donor to help expand the governors relationships with business and labor groups, a person close to Mr. Spitzer said on Tuesday.

title: Report Finds U.S. Agencies Distracted by Focus on Cuba
description: Catching Americans who travel illegally to Cuba or who purchase cigars, rum or other products from the island may be distracting some American government agencies from higher-priority missions like fighting terrorism and combating narcotics trafficking, a government audit to be released Wednesday says.

title: Judge May Not Step in to Halt Arizona Law
description: LOS ANGELES  The legal effort to block what is widely considered the nations toughest law against employers who hire illegal immigrants may be headed for a setback in Arizona after a federal judge said Tuesday that he was not inclined to stop the law from going into effect Jan. 1.

description: WASHINGTON  NASA spent Tuesday troubleshooting problems in space and on the ground, with astronauts examining malfunctioning joints on the International Space Station and engineers testing fuel tank sensors aboard the shuttle Atlantis as it sits on its launching pad.

description: A 25-year-old woman and her 6-year-old daughter were found dead in their Bronx apartment Tuesday after friends and relatives grew worried that the girl had not shown up at school and the woman had not arrived for work.

title: Picture of Secret Detentions Emerges in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pakistans military and intelligence agencies, apparently trying to avoid acknowledging an elaborate secret detention system, have quietly set free nearly 100 men suspected of links to terrorism, few of whom were charged, human rights groups and lawyers here say.

title: G.M. to Start Another Round of Buyouts and Seek Cheaper Labor
description: DETROIT  General Motors said Tuesday that it would begin another round of buyout offers that would allow it to begin hiring new workers for significantly less pay.

description: Silver Lake Partners has agreed to acquire a quarter of the Gerson Lehrman Group, the upstart Wall Street research firm that has come under scrutiny from regulators, according to people involved in the negotiations.

title: Flights of Pianistic Fantasy, Not for the Fainthearted
description: One of the most formidable performances of 2007 in New York came in February when the pianist Yefim Bronfman played the premiere of Esa-Pekka Salonens Piano Concerto with the New York Philharmonic. Mr. Salonen, who conducted the performance, was late in finishing the work, an exuberantly modernist riff on Rachmaninoff-style late Romanticism. The piano part is astoundingly difficult. Yet Mr. Bronfman, who had fewer than five weeks to learn it, played with commanding virtuosity.

title: Seminarys Renovation Juggles the Old, the New and the Financial
description: The General Theological Seminary in Chelsea has been on the same site in Manhattan for almost two centuries, and this is both a blessing and a burden.

description: BEEP, beep, beep, beep: its the truck backing up with this years crop of wine books for the holidays. Make no mistake, reading is the next best thing to drinking for the wine lover, and much more practical on subways, buses and trains.

title: Betting on the Patriots Isnt the Lock of the Year
description: None of them wear a headset or pore over game film. Their defensive schemes are better suited for an abacus than a computer. Las Vegas oddsmakers, however, have done something that none of the N.F.Ls. brightest offensive and defensive coordinators have done this season: beat the New England Patriots.

title: Huckabee Now a Candidate With Something to Lose
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Mike Huckabee was taking a vigorous morning run on a hotel treadmill on Saturday, avoiding the trail outside. Too much snow out there, said Mr. Huckabee, a former Arkansas governor, explaining his wariness of the slick roads and blocked pathways of New Hampshire. He worried, he said, about getting sideswiped or hitting some patch of black ice and getting hurt.

title: Busy Bank Robber at Fulton Mall Was Too Predictable, Police Say
description: For Orlando Taylor, a 26-year-old Brooklyn man who apparently had a strange attraction to a couple of bank branches at the bustling Fulton Mall, three times was a charm. So was the fourth time. But according to the police, when he returned on Tuesday to commit a fifth robbery in five days, his luck ran out.

title: McCain Sees a Need for Mortgage Aid

title: WORLD BRIEFING | THE AMERICAS; Brazil: Santa Comes Under Fire
description: Suspected drug traffickers shot at a helicopter carrying a Santa Claus to a Rio de Janeiro slum to distribute toys. No one was hurt, although two shots hit the copter. It returned to its base, and the Santa took a car to complete his mission. According to the police, the gunmen apparently mistook the helicopter and its passenger as a police operation.

title: Canada: Core Inflation Rate Falls
description: Cheaper new cars, a result of the surging Canadian dollar, lowered Canadas core inflation rate last month, Statistics Canada reported. The core portion of the countrys consumer price index, which excludes volatile items like gasoline and mortgage interest, was 1.6 percent in November, compared with 1.8 percent in October. The agency attributed that unexpected decline to a 3.9 percent drop in new car prices and lease rates. Canadas overall inflation rate grew slightly in November to 2.5 percent, compared with 2.4 percent in October. Much of that was attributed to a 17.6 percent increase in gasoline prices.

description: WASHINGTON  President Bush has approved what officials are describing as the most significant reorganization of American ground forces since World War II, signing off on a plan that will keep more troops than previously envisioned in Europe and add large numbers of soldiers to bases in Colorado, Georgia and Texas, Army officials said Wednesday.

title: Master of Rings to Tackle Hobbit
description: LOS ANGELES  Goblins, trolls and dragons were a breeze compared with the caustic clash of egos that kept The Hobbit in Hollywood limbo for years. But a settlement announced on Tuesday between Peter Jackson and New Line Cinema holds the promise that peace will break out in Middle Earth and that fans could see the first of two resulting movies by December 2010.

title: Laugh at the Web Clips, Then Buy the Gel
description: ADVERTISING about advertising has long been a popular ploy on Madison Avenue. So, too, has the idea of ads that parody other ads. Now, with the increasing interest among marketers in embedding brands in entertainment programming, a viral campaign is arriving that spoofs the concept  while at the same time, of course, playing up the product.

title: Its Edwards the Fighter in the Iowa Homestretch
description: OTTUMWA, Iowa  More than 150 Iowans were rustling in their chairs at a community college here the other night, waiting for John Edwards. Mr. Edwardss bus was parked and running outside the door, but it was nearly 45 minutes before he finally made his characteristically late entrance.

title: What You Get for ... $4 Million
description: Miami

title: Cereal as a Metaphor for Capitalism
description: A business course on cutthroat capitalism disguised as a slacker comedy: Thats the kindest way to describe Michael Lehmanns Flakes, a movie that shares the smug, hipper-than-thou sensibility of its sour protagonist, Neal Downs (Aaron Stanford).

title: A Crisis Long Foretold
description: A truism of crisis management is that most seemingly out-of-the-blue disasters could have been prevented if someone had paid attention.

title: Goldmans Record Year Ends With Modest Gain
description: Goldman Sachs did it again. Now the question is whether the Wall Street bank can do it again and again.

title: Union Leader Is Accused of Extortion
description: The former president of a New York area Teamsters local was arrested on Tuesday on charges that he forced his union members to do work for him personally, including building a new roof on his country home, squiring his daughter to her yoga class and setting up a Christmas tree at his Manhattan apartment.

title: Mixing a Rare Verdi With a Difficult Babbitt
description: I dont know whether the quartet is beautiful or ugly, Verdi said after the premiere of his String Quartet in E minor in 1873. He wrote the piece to pass the time when a production of Aida was postponed after the lead soprano fell ill, and he continued to worry about its worth for several years.

title: From That Trip to the Forest, Heres the Cake
description: Posters for the Metropolitan Operas new production of Hansel and Gretel show the children in the witchs house as Hansel gorges on a hunk of chocolate cake. When the opera opens on Monday, and for all of its nine performances through the end of January, Alice Coote, who portrays Hansel, will be indulging in a seriously delectable treat.

title: Trial in Slaying of L.I. Man Turns on Reaction to Threat
description: RIVERHEAD, N.Y.  I did what I had to do; you might as well put the cuffs on me now.

title: Opening of Memorial for Sept. 11 Is Postponed
description: For years, under Gov. George E. Pataki, state officials told the public that the World Trade Center memorial would open Sept. 11, 2009, the eighth anniversary of the attack.

title: Executions in U.S. Decline to 13-Year Low, Study Finds
description: The number of executions in the United States has declined to a 13-year low, according to a study by a research group that has been critical of the way the death penalty is applied.

title: E.P.A. Denies California Emissions Waiver
description: DETROIT  The Bush administration said Wednesday night that it would deny California's bid to set stricter vehicle emissions standards than federal law required as part of the state's efforts to fight climate change.

title: A Fruitcake Soaked in Tropical Sun
description: WHEN a man in a hairnet beckons, who can resist?

title: Alarming Alliance of Mafia and Street Gang Is Broken Up
description: WEST ORANGE, N.J.  State authorities on Tuesday broke up what Attorney General Anne Milgram said was an alarming alliance between the Luchese crime family and the Bloods street gang to supply drugs and cellphones to gang members inside a New Jersey prison.

title: Bush Lawyers Discussed Fate of Tapes
description: WASHINGTON  At least four top White House lawyers took part in discussions with the Central Intelligence Agency between 2003 and 2005 about whether to destroy videotapes showing the secret interrogations of two operatives from Al Qaeda, according to current and former administration and intelligence officials.

title: Sprint Nextel Hires a Chief From Its Spinoff
description: The Sprint Nextel Corporation, the cellphone company that lost more than a million customers in the last five quarters, named Daniel R. Hesse as chief executive on Tuesday, succeeding Gary D. Forsee, who was ousted two months ago.

title: F.C.C. Reshapes Rules Limiting Media Industry
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Communications Commission approved two new rules on Tuesday that are likely to reshape the nations media landscape by setting new parameters for the size and scope of the largest news and cable companies.

title: Comfort in Layers of Chocolate
description: MY parents love to tell the story of me and the bowl of schlag (whipped cream) at Demel coffeehouse in Vienna. I was a toddler, the tale goes, held in my mothers arms in front of the pastry counter, when I pitched myself forward, diving into a bowl of said schlag. I made it up to my wrists before being caught, but after licking the white fluff from my fingers, I apparently spent the rest of the day ecstatic.

title: This Time, Sarkozy Embraces Attention to His Private Life
description: PARIS  President Nicolas Sarkozy told journalists he did not mind media reports about his love life, one day after reports of his romance with a former supermodel, Carla Bruni, surfaced in the French press.

title: Beneath the Roar of Times Square, an Old, Familiar Rhythm Returns
description: All of a sudden, on his way to Brooklyn one recent evening, Victor Miranda decided to change trains at 42nd Street, instead of 14th.

title: Fehr and Selig to Begin Talks on Mitchell Report
description: Donald Fehr, the head of the baseball players union, and Commissioner Bud Selig have agreed to discuss recommendations from the Mitchell report, a move that could lead to a third reopening of the collective bargaining agreement since 2005 in an ongoing bid to crack down on the use of performance-enhancing drugs.

title: Senate Adds $70 Billion for Wars in Spending Bill
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate voted Tuesday night to approve a sweeping year-end budget package after adding $70 billion for the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan over the objections of Democrats who have been stymied all year in their efforts to change the course of the conflict in Iraq.

title: For Now, U.S. Wont Cap Flights Per Hour at J.F.K.
description: WASHINGTON  The United States transportation secretary will announce on Wednesday that her department has negotiated an agreement with the airlines to ease congestion at Kennedy International Airport next summer by shifting some flights to less busy times, according to government officials and industry executives.

title: The Vaticans Relative Truth
description: POPE BENEDICT XVI has offered a couple of recent previews of whats likely to be his core message to the United Nations next April, the projected highlight of his first visit to the United States. Last Tuesday, the pontiff released the text of his annual statement for the Vaticans World Day of Peace, raising typical papal concerns like poverty and disarmament, but also a defense of the family based on heterosexual marriage and, in the section reflecting Benedicts budding environmentalism, a reminder of human supremacy over the animal kingdom.

title: WORLD BRIEFING | EUROPE; Ukraine: Ex-Premier Makes Comeback
description: Yulia Tymoshenko, who helped lead the street protests that overturned a rigged presidential election three years ago, was narrowly approved by Parliament to be prime minister. She held the same post in 2005 before a falling-out with President Viktor A. Yushchenko, with whom she has reconciled.

title: Rice Visits Iraq Amid Strain With Turkey
description: BAGHDAD  Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice made an unannounced visit to Iraq on Tuesday, visiting the oil-rich city of Kirkuk and then Baghdad, as tensions mounted along the countrys mountainous border with Turkey.

title: When a Universe Reels, a Baryshnikov May Fall
description: Mikhail Baryshnikov, who defied gravity as a ballet dancer, is gravitys slave in Beckett Shorts, which opened on Tuesday night at the New York Theater Workshop. Mr. Baryshnikov enters falling in the opening segment of this 70-minute compilation of four brief plays by Samuel Beckett. And for the rest of the show you can feel good old physics tugging at feet that once took flight like no one elses.

title: A Producer of Movies to Try Hand at Games
description: The Hollywood producer Jerry Bruckheimer, whose movies and television shows are so replete with car chases and fast action that critics say they look like video games, is finally lending his expertise to that medium.

title: What Was That All About?
description: Bali, Indonesia

title: Osorio Leaves Fire to Coach Red Bulls
description: Juan Carlos Osorio said he had landed his dream job. The New York Red Bulls said they had landed their dream coach. As many others have found, the mystical force that seems to surround the MetroStars/Red Bulls has often turned those dreams into night terrors.

title: Thomas Sticks With Knicks Team He Criticized
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Isiah Thomas the point guard was a fierce competitor who drove his teams to titles and glory. Isiah Thomas the team executive is a manic day trader who pounces on every chance to stockpile talent. Isiah Thomas the coach is a frustrated, tortured soul who cannot find players as intense as he was, and is now openly wondering why.

title: Recipe: Royal Fans
description: 2 cups sifted cake flour

title: In Reversal, Fed Approves Plan to Curb Risky Lending
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve, acknowledging that home mortgage lenders aggressively sold deceptive loans to borrowers who had little chance of repaying them, proposed a broad set of restrictions Tuesday on exotic mortgages and high-cost loans for people with weak credit.

title: Too Costly for Even the Well-to-Do
description: Harvards new financial aid policy is the boldest move yet to mitigate the soaring costs of a college education. Most previous efforts to make higher education affordable have focused, as they should, on helping low-income students. Now Harvard will also provide generous aid to students whose annual family incomes reach as high as $180,000. It is a welcome move, but also a disturbing admission that the priciest colleges are now beyond the reach of even many upper-middle-class families.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the Houses passage of a budget bill misstated the amount approved for two programs. The legislation provides $602 million, not billion, for agricultural drought relief; and $195 million, not billion, for repair of the collapsed highway bridge in Minneapolis.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the Houses passage of a budget bill misstated the amount approved for two programs. The legislation provides $602 million, not billion, for agricultural drought relief; and $195 million, not billion, for repair of the collapsed highway bridge in Minneapolis. (Go to Article)

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Science Times on Dec. 11 about the effort to develop a malaria vaccine using live mosquito parasites misstated the timing of research into the mosquito genome. It was decoded in 2002, along with that of the parasite that causes malaria  not in the 80s.

title: Cinephiles, Pack Your Bags. An Uncut Version Awaits.
description: SHANGHAI  For weeks now, the ranks of Chinese visitors to Hong Kong have swelled with a brand-new category of tourists: moviegoers.

title: Laura Huxley, Her Husbands Biographer, Dies at 96
description: Laura Archera Huxley, a writer who was best known for her memoir of her years with her husband, the novelist Aldous Huxley, died on Thursday at her home in Los Angeles. She was 96.

title: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
The Gifts of Bachs Melodic Generosity
description: For more than a decade the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center has greeted each holiday season with performances of Bachs six Brandenburg Concertos in a single sitting. It has become a staple, selling out year after year. When David Finckel and Wu Han, the societys current artistic directors, inherited the tradition last year, they built a winter Baroque Festival around the Brandenburg concerts, a venture repeated this year.

title: Bush to Visit Middle East in January
description: WASHINGTON  The White House confirmed on Tuesday President Bushs plans to visit Israel and the West Bank next month, as well as other Middle East destinations, as he works to nudge peace talks forward.

title: Down Payment on Mideast Peace
description: The political and territorial challenges facing Israeli and Palestinian peace negotiators are formidable and familiar. The economic obstacles to the creation of a viable Palestinian state are also formidable, but easier to make a dent in  if all the donors who claim to care about the Palestinians and peace live up to their promises.

title: Meat to Wrap the Mind Around
description: IN September, when Sasha Wizansky and Amy Standen published the inaugural issue of Meatpaper, a slender magazine that is, according to the cover, Your Journal of Meat Culture, they werent entirely surprised that both omnivores and vegetarians responded enthusiastically.

title: Green Light for Institute on Creation in Texas
description: HOUSTON  A Texas higher education panel has recommended allowing a Bible-based group called the Institute for Creation Research to offer online masters degrees in science education.

title: House, 314-100, Passes Broad Energy Bill; Bush Plans to Sign It
description: WASHINGTON  Legislation that will slowly but significantly change the cars Americans drive, the fuel they burn, the way they light their homes and the price they pay for food cleared the House on Tuesday by a large margin. President Bush said he would sign it on Wednesday.

title: At End of Her Mothers Life, Finding Unconditional Love
description: The beatings started when her father left.

title: 101 Simple Appetizers in 20 Minutes or Less
description: YOU want good food at a holiday cocktail party and you want to impress people? You dont want a caterer, you refuse to heat up frozen food, and you want to show that your expertise extends beyond buying perfectly ripe hunks of cheese and juicy olives? Then think about doing some cooking.

title: Detroit Revival Vies With Industrys Decline
description: DETROIT  For decades, city leaders and local business executives here have been predicting an imminent revival of their desolate downtown. For all their cheerleading, though, nothing much changed.

title: WORLD BRIEFING | THE AMERICAS; Canada: New Mad Cow Case
description: Mad cow disease has been confirmed in a 13-year-old beef cow from Alberta, the Canadian Food Inspection Agency said. No part of the cow entered the human or animal food or feed chain, it said. The cow was born after restrictions on feed were put in place. It is the 11th case of the disease since 2003.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,884 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:

title: After Delay, Clinton Embarks on a Likability Tour
description: DES MOINES  The tableau was classic Clinton: Bill Clinton chatting with African-American cashiers and baggers at a grocery store here Tuesday, telling them how wonderful Hillary Rodham Clinton was, while she waited quietly for him to finish so they could dazzle more voters.

title: A Pushcart Vendor Defies a City, With Persistence and Hot Dogs
description: Out in front of the crowded entrance to the Metropolitan Museum of Art is one of the more lucrative spots in Manhattan to sell hot dogs. It is so good, in fact, that one of the largest pushcart vending companies in New York City pays $574,000 a year to the city for the right to place two hot dog carts there.

title: In the Kitchen of Long Ago, With Grandma
description: THE daughter of an interfaith marriage, I chose Judaism, but Christmas cookies chose me.

title: This Magna Carta to Remain in U.S.
description: The man who just paid $21.3 million for a 710-year-old copy of the Magna Carta, the English document that helped establish the rights of man and lay the framework for the Constitution, says he wants to keep the copy on display in the United States.

title: Bad Bill Now, Bad Bill Later
description: While trying to do the wrong thing  shove a bad bill on electronic spying through the Senate  Majority Leader Harry Reid ended up doing the country a favor. He put off the vote until January. It was the right move, but senators who care about national security and the Constitution will have to be careful not to be stampeded into supporting what will still be a bad bill next year.

title: Concerns Grow Over Work of Official in California
description: LOS ANGELES  Chriss W. Street was called a hero in 1994, when he sounded the alarm on high-risk investments in the Orange County portfolio and predicted the countys $1.7 billion bankruptcy filing.

title: Manhattan Market Dips, but Parts Remain Rarefied
description: Once part of the sprawling Nabisco cookie complex, the eight-story red-brick building at 450 West 15th Street, just east of 10th Avenue in the meatpacking district of Manhattan, is the epitome of understated warehouse chic, with polished concrete floors and century-old brick walls and frosted windows.

title: Magna Carta Copy Sold
description: A 710-year-old copy of the declaration of human rights known as the Magna Carta  the version that became part of English law  was auctioned Tuesday for $21.3 million, a Sothebys spokeswoman said.

title: Tribune Chief to Step Down After Sale
description: Dennis J. FitzSimons will step down as chairman and chief executive of Tribune Company as soon as an $8.2 billion takeover deal is completed, the company announced Wednesday.

title: 205 Schools Accept Plan for Bonus Pay
description: New York City officials released the names of 205 public schools where teachers have chosen to take part in a new bonus program based largely on improving test scores.

title: Nets Force a Long Shot That Costs Them the Game
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  When everything is going right for the Nets, they seal every route to the basket and force opponents to shoot from outside. Long shots can carom hard off the rim, and the Nets can collect the ball and speed the other way.

title: In France, Swapping a Pied--Terre for a Chteau
description: LIMSY, France

title: Romney Refocuses on His Business Experience
description: GOFFSTOWN, N.H.  Mitt Romney was recounting to his audience here a political fable of sorts, about how he never expected to get into politics after spending his life in business. The moral is one he has been telling again and again in his final sprint before the first votes are cast.

title: Holiday Cheer (and Calories)
description: Dinella Ascenso teaches her students at the High School of Food and Finance in Manhattan how to make holiday-season biscotti. At the Anderson School, also in Manhattan, first graders were asked to bring in foods that their families serve during the holidays. The results included challah and gingerbread cookies. Jordyn Peques and Naqueilla Paul were among the children who sampled the treats.

title: Juiced Ghostwriter: I Told You So
description: Whatever else its eventual impact, the Mitchell report last week immediately recasts the importance of the small library of books documenting  and in some cases, shaping  baseballs steroid era.

title: Bush Lawyers Discussed Fate of C.I.A.Tapes
description: WASHINGTON  At least four top White House lawyers took part in discussions with the Central Intelligence Agency between 2003 and 2005 about whether to destroy videotapes showing the secret interrogations of two operatives from Al Qaeda, according to current and former administration and intelligence officials.

title: Child Health Plan to Be Expanded
description: TRENTON (AP)  Under an agreement to be unveiled on Wednesday, New Jersey will offer low-cost health coverage for the children of families who lack insurance but who earn too much for government help.

title: Douglas Kneeland, Former Reporter for The New York Times, Dies at 78
description: Douglas E. Kneeland, a former reporter for The New York Times who covered some of the major stories of the 1960s and 70s and later became a high-level editor at The Chicago Tribune, died on Saturday in Lincoln, Me., the town in which he was born and to which he returned in retirement. He was 78.

title: Recipe: Black Forest Cake
description: Adapted from Johnny Iuzzini, Jean Georges

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about the laws of physics and nature misstated the time in which Plato was forming his idea of a higher realm of ideal forms. It was in the fourth century B.C.; it was not a few hundred years after the fifth century B.C., when the Greek mathematician and philosopher Pythagoras and his followers proclaimed that nature was numbers.

title: Newborn Pulled From Trash in Stable Condition Next Day
description: A newborn girl who was found crying in a commercial trash bin in Queens on Monday night was in stable condition Tuesday in the intensive care unit at Elmhurst Hospital Center, where the staff has unofficially named her Christina because she was found around Christmas, a doctor said.

title: E.C.B. Makes $500 Billion Infusion
description: FRANKFURT  The European Central Bank on Tuesday pumped 348 billion euros ($500 billion) into the financial system, easing conditions in credit markets grappling with a global lending squeeze linked to the United States housing downturn and traditional year-end demands for cash.

title: How a Middle School Can Be Dangerous and Still Get an A
description: When Shawn Carson taught last year at a middle school named the South Bronx Academy for Applied Media, he entered his room on many days to find a message from his students on the blackboard. In graphic and vulgar language, as he recalled in a recent interview, it described him committing a homosexual act.

title: Some Dirty Little Detours on the Road to Shangri-La
description: Somewhere out there, right now, everyones dream vacation awaits. It is a collective dream, created by travel journalists who describe, in a cascade of clichs and superlatives, a world of white-sand beaches, quaint villages and smiling locals eager to share their secret knowledge. It is a world in which all places, regardless of location, history or culture, embody a bewitching blend of the ancient and modern.

title: Morgan Stanley to Sell Stake to China Amid Loss
description: Morgan Stanley posted its first quarterly loss ever on Wednesday after taking an additional $5.7 billion write-down related to subprime mortgages. The investment bank said it would sell a $5 billion stake to the China Investment Corporation, that countrys sovereign wealth fund, to shore up its capital.

title: Pentagon Says Services in Iraq Are Stagnant
description: WASHINGTON  Despite a significant reduction in violence in Iraq over the past three months, the Iraqi government has made little headway in improving the delivery of electricity, health care and other essential services, a new Pentagon report said Tuesday.

title: F.S.U. to Bar as Many as 25 Players From Bowl
description: There had been hope in the Florida Panhandle the last few years that Bobby Bowden would rally Florida State to its former prominence before he retired.

title: Colorado Decertifies Machines for Voting
description: DENVER  Thousands of Colorados electronic voting machines do not work properly and have been decertified, according to a review by the Colorado secretary of state that has left elections officials scrambling to find viable machines in time for local and Congressional primary elections in August and the presidential election in November.

title: United Nations: Assembly Calls for Freeze on Death Penalty
description: In a vote that made for unusual alliances, the General Assembly passed, 104 to 54 with 29 abstentions, a nonbinding resolution calling for a moratorium on the death penalty. Among the countries joining the United States in opposition to the European-led measure were Iran, Myanmar, North Korea, Sudan and Zimbabwe. Opponents argued that the resolution undermined their national sovereignty. Two similar moves in the 1990s failed, and Secretary General Ban Ki-moon said the new vote was evidence of a trend toward ultimately abolishing the death penalty.

title: Machismo, Down to the Studs
description: ON todays voluble, provenance-obsessed menus, its not uncommon to be told what breed of cattle your beef comes from or where it was raised.

title: Illinois Town Chosen as Site for New Type of Coal Plant
description: WASHINGTON  An industry consortium planning a coal plant that will capture its carbon dioxide and pump it underground selected a site near Mattoon, Ill., on Tuesday for the $1.5 billion project. A second site in Illinois and two in Texas had been considered..

title: Baseball Union Agrees to Discuss Report
description: The baseball players union has agreed to discuss the findings in the report from former Senator George J. Mitchell on performance-enhancing drugs in baseball, the union and the commissioners office said Tuesday afternoon.

title: New Business Helps Oracle to a Strong Quarter
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Second-quarter revenue at the Oracle Corporation, the business software company, soundly surpassed Wall Streets projections on Wednesday as the company reported a sharp rise in new software licenses.

title: Joseph Henderson, an Early Jung Disciple, Dies at 104
description: Dr. Joseph L. Henderson, a psychoanalyst and author who was an early practitioner of methods developed by Carl Jung to explore cultural influences on the unconscious mind, died on Nov. 17 in Greenbrae, Calif., outside San Francisco. He was 104.

title: Verdis Swedish Monarch Is Returned to His Native Land
description: Political relevance, mothers milk for opera in the 21st century, was poison for Italian composers like Verdi. Un Ballo in Maschera broadly re-enacts the assassination of the Swedish king Gustav III in 1792. Neapolitan censors in the 1850s, edgy on the subject of regicide, said no to it and also to an alternative setting by Verdis librettist Antonio Somma, one that would have had Renato, Riccardo and Ulrica cavorting improbably in the drawing rooms of Boston and enlisting conspirators from colonial legislatures.

title: Credit Is Passed Around in Complete Rangers Victory
description: After they had seemingly dug themselves out of a midseason funk with a victory over Pittsburgh that was impressive on many fronts Tuesday night at Madison Square Garden, the Rangers passed credit around their locker room as if it were a puck in a power-play drill.

description: One of my male colleagues was explaining why men age better than women.

description: Its an arms race out there in opera land.

title: Kyrgyz Vote Law Voided
description: BISHKEK, Kyrgyzstan  The Supreme Court struck down a contentious election law on Tuesday that had appeared to guarantee all seats in Parliament to the Ak Zhol Party of President Kurmanbek Bakiyev.

title: Hands Across Iowa for Thompson
description: Fred D. Thompsons hands down moment in the Des Moines Register Republican debate last week is still resonating throughout his campaign, and keeps popping up on his bus tour this week.

title: Name a Patriot, and Hes Probably Scored
description: Andrew Das, Benjamin Hoffman, Naila-Jean Meyers, John Woods and Toni Monkovic contributed to this notebook.

title: Wednesdays Links: Playoff Picture Almost Ready for Framing
description: Tis the season  when your boss at the newspaper tells you not to use cliches like that. And when the last remaining pieces of the N.F.L.s playoff tournament are falling into place. For one thing, the Patriots have wrapped up home-field advantage, but is that really going to help them? The N.F.C.s division titles are locked up, but four teams (Giants, Vikings, Redskins and Saints) remain in the running for the two wild-card spots. The Vikings (8-6) are the team with the hot hand. They have won five in a row (and have the tie breaker over the 9-5 Giants, if it should come to that.) There is less suspense in the A.F.C., where four teams (Steelers, Jaguars, Browns and Titans) are vying for three spots. Incredibly, the Chargers (9-5), who started the season 1-4, have already clinched a spot and its the Steelers (9-5) who might have to win out to make the playoffs.

title: For the Moment | Party politics in L.A.
description: Franklin Getchell

title: Bangkok Christmas gift ideas, part one
description: Last-minute Christmas shoppers in Bangkok can pick up beautiful silk scarves, home-made jewelry, mulberry-paper greeting cards, cutlery, artisanal soaps, lotions, locally grown tea and coffee, pottery, and lots more handicrafts at the Ambassador Hotel (Sukhumvit Soi 11) on Saturday, Dec 22. The craft fair, which runs from 10am to 2pm, works on the fair-trade concept, only selling things made by Thai artisans; 70 percent of sales revenue goes directly to the people who made the handicrafts.

title: Bangkok Christmas gift ideas, part two
description: A half-dozen vineyards have started up in Thailand in recent years, part of the global trend to make wine at non-traditional latitudes. Most of the Thai wine, to be honest, is plonk. But one exception is Chateau de Loei, located on a plateau near the border with Laos. Their best wines are not bargains  upwards of $20  but theyre very drinkable.

title: Harmony Gold Sells $252 Milion in Assets
description: Harmony Gold Mining, Africas third-largest gold producer, agreed to form a venture and sell a stake in assets including its Cooke uranium ore dump in South Africa to Pamodzi Resources Fund for $252 million.

title: Level 3 Sells Ad Unit to DG FastChannel
description: Level 3 Communications on Wednesday said it will sell the advertising distribution business of Vyvx to DG FastChannel. Vyvx is a wholly owned subsidiary of Level 3. Under the terms of the deal, Level 3 will receive $129 million payable in cash.

title: Deutsche Bank Settles Enron Claims
description: Deutsche Bank has agreed to pay creditors of Enron, the energy trading company, $25 million to settle a lawsuit related to transactions between the companies, Enron said on Tuesday.

description: Federal prosecutors charged the former outside counsel for the bankrupt commodities brokerage firm Refco on Tuesday with fraud tied to the eventual collapse of the commodities and futures brokerage.

description: Accel-KKR said Tuesday that it boosted its stake in iTradeNetwork, a vendor of software for food suppliers, by buying out founding shareholders in a deal of undisclosed size.

description: The European Central Bank on Tuesday pumped 348 billion euros ($500 billion) into the financial system, easing conditions in credit markets grappling with a global lending squeeze linked to the United States housing downturn and traditional year-end demands for cash.

title: F.C.C. Reshapes Rules Limiting Media Industry
description: The Federal Communications Commission approved two new rules on Tuesday that are likely to reshape the nations media landscape by setting new parameters for the size and scope of the largest news and cable companies.

description: Microsoft co-founder Paul Allen has applied to bid in an upcoming U.S. auction of coveted wireless airwaves, according to auction documents released late Tuesday.

title: Applied Precision Cancels I.P.O., Sells Unit
description: Seventeen months after filing for an initial stock offering that it never completed, Applied Precision said it had dropped its I.P.O. plans and has sold its semiconductor test-instrumentation business to Rudolph Technologies.

title: Opponents Of Googles DoubleClick Deal Threaten Lawsuit
description: A coalition opposing Googles $3.1 billion merger with DoubleClick renewed charges of conflicts and threatened possible legal action over a decision by a regulatory chairman not to recuse herself from reviewing the merger.

title: Crunch Time for Tribune Buyout
description: Tribune executives were sweating out aggressive last-minute questioning Tuesday from bankers reluctant to fund the final portion of a debt-laden $8.2 billion deal to take the company private with Chicago billionaire Samuel Zell, The Chicago Tribune reported.

title: Milestone Postpones I.P.O.
description: Milestone AV Technologies postponed plans on Tuesday for an initial public offering because of unfavorable market conditions, an underwriter said.

title: Cardiac Dimensions Raises $35.5 Million
description: Cardiac Dimensions said Tuesday that it has raised $35.5 million in venture capital financing, money it will use for clinical trials for a device that repairs the mitral valve in patients suffering from congestive heart failure.

description: Internet broadcast start-up Ustream.TV said Tuesday that it completed a $2 million angel round and that former Democratic presidential candidate Wesley Clark joined its board.

title: Harbinger Takes Stake in Media General
description: Distressed and special situations hedge fund firm Harbinger Capital Partners has taken a stake in a struggling media company with a warning to management that it may clean shop.

title: Peltz Has Another Bone to Pick With Cadbury
description: Shares in Cadbury Schweppes rose on Tuesday as Nelson Peltz, the activist shareholder, urged a faster rate of change as he warned the British companys sweets and drinks units may become takeover targets.

title: The Year in Technology M&A
description: Microsoft, Oracle, I.B.M. and a host of private equity firms helped drive technology mergers and acquisitions to a fourth consecutive record year in 2007. The introduction to The 451 Groups Technology M&A Outlook report lists the years significant deals, identifies M&A drivers and looks at the outlook for 2008.

title: Eton Park Bulks Up Goodyear Stake
description: Hedge fund Eton Park Capital Management has raised its stake in Goodyear Tire & Rubber to 7.7 percent.

title: Cerberuss Feinberg Testifies in United Rentals Trial
description: Stephen Feinberg, the famously reclusive founder of hedge fund and private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management, faced a grilling Tuesday over his decision to pull out of the $7 billion takeover of United Rentals during the first day of trial in the court battle.

description: Officials from Merrill Lynch, Bear Stearns and other major banks are in talks to bail out a struggling bond insurance company that has guaranteed $26 billion in mortgage securities, according to The New York Times, because the insurers woes could force the banks to take on billions in losses they had insured against.

title: Cobham Buys BAE Surveillance Unit for $240 Million
description: British aerospace company Cobham said it had agreed to buy BAE Systemss Pennsylvania-based Surveillance and Attack business unit for $240 million.

title: Are Wall Street Analysts Worth Their Salt?

title: Credit Crunch Crimps Manhattan Office Deals
description: Once part of the sprawling Nabisco cookie complex, the eight-story red-brick building at 450 East 15th Street, just east of 10th Avenue in the meatpacking district of Manhattan, is the epitome of understated warehouse chic, with polished concrete floors and century-old brick walls and frosted windows.

title: NetSuite Boost Price Range Again
description: NetSuites hotly anticipated initial public offering just keeps getting hotter.

description: Goldman Sachs did it again. Now the question is whether the Wall Street bank can do it again and again.

title: Morgan Stanley Posts Loss, Sells Stake to China
description: Morgan Stanley posted a fourth-quarter loss, its first-ever quarterly loss, after taking an additional $5.7 billion write-down related to subprime mortgages. The investment bank said it would sell a $5 billion stake to the China Investment Corporation, that countrys sovereign wealth fund, to shore up its capital.

title: Silver Lake to Take Stake in Gerson Lehrman
description: Silver Lake Partners has agreed to acquire a quarter of the Gerson Lehrman Group, the upstart Wall Street research firm that has come under scrutiny from regulators, according to The New York Times.

title: Rubenstein Buys Copy of Magna Carta
description: David M. Rubenstein, chief of the private equity firm Carlyle Group, did some serious holiday shopping on Tuesday  but he wont be taking his purchase, a 710-year-old copy of the Magna Carta, home with him. Though Mr. Rubenstein won the auction for the document with a $19 million bid ($21.3 million with fees and commissions), he told reporters he was just a temporary custodian of the historic piece of parchment, which David Redden, Sothebys vice chairman, called the most important document in the world, the birth certificate of freedom.

title: A Spout and a River of Blood

title: The Early Word: Looking for Magic in Iowa
description: In these final stages of the campaigns in Iowa, some of the candidates have retooled their styles and their speeches on the stump. The Timess Adam Nagourney examines John Edwardss closing argument to Iowas caucusgoers, voters who know him well.

He ought to know because, it turns out, Mr. Hudson lives in Berlin. And the Bagger thought covering movies from Jersey was tough.

Salon does, and though Los Angeles is not reeling from a terrorist outrage, it is going to be a bit weird for the place to get its party on, given the pall hanging over the town, which seems to part only for verbal flamethrowing.

Wald reports. As a result, the department will not, at least for now, order a reduction in the number of flights per hour at Kennedy, and will not immediately issue rules to carry out a more controversial tactic  auctioning off landing slots  to reduce the number of flights to Kennedy.

The four companies operate about half of the approximately 20,500 rides provided each average weekday under the paratransit program, which runs door-to-door van service for eligible residents who cannot use regular public transit.

description: Thursdays paper has a story about Pantones choosing Blue Iris as its color for 2008. The reporting did yield a certain symmetry: Raf Simons dresses and pantsuits in Yves Klein blue for Jil Sanders fall 2007; a super cool and curvy sofa by Zaha Hadid in a similar hue, and those blossomy colors in the spring 2008 Balenciaga show. Of course that only proves that Pantone is on the curve, and not ahead of it, and I recognize the pure publicity value of naming a color from the 21st century palette. As if.

title: Viacom Dumps DoubleClick for Microsoft
description: Microsoft and Viacom today  announced a multiyear content and advertising partnership. Under the deal, Microsoft will become the exclusive seller of remnant display ads on Viacoms Web sites. (Remnant refers to ad space that Viacom cannot sell through its own sales force.) In addition, Microsoft will use technology from aQuantive, which it recently bought, to serve ads on Viacoms Web sites; it will buy ads on Viacoms online and broadcast networks; and it will license Viacom content, on a nonexclusive basis, for use on outlets like MSN and the Xbox 360.

title: Google: Theres Nobody in Our Black Box. Yet.
description: My post Tuesday about the role of humans in Googles search results misinterpreted a comment by Peter Norvig, Googles head of research. In an interview with Technology Review, Mr. Norvig talked about how the search engine has a vast network of part-time employees evaluating how good its results are. As I read the interview, I incorrectly thought he was saying that human ratings were fed into Googles algorithms and used, alongside PageRank and other quantitative measures of pages, to determine the order in which sites are listed in response to a given query.
