title: In New Jersey, a Health Plan to Cover Uninsured Children
description: WOODBRIDGE, N.J.  Moving New Jersey closer to universal health care coverage, Gov. Jon S. Corzine said on Wednesday that the state had reached an agreement with Horizon Blue Cross Blue Shield allowing working- and middle-class families to obtain health insurance for children at drastically reduced rates.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on June 30, 2000, about Tobin Rote, a championship quarterback for the Detroit Lions in the 1950s, misstated his full name, referred incorrectly to a relative in the list of survivors and omitted the names of two others. He was Tobin Cornelius Rote Sr.  not Jr.

title: Jamie Lynn Spearsis Pregnant at 16
description: Jamie Lynn Spears, right, the 16-year-old star of the popular Nickelodeon series Zoey 101 and the sister of the troubled singer Britney Spears, 26, said she was 12 weeks pregnant by her boyfriend, Casey Aldridge, The Associated Press reported. It was a shock for both of us, so unexpected, Jamie Lynn told OK! magazine. I was in complete shock, and so was he. Her mother, Lynne Spears, said: I didnt believe it because Jamie Lynns always been so conscientious. Shes never late for curfew. I was in shock. I mean, this is my 16-year-old baby. Jamie Lynn said she planned to rear the baby in her home state, Louisiana, so it can have a normal family life. In a statement, Nickelodeon said: We respect Jamie Lynns decision to take responsibility in this sensitive and personal situation. The third season of Zoey 101 ends on Jan. 4. Filming of the fourth season, beginning in February, has been completed.

title: Officers Charged in Cocaine Disappearance
description: Two city police officers were arraigned Wednesday on charges of misconduct and falsifying records in connection with the disappearance of 11 bags of cocaine.

title: An Encore for Gypsy
description: Well, they had the hopes and the rhythm and the girl to go with em, but they needed the time and place. And, after much considering and calculating, theyve got those, too. A revival of Gypsy, based on the production that was part of the summers City Center Encores! series and starred Patti LuPone, Boyd Gaines and Laura Benanti, is to begin previews on March 3 at the St. James Theater on Broadway. The opening is March 27. The three headliners are coming with the show, and further casting is to be announced.

title: France Convicts 5 Former Guantnamo Inmates
description: PARIS (AP)  A court convicted five former inmates of the American detention center at Guantnamo Bay on Wednesday on terrorism-related charges, but did not send any of them back to prison in France. A sixth man was acquitted.

title: Charter Schools Outshine Others as They Receive Their First Report Cards
description: Education officials, acting under the citys new system of accountability, released report cards on Wednesday for several charter schools, with the majority receiving As and Bs, but one school in Queens getting an F.

title: Columbias Historic Atom Smasher Is Now Destined for the Junk Heap
description: Columbia University has decided to junk a 70-year-old atom smasher that is the nations oldest artifact of the nuclear era, ending weeks of internal debate and lobbying over its fate.

title: Simplify the Controllers, and Everyones a Video Gamer
description: Pass a traditional video game controller to someone older than 50, and you are likely to get a look of bewilderment. Thats one reason Nintendos Wii controller  modeled after the familiar TV remote  has mass appeal, even in places like retirement homes. As the battle for the living-room screen escalates, there are signs that Sony and Microsoft are seeing the importance of simplified controls as well.

title: Bond Insurer Cut to Junk; Negative Outlook for 4 More
description: Citing deepening problems in the mortgage market, Standard & Poors cut the rating of one troubled bond insurer on Wednesday and assigned a negative outlook to four other companies that guarantee debts linked to home loans.

title: Art Show Imperiled
description: A major exhibition of art from Russia, scheduled to be shown next month at the Royal Academy of Arts in London, may not go on after Russian authorities again expressed fears that the paintings could be seized to satisfy private legal claims while in Britain, The Associated Press reported. The British cultural agency said it had assured Russia that the works to be displayed in From Russia: French and Russian Master Paintings 1870-1925 were protected under British law and would not be seized. But Zinaida Bonami, deputy director of the Pushkin Fine Arts Museum in Moscow, said the Russian federal cultural agency notified the Pushkin, the State Hermitage Museum, the Russian Museum and the Tretyakov Gallery on Tuesday that it would not issue an export license for the art, including works by Matisse and van Gogh. No specific British claims against the paintings were mentioned. Some of the paintings have rarely been seen outside Russia. A Russian cultural official said that a final decision on lending the paintings would be made on Thursday.

title: $9.4 Billion Write-Down at Morgan Stanley
description: Morgan Stanley reported the first quarterly loss in its 72-year history Wednesday, heightening fears that the financial toll would keep mounting from the fast-spreading crisis in the subprime mortgage market.

title: Already Got the iPhone? How About Making It Hands-Free?
description: What could you give to someone who already has an iPhone? One possibility is the Vibe Duo headset from V-Moda. Its one of the first iPhone accessories that works both as a hands-free device for the phone and as a two-speaker headset for audio.

title: Pete Roses Lesson for Roger Clemens
description: If, as it seems, Roger Clemens is following a script, expect him to write a book in 2022. Following the lead of a venerable leader, Pete Rose, Clemens will admit in the book that he used steroids when he played baseball, just as Brian McNamee told George J. Mitchell that Clemens did.

title: New Subway Math May Bring Windfall of Spare Change to Transit System
description: Beginning in March, many subway and bus riders will have to learn a new math  and it could leave them scratching their heads. Or gnashing their teeth.

title: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
description: Previously recorded: $3,163,562

title: Foundation Hopes to Lure Top Students to Teaching
description: Taking the prestigious Rhodes Scholarships as a model, the Woodrow Wilson National Fellowship Foundation in Princeton is creating a fellowship program that it hopes will lure top students into teaching and transform teacher education in the United States.

title: Lottery Numbers
Todays HDTV, or Next Years?
description: BUYERS of consumer electronics are haunted by one question: Should I buy now or wait for new features, better performance and lower prices?

title: Mighty Canadians and a Book About Them
description: Two bridge books have received more press than any others this year. This is especially surprising for one of them, The Backwash Squeeze & Other Improbable Feats by Edward McPherson (HarperCollins), because it contains no deals. It is the story of the authors quest to learn our game.

title: Congress Averts Higher Tax Bill for Middle Class
description: WASHINGTON  Congress on Wednesday gave final approval to a plan that will spare millions of middle-class taxpayers higher tax bills for 2007. The White House welcomed the development and said President Bush would sign the bill.

title: The Feds Empty Gun
description: To the Editor:

title: Obamas Vote in Illinois Was Often Just Present
description: In 1999, Barack Obama was faced with a difficult vote in the Illinois legislature  to support a bill that would let some juveniles be tried as adults, a position that risked drawing fire from African-Americans, or to oppose it, possibly undermining his image as a tough-on-crime moderate.

title: A Holiday Political Quiz
description: Five days to Christmas and two weeks to Iowa.

title: Central Asia on Front Line in Energy Battle
description: BUKHARA, Uzbekistan  In the scrub brush desert south of this ancient Silk Road town, the natural gas wellheads are built on modest concrete platforms about the size of basketball courts. Because the gas is naturally pressurized, pumps are not needed to bring it to the surface. Pipes simply kiss the ground and gas pours through them.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A front-page article last Thursday about a major confrontation between the Congolese Army and a renegade general that is increasing the risk of war in Congo and threatening to undermine the fledgling democratic state misidentified the countrys first democratically chosen government. It was the one that took power at independence in 1960; it is not the current government, in office for a year.

title: Grobans Christmas Grows Merrier
description: Breaking Elvis Presleys record for the most consecutive weeks at No. 1 for a Christmas album, Josh Groban, above right, saw his Nol (Reprise) hold the top spot on the Billboard chart for the fourth week in a row. With 669,000 sales for the week that ended on Sunday, Nol, helped by Mr. Grobans performance last month on The Oprah Winfrey Show, also inched past the High School Musical 2 soundtrack (Disney) to become the best-selling album of the year so far, with a total of 2.77 million copies sold, Nielsen SoundScan reported. (High School Musical 2, which sold 178,000 copies last week to reach No. 6, is right behind with 2.7 million, and two sales weeks remain for 2007.) With almost no new releases in stores, the rest of the Top 10 is little changed from last week. Alicia Keys holds at No. 2, the Eagles at No. 3 and Now Thats What I Call Music! Vol. 26 at No. 4. Mannheim Steamrollers Christmas Song (American Gramaphone) rose six spots to No. 5, Miley Cyrus is No. 7; Taylor Swift, No. 8; Carrie Underwood, No. 9; and Garth Brooks, No. 10.

title: President Approves Realignment of the Army
description: WASHINGTON  President Bush has approved what officials are describing as the most significant realignment of the Army since World War II, signing off on a plan that will keep more troops than previously envisioned in Europe and add large numbers of soldiers to bases in Colorado, Georgia and Texas, Army officials said Wednesday.

title: Mukasey Signals Hell Be a Strong Bush Advocate
description: WASHINGTON  Attorney General Michael B. Mukasey has signaled in his first weeks on the job that he intends to be a forceful advocate for some of President Bushs most controversial antiterrorism policies, even if that means angering Congressional leaders who hoped that he would instead focus on repairing the strained relationship between the Justice Department and Capitol Hill.

title: As Voting Nears, Romney Shifts Political Narrative
description: GOFFSTOWN, N.H.  Mitt Romney was recounting to his audience here a political fable of sorts, about how he had never expected to get into politics after spending his life in business. The moral is one he has been telling again and again in his final sprint before the first votes of the 2008 presidential campaign are cast.

title: Statistics on Children in Newark: Grim, With a Ray of Hope
description: NEWARK  The numbers bear out the conventional wisdom that growing up in New Jerseys largest city can be rough. Each week, the authorities remove an average of 33 children from their homes because of abuse and neglect. Every month, about 150 teenagers are infected with a sexually transmitted disease. One-third of all children here live in poverty.

title: G.M. Said to Be Selling a Truck Unit
description: DETROIT  Navistar International, an Illinois-based maker of trucks and diesel engines, is expected to announce Thursday that it is buying General Motors medium-duty truck business, according to people with direct knowledge of the discussions.

title: The Green House as Classroom
description: WHEN the actors Alysia Reiner and David Alan Basche embarked on a renovation of their four-story, 5,000-square-foot row house in Harlem two years ago, they did not intend for it to become a show house. But a chance meeting with Michela OConnor Abrams, the president and publisher of Dwell Magazine, led to a Web chronicle of the job on dwell.com, and turned the renovation into a marketing vehicle for manufacturers of environmentally conscious products and a chance for the couple to evangelize on green building.

title: Britain Detains 3 Men Freed by U.S.
description: LONDON  Three former British residents who were held for more than four years in the Guantnamo Bay detention center arrived Wednesday at Luton, outside London, aboard a jet chartered by the government and were turned over to the police.

title: Chinese Anti-Corruption Site Crashes
description: SHANGHAI  A Web site created by Chinas anti-corruption bureau crashed after it began operating on Tuesday, overwhelmed by traffic from people wishing to file complaints, according to the Beijing Youth Daily newspaper.

title: Bush Deflects Questions on C.I.A. Tapes
description: WASHINGTON  President Bush deflected questions on Thursday about the destruction of C.I.A. interrogation tapes, saying that he will withhold comment until investigations into the affair are complete.

title: Lost and Found in London
description: To the Editor:

title: Denmark: Christmas-Tree Growers Face Cartel Charges
description: The state prosecutor for serious economic crimes charged the Danish Christmas Tree Growers Association with price fixing. The association has been charged with instructing its members over a four-year period what prices they should charge for their Christmas trees, he said. Denmark exports about 10 million trees a year. Prices for Nordmann firs, coveted for their soft, long-lasting needles, rose 25 percent this season.

title: A Cosmopolitan Cubist With a Wandering Eye
description: Charles G. Shaw (1892-1974) belongs to a generation of abstract painters who remain for the most part stubbornly lost. Active in the interwar period, they organized themselves into the American Abstract Artists when abstraction was viewed as un-American and then were largely swept aside by Abstract Expressionism.

title: Guilty Plea From Ex-HealthSouth Exec
description: A former HealthSouth executive, Malcolm E. McVay, pleaded guilty Wednesday to making illegally structured bank deposits 10 months after being resentenced to probation for his role in the companys $2.7 billion fraud.

title: China: Complainers Crash Anti-Graft Web Site
description: A Web site created by Chinas anti-corruption bureau crashed after it began operating on Tuesday, overwhelmed by traffic from people trying to file complaints, The Beijing Youth Daily reported. When the site, which is operated by the National Bureau of Corruption Prevention, reappeared online Wednesday, it contained more than 250 complaints, including several claims of official corruption.

title: Corrections
description: The subheading with a front-page headline on Wednesday for an article about discussions between four top White House lawyers and the Central Intelligence Agency over whether to destroy videotapes showing secret interrogations of members of Al Qaeda referred imprecisely to the White Houses position thus far on the matter. While Bush administration officials have acknowledged some discussions leading up to the destruction of the tapes in November 2005, as the article noted, the White House itself has not officially said anything on the subject, so its role was not wider than it said. (A related article appears today on Page A6.) (Go to Article)

title: Let Freedom Remain, Says Financier Who Bought Copy of Magna Carta
description: The man who paid $21.3 million for a 710-year-old copy of the Magna Carta, which laid the framework for the United States Constitution and is one of the most prized historic documents in the world, says he wants to keep the copy on display in the United States.

title: Facing Treacherous Streets With Limited Mobility
description: You just have to be careful, said Jeffrey Watler, wearing a winter coat over the collared shirt required by his employer, a messenger service. Knapsack on his back, he threaded his way through pedestrians, bike messengers and dogs on the way to his next pickup near Grand Central Terminal.

title: Leave Him in or Take Him Out? Coaches Ponder Clemens as a Speaker
description: In normal times, decisions undertaken by the Texas High School Baseball Coaches Association are not of much concern outside Texas. The seven members on the associations executive board plan all-star games and the groups yearly convention and help oversee the state playoffs.

title: Japan: U.S. Pushes to Halt Humpback Whale Hunt
description: The United States is pushing Japan to suspend its hunt of humpback whales, and the American ambassador to Tokyo said an agreement to stop it may have already been reached. Japan dispatched its whaling fleet to the southern Pacific last month in the first major hunt of the endangered species since the 1960s.

title: Portugal Polishes Its Image as the West Coast of Europe
description: FOR Portugal, the signing in Lisbon last week of a treaty to overhaul the governance of the European Union was a tipping point, said Manuel Pinho, Portugals minister for the economy and innovation.

title: A Landscapes Isolation Is Turned Into a Virtue
description: The winning design for a 40-acre park that would unfold across the southern half of Governors Island is not the kind of grand public-works project the city once championed. But in an age when developers regularly usurp the governments planning role, it reflects the kind of imaginative, civic-minded thinking that can restore our faith in city and state leaders.

title: Hopes Dim for U.N. Solution for Kosovo
description: UNITED NATIONS  The Security Council signaled Wednesday that it would not be able to resolve the status of Kosovo, the breakaway Serbian province, and that a solution would have to come from outside the United Nations.

title: Winehouse Free on Bail
description: The British singer Amy Winehouse was released on bail after her arrest in an investigation into perverting the course of justice, Reuters reported. The police in London said on Wednesday that Ms. Winehouse, 24, was to return to a police station in March pending further inquiries. Her husband, Blake Fielder-Civil, has been in custody for several weeks on charges of trying to pervert the course of justice in relation to an assault case.

title: Bolivias Leader Says States Dispute Can Be Resolved
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia  At 6 a.m. in this city 11,900 feet above sea level, the corridors of the presidential palace are bitingly cold. Aides huddle in overcoats near space heaters. Soldiers clasping rifles with bayonets stand guard with chattering teeth.

description: Q.  What is the best way to clean a granite countertop?

title: When Piano and Strings Make Room for the Horn
description: Chamber Music at the Y devoted its Tuesday evening concert at the 92nd Street Y (and a repeat on Wednesday) to works by Schumann and Brahms, with two well-known scores set beside two that usually slip below the radar.

title: Ransom-Note Ads About Childrens Health Are Canceled
description: The Child Study Center at New York University said on Wednesday that it would halt an advertising campaign aimed at raising awareness of childrens mental and neurological disorders after the effort drew a strongly negative reaction.

title: Congress Is Still Pursuing Earmarks
description: WASHINGTON  It has a been a difficult few years for earmarks, the pet spending projects that lawmakers pursue in Congress. They have been linked to felony cases, blamed for the national debt, stripped from the budget, exposed to public scrutiny and subjected to ridicule. Yet earmarks and the lawmakers who love them will not be denied.

title: C.I.A. to Cooperate With House on Tapes
description: WASHINGTON  The Central Intelligence Agency has agreed to make documents related to the destruction of interrogation videotapes available to the House Intelligence Committee and to allow the agencys top lawyer, John A. Rizzo, to testify about the matter, Congressional and intelligence officials said Wednesday.

title: The Islanders Simon Is Banished 30 Games
description: Nine months ago, the N.H.L. handed down a 25-game suspension, its longest for an on-ice incident. The recipient was Chris Simon.

title: Hitting the Bottom, the Bottom Hits Back
description: In this damp weather, its not hard to tell when the fans grab their clumpy jackets and head for the exits. The fans actually departed Madison Square Garden Wednesday night because the Knicks were winning by 19 points with 8 minutes 50 seconds left.

title: Missing in a Snowy Forest for Days, a Family Is Safe
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A man and his three children who disappeared in the snowy woods last weekend were found shivering, but alive, by rescuers on Wednesday, in a three-day saga that began with a hunt for a Christmas tree and ended with what rescuers called a Christmas miracle.

title: Illinois: Man Admits Ninth Killing, Police Say
description: The authorities named a ninth victim of a man who had previously confessed to killing eight women from 1977 to 1982. Police officials in Paducah, Ky., said the man, Timothy W. Krajcir, 63, had admitted to the 1979 kidnapping and murder of Joyce Tharp, 29. Earlier this month, officials announced that Mr. Krajcir, who has been imprisoned since 1983, had confessed to the killings of five women in Missouri, two in Illinois and one in Pennsylvania. Sexual assault accompanied many of the killings. Mr. Krajcir, who has yet to be charged in three of the killings, awaits extradition from Illinois to Missouri, where he faces multiple life sentences.

title: A Bigger Screen for the Gamer With High-Definition Needs
description: While it is nice to have a big-screen HDTV in the living room, these behemoths are not intended to keep up with high-end game consoles and PCs. Now, however, theres the Sharp Aquos LC-32GP3U, a high-definition television created especially for gamers.

description: To the Editor:

title: Wouldnt You Know It, the Knicks Win
description: In the wake of protests and chants, taunts and insults  all aimed at a team and a coach that has pushed its fans to the point of insanity  the Knicks found a new way to torture their critics Wednesday. They won, big.

title: After Chief Holds a Chat, Sallie Mae Stock Plunges
description: You known the conference call is going badly when the chief executive tells shareholders they will have to walk through a metal detector the next time they meet.

title: G.M. Selling a Truck Business to Navistar
description: DETROIT  General Motors said Thursday that it had agreed to sell its medium-duty truck business to Navistar International, an Illinois-based maker of trucks and diesel engines.

title: Giants Look to Rookies to Fill Shockeys Void
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Kevin Boss has been called the un-Jeremy Shockey. Even Boss struggles to build a list of similarities between the two.

title: Washington: Lawyers Can Take a Number
description: A Web site that rates lawyers the way Zagat rates restaurants, by number, is protected by the First Amendment, a federal judge in Seattle ruled Tuesday. Saying the ratings assigned by the Web site, Avvo, are opinions rather than facts, the judge, Robert S. Lasnik of Federal District Court, dismissed a lawsuit brought by two disgruntled lawyers, John Henry Browne and Alan J. Wenokur, who claimed their low rankings had cost them clients and money. Rather than seeing the Avvo ratings for what they are  that and $1.50 will get you a ride on Seattles new South Lake Union Streetcar  plaintiffs Brown and Wenokur want to make a federal case out of the number assigned to them, Judge Lasnik wrote.

title: The Evolution of a Man Called Bulldozer
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The man chosen as South Koreas next president in Wednesdays election owes much of his victory to a wildly successful project he completed as this citys mayor: the restoration in 2005 of a paved-over, four-mile stream in downtown Seoul, over which an ugly highway had been built during the growth-at-all-cost 1970s.

title: Late Shows to Return, but Wholl Be Talking?
description: LOS ANGELES  The late-night talk show hosts are returning. But the stars are not yet ready to come out for them.

description: Given the surfeit of circus rings engaged under the political big top, there are only so many acts that can get much attention.

description: Bear Stearns reported its first quarterly loss ever in its eight-decade history on Thursday, stung by the mortgage crisis that has swept markets across the globe.

title: Jury Rejects Mans Bid for Share of Sopranos
description: TRENTON  A jury in federal court here found the writer and producer David Chase, much like Tony Soprano, the character he created, to be a man of influence who could grant valuable favors.

title: Wheelchair Van Operators End Strike
description: A 10-day strike that inconvenienced about 9,000 wheelchair users and other people with disabilities who depend on Access-a-Ride, a government-financed van service, ended on Wednesday when members of Local 1181 of the Amalgamated Transit Union voted to ratify a contract settlement.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A pop music entry in the Listings pages of Weekend on Friday about Ian Hunter, at the Music Hall of Williamsburg, misidentified the bass player in his Rant Band. He is Paul Page  not Graham Maby, who has played with Mr. Hunter.

title: Refugees Risk Coming Home to an Unready Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  The widow Hashim crossed the border into Iraq from Syria at dusk last month, heading homeward as the sun set behind her and the sky ahead grew dark.

title: The Civilized World Finds a Refuge
description: I DONT know about you, but I dont get the holiday blues anymore. That syndrome seems like a quaint, forgettable rash compared with my now-annual The World Is Headed for Disaster winter panic, which is caused by exposure to extreme weather changes, scary news reports and unrelentingly cheery holiday excess.

title: Backing Up Master Mixes

title: Nanotechnology Companies Planning to Sell Shares
description: NANOTECHNOLOGY companies, nurtured on billions of dollars in government grants and venture investments through most of this decade, are getting ready to go public.

title: Slowing the Rise in Health Costs
description: With the disjointed American health care system in perpetual crisis, it is essential to find ways to slow the relentless rise in costs, without jeopardizing the quality of care. There is no single solution. But a broad range of reforms could combine to produce worthwhile savings.

title: Plaintiff Drops Suit Against Leonard Lauder
description: A grandson of a Viennese woman who disappeared in the Holocaust has dropped his lawsuit in Manhattan Federal Court demanding the return of a Gustav Klimt painting from the private collection of Leonard A. Lauder, the cosmetics magnate. The lawsuit was abandoned because of conflicting evidence, said E. Randol Schoenberg, a lawyer for the plaintiff. In a statement Mr. Lauder said: We are pleased that the case has been withdrawn. It confirms what weve always asserted, that there is no evidence to support the claim. The plaintiff, Georges Jorisch, 79, had charged that the painting was owned by his grandmother Amalie Redlich, who disappeared after she was deported by the Nazis to the Lodz ghetto in Poland in 1941. The signed oil painting, Blooming Meadow (1906), was purchased by Mr. Lauder in 1983 from the art dealer Serge Sabarsky.

title: Paying Homage to Visions of Bowl Games Gone By
description: It is nearly time to break out the Barcalounger, football fans. Bowl season kicks off this week, setting off an indulgence of 32 televised games in 20 days featuring teams and players you have scarcely heard of and may never hear from again.

title: Bank of Japan Holds Its Key Rate Steady
description: TOKYO (Bloomberg News)  The Bank of Japan kept interest rates steady on Thursday in its first unanimous decision since June, after a drop in business confidence signaled that companies were bracing for slower growth.

title: A Pause From Death
description: The United Nations General Assembly voted on Tuesday for a global moratorium on the death penalty. The resolution was nonbinding; its symbolic weight made barely a ripple in the news ocean of the United States, where governments right to kill a killer is enshrined in law and custom.

title: A Centennial Face-Lift for a Beaux-Arts Gem
description: About four years ago, Paul LeClerc, president of the New York Public Library, began noticing the streaks blackening the marble facade of the Beaux-Arts main building when he walked into work each day.

title: Pantone's Color of the Year Is...
description: AT least one color authority, Pantone, has taken the plunge and announced its favorite color for 2008. To be sure, this news doesnt seem as delectable as Peoples Sexiest Man Alive or as snugly affirming as Times Person of the Year. You probably did not even know that chili pepper red was the color for 2007.

title: A Tradition Lives: A Home Away From Home
description: MINNEAPOLIS  James Sheppard of the Minnesota Wild can afford his own apartment or home and enjoy an expensive dinner at any restaurant in the Twin Cities. So why is he living in a basement in suburban St. Paul?

title: Hasidic Rabbi and Assistant Are Arrested in Tax Scheme
description: The grand rabbi of Spinka, a Brooklyn-based Hasidic sect, was arrested Wednesday with his executive assistant in Los Angeles on charges that they arranged and profited from inflated charitable donations that saved the donors millions of dollars in federal income taxes.

description: Florida State Coach Bobby Bowden finished the regular season with the most career victories in major college football, but there are no guarantees he will start next season as the leader.

description: The Campbell Soup Company agreed on Thursday to sell its Godiva Chocolatier unit to Yildiz Holding of Turkey for $850 million.

title: Columbia Expansion Gets Green Light
description: The New York City Council cleared the way Wednesday for the largest expansion in the history of Columbia University. The university plans a $7 billion project over the next 25 years that will transform a section of Upper Manhattan now dominated by warehouses and auto body shops into a campus with glass-walled high-rise buildings, tree-lined thoroughfares and student dormitories.

title: Man and Woman, Hot and Acting Hotter
description: She has that thing that all Latin American ballerinas have, the Russian ballerina Alexandra Danilova is reputed to have said of a dancer to a critic friend. Hmm, I cant think of the word ... The critic suggested, Temperament? Danilova replied at once: No. Bitchiness.

title: No Password Needed, Just Look Your Best
description: In a twist on the old RCA advertisement showing a dog listening to its masters voice coming from a phonograph, Asus has created a laptop that uses its camera to scrutinize the user and, if the masters face is familiar, lets the person log on without a password.

title: Conservative Wins Vote in South Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Lee Myung-bak, a conservative politician famous for his success in business but dogged by questions about his character, swept to a huge victory on Wednesday in a presidential election dominated by economic concerns.

title: The Online Gold Standard

Judging by holiday purchases, online buying sprees are turning even the most solemn of sobersides into saucer-eyed children mesmerized by glitter and gilt.

title: Putting Very Little Weight in Calorie Counting Methods
description: THE Spinning class at our local gym was winding down. People were wiping off their bikes, gathering their towels and water bottles, and walking out the door when a woman shouted to the instructor, How many calories did we burn?

description: MORRISTOWN, N.J.  It was a mob scene.

title: Religious Leaders Call for Talks With Iran
description: More than 60 Christian, Jewish and Muslim leaders have signed a call to the American government and the religious authorities in Iran to open direct negotiations and stop planning for war. The statement, A Pax on Both Our Houses (pax is Latin for peace) says the war in Iraq demonstrates how war wastes lives and resources, and violates human rights. The statement was released Wednesday in Des Moines, to remind the presidential candidates and reporters now crisscrossing Iowa that many religious constituencies are still focused on foreign policy, organizers said. The full text of the statement is available on interfaithpeacecommittee.org.

title: U.S. to Cap Flights at Kennedy at Peak Times, but Its Daily Totals May Increase
description: HERNDON, Va.  Travelers going through Kennedy and Newark Liberty Airports next summer may find somewhat fewer flights at the hours they most want to travel, but are far more likely to leave on time or arrive in time to make connections, federal transportation officials said on Wednesday.

description: AND the cat came back, but it was not the very next day. It was not even the next year, because that would have been tacky.

title: Survivor Is Poised to Lead South Africa
description: POLOKWANE, South Africa  When Jacob Gedleyihlekisa Zuma, the man who is likely to be South Africas next president, was 21 years old, South Africas apartheid government condemned him to 10 years imprisonment on Robben Island, in a cell not far from that of Nelson Mandela.

title: Outside the Garden, an Eight-Foot Pink Slip for Thomas Seeks Change
description: Outside Madison Square Garden on Wednesday morning, on the busy city sidewalk, there stood a Salvation Army group singing Christmas carols.

title: Producers Charged
description: Two Hollywood producers were charged in Los Angeles with bribing a Thai government official to get contracts to run the Bangkok International Film Festival. Federal agents on Tuesday arrested Gerald Green, whose film credits include this years Rescue Dawn, shot largely in Thailand, and his wife, Patricia T. Green, who was a producer of The New Swiss Family Robinson. Prosecutors said the two paid the governor of the Tourism Authority of Thailand, who was also the president of the festival, more than $1.7 million to obtain contracts worth more than $10 million between 2003 and 2007. The governor during that period, whom prosecutors did not name, was Juthamas Siriwan. Investigators said the governor had authority to approve contracts up to a given amount, and that the Greens set up shell companies to get contracts that didnt exceed that amount. Authorities said the Greens passed bribes to the governor through her daughter and other intermediaries. Prosecutors also said that the Greens tried to concoct a cover story for the payments after a July raid of their offices by the F.B.I. The Thai government this year stripped the tourism agency of control over the festival.

title: An Idea Whose Time Should Be Past
description: The mandatory sentencing craze that began in the 1970s was a public-policy disaster. It drove up inmate populations and corrections costs and forced the states to choose between building prisons and building schools or funding medical care for the indigent. It filled the prisons to bursting with nonviolent drug offenders who would have been more cheaply and more appropriately dealt with through treatment. It tied the hands of judges and ruined countless young lives by mandating lengthy prison terms in cases where leniency was warranted. It undermined confidence in the fairness of the justice system by singling out poor and minority offenders while largely exempting the white and wealthy.

The Steelers suddenly find their division lead in jeopardy and are in a fight for playoff positioning. A game against St. Louis (3-11) would seem to be a nice break after tough losses to the Patriots and the Jaguars. But the Steelers other three losses were on the road: to Arizona, Denver and the Jets, which all have losing records. Before allowing 117 yards to the Jets Thomas Jones in Week 11, the Steelers had not allowed a 100-yard rusher in two years. But they allowed 147 yards to Fred Taylor last week as the Jaguars rushed for 224, and the Rams Steven Jackson is coming off his best game of the season, with 143 yards against the Packers. This is the first time the Rams have played host to the Steelers since moving to St. Louis in 1995.

Turns out its a digital look book  a high-tech iteration of the runway-fashion flipbook that designers send to editors. The Donna PR team hails its gizmo as a paperless ecological breakthrough. title: Turn-Ons Include Museums and Gmail. Turn-Offs Are Liars.
description: It was a quixotic open casting call made via e-mail: Have your moving silhouette, iPod-ad-style, be immortalized as part of an exhibition on online dating for the Museum of Modern Art in February. R.S.V.P. to a gmail address, then show up in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, with props for banal everyday activities like brushing your teeth, drinking water or reading a book. The filming of some 1,000 silhouettes images began today and continues Friday.The project, called I Want You to Want Me (not, apparently, named after the 1977 song by Cheap Trick), is a creation of Jonathan Harris and Sep Kamvar. The pair combined art, emotion and statistical combing of the Internet in their last project, We Feel Fine, which crawled blogs and online postings and aggregated statements about peoples emotional states. The new project is one of a handful commissioned by MoMA to be part of the Design and the Elastic Mind exhibition, an exploration of how disruptive technology has been incorporated into everyday lives. The show will be on view from Feb. 24 to May 12.

Britain: Long Lives the Queen

title: Cactus Makes Perfect
description: Heat-seeking golfers who favor Scottsdale, Ariz., will encounter a curious phenomenon this winter: What's old is new. November witnessed extreme makeovers applied to two of the Sonoran Desert's "must-play" destinations, Troon North and the TPC Scottsdale. Troon North's tweaks are the more subtle. Its Saguaro-laced Monument and Pinnacle courses have been rated as Arizona's top two public-access tracks for than 10 years, but the layout routed players in confusing directions. After much soul-searching, Troon Golf executives split up the vaunted Monument layout, pairing its old back nine with the old back nine of the Pinnacle to form a "new" Pinnacle course. The "new" Monument course comprises the old front nines. Original designer Tom Weiskopf resurfaced the greens and reworked the bunkers to achieve a consistent look throughout. The result is better flow. Gone are the "Where-in-the-world-am-I-going" cart rides that slowed up play considerably. Monument is the more spectacular of the two, with gigantic rocks and elevation changes at every turn, but Pinnacle is tougher -- and, in a rarity for the desert, is a walkable course, even if its ninth hole doesn't return to the clubhouse.

Reilly is Dewey Cox  who conquers the nations eardrums with a song in his heart, a guitar in his hands and a million clichs in his DNA. Hes a tuneful pastiche: a little bit country, a little bit rock n roll, topped off with a pinch of Ray Charles, a dash of Buddy Holly and a whole mess of Johnny Cash as filtered through Joaquin Phoenixs impersonation and mischievously repurposed through the Judd Apatow laugh factory.

Mr. Ahsan; the dismissed chief justice of the Supreme Court, Iftikhar Muhammad Chaudhry; and several other dismissed justices have been jailed or placed under house arrest since President Pervez Musharraf declared a state of emergency last month, suspended the Constitution and appointed a new Supreme Court. title: France: Housing Aide Out Over Cheap Home
description: Jean-Paul Bolufer, the chief of staff in the Housing Ministry, was ordered to step down for enjoying a subsidized 2,000-square-foot Left Bank apartment at a quarter of the market rent. The scandal came as the ministry faced pressure over high rents and homelessness.

title: Top Concert Promoter Sets Up a Challenge to Ticketmaster
description: In a bid to consolidate its hold on live-music fans, the concert giant Live Nation said on Thursday that it would acquire the software and services to ramp up its ticket-selling operation, potentially positioning the company to compete directly with its longtime contractor, Ticketmaster.

title: China and India in First War Games
description: China and India began a weeklong joint military exercise in Chinas southwestern Yunnan Province. The drills, which involve about 100 soldiers from each side, are intended at strengthening cooperation on anti-terrorism, according to China Daily. China and India fought a brief border war in 1962 and have been unable to resolve a related territorial dispute through negotiations.

title: Sierra Leone: Blast in Capital Kills 17
description: A huge explosion in the center of the capital, Freetown, killed at least 17 people and wounded many more, according to witnesses and rescue officials. Officials said that the blast, which occurred on a busy street in a main shopping district of Freetown as crowds thronged to shop for Christmas, was most likely caused by a gas leak. Sierra Leones infrastructure remains badly dilapidated from a decade-long civil war that ended in 2002.

title: Violent Protest Over Housing in New Orleans
description: NEW ORLEANS  After protesters clashed violently with the police inside and outside the New Orleans City Council chambers on Thursday, the council voted unanimously to allow the federal government to demolish 4,500 apartments in the four biggest public housing projects in the city.

title: Gone for the Holidays, but Leaving a Light on (Got It, Mr. President?)
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate seemed to wrap up its last business of the year on Wednesday night. But anyone listening carefully to the majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, would have heard him laying out plans for the Senate to work through the holidays  sort of.

title: 50 Killed in Pakistan Bombing
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan -- A suicide attacker detonated a powerful bomb inside a crowded mosque in northwestern Pakistan Friday morning, killing as many as 50 men and wounding 80 as they prayed to mark the Muslim holiday of Id al-Adha, Pakistan's former interior minister said.

title: Stocks Soar on Merrill Report and Economic Data
description: Stock markets surged on Friday as reports of talks on an investment in Merrill Lynch and a strong report on consumer spending lifted investors spirits heading into the holiday weekend.

title: Man Sought for Questioning in Killing
description: The police identified a Brooklyn man on Thursday that they are seeking for questioning in the Dec. 15 death of Carol Simon-Hayes, who was shot as she walked to the entrance of her Crown Heights apartment building.

title: Searching Across the Border
description: SOUTH of the border? How about north? Second-home shoppers who want something more exotic than their friends mountain bungalows and beach condos have two easy options: Mexico and Canada.

title: Giants Stay Relaxed Despite the Stakes
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The temperature was in the 40s, the field was bathed in sunshine, the wind was barely blowing and Giants Coach Tom Coughlin was happy. Preparations for a big game were going smoothly  maybe even better.

title: Newly Elected South Korean Forecasts Chill With North
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The South Korean president-elect, Lee Myung-bak, who said during his campaign that he intended to get tough with North Korea, declared Thursday that he would not hesitate to criticize its authoritarian government.

title: Epiphanies in a Medieval Courtyard
description: THE first thing I see every morning is the Cloisters tower, gray and severe, perfectly framed by the living room window of my apartment. The Cloisters, the Metropolitan Museums medieval outpost, is about a quarter-mile to the south, on a hill a little higher than the one my building is on, near the stony tip of northern Manhattan. In between is a valley of rooftops, garages and streets. Above, open sky, clouds, the moon, stars.

title: Tyson Finds a Label for Its Antibiotic-Free (Well, Almost) Chicken
description: Tyson Foods ran into an unusual snag after it introduced a marketing campaign to promote its raised without antibiotics chicken. The Department of Agriculture initially approved the label, but later said it had made a mistake.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about the social networking of technology start-ups in California misidentified the location of the part of Sand Hill Road where Silicon Valley venture capital firms are concentrated. It is in Menlo Park, not Palo Alto.

title: Musical Greetings That Swing Angelically
description: The pop-jazz singer Ann Hampton Callaway possesses what I think of as a quintessential Christmas voice. Sweet and pure, with a fluty upper register, her sound transports you to an ethereal realm where the air is thin and clear, and moonlight lends the snow on the earth below a bluish tint.

title: Mint to Add 6 Nonstates to State Quarters Lineup
description: Americans who are unsure where the Northern Mariana Islands lie, or just what Guam is famous for, may find answers in their pocket change by the end of 2009.

title: Gold in the Ivory Tower
description: THE separation of the wealthiest from the rest of the country is alarming. But it would be even more alarming if we recognized that income isnt the only measure of wealth. Health and education are forms of wealth, too, essential to happiness and a strong society. Yet in the discussion of Americas growing wealth gap, they too often go unnoticed.

title: Cubans Still Waiting for Castro
description: CIENFUEGOS, Cuba  The speculation was that he would be here, that Fidel Castro was ready to leave his hospital bed after 17 months of convalescence and that he would come to inaugurate a revamped Soviet-era oil refinery that he had been saying for years was a key to Cubas energy future.

title: Class-Action Cases Rise, Fueled by Subprime Troubles
description: The subprime mess is turning out to be a boon for class-action lawyers.

title: Man Cleared in 1998 Northern Ireland Blast
description: LONDON  A judge in Belfast on Thursday cleared Sean Hoey, a 38-year-old electrician, of murder and all other charges stemming from the car bombing in 1998 that killed 29 people and wounded more than 200 in the Northern Ireland town of Omagh.

title: Smoothing Bumps for Boomers
description: IT was at the top of a trail called Hanging Tree that the fear set in. And at the crest of a steep, mogul-filled and tree-strewn trail, its all about the fear, isnt it? This was near the top of Aspen Mountain last winter, and at moments like these  surveying a no-nonsense double-black-diamond run  the mind will race.

title: F.T.C. Approves DoubleClick Deal
description: THE Federal Trade Commission said Thursday that it had cleared Googles proposed merger with DoubleClick, the digital marketing company, saying that the deal was unlikely to substantially lessen competition in the Internet advertising realm.

title: Out of Uncertainty, a Coach Brings Success
description: Bill Lynchs cellphone buzzed early one morning in June at the Indiana University football complex. It was the daughter of his good friend, Indiana Coach Terry Hoeppner, calling to tell Lynch that her father had died that morning after an 18-month fight with brain cancer.

title: U.N. Body Plans to End Investigation of Contracts
description: UNITED NATIONS  The General Assembly is preparing to put an early end to an in-house panel that has exposed more than $600 million in tainted United Nations contracts and is currently investigating an additional $1 billion in suspect agreements.

title: Russia Signs Deal for Gas Pipeline Along Caspian Sea
description: Desperate to meet growing domestic and European demand, Russia signed a deal Thursday with the Central Asian republics of Kazakhstan and Turkmenistan to build a natural gas pipeline along the Caspian Sea, a move that analysts said could strengthen Russias monopoly on energy exports from the region.

title: Solving the Mortgage Crisis May Require a Guardian Angel

title: Decongesting the Skies
description: The Bush administrations remedy for the nations overcrowded skies, months in the making, correctly zeros in on the New York area where steady and sometimes monumental delays have created flying misery across the nation. The short-term solution includes caps on hourly traffic, which should help. But Washington also needs to aggressively pursue longer-term solutions, chief among them cutting-edge air traffic control systems and relieving congestion on runways and taxiways.

title: Visions of Sugar Plums
description: On Wednesday evening at the New York State Theater, George Balanchines production of The Nutcracker achieved its 2,000th performance by New York City Ballet. After a perfectly straightforward account of the first act, the second one became a special event. The three principal dance roles  the Sugar Plum Fairy, her Cavalier and the Dewdrop Fairy  were performed in multiple castings. One Sugar Plum ballerina (Maria Kowroski) danced the characters solo; later another (Wendy Whelan) danced her adagio; then three (Darci Kistler, Yvonne Borree and Abi Stafford) shared the stage in its coda, of whom one (Ms. Kistler, who was dancing lead Nutcracker roles in her 1980 debut season) took charge of the end of the ballet.

title: Treasures From Afghanistan to Tour the United States
description: A traveling exhibition of some 200 artworks from the National Museum of Afghanistan in Kabul will begin a 17-month tour in the United States in May, making its first stop at the National Gallery of Art in Washington.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article and a picture caption on the Square Feet pages of Business Day on Wednesday about the office market in Manhattan misstated the address of the Milk Studios Building, which recently sold for more than $160 million. It is at 450 West 15th Street, not East 15th Street.

title: Murder Most Musical
description: Tim Burton makes fantasy movies. Stephen Sondheim writes musicals. It is hard to think of two more optimistic genres of popular art, or of two popular artists who have so systematically subverted that optimism. Mr. Sondheim has always gravitated toward the dissonance lurking in hummable tunes, and has threaded his song-and-dance spectaculars with subtexts of anxiety and alienation. Mr. Burton, for his part, dwells most naturally (if somewhat uneasily) in the realms of the gothic and the grotesque, turning comic books and childrens tales into scary, nightmarish shadow plays.

title: Handels Holiday Hit, Tactfully Modern
description: For a week or two in mid-December, Handels oratorio Messiah is performed somewhere in New York almost every day. As holiday traditions go, this has certainly proved to be among the more durable. The New York Philharmonic threw its collective hat into the overcrowded ring just a few years ago, offering performances played by an instrumental complement scaled down to the proportions of a Baroque ensemble.

title:
Helping Police Officers
Understand the Autistic
description: BRICK TOWNSHIP, N.J.  An autistic boy is discovered standing in the middle of a busy road, on his way to the beach. A young girl with autism outsmarts a number of locks, leaves the house before her mother wakes up and is found, naked but alive, in a neighbors pool.

title: Albany Adds 60 Schools to City List of Failures
description: Sixty New York City elementary and middle schools have been newly identified as failing under the federal No Child Left Behind law, according to a list released on Thursday by the State Education Department, which also showed that the number of failing schools was rising in both the city and the state.

title: India: Premier Asks States to Fight Maoists
description: With ill-equipped and short-staffed local police forces unable to handle an increasingly well-organized Maoist insurgency in central India, Prime Minister Manmohan Singh urged state governments to establish special police forces to take on the guerrillas. Mr. Singh was speaking to a conference on internal security in the capital, New Delhi, four days after Maoists led a jailbreak that freed 300 prisoners from a local jail in Chhattisgarh, the epicenter of the conflict. Mr. Singh, who has called the Maoist rebellion the most significant internal security challenge to the country, acknowledged that a lack of opportunity in some of Indias poorest hinterlands had provided a fertile ground for extremist ideologies to flourish, but also said that insecurity had hindered economic expansion in those very areas.

title: Data About Zetia Risks Was Not Fully Revealed
description: New evidence shows that the drug makers Merck and Schering-Plough have conducted several studies of their popular cholesterol medicine Zetia that raise questions about its risks to the liver, but the companies have never published those results.

title: With Detroit Downbeat on 2008, Its Suppliers Are Singing the Blues
description: CARMAKERS expect 2008 to be challenging, at best, but hundreds of automotive parts suppliers are anticipating the year ahead to be one of the ugliest ever.

title: In Bhutan, Sacred Sights Amid the Clouds
description: Traveling many years, I have not yet seen a place as peaceful as Bhutan, or a place affecting such peacefulness within myself, the photographer Kenro Izu writes. If there is a place indeed named Utopia, this place may come the closest to it. Mr. Izu has been taking photographs of sacred places since the late 1970s, but Bhutan, a Buddhist country of about 670,000 people nestled in the Himalayas, has become his personal Shangri-La.

title: I.R.S. Says Bill Would Aid Tax Fraud in Virgin Islands
description: The Internal Revenue Service has criticized proposed legislation that would scale back audits of wealthy taxpayers in the United States Virgin Islands, saying that the bill would significantly affect the agencys efforts to combat offshore tax fraud.

title: Sallie Mae Delays Stock Repurchase
description: The parent of Sallie Mae, which for years profited from placing large bets on its own stock going up, now faces a possible loss of more than $1 billion as the bet has gone drastically wrong. On Thursday it negotiated a two-month delay in the deadline for coming up with the money.

title: Good-Time Charlies Foreign Affairs
description: Most of the recent films weve seen about the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq remind us what a drag those conflicts are, which may be why so few of us have bothered to go see them. Of course all wars are terrible, but good movies have a way of mitigating that dreary fact even as they acknowledge it. Take the cold war: a long twilight struggle (as John F. Kennedy put it) that brought the world to the brink of annihilation and provided a persistent source of tension, anxiety and dread for hundreds of millions of people around the world. Horrible, to be sure. But also kind of a blast.

title: Penn State Players Charged
description: Felony assault charges were refiled against two Penn State football players, two weeks after a judge dismissed the same charges at a preliminary hearing. Defensive tackle Chris Baker and linebacker Navorro Bowman were charged Wednesday with being part of a group of people that beat a man Oct. 7. Centre County District Attorney Michael Madeira said District Judge Carmine Prestia erred when he dropped the charges.

title: Study Shows Marathons Arent Likely to Kill You
description: Worried about dropping dead if you run a marathon? Researchers in Canada say you can put your mind at ease. The risk of dying on a marathon course is twice as high if you drive it than if you run it, they find.

title: Denial of State Emissions Plan Was Foreshadowed

New York state history doesnt get a lot more palpable than this.

title: Water Taxi to Skip East River Route for 4 Months
description: As of Jan. 1, the New York Water Taxi is suspending its ferry service on the East River route serving points in Brooklyn and Lower Manhattan for four months, citing a combination of rising fuel costs and the low ridership during the winter season. While the companys tourist service has been profitable, ferry companies have long struggled with the economics of ferry service. It will reopen in May.Fuel costs have doubled in 2007 alone, said Tom Fox, the president of New York Water Taxi. Even so, the companys East River route broke even for the first time in 2007 during the fall, spring and summer seasons. But ridership declines by about 30 percent in the winter because of a fall in tourism, and the commuters are not profitable.

title: Japan: Its O.K. to Fire on Godzilla, Official Says
description: The minister of defense caused a media squall after joking about invasions by space aliens and movie monsters. Responding to a question at a news conference, the minister, Shigeru Ishiba, told reporters that he was studying whether the nations pacifist Constitution would limit a military response to an attack by space aliens. There are no grounds to deny that there are unidentified flying objects and some life forms that control them, Mr. Ishiba said, smiling at first, but then delivering a straight-faced explanation. If Godzilla attacked, that would probably be a natural disaster relief operation, making military action legally permissible, he said. The comments came days after Japans chief cabinet secretary, Nobutaka Machimura, who is the governments top spokesman, professed belief in U.F.O.s.

title: Belgium Holds 14 in Plot to Free Qaeda Supporter
description: BRUSSELS  The Belgian authorities detained 14 people they described as Islamic extremists on Friday, saying they planned to use explosives to free a supporter of Al Qaeda in prison for plotting an attack on an air base. title: Kentucky: Louisville Smoking Ban Is Struck Down

Only after voting that Churchill Downs would keep its exemption did the Council pass the smoke-free law, Judge Steven Ryan wrote. The converse of this fact is that the Council would not have passed a smoke-free law devoid of said exemption. A group of business owners, the Metro Louisville Hospitality Coalition, sued to overturn the ban.

title: Bushs Chief Terrorism Adviser Is Leaving, Unscathed
description: WASHINGTON  For more than four years, Frances Fragos Townsend, President Bushs departing chief terrorism adviser, has worked at the center of contentious antiterrorism programs, but unlike other battle-scarred West Wing colleagues, she is leaving with barely a scratch.

title: Arrest Provides Some Solace to Slain Deliverymans Family
description: As a slain deliveryman from Yonkers was buried on Friday, family members and friends took solace in the quick arrest of a suspect in the killing.

title: Rice Has Sharp Words for Taiwan, as Gates Does for China
description: WASHINGTON  Senior administration officials sharply criticized China and Taiwan on Friday, saying they were inflaming tensions with each other and with the United States.

title: Pair of Meditations, Mystical and Rambunctious
description: Late Thursday afternoon, as a steady stream of holiday shoppers, tourists and people leaving offices bustled past St. Thomas Church on Fifth Avenue, inside the church almost every pew was filled to capacity for a choral program and organ concert.

title: Hijacking Comes to Little When Robbers Cant Get the Cargo Out
description: It began as a brazen robbery and kidnapping in Hells Kitchen on the West Side, as men with guns and a phony police badge hijacked a FedEx tractor-trailer loaded with holiday gifts.

title: Judge Supports Arizona Law on Immigrants
description: A new Arizona law considered among the nations toughest against employers who hire illegal immigrants will go into effect on Jan. 1 after federal judges on Friday refused to block it.

title: Under Pressure, Japan Delays Plan to Hunt the Humpback
description: Japan, under pressure from the United States and Australia, is delaying plans to kill 50 humpback whales as part of its already contentious annual whale harvest in waters near Antarctica.

title: Information Con Game
description: The very title of a now 41-year-old law  the Freedom of Information Act  sounds nave in todays Washington, where government secrecy has become an even higher and darker art under the Bush administration.

title: Truce Reached in Fight Over Chinese Beverage Company
description: SHANGHAI  After months of legal skirmishes and name-calling over who controls Wahaha, one of Chinas biggest beverage makers, Groupe Danone of France and the Wahaha Group of China have agreed to return to peace talks.

title: Jets Statement on Their Treatment of Concussions
description: With any injury, player safety is our foremost concern. Our approach to treating concussions is conservative and involves a team of specialists including a neurologist, neuropsychologist, and neuroradiologist. No player has been allowed to return to a game unless he is entirely without symptoms; has normal mental status testing; and has a normal neurological examination. Most recently any player who has loss of consciousness is not allowed to return to play regardless of symptoms, results of mental status testing or neurological examination. Medical staff and coaches continue to follow the player through the game and if the status of the player changes, he is removed. Players are expected and encouraged to report their symptoms, both on the day of the game and thereafter. However, in-game decisions are only one component of the process.

title: Celebrity Architects
description: To the Editor:

title: Spitzer Pardons Ex-Convict to Spare Him Deportation
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer announced the pardon on Friday of a 54-year-old Brooklyn man convicted of robbery 16 years ago, saying the pardon would spare the man from being deported to Jamaica.

title: Cowboys at Panthers
description: 8:15 p.m., NFL Network

title: Charming and Aloof, Huckabee Changed State
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark.  In more than a decade of presiding over this state, Mike Huckabee produced a legacy like few other Republican governors in the South, surprising even liberal Democrats with his willingness to upend some of Arkansass more parochial traditions.

title: Awakening Councils by Region
description: At the heart of the American militarys counterinsurgency campaign  and a large part of its success  has been the expansion of the Awakening Councils, groups of Sunnis, some of them former militants themselves, who have bonded together to fight the most violent of the Sunni insurgents.

title: The State of Iraq: An Update
description: AS 2007 comes to close, how should we understand the situation in Iraq? Are we witnessing the greatest American military comeback late in a war since Shermans march to the sea in 1864? Or is Iraq still a weakly governed and very violent place where sectarian reconciliation is starkly absent?

She is Patricia T. Green  not Patricia M. Green, a writer and producer, whose television credits include Chicago Hope, China Beach and L.A. Law. (Go to Article)

title: News Mixed, but Stocks Still Manage Strong Rally
description: Stock markets surged Friday on reports of a possible foreign investment in Merrill Lynch and an uptick in consumer spending.

title: Goldman Is Buying Stake in a Troubled Student-Loan Company
description: Goldman Sachs on Friday agreed to buy a $260.5 million stake in the First Marblehead Corporation, shoring up the troubled student-loan company and sending its stock soaring.

title: Punitive Arizona
description: To the Editor:

title: Vermont Rejects Sale of Verizon Lines
description: MONTPELIER, Vt. (AP)  Vermont regulators on Friday rejected a $2.7 billion plan by FairPoint Communications to buy Verizons landlines in northern New England.

title: No Joke, Bulb Change Is Challenge for U.S.
description: The new energy bill signed this week makes it official. When 2012 hits, stores can no longer sell the cheap but inefficient incandescent light bulbs that are fixtures in most homes.

title: Frank Capra Jr., Movie and TV Producer, Dies at 73
description: Frank Capra Jr., who never wanted to go into his fathers business but found in the end he could not resist its pull, died on Wednesday in Philadelphia. He was 73 and lived in Wilmington, N.C.

title: Saudi Arabia: Officials Say They Foiled Plot Against Holy Sites
description: The police arrested a group of men planning to attack holy sites around Mecca during the hajj, the annual Muslim pilgrimage, the Interior Ministry said. The group was arrested three days before the hajj season, said Mansour al-Turki, a spokesman for the ministry. Nearly three million pilgrims went to Saudi Arabia for the hajj, which concluded this week with a final visit to Mecca after days of rituals in the surrounding hills. The minister gave no further details on the number or identity of those arrested, but the Saudi-owned satellite television station Al Arabiya described them as Saudis.

title: Makeover Scrambles City Opera Schedule
description: When the New York State Theater closes next year for renovations, the homeless New York City Opera will probably put on four stripped-down productions at other locations, possibly Carnegie Hall, the Beacon Theater and other Lincoln Center halls, company officials said on Friday.

title: What's Offline: Buy Little, Waste Less
description: A GROUP of environmentally concerned friends in San Francisco got together on Jan. 1, 2006, and decided to flee the consumer grid, vowing not to buy anything new for at least the next 12 months.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The Antiques column in Weekend on Friday, about an exhibition at the Seattle Art Museum, Japan Envisions the West: 16th- to 19th-century Japanese Art From the Kobe City Museum, at one point misspelled the name for Japanese art made in the late 16th and early 17th centuries under the influence of contact with the Spanish and Portuguese. As noted in the headline and elsewhere in the column, it is Namban, not Nambam.

title: Triumph for an Inmate, and a Persistent Investigator
description: Hours after learning that Martin H. Tankleffs conviction for the 1988 murders of his parents had been overturned, Jay Salpeter, a former New York City homicide detective whose work was crucial in winning a new trial for a man imprisoned half his life, was about as ecstatic as a hard-boiled private eye ever gets.

title: A Buyout for Manager of Drug Trials
description: The private equity arm of JPMorgan Chase, One Equity Partners, agreed on Friday to sell its stake in Quintiles Transnational, a big manager of clinical drug trials, to the companys chief executive and other buyout firms.

title: Giuliani, on the Mend, Slows Campaign Pace
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani scaled back his weekend schedule in New Hampshire on Friday as he recovered from the illness that led him to be hospitalized overnight this week for what his aides called flulike symptoms.

title: I.R.S. Bars Investment Strategy Used to Sidestep Rule on Losses
description: The Internal Revenue Service has banned a year-end investment strategy used to get around the so-called wash sale rules on harvesting tax losses.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in some editions on Dec. 10 about a single mother in the Bronx who had trouble finding work and received help from The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund to pay her rent misspelled her given name. She is Idelle Doulin, not Adelle.

title: The Price of Food Safety
description: Americans can be forgiven for wondering if anything these days is safe to eat. Recent food scares have involved such all-American staples as spinach, peanut butter and hamburger meat. A stomach-churning article in The New York Times recently made it clear that some imported seafood, the stuff that is supposed to be good for the heart, can be heavy with pesticides, veterinary antibiotics and other unhealthy extras.

title: Russia to Lend Art
description: One day after announcing that it was canceling plans to lend paintings from its museums to a major exhibition in London, Russia reversed itself after the British government moved up the date on which legislation protecting art from seizure in lawsuits would become effective, The Associated Press reported. The exhibition, From Russia: French and Russian Master Paintings 1870-1925, was scheduled to open at the Royal Academy on Jan. 26. But Moscow refused to lend major French and Russian paintings out of concern that they might be held. (Above, Kuzma Petrov Vodkins 1912 work Bathing of a Red Horse.) Among the paintings to be shown were prominent Impressionist and Post-Impressionist works, which descendants of some Russian collectors claim were taken by the new government after the Bolshevik Revolution in 1917. James Purnell, head of the British Culture Department, said on Thursday that Britain would move up, to early January from late February, the effective date of a provision in legislation that bars the seizure of art lent on a government-to-government basis. Natalia Uvarova, a spokeswoman for Russias federal culture agency, said that her office would issue licenses for the paintings only after the law takes effect, which means that the Russian works, now in Dusseldorf, Germany, will return to Moscow instead of continuing on to London, she said. It was up to the organizers of the London exhibition, Ms. Uvarova added, to decide whether the paintings could be shipped quickly enough for the show to open as scheduled on Jan. 26.

title: Romney Learns That Facts Are Stubborn Things
description: FORT DODGE, Iowa  There was the period last spring when Mitt Romney claimed while campaigning in Iowa and New Hampshire that he had been a hunter pretty much all my life, only to have to admit later he had seriously hunted on only two occasions.

title: Accused Doctor Gets His Visa Back
description: An Indian doctor once accused of involvement with terrorist bombers in Britain was given back his Australian visa, in the latest chapter in a case that has embarrassed the police, prosecutors and the government. The high court in Melbourne rejected an appeal by Kevin Andrews, the former immigration minister, to stop the reinstatement of the visa for the doctor, Mohammed Haneef. Dr. Haneefs lawyer, Peter Russo, said his client wanted to return to his old job as a hospital registrar. Dr. Haneef was arrested on July 2 in Brisbane, two days after a distant cousin, Kafeel Ahmed, had crashed a burning Jeep Cherokee into the main terminal at Glasgows international airport. Prosecutors said Mr. Ahmed, who later died of burns, had also helped plant two car bombs in central London. On July 27, the charge against Dr. Haneef was dropped, and Australias chief prosecutor admitted that prosecutors had made erroneous statements in court.

title: Alan Wagner, 76, First President of the Disney Channel, Is Dead
description: Alan Wagner, a former CBS programming executive who became the first president of the Disney Channel, died on Tuesday in Manhattan, where he lived. He was 76.

title: Fernandez and Rose Jr. Are Linked to Radomski
description: A chubby left-handed pitcher with an awkward delivery and the son of a banned baseball legend became the last two players of note linked to Kirk Radomski, a former Mets clubhouse attendant who provided dozens of major league players with performance-enhancing drugs.

title: The High Cost of Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Rookie Helps Isles Hold Off Penguins
description: PITTSBURGH (AP)  Blake Comeau scored his first career goal to give the Islanders the lead midway through the third period Friday night, Trent Hunter added a goal 37 seconds later and the Islanders shook off a recent slump to beat the Pittsburgh Penguins, 4-2.

title: In Trade Ruling, Antigua Wins a Right to Piracy
description: PARIS  In an unusual ruling on Friday at the World Trade Organization, the Caribbean nation of Antigua won the right to violate copyright protections on goods like films and music from the United States  an award worth up to $21 million  as part of a dispute between the countries over online gambling.

title: Pennington and Coles Share a Bond That Extends Beyond the Field
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y.  The quarterback grew up in Knoxville, Tenn., the son of a high school football coach. He speaks carefully and evenly. A mop of sandy brown hair flows from underneath his baseball cap.

title: Weakening Pakistan
description: Pakistans president, Pervez Musharraf, insists his outrageous power grabs are aimed at stabilizing and protecting his country. His authoritarian maneuvers only weaken the countrys already feeble political institutions and fuel more political turmoil.

title: Peters Is Making a Name for Himself
description: ORCHARD PARK, N.Y.  At 6 feet 4 inches and 340 pounds, Jason Peters would seem to be a hard guy not to notice, particularly for N.F.L. coaches. After all, he ran the 40-yard dash in 4.94 seconds, blazing fast for a man his size.

title: In Racially Charged Manslaughter Trial, Jury Sends Messages of Discord
description: The Long Island jury hearing the manslaughter trial of a black man charged with shooting a white teenager last year sent the judge several notes on Friday, saying it was hopelessly deadlocked and asking to hear the jurors oath again because some jurors arent interpreting the law as stated in our directions.

title: Bonds Will Keep Lawyers, Despite Potential Conflicts
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A soft-spoken Barry Bonds told a federal judge Friday that he wanted to keep his legal team intact despite a potential conflict of interest.

title: Lottery Numbers
Israel: Army Denies Role in Hamas Death
description: A 17-year-old Hamas fighter was shot to death in Gaza near the border with Israel, but the Israeli Army denied that it had anything to do with it. Hamas said the fighter, identified as Awad al-Foujom, died in a gun battle with Israeli forces. Nearly 20 Palestinian fighters have been killed this week, most of them from Islamic Jihad. Near Nablus, in the occupied West Bank, a Palestinian was stopped at the Hawara checkpoint trying to smuggle a mortar shell; the previous day, another Palestinian tried to stab an Israeli soldier there, the army said.

title: From an Asylum, Dark Tidings of Hope
description: The Italian avant-gardist Dario DAmbrosi has been establishing a new downtown theater holiday tradition: Christmas in the madhouse.

title: A Life of Helping Becomes One in Need of Help
description: This was life, until Susan Barron crossed Second Avenue on a Saturday morning two and a half months ago: an apartment on the East Side of Manhattan, where she has lived for decades. A fat Scottish terrier that she doted on. A psychology practice treating people with physical disabilities, offering scholarships to patients who could not pay full fees.

title: Jailed 17 Years, Long Island Man Gets Second Trial
description: A state appeals court on Friday overturned the conviction of a Long Island man imprisoned 17 years for the grisly murders of his parents in 1988. The decision cited the cumulative effect of new witnesses and extensive new evidence that have emerged in recent years, pointing to other suspects as the real killers.

description: An article on Dec. 5 about the distinctions between Irans civilian and military nuclear programs referred incorrectly to an assessment in the new United States national intelligence estimate that Tehrans nuclear program is now entirely civilian in nature. The document says that American intelligence agencies have moderate  not high  confidence in that judgment.

title: China Less Willing to Be Americas Piggy Bank
description: For the last three years, China has been the financier that kept the American government well funded. In 2004, it bought a fifth of the Treasury securities issued, a proportion that rose to 30 percent in 2005 and to 36 percent in 2006.

title: As Cars Hit More Animals on Roads, Toll Rises
description: BOZEMAN, Mont.  On a dark highway near Anchorage, Specialist Steven Cavanaugh of the Army, who had survived 300 missions in Iraq, was critically injured in December when his vehicle hit a moose. Specialist Cavanaugh died Dec. 6.

description: To the Editor:

description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, Democrat of New York, began running the following new 30-second advertisement in New Hampshire on Thursday and in Iowa on Friday.

title: Bail Is Set at $1 Million for Husband in Slaying
description: WHITE PLAINS  Shortly after a county court judge set bail at $1 million for a disbarred Chappaqua lawyer charged with murdering his wife, the Westchester County district attorney asserted on Friday that the defendant, Carlos Perez-Olivo, pulled their car over on a darkened road 13 months ago and shot his wife once in the back of the head.
