description: Singers Former Condo Goes Platinum

title: American Takes Overall Lead
description: Lindsey Vonn of the United States moved to the top of the womens World Cup overall standings by winning her second consecutive event, a super-combined Saturday in St. Anton Am Arlberg, Austria.Her teammate Julia Mancuso was third for the second straight race.Vonn, who won the downhill Friday, was the leader after the downhill leg of the combined. She retained the lead with her slalom run and had a total time of 2 minutes 20.28 seconds. She has three World Cup victories this season.Maria Riesch of Germany took second, 0.63 seconds back, and Mancuso was 0.65 behind.Vonn, who had been fourth in the standings, took the lead with 474 points, ahead of Nicole Hosp of Austria (419) and Riesch (389). Mancuso was sixth (364).

title: How Ugly? Put a Bag on That Car
description: I ALWAYS wanted to own a dream car, said Andy Saunders, 44, who has a flair for customizing cars. But others had already bought all the dream cars.

title: Santa? Dont Be Silly. But Still ...
description: MY husband, Frank, and I had been waiting for The Question for a few years already, and while our son Sean may have thought of it a year or two before he finally asked it, he did not bring it up until he was nearly 10.

title: Rich Legacy of an Artist of the Rails
description: MOST mornings over the last decade, after a long, dark night underground working on the subway tracks, Marvin Franklin would ride the F train to the end of the line and make his way to his home in St. Albans, Queens. He would then regroup, turn around and ride back into Manhattan for three hours of art classes.

title: Jets vs. Titans
description: Vince Young

title: Champagne Beyond the Big Names
description: WHEN it comes to Champagne, are you a slave to fashion?

title: A Tiny Brain for Your Tire
description: KEEPING track of tires is no problem for most motorists, even if they own more than one car and switch between sets of winter and summer treads. But for commercial fleets that operate hundreds of trucks with 18 tires each, knowing the history and location of individual tires is more pressing.

title: Savior or Saboteur?
description: WASHINGTON

title: Homer Nods Again
description: Do you get a kick out of watching a Bigfoot columnist grovel? A few kindly souls dont give a tuppence for comeuppance, but the stern legion of the Nit-pickers League looks forward to this column all year. (The League was split for decades in a fight between Nit-pickers and Nit-pickers, which they finally resolved by eliminating the apostrophe altogether. The elite squad of its Gotcha! Gang is still at odds over the inclusion of their exclamation point.)

title: High Scores for the Games of 2007
description: FOR gamers 2006 was all about the introduction of Sonys PlayStation 3 and Nintendos Wii systems; there werent many great games released. This year, by contrast, has delivered one fabulous interactive entertainment experience after another. Even without Grand Theft Auto IV, which was delayed until next year, 2007 has witnessed the strongest lineup of new games since the fall of 2004, when Halo 2, Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas, and World of Warcraft were introduced.

title: 1958: Eggnog
description: Eggnogs have long been a Times recipe staple. An 1895 article on Christmas-food traditions noted that Americans eat more lightly than the English throughout the season. The only exception, the writer added, is eggnogg, a mixture of eggs, milk, sugar, spices, rum, brandy and  headache. This beverage, however, has lately fallen somewhat out of favor. Either our stomachs have grown weaker or our brains stronger, and we are not willing to sacrifice future well-being for the sake of a momentary gratification, even though sanctioned by the precept and example of our ancestors. Well, pooh-pooh!

title: A Very Busy Year for Passing Batons
description: THEY usually make no sound, at least in concert. Too much talking in rehearsal often works against them. When they are at their best, explanations of success often dissolve into words like chemistry and charisma. At their worst, they are called dictators or just superfluous.

title: Robots, Lies and Smoking for $800, Alex
description: FORD MOTOR COMPANY suffered the Edsel, United Artists wobbled under the crushing failure of Heavens Gate, and then there was John From Cincinnati. That belly-flop cost HBO momentum it could ill afford after the end of The Sopranos, but luckily other networks  some cable, some not  stepped in to fill the gap. And the writers strike, which threatens to last well into 2008, enhances what was so good about the best-scripted shows of the year.

title: Tony Wasnt Whacked, but What About HBO?
description: THE scene of the year in television was 10 seconds of black screen.

title: Two Projects Claim Street Savvy
description: The In the Region article in New Jersey copies on Dec. 9 about street design within two new housing complexes in Jersey City referred incorrectly to two train stops. A train stop near the Liberty Harbor development provides access to the Hudson-Bergen Light Rail system  not the PATH system  and is at Jersey Avenue. (There is no Avenue B.) A PATH stop within walking distance of the Hamilton Square development is called the Grove Street station. (There is no Seventh Street station.)

title: Masterpieces Lost, Masterpieces Found
description: IF you havent already, it might be time to get out a flashlight and take another look at that dusty old oil painting of your great-uncles that youve been using as a vent cover down in the basement. And just in case, jot down the numbers for Sothebys and Christies.

title: In the Age of Noah
description: Jakarta, Indonesia

title: The Angels of 191st Street
description: THE morning before Thanksgiving, Lisa Donath was waiting for the No. 1 train at 191st Street in Washington Heights when she was overcome by dizziness. She leaned against a pillar, and the next thing she knew, she was being dragged across the subway platform by what felt like many people at once. She thought she had been mugged.

title: When the Ground Is Up
description: Q I recently moved into a brand-new house in a development in Queens. Most houses have the electrical outlets positioned with the opening for the ground pin below and the openings for the two flat prongs above that. But in my house, all the electrical outlets have the ground-pin opening above the opening for the two prongs.

title: All We Are Saying
description: NEW words are most happily received when they arrive without fanfare. When they appear with ta-da! or look what I did! and are touted as clever or cute, they feel like impositions on our time. We resent that they exist mostly to exalt their makers.

title: Electricity Bills Likely to Soar in South River
description: SOUTH RIVER

title: Walker in the City
description: In 1934, the English writer Laurie Lee set out to walk to London from his home in Gloucestershire, in the southwest of England. In As I Walked Out One Midsummer Morning, he noted how lucky he was to have begun his journey when he did, before the landscape had been bulldozed for speed. By the time his book was published, 35 years later, the automobile had cut the landscape to pieces, through which the hunched-up traveler races at gutter height, seeing less than a dog in a ditch. Another generation later, the landscape has been not just bulldozed but graded and paved and painted for speed, and we are all dogs in ditches.

title: A Place Called SEE-Me Looks at the East End
description: BRIDGEHAMPTON

title: Letters: The Web Users Campaign
description: Howard Deans loss in 2004 stemmed from his inability to translate his Internet riches into an effective broadcast message (Matt Bai, Dec. 9). This suggests that the balance of power in contemporary elections remains with the mass media. To take another prominent example, the George Allen macaca episode does not demonstrate the power of YouTube but the ability of traditional media gatekeepers to capitalize on new technology. And events beyond the candidates control have always influenced elections. While the Internet has proved to be a valuable fund-raising and organizational tool, mass advertising still wins the day. Does anyone expect Ron Paul to win the Republican nomination?

title: How to Avoid Recession? Let the Fed Work
description: THE economy is teetering on the edge. Many economists, as well as online betting sites, put the risk of recession next year at about 50 percent. Once we get the final numbers, we might even learn that a recession has already begun.

title: Letters: Issues for Real People
description: To the Editor: Why doesnt The New York Times print an article on the 53 coolest backpacker destinations, where you can stay for under $10, eat a decent meal for $3 and sit around a funky common room and chat with fellow travelers about real issues involving real people?

title: Every Generation Makes Its Own Mark
description: BEING a choreographer in New York isnt easy. Theres the constant struggle for money and studio time, as well as the typical, disheartening four-day run after months of rehearsing. So its a testament to a select group of New York artists that 2007 brought vibrant dance from a multitude of generations. By decade:

title: Serbia Enlists Some Unlikely Faces in Its Quest to Keep Kosovo
description: BELGRADE, Serbia  As the dispute over Kosovos future nears a climax, the Serbian government has enlisted the support of some the worlds best known statesmen  all of them dead.

title: Who Moved My Glacier?
description: Glacier Peak Wilderness Area, Wash.

title: Letting the Post Office Sort a Co-ops Mail
description: Q The mail delivered to my co-op, which has more than 300 apartments, is sorted by the concierge staff, which spends much of the day accomplishing this task. The board is hoping to install lockable mailboxes and thus transfer the all the responsibility for the mail to the Postal Service.

title: Rachel Silbiger, Evan Goren
description: Rachel F. Silbiger, a daughter of Naomi and Morry Silbiger of Ardsley, N.Y., is to be married Sunday afternoon to Dr. Evan Matthew Goren, a son of Jody and Mark Goren of Rockville, Md. Rabbi David Holtz is to officiate at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Spare Spaces, Bare Bulbs, Wonderful Works
description: CREATING a dance piece takes money, bodies, time and space. Since the last three imply the existence of the first, none of them are easy for choreographers in the United States to come by. But a number of pieces over the last few months employed a bare minimum of means to produce thrilling works that show how dance can powerfully focus attention on the essentials: the body, movement, human existence in a mysterious and unknowable world.

title: Opening Our Eyes to Slavery
description: However capably federal lawyers may have prosecuted the case against Varsha and Mahender Sabhnani, who were convicted last week of enslaving and torturing two Indonesian women in their opulent home in Muttontown, it was certainly not brilliant or aggressive law enforcement that broke the case.

title: Jennie and the Manhattan
description: Jennie and the Manhattan

title: In Ending Executions, Soul Searching
description: TRENTON

title: The Clinton Referendum
description: Winters first storm punished the White Mountains of New Hampshire on the Friday before Thanksgiving, rendering the terrain all but impassable. And yet in Gorham, a small town 50 miles from the Canadian border, hundreds of people shuddered patiently in the snow, in a line that snaked halfway around Gorham Middle-High School, while Secret Service dogs sniffed the gymnasium for bombs. Ive got a lot of people freezing out here, a campaign aide barked into a phone, as if this might make the agents go any faster. When they finally allowed everyone in, a few of the 500 or so folding chairs remained unfilled, but the place was humming with excitement; a teacher near me was saying that this was the biggest thing to happen here since Dwight Eisenhower visited in the 1950s.

title: The African Front
description: One hot, cloudless afternoon in October, I sat in the members salon of the Kenyan Parliament as the guest of Joseph Lekuton, an M.P. from the desolate bush country to the east of Lake Turkana. Around us a dozen other Kenyan politicians sat in comfortable armchairs, sipping tea from silver services and gliding from English to Swahili to tribal languages and back again. The dcor  dark wood paneling, white concrete pillars and a flying-saucer-like brass-and-steel chandelier  suggested both the Soviet Politburo and a Las Vegas lounge in the Rat Pack era. Lekuton (pronounced LEH-koo-tone), an animated man in his late 30s, had dropped by to catch up on developments in the countrys election campaign. On Dec. 27, Kenyans are voting, for the first time since 2002, to choose a new president and Parliament; Lekuton was in the capital raising money and trying to decide whether to throw his lot in with the government coalition or with the main opposition party. (Kenyas parties are fluid, and continuous maneuvering takes place during a campaign season.) Lekuton, a rising political star, was being wooed by both sides, which put his constituents in a state of considerable anxiety. The election, meanwhile, was promising to be the most democratic and unpredictable in Kenyas history: polls showed President Mwai Kibaki slipping behind the challenger, Raila Odinga, a former political prisoner. The prospect of an incumbent president caught in a genuine electoral contest  a nearly unprecedented event in Africa  excited Lekuton. Theres never been anything like this in Kenyan politics, he told me.

title: Austrian Wins Cup Event
description: Stefan Gimpl of Austria won a Big Air snowboarding World Cup event Saturday in Sofia, Bulgaria. Janne Korpi of Finland, the overall standings leader, was second. The competition was on man-made snow under the lights at a square in Sofia, the capital. It was a great evening and a great Christmas present for me and my family, Gimpl said.

title: A Beast in the Jungle
description: In the title essay of a collection published this year, the novelist and critic David Lodge declared 2004 to have been The Year of Henry James. This was because 2004 saw the publication of two major biographical novels about James  The Master, by Colm Toibin, and Lodges own Author, Author  as well as a novel by Alan Hollinghurst, The Line of Beauty, in which the hero is writing a thesis on James. Both Toibins and Lodges novels took as their starting points the facts of Henry Jamess life, and while they shared certain material, each had a distinct focus: Lodge wrote primarily about Jamess involvement in the theater and his friendship with the caricaturist and writer George du

title: A City of Churches Emerges as a Culinary Hub
description: WE searched all over the world for where we could start the kind of restaurant I always wanted to go to, said Jim Carreker, who left his job as a chief executive in Silicon Valley to start the much-lauded gastronome hotel, the Louise, in the Barossa Valley in Australia last year. When we came to Adelaide, we were stunned to discover the area had the best of everything: great wine growing, people who raised good livestock, fantastic fruits and vegetables. Its like the Australian version of Tuscany except we also have extraordinary seafood.

title: What Does $6,500 Buy? A Healthier, Happier Village
description: QARABATUR is a small village nestled on a mountain in Kunduz Province in northern Afghanistan. Like many Afghan villages, it is impossibly remote.

title: Brooklyn Mall Is Oasis and Anomaly
description: Ten, 9, 8, 7, 6 nights before Christmas and Santa is in full effect outside the Nextel store on the Fulton Street Mall. He cranks up the skipping soca rhythm on the backing tape and kicks it to the crowds pouring off the buses and trudging with bulging shopping bags down Brooklyns bustlingest outdoor retail strip.

title: A Shanghai Hotel Goes Green
description: With China and the United States roughly neck-and-neck in greenhouse gas emissions, it only makes sense that the carbon-neutral movement  now an established travel trend in America  has finally penetrated Chinas hospitality industry. This month, Chinas first carbon-neutral hotel is scheduled to open in Shanghai.

title: A Toy Makers Conscience
description: With just a few weeks to go until Christmas, the sensory onslaught inside the Times Square Toys R Us was well into its merciless ratchet upward. The infrastructure of aggression  the indoor Ferris wheel, the roaring animatronic T-rex, the woman who blocks your path as you enter the store to snap a picture of you that another employee will try to sell to you on your way out  was augmented by the holiday tension on the ground: mothers on cellphones, seasonal employees in the stores dark blue shirts pushing carts full of inventory, children banging away at the sample electronics. It seemed as loud as a factory floor; but that is only because most of us cannot imagine how loud a factory floor actually is.

title: Kamsky, the Comeback Kid, Nears Another Shot at the Title
description: The United States has a shot at the world championship again. Gata Kamsky, who lives in Brooklyn, won the World Cup last weekend in Russia, and is one match victory away from the title match.

title: Abolish Earmarks
description: To the Editor:

title: Mourning Many Losses, Rebuilding a Sense of Home
description: Stacks of plastic bags line a wall of Joanne Sawyers front room. From the jumble of her belongings, she pulls out a child-size pink chair, and bursts into tears.

title: Manhattans Year of Building Furiously
description: LETS take a minute to pat ourselves on the backs.

title: A Slow Taxi to Development
description: FOR two decades, a grass-roots effort has been under way in Austin, Tex., to transform the now-shuttered Robert Mueller Municipal Airport into an urban village.

title: The Sound of the New Is Heard All Over
description: NEW music is always plentiful in New York, if you look beyond the New York Philharmonic and the two big opera companies. But even that qualification may change soon. The Met is about to stage Philip Glasss Satyagraha, at long last, and plans for recent works and commissions continue to be dangled. At the New York City Opera, always the more adventurous company, reports of Gerard Mortiers plans involve contemporary scores as well.

title: Intimate Shopping
description: Information, the apostles of cyberspace have been singing for more than a decade, wants to be free. Well, maybe your information does. But in late November, the social networking Web site Facebook discovered that many of its 58 million members dont feel that way. On social networks, people can exchange photos, letters and information with people they know, and friend people they dont. Facebook has grown so big, so rich (its market value is estimated at $15 billion) and so addictive because it offers its users new ways to exchange information and intimacies with people they care about. In early November, Facebooks 23-year-old C.E.O., Mark Zuckerberg, rolled out an advertising program called Beacon. It would track users onto the sites of Facebooks commercial partners  Coca-Cola, the N.B.A., The New York Times and Verizon, among others  and keep their friends posted about what they were doing and buying there.

title: But Does It Have iDrive?
description: DESIGNWORKSUSA, the BMW studio in California that conceives products as well as automobiles, has come up with a new espresso maker for Saeco: its Sirena is being sold for $599 online and at some Starbucks stores.

title: Wish Him Happy Holidays if You Dare
description: Patchogue

title: The Dead and the Naked
description: Chapter 15: No Stone Left Unturned

title: Paperback Row
description: SACRED GAMES, by Vikram Chandra. (Harper Perennial, $16.95.) Chandras sprawling second novel, set in Mumbai, is a thriller, mob saga and police procedural full of sex and violence that also addresses themes like the partition of India and nuclear terrorism. It involves a gang boss who tells his life story (interrupted only briefly by his suicide) and an insomniac Sikh police inspector who investigates him. Paul Gray, our reviewer, called Sacred Games an immense, demanding novel  it is 947 pages long, not counting the glossary of the Hindi words left untranslated in the text  and noted that Chandra is paying homage to both Ian Fleming and James Joyce.

title: Public Schools Say They Want Level Playing Field
description: BERT AMMERMAN watched a football game last month between Don Bosco Prep and Bergen Catholic High School. A top player from each team, he noted, came from the same town about 45 miles away: Vernon.

title: Embracing the Imagery of Childhood
description: First there was the simple collage. Ever since Pablo Picasso thought it might be cool to stick a piece of newspaper onto a painting, artists have been appropriating all kinds of materials, objects and mass-media imagery for their artworks, challenging in the process our ideas and assumptions about art.

title: Austrian Off to Best Start
description: Thomas Morgenstern of Austria won the large-hill event Saturday in Engelberg, Switzerland. He is the first ski jumper to open a World Cup season with six victories in a row. He had jumps of 132.5 and 133.0 meters for 260.4 total points, finishing ahead of his compatriot Andreas Kofler.Morgenstern is tied with Janne Ahonen and Matti Hautamaki, each of Finland, for most consecutive victories at any point in a season. He can claim the record for himself Sunday, in another large-hill event.

title: Treats, in a Home-Cooked Style
description: Kitchen fatigue is a natural phenomenon at this time of year, what with all the obligations of entertaining. Relief from oven duty is available, however, courtesy of Lombardis Bakery, without any loss in home-cooked quality.

title: Atlantis Joins Effort to Save the Reefs
description: If the luxury accommodations of the Reef Atlantis, a 22-story beachfront tower that opened this month at the Atlantis, Paradise Island resort (www.atlantis.com) arent enough to lure you to the Bahamas, then maybe the propertys involvement with coral reef conservation will win you over.

title: In Writers Strike, Actors Turn to Temp Jobs to Make Ends Meet
description: If youre a moviegoer or TV watcher, dont be surprised if you could swear youve seen that face before. That person wrapping your present, selling you a sweater, serving booze at your holiday party or sweating beneath that Santa beard could be an actor.

title: Second Victim of Bronx Shooting Dies
description: A man whose companion was fatally shot outside a Bronx store on Friday died on Saturday morning of wounds suffered in the same shooting, the police said.

title: One for the Money, One for the Art
description: WHO knew that Ben Affleck could direct and Josh Brolin could act? Or that Casey Affleck could act and Johnny Depp could (sort of) sing? Even as the entertainment world splinters into ever-smaller niches, 2007 was a year when stars broke free of their confining boxes, when the most appealing work often came out of nowhere, while big names landed with giant thuds.

title: A Masterful Touch as a Chef Branches Out
description: DAVID DRAKE, both the brains and the brawn behind the impeccable restaurant bearing his name in Rahway, has done it again with Daryl Wine Bar and Restaurant in downtown New Brunswick, which opened in October.

title: Few Big Albums, but Small Ones Sounded Just Fine
description: 1. FEIST: THE REMINDER (Cherry Tree/Interscope). Her modest, beguiling CD is full of carefully composed songs that sound like happy accidents. And even after a ubiquitous iPod commercial, that famous first line  1-2-3-4 tell me that you love me more  still sounds inviting. In a year with shockingly few big albums, Feist made the best small one.

title: The Message Behind a Message Leads to a Series
description: ITS hard to say which tale is more compelling: Marvelous Effect, the first installment in a fantasy book series begun this year by Simon & Schuster, or the back story of its author, Troy Tompkins, 31, who self-published an initial paperback edition and freely admits he used every trick up his sleeve to attract attention to it.

title: The Object of His Obsession
description: Alexander Theroux, the younger of Paul Therouxs two older brothers, is one of Americas premier frotteurs, to use a French term the impeccable James Salter applies to someone who rubs words in his hand. In 99 Novels, Anthony Burgess praises Therouxs second novel, Darconvilles Cat, for being word drunk. And it is. Its a lexiphanic casserole containing nursery rhymes, lists and a pastiche of 18th- and 19th-century British fiction, garnished with such flourishes as gynotikolobomassophile.

title: All That Fizz, for Less
description: Nonvintage Roederer Estate brut, from Anderson Valley in Mendocino County, Calif., is Americas top low-cost sparkling wine. This supple blend of chardonnay and pinot noir enchants Francophiles.

title: Sara Sebrow and Elan Fredman
description: Sara Sebrow, the daughter of Dr. Tova Yellin and Dr. Osher Sebrow, both of Teaneck, N.J., is to be married Sunday to Elan Fredman, a son of Marsha and Shlomo Fredman of Chesterfield, Mo. Rabbi Aaron Winter is to officiate at the Westmount Country Club in West Paterson, N.J.

title: Florida State Missing 34
description: Thirty-four Florida State players will not be going to the Dec. 31 Music City Bowl against Kentucky because of an academic cheating scandal, other violations of team rules or injuries.Linebacker Dekoda Watson, cornerback Patrick Robinson, who had six interceptions, and three top defensive tackles were among the players sidelined either as a result of the investigation into an academic cheating scandal at the university or some other violation of team rules.It is very important that the media make clear that those missing the bowl trip are not included because of either injury or for a violation of team policy, the associate athletic director Rob Wilson said in a statement accompanying the travel list. It would be irresponsible to imply or state that any or all of the student-athletes will miss the trip for one particular reason. The junior quarterback Xavier Lee, who started three games for the Seminoles, was among offensive players not traveling. The offensive line was also hit hard with tackle Caz Piurowski, offensive tackle Damon Rose and guard Jackie Claude not making the trip.A violation of team rules could range from poor class attendance to a run-in with the law or failing a drug test, among many other things.

title: Staged Readings for a Few, Well Fed
description: Fairfield

title: Interrogation Tricks Under Scrutiny After Ruling
description: Lies. Trickery. Deceit. For detectives interrogating murder suspects, they are part of the standard playbook.

title: BROWNS at BENGALS
description: BROWNS at BENGALS

title: A Rsum Cant Buy You Love
description: WE can only imagine what is going on inside John McCains head when he contemplates Mike Huckabee. It cant be pretty. No presidential candidate in either party has more experience in matters of war than the Arizona senator, and yet in a wartime election he is being outpaced by a guy who has zero experience and is proud of it.

title: Knicks Say Benchings Are a Family Matter
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Dysfunction in a sports family is not necessarily a bad thing. At least the Knicks seem to think so. After practice Saturday, Quentin Richardson suggested that a modicum of familial disorder was no reason for concern.

title: As the World Warms
description: Delegates to the recent United Nations climate talks in Bali decided they needed two years to formulate a plan for making deep cuts in global emissions. The earths changing climate seems unlikely to wait. The Op-Ed page asked four writers to report on the weather in their part of the world. Here are their dispatches.

title: Move Quickly on School Aid
description: A long-promised moment has arrived: Gov. Jon Corzine has proposed an important change in the way public schools are financed, a change that would benefit disadvantaged children who do not live in the states 31 designated special-needs districts. Whats more, the new formula addresses complaints that state spending on special-needs districts has shortchanged other districts, leading to burdensome property tax increases.

title: Increase the States Share of Education Expenses (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction: On Long Island, Fatalities in an Age Range Are Flat After Law
description: An article on Dec. 9 about restrictions on teenage drivers in Suffolk and Nassau Counties referred incompletely to the rules for driving to school alone. Although students with junior licenses may drive to classes in a registered evening high school, they cannot drive alone to day classes in high school. (They can drive alone to college classes anytime.)

title: Big Bucks and Big Shots
description: MONEY, money, money. The ranks of the superrich are growing, youve probably heard. This year television  good, bad and mediocre  found itself obsessed with big shots, big bucks and the arduous climb up the class ladder. So lets hoist a glass, have some fun and raise some fury.

title: Understated Elegance at a Low-Key Italian
description: PIERANGELO in Greenwich is not your usual mom-and-pop neighborhood Italian restaurant. Not even close.

title: Three Museums Seek Answers to Tough Questions
description: EVEN as some cultural organizations turned the page this year, opening new buildings (the New Museum of Contemporary Art on the Bowery, for example) or shifting strategies (Asia Society plans to build a contemporary art collection), others are in transition. Having backed out of an expansion of its Marcel Breuer building on Madison Avenue in 2006, the Whitney Museum of American Art says it is close to releasing a design by Renzo Piano for a new downtown site at the entrance to the High Line, the abandoned West Side elevated railway that is to become a park. But the museums financial ability to sustain both sites is an open question.

title: Boston: Liberty Hotel
description: THE BASICS

title: Helping Kids Thrive at School and at Home (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Capital Ideas and Social Goals
description: SINCE 2001, Lee Zimmermans Evergreen Lodge has helped almost 60 low-income young adults get their lives on track, while consistently paying 9 percent back to investors backing his business. Pura Vida Coffee, of which John Sage was a co-founder in 1997, has generated $2.7 million in cash and resources for health and education programs for children and their families.

title: Stacy Mehrfar and Gavin Caganoff
description: Stacy Arezou Mehrfar, the daughter of Nadreh Mehrfar and Dr. Manocher Mehrfar of Great Neck, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Gavin Nathan Caganoff, the son of Linda Caganoff and Solomon S. Caganoff of Sydney, Australia. Rabbi Dale Polakoff performed the ceremony at Temple Israel of Great Neck.

title: Julia Boorstin and Couper Samuelson
description: IT is a truth not universally acknowledged that a single man who meets his wife-to-be at the Sundance Film Festival is likely to make his proposal of marriage a cinematic one.

title: Labor Board Restricts Union Use of E-Mail
description: The National Labor Relations Board has ruled that employers have the right to prohibit workers from using the companys e-mail system to send out union-related messages, a decision that could hamper communications between labor unions and their membership.

title: Some Parents Seek Options to Vaccine Orders
description: CONCERNED about possible side effects of vaccines and an ingredient they contain, some New Jersey parents are investigating ways to opt out of the shots, four more of which will be required of public school students beginning next fall.

title: Corrections: Before It Disappears
description: An article last Sunday about travelers who seek destinations that they think are ecologically endangered misspelled the surname of the editor in chief of Travel & Leisure. She is Nancy Novogrod, not Novograd.

title: Atp Suspends Two
description: The ATP suspended the Italians Potito Starace and Daniele Bracciali Saturday for making bets  some as little as $7  on tennis matches involving other players.The Italian federation denounced the penalties by the governing body as an injustice, and the players said they have been made scapegoats.Starace, ranked 31st, was suspended for six weeks and fined $30,000, the federation said. Bracciali, ranked 258th, was banned for three months and fined $20,000. Both suspensions take effect Jan. 1.The federation said Starace made five bets for a total of $130 two years ago, and Bracciali made about 50 bets of $7 each from 2004 through 2005.

title: Letters: 7th Annual Year in Ideas
description: Isnt it strange how at a time (heightened by the holidays) when many of us are trying to avoid family members we already know, people are searching via the Internet for DNA connectivity? (Zygotic Social Networking, Malia Wollan, Dec. 9).

title: Enough of the Hills and Woods, Can I Send Grandma an E-Card?
description: NO pressure, but spill it: How much do you love your family?

title: Calendar of Events
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com

title: Holiday on Thin Ice
description: THE director Judd Apatow and the actress Leslie Mann have been married for more than 10 years. The following is a transcript of an argument they have two or three times a year, or whenever presents need to be given. This conflict will never be resolved.

title: Blair, a Regular at Mass, Is Now Catholic
description: LONDON  Six months after stepping down as Britains prime minister, Tony Blair has completed his long-expected conversion to Roman Catholicism from Britains established church, Anglicanism, Catholics officials said in a statement on Saturday.

title: Letters to the Editors
description: Diminished, Not Enhanced

title: Berlins Tempelhof to Close Next Year
description: The crescent-shaped Tempelhof Airport in Berlin, one of the few examples of Nazi-era architecture that still exists  and described by the British architect Norman Foster as the mother of all airports  is scheduled to close next fall.

title: The Tax Loss as Consolation Prize
description: WITH only a few days left in the calendar year, uncertainties abound for tax-conscious investors.

title: The Nike Air Force 1 Sneaker Turns 25 Years Old
description: In 1982, Nike released the Air Force 1, a basketball shoe that featured a revolutionary technological innovation: a pocket of air in the heel for cushioning and support. The shoe, although expensive at $89.95, was an immediate hit among players, from the N.B.A. to the playground, with professionals like Moses Malone and Michael Cooper endorsing them and wearing them during games.

title: The Wrap-Up
description: As the style diaries of 2007 draw to a close and the fashionable set prepares for one last night on the town, the focus is on evening coats. The latest burgeoning retail category, glamorous (albeit none-too-warm) coats made of brocade, taffeta, satin and fistfuls of crystals are adding one final lavish touch to the year.

title: Sleeping With the Enemy
description: Imagine, if you care to, a high school stage packed with fresh-scrubbed Oklahoma teenagers, shrilly belting out a ballad of tribute to a woman of mystery whose passions they cant conceive, whose name they can scarcely pronounce: Mata Hari, Mata Hari  oh what a wicked girl was she! Thats the kind of girl Ill never be! What were her crimes? Mata Hari had a very wicked reputation. She was willing to be thrilling for her information. These may be scandalous charges in Oklahoma, but was Mata Hari really so wicked?

title: The Sweater Only a Mom (and Analyst) Could Love
description: I LOVE giving gifts, but lets not pretend: I prefer to receive them. Unfortunately, Im one of those people who is never satisfied and mostly disappointed. It could be because I am an ungrateful jerk with a childish temperament who places too much emphasis on what is essentially a symbolic ritual. Or it could be the medias fault.

title: Calendar of Events
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Cultural Calendar, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018.

title: News Corporation Sells 8 TV Stations
description: The News Corporation, the media company controlled by Rupert Murdoch, agreed to sell eight Fox network-affiliated television stations in the United States to Oak Hill Capital Partners for about $1.1 billion.

title: Of Radiohead and Rehab, 1234 and Calle 13
description: 1. RADIOHEAD: IN RAINBOWS (ATO). While Radioheads discontinued pay-what-you-want proposition for downloading its new album made a great music-business story, the more lasting news is that In Rainbows  in either its one-disc or two-disc configurations  needs no gimmicks. The songs sound tuneful and modest, often pared down to just a handful of instruments. But they work up knotty structures and plunge into a troubled mind-set where nothing is secure: not relationships, businesses, identities or song forms.

title: My Mothers Home
description: IN 1928 my grandparents built a summer house in northwestern Connecticut, on a wooded hillside overlooking a small lake. Trees cluster closely about its dark rough clapboards and massive chimneys; a stone porch looks out toward the water. Its a refuge, knitted smoothly into the natural world around it.

title: Retired With High Taxes? Heres an Idea
description: GREENBURGH

title: In a Force for Iraqi Calm, Seeds of Conflict
description: BAGHDAD  The thin teenage boy rushed up to the patrol of American soldiers walking through Dora, a shrapnel-scarred neighborhood of the capital, and lifted his shirt to show them a mass of red welts across his back.

title: Bold Performances, Bolder Audiences
description: IN May the French pianist Pierre- Laurent Aimard ended his Carnegie Hall Perspectives series with an eclectic program at Zankel Hall, Collages-Montages. Mixing and matching short pieces or excerpts from longer ones (46 in all) he created an evening-length patchwork composition that leapt across centuries and defied stylistic categories.

title: Playing Fair at Divorce, Cheating on the Other Stuff
description: HE HAD IT COMING

title: An Audition on a Global Stage
description: For the blue-chip prospects who will compete at the world junior championship, which begins Wednesday in the Czech Republic, a defining moment awaits. The tournament, for players younger than 20, offers the closest approximation of the intensity of the N.H.L. playoffs.

title: Other Voices: T, Art and Times Standards
description: Re A Semi-Nude Minor? In The Times? (Dec. 16):

title: Correction: Calendar of Events, New Jersey
description: A picture caption on Dec. 9 about performances of the musical Annie at the State Theater in New Brunswick misstated the surname of the actor shown playing Daddy Warbucks. It is Barton, not Baron.

title: Uninvited Guests, and the Hope That They Wont Stay
description: ONE evening in late September, a contractor named Michael Tubridy was relaxing in his boat on Jamaica Bay when he saw a tug pulling a derelict-looking barge. The barge was covered with old tires and rusted pipes, and grass grew on its deck. Two pumps worked furiously to keep it afloat.

title: Ode to Joylessness: Hold That Yule Log
description: BEING green is not so easy, unless youre a Martian or something. It seems everything you do to try to save the planet has unforeseen effects.

title: Correction: A Shift, but for Some Drivers, a Vicious Circle
description: An article on Nov. 25 about the use of roundabouts as a solution to traffic problems misstated the branch of government that financed and built a roundabout on Route 520 at the entrance to Brookdale Community College in Lincroft. It was Monmouth County, not the state.

title: Where War Stories Come Alive
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J.

title: Cookies and Birdseed
description: As we pull up after a five-hour drive from Maine for Christmas at my parents house in Connecticut, my husband and I notice that their car is not in the driveway. Thats unusual for my mom and dad, who are both in their 80s. They stopped coming North a few years ago after episodes involving forgotten medications and midnight visits to the emergency room. Ive baked pies and cookies according to recipes that I got from my mom, which she got from her mom, back so far in time that amounts are in pounds and pecks. My oldest, Kelly, has flown East to come with us. Her teenage sister, Hannah, is looking forward to seeing her grandparents. Holiday meals used to include about 20 relatives; every table in the house was brought into the dining room. Tonight it will be my parents, my brother and my family.

title: The Unmaking of a Technophobe
description: LAST December, I bought a television set, my first ever as an adult. I was, in the terms of the classic studies on the diffusion of innovation in the 1950s, a very late adopter, or laggard.

title: A Jazzmans Farewell and a Rock Manifesto
description: 1. MICHAEL BRECKER: PILGRIMAGE (Heads Up). The intensely focused final album by the tenor saxophonist Michael Brecker galvanizes a dream team of jazz modernists, including the guitarist Pat Metheny and the pianists Herbie Hancock and Brad Mehldau. They all rise thrillingly to the occasion, but somehow its the ailing Mr. Brecker who makes it sound easy.

description: Previously recorded $3,664,828

title: Tattered Standard of Duty on Wall Street
description: WITHOUT trust, there can be no free-market capitalism. Capitalism took root in Europe when wealthy families had excess income to invest, and they entrusted their money to managers who would treat their funds with due care.

title: Bell Labs Is Gone. Academia Steps In.
description: A headline last Sunday with the Ping column, about research partnerships between universities and corporations, referred incorrectly to the status of Bell Labs. Although it is no longer part of AT&T, it has not been discontinued; it is now the research arm of Alcatel-Lucent. The column also misspelled the surname of the president of Arizona State University, who said that universities roles in such partnerships would evolve in coming decades. He is Michael Crow, not Crowe.

title: Prometheus Bound?
description: Like the Rockefeller Center Christmas tree, which was first lighted in 1933, these nearby restaurants have stood the test of time.

title: Correction
description: A review on Dec. 9 about Touch and Go, a memoir by Studs Terkel with Sydney Lewis, misstated the first name of the author of the poem Richard Cory, which Terkel cites at one point. He was Edwin Arlington Robinson, not Edward.

title: What Do You Mean, Giving Me That?
description: HERE is a formative moment from the life of a writer, at the long ago age of 5. It is Christmas. There is a fir hung with metallic icicles, a fleecy snow blanket wrapped around its base. On the fake snow blanket are piled many shiny boxes, and several of them are his.

title: Outlet for Exclusivity
description: True Religion Outlet Jeans

title: Stopping at 10 Just Seems Wrong
description: BY the end of next week, the number of movies reviewed in The New York Times in 2007 will top out somewhere around 640. The traditions of movie criticism decree that I select 10 as the years most worthy candidates for immortality (or at least future Netflix rental). Everyone knows that this is an arbitrary and subjective exercise  thats part of the fun of it  but this year Ive found it especially difficult to commit to so narrow and exclusive a list.

title: Few Feel a Need to Walk and Surf at the Same Time
description: Access to the world in your purse or your pocket  that is what technology companies promised when they added Internet capability to cellphones. But the fact remains that a vast majority of cellphone owners are not taking advantage of this on-the-go technology, even though it is available to most of them.

title: Bye-Bye, Bohemia
description: IF you are one of those who brim with nostalgia for the storied Lower East Side, with its grubby soul and vaunted pickle vendors, you might want to stop reading now, before you read too much about yet one more velvet-rope nightclub joining the neighborhood.

title: Even for an Ancient People, Theres Always Saturday Night
description: THE dancing at Ali Baba restaurant in Fresh Meadows, Queens, began before dinner was served. A tuxedo-clad D.J. spun earsplitting Middle Eastern melodies set to reggaetn beats. On the dance floor, beneath a bronze chandelier that hung like an upside-down minaret, women in long dresses swung their hips and howled celebratory shrills. Men with their suit jackets removed stretched out their arms and wiggled their shoulders as they shuffled about. Small children spun in place and ran in circles.

title: Letters: Beautiful Bulgaria
description: To the Editor: I was terribly disappointed by your piece "Is Bulgaria Really Skiings Next Hot Spot?" (Dec. 2). Having traveled extensively in Eastern Europe, I can say with great pride that Bulgaria is exquisitely beautiful: one-third of the country is blessed with mountains, the food is superb  delicious cheese and yogurts, foods laced with nuts and garlic, grilled meats, fresh fruit (above)  and, most importantly, it is home to a most hospitable and generous people.

title: Taxes Are Reassessed in Housing Slump
description: LOS ANGELES  Home owners across the nation are looking to county governments to reassess the values of their homes in the face of flattening and falling prices that have befallen scores of markets. Downward assessments, done at the request of homeowners or pre-emptively by government, appear to be most pronounced in areas where the housing market was exploding just a few years ago, or where economic conditions are poorest.

title: Where Boys Were Kings, a Shift Toward Baby Girls
description: SEOUL, South Korea  When Park He-ran was a young mother, other women would approach her to ask what her secret was. She had given birth to three boys in a row at a time when South Korean women considered it their paramount duty to bear a son.

title: Calendar of Events
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in around Nassau and Suffolk Counties. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018.

title: Garcia Returns to Haunt 49ers
description: During his time as the quarterback in San Francisco, Jeff Garcia set about writing his name into the record books of the 49ers, a team that has featured Y. A. Tittle, John Brodie, Joe Montana and Steve Young. In 2000, Garcia set team records for completions (355) and passing yards (4,278) in a season, and his 32 touchdown passes in 2001 were the third most in team history.

title: Letters: The New, New Philosophy
description: I share Kwame Anthony Appiahs (Dec. 9) sense that whatever encourages any of us  philosophers and nonphilosophers alike  to accurately judge the weight of our own intuitions is not to be lightly dismissed. It is puzzling, however, that Appiah explicitly demurs from the claim that the contributions of the x-phi movement have anything essential to do with the experiments. Those who know the old joke about the man who ordered a cherry soda, hold the cherry syrup, may have suffered a bout of dj vu while reading Appiahs remarks. For if the best work in experimental philosophy would be valuable and suggestive even if it skipped the actual experiments, then the best work in experimental philosophy is actually just the philosophy.

title: In Defense of Town Houses
description: To the Editor:

title: Inside the List
description: DARK MATTER: The British writer Philip Pullman isnt exactly a come-from-nowhere phenomenon  his giddy fantasy series His Dark Materials has sold millions of copies worldwide and garnered praise from critics for years. In 2002, Margo Jefferson rhapsodized about the series in an essay for The Times, headlined Harry Potter for Grown-Ups: War, politics, magic, science, individual lives and cosmic destinies are all here. They are not flung together, they are shaped and assembled into a narrative of tremendous pace by a man with a generous, precise intelligence. Similarly, when Christopher Hitchens reviewed the final Harry Potter book for us this summer, he urged bereft muggles to graduate to Pullman. But the books didnt crack our best-seller list until last week, when they finally landed on the childrens series list at No. 4, thanks to the movie version of The Golden Compass, the first novel in the trilogy. Critical acclaim is nice and all, but when it comes to selling books in America, a few things are evidently nicer: Nicole Kidmans face, a Hollywood marketing budget and a healthy dollop of religious controversy. This week, His Dark Materials jumps to No. 1 on the series list.

title: Devotion in Its Various Homes
description: MACYS SANTALAND and the tree at Rockefeller Center notwithstanding, many New Yorkers are not celebrating Christmas. In addition to our sizable humbug community, they include Jews, Muslims, Hindus and members of just about any other non-yuletide-caroling religion you can think of. (Not to mention atheists.)

title: A Greek Newcomer With a City Touch
description: ON Long Island, a Greek restaurant is still usually an inexpensive storefront specializing in gyros and huge salads. However, the upscale places selling fish by the pound that have become popular in Manhattan are slowly starting to make their mark on the Island. Trata East arrived in Water Mill last year, and now Ethos, which opened in early November, is turning heads in Great Neck.

description: To the Editor:

title: We Must Stop Failing Our Children
description: Researchers at Haskins Laboratories in New Haven say that 95 percent of all children can learn to read relatively easily, regardless of whether they are rich or poor, bright or burdened with a low I.Q. This is no empty statement; the nonprofit institute has been at the forefront of scientific research on speech, language and literacy for decades.

title: Not Much to Discover, but Quite a Bit to Ponder
description: I HAVE found precious little music to rediscover this year, but several concerts have helped me rediscover other things. If none were significant musical events or, for that matter, very successful, they set me to thinking about bigger matters, and for that I am grateful.

description: With most polls showing that voters believe trade with other countries is hurting the American economy, it is not surprising that there has been a lot of posturing about the perils of trade on the campaign trail.

title: Candidates Trade Criticism Ahead of the Holiday Break
description: PLEASANTVILLE, Iowa  Before pausing for a brief holiday reprieve from a yearlong campaign, the leading presidential candidates on Saturday traded a fresh round of sharp exchanges over experience, campaign tactics and voting records as they worked to solidify support or change the minds of voters in Iowa and New Hampshire.

title: A Much-Loved Home for the Blind Is Leaving Yonkers
description: YONKERS

title: Speech Rules
description: As a former Op Ed columnist for this paper and a longtime voice of liberalism who is now 80 years old, youre about to publish an incisive book on the First Amendment, Freedom for the Thought That We Hate. Why would you write a book about an amendment we already know and love so well? We need to celebrate and understand our unique freedom, and it is unique in this country  this freedom of speech and press. And I dont actually think we understand it well.

title: The Outsiders
description: Several years ago, the British Broadcasting Corporation conducted a public survey to determine the 100 Greatest Britons of all time. When the results came in, they were utterly predictable, an honor roll of long-dead heroes and pop headliners, from Lloyd George to Boy George, from Sir Walter Raleigh to Sir Paul McCartney. The only really interesting thing about it, in light of the current buzz about a new, multicultural Britain, was who was left out: all of the hundred were white.

title: Food Pantries See a Surge in Demand
description: Greenwich

title: Make the Paper Mill a Stop Before Broadway (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Films That Look Death in the Eye
description: THE betrayal of the body, decrepitude and death: in 2007 an unprecedented number of serious films, along with the usual slasher movies, contemplated the end of life. Might they be a collective baby-boom response to looming senescence and a fraying social safety net? Or do they reflect an uneasy sense that humanity is facing end times, when global warming, terrorism, nuclear proliferation and the war in Iraq, or any combination thereof, could bring on doomsday?

title: Lauren Goldfarb and Eric Siskind
description: Lauren R. Goldfarb and Eric J. Siskind are to be married Sunday evening at the Marina Del Rey, a caterer in the Bronx. Rabbi Hershel Schachter is to perform the ceremony.

description: VERNON

title: Father Finds Answers to What Ails Family
description: For families that become homeless in New York City, it is a hard road from shelter back to home. Even after an apartment is found, it must still be turned into a stable home.

title: Tools to Help Disabled Vote Are on Way
description: The citys Board of Elections said on Saturday that it would put devices to allow disabled voters to cast ballots in every polling location by next Septembers Congressional and legislative primaries.

title: Attention Must Be Paid, They Insist
description: SOME 1,700 people poured into the Park Avenue Armory in September to see the visual effects left after 10 motorcycles had raced around the cavernous drill hall over 288 panels of painted plywood. Greeting Card, in which riders wearing Tom Ford sunglasses made colorful, choreographed patterns with their burning tires, was the first contemporary art performance in the armorys 128-year history, and it was a see-and-be-seen event.

title: Soaring Saxophones and American Gothic
description: 1. JOSHUA REDMAN: BACK EAST (Nonesuch). A tenor saxophone-bass-drums trio in jazz means a rugged structural challenge, and possibly an exercise in nostalgia, as it was more or less trademarked and sewed up by Sonny Rollins 50 years ago. But when its done this well, you can forget about all the other things jazz could or should be doing. Here Mr. Redman compresses his goals, leaves distractions behind and makes the most agile and personal record of his career.

title: Holiday Gifts for the Family, and Someday a Car for You
description: CARMAKERS are forever looking for ways to keep customers coming back. They spend hundreds of millions of dollars on advertising. They slash prices. They throw in all sorts of options.

title: Not All the News Was on the Rialto
description: THE shallow pools of limelight trained on theater by the news media these days often exclude everything that happens outside the precincts of Broadway. Accordingly, producers seem to believe that if a show has not opened somewhere in the vicinity of 42nd Street, it hasnt really opened at all.

title: Next Generation: Mineola Wants You
description: CHRIS AND LESLEY AUSTIN grew up on Long Island and had no intention of settling down far from their roots. When they were married in July, they moved into the basement of Ms. Austins parents home in Bellmore.

title: Giulianis Doctor to Provide Update
description: HOPKINTON, N.H.  Rudolph W. Giuliani on Saturday provided the most detailed account yet of the health scare that led to his recent hospitalization, saying that he had suffered a terrible headache but had not blacked out, and that his doctor would update his health condition after Christmas.

title: Democrats Make Bush School Act an Election Issue
description: WASHINGTON  Teachers cheered Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton when she stepped before them last month at an elementary school in Waterloo, Iowa, and said she would end the No Child Left Behind Act because it was just not working.

description: RIVERHEAD

title: Coles Is Placed on Injured List
description: The enduring image of Laveranues Coless season came after the Jets lost to Cleveland on Dec. 9. Coles, a wide receiver, caught seven passes for 48 yards that afternoon. But after taking questions at a news conference, he needed assistance to walk down three steps.

title: With Loss to Baylor, St. Johns Has Work to Do
description: The St. Johns womens program may be making strides, but it is apparently not ready for prime time. Facing a ranked opponent for the first time this season, the Red Storm was no match for No. 11 Baylor on Saturday, losing, 81-58, at Carnesecca Arena.

title: As Earth Warms Up, Tropical Virus Moves to Italy
description: CASTIGLIONE DI CERVIA, Italy  Panic was spreading this August through this tidy village of 2,000 as one person after another fell ill with weeks of high fever, exhaustion and excruciating bone pain, just as most of Italy was enjoying Ferragosto, its most important summer holiday.

title: Despite U.S. Opposition, United Nations Budget Is Approved
description: UNITED NATIONS  The General Assembly approved a two-year budget of $4.17 billion on Saturday, with the United States casting the only vote against the measure because it included financing for a conference the United States felt would be prejudicial to Israel.

description: Darien

title: Pastries That Speak to Adults
description: With its bold red and white crest, the Swiss Chalet Bakery, in downtown Morristown, is likely to summon visions of hot chocolate.

title: Clicking the Way to Mortgage Savings
description: LAST week, the Federal Reserve got around to tightening mortgage lending standards, hoping to eliminate some of the practices that have made borrowing to buy a home so confounding and costly. Many of the Feds changes make sense, especially those that require hidden broker fees to be clearly disclosed and prepayment fees to disappear before a huge rate reset occurs.

description: To the Editor:

title: It All Started With Horses
description: I NEVER expected to run a big company. I like making money, but its not the driving factor in my life. I always wanted to learn new things, and I was never afraid of change. If anything, it was my passion for horses, not a rsum, that eventually pulled me into corporate life.

title: The Trophy Christmas Tree
description: AT 10:30 on a blustery cold Saturday morning three and a half weeks before Christmas, the Jones Family Christmas Tree Farm in Shelton, Conn., is packed with hundreds of cars. Dan and Pam Collins of Rockaway Beach, with their friend Nicole Twomey and a gaggle of children, are already dragging freshly cut evergreens down the wind-whipped hillside that leads from the farms 200 acres of trees.

description: PASADENA, Tex.  Even before the police called the night of Nov. 14, Stephanie Storey said, she knew that her fianc of two days, Miguel Antonio DeJesus, was dead.

title: For a Singer and a Sect: A Rift Amid the Riffs?
description: OVER the last three years, the most visible adherent of the Chabad-Lubavitch sect of Hasidic Judaism has been a strapping 20-something reggae singing star named Matisyahu.

title: Teams Looking for Game Plan to Combat Cold
description: Giants quarterback Eli Manning has a hand muff around his waist, and a little zippered compartment inside holds a disposable warmer. Punter Jeff Feagles has heated insoles to keep his feet warm. Running back Reuben Droughns rubs a homemade concoction he calls hot sauce on his chest. And linebacker Antonio Pierce smears an entire tube of Vaseline all over his body, trying to lock the warmth in his pores. Lubed up, he called it.

title: Some Voices That Might Carry for a While
description: OPERA lovers, myself included, are fond of wringing their hands about the failings of the present generation of singers compared with the great voices of the past. But in 2007, even as we furrow our brows about operas increased focus on the visual at the expense of the vocal, a number of artists offered evidence that the pendulum may be swinging back far enough that more singers understand the part about artistry, and are developing it.

title: Bested by the Brits
description: There is good and bad to the news that Britain surpassed the United States for the first time ever in donations to the World Banks unit to combat world poverty.

title: My Sister, My Surrogate
description: MOHEGAN LAKE, N.Y.

title: The High Price of Parking
description: AFTER years of traffic jams and air pollution, New Yorkers are finally starting to rethink the role of cars in our city. Mayor Michael Bloombergs PlaNYC initiative has suggested programs like congestion pricing, new bike lanes and expanded mass transit. But city policy has not yet addressed a confusing tangle of off-street parking rules that still quietly encourage automobile use. These requirements not only add to congestion and pollution, they also make life in the city more expensive for every New Yorker.

title: Modern Movements, Forever Fresh
description: I THREW away my I  Butoh button last month after some disappointing experiences with that Japanese theater-dance form, celebrated this year in not one but two ambitious festivals. But I cant quite bring myself to ditch my Ohno Lives T-shirt. Kazuo Ohno, a founder of the form, who turned 101 this year, did live onstage and does live in my memory for the harrowing yet antic way he epitomized the physical and psychic decay at the heart of Butoh.

title: Break Up This Merger
description: Anne Milgram, the state attorney general, called it an alarming alliance. That was an understatement. She was referring to evidence that members of the Luchese crime family joined forces with the Bloods street gang to supply prison inmates with drugs and cellphones.

title: Worth the Long Climb
description: IN the fall, when Yael and Eli Hanover planned to move to the Upper West Side to be within walking distance of Mrs. Hanovers new job, real estate agents warned that it would be tough to find large enough rental space that also allowed dogs.

title: Quebecs Panel on Immigrant Relations Adds to Din of Discord
description: MONTREAL  Viewed separately, the incidents seemed relatively insignificant. Members of a Hasidic synagogue here wanted a neighboring Y.M.C.A. to block or tint the windows of an exercise room used by women. A Muslim girl was barred from playing soccer for wearing a hijab on the field. And, in Quebec, some Muslims and Orthodox Jews refused to deal with police officers and physicians of the opposite sex.

description: Heres whats going to happen today in Foxborough, Mass., if National Football League games can be made to bend not to the laws of physics and probability, but to the fevered dreams of middle-aged Miami Dolphins fans.

Now, with the cost of the project skyrocketing, the city finds it needs help.

title: Unhappy Together
description: The comics collected in this book range fairly far and wide, but the strong center of gravity is plaintive tales of everyday life, set in the present, and usually about the social groups that comic artists themselves belong to. The appeal of such work is its emotional directness  in this age of highly branded, executive-produced cultural output, comics promise a more resonant and unadulterated link between creator and reader.

title: Concord Monitor: Not Romney

title: Henry James: The Mature Master
description: He had long lived in the country, in an old brick house on the south coast of England, where atmospheric conditions sometimes produced a quivering mirage of his beloved France, just over the horizon. But now that he had grown old and ill, the dark and solitary country winters were too oppressive to be borne, and he had taken a flat in London, or rather in Chelsea, which was like a little riverside village loosely attached to the metropolis, and where the light, movement, and companionship helped him to ward off the depression that always threatened to descend upon him in the winter. His flat was in a spanking new and bright red-brick building, with an elevator! He had been ill, and the elevator was a wonderful innovation. He who had thought nothing of twenty-mile walks had even allowed little Noakes to push him along the Embankment in a Bath chair, enjoying the sense of space and of passersby, a delicious mixture of privacy and publicity. The flat's windows looked southward over the treetops on the Embankment to the river that flowed past with massive opacity.

title: Foreigners
description: It was a cold December morning, and the bitter wind penetrated my black cloak with ease. However, the stubborn sun continued to shine brightly in the sky, although it failed to bestow any warmth on either myself or the two dozen sombre souls gathered outside of Bolt Court. I glanced about my person, realising that I was part of a bizarre congregation that represented both high and low society, but how could we be anything other than a queer assembly of misfits when one considered the personage who was to be buried on this melancholy English morning?

title: School for Liars Teaches the Dishonesty of Truth and the Truth About Dishonesty

But anyone with a taste for the elusive will find that this smart, audacious work becomes as gripping as a good thriller, which it partially resembles.

A surly woman behind the snack-bar counter glared at Heschel  his yarmulke and white beard making him look like an ancient Hebrew prophet  and mockingly proclaimed: Well, Ill be damned. My mother always told me there was a Santa Claus, and I didnt believe her, until now. She told Heschel that there was no food to be had.

title: Madrid Tops Barcelona
