description: To the Editor:

title: A Happy Holiday Greeting From Maam
description: LONDON  Seventy-five years ago, courtesy of what he referred to as the marvels of modern science, King George V became the first British monarch to broadcast a message to his subjects at Christmastime via the radio.

title: N.C. State Guard Out for Season
description: North Carolina State point guard Farnold Degand is out for the season with a torn anterior cruciate ligament in his left knee. Degand, a sophomore, had started all 10 games for the Wolfpack (7-3) this season and was averaging 6.9 points, 3.2 rebounds and 28.6 minutes. He led the Wolfpack in assists and 3-point shooting.

title: Officials Falling Behind on Mortgage Fraud Cases
description: The number of mortgage fraud cases has grown so fast that government agencies that investigate and prosecute them cannot keep up, lenders and law enforcement officials have said.

title: When the Senses Become Confused
description: One morning seven years ago, Sherrilyn Roush woke to discover that the left side of her body had gone numb.

title: Curry and Randolph May Be One Big Man Too Many
description: Nate Robinson had seen enough, and he wanted out  away from the chaos, the congestion and the cameras. His locker stall, squeezed between those of Eddy Curry and Zach Randolph, was prime territory for reporters staking out the Knicks burly big men. The nightly swarm had become intolerable.

title: The Giants May Rest, but the Debate Will Not
description: Tom Coughlin suspected he would face some tough questions this week. Had his Giants lost to the Bills on Sunday, they would have been desperately preparing for a game on Saturday night against the undefeated Patriots, perhaps needing a victory for a playoff berth, with the accompanying anxious speculation over their coachs fate.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Statues of Hindu God Stolen

title: Football Leads the Night
description: Sunday Night Football lifted NBC into first place on Sunday, followed by CBS, which benefited from an overrun of its own football coverage into the 7 p.m. hour. Directly after football, CBSs 60 Minutes and then The Amazing Race delivered approximately 12.8 million and 8.3 million viewers, respectively, Nielsen estimated. Later in the night, CBSs two-hour special, In Gods Name, drew just 3.8 million viewers. ABC ranked third, as the finale of its week-long series Duel earned a disappointing 6.1 million viewers. After Duel at 8, ABCs broadcast of the movie The Santa Clause II averaged 8.7 million viewers from 9 to 11. Just 4.6 million tuned in to Fox for Spiderman II from 7:30 to 9. Fox finished fourth over all.

title: Uconn Women Back at No. 1
description: After an absence of nearly four years, the Connecticut womens basketball team is back at No. 1 in the rankings. The Huskies received 49 of the 50 first-place votes in the Associated Press poll after being No. 2 all season. Tennessee had been No. 1 since the preseason poll, but lost to Stanford, 73-69, in overtime Saturday night.The Lady Vols fell to No. 3. Stanford received the other first-place vote, moving to No. 2 from No. 5.Connecticut last held the top spot Feb. 23, 2004. The time away from the top ranking was the longest drought in Coach Geno Auriemmas career, since Connecticut first reached No. 1 on Jan. 17, 1995. Connecticut has now held the top spot 95 times. Only Tennessee has held it more. The Huskies (9-0) have been winning by an average of 40 points this season.

title: Fearsome Nessie Started Out as a Good Egg and Playmate
description: Many lonely children yearn for a pet to call their own. In The Water Horse: Legend of the Deep, based on a novel by Dick King-Smith, a boy, Angus (Alex Etel), finds not only that, but a best friend as well, after the mysterious egg he stumbles across hatches a creature unlike any hes ever seen. Adorable and full of mischief, his new companion, Crusoe, who looks something like a cross between a dinosaur and a snail, immediately adds spice to his drab life.

title: A Life Turning Around
description: At just 17, Jay supports himself by working two jobs. He tries to keep his little brothers out of trouble, and he calls his mother my first love. To protect him, we cannot tell you his last name, because when he was 12, he yielded to heavy recruitment and joined a gang in the rough section of Brooklyn where he grew up. Today, Jay is working and studying as hard as he can to build a full, new life. The gang has not forgiven him for leaving.

title: Regional Carrier Sold
description: Air France-KLM Group, the worlds largest airline, agreed to buy the regional carrier VLM Airlines to expand its business travel to London. Air France is buying the airline from Panta Holdings.

title: Singapore: Temasek Raises Stake
description: Temasek Holdings, the biggest shareholder in Standard Chartered, increased its stake in the British bank to 18 percent, increasing the financial services investments in its $100 billion portfolio. Temasek bought 12 million shares of Standard Chartered, raising its holding by one percentage point, the bank said in a filing. Standard Chartered gets most of its profit from Asia and spent more than $2.7 billion since 2006 on acquisitions, including Hsinchu International Bank in Taiwan and Union Bank Ltd. in Pakistan. The shares purchased by Temasek, worth 220 million ($436 million), lift the total holding to 253.7 million shares.

title: Sharks Forward Arrested
description: San Jose forward Ryane Clowe was arrested early Monday morning on suspicion of drunken driving in Los Gatos, Calif. Clowe, who has been out of the lineup after having knee surgery, is the second Sharks player in two seasons to be arrested on that charge, despite a policy to reimburse Sharks players or staff members for a taxi or car service if they need transportation.

title: Conserving Cuba, After the Embargo
description: Through accidents of geography and history, Cuba is a priceless ecological resource. That is why many scientists are so worried about what will become of it after Fidel Castro and his associates leave power and, as is widely anticipated, the American government relaxes or ends its trade embargo.

title: Jets Answers Are Familiar Refrain After Latest Loss
description: At the beginning of Coach Eric Manginis conference call Monday, every sentence came out twice. This was not because Mangini used his pet phrases  collective effort and each season is different and we dont discuss injuries  but because of an echo on the phone line.

title: Switzerland: UBS Examined
description: The countrys banking regulator is planning to find out how UBS racked up $10 billion in write-downs related to the subprime lending problems in the United States. We have to look how the situation got so far into a loss, a spokesman for the Federal Banking Commission, Alain Bichsel, said. Its our job. On Dec. 10, UBS announced the largest subprime write-downs by any European bank and said it would raise $16.8 billion to improve its financial strength. Mr. Bichsel said that the banks response to the losses was very good and that UBS would not face an investigation in the legal sense. There is no evidence of any wrongdoing by UBS, Europes largest bank by assets, he added. A spokesman for UBS, Serge Steiner, declined to comment.

title: Hurting U.S. Research Labs
description: To the Editor:

title: Thai Party Says It Can Form Coalition
description: BANGKOK  A party that backs former Thai Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra said Monday that it had made alliances with enough other parties following parliamentary elections Sunday to form a coalition government.

title: Merrill Lynch Sells Stake to Singapore Firm
description: Merrill Lynch became the latest Wall Street bank to grab a financial lifeline from a foreign government, agreeing on Monday to sell $5 billion of new stock to an investor from Singapore and a smaller stake to a domestic firm, as the fallout from mortgage mess continues to spread.

title: Tolling Against Executions
description: To the Editor:

title: Food Scarcity and H.I.V. Interwoven in Uganda
description: MBARARA, Uganda  At the AIDS clinic here, the stories are brutal. A young cattle herder, infected with H.I.V. along with his wife, tells me that all four of their children died before turning 3.

title: Wallace, Fan of Clemens, Becomes His Questioner
description: Mike Wallace has been a correspondent for CBSs 60 Minutes for the past four decades and more recently has taken on a reduced role, with the weekly news show now describing him as a correspondent emeritus.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Thursday about Jacob Zuma, the man who is considered likely to be South Africas next president, described the countrys political system incorrectly in some editions. It is a democracy dominated by one party, not a one-party democracy.

title: Uzbekistan: Leader Wins New Term
description: Islam A. Karimov won a third seven-year term as president with 88 percent of the vote in weekend voting, Uzbek election officials said. The Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe said that the contest failed to give the population a true choice and noted that all three of Mr. Karimovs opponents publicly endorsed him. Mr. Karimov has led the ex-Soviet state of 28 million people since 1989. He was technically barred from seeking another term under the Constitution, but election officials dealt with the issue by simply ignoring it, or by contending that the countrys various referendums  the last in 2002 extending the presidential term to seven years from five  left Mr. Karimov with a clean slate.

title: Restructuring Aims to Give Canadas Debt Market a $33 Billion Lift
description: OTTAWA  A tentative restructuring agreement should unlock a $33 billion portion of Canadas debt market that has been frozen since August, its chief architect said on Monday.

title: Israel Wont Prosecute for Use of Cluster Bombs in Lebanon
description: JERUSALEM  Israeli military prosecutors announced Monday that they would not press charges over the armys use of cluster bombs during the war against Hezbollah guerrillas in Lebanon, actions that had been widely criticized by human rights organizations.

title: Britain: A Drop in Home Prices
description: Home prices in Britain fell the most in three years in December, and the threat of more declines may cause the property market to seize up in 2008, said Hometrack Ltd., a London-based research group. The average cost of a home in England and Wales slipped for a third month, dropping 0.3 percent to 175,200 ($348,350). The second half of the year has seen a major reversal in confidence, Richard Donnell, director for research at Hometrack, said in a statement. Just as the financial markets have faced a liquidity squeeze, so the housing market is in danger of facing its own liquidity squeeze. Prices increased 3 percent from a year earlier, the least in 18 months, Hometrack said.

title: Better Arrests in New York Decoy Program After Officers Receive More Training
description: Earlier this year, prosecutors in Manhattan and the Bronx grew concerned over some arrests stemming from the Police Departments Operation Lucky Bag, in which an undercover officer leaves an item in the subway to see if someone will take it.

title: A Master of Motion Learns Lessons of Inspired Immobility
description: In the last of the four one-act plays by Samuel Beckett currently at New York Theater Workshop, Mikhail Baryshnikov sits on an iron bed in a tatty red plaid bathrobe for 17 minutes, not moving or speaking, as a voice recites the thoughts that relentlessly taunt him. A close-up of his face is projected on a giant scrim, shrinking the already intimate space between the audience and the man.

title: For Christmas Joy, a Cure?
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in Science Times on Dec. 11 about the effort to develop a malaria vaccine using live, weakened parasites grown in mosquitoes misstated the role of Dr. Ruth S. Nussenzweig in earlier discoveries leading to the vaccine. Along with Dr. Jerome Vanderberg and other scientists, Dr. Nussenzweig was a co-author of a 1967 paper showing that the vaccine worked in mice; she was not a co-author of several papers from the 1970s showing that the concept worked in humans.

title: Whatever Games Integrity, Fans Show Up
description: Major League Baseball has always had its doomsayers. Well, maybe not always, but certainly in the past several decades. For one reason or another, baseball has been a dying sport. Except it has never died. And its not about to die now because of the Mitchell report.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a sports article on Saturday about Barry Bondss desire to keep his legal team intact for his perjury and obstruction of justice case despite potential conflicts of interest referred incorrectly to the professional relationship between his lead lawyer, Allen Ruby, and a surgeon for Mr. Bonds who could be called to testify. Mr. Ruby was a lawyer for the surgeon, Dr. Arthur Ting, for a month in 2005  not when Dr. Ting testified a year later before a federal grand jury hearing evidence against Mr. Bonds.

title: A Threat So Big, Academics Try Collaboration
description: It is a basic tenet of university research: Economists conduct joint studies, chemists join forces in the laboratory, political scientists share ideas about other cultures  but rarely do the researchers cross disciplinary lines.

title: Broadway Hit Captures Era, and Saves a Tailor
description: The bolts of cloth on display in the quiet showroom of Saint Laurie Merchant Tailors whisper the tones of serious business  dark blues, every shade of gray and brown, subtle stripes and plaids. You have to venture back into the adjoining suit factory to see the fabrics that scream Showtime!

title: Fishing and Floating in Costa Rica
description: UPALA, Costa Rica  In Costa Rica, there are fishermen, and then there are members of the Club Nacional de Pesca.

title: Surfs Up, and So Is the Crime Rate on Bajas Beaches
description: ROSARITO, Mexico  Surfers talk endlessly about waves  their size, their intensity, their roll. And crime waves are no exception.

title: Recent Entries From Our Blogs
description: Dot Earth

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption in The Arts on Monday with the continuation of a music column about national music identity and the annual Christmas show at Radio City Music Hall misidentified the scene for which some Rockettes were shown preparing backstage at Radio City. It was the Dance of the Toy Soldiers  not the Nutcracker scene, which does not include the Rockettes.

title: Parents Defend Schools Use of Shock Therapy
description: Nearly a year ago, New York made plans to ban the use of electric shocks as a punishment for bad behavior, a therapy used at a Massachusetts school where New York State had long sent some of its most challenging special education students.

title: A New Sensation in Iraq: Motor Scooters
description: BAGHDAD  Violence may be down in Iraq, but road rage is up.

title: Price Range for Morgan Stock
description: SHANGHAI  Morgan Stanley, the investment bank, and the Chinese government said Monday that the bank had determined the range of prices to be used when Chinas international investment fund converts $5 billion in securities into Morgan Stanley stock.

title: Leading the Charge to Inspire Underdogs
description: Its steadfast humanity, its literacy, its passionate belief in education, its faith that history teaches invaluable lessons and its strong, emotionally grounded performances: There are enough things to admire about The Great Debaters, the heavily fictionalized true story of The Little Debate Team That Could, that your impulse is to forgive the movie its shortcomings.

title: Mission to a Distant Comet (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: When Christmas Morning Comes
description: This is a simple holiday. Ask any child, or, better yet, ask yourself what you recall from your own childhood Christmases. Presents, yes, and shopping and decorations and the return of familiar songs and the smells of baking and perhaps the cadence of a few verses from the early chapters of Matthew and Luke.

title: St. Nick in the Big City
description: ST. NICHOLAS was a super-saint with an immense cult for most of the Christian past. There may be more icons surviving for Nicholas alone than for all the other saints of Christendom put together. So what happened to him? Wheres the fourth-century Anatolian bishop who presided over gift-giving to poor children? And how did we get the new icon of mass consumerism in his place?

title: In San Francisco, Its Work to Find Toys
description: SAN FRANCISCO  This is the city of lost toy stores.

title: To Provide Quality Music Education Now, Schools Could Learn From the Past
description: Schools out for the holidays, and its probably the last thing on anyones mind. But in the marginalized world of music education, a good deal of serious thinking needs to be done. Now that Charles Dickenss Christmas ghosts have made their rounds for the year, perhaps they might be enlisted to provide perspective and encourage some soul-searching.

title: On the Ground and in the Water, Tracing a Giant Waves Path
description: TEMPE, Ariz.  Next to the office of Harindra Joseph S. Fernando at Arizona State University is a 107-foot-long wave tank that can mimic oceanic motions.

title: Footnotes
description: WKCR (89.9 FM and wkcr.org) began its annual Bach Festival on Monday morning. From Christmas Eve through New Years Day, the station dedicates its broadcast hours to the music and influence of Johann Sebastian Bach. ... For the second year running, Songs From the Labyrinth, a collection of lute songs by John Dowland performed by Sting, was the best-selling classical music album of the year, Billboard reported.

title: Democrats Try to Rein In Fees on Consulting
description: It was the spring of 2004, and Senator John Kerry had just secured the Democratic presidential nomination. But as huge sums of money began pouring into his campaign, his top strategists had more on their minds than just getting ready for a tough race against President Bush.

title: A Question of Blame When Societies Fall
description: As I pulled out of Tucson listening to an audiobook of Jared Diamonds Collapse: How Societies Choose to Fail or Succeed, the first of a procession of blue-and-yellow billboards pointed the way to Arizonas strangest roadside attraction, The Thing?

title: Its Downhill for Sleds, Lamentably
description: These are desperate times for sledding and its urban fans.

title: Rivera, Fridamanias Other Half, Gets His Due
description: MEXICO CITY  Its easy to forget that at the height of Diego Riveras fame, in the 1920s and 30s, he had star power. A Communist who painted murals for the great capitalists of his day, he offered an epic view of history and a cosmic vision of human potential. But in the last few decades here, his reputation has been vastly eclipsed by Fridamania, the cult status of his third wife, Frida Kahlo.

title: The Silent Scream
description: Q. My dog is bothered by a sound my espresso machine makes that I cannot hear. And then there is that cellphone ring tone that kids can hear but older people cannot. Can your hearing be harmed by a loud, high-frequency noise you cannot hear?

title: Zap! Make the Interview Part Jig, Part Bullfight
description: In journalisms grocery store, the interview is found not among the staples but with the produce. It has a short shelf life. It wilts. What the politician, the police chief and the porn star have to say, even if startling, rarely startles for more than a week or so.

title: District Trying to Forge a New Identity
description: A train thundered across the Manhattan Bridge, high above the wind-swept streets of Dumbo, where two young graphic designers were trundling a hotel-style luggage cart, loaded with laundry bags and cardboard boxes, toward their building.

title: Louisville Center Healing Fast
description: The injured Louisville center David Padgett has been cleared to work out and could be back when the Cardinals face West Virginia next month, Coach Rick Pitino said Monday. Padgett, a fifth-year senior who fractured his right knee Nov. 18, was expected to miss up to 10 weeks and possibly the entire season.

title: For the Lost and Stranded, Help From a Smiling Face
description: ONE of those long faces at the airport last week belonged to me. After my Continental flight from Tucson arrived late in Houston, I double-timed it across two terminals to make my connection.

title: Giants Should Dream Big and Play for an Upset
description: Tom Coughlin can play it good and safe Saturday night, treat the last game of December like the first week of August. He can be the pragmatic professional, the staunch football conservative, deploy his starters for a series or two and give them the rest of a well-deserved game off.

title: Court Ruling on Protests Curbs Malls in California
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The California Supreme Court ruled Monday that privately owned shopping malls cannot stop protesters from demonstrating there to urge a boycott of one of the tenants.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about the selection of a new leader by the Liberal Democrats in Britain misstated the span over which the countrys two main parties have dominated the government. Since 1922  not 1992  every British election has been won by either Labor or the Conservatives. (Go to Article)

title: Two Shot, One Fatally, at a Party in Bronx
description: Five people were killed in four separate shootings in the Bronx and Brooklyn on Monday, the police said.

title: African Players Choose Club or Country
description: Every two years, as the start of the African Cup of Nations tournament approaches, coaches and club officials throughout Europe whine, gnash their teeth and lament the departure of their African players.

title: Rhode Island Men Return to Poll
description: Rhode Island made it into the Associated Press mens college basketball poll for the first time in nine years, entering at No. 25 after the programs best start since the 1991-92 season. The Rams (11-1) were last ranked briefly in November 1998.For the fourth consecutive week, North Carolina, Memphis and Kansas were the top three teams in the rankings. Losses last week by No. 4 Texas, No. 5 Georgetown and No. 6 Duke moved Washington State (11-0) up three spots to No. 4, the highest ranking in team history.

title: Brain Cells, Doing Their Job With Some Neighborly Help
description: A region deep in the brain called the hippocampus tracks, sorts and stores the onslaught of information pouring through the senses every waking minute. A large question in neuroscience is one a kindergartner would ask: How?

title: Arecibo Radio Telescope Is Back in Business After 6-Month Spruce-Up
description: Its future may be uncertain, but if the Arecibo radio telescope in Puerto Rico is headed into mothballs it will go there with a fresh coat of paint.

title: Sleeps Restorative Value (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Albany G.O.P. Plans Inquiry on Reports of Purged E-Mail by the Administration
description: The State Senate investigations committee will hold hearings next month as part of an inquiry into claims that the Spitzer administration has been deleting electronic records, including e-mail messages, the committees chairman said Monday.

title: Spread of Mumps Is Feared After Maine Reports Cases
description: BOSTON  State health officials across New England are on alert after dozens of cases of mumps have been confirmed or suspected in Maine.

title: Pope Makes Appeal to Protect the Environment
description: ROME  Pope Benedict XVI reinforced the Vaticans growing concern with protecting the environment in the traditional midnight Christmas Mass on Tuesday, bemoaning an ill-treated world in a homily given to thousands of pilgrims here in the seat of the worlds billion Roman Catholics.

title: Insights: Clinical Trials May Not Represent Population
description: The randomized clinical trial, widely considered the most reliable biomedical research method, can have significant drawbacks, a new study suggests, because patients included may not be representative of the broader population.

title: Professor Cites Bible in Faulting Tax Policies
description: At a time when some voters are asking how the religious views of candidates will shape their policies, a professors discovery of how little tax the biggest landowners in her state paid to finance the government has prompted some other legal scholars to scour religious texts to explore the moral basis of tax and spending policies.

title: The Right Answer in New Orleans
description: New Orleans will never recover economically unless it attracts a work force large enough to drive the industries upon which the city has historically depended for its livelihood. Low-wage workers, in particular, are unlikely to return until the tens of thousands of rental houses and apartments that were destroyed by Hurricanes Rita and Katrina are replaced. To secure its economic future, the region needs an aggressive, farsighted plan for rebuilding the rental housing stock and creating more affordable housing.

title: Michigan State Players Ineligible
description: Defensive end Jonal Saint-Dic and linebacker SirDarean Adams, both seniors, are among five Michigan State players who will sit out the Champs Sports Bowl on Friday against No. 14 Boston College because of academic or other violations.The Spartans said Monday that Saint-Dic was academically ineligible, along with wide receiver and return specialist Terry Love, wide receiver/cornerback T. J. Williams and offensive guard Abre Leggins. Adams violated unspecified team rules.

title: Birds, Bugs Named as Steroid Users!
description: I am a baseball fan of the most fitful and narrow-minded sort. I love the Yankees, but really only when theyre winning, I hate the Red Sox, especially when theyre winning, and the other teams, as far as Im concerned, can all go take a whiff.

title: In a Flat World, a Rebel With a Cause
description: Persepolis is a simple story told by simple means. Like Marjane Satrapis book, on which it is based, the film, directed by Ms. Satrapi and Vincent Paronnaud, consists essentially of a series of monochrome drawings, their bold black lines washed with nuances of gray. The pictures are arranged into the chronicle of a young girls coming of age in difficult times, a tale that unfolds with such grace, intelligence and charm that you almost take the wondrous aspects of its execution for granted.

title: Giving Till It Hurts
description: The public has rightly shown its empathy with wounded and troubled war veterans, contributing hundreds of millions of dollars to private charities that claim to have the veterans best interests at heart. A new study details rampant abuses of the money flow.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The Critics Choice column on Monday, about new CDs, misspelled part of the title of the new CD by the German band Einstrzende Neubauten. It is Alles Wieder Offen, not Weider.

title: Two Venerable Lighthouses Compete for One Genuine Lens
description: ROCHESTER  In the evening, the Rev. Thomas H. Wheeland likes to retreat to the back porch of his rectory at Holy Cross Church and look out onto Lake Ontario, illuminated by a wide beam of light from a neighboring lighthouse.

title: A TV Doctor Who Travels Into Trouble
description: MY television series and work with various humanitarian organizations takes me to some of the worlds most remote and hazardous locations.

title: States Widening of Health Care Hits Roadblocks
description: SACRAMENTO  A year that began with great ambition for major expansions of health insurance here and in other state capitals is ending with considerable uncertainty, as a second wave of change runs headlong into a darkening economy and political divisions over how to apportion the cost.

title: On the Same Wavelength With the Doctor
description: My friends grandmother-in-law, at 94, has refused her sons pleas to make a routine doctor visit. Why should I go to the doctor? my friend recalled her exclaiming. They dont know anything anymore. You used to go to one doctor and he told you what was wrong and what to do about it. Now all the doctor does is draw vials of blood, order tests, and then tell you to go to another doctor.

title: United Rentals Will Not Appeal Ruling
description: United Rentals said Monday that it would not appeal a Delaware judges ruling Friday that the private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management cannot be forced to complete its $4 billion buyout of the rental equipment operator.

title: Uzbekistan Re-elects Its President
description: OSH, Kyrgyzstan  President Islam A. Karimov of Uzbekistan won 88.1 percent of votes in the presidential election Sunday, according to preliminary results released on Monday by the countrys Central Election Commission.

title: Researchers Find Animal That Links Whales to Land
description: Scientists who study evolution have long known that whales must have had ancestors that lived on land. Some characteristics were dead giveaways, most notably the fact that they are air-breathers.

title: Lottery Numbers
The Hard Nut Cleans Up
description: Ovation TVs Battle of the Nutcrackers has produced a winner. The Hard Nut, Mark Morriss version of the classic Tchaikovsky ballet, received the most votes in online viewer polling. Ovation will replay all four versions of The Nutcracker featured in the competition in a Christmas-day marathon beginning at 8 a.m. Eastern time. In addition to The Hard Nut, there will be a filmed version of George Balanchines Nutcracker, featuring dancers from the New York City Ballet; a performance of The Nutcracker by the Bolshoi Ballet; and Matthew Bournes Nutcracker!

title: Lost Star Goes to Jail
description: Michelle Rodriguez, the former star of Lost, will be spending the holidays in jail, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Rodriguez, below, reported to a Los Angeles County jail on Sunday to begin a six-month sentence for failing to complete community service and alcohol monitoring as part of her probation from a drunken driving incident, authorities said. She was booked into the Century Regional Detention Facility on Thursday, the same jail where Paris Hilton served much of her sentence earlier this year. Ms. Rodriguez received the sentence in October after she admitted violating her probation by failing to provide proof of community service and by drinking alcohol while wearing a monitoring device. She was on three years probation after pleading no contest to a hit-and-run, driving on a suspended license and drunken driving in connection with two incidents in Hollywood in 2003.

title: Treatments: Talking Out the Choices for Breast Cancer Surgery
description: Two-thirds of general surgeons fail to mention the possibility of breast reconstruction before their patients choose between mastectomy and breast-conserving surgery, researchers have found. When that talk does occur, it sharply increases a womans willingness to consider mastectomy.

title: Even Top Performers Have Flaws, and That Might Be a Good Thing
description: Dont tell the piano teacher, but practice doesnt really make perfect. A virtuoso musician may seem to nail every note, but actually there are tiny variations in even the most skilled performance.

title: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
description: Previously recorded $3,742,926

title: The Comeback Kid
description: St. Johns forward Rob Thomas scored his first college basket last week. It came nearly 5,000 miles away, in an empty gymnasium during a Red Storm loss at a tournament in Hawaii.

title: Memo Pad
description: HOLIDAY TRAVEL More than 65 million Americans will travel 50 miles or more from home during the Christmas-New Years holiday period, about the same as last year, AAA says. The automobile club said that that gas prices and air fares would be well above last years levels. Domestic air fares are averaging more than 15 percent higher than fares at the same time last year, and gas prices are up an average of 70 cents a gallon. Rates at midlevel hotels are 4 percent higher than they were at Christmas last year and 9 percent higher than at New Years. But average car-rental rates are 4 percent lower this Christmas and are expected to be 13 percent lower for New Years, AAA said.

title: Doubts Engulf an American Aid Plan for Pakistan
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  Weeks before it is to begin, an ambitious American aid plan to counter militancy in Pakistans tribal areas is threatened by important unresolved questions about who will monitor the money and whether it could fall into the wrong hands, according to American and Pakistani officials and analysts familiar with the plan.

title: On Ukrainian Screens, Say It in Ukrainian
description: A Ukrainian court on Monday banned the screening or distribution of all foreign films that are not dubbed or subtitled in Ukrainian, Agence France-Presse reported. The constitutional court said foreign films could not be distributed or shown if they are not dubbed or post-synchronized or do not have the captioning data in the state language. The move follows a campaign calling for a boycott of foreign films dubbed into Russian or carrying Russian subtitles. Ukraine, a former Soviet republic with 47 million inhabitants, is split over the language issue. In a poll released on Monday about 42 percent of 1,800 respondents said Ukrainian should be the sole state language; 30 percent said Russian should be granted the same status.

title: Juror in Long Island Killing Says He Was Pressured Into a Guilty Verdict
description: At 8 p.m. on Saturday, a jury deciding the racially charged manslaughter case of a black man who shot a white teenager last year was still hopelessly deadlocked, to use the term the jurors used earlier in a note to the judge.

title: Hazards: More Transfusions Mean More Risk for Women
description: Women are more likely than men to die after heart surgery, and one reason may be the use of a common medical procedure: blood transfusions.

title: Election Rules Complicate Kenya Race
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The fate of Kenyas hotly contested presidential election could come down to a single slum.

title: The Claim: Calories From Alcohol Go to Your Midsection
description: THE FACTS

title: Snowstorm Sweeps Across the Midwest, Killing 19
description: CHICAGO  Ice storms, then a thick layer of snow and finally a raging, blinding wind paralyzed parts of the nations middle section over the weekend, stranding holiday travelers in roadside motels and shelters and leaving at least 19 people dead.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day last Tuesday about a public offering by the software company NetSuite misstated its losses in the first nine months of 2006 and the year its chief executive joined the company. The losses were $26.9 million, not $27.6 million, and Zachary Nelson joined the company in 2002, not 2000. The article also misstated the companys plans for some proceeds of the offering. NetSuite said it would retire the outstanding balance on an $8 million secured line of credit, not start paying it down.

title: Will Smith Says He Was Misunderstood
description: Calling it an awful and disgusting lie, Will Smith, above, said through his publicist that he is angry with a newspaper reporters interpretation of comments he made about Hitler, The Associated Press reported. In an article published Saturday in The Daily Record, in Scotland, Mr. Smith was quoted as saying: Even Hitler didnt wake up going, Let me do the most evil thing I can do today. I think he woke up in the morning and using a twisted, backwards logic, he set out to do what he thought was good. The quotation was preceded by the reporters observation, Remarkably, Will believes everyone is basically good. On Monday the Jewish Defense League denounced the reported comment and urged movie theaters to stop showing I Am Legend, in which Mr. Smith stars. In his publicists statement, the actor said: I am incensed and infuriated to have to respond to such a ludicrous misinterpretation. Adolf Hitler was a vile, heinous vicious killer responsible for one of the greatest acts of evil committed on this planet.

The musical, whose limited-engagement run at the St. James Theater ends on Jan. 6, took in $1.57 million  down slightly from nearly $1.7 million for the same week last year, but still enough to qualify The Grinch (with Patrick Page, right, in the title role) as Broadways top earner for the week. Wicked was a close second, with a weekly gross of nearly $1.45 million, followed by Jersey Boys at $1.26 million, The Lion King at $1.12 million and The Little Mermaid, at $1.02 million. title: Little Tramps Mansion

The colonnaded Manoir de Ban, above, in Corsier-sur-Vevey, is set in a large wooded park, with views of Lake Geneva and the Alps. Under an agreement between the museums foundation and a group of investors from Luxembourg, the house will be turned into a museum at a projected cost of $30 million. The former staff quarters will become a 200-seat cinema, and the vaulted cellars will be transformed into a Hollywood street, complete with street lamps, from the 1920s. Until last year the home was occupied by Chaplins descendants. Regularly people used to ring at the door to ask to visit, recalled Michael Chaplin, one of Chaplins sons, who settled there with five of his seven children. They came from China, Latin America, Africa. The museum is scheduled to open at the end of 2009. title: Editors Note: The Ron Paul Vid-Lash
description: A post in The Medium that appeared on Monday about the Republican presidential candidate Ron Paul and his purported adoption by white supremacist and neo-Nazi groups contained several errors. Stormfront, which describes itself as a white nationalist Internet community, did not give money to Ron Pauls presidential campaign; according to Jesse Benton, a spokesman for Pauls campaign, it was Don Black, the founder of Stormfront, who donated $500 to Paul. The original post also repeated a string of assertions by Bill White, the commander of the American National Socialist Workers Party, including the allegation that Paul meets regularly with members of the Stormfront set, American Renaissance, the Institute for Historic Review and others at a restaurant in Arlington, Va. Paul never attended these dinners, according to Benton, who also says that Paul has never knowingly met Bill White. Norman Singleton, a congressional aide in Pauls office, says that he met Bill White at a dinner gathering of conservatives several years ago, after which Singleton expressed his indignation at the views espoused by White to the organizer of the dinner. The original post should not have been published with these unverified assertions and without any response from Paul.

The minister, Mikhail Shvydkoi, told the Itar-Tass news service, I received a draft of the law from Britain, which gives a significantly greater chance for a positive resolution of the question and the holding of the exhibition. Moscow had threatened to cancel the show, From Russia: French and Russian Master Paintings 1870-1925, scheduled to begin on Jan. 26 at the Royal Academy of Art, unless the art could be safeguarded from lawsuits by descendants of some Russian collectors contending that the works were confiscated by the new government after the Bolshevik Revolution in 1917. Britain then promised to accelerate passage of legislation offering guarantees. The law offers the possibility to enter into serious negotiations on sending the exhibition to London, Mr. Shvydkoi said. The art is now on view in Dsseldorf, Germany.

title: Did Art Thieves Try, Try Again?
description: The police say that they suspect that the thieves who stole Picassos Portrait of Suzanne Bloch and Candido Portinaris Coffee Worker, above, from the So Paulo Museum of Art last week are the same men who tried to break in at least twice previously, Bloomberg News reported. On Oct. 29 intruders overpowered two security guards, who did not have keys to the section of the museum where paintings are displayed. On Dec. 17 security guards chased away two people who were using a blowtorch to try to cut through a back door. The second incident was not reported to the police. Last weeks theft, carried out in three minutes, has led to calls for the Brazilian government to take control of the museum, which lacks an alarm system and where the collection, valued at more than $1 billion, is uninsured. The stolen Picasso is said to be valued at $50 million. Its appalling that anyone with half a brain would be able to walk into one of Latin Americas most important museums and steal a Picasso, said Jones Bergamin, who runs the auction house Art Bourse in Rio de Janeiro. The guardians of art in Brazil nearly invited these thieves to rob them. Jose do Nascimento Jr., director of museums at the Institute of Heritage and National Arts in Brazil, said the country had the worlds fourth-highest number of art thefts, after the United States, France and Iraq.

description: BAGHDAD  American soldiers raided a neighborhood in the southern Iraqi city of Kut early Thursday morning, killing 11 members of the Mahdi Army, the militia loyal to hardline Shiite cleric Moktada Sadr.

title: Protection for Endangered Whistle-Blowers
description: Congress is finally ready to stand up to the Bush administration and for those courageous federal workers who dare to reveal waste and abuse in government. The Senate has passed strong reforms to the 1989 whistle-blower protection law, counteracting the gag orders, retaliatory investigations and other harassments that have become shamefully standard practice during the last seven years.

title: Queens Man Found Stabbed to Death
description: The body of a man was found Wednesday on a handball court in a Queens park, where he was pronounced dead from what appeared to be stab wounds, the police said.

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: Nigeria: Pfizer Fights Jailings
description: Pfizer said it would fight a Nigerian court order that could jail three employees who had failed to appear at a trial over whether the company had improperly tested an experimental drug on Nigerian children. The employees did not receive summonses to appear at last months trial, Pfizer said. The state of Kano is demanding $2.75 billion from Pfizer, which it says used an untested meningitis drug in a 1996 outbreak. Pfizer has said its use of the drug obeyed government rules and saved lives.

title: Some Orders That the Boss Should Heed
description: NEW YEARS resolutions tend to be discarded like old Christmas trees, and often just as quickly. But blaming ourselves for being weak only masks a larger problem. We dont go to the gym or get home in time for dinner with the family because our lives contain too much stress and not enough time, and we, the workers of the world, cannot unilaterally change that.

title: Home & Garden Calendar
description: Winter Artworks

title: New York Heresy: Editor Heads South
description: Until the moment several short weeks ago when Sid Evans abruptly decided to leave town, he seemed like the sort of person who had stepped straight out of a Dawn Powell novel about a young, ambitious newcomer to New York.

title: Inside Apple Stores, a Certain Aura Enchants the Faithful
description: It was 2 oclock in the morning but in the subterranean retailing mecca in Midtown Manhattan, otherwise known as the Apple store, it might as well have been midafternoon.

title: Crime Drops, and New York Acts to Keep It Under Control
description: Every new police officer in New York City will be sent onto the streets, into some of the citys toughest neighborhoods as part of an broad anticrime operation that the authorities say has helped produce historic drops in crime, the city announced Wednesday.

title: In Europe, Tighter Lending but Not a Squeeze
description: FRANKFURT  Ralf Friedrichss business in shipping finance has hit a rough patch.

title: In Laos, Chinese Motorcycles Change Lives
description: LONG LAO GAO, Laos  The pineapples that grow on the steep hills above the Mekong River are especially sweet, the red and orange chilies unusually spicy, and the spring onions and watercress retain the freshness of the mountain dew.

title: Despite Aid, Malnutrition in Darfur Rises
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Child malnutrition rates have increased sharply in Darfur, even though it is home to the worlds largest aid operation, according to a new United Nations report.

title: Bloggings a Low-Cost, High Return Marketing Tool
description: TO its true believers at small businesses, it is a low-cost, high-return tool that can handle marketing and public relations, raise the company profile and build the brand.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An obituary on Tuesday about the choreographer Michael Kidd misstated, in some copies, the year that he was given a special Academy Award. It was 1997, not 1996.

title: Throwing the Book at Them
description: It turns out the library can do more than just shush you. If you accumulate enough unpaid late fees, some New York libraries are ready to hit you where it really hurts: your credit score. They have reported millions of dollars in such bad debts. Most people make good before their creditworthiness is damaged. But there is something chilling in this kind of threat from a library.

title: Wonderful Life but So-So Ratings
description: Few tuned in for prime-time television programming over the Christmas holiday, and those who did were not necessarily interested in traditional holiday fare. Nielsen estimated that NBC led Tuesday nights ratings with a special two-hour edition of Deal or No Deal, which averaged 9.8 million viewers from 8 to 10, but the networks Christmas Eve broadcast of the classic 1946 film Its a Wonderful Life fell just short of its competitors (4.5 million), giving NBC a second-place finish on Monday night in a tie with CBS among adults 18 to 49. CBS broadcast repeats of its regular Monday- and Tuesday-night lineups, leading on Monday in total viewers but trailing well behind on Tuesday. ABC got a lift from the computer-animated 2005 film Madagascar (4.8 million), which helped it eke out a victory on Monday with the 18-to-49 set. On Tuesday ABCs broadcast of the 2003 movie Pirates of the Caribbean (5.5 million) put the network in a virtual tie for second with Foxs lineup of reruns.

title: Giulianis Doctor Says Tests Reveal Very Good Health
description: LARGO, Fla.  A week after a severe headache landed Rudolph W. Giuliani in a St. Louis hospital, the Giuliani campaign on Wednesday released the first statement from one of his doctors, who pronounced him in very good health.

title: Hunt for Suspects in Mauritania Killing
description: DAKAR, Senegal  Law enforcement officials in Mali, Mauritania and Senegal were searching on Wednesday for three men linked to a North African affiliate of Al Qaeda and suspected of killing four French tourists in a Christmas Eve attack.

title: 6 in Family Are Found Slain in Home Outside Seattle
description: SEATTLE  Six people were found shot to death at a home in a rural part of King County on Wednesday, and investigators arrested two people they said were responsible for the killings, law enforcement officials said. The victims included two children.

title: North Korea: Hint at Slowing Disabling
description: North Korea indicated it would slow down the dismantling of its nuclear weapons program because of what it said was a delay in the delivery of energy aid it was promised as a reward under an international deal. The United States, China, Japan, Russia and South Korea had set a year-end deadline for the disabling.

title: Bulldog With Attitude Has Big Freshman Year
description: ATHENS, Ga.  Georgia tailback Knowshon Moreno crashed into the line, and tempers flared.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An architecture column on Wednesday about Oscar Niemeyer and the impact his new work is having on some of his earlier work in Braslia, where he has created several masterpieces, misstated the name of a major roadway and open space in the city. It is the Monumental Axis, not the Ceremonial Axis. The column also misidentified the area where Braslia was built. It was a savanna, not a jungle.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A report in the Arts, Briefly column on Wednesday about Broadway box office grosses for the week ending Dec. 16 referred incompletely to the gross for The Homecoming, at the Cort Theater. Although the play grossed just $165,679 and saw an attendance rate of less than 40 percent, it was in previews until Dec. 16. (In the week ending Dec. 23 its gross increased nearly 50 percent, to $247,572, and attendance was just over 50 percent of capacity, an increase of 30 percent over the previous week. )

title: Lottery Numbers
Has Vitamin A. Needs a Martini.
description: SEVERAL cultures clash at the intersection of Broadway and Columbus in San Franciscos North Beach. Right behind beatnik Mecca  the City Lights bookstore and the Vesuvio cafe  is Chinatown, authentic down to the hanging smoked ducks and unmistakable fish-feather-ginseng smell. Up Columbus Avenue, Italian restaurants beloved exclusively by tourists are forever dying and being born.

title: Ruling Allows Wider Investment Options for Bloomberg and His Foundation
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, seeking to bolster his charitable giving, has reached a new agreement with the City Conflicts of Interest Board that will allow him to move his money into more aggressive investments, including hedge funds and publicly traded stocks.

title: Feinsteins New Venture
description: Michael Feinstein is establishing an outpost in London. Mr. Feinstein, the singer, pianist and impresario of the Manhattan supper club Feinsteins at Loews Regency, has entered into an arrangement to take cabaret artists to the 450-seat Shaw Theater in London under the name Feinsteins at the Shaw. Mr. Feinstein will inaugurate the series himself, with a show called An American in London, from Jan. 6 through Jan. 11. On his Web site, michaelfeinstein.com, he wrote on Wednesday: The vision for the Shaw will be similar to its New York counterpart and will present many of the multigenerational artists who are best appreciated in a more intimate theatrical setting, but it will also have a more Eurocentric flavor. We plan to present a Songwriters series, a Legends series and evenings of special tributes that will run the gamut of all different types of good music. The theater is part of the Novotel London St. Pancras Hotel on Euston Road, next to the British Library and the St. Pancras train station.

title: Tiger on the Loose: Can It Happen Here?
description: New Yorkers have plenty of reasons to be on edge when walking the streets, from armed thugs to reckless taxi drivers to aggressive hawkers.

title: Fastest-Growing States Show Slower Expansion
description: The bursting housing bubble squelched expansion in some of the nations fastest-growing states in the year that ended July 1, according to an analysis of census figures released Wednesday.

title: Fountain of Youth? Go Wash Your Face
description: IN my job as this newspapers resident beauty skeptic, I receive a lot of books about longevity with preposterous titles like Stop Aging, Start Living, The New Anti-Aging Revolution: Stopping the Clock and The Science of Staying Young.

title: More NetSuite Sold
description: The software maker NetSuite and its investors have sold an additional 930,000 shares. The stock, which had risen 49 percent since going public Dec. 20, fell 6.6 percent on Wednesday.

title: U.S. Ruling Backs Benefit Cut at 65 in Retiree Plans
description: WASHINGTON  The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission said Wednesday that employers could reduce or eliminate health benefits for retirees when they turn 65 and become eligible for Medicare.

title: Turkish Jets Strike Kurdish Rebels
description: ISTANBUL  Turkish warplanes attacked Kurdish rebel camps in northern Iraq on Wednesday, the Turkish military said, acknowledging its second cross-border airstrike this week and its third in recent days.

title: Bush Condemns Assassination
description: CRAWFORD, Tex.  President Bush on Thursday condemned the assassination of Pakistans opposition leader, Benazir Bhutto, a killing that left in ruins the delicate diplomatic effort his administration had pursued for the last year to reconcile that countrys deeply divided political factions.

title: Thomas Morgan, a Journalist and Activist, Dies at 56
description: Thomas Morgan III, a former reporter and editor at The New York Times who was a president of the National Association of Black Journalists, died on Monday in Southampton, Mass. He was 56 and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Bridging 2 Marriages and 4 Decades, a Large, Close-Knit Brood
description: Before Senator John McCain steps in front of an audience at a presidential debate, his daughter Meghan makes sure his nose is properly powdered. And from the campaign bus, Ms. McCain blogs about New Hampshire through the prism of politics and fashion (I helped Dad pick out some swank Timberland boots.)

title: Shifting Coupons, From Clip and Save to Point and Click
description: COUPON lovers, take heart. The era of waiting, scissors in hand, for the Sunday newspaper circular is over.

title: Therapists Are Leashed, but Affection Is Unbridled
description: With a jingle of tags and bells, Harley, Dolly, Feather and Bailey trot past a bank of poinsettias and into the Clove Lakes Health Care and Rehabilitation Center, a nursing home on Staten Island. The lobby erupts, as if rock stars just walked in.

title: Belichick Puts Pads Away in Short Week for Patriots
description: From the files of intriguing coaching decisions, we have the New England Patriots.

title: Becketts Bow to Ballet: A Dramatist With the Precision of a Choreographer
description: Anyone who sees Mikhail Baryshnikov in Beckett Shorts, the set of four brief plays by Samuel Beckett at the New York Theater Workshop, must reflect on how far this former ballet luminary has come from his training in Leningrad and his roles in the 19th-century classics. He is best known now as a star of the TV series Sex and the City, and the distance between that and Beckett Shorts is virtually as far. Part of his virtuosity has always dwelt in his need to elude definition or pigeonholing. His whole career has kept people asking, Who is he really?  which must be what he wants.

title: Its All About the Monroes
description: The United States Mint has announced the designs for the next four coins in its decade-long series of one-dollar coins featuring American presidents. James Monroe, the fifth president, will appear on Feb. 14, followed at three month intervals by John Quincy Adams, Andrew Jackson and Martin Van Buren. The Mint is also redoubling its efforts to get the public to use more of the dollar coins, which are the same size and color as the Sacagawea dollars first issued in 2000. A test program in the Washington, D.C., area is trying to encourage businesses to use more of the coins and is gathering feedback about why they might be resisting. The Mint turned out 800 million presidential $1 coins in 2007.

title: Human Rights Activist, Jailed in Iran, Is Transferred to Hospital
description: TEHRAN  A prominent human rights activist who has been jailed since October was transferred to a hospital Wednesday, according to his wife and the news agency ISNA.

title: New Jersey Requires H.I.V. Test in Pregnancy
description: TRENTON  An H.I.V. test is about to become as routine as an ultrasound for pregnant women in New Jersey.

title: A Winters Tale, Told in Handy Tools
description: IT is always good to be prepared for a new season. Now that winter is here, a shovel that can be used to clear the walk without risking back injury, retrofitted stair treads that automatically melt snow and ice, and an inflatable castle for children to play in are all worth having on hand.

description: Google must face a Wisconsin companys lawsuit over a toolbar feature that generates Web links from search data, a federal appeals court decided in a ruling posted on Wednesday.

In fist-shaking defiance he wrote formidable, complex and ingenious works. And if people resisted, that was their problem.

title: A Small Label Printer for Stickers on the Spot
description: For those who are still creating paper trails in the digital age, a new miniprinter might help. The Brother QL-570 Label Printer, due early next month for $99, pops out a wide variety of peel-and-stick labels with your own text and graphics.

title: Tyson Rewards Top Executives After Return to Profit
description: Tyson Foods, the largest United States meat producer, increased the compensation of its chief executive, Richard L. Bond, fivefold and quadrupled the pay of its former chief, John H. Tyson, as the company returned to profit after a 2006 loss.

title: Not a Ringing Endorsement
description: More than 500 e-mail messages, a couple of dozen phone calls and at least a handful of reader threats to cancel subscriptions have poured in since the editorial board of The Concord Monitor ran its scathing anti-endorsement of Mitt Romney, the Republican presidential candidate.

title: Both Jagr and Power Play Score Twice for the Rangers
description: The Rangers created plenty of fireworks in Wednesdays 4-2 victory over Carolina  some good, some ugly  and generally turned an otherwise mild rivalry with the Hurricanes into a combustible night at Madison Square Garden.

title: A Woman of Ambition, Neither Hero Nor Villain
description: The writer of contemporary history is like the man with his nose pressed against the mirror trying to see his whole body, Arnold Toynbee cautioned. Yet whatever their limitations, books about prominent sitting officials are irresistible, partly driven by an insatiable public appetite for gossip about public figures and an interest in understanding and judging them.

title: Documents of Library in Boston to Go on Web
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The historical record of the United States government will soon be more accessible.

description: Canal Plus, Vivendis pay-television unit, said it had agreed to buy Occade Sport, an organizer of sporting events. Canal Plus will acquire all of Occade Sports shares from Gones & Sports by the end of February, Vivendi said. Financial details were not disclosed.

title: Extra Points
description: Kansas City cornerback Ty Law told reporters on a conference call that when he played under Eric Mangini in New England, he knew Mangini would one day become a head coach. Law added that the Patriots used to jokingly call Mangini Mini-Me in reference to his relationship with his former mentor, Patriots Coach Bill Belichick.

description: Rapper Fails to Appear

title: Pistons Hit the Nets With Their Best Shot, and the Nets Fall
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Nets have enough talent to match one surge by an elite opponent such as the Detroit Pistons, but not two. Detroit kept pounding away at the Nets on Wednesday, like the surf battering a flimsy pier, and the Nets crumbled.

title: McCain Campaigns in Iowa, Energized by New Hampshire
description: URBANDALE, Iowa  Senator John McCain kicked off his first full day of a brief campaign swing through Iowa on Thursday, hoping his ascendancy in recent polls in New Hampshire would help propel him in Iowa, where he has struggled and spent little money.

title: Long Before Video Cameras, a French Artist Brought Motion to His Images
description: Ah, boredom, the curse of the rich and idle in 18th-century France. So how did the aristocrats while away their leisure time on dreary winter days?

description: AMERICAS

description: Good evening, and welcome to the third annual Pogie awards! Lets hear it for Rico and the band!

description: In her recent campaigning, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has been toning down her gender-based appeal as she emphasizes strength and experience. But now she is making a direct pitch to young women in a new online essay for Glamour magazines Web site (www.glamour.com) in its political space, Glamocracy.

title: Edwards Campaign May Have Expected Union Group Plan
description: DES MOINES  In the final days before the Iowa caucuses on Jan. 3, John Edwards has stepped up his criticism of outside organizations that spend money to influence elections, repeatedly disavowing a labor group that is blanketing Iowa with commercials supporting his candidacy.

title: The $50 Ticket: A Lottery Boon Raises Concern
description: With the popularity of traditional lotteries waning across the country, many states are turning to instant games priced at $20, $30 and as high as $50 to lure new players and raise revenue.

description: Every new police officer in New York City will be sent onto the streets of some of the citys toughest neighborhoods as part of a broad anticrime operation that the authorities say has helped produce historic drops in crime, the city announced on Wednesday.

title: State Without Pity
description: It is a shameful distinction, but Texas is the undisputed capital of capital punishment. At a time when the rest of the country is having serious doubts about the death penalty, more than 60 percent of all American executions this year took place in Texas. That gaping disparity provides further evidence that Texass governor, Legislature, courts and voters should reassess their addiction to executions.

title: In Their Own Words
description: Former Senator John Edwards, Democrat of North Carolina, speaking Wednesday in Conway, N.H.

title: Russia: Another Candidate Exits
description: Boris Y. Nemtsov, a leader of the Union of Right Forces, a mainstream liberal party, pulled out of the March presidential election, asserting that improper pressure by the Kremlin had turned the campaign into a farce. Mr. Nemtsov, left, a first deputy prime minister under President Boris N. Yeltsin, called on opposition parties to unite around a single candidate to oppose the favorite, Dmitri A. Medvedev, a longtime aide to President Vladimir V. Putin.

title: Offering Enlightenment, or Just a Little Peace
description: Room 315, the Rose Main Reading Room of the New York Public Library on Fifth Avenue, has a loyal cast of repeat visitors. The regulars have their own reasons for being there: a love of words, a desire for serenity amid the din of the city, a place they can use as their office for school work or research.

title: Tip of the Week: Increasing the Speed of a Vista-Operated PC
description: If you have a spare U.S.B. flash drive with at least 256 megabytes of free space on it, you can use it to give your Windows Vista-operated PC an extra cache of memory to help increase speed, using the Windows ReadyBoost feature. Just plug the drive into a U.S.B. 2.0 port, and if it is fast enough to work with ReadyBoost, the system will prompt you to set it up. You do not have to erase any existing files on the drive and can indicate how much space you want to use for storage. The feature also works with Secure Digital cards. Full instructions for using ReadyBoost are at http://snipurl.com/1vmik.

title: Clemenss Legal Team Adds Private Investigators
description: Roger Clemenss lawyer has hired private investigators to try to challenge the credibility of Brian McNamee, the trainer who told federal agents and former Senator George J. Mitchell that he had injected Clemens with steroids and human growth hormone, a lawyer familiar with the matter said Wednesday.

title: A Global Trek to Poor Nations, From Poorer Ones
description: JUAN GMEZ, Dominican Republic  The scrap-wood shanties on a muddy hillside are a poor mans promised land.

title: Garden Settles a Lawsuit Filed by a Former Rangers Cheerleader
description: Rather than defend itself against sexual harassment again, Madison Square Garden on Wednesday settled a lawsuit filed three years ago by the former captain of the Rangers cheerleading squad, the Rangers City Skaters.

title: Holiday Cheer Gives Way to Final Primary Push in Iowa
description: DES MOINES  After a 48-hour lull for Christmas, the Democratic and Republican presidential campaigns roared back to life on Wednesday with a barrage of new advertisements, closing campaign arguments and more than a few attacks as they girded for the eight days leading to the first vote of 2008 here.

title: Knicks Lineup Gets New Look, but the Result Is the Same
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Changes swept through the Knicks locker room Wednesday night, though it was hard to discern just who got the worst of it and whether it was all worthwhile.

title: 2 Newark Bouncers Shot, One Fatally, After Dispute at Club
description: NEWARK  Two men who worked as bouncers at a bar here were shot early Wednesday, one of them fatally, by a man they had turned away from the club earlier that night, the police said.

description: LOS ANGELES  At home, in gang territory near the 10 freeway, Malcolm Mays, 17, sleeps on the faded carpet of his grandmothers living room.

description: ONCE their eyes adjusted to the dim interior of the house that would be theirs, Marcel and Sherrie Deans marveled at the architectural details they could make out amid the dust-covered desks and armchairs and piles of books.

title: China Offers Production Guidelines for Seafood
description: SHANGHAI  Responding to growing concerns about the quality and safety of its seafood, China said this week that it would introduce production standards, including several measures intended to improve product safety and guard against the use of illegal veterinary drugs.

title: New Law Allows Needle Exchanges in Washington
description: WASHINGTON  President Bush signed legislation on Wednesday lifting a ban that for nearly a decade has prevented city officials here from using local tax money for needle exchange programs.

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: China: Cellphone Upgrade Approved
description: Chinas government approved a plan to build an improved wireless broadband cellphone network to elevate the countrys competitiveness with homegrown technology. The plan is a major thrust in the future of Chinas information technology, Chinas State Council said, but it did not provide details.

title: China: I.B.M. License for Chip Maker
description: I.B.M. licensed technology used in making computer chips for mobile devices and consumer electronics to a chip company in China, the companies said. The Chinese company, Semiconductor Manufacturing International of Shanghai, bought the license. The buyers will use it to expand offerings for mobile devices.

title: Jurors Regrets May Be Used in Appeal of L.I. Conviction
description: Lawyers for a black Long Island man convicted of manslaughter in the shooting death of a white teenager said on Wednesday that in filing their appeal, they planned to use doubts about the verdict raised by two jurors.

title: Fuel for Bushehr
description: President Bush is not eager to pick another fight with the Russians. So he did the diplomatic thing last week and said that it is good that Russia finally delivered fuel for Irans Russian-built nuclear power reactor at Bushehr. Dont believe it.

description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The lines started to form at dawn on Thursday and some were literally miles long.

title: Spiritual Journey Guides an Imposing Jets Tackle
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y.  Before he embarked on a two-year mission for the Mormon Church, Sione Pouha heard all the horror stories. Friends told him to expect more than a few doors slammed in his face.

title: Private Place for Smokers, on the Web
description: PARIS  Only the select few can enter the online preserve of Altadis, the European tobacco giant. Inside, visitors find a parallel universe where willowy models strut down the runway with cigarettes hanging from their pouty lips, and celebrities like Bob Dylan, Clint Eastwood and Brad Pitt flaunt smoking as the ultimate symbol of chic rebellion.

title: California: Part of San Francisco Health Plan Struck Down
description: A federal judge has struck down a key provision of a new San Francisco program to provide basic health care for uninsured residents. The city was set to begin requiring employers with more than 20 workers to start subsidizing the health plan on Jan. 2. But the judge, Jeffrey Wright of Federal District Court, ruled that the mandate would violate a 1974 federal law designed to prevent inconsistencies in the coverage afforded employees who work for the same company but live in different jurisdictions.

title: Japan Textbooks to Restore Reference to Wartime Suicides
description: TOKYO  Japans Education Ministry announced Wednesday that it would partly reinstate references in textbooks to the militarys role in forcing civilians to commit mass suicide during the Battle of Okinawa in the final months of World War II.

title: Rapper Fails to Appear for Arraignment
description: The rapper Yung Joc was designated a fugitive after he failed to appear on Wednesday for arraignment in Cleveland on a felony charge of carrying a concealed weapon, The Associated Press reported, citing a prosecutor. Yung Joc, right, whose real name is Jasiel Robinson, was accused of trying to take a loaded semiautomatic handgun onto a Delta Air Lines flight on Sunday at Cleveland Hopkins International Airport. An assistant Cuyahoga County prosecutor, Gayle Williams, said that Mr. Robinson was considered a fugitive and that she planned to seek a warrant for him. His lawyer, Stanley Jackson Jr., was apologetic and said Mr. Robinson, 27, of Atlanta, was out of town attending to family and personal obligations. Mr. Robinson was arrested at an airport security checkpoint, where the police said they found the gun and ammunition in his carry-on bag. He told them he did not know the weapon was there. Mr. Jackson said Mr. Robinson maintained his innocence. He was released on Monday on $50,000 bond, but on Wednesday Municipal Judge Michael John Ryan doubled the bail to $100,000.

title: Danger Is Part of Races Allure
description: With 49 deaths in 29 years, the annual Dakar Rally off-road race has been panned by the Vatican newspaper as the bloody race of irresponsibility.

title: Nepal: 50 Missing in Icy River
description: Policemen, soldiers and villagers searched the icy Bheri River for more than 50 people believed missing after a steel footbridge collapsed on Tuesday. At least 16 people were confirmed dead.

title: The Experience of Surround-Sound Speakers at Home, but Without All That Surround
description: Home theater surround-sound setups use five speakers to emulate the movie-hall experience  a pair front and back, and one speaker in the center. But if you cant wire and hang such a system, there is a workaround: Single-enclosure sound bars for mounting under flat-panel TV screens.

title: Promising Dystrophy Drug Clears Early Test
description: Researchers in the Netherlands have developed a drug that may eventually be used to treat children with a severe and fatal type of muscular dystrophy.

title: The Year That Yelled Notice Me
description: FASHION historians may someday reflect on 2007 and overlook the significance of its finer moments: the ascension of a new generation of design talent, the influential Poiret show at the Costume Institute, the retirement of Valentino, to give but a few examples. Those scholars may conclude instead that this was the year in which designers finally succumbed to the baser desires of an overheated celebrity culture, in which the only thing that matters is fame and the only means to succeed is by screaming, Look at me!

title: You Must Remember This
description: IT was a year of miraculous events. President Bush invited Al Gore to the Oval Office for a friendly chat about global warming. France elected a president who likes and admires Americans. Eliot Spitzer discovered the virtue of humility. In mid-rant, Hugo Chvez was finally told to shut up. The cute little Canadian dollar  the loonie  became worth more than a greenback.

title: Afghanistan to Expel 2 Officials
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Two senior political officers working for the European Union and the United Nations assistance mission in Afghanistan will leave the country as ordered by the Afghan government after discussions on Wednesday failed to resolve a dispute over whether the two had held talks with the Taliban, according to a United Nations spokesman.

title: Spectacle on 34th Street
description: GRIPPED by last-minute holiday fever, shoppers thronged Macys on the weekend before Christmas, pouncing on the announcement that the store would stay open around the clock. Visitors, and even a few rebellious staffers, were tricked out for the occasion like 24 Hour Party People. Tweaking a store tradition that asks employees to dress in black, Jose Benavidez brightened up his uniform with a fuchsia scarf he had bought on the street. His colleague, JJ Martin, patrolled the makeup counter wearing fingerless gloves, a studded cuff and a generous daub of lip gloss. Plaid caps and Peruvian knitwear were de rigueur. But one dapper gent broke with form by flaunting a rep tie and a rakish beret. I dress this way every day of my life, he said. Im a fashion designer in my heart.

title: Tankleff Freed After Posting Bail
description: RIVERHEAD, N.Y.  After being imprisoned nearly half his life for the murders of his parents, crimes he insists he did not commit, Martin H. Tankleff walked free on Thursday after a bail hearing here.

title: San Francisco Police Look for Clues Indicating How Tiger in Fatal Attack Escaped

The victims had just cleaned up a mud-covered home. They were having dinner together when they were hit by another landslide, the official said. At least 61 people were buried. Mexican oil export revenue rose 69 percent last month to $4.89 billion, the ministry said. Nonoil exports grew 8.7 percent to $19.5 billion. Total imports rose 12 percent to $25.18 billion.

title: For the Moment | The Sands of Time
description: Sheikh Majed Al-Sabah, this weeks guest blogger on The Moment, is fashion royalty. Not only is Majed, as he is better known, a member of Kuwaiti royal family (his father is the first cousin of the emir of Kuwait; his mother is the emirs sister), but he is a retail visionary, whose Villa Moda store in Kuwait is the crown jewel in a luxury company that now spans five countries in the region. In todays post, Majed shows how luxury in the Middle East is a nebulous concept that extends beyond the shopping mall.The nomadic Arabs called The Bedouins were pastoralists who moved their herds from place to place in search of water, securing spots throughout the Arabian Peninsula. They lived in small, tightly-knit hereditary tribes. They were known for their hospitality, pride, courage and endurance. Their precarious, wandering existence demanded these traits, given that they had to tend to their sheep, camels and goats, as well having to protect their extended family and honored tribal rules. They lived in Sadu tents made out of camel wool, which the Bedouin women wove, and they survived on the livestock and the dairy products they carried with them.

title: Ashcan Views of New Yorkers, Warts, High Spirits and All
description: The painters of the Ashcan School just wanted to have fun. They chronicled the lives of poor city dwellers, but they were neither social critics nor reformers. Robert Henri, George Luks, John Sloan and other early-20th-century American realists identified with the group were high-spirited fellows who prided themselves on fielding a baseball team that regularly defeated those of the National Academy of Design and the Art Students League. They liked to dine in fancy restaurants and hang out at McSorleys, the mens-only tavern on East Seventh Street. They enjoyed the theater, the circus and trips to Coney Island. No Puritan crusaders, they were manly epicureans, and their virile hero was Teddy Roosevelt.

I do think all these atom bombs are very wrong, one of the women says. title: Atlantis Launching Delayed Again
description: The next flight of the space shuttle Atlantis, already delayed until Jan. 10, will be further delayed to replace a socket in the electrical system on the external fuel tank. In the countdown on Dec. 6, the original launching date, sensors designed to ensure that the main engines shut down at the proper time during launching malfunctioned. Engineers think the problem is in the part of the socket on the outside of the tank and can be repaired on the launching pad by soldering electrical connections. If a more major repair is required, the Atlantis would have to be rolled back to its hangar, lengthening the delay.

title: Needling More Than the Feminist Consciousness
description: In the 70s, artists who swapped their paintbrushes for a needle and thread were making a feminist statement. Today, as both men and women fill galleries with crocheted sculpture and stitched canvases, the gesture isnt quite so specific. Some contemporary artists gravitate to the retro-kitsch factor; others seize on the exacting technique, or the association with sweatshop labor, or a personal memory of Aunt Gladyss afghans.

title: Indiana: Sentence in 2006 Sniper Shootings
description: A teenager who pleaded guilty to killing one man and wounding another in a series of 2006 Indiana highway sniper shootings was sentenced Thursday to 42 years in prison. Defense lawyers tried to portray the defendant, Zachariah Blanton, 18, as troubled and the victim of teasing, but the judge said his emotional problems were no excuse for killing someone he had never met. Prosecutors said Mr. Blanton fired his hunting rifle into Interstate 65 traffic on July 23, 2006, from an overpass about 60 miles south of Indianapolis, killing Jerry L. Ross, 40, of New Albany. An Iowa man traveling in a pickup truck was injured. Mr. Blanton pleaded guilty this month to voluntary manslaughter with a deadly weapon and criminal recklessness.

But, somewhere along the way, he changed his mind, the article said. Writings by author and commentator Christopher Hitchens on the moral case for war deeply influenced him.

They are the Minnesota Council on Foundations, not the Minneapolis Council on Foundations, and Twin Cities Rise, not Twin Cities Rising. The column also referred incorrectly to financing of a pedestrian bridge over an interstate highway. The bridge  the Irene Hixon Whitney Bridge, which crosses I-94 to connect the Walker Art Center to the citys park system  was built with donations from the Whitney family and others. Dayton-Hudson, a predecessor to the Target Corporation, did not build the bridge.

title: A Year of Books Worth Curling Up With
